title: DOCK UNION STRIKES EAST AND GULF PORTS OVER JOB SECURITY
description: The International Longshoremen's Association went on strike at ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts today, after efforts failed to settle a dispute over job security and other contract issues.

title: Film Festival: Truffaut Comedy:'The Man Who Loved Women' Full of Double-Edged Wit
description: Bertrand Morane (Charles Denner) is a bachelor in his early 40's. He lives in Monpellier in southern France, where he makes a decent if not great living in a testing laboratory. Bertrand is polite, intelligent and sensitive, but mostly he is obsessed by women. Pretty ones, beautiful ones, plain ones, old ones, young ones. There are also one he never sees (the voice of the telephone operator who awakens him in the morning) and one he hasn't seen for many yearshis mother.When Bertrand dies, which is the way Francois Truffaut begins his lighthearted, wise new comedy, "The Man Who Loved Women," the mourners who push through the winter chill to the cemetery are, without exception, women. Though Bertrand was obsessed by women and though he might have felt guilty about using them at times, it is not an untypical Truffaut reversal that Bertrand was as much used by them, not meanly but, after all, a man who loves women with such persistence (which is not to be confused with fidelity) is rare these days, worthy of having attention paid."The Man Who Loved Women" will be shown at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center tonight at 9 and Monday evening at 6:15. It will go into regular theatrical release here later this month.In this new film, Mr. Truffaut's 16th feature since "The 400 Blows" in 1959, the director is working in a vein usually thought to be frivolous to examine the serious, primary game that men and women play, an ancient pastime whose rules are changing, as one of his characters notes. I suppose there's always been a little of the late Ernest Lubitsch in all Truffaut comedies, though I wouldn't want to have to prove it, but there is more than I've ever seen before in "The Man Who Loved Women."It's full of the double-edged wit of the self-aware. Although it's a comedy about the sexes, it's less sexist; essentially, than Agnes Varda's liberation ode," "One Sings, the Other Doesn't." I don't mean to impose a heavier burden on "The Man Who Loved Women" than it can carry, but the Truffaut comedy, in the way it appreciates women in their infinite variety and understands what they're up against, is infinitely more liberated than most liberated films, which reduce women to abstract concepts.Enough of that sort of talk, though.The movie is a supremely humane, sophisticated comedy that is as much fun to watch for the variations Mr. Truffaut works on classic man-woman routines as for the routines themselves. The narrative line is so gossamer-thin it barely sustains the sentence that describes it: Bertrand, in his memoirs completed shortly before he's killed in an accident, remembers all the women he's loved, and a number he hasn't, trying in this fashion to understand why he has never been able to settle down.There are, among others, Nicole, the theater usher who first caught his attention by the seductive noise of one silk-stockinged leg crossing the other; Helene, a woman of his age who turns him down because she's only attracted to young men; Liliane, the head-strong waitress with whom he never slept and who, he says, is his "evidence that a man and a woman can be just friends."Most hilariously there is Delphine (Nelly Borgeaud), a married woman whose deepest passions are unlocked by the unsuspecting Bertrand and who has a way of maneuvering him into situations in which they are threatened with public exposure. "Oh," says the overheated Delphine, tearing off her clothes in the car, "the things you make me do!"There is also  in the film's most marvelous, most surprising sequence  an encounter with Vera, beautifully played by Leslie Caron, a woman with whom he had an extended affair some years before. It's a scene that lasts no more than four or five minutes, but it's so remarkably well played and written that an entire love affair, from the beginning to the middle and the end, is movingly evoked through what is really just exposition.The film's style is so economical it seems almost terse. The flashback to Bertrand's childhood, in which the boy was made the go-between for his mother in her affairs, suggests the young Antoine of "The 400 Blows," while Bertrand's funny, sweet encounter with a little girl he finds crying on a stairway recalls the Antoine of "Love at Twenty." Bertrand asks the little girl why she's crying and finally gets her to concede that there is a certain amount of pleasure in being so unhappy, which makes her brighten immediately.Brigitte Fossey plays Bertrand's literary editor, the one person, you feel, who might have straightened him out if she had taken him as seriously as he had begun to take her. Perhaps not. The film is open-ended on this.Charles Denner is very, very funny, as Bertrand, a fellow who has the same single-minded purpose as the rat-exterminiator he played in "Such a Gorgeous Kid Like Me," as well as the delicacy of touch of Antoine Doinel on his best behavior.It's not the Truffaut way to make movies that contain flat statements. Like almost every film he's ever done, "The Man Who Loved Women" considers some of the aspects and manifestations of love and then shakes its headin a mixture of wonder, delight and sadness.

title: Saul Levitt, Playwright, Dies; Wrote The Andersonville Trial
description: Saul Levitt, whose plays about the morality of war were produced on television, on Broadway, across the country and in theaters throughout Europe, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 66 years old and lived at 320 Riverside Drive.

title: Stephen Rumpf Demonstrates Virtuosity on the Harpsichord
description: All pianists know that if you press the keys down, sounds emerge, and a few suspect that the pedals have some sort of function in regulating and varying the tone. But beyond those rudiments, the instrument they play remains a mystery to all but a few inquisitive, mechanically inclined pianists. Harpsichordists, however, are another kind of musician: they tune their own delicate and flighty instrumentsincessantly, it sometimes seemsand must he prepared to make all sorts of minor and even major repairs.

title: Hijackers in Dacca Release 5 More
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Saturday, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Japanese guerrillas released four more hostages yesterday and a fifth early today from the Japanese airliner they hijacked to Dacca Wednesday.

title: Pope Opens Synod, Asks Vigor in Propagating Faith
description: ROME, Sept. 30Pope Paul VI today opened the fifth synod of Roman Catholic bishopsa gathering of 204 prelateswith a call for energetic propagation of the Christian faith in a world that is abandoning religion in favor of technology and science.

title: SECOND GEM DEALER IS REPORTED MISSING
description: As the material witness in the case of a diamond broker who was robbed and slain came forward yesterday with a new twist to his bizarre story, it was disclosed that another broker had been missing for more than two months, with possibly as much as $300,000 in gems.

title: Notes on People
description: Among 50 women runners who set out yesterday on the first leg of 2,500mile relay to Houston were Judy Carter, a daughterinlaw of President Caller. Mrs. Carter, who is married to Jack Carter, left Seneca Falls, N. Y., With other runners and headed southeast. Eventually, 2,000 women will take part in the longdistance run to dramatize the fight for enactment of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: Activists Prod Senators on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The scene was the baroque reception room just off the Senate floor, where flocks of painted angels sweep across the ceiling and portraits of august Senators adorn the walls.

title: S50.000 Prize to Miss Wade
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Sept. 30 (UPI)  Virginia Wade won the World Invitational Tennis Classic today when she and Vitas Gerulaitis rebounded from a mixeddoubles deficit of 3 match points to defeat Roscoe Tanner and Kerry Reid, 67, 63, 76.

title: TRADING RESUMES IN PORT UNIT BONDS
description: Trading in Port Authority bonds resumed yesterday following the lull that developed as bond dealers and investors studied the bistate agency's refunding proposal made public early Thursday. Some Port Authority issues climbed sharply and others sank even more decisively.

title: Brazilian Author Reflects Nation's African Heritage
description: SALVADOR, BrazilFor three hours ??? hundred admirers of Jorge Amado stood in line holding copies of his new, 590page novel, Tieta do Agreste, to have it autographed by the author.

title: Lewis C. Perkinson, Former Officer Of American Cyanamid, Dies at 75
description: Lewis C. Parkinson, former financial vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, died or. Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla., following a short illness. He was 75.

title: Tammany's New Chief
description: Aaron Burr, William Marcy Tweed, Fernando Wood, Carmine G. De Sapio, Miriam Bockman

title: Begin Hospitalized; Reported Fatigued By Heavy Schedule
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 30Prime Minister Menahem Begin was hospitalized today for what aides said was fatigue resulting from a strenuous schedule.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THROUGH A GLASS COLORFULLY The belief is that stainedglass windows developed in the Middle East, where the glass industry began. Stainedglass windowspictures in colored glasshave been traced as far back as the ninth century, mentioned peripherally in a story on the life of St. Ludger. A more solid reference appeared later in a manuscript recording the fact that the bishop of Rheims' had rebuilt the cathedral and put in windows representing different stories.

title: Moynihan Terms President's Plan On Relief System Disappointing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan told Congress today that President Carter's plan to overhaul the nation's welfare system was grievously disappointing, and he expressed doubt that it could attract the necessary Congressional support.

title: The Pennant Race
description: REMAINING GAMES

title: Panamanian Leader Visits Belgrade
description: BELGRADE. Sept. 30 (Reuters)Panama's head of government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, arrived in Yugoslavia today for a threeday official visit that will include talks with President Tito.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL ELIMINATING 2,500 FROM OFFICE STAFF
description: BETHLEHEM Pa., Sept. 30The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced today that it was elimtnating the jobs of 2,500 whitecollar workers. They were the latest layoffs in the troubled steel industry, which have now grown to 18,000.

title: Mets Win for Matlack After Losing to Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP)Bruce Boisclair drew a basesloaded walk and Roy Staiger followed with a twbrun single to highlight a fourrun sixth inning that sent the New York Mets to a 63 triumph over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight ana a split of their twilightnight doubleheader.

title: 54 Children of Factory Employees Found With Excess Lead in Blood
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP)Fiftyfour children of employees at a battery factory in Raleigh, N.C., have been found to have excessive levels of lead in their blood since February 1977, the National Center for Disease Control said today.

title: United Press International
description: ATLAS LAUNCHING FAILS: An Atlas Centaur rocket carrying a multimillion dollar communications satellite lift ing off and then exploding Thursday at Cape Canaveral, Fla. It was the second major failure in two weeks.

title: Rangers and Gilbert Closer in Talks on Pact
description: Contending that he wanted Rod Gilbert to be the one Ranger to finish his career with New York, Mike Burke characterized the hockey player's contract dispute as moving closer to solution yesterday.

title: GERALD F. MAULSBY
description: Gerald F. Maulsby, a longtime executive with the CBS radio network in New York, died Sunday at his home in Tucson, Ariz., after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA French civil engineer has invented a noisereducing squaremesh screen and other devices to protect occupants of buildings along railways and highways. Andre L. Dcsenfant has reported constructing a soundattenuating system in a noisy section of Highway A4 leading to Paris from Strasbourn.

title: But Rome Public and Critics Like It
description: ROME  Seized, censored, appealed and finally absolved, Pier Paolo Pasolini's Salo, 120 Days of Sodom, was even kidnapped before it was released to the mild enthusiasm of the public and the praise of the critics here. Along the way, in and out of the courts in Italy, the film created a furor.

title: MRS. BUCKMAN HEADS TAMMANY DEMOCRATS
description: Miriam Bockman was unanimously elected the first woman leader of the Manhattan Democratic organization yesterday in a move that signaled the transfer of political power from Mayor Beame to Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

title: Addis Ababa Attack Confirmed
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)  Ethiopian authorities today confirmed reports that gunmen stormed the Italian Embassy here Wednesday and briefly held captive 12 people, including Ambassador Marcello Guidi. There was no sign of the gunmen when the police arrived, the Ethiopian news agency reported.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses Wed In order of cost positions

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Amid behindthescenes pressure for his withdrawal, Irving Anker, the Chancellor of New York City schools, notified the Board of Education yesterday that he would retire at the end of the current school year, when his present oneyear contract expires.

title: WORLD BANKERS SAY POOR NATIONS DEBTS AROUSE NO WORRIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The poorer nations are saddled with debt and alarms have been sounding from various quarters, including a harsh report recently by a Congressional committee. But are the world's international bankers worried?

title: Final Draft of Soviet Constitution
description: MOSCOW. Sept. 30 (Reuters)The final draft of the new Soviet constitution incorporating changes suggested during three months of public discussion of the original version, was approved today by he nresidium of the country's legislature, the Supreme SoyIet.

title: Jo Ann Ryan Becomes Bride
description: Jo Ann Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Emmett Ryan of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Paul H. Couture, son of Mr. and Mrs. Napoleon Couture of Chicopee, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Martyrs in Forest Hills by the Rev. Francis Mulhall. The bride. an assistant buyer for J. C. Penney Company in New York, was graduated from Marymount Manhattan College. Her husband, an alumnus of the Stockbridge School of the University of Massachusetts, is a sales representative with the Automatic Lawn Sprinkler Company in Farmingdale, L. I.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Subway
description: My subway is shrinking. It began months ago and is getting worse. Last winter it was, a fine, fullgrown subway. You descended those hideous steps and there at the bottom was a perfectly normal subway filling the platform, and you stepped aboard and looked at those numb faces and thought about the futility of absolutely everything and yet did not really feel intimations of the absolute end because your subway, was big and noisy and dirty and full grown and, after all, normal.

title: Parr Hopes to Reopen on Friday, But Chances Are Believed Poor
description: YAPHANK, L.I., Sept. 30Although Parr Meadows is beset with financial troubles and has been closed since last Monday, officials said today they hoped to reopen the quarterhorse race track next Friday night. But the chances seemed slim.

title: Carter to Wait at Least 3 Months Before Naming Lance's Successor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30President Carter said today that he planned to wait at least three months before naming successor to Bert Lance as director of the Office of Management and Budget.

title: FORD'S PAY OFFER TOPS BRITAIN'S 10% GUIDELINES
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP)Government hopes of lowering Britain's soaring inflation rate and restoring economic stability received a blow today when the Ford Motor Company Ltd. offered its workers a pay settlement above Government guidelines.

title: Head of Episcopal Church Offers To Resign Over Women Priests
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Sept. 30The head of the Episcopal Church in the United States, Presiding Bishop John M. Allin, offered tonight to resign if his fellow bishops were unwilling to accept his outright opposition to ordaining women as priests.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 (UPI)A state Superior Court judge struck down today a lower court order that barred the airing of a controversial television program that includes interviews with members of the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party.

title: Vacational (Sic) Schools
description: ALBANYHi Pay, No Collegethe lure of private vocational schools becomes sirenlike this time of year as new high school graduates find that there are not enough jobs for everyone who wants one.

title: About New york
description: Jeff Williams is a young black man at Haaren High School, sharp on the street, coltish in the classroom. He is only months away from his graduation into one of the most depressing statistics in a land that brags of opportunity the 40 percent unemployment rate for young minoritygroup males.

title: HANS HABE, NOVELIST AND EDITOR IN EUROPE
description: Hans Habe, a leading European novelist and journalist, died Thursday night at a hospital in Locarno, Switzerland. He was 66 years old and lived in nearby Ascona.

title: Carey Seeks Legislative Action To Help City Sell Notes to Public
description: Governor Carey indicated yesterday that he hoped to get the Legislature working next week on measures that New York City needs to sell notes on the public market before the end of this year and put off more difficult issues relating to the sale of longterm bonds.

title: Grandfathering
description: TROY, N.Y.It is decided. While his mother is reordering her life in Philadelphia, I will shepherd the threeyearold for a month. He is Yanni, a transliteration of Ioannis, named for his Greek grandfather. I am Poppy, the residue of Papoo, a name selected by his mother.

title: New York State's First Women Forest Rangers Report for Duty
description: NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Sept. 30The first women forest rangers in New York State reported for work yesterday in the Catskill mountains.

title: G.M. INTERMEDIATES LIFTED 2.6% IN PRICE
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30  The General Motors Corporation announced today baseprice increases averaging 2.6 percent on its redesigned, trimmeddown, intermediatesized passenger cars for 1978considerably less than the 4.6 percent rise that G.M. disclosed five weeks ago for its 1978 fleet as a whole.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and on other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the Newspaper and the radio station.

title: G.O.P. Committee Votes to Oppose Canal Treaties
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30The Republican National Committee voted overwhelmingly today to oppose the ratification of the new Panama Canal treaties proposed by the Carter Administration.

title: News Summary
description: Pledges to use our utmost effort were made by the United States and the Soviet Union to overcome ArabIsraeli differences and bring about a Middle East peace conference before the end of the year. Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. wile had an hourandahalf meeting with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, said a joint statement probably would be forthcoming soon that would enable proposals on resolving the issue of Palestinian representation that has delayed a Middle East meeting. description: Leo M. Cooper, the founder and board chairman of White Swan Uniforms Inc., a leading manufacture of women's dresstype uniforms, died Wednesday night at his home at 30 West 54th Street. He was 92 years old.

title: With Garbage Cans and Crescendos, Public. Television Will Present Its Music Series for Children
description: WASHINGTONIt is all very well to lead children to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, but how do you make them listen? One basic rule, for the people who just put together a 10part television series designed to get the young to listenand love itis, Don't tell them that it's good for them.

description: A dispatch from Peking in The Times Thursday incorrectly identified the actor accompanying a New York businessman who was stabbed on the street there. The actor was William Holden.

description: Two French readytowear designers interrupted work on their spring collections to come to New York this week to present their fall styles.

title: Film Festival: 'Salo' Is Disturbing...
description: Had Pier Paolo Pasolini not died the way he did on Nov. 1, 1975, murdered (the Rome court found) by a 17-year-old boy who repeatedly ran Mr. Pasolini's silver Alfa Romeo over the body in a scrubby vacant lot, I'm not at all sure we'd take the film that became his last work as solemnly as we must.The young murderer's defense was that he'd become enraged after Mr. Pasolini, who had picked him up several hours earlier near Rome's Termini Station, made homosexual advances. The boy was convicted and sentenced to prison for nine years, seven months and 10 days. Mr. Pasolini, said Michelangelo Antonioni, "was the victim of his own characters."If Mr. Pasolini really was the victim of his own characters, then his most significant film must be his last, "Salo, 120 Days of Sodom," Mr. Pasolini's transposition of the Marquis de Sade's 18th-century novel to Italy (1944), and the puppet government set up at Salo in northern Italy when Mussolini was briefly free after his rescue by the Nazis from Italian partisans.Mr. Pasolini, a poet and novelist as well as a film maker, an ardent Marxist who early on had been thrown out of the Communist Party for his homosexuality, made controversial films throughout his career, but none to equal "Salo," which was completed shortly before his death.De Sade's novel has the small distinction of being the only novel I couldn't bring myself to finish reading. Indeed, de Sade himself hardly finished writing itthe last half being no more than a plan for the humiliations and tortures he wished to describe in greater detail when he had the time, which he never had.De Sade saw his work, about the epic 120-day debauch of four pillars of French society, as a revolutionary act, designed to bring down the old order so that a new one might be established. As he described the debauch, though, he also indulged his own fantasies that passed through more or less commonplace sexual perversions to coprophilia, necrophilia and explicit torture of the young women and young men who had been kidnapped to share the hosts' pleasures.Mr. Pasolini has made a very significant change in updating this work, however. The four hoststhe duke, the president, the magistrate and the bishopare now Fascists, expressing their ultimate desires as the world is crumbling around them in the last days of the fascist regime. They are no longer rebelling against God. They are demonstrating the evil of the human spirit, which is something else entirely, though I can't help but feel that de Sade and Mr. Pasolini share a peculiar delight in speculating about the specific details of this evil.For all of Mr. Pasolini's desire to make "Salo" an abstract statement, one cannot look at images of people being scalped, whipped, gouged, slashed, covered with excrement and sometimes eating it and react abstractedly unless one shares the director's obsessions.Far from being the "agonized scream of total despair" the New York Film Festival calls the film, it is a demonstration of nearly absolute impotency, if there is such a thing. Ideas get lost in a spectacle of such immediate reality and cruelty."Salo" will be shown at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center today at 1 P.M. and repeated there tomorrow evening at 6. It opens its regular commercial engagement Monday at the Festival Theater."Salo" is, I think, a perfect example of the kind of material that, theoretically, anyway, can be acceptable on paper but becomes so repugnant when visualized on the screen that it further dehumanizes the human spirit, which is supposed to be the artist's concern. When one reads, one exercises all kinds of intellectual processes that are absent when one looks at pictures. An image frequently says less than a thousand words. It's of especially limited use when dealing with the kind of ideas that Mr. Pasolini was playing with here.The new film has no conventional story, being an allegory composed of tableaux in which we see the four hosts making their compact, their victims being rounded up and inspected, and finally the revels themselves. These begin with some simulated sex and move on to the series of parties in which the hosts carry coprophilia as far as it can go, and then begin their elaborate, tortures, In between, a lot of high-toned talk about how the domination of one person by another is a metaphor for the capitalist's treatment of the working man, and how murder is the logical extension of such power.The words are not nonsensical, but they are feeble in conjunction with the ferocity and explicitness of the images. The film is not without style in its settingslots of Mussolini-era dcoror in several of its performances, including that of Caterina Boratto, who plays one of the madams who attempt to arouse the four hosts by telling them lewd stories with a piano accompaniment. Yet it all finally seems thin and superficial.Throughout his career as a film maker, Mr. Pasolini was very good at intellectualizing. after the fact, what he was doing on the screen. His best films"The Gospel According to St. Matthew" and "Accatone"can stand alone. His later films, even the rambunctious "fable films" ("Decameron" and "A Thousand and One Nights") require a certain amount of rationalizing to be acceptable.As Mr. Pasolini's vision of the world became increasingly bleak, his films became more arid. "Salo" is the bitter, empty end.

title: New Delhi Official Says I. B. M. Told India It Is Leaving
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 30The International Business Machines Corporation has informally told the Government that it is ceasing operations in India and would like to complete its withdrawal in six months, an official source said today.

title: Prices Move Lower In Coffee Futures; Soybeans Retreat
description: Coffee futures continued to drift lower on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The downturn, influenced by the pressure of ample supplies, came despite a statement from a Brazilian official that Brazil hoped to keep prices at about twice their current level.

title: The Hunt for Human Origins: An ExHerdsman Tracks Fossils
description: KOOBI FORA, Kenya  Kamoya Ximeu trudges across a rocky a rocky slope in this desolate but strangely beautiful wilderness, his sharp eyes methodically scanning the ground for pieces of ancient bone.

title: Associated Press
description: OVERCOME BY CHLORINE FUMES: Women who fled homes after chlorine gas leaked from a water treatment plant in East Falls, Philadelphia, await treatment in hospital. There were no serious injuries and leak was soon corrected.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: McLendon and Jones Share Lead In Napa Golf
description: NAPA, Calif., Sept. 30 (AP)Tom Watson, seeking his sixth victory of the year, charged into contention in the $200,000 AnheuserBusch golf tournatnent by finishing today's second round with a 40foot eagle putt that left him four strokes behind the coleaders, Mac McLendon and Grier Jones.

title: Ramblers Present OldFashioned Country Music
description: The Falls City Ramblers, a string band from Louisville, Ky., that is making its first New York appearance at O'Lunney's, 915 Second Avenue, through tomorrow, offers something out of the ordinary in bluegrass and oldtime country music. With is members hailing from Kentucky and Ohio, the group purveys harmonysinging and instrumentqlplaying that are authentic.

title: Sigmund W. Kunstadter, 76, Farmer President of Formfit
description: Sigmund W. Kunstadter, who retired in 1966 as president and chief executive of the board of the Formfit Company of Chicago, died Thursday in PresbyterianSt. Luke's Hospital, Chicago. He was 76 years old and lived in Highland Park, Ill.

title: Johnson Formally Nominated
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)President Carter formally nominated Frank M. Johnson Jr. to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today. Mr. Carter had announced Aug. 17 that he would nominate the United States District Court judge from Montgomery, Ala., for the position.

title: One by Werner Herzog Soars, but 2d Doesn't
description: "La Sourfrire" is only 30 minutes long, but it is one of Werner Herzog's most exquisite efforts, a perfect distillation of his talents. Made in 1976, the film is a serene, strangely clear-headed documentary about the end of the world."La Sourfrire" is the name of a volcano on Guadeloupe that threatened to erupt about a year ago; Mr. Herzog learned of the near-catastrophe only by chance, spotting a newspaper item about a native man who refused to leave the area after everyone else had been evacuated.Thirty-six hours later, Mr. Herzog and two cameramen had arrived in the town of Basse-Terre, at the foot of a mountain that had begun to spew forth white clouds of sulfurous steam.Mr. Herzog's narration deliberately skirts the question of whether he and his crew were afraid, but the implication is that they have passed beyond fear into a state of purely objective curiosity. When one of the cameramen lost his glasses, said Mr. Herzog, "we decided to pick them up the next day, if the mountain still existed by then."The town is deserted, "just a few doors banging in the wind and water dripping." The sea is full of drowned snakes, which have been driven out of the mountains where they normally dwell. A shot of a civic monument becomes wonderfully ironic, because the town is now a monument in its own right. The police station, like everything else, is silent and deserted: "It was great not to have the law hanging around." Even the scientists have fled. Mr. Herzog had every reason to expect, as he says, that these pictures of the town were the last ones that would ever be taken.The crew finds the peasant man, who is lying on the ground, waiting peacefully; turning his palms upward, he shows them the position in which he plans to die. He talks confidently about God's will, and explains that he has no fear. At Mr. Herzog's prompting, he sings a love song.The film includes an extraordinary anecdote, about a city on the neighboring island of Martinique that was destroyed in a volcanic eruption in 1902. There was no lava, only a burst of flame"the whole thing can only have taken seconds," Mr. Herzog explains, showing a photograph of vultures circling the next day. There was only one survivor in a population of 32,000, and he was the town's most evil man, a convict who had been put in solitary confinement underground. He eventually became a sideshow attraction in an American circus.La Soufrire never erupted even though the warning signs were definite enough almost to guarantee that it would. Mr. Herzog is doubtless glad to have survived, but the film reflects only his disappointment. "It all ended up a dead loss and a laughing stock," he said, almost angrily."La Sourfrire," one of the foremost attractions of the New York Film Festival (it will be shown tonight at 6 o'clock and Monday evening at 9:30), is on a bill with "Heart of Glass," a feature by Mr. Herzog that is far less successful. Mr. Herzog hypnotized his entire cast to film a parable about a medieval town that has thrived by producing ruby-colored glass, until the only man who knows the formula dies. After that, the town goes mad trying to recapture its lost glory.In its own way, "Heart of Glass" is as much about the end of the world as is "La Soufrire," but the longer film is much less accessible, and often obscure. The actors' trance is contagious, and the film has some genuinely mesmerizing moments, as when the town seer, whose words have made little sense, suddenly begins to predict an alarmingly familiar future in which "no man will like another man." Mr. Herzog seems not to be working with real actors, but rather with apparitions.At times, the script reads like a collection of nonsequiturs. Do you want our people to eat oatmeal bread again, that gives them headaches?" asks one character. "Rats will bite your earlobes," someone swears. Even the film's meticulousnessevery trace of red anywhere, even on a goose's head, is clearly plannedis not entirely decipherable.The elusiveness of "Heart of Glass" makes it something of a disappointment. But it is too mysteriously lovely to be regarded as a failure.

description: The Labor Department intends not simply la enforce existing laws against discrimination but to try to change the deepseated institutional patterns of discrimination. Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall told an audience in New York yesterday.

Levin, director of the state's Consumer Affairs Division, said yesterday that a recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that led to the removal of prohibitions against advertising by professionals was the most important action on behalf of consumers in the last decade.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Muhammad Ali sounded as if he wished he were Pale, whose soccer farewell will occur today with festive elegance, It's important to get out with the title, with the briefcase, with the necktie, the world heavyweight champion was saying yesterday, his face still shiny from the slam of Earnie Shavers's right hand. Look at Pele, he's getting out of soccer now while people remember the best. He came over to see me at my hotel. He invited me to his game. He got to me. I was going to get to him, but he got me first. But he's right. It's important for the people to remember the best. The world's two most famous athletes had never met until the 36yearold soccer player visited the 35yearold heavyweight champion. And if there is anything that might convince Muhammad Ali to retire, at least until he makes a comeback sooner or later, it might be watching the celebration of Pele's departure. The difference is that PeI6, organized and wealthy, can afford to retire, while Muhammad Ali, disorganized and a man who will always need another big payday, really can't afford to retire despite having earned more than $40 million in the ring. Ali isn't broke. He won't wind up like Joe Louis did. But the way he lives, he'll always need big money. And boxing is the easiest, if not the only way, for him to make big money and stay on the big stage that his ego demands.

title: Yanks Clinching Stalled Again as Tigers Beat Guidry, 52
description: The Yankees did not win their 100th game last night. They did not win their second straight division title either. Today the Yankees will try again to win their 100th game. Today they will try again to win their second straight division title.

description: The stock market advanced sharply yesterday, encouraged by a drop in the nation's money supply announced late Thursday.

title: New York City Police to Receive 6% Pay Rise Retroactive to July
description: Concurrent actions by the Emergency Financial Control Board and a justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday guaranteed New York City's 18,000 police officers that the 6 percent raiseabout $19 a weekthat they had expected to begin receiving last July will be reflected in their next paycheck, next Friday.

However, the poll, in which the Governor was given fairly high marks for his performance in office, showed that the Governor still trails State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, his Republican opponent, by seven points.

Deming of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The ceremony was performed in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Terence J. Finlay. title: The Race Lottery for Teachers
description: The 3,500 recently rehired teachers in New York City are being assigned to schools through two doors, one marked whites, the other blacks and Hispanics. This normally offensive, stigmatizing routine is necessary, according to the Board of Education, to make certain that more whites are assigned to schools with heavy black and Hispanic enrollments and that more blacks end up teaching in schools with mostly white students. The teachers union is complying reluctantly. The deplorable assignment by race is necessary, they add, to satisfy a Federal order for greater integration of teachine staffs and to avoid a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: A Peach Isn't a Peach Isn't a Peach
description: Plastic dogwood is pass. And so is polyethylene pyrocanthus and fake forsythia. In short, plastic plants are out and real greenery is in. There is a pronounced trend now away from the artificial and back to the natural.

title: Books of The Times
description: Not long ago I ran into an American businessman who had recently returned from a 10year stint in England. He and his wife enrolled their daughter in a suburban private school, and as part of the admissions process she took an individually administered I.Q. test. Several days later the tester called and asked the young girl to come back and repeat some of the exercises. In analyzing the results, the psychologist had concluded that growing up in England had put her at a disadvantage, and she wanted another look before giving her a score.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts Brooklyn Lawyer
description: A 54yearold Brooklyn lawyer was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of defrauding the Government of thousands of dollars by filing false claims, on behalf of herself and others, for Federal tax refunds, Social Security payments and unemployment insurance.

title: Women in Business: Three Success Stories, Side by Side
description: Although this has been Women in Business Week in New York, it's still not all that easy to find a business that is owned by women. Or two businesses that are owned by women. Let alone three.

title: Another Supporter of Teng Given Key Chinese Position
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 30  In 1968, during the Cultural Revolution, people in Hong Kong were shocked when bodies of more than 100 young Chinese, some headless and with their hands bound behind them, floated ashore after having drifted down the Pearl River. They were believed to have been executed after factional fighting in Kwangsi Province, where the local Communist Party strongman, Wei Kuoching, had ruthlessly suppressed Red Guard groups who challenged his rule.

title: Tarkanian Wins A Court Order To Retain Post
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 30 (UPI)Jerry Tarkanian won a court order today to remain head basketball coach at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, in a legal decision that may shake the foundation of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's investigatory procedures.

title: 4 South African Soldiers Killed
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Four South African soldiers were killed in a shooting accident in the army's operational area last night. defense headquarters said today. It gave no details. The operational area is generally taken to be the northern area of SouthWest Africa.

title: Judge's Threat of Jail Brings End To Massachusetts School Strike
description: FRANKLIN, Mass., Sept. 30A judge's threat to jail all striking teachers in this town, the birthplace of Horace Mann, brought an end to a bitter twoweek school strike just after dawn today.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP HELD NO CAUSE FOR ALARM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)The head of the International Monetary Fund, H. Johannes Witteveen, said today that the huge American trade deficit was no immediate problem because it was offset by a flow of foreign investment money into the Uniteti Statec.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Reking in The Times Thursday incorrectly identified the actor accompanying a New York businessman who was stabbed on the street there. The actor was William Holden.

title: Whalers 4 in 2d Period Help Topple Rangers, 74.
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30 (AP)Powerplay goals by John McKenzie and Tom Webster sparked a fourgoal surge in the second period that carried the New England Whalers to a 74 victory over the New York Rangers in a preseason hockey game.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (Reuters)President Tito has accepted an invitation to visit the United States, possibly next spring, his closest aide told President Carter today.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Administration forces favoring continued regulation of natural gas prices lost a key test vote on deregulation today but showed increased strength since a similar vote week ago.

title: Mostel Leaves $1 Million
description: Zero Mostel, who died Sept. 8 at the age of 62, left an estate of $1 million, according to his will filed yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's Court. It provided that his wife, Kathryn, receive half the estate, and income from the remaining half while she is alive. The remaining half will go to two sons on her death.

title: Senate Panel Votes Limited Rise From 65 to 70 in Retirement Age
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A Senate committee, after adopting several exemptions, approved legislation today that would raise from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may require their workers to retire:

title: PRICES DECLNE AGAIN FOR FARMERS CROPS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.30 (AP)  The prices that farmers receive for their crops fell an average of 1 percent between midAugust and midSeptember, the Agriculture Department reported today. It was the fourth consecutive monthly decline.

title: Elizabeth B. Dater Wed in Connecticut
description: Elizabeth Burgard Dater and Wm. Mitchell Jennings Jr., both of New York, were married yesterday evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jennings of Byram, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Joseph Bishop of the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Personal Investing
description: Individual investors often have the same portfolio objectives as institutional investors, but they cannot always draw on the same expertise as institutions. That appears to be one of the reasons why the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's recent tender offer for Mountain States Telephone and Telegraph Company 9.75 percent debentures brought in only 65 percent of the issue.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: An unfriendly takeover battle erupted yesterday between Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., and American Medicorp of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., two of the nation's leading hospital operators.

title: 3 TEXANS IN SLAYING GUILTY IN RIGHTS CASE
description: WACO, Tex., Sept. 30A former Texas police chief, his wife and sisterinlaw were found guilty by a Federal jury here last night in a case based on violation of the civil rights of a MexicanAmerican who was killed while he was in the chief's custody.

title: Domino Games Are Dominant Pastime For Many Cuban Refugees in Miami
description: MIAMIAround 10 A.M. every day, weather permitting, scores of Cuban refugees, many of them elderly, gather at a small park in the heart of the town's Little Havana section. Within minutes, they occupy all seats at a dozen square tables and begin what for many is a daily routine of playing dominoes. With everpresent kibitzers becoming players, and with new players constantly arriving on the scene, the game, an allmale affair at the municipal park, ends when the lights are turned off at 11:30 P.M.

title: CONGRESSMEN OFFER NEW ABORTION PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30House conferees rejected today a Senate proposal that would significantly increase the number of abortions that could be paid for with Federal funds. Instead they drafted a counterproposal that would allow payment for medical procedures for victims of rape and incest.

title: Ford Repeats Support for Pacts
description: SAN. DIEGO, Sept. 30Former President Gerald R. Ford entered a stronghold of Republican conservatism today and unequivocally reiterated his support for the Panama Canal treaties, but acknowledged it's going to be a tough battle to win ratification.

title: NASA Shuts Moon Stations in a CostCutting Move
description: A link with the moon, and with the past, was severed yesterday when American scientist shut down operations of five automated lunar stations set up by the Apollo astronauts.

description: An elderly man stood up at the Harlem Young Men's Christian Association yesterday and spoke in a trembling voice to Secretary of the Army Clifford L. Alexander Jr.

description: BONN, Sept. 30 (AP)The West German Parliament approved today a bill that prevents detained terrorist suspects from seeing their lawyers or other visitors.

description: For the roster of great barren controversies of government, we submit the current turmoil over Eskimo rights and the endangered bowhead whale. It is a splendid example of why Federal bureaucracies are in no danger whatever of extinction.

title: Income Tax Still the Big Issue
description: TRENTON THE state income tax, which is dominating the race for Governor, has been enlivening New Jersey politics for almost 12 years. Since 1966, every GovernorDemocrat and Republicanhas urged the Legislature to pass the tax, a move that many legislators believed tantamount to political suicide, but it was not Until last year that the circumstances of time and pressure coverged to provide the votes needed to enact the levy.

title: POLITICS
description: IF ANY evidence is needed to prove that we have entered the silly season in the race for Governor, just examine the fact that the two major candidates managed to put out 11point and 13point economic recovery programs within days of each other.
