Loneliness and the search for love underlie this overtly kinky story of two women who marry Siamese twins.

title: Mary Keil, Bank Aide
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Mary Keil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Keil of Venice, Fla., to Jahn Callary Lathrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Lathrop of West Bloomfield, Mich., formerly of North Caldwell, N. J.

title: Letters: Spending Vacations Separately
description: To the Editor: Regarding William It Dunnett's article on SeparatebutEqual VacationsFor the Couple Whose Marriage Works (Travel Section, Sept. 18): Separate vacations are just fine for couples who bore each other and terrific for meeting those of the opposite sexwhich may lead to a temporary arrangement and no worry about lasting involvement. A separate vacation may also project a subtle threat to one's partner and create more appreciation when the principals meet again.

title: Three for the Show
description: A PIECE OF THE ACTION;Sidney Poitier and Bill Cosby play a pair of con artists whose laughter turns to tears when they are blackmailed into reforming. The comedy, directed by Poitier, arrives Friday at the Criterion, 86th St. East and Eastside Cinema.

title: NATO AGAINST A CURB ON CRUISE MISSILES
description: WASHNGTON, Oct. 1;The Carter Administration has begun to encounter problems in accommodating its goal of achieving a strategicarms agreement with the Soviet Union to the growing interest of its key allies in Europe in the United States cruise missile.

title: Sandra Scoppettone Relates How She Came to Write Her Book About the Rise and Tragic Fall of a Flapper
description: GREENPORT, L.I. ; There's a bay that faces Shelter Island at the end of the block where Sandra Scoppettone lives here, in a colonial house with a screenedin front porch and tasteful antique furnishings. But she does not go down there much these days, retiring instead to her own backyard for a dip in the swimming pool she built last spring from the $375.000 sale of paperback rights to her new novel, Some Unknown Person, about the rise and tragic fall of a famous flapper, Starr Faithfull, who was turned into an unwilling party girl by circumstances beyond her control.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Wednesday;Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey general meeting at Elm Room, Main Street. Little Falls, N.J., at. 8:30 P.M. All interested persons welcome.

title: Goldin Taking His Own Poll On State Post
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, a virtual shooin for reelection in November, has been making speaking trips around the state in recent months and is now having poll conducted asking voters, among city Hall Notes other things, wnetner they prefer him or Arthur Levitt City Hall for State Comptroller. Last Notes weekend Mr. Goldin was the principal speaker at the annual dinnerdance of the Orange County Democratic Committee, and the weekend before he was the principal speaker at the annual dinner of the Delaware County Democratic Committee, where James Stewart, the county chairman, reported, It was a favorable impression he made on the crowd that evening.

title: Carter Extends Term of Aide. 70
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP);President Carter has announced today that he has signed an executive order permitting G. Joseph Minetti to serve as a member of the Civil Aeronautics Board until Oct. 31. Mr. Minetti has reached the mandatory retirement age of 70.

title: Kay Sutler Plans Marriage Feb. 25
description: Kay Leigh Sutler and Charles Burr Spencer 3d plan to be married in Dallas on Feb. 25. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sutler of Riverton, Wyo. Mr. Spencer is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Spencer of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Miss Current Bride Of James Burns Jr.
description: Deborah Virginia Curren! and Jams Shea Burns Jr., sales representatives for Milliken & Company, textiles, in Nev. York, were married yesterday in West port, Conn. The Rev. William B. Bryan; performed the ceremony in the Green's Farms Congregational Church.

title: Hanging Heavy Mirrors
description: When redecorating or moving, many homeowners and apartment dwellers find themselves faced with the task of hanging or mounting a very large mirror or heavy picture frame on one or more walls;and often they are not quite sure how to go about doing this safely.

title: Girls' Sports: Centereach Thrives in Sand Hockey
description: The defending Suffolk County field hockey champion has a secret.

title: Michael Gruhin Fianc Of Gloria A. Schneider
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mannie Schneider of University Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gloria Ann Schneider, to Michael H. Gruhin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Gruhin of Belleville. N.J.

title: Questions/Answers
description: We are surrounded by woods which must house many rabbits who invariably visit our roses, geraniums and marigolds. My greatest delight is in planting and watching things grow, but the rabbits are frustrating me. How can I discourage them? Mrs. M.A., Lakehurst, N.J.

title: From Kennedy to Carter, It Apparently Never Means Full
description: WASHINGTONWith the national unemployment rate stuck for the last several months at 7 percent 6.9 million persons were looking for work AugustCongress and Administration policy makers are being forced to ask anew what full employment means in the late 1970's.

title: If You Go&
description: to Woodlawn Plantation and the PopeLeighey House from Washington and prefer to stick closely to the Potomac River, take the George Washington Memorial Parkway (which becomes alternate U.S. 1 and then Mount Vernon Memorial Highway) about eight miles south and two miles west to Mount Vernon. From Washington's home, follow the signs three miles farther west to Woodlawn. If you choose public transportation, take Metrobus route 9A or 9B from the District of Columbia. Bus schedule information: 2026372437.

title: Film Festival Today
description: OMAR GATLATO. Algerian comedydrama directed by Merzak Allouache. 1 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. $5.50, $4, $3.

title: Fantasy in Sculpture
description: WEST WINDSOR DAVE PATTERSON has always been nimble with his fingers. As a research associate at the RCA David Sarnoff Research Center here, he has designed and built intricate electronic circuitry for 15 years in the materials and processing laboratory. But it wasn't until he was babysitting with his 7yearold daughter, Susan, early this year that his fingers led him to a new form of modern art.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Very early in Ettore Scola's A Special Day, you feel that things are going to be all right, that the director and his actors know what they're up to. The time is the day in 1938 when Mussolini threw gigantic rally to honor Hitler on his visit to Rome in celebration of their historic axis. The setting the film, though, is confined entirely to a modern workingclass apartment block of terrifying drabness. The moment I'm thinking of occurs just after Antonietta (Sophia Loren), the barely literate mother of six and prematurely exhausted, has just packed her children and her husband off to the rally. She slops the coffee remains from several cups into one, sits at the littered table and sips the coffee while surveying the incredible kitchen mess. She doesn't anticipate the morning's chores with any pleasure, but she still can enjoy the momentary peace. Suddenly this peace is broken by the cry of the family's pet mynah bird who, though it can talk, always gets her name wrong. There's something very funny and touching and revealing about Antonietta's reaction. She's both annoyed with the bird and aware that to be furious with a bird a waste of her energies.

title: Geneva May Become an End in Itself
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y.;With the parties disagreeing over fundamental issues such as the nature of peace, the final borders and the Palestinian homeland, the question is raised over the value of convening a Middle East peace conference at Geneva without advance assurance of success. An equally valid question is whether Geneva should be convened at all These questions have been debated for years by Middle East officials, diplomats and analysts. In the past, the prevailing view was the one often enunciated by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger. He argued that unless most of the substantive issues were solved through secret, preGeneva diplomacy, a fullb16wn peace conference would turn out to be disastrous for the Middle East; instead of advancing the cause of peace it would set it back.

title: The Standings
description: Sunday, October 2, 1977

title: Williams Kick Aids Victory By Somerville
description: Jon Williams's 32yard field goal In the first period proved to be the differonce as Somerville edged Bridgewater East, 15,12, at Bridgewater yesterday for its secondstraight victory.

title: Top Spot to Pol Pot
description: Until last week, the names of Cambodian leaders were not known. But that has changed: Pot Pot identified as Prime Minister and Secretary of the Central Committee its Communist Party, visited China. Mr. Pol Pot's trip the only known visit to a foreign nation by a Cambodian official since the war there ended in 1975. His. accounts Chinese leaders of a country prospering under a new stability were in conflict with reports by Cambodian refugees of executions and food shortages. Discussions between Mr. Pol Pot and Chinese officials were said to center on continued Chinese aid to Cambodia, and on Cambodian clashes with its neighbors, Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia.

title: GARDENING
description: ALTHOUGH Marchblooming gardens are rare in North Jersey, they need not be. Several hardy bulbs do bloom in March, or even at the end of February.

title: Are Nuclear Protesters Off Target?
description: IN justification for her actions at the site of the proposed nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N.H., (A Defense of Civil DisobedienceSept. 11, Westchester Weekly), Connie Hogarth asserts she has :an obligation to disobey a law protecting a property on which would be built an energy system threatening to world peace, threatening to the very future of humankind. Like many people, she incorrectly associates nuclear power plants with nuclear weapons.

title: Two Feet and Four Wheels
description: IF THERE is grass growing in the streets, or on the sidewalks of the Island, it is because there are no corns growing on the feet of the people who live there. Walking, it is not announced here as a revelation, is a lost pastime, something that must be done in the guise of a hike, golf or a journey no farther than four doors down the block?. It is not to be enjoyed for itself but must be presented as something with a goal or a score, to be measured as an achievement.

title: Tristate Panel Gets Into Local Issue
description: A zoning fight over a proposed housing project in Bernards Township, N.J., preoccupied the regular meeting of the TriState Regional Planning Commission last week in its offices in the World Trade Center. It voted to remove this particular proposal pending further study and review from the latest amendments to its longrange Regional Development Guide.

title: The Man Who Wasn't President
description: ADLAI STEVENSON, John Bartlow Martin tells us in a brief account of his labors on this work, was a stringsaver; he almost literally never threw anything away. One wonders about the qualifying almost. Stevenson even held on to the stubs of tickets to football games. Martin and his researcher did not catalogue the stubs, but they used 65,000 index cardsa thousand for each year of his life, almost three a dayto make a file of the materials they thought might be used, and on the evidence of this enormous work (the first volume, Adlai Stevenson of Illinois, was published last year) there was little that was not used wnat we nave, especially in this second and concluding volume, Adlai Stevenson and the World, which covers the period between his 1952 defeat by Dwight Eisenhower and his death in 1965. is very nearly a daybyday account of his last 13 years. (Sometimes it seems hourbyhour, even minutebyminute: On April 14 [1953] Stevenson and his companions left Singapore at 8:15 A.M. aboard a U. S. Air Force DC3 for Kuala Lumpur, capital of the federation of Malaya.) And what is not to be found in Martin's work, as well as much that is, is likely to have a place in The Papers of Adlai E. Stevenson, of which the seventh and penultimate volume;edited, as were its predecessors, by Walter Johnson;covers the 195761 period and includes, along with speeches and diary excerpts, innumerable thank youforthelovelyweekend notes and, in between expository and explanatory matter by Johnson;who, like Martin, had earlier written a book about Stevenson. There can be no more than a halfdozen figures in this country whose lives have been more amply recounted and documented than that of the man who served one term as Governor of Illinois, was overwhelmingly defeated in two Presidential elections and spent four bruising and disillusioning years as our chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: Fans at Yankee Stadium Rewarded By a Title Though Not by a Triumph
description: In the rain and without a single baseball player on the field yesterday, thousands of Yankee fans celebrated victory won for their team by another team.

title: North Rockland Regaining Touch
description: It has been five years since the end of North Rockland's reign over P.S.A.L. football, but coach Ralph Cordisco may have a winner again. The Red Raiders recorded their third straight victory yesterday, 340, over Spring Valley.

title: Vanessa Redgrave;The Only Person Who Could Play Julia
description: Vanessa Redgrave is, mainly, an actress. But some other things should be considered, too: that she has been jailed for taking part in antiwar demonstrations in London's Trafalgar Square. That she has traveled to Castro's Cuba. That in May, 1962, on the very day she returned from her honeymoon with her then husband Tony Richardson, she mounted a soapbox in Hyde Park and urged her audience to ban the bomb. That she has run for Parliament on the Workers Revolutionary Party ticket. That she calls herself Trotskyite.

title: FOOD
description: ONE of the Island's greatest delicacies is likely to be rather rare one this year. A bountiful harvest of Peconic Bay scallops is not expected, and prices are going to be highmore than $5 a pound.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: people go inside themselves, instead of outside. His language is probing rather than defining, his rhythms rise almost in crescendoes but stop short. His people come up against the paralyzing realization that there is no necessary forward movement in events or in themselves. They are like amnesiacs, forced to begin at the beginning, but without knowing the process.

title: Peruvian Ceramics at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ONE of the modern attitudes that has partly impaired a full understanding of the art of the past is an excessive reverence toward it. We have learned to appreci ate art objects from other eras as if they were made on Olympus or in Heaven, and had little to do with humanity.

title: An Ecumenical Premiere
description: UNLESS you read your paper with breakfast, it may be already too late to attend 10:30 services this morning at the Congregational Church in Sherman, about 15 miles north of Danbury, but did want to tell you about this rather special occasion. After all, how many towns can boast a combined birthday party, world premiere and ecumenical salute, all put together by volunteer forces?

title: FISHING
description: SOME of the finest bluefish action of the season is stirring the waters around the Island now. Big blues are pushing mossbunkers into the bays along the North Shore. Off the South Shore, the super bluefishing is being augmented by a strong line of bluefin tuna, albacore and bonito.

title: Dr. Rockefeller Tells of His Day As an Osteopath
description: GREENVALE, L. I., Oct. 1;Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Vice President of the United States, former Governor of New York and one of the world's richest men, described today another aspect of his background;he said he had practiced osteopathic medicine and was able to cure a bride of a dislocated jaw and thus save her wedding day.

title: Weighing the Possibilities
description: THE Nassau Republican organization and its powerful leader, Joseph M. Margiotta, won the battle on primary day, but the war is still ahead. Just as Mr. Margiotta, Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor Francis T. Purcell and their followers could not afford to lose the Republican nomination for County Executive to the incumbent, Ralph G. Caso, or to State Senator John R. Dunne in the primary, so they now cannot afford to lose the County Executive post itself to the Democratic candidate, Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes.

title: Alabama Sinks Georgia, 1810, on Chapman Kicks
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 1 (UPI);Roger Chapman kicked three secondhalf field goals today, two of them set up on fumble recoveries by Wayne Hamilton, to enable Alabama to score a hardearned 18,10 victory over Georgia.

title: Thea Musgrave at City Opera, Introduces Voice of Ariadne
description: Thea Musgrave is a British composer, now living in this country, whose operas are beginning to attract a great deal of attention. On Friday night the New York City Opera introduced Miss Musgrave's The Voice of Ariadne to this city. She herself conducted the performance.

title: SCHOOL DIFFICULTIES ON ROOSEVELT ISLAND
description: A growing number of parents on Roosevelt Island have become increasingly angry over the failure of the Urban Development Corporation and the Board of Education to find a way of getting fresh air into the classrooms and keeping raw sewage out.

title: How Gerber Foiled a Takeover
description: FREMONT, Mich.;John C. Suerth, chairman of the Gerber Products Company, was vacationing at his winter home in Naples, Fla., last April 15 when a visitor arrived;T. J. Barlow, chairman of Anderson, Clayton & Company, the Houston producer of consumer and institutional foods. The two men had talked before, the first time at a food convention in June 1976, about a possible acquisition of Gerber by Anderson, Clayton. Twice the Gerber board had rejected the proposition. Mr. Barlow was here to discuss the subject again, but Mr. Suerth's response was the same: Gerber did not wish to be acquired. In that case, Mr. Barlow said, handing over a thick stack of papers, intend to take.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Gold symbolized wealth and power to the ancient Peruvians, but unlike the Spaniards, they never converted it into money, assistant curator Craig Morris explains on the occasion of Peru's Golden Treasures, opening Wednesday at the American Museum of Natural History. PreInca peoples, in fact, buried much of their gold with their dead, a practice which permitted many objects to survive the Spanish search for gold. And, at this time, permits the display of 225 items which did survive the Spanish conquistadors: masks, beakers, figurines and jewelry. (See Art)

title: Autumn in Party Dress
description: October is the year at rich maturity, a brisk wind in the treetops, a whisper among the crisping leaves, a breath of apple cider and a gleam from an early hunter's moon. The lawn mower is put away for the season and thegarden is sere with frost. The month is bright as a bittersweet berry. It is the year come to harvest, in root cellar, jam closet and pantry.

title: The Big White House Error On Energy Was Overconfidence
description: WASHINGTON;Back in the late summer, just as the White House was congratulating itself on getting an energy bill much to its liking through the House of Representatives, the opposition gathered to sharpen its knives in anticipation of the serious surgery planned for the Carter energy program in the Senate.

title: Afghan Gains Top Award At Suffolk County Show
description: LAKE GROVE, LL, Oct. 1;Ch. Jamica's Rani Fafnir, a black and tan Afghan with a spectacular coat, came through the rain in great style today to win over 1,329 other dogs at the Suffolk County Kennel Club's 39th show on the Lake Grove school grounds.

title: Fashion
description: Above: Angela Cummings's red jasper beads, punctuated by 18karat gold rondels and strung on a blue silk cord, can be fondled as worry beads. They are meant as a necklace;though not necessarily for a dog. 36inches long. $525 at Tiffany & Co.

title: Hnueilings
description: GOLDFINE;Winiam. The ??? erected in our beloved father and usband's memory will be unveiled Sunday morning, October 9th, 1977 at 10:15 AM, Block 54, Saction 7.

title: CURB ON PHOSPHATES BEGINS RI MICIIIGAN
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1;To those who do the nation's laundry, the gaily colored detergent boxes with the punchy names like Dash, Cheer, Fab, Tide and Ajax are as familiar as anything on supermarket shelves. Less obvious are the smallprint messages on the boxes telling the buyer that the product is 8 percent phosphorus, or 7.5 percent or 6 percent.

title: GARDENING
description: IF YOUR house plants are still outdoors, by all means bring them in at once, not only to prevent damage by frost, but also so that they may become acclimated to indoor conditions before the heatine season beeins.

title: New York City Unemployed Found Unable to Fill 6,000 Skilled Jobs
description: At least 6,000 jobs for skilled laborers and clerical workers are currently available in New York City, but only a small proportion of those who are out of work and looking for employment have the necessary skills for those jobs, according to the New York State Manpower Service Council.

title: Why Con Edison Cut the Power Here
description: LIGHTS were back on in a score of Westchester cities and towns where whole communities briefly lost power early last week, but questions still lingered following the second significant blackout for those municipalities in the last three months. Why, many residents asked, were we the ones who had to suffer?

title: Classic and Contemporary on the Potomac
description: A Georgian mansion, circa 1800, and a fiveroom house, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, share the pleasure of each other's company on a 180acre piece of the Virginia countryside. Woodlawn Plantation, built for relatives of George and Martha Washington, offers the likes of mahogany antiques and Colonial portraits, plus a touch and try historic exhibit area. The PopeLeighey House, a Wright creation for moderateincome families, reflects the master's touch, from modular seating to Oriental rugs. And though the pairing of ample classic Federal with spare contemporary was no easy matter, the match has proved felicitous, and provocative.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SET MUTUAL GUIDELINES FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union said in a joint declaration yesterday that a new Middle East peace conference should insure the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people and establish normal peaceful relations in the region.

title: The Estimate
description: This is how the author projected expenses for a fourweek European vacation for his wife, himself and their three children:

title: New York TV Fans to Miss 2 Key Rivalries
description: There will be surly fans muttering before their television sets this afternoon when they realize they are not going to see either of the two big games of the dayPittsburgh at Cleveland or St. Louis at Washington. The Pro Football latter will be televised to About most parts of the United States, but not to New York. Channel 2 here will present, as it must by Federal law, the Giants road game in Atlanta.

title: The Theater Goes To the Audience
description: IT'S not easy for actors to perform when there's a pillar im the middle of their stage and when the stage is half the size they're used to. It takes a little extra effort when most of those in the audience are over 80, some can't hear, some fall asleep and some get up and leave in the middle of the performance. Concentration is difficult when bells ring every 15 minutes and nurses patrol the aisles in swishy plastic aprons.

title: He Turns Orchestras Into TV Stars
description: Aonehundredpiece orchestra on a 19inch screen is not what would call the ideal television show, admits Jordan Whitelaw, a pioneer of televised classical music and the producer of Evening at Symphony, the PBS series featuring the Boston Symphony Orchestra. As far as I'm concerned, music is primarily to be listened to. But I'm faced with putting an orchestra on TV so I do the best I can to make it both musically valid and visually interesting.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a careless smoker allows a match or cigarette to fall on a piece of finished furniture, the black, scarred mark that remains is usually quite an eyesore. Fortunately, in many cases, it can be removed successfully by the patient doityourselfer so that the damage is scarcely visible, or at least much less noticeable.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: Perhaps it is not for me to come to Harold Bloom's defensehaving myself attacked his views when they were a bit fresherbut he certainly does not deserve the mocking intemperate treatment dished out by Hilton Kramer in The Literary View (Aug. 21).

title: Creek Washes Away Village's Police Car
description: UNADILLA, N.Y., Oct. I (AP) ; Recent rains here swelled a creek and washed away most of Police Chief James (Cane's backyard as well as the village's only police car.

title: Vatican Document Says Dissident French Prelate Is Moving Toward Schism
description: ROME. Oct. 1;The dissident French priest, Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, and his disciples were castigated in an official Vatican document here as advancing step by step down the road toward the schism of the Roman Catholic Church, it was announced today.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The 1977 prooflike coin sets from the Soviet Union will be sold with an unusual threeyear repurchase guarantee from the United States distributor. It will be a ninepiece set containing all the coins currently in circulationfrom one kopek to one ruble. According to an official of the distributing company, the Paramount International Coin Corporation, it is offering the buyback guarantee because it is so certain of the potential future demand and subsequent appreciation in value. The offer provides for a full refund of the original issue price.

title: Deaths
description: ALLEGRI;Dr. Linda, 68 of 271 Brevoorf St, Kew Gardens, N.Y. Retired Professor of Mathematics,Hunter College, CUNY. Associate Professor, Columbia UniverslIv. Survived by brother, nwodore Allegrl of 5617 Fairmont Drive, Peoria, Ill. Services and entombmeat were held Peana,111,Sept 30, 1977.

title: Let's Hear It For (Cough) Opening Nights
description: Opening night. As we all know from Hollywood movies of the 90's, everything depends on opening night. This is the night on which years of effort by the playwright and months of effort by the cast are judged by an audience consisting of members of the press and the families of the actors.

title: CHESS
description: As an antidote for panic, the successful defender should keep in mind that a mating attack often requires a considerable unbalance of the attacking force and that there are ways to take advantage of this.

title: The Loose, Drifting Material of Life
description: AGAINthese lyrical, allusive and alluring names! Lytton, Carrington, Clive, Roger, Vanessa, Duncan, Leonard, Maynard, Gertler, Ka, Kot, Janet, Aldous, Bob, Arnold, Ottoline, Morgan, Logan, Katherine, Desmond, Murry, Nick, Saxon, Mix.Miniaturized by the Cyclops eye of hindsight, with the gold dust shaken out of them, one or two have broken out of legend to survive;E.M. Forster, solidly and on his own, also the economist Keynes; the rest shakily and in shadow, reduced to period names: the polemicist Toynbee, rapidly growing quaint, Aldous Huxley's novels long ago turned problematical, Katherine Mansfield, fallen even out of the anthologies, Sidney and Beatrice Webb, fixed in Fabian caricature. The men of letters;Robert Trevelyan, John Middleton Murry, Desmond MacCarthy, Logan Pearsall Smith: How far away and small they now seem! And the painters, Vanessa Bell, Duncan Grant, Mark Gertler, and the art critics, Clive Bell and Roger Fry;lost molecules in the antiquity of modernism. And Saxon SydneyTurner? Less than a molecule; a civil servant in the British Treasury. Lytton Strachey? A minor psychological historian given to phrasing both fustian and trite; he had his little vogue. Leonard Woolf? An ungainly writer and social reformer active in anticolonial causes, an early supporter of the League of Nations ; who thinks of him as anything other than Virginia Woolf s husband?

title: Reggie Jackson: The Most Valuable Player
description: Of all the annual accolades in baseball, the most controversial are invariably the Most Valuable Player awards. And in the American League this season, the Yankees most controversial player, Reggie Jackson, has emerged as the most controversial candidate in what looms as a most controversial election. When the Yankees hired him for nearly $3 million over five seasons. The Times Reggie Jackson was described by Thurman Munson as slugger who cart carry a club for a month. Reggie Jackson exceeded that reputation. Since being knighted as the cleanup hitter, he has carried the Yankees for nearly two months in their quest for another Eastern Division title. For the season he has 32 home runs and 111 runs batted in.

title: Mexican Favors Border Casinos
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI)The Governorelect of Lower California, Mexico, says he favors legalized casinostyle gambling in Tijuana and other border areas as a way to bolster Mexico's tourist economy.;Roberto de la Madrid, who takes office Nov. 1, said yesterday that changes would have to be made in Mexican federal law to legalize gambling and that a way would have to be found to, minimize, the possibility of Mafia participation in casino operations.

title: HOSPITAL MONITORS STIR GROWING DISCORD
description: The increasingly bitter conflict between New York and Federal monitors of publicly financed hospital care in the state has divided Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Jacob K. Javits.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a careless smoker allows a match or cigarette to fall on a piece of finished furniture, the black, scarred mark that remains is usually quite an eyesore. Fortunately, in many cases, it can be removed successfully by the patient doityourselfer so that the damage is scarcely visible, or at least much less noticeable.

title: JAPAN'S SOCIALISTS FAIL TO PICK LEADERS
description: TOKYO. Oct. 1;Japan's troubled Socialist Party, the largest single opposition group in Parliament. held a convention here this week to pick new leaders. But about all that the disputing delegates could agre on was that they could not agree on new leaders.

title: Reorganization and Race Relations
description: ACLOSER examination of the facts in the appointment of James W. Couch to the Suffolk Human Rights Commission affords a remarkable insight into a sociopolitical phenomenon that is arousing growing concern across the nation in the arena of race relations.

title: Penn State Beaten, 2420; Columbia Subdues Penn
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 1 ;Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, spoke nothing but the truth after his team's first loss of the season today when he said, Kentucky made no mistakes and we made too many and that was the game.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: BridgeJumper Gets An Offer for His Play
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 (AP) ; Dan Cameron Rodill, who jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge in frustration over the lack of interest in his play The Dry Season, has attracted interest in his work.

title: Record 67Yard Field Goal
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 1 (UN) ; Russell Erxleben established a National Collegiate Athletic Association record with a 67yard field goal and Earl Campbell scored four touchdowns as the University of Texas trounced Rice, 7214 today.

title: Lawyer Is Appointed to Head Unit To Police Medicaid Overpayments
description: A New York lawyer has been appointed to head a new unit of the special state proseqution's office charged with recoving $20 million in Medicaid overpayments to nursinghome operators.

title: Michigan Crushes Aggies; Notre Dame Wins by 166
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) After losing two fumbles, Russell Davis ran for two touchdowns that put Michigan on its way to an overwhelming 413 rout of mistakeprone Texas A. & M. today.

title: Letters
description: It was with disappointment that I read the article, Landscape Gardeners Are Flourishing, [Aug. 7].

title: Tennis
description: E.C.A.C. FALL CHAMPIONSHIP Quarterfinals;Eric Fromm, Columbia defeated Bud Robinson, Navy, 6.0, 6.2; JaY Lapidus, Princeton, defeated Murray Rob. Inson, Penn, 61, 6.2; Malt Doyle, Yale, defeated Jon Gross, Princeton, 7.6, 6.1; Jeff Patten, Conimble, defeated Dave Hag(tarty, George Washington), 6.4, 6.2.

title: GARDENING
description: JUNIPERS are among the most versatile plant groups, as anyone who visited the recent Garden Festival at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains had an opportunity to see.

title: Where to Seek Help
description: IF YOU feel you have been the victim of a criminal act and have cause to seek criminal prosecution or protection, there may be some recourse at the District Attorney's Office. While the office won't necessarily issue an immediate warrant for a person's arrest, it may take steps that could lead to prosecution.

title: INTERVIEW
description: TRENTON ROCCO D. RICCI believes that solutions are forthcoming to the various environmental problems that appear to defy solving, problems like waterquality standards in the pinelands, the covetous looks that wouldbe casino developers are casting on forbidden wetland areas in Atlantic City and the myriad streams and lakes that attract polluters like magnets.

title: Ruth Butler Is Wed To Daniel R. Harper
description: Ruth Taylor Butler and Daniel Robert Harper, members of the staff of the Outward Bound School on Hurricane Island in Rockport, Me., were married yesterday aboard the motor vessel Hurricane. Capt. William H. Zuber 2d performed the ceremony in international waters off the Maine coast.

title: A Fine Team Brings Gypsy New Cheers
description: AN EVENING DINNER THEATER in Elmsford has welcomed fall with a big fat hit. The show is Gypsy, and to make it into the steamroller the musical can be requires top professional hands working at their top form. An Evening has them.

title: Calling All Singers
description: As I had occasion to say in these pages some months ago, singers are luckier than instrumentalists: after all, it takes years of study and practice to play an instrument well enough to hold down a chair in any selfrespecting orchestra, even of the amateur variety, but anybody with a nice voice and a semblance of musicality will usually find a welcome in one of the many avocational choirs that operate near or at professional levels.

title: Film Festival: 'Roseland' Casts Spell Over Lonely Fox-Trotters
description: It is the basic proposition of "Roseland," the funny, moving, imaginative new movie directed by James Ivory, written by Ruth Prawer Jhablava and produced by Ismail Merchant, that the world is a dance hall in which everyone, even the comparatively young and the quite old, have been arrested in middle age. It's as if they'd been put under a spell by the music of the old-time swing band, whose anonymous players, their faces as expresionless as death-masks, pump and blow and beat away night-after-night-after-night, plus two afternoons a week."Roseland" is a stunt that comes offthree interlocking stories, set almost entirely within New York's famous Roseland Ballroom, about essentially lonely people who live their lives (and sometimes end them) to nonstop Waltzes, fox-trots and occasional hustles. Considering that most of the earlier efforts of the Ivory-Jhablava-Merchant team ("Shakespere Wallah," "The Guru" and "Bombay Talkie," among others) have been set in India, the success of "Roseland" is all the more dramatic.The film will be shown at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center tonight at 9 o'clock and Tuesday evening at 6:15. It will open its regular commercial engagement at the Columbia 1 Theater Oct. 16.Most remarkable to me is Mrs. Jhablava's ear for New York speech, such as the genteel mannerisms affected by someone like May (Teresa Wright) a middle-aged widow who bores everyone with stories about her late husband, Ed. ("He wouldn't wear anything with a spot on it . . . he always had to be spotless."But Mrs. Jhablava is equally good with the dialogue of the elderly, heavily made-up former cook, Rosa (Lilia Skala), who wants only to win "the Champagne Hour" dance contest, and the desperate, self-deprecating lines of Pauline (Joan Copeland), a rich, uncertain woman who fusses over her gigolo and says, after making the smallest, most timid demand of him, "Oh, darling Russel, I'm spoiling your whole day!"The ear is accurate, but the effect of the film is less real than surreal, less slice-of-life than so romantic that Mr. Ivory makes us accept, in the concluding episode, an explosion of outrageously overblown sentiment.The film's enclosed settingthe dance hall, its bar, lobby and rest roomsas well as the dominating vulgarity of its dcor and the music contribute to an eerie, confined "Outward Bound" atmosphere that's maintained even when Mr. Ivory allows the camera to go outside on a couple of occasions.The performers have a ball with the kind of roles that allow them to get on and off the screen fast, thus to leave vivid impressions. Among the best are Miss Wright, Miss Copeland and Miss Skala, who more or less star in their own vignettes. There are also Helen Gallagher, the Roseland dance teacher whose commentary provides continuity; Lou Jacobi, as Miss Wright's no-nonsense suitor; Christopher Walken (in his best screen role to date) as Miss Colepland's gigolo; Geraldine Chaplin, as a divorcee who spends some time briefly at the dance hall before fleeing with her sanity, and David Thomas, who is especially fine as Miss Skala's aging suitor, an old man who simply can't remember to smile while counting out the dancesteps.Don De Natale, Roseland's real-life master-of-ceremonies, a young man with a patent-leather look and the kind of patter that Pal Joey would have admired, hovers over the show, so persistently cheerful that, finally, he becomes macabre, which is, I suspect, exactly what Mr. Ivory intended.

title: 2 Battles in Germantown: One ReEnacted, One Waged Every Day
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1;Cannon and rifle fire boomed and cracked, leaving blue smoke over Germantown Avenue today as men in uniforms, red for the British, motley for the Continentals, reenacted the Battle of Germantown.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a careless smoker allows a match or cigarette to fall on a piece of finished furniture, the black, scarred mark that remains is usually quite an eyesore. Fortunately, in many cases, it can be removed successfully by the patient doityourselfer so that the damage is scarcely visible, or at least much less noticeable.

title: Rally by Miami of Ohio Sets Back Elis, 2814
description: NEW HAVEN Oct. 1.;On an afternoon for comparing, the Ivy League came out second best here today, although a respectable second. Yale, which expects to prove that it is the best of the Ivies this season, lost to Miami of Ohio, 2814, but led, 146, for half the game before a crowd of 19,026 in Yale Bowl.

title: Civil Rights
description: The first week in October, as usual, is National Employ the Handicapped Week. But crippled, palsied and blind peotole aren't just asking anymore. They are demanding.

title: Spaghetti Racquet Banned
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 1 (Reuters) ;The International Tennis Federation's executive committee decided today to place a temporary ban on doublestrung racquets in tournaments. The ban takes effect Monday.

title: Artists Bank to Aid Health Costs
description: A new nationwide campagin to establish a $10 million bank of donated art to pay for the hospitalization of needy artists has been started by Change, a foundation headed by Robert Rausehenberg, the painter.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: More on Rutgers Eleven; The Game the Bears Won
description: the Sports Editor: In response to Peter A. Peyser's attack (Mailbox, Sept. 18) of the Sept. 2 RutgersPenn State football game, and as a ticketbuying fan in attendance, I did not feel betrayed by Peyser's irraaional description of the money:hungry Rutgers administration. I have no past or present affiliation with either university, and no one twisted my arm or conned me into buying a ticket. I attended the game, like so many others, to see a bigtime venture by local college team that will eventually bring much pride to the greater New JerseyNew York area.

title: Country Music Month Designated
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP);President Carter, terming country music as universal as a sunset and as personal as a baby's smile, signed yesterday a proclamation designating October as Country Music Month. It Is fitting, lie proclaimed, that we acknowledge the importance of a form that reflects so much the lives and hopes of the people who make up our nation and pay tribute to the talented people who have contributed to its growing popularity.

title: MENGISTU ACKNOWLEDGES SETBACKS FOR ETHIOPIANS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 1 (Agence France Presse);The Ethiopian head of state, Mengistu Haile Mariam, conceded today that Ethiopa had suffered some temporary reverses at the I hand of enemies who had encircle it. But he also predicted that the nation's forces would defeat the enemies and emerge victorious soon.

title: Weddings
description: HessRosenzweig Sylvia and Jay Rosenzweig of Brooklyn, New York joyfully announce the marriage of Adrian Dian to Robert Anthony Hess of Brooklyn, Ohio, on Saturday, October 1, 1977.

title: World Food Supplies Are Just Below Record Levels;
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1;With the grain harvest either completed or well under way in the Northern Hemisphere this week, the world's food supplies were nearing the second highest leyel on record. Some countries will, not get enough nevertheless.

title: Rowdies and Tornado Set Exhibition in Tulsa
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP) ;The Tampa Bay Rowdies will play a North American Soccer League exhibition game against Dallas in Tulsa, Okla., on Oct. 18. The purpose of the match is to test the market for a N.A.S.L. franchise. Proceeds will go to area youth soccer.

title: New Leader in Tammany
description: Miriam Bockman,the Democratic coleader of Greenwich Village, was unanimously picked last week to head Tammany Hall, the Manhattan Democratic organization. Mrs. Bockman is a close friend and political ally of Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor who is the oddson choice;because he's a Democrat;to win next month's election. The significance of Mrs. Bockman's election is clearly that power among New York City Democrats has shifted from the party regulars led by Mayor Beame, who, lost in the primary, to the reform wing now led by Mr. Koch. She replaced Frank G. Rossetti who was a Beame supporter and who was county chairman for the last 10 years. Mrs. Bockman also follows such names as Aaron Burr, William Marcy Tweed and Carmine G. De Sapio. She is the first woman to hold the post.

title: Farrell Stumbles, 300, on Trip to Ohio
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 1 (AP);A senior wingback, Tom Schroeder, scored 20 points and rushed for 108 yards last night to lead the defending Ohio Class AAA champion Cincinnati Moeller team to a 30.0 victory over a New York State powerhouse, Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island.

title: If You Go
description: &to the Parco Nazionale d'Abruzzounless you're a hearty skier or snowshoeryou'll probably want to avoid visiting in winter, when snowfall may limit you to the lower trails and valleys. There are 25 points of road access into the park and from each of these, trails of varying difficulty lead into the interior.

title: Koch Takes to the Streets Again in Mayoral Bid
description: Although he is the overwhelming favorite for election in November, Representative Edward I. Koch, yesterday plunged back into a frenetic style of street campaigning for the first time since he won the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York nearly two weeks aeo.

title: ALBERT J. O'BRIEN
description: Albert J. O'Brien, executive director of Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y., from 1941 to 1971, died Friday at his home in Columbia. Tenn. He was 67 years old.

title: Round About isicily With Lawrence Durrell
description: The plane hovered and tilted and the green evening, darkening over the planes of coloured fields girdling Catania, swam up at us, The island was there, below us.

title: WATCHING WISEMAN WATCH
description: When I first learned that the subject of Frederick Wiseman's latest documentary film was the Panama Canal, I thought: What can this mean? Has he gone political? Polemical? Has he sold out? Has Fred gone straight? Poor old Fred. Silly old me: I should have known better.

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: For nearly two centuries Americans have enjoyed freedom of press, speech and assembly, due process of law, privacy, freedom of conscience and other important rights ; in their homes, churches, politicai forums and social and cultural life. But Americans have not enjoyed these civil liberties in most companies, government agencies and other organizations where they work. Once a United States citizen steps through the plant or office door at 9 A.M. he or she is nearly rightless until 5 P.M., Monday through Friday.

title: Jean Strumpf Plans Wedding for Nov. 6
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome C. Strumpf of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Sarah Strumpf, to Stefan Ellis Sommerfield, on of Mrs. Alvan B. Sommerfield and the late Mr. Sommerfield.

title: Practical Traveler: Airline Fares
description: It was bound to happen sooner or later. in the zany world of air travel, but for the last couple of weeks it has happened regularly. Twopassengers sit side by side on Pan American World Airways Flight 100 from New York to London. Both bought their economyclass seats the morning of departure. But one paid $313 while the other paid $146.

title: Television This Week
description: 9 (4) JUST A LITTLE INCONVENIENCE. A twohour madeforTV movie dramatizing the problems facing a Vietnam veteran who lost an arm and a leg in combat; starring James Stacy, Lee Majors and Barbara Hershey.

title: Levitt Marks the 30th Anniversary of His First Levittown, on Long Island, as Another Rises in Iran
description: LEVITTOWN, L.I. ; With this, the first Levittown, celebrating its 30th anniversary, William J. Levitt is at work on the latest Levittown. But the latest Levittown is being built in Iran and the next one probably will go up in Nigeria or perhaps Venezuela. Despite their success, there will be no more American Levittowns.

title: San Francisco Students Who Cut Grafitti to Be Given Cash Awards
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1;Secondary school students who can reduce grafitti at their schools will be granted cash incentives by the San Francisco Board of Education under an experimental program to curb vandalism, which last year cost the city schools more than $1 million.

title: JOSEPH LITTAU
description: Joseph Littau, conductor of the Radio City Music Hall orchestra in the early 1930's and the World's Fair Band in 1938, died Thursday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in CrotonontheHudson, N.Y.

title: Byrd Vows Senate Will Vote on Energy Despite Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1;Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader, insisted today that he would not allow the Senate to drop consideration of the natural gas legislation under any circumstances, despite a weekold filibuster over deregulation of gas prices that shows no siens of dissipating.

title: Light, Reflective Substance Seen In a Photo of the Surface of Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) ; A light, reflective substance, possibly carbon dioxide frost or snow, has been seen on the Martian surface in a picture returned by the Viking 2 spacecraft, scientists report.

title: Two Women Tied for Golf Lead
description: DALLAS, Oct. 1 (AP)Judy Rankin end Jan Stephenson fired twounderpar 70's today to share the 36hole lead in the $50,000 Dallas Civitan open golf tournament.

title: WETLANDS ACT CASE HAILED AS LANDMARK
description: In what its lawyers hail as a landmark case, New York State has successfully prosecuted a Long Island builder who dressed a channel and then used the socallttl spoil from the dredging to fill in a wetlands area, thus building up the property.

title: Janet Krupensky Engaged
description: The engagement of Janet Krupensky to Richard M. Stone Jr. has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Krupensky of Pittsburgh. Mr. Stone is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Stone of Garden City, L.I. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: ISLAND OFF COAST SOUGHT FOR A WILDLIFE PRESERVE
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (UPI) ; The Nature Conservancy wants to buy 55,000 acres on Santa Cruz Island for a plant and wildlife preserve.

title: GiantFalcon Game Pairs 2 Fine Rookies
description: The Giants meet the Falcons today in Atlanta, and doing so must be something like looking into a mirror.

title: STAMPS
description: Ffifty years of talking pictures, reckoning from the premiere of The Jazz Singer with Al Jolson, are being marked by the United States this Thursday with a new 13cent com memorative, a companion to the Centennial of Sound Recording stamp issued earlier this year.

title: ONE DEAD, 2 WOUNDED IN CHINATOWN MOVIE
description: A 17yearold youth was shot to death In the balcony of a crowded Chinatown movie theater last night, allegedly because he had refused to join one of the area's youth gangs.

title: CHARLES P. GRAVES
description: Charles P. Graves, head of the garden advertising department or The New York Herald Tribune for 40 years, died yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: LEITERS
description: Frank E. Armbruster (The More We Spend, the Less Children Learn, Aug. 28) dismisses all innovators as either fools or goofoffs. If an innovative English teacher can teach his students to follow a fictional plot by watching a movie with them, he can teach them to use this skill in the study of a Dickens novel. If he can teach them to spell by writing television commercials, why must we insist on oldfashioned rote learning? Innovative programs must be monitored and evaluated, but mini courses and modular scheduling can be valuable. In most cases they do not represent a dilution of the material.

title: Waits Defeat Fleming
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP) Butch Wats, in a duel of big servers, gained the final of the $125,000 Transamerica open tennis tournament today by defeating Peter Fleming, 6.4, 36, 7.5.

title: Abortion;One Mother's View
description: MY CHILD is dead, if one can call a 3monthold fetus a child. I do. He lived for three hours, a rare feat for a premature baby the size of a pen and weighing but six ounces. He was only two weeks over the legal limit in every state for being aborted on demand.

title: Peter DuBois Morris Weds Bennie Beach, Summer Resort Aide
description: Ann Penfield Beach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harvey Beach of Vergennes, Vt., was married there yesterday to Peer DuBois Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. DuBois Schanck Morris Jr. of Weston, Conn.

title: BISHOP AWN BACKED BY EPISCOPAL BODY
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Oct. 1;Upholding the principle of freedom of conscience, the House of Bishops of the Episcopal Church today supported the right of Presiding Bishop John M. Allin to retain office even though he strongly opposed the church's ruling in favor of the ordination of women.

description: Following is the text of a SovietAmerican statement on the Middle East released yesterday.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: I was dismayed recently when my evening in New York City was ruined by those happy hookers, and I don't mean prostitutes. It was those police tow trucks to which I refer.

title: Nastase Gains Final
description: AIXENPROVENCE, France, Oct. 1 (UPI)Ilia Nastase reached the final of a $50,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament without, setting foot on the court today when his French opponent, Georges Goven, pulled out with a sprained ankle.

It's as if they'd been put under a spell by the music of the oldtime swing band, whose anonymous players, their faces as expresionless as deathmasks, pump and blow and beat away nightafternightafternight, plus two afternoons week.

title: Home Style
description: Unattended garages present three threats to tenants who own automobiles: that a car, or its parts, will be stolen; that a dangerous assailant will enter through the garage to attack tenants in the garage, in the elevator that ascends from the garage or inside thd building; and that a burglar will enter the building through the garage.

title: THE 1921 SALT TALKSAND YOU ARE THERE
description: Competitionin armamentmust stop! The Secretary of State pronounced the words carefully, with pauses for emphasis. There was applause, and he looked up at his audience. Before him in the large, whitepaneled hall, sat premiers and prime ministers past and present, diplomats and beribboned admirals from the world's dozen strongest nations, all the members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives, and more than 400 journalists from every place on earth.

title: ANOTHER GEM DEALER IS FOUND MURDERED
description: Detectives investigating the murder of a midtown Manhattan diamond broker and the disappearance of another, were looking yesterday into the killing of third Manhattan diamond dealer in Florida.

title: Demand for Firewood Up in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30 (AP);Demand for firewood in Connecticut already larger than some sources can handle, officials said this week.

title: White Cane Safety Day Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)President Carter has proclaimed that Oct. 15 will be White Cane Safety Day. He called on Americans Thursday to be mindful that whit canes enhance the safety of blind and Visually handicapped citizens.

title: Schnol Custodian Practices Mentally for Plowing Test at L.I. Fair
description: Nikola Baricevic doesn't own a horse or a plow. His backyard in Mount Sinai isn't large enough to accommodate either. But that isn't stopping Mr. Baricevic from practicing';mentally, at least;to take firstplace honors in plowing at next weekend's Long Island Fair.

title: Upstate Utility Is Ordered to Pay New York City for Power Hookup
description: An arbitrator has ordered an upstate New York utility to pay New York City $1.25 million immediately and $14.5 million over the next 10 years for the right to generate electricity at a cityowned water.,supply aqueduct, W. Bernard Richland, the city's Corporation Counsel, announced last week.

title: BRIDGE
description: Acomputer can have a major impact on bridge tournaments in three distinct ways. For more than 15 years computerdealt hands have been commonplace, allowing players at many different tables, perhaps hundreds, to play the same deals. The third stage of the process is still far in the future: There is no sign of computers playing the game effectively, or indeed at all, although they do play chess. But the second stage, scoring by computer, has now arrived.

title: Music in Review
description: Recent decades have seen something of a Diaspora of Latvians into the world, at least to judge from some of the biographical particulars attendant upon Rasma Lielmane's New York debut last Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Radio
description: 89, WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories.

title: Under Budget Ax, Carle Place Carves Out Victory.
description: Carle Place showed its appreciation for a community fundraising effort that allowed it to field a varsity football team as it smashed East Rockaway, 200, yesterday in a Nassau Conference VI game.

title: Aaron Burr Group Fights the In in
description: MEMBERS of the Aaron Burr Association, who for 31 years have been seeking to burnish their idol's tarnished image, might dismiss what Car11 S. Burr Jr. of Northport did in 1949 as an act of youthful indiscretion.

title: Air War Over the Atlantic: Predatory Fares?
description: Come fly with me, Freddie Laker invited the public, and last week they began to take the British entrepreneur up on it as the first of Laker Airways Skytrain flights from New York to London took off.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: In 1905 Alfred Stieglitz and Edward Steichen opened the PhotoSecession Gallery at 291 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, and for a period of 12 years this Gallery was a focal point for the finest of photographic work and served as a gathering place for the notable photographers of that period. Its closing in 1917 left a gap in the photographic field that was not to be filled until July 15, 1974, when the International Center of Photography (ICP) opened its doors in a beautiful landmark building at 94th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Transplant new evergreens or move old established ones to renovate tired landscapesExamine trees for weak and/or broken limbs which should be pruned now before the ice storm season  Mow new lawns when grass is over two inches highKeep up with bulb planting.

title: Complaint Bureau For the Aggrieved
description: MINEOLA AS the young woman detailed how her vituperative neighbor chased her at discotheques, screamed obscenities at her and threatened her life, Henry Steiner listened attentively, took studious notes and tried to calm her down.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Nancy Burkert's pictures are treasures, permanent visions of an exalted other world. Previously unpublished paintings and powerful sculptured heads appear in this new book, along with some of the most extraordinary of her illustrations for Hans Christian Andersen's stories, The Nightingale and The Fir Tree, Edward Lear's poem, The Scroobious Pip, and Randall Jarrell's translation of SnowWhite and the Seven Dwarfs by the brothers Grimm.

title: Key Legislative Race in North
description: YORKTOWN GEORGE J. WINTER, a littleknown Conservative councilman from North Salem, in upper Westchester, may be the key to the battle between the Republicans and Democrats for control of the County Board of Legislators.

title: INVESTING
description: That's what the 16thcentury English financier actually wrote, although it has since been corrupted into bad money drives out good money. The observation still holds, and nowhere does the real Gresham's Law apply more exactly than to the coins in your pocket.

title: Maria Del Presto Wed In Chapel of College
description: In the Cole Memorial Chapel at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., yesterday afternoon, Maria Del Presto, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco Robert Del Presto of West Caldwell, N. J., became the bride of Steven Devereux Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Devereux Hill of Marblehead. Mass.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: She was the first overnightcruise paddlewheel steamboat built in the United States in 50 yearsand what a boat. The. Mississippi Queen: longer than a football field, more lavish than a grand hotel, with seven decks and room for 500 passengers. She sailed regally from Cincinnati on July 27, 1976. on her maiden run to New Orleans.

title: IN BRIEF
description: THE LABOR DEPARTMENT certified nearly 5,000 Youngstown, Ohio, steelworkers as eligible for special Federal assistance on the ground that Import competition was an important factor in the elimination of their jobs. The workers will receive retraining and special cash allowances to supplement regular state unemployment benefits Despite a dwindling supply of natural gas, the Federal Energy Administration said home deliveries should be better this winter than last, provided the weather stays normal The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced that, as a result of its Improved financial condition it had won an agreement from its lender banks to eliminate the controversial sixyearold Federal guarantee of its major bank loans. At the Lockheed annual meeting, shareholders were told there was still no immediate hope for resumption of dividends. The shareholders gave standing ovation to the departing Lockheed chairman, Robert W. Haack. As expected, directors elected Roy A. Anderson as the company's next chairman.

title: Wall Street Buzzing as Bookies Are Thrown for a Loss
description: There has been some concern, of late, that the members of the New York Stock Exchange have lost their gambling spirit ;the markets have been that dull recentl. But last week there was a reminder that the chancetaking element still lives. The Big Board announced it had disciplined three men for accepting bets on sports events on the exchan2,e's trading floor.

title: STRIKE BRINGS A CURB ON WATERBORNE MAIL
description: The longshoremen's strike brought containership operations to a halt yesterday at ports on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and precipitated a Postal Service embargo on surface mail to and from Europe, Africa, South America, the Middle East and the Caribbean.

title: Associated Press
description: RECEIVES HONORARY DEGREE: Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy being congratulated by her daughter, Eunice Kennedy Shriver, after Mrs. Kennedy was awarded honorary Doctor of Humane Letters at Georgetown University for work on behalf of mentally retarded. Her son, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, hailed his 87yearold mother as the Rose of all rosesthe Rose of Old Boston.

title: Reality Gripped by Fictions
description: STEVEN MILLHAUSER'S first novel, Edwin Mullhouse: The Life and Death of an American Writer, 19341951, by Jeffrey Cartwright, probably the best Nabokovian novel not written by the master himself. It is in the form of a biography by an 11yearold boy of his friend, a genius, author of a novel called Cartoons, dead a few seconds into his 11th birthday. And there is not a cute word in it. As it turns out, the backandforths through which the biographer invents his author and the author his biographer stir the mind and agitate the emotions as unexpectedly as do the ins and outs through which nature and art invent each other in Nabokovthrough which, for example, the critic Kinbote and the poet John Shade invent each other in Pale Fire. Millhauser's demonstration that the preadolescent imagination is a lost genius within us all provides the Nabokovian note of pathos. That the author's name is so close to his character's (Millhauser/Mullhouse) adds reflections for us to reflect upon. In a note written before a mock suicide, which the biographer turns into a real murder, the young novelist uses a phrase given to him by that same biographer: P.S. Goodbye Life. I aspire to the condition of fiction.

title: Chief Awards
description: floc:line (Henry Stoecker, ludee);1, Marie Annelio's and Barry PearIstein's Gordon setter, Ch. BenWen's Berth, McDee; 2, Mrs. Collier Platt's English cocker spaniel, Ch. Buff Tip of Broomleaf; 3, Mrs, Cheever Porter's Irish setter, Ch. McKendree's Bold Venture; 4, Mrs. Anne E. Snelling's Irish water spaniel, Ch. Oaktree's Irishfocret.

title: Nomina Twining Fay Is Bride
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Nomina Twining Fay was married to Antoine Bertrand Giaume by the Rev. John Andrew. The Rev. Dr. Frederick M. Morris assisted. A reception was held at the Colony Club.

title: A Bank That Gives Equal Credit Where It's Due
description: WEST POINT, Ky.It's still regarded as news across the country when woman's bank (right now, there are about a halfdozen of them) opens. But in this community of 1,800 people, the news is more than three decades old.

title: C.I.A. Says Soviet Steps Up Arms Aid to Third World
description: Soviet deliveries of military supplies to the third world in 1976 were the largest since Moscow replenished the armories of its Arab clients after the Middle East war of 1973, according to a study issued by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Fears Behind Reorganization
description: HARTFORD THOSE, including the State Auditors, who oppose the sweeping reorganization proposed by the Filer Committee were dismissed by many as bureaucrats who felt threatened by change. The branding of the Auditors as defenders of the status quo must dismay agency heads who find us as overly aggressive advocates of change.

title: PRESSURES ON BOARD ARE CITED BY ANKER
description: The Chandellor of New York City Schools, Irving Anker, said yesterday that the Board of Education's demand that he issue a formal announcement of his retirement next June was rooted in the desire of some board members to survive public and political pressures to limit their powers or abolish the board entirely.

title: Foghat Tribute for Sound Archive At Library Is a Roaring Success
description: The Foghat Blues Tribute, a threehour blues extravaganza for the benefit of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Archive of Recorded Sound at the New York Public Library, was a roaring success because it found the right balance between the freewheeling atmosphere that makes for good blues performances and the forethought necessary to stave off anarchy. Conceived by the members of the English rock group Foghat to help the library build and catalogue a permanent blues collection, the tribute was a doubly happy event because it introduced the young audience at the Palladium on Friday to several bluesmen who are better known among musicians than to the general public.

title: SHOP TALK
description: INTHE suburbs, where the golden retriever is king, cat enthusiasts often tend to be a little defensive when their felines are more than mere mouse chasers or dog companions. So when cat fanciers stumble upon the Cat House, located at 40 Boutiques in Stamford's Ridgeway Center, and meet the proprietor, Jean Cantin, they feel they've found a true friend.

title: Emily Kernan, John P. Rafferty To Wed Nov. 26
description: Emily Hadden Kernan, a. development associate at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and John Philip Rafferty, a C.P.A. with Arthur Young & Company, plan to be married Nov. 26.

title: Major League Averages
description: PITCHING 12 at more decisions

title: In Los Angeles, the Dodgers And Phillies Match Power
description: After 2,106 games watched by, a record total of 38.5 million paying customers, major league baseball rings down the curtain today on its regular sixmonth season. And, scarcely pausing for breath, it rings up the curtain Tuesday evening in Los Angeles on its ninth annual round of playoffs to decide who wins the old rose of summer: the pennant.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange;Hedda Gabler. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Oct. 22). $2.90$4.90; students and the elderly, $1.9043.90; group rates. (201) 4297662. Production will move Friday to theater's new home at Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets, Bloomfield.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: OCONOMOWOC, Wis.;On a snowy Sunday morning in 1963, Harold W. Bostrom found himself standing at his front door in his pajamas, listening to the entreaties of a solicitor for the Milwaukee affiliate of the National Planned Parenthood Federation. The woman asked for $5. Mr. Bostrom gave $100.

title: In Summary
description: When the experiment with an allvolunteer military began four years ago, there were fears that the services would have difficulty meeting their recruitment quotas without accepting less qualified, poor and mainly black youths for whom soldiering was the only possible employment. But a private thinktank study commissioned by the Government concluded last week that those fears have proven unfounded.

title: Strike at 2 Wisconsin Papers
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1 (UPI);Five unions at The Wisconsin State Journal and The Madison Capital Times went on strike early today in a contract dispute. Members of the Newspaper Guild failed to show up for work at the Madison Capital Times. Elliott Maraniss, the executive editor, said. The other unions involved are Local 25 of the International Typographical Union, the Pressmen's Union, the International Mailers Union and the Wisconsin State Employees Association.

title: Theater
description: VICTOR GORGE;An evening of comedy and music. With Marylyn Mulvey. 1mPenal, 249 W. 45th St. (CO 524121 Opens Mon.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Ask a bowler why his ball rolled out (lost its hitting power when it reached the pins), and he will probably tell you he dropped the ball.

title: INTERVIEW
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE 200seat theater in the Fine Arts Building of the College of New Rochelle is hardly one of the betterknown playhouses in Westchester. Intimate but flexible, was designed for experimental work and has been used almost exclusively over the years by the drama club at the Roman Catholic school.

title: Duke Defeats Navy, 2816, On 3 Scores by Defense
description: DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 1 (AP);Scores by three defensive players and a 63yard touchdown run by the fullback, Stanley Broadie, sparked Duke to 2816 victory over Navy today.

description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Meet the People: Melba Tolliver, host. Frank Arricale, director of personnel, Board of Educatin; Dr. Jerome Harris., superintentendent of School District 13 in Brooklyn (premiere).

title: West Bank Mayors May Play a Role
description: JERUSALEM ; The prospects for a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East move blurrily in and out of public focus as it they were a camera operated by a myopic amateur with nervous hands. But despite the overall fuzziness, it is clear that the Palestinian ques7 tion remains central not only to getting to Geneva but in any talks held there.

title: Necessity Turned Out to Be Mother of Cooperation
description: WASHINGTONThey don't fight or ignore each other as they once did. Like longseparated, rancorous relatives gathered around a loved one in a hospital emergency room, they are unmistakably cooperative these days.

title: Nureyev as Valentino: I May Be a Huge Flop
description: Throughout the fourmonths shooting of Valentino, the film biography of the silent screen snr, Rudolf Nureyev, who plays the title role, never for a moment forgot that he was a dancer first. Not a day passed that he did not execute a lengthy barren ; usually during lunchbreaks on the London set ; or, when time permitted, attend classes at London's Royal Ballet School.

title: East Berlin Workers Ask Part of Wage in West Marks
description: EAST BERLIN, Oct. 1;A factory team of East Berliners shocked their bosses recently by demanding that part of their salaries be in hard currency;the muchcoveted West German mark.

title: Big Red Battles to End, Then Succumbs, 3014
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 1 (AP)Glen Kehler ran for 159 yards and one touchdown in the rain as Rutgers defeated Cornell, 3014, in a college football game today.

title: GiantsFalcons Statistics
description: PASSING

title: Poems: Parents and Children
description: A number Or poets in the middle generation todaypoets between 30 and 40seem to face a special predicament: they are not at home in recent history. It is not their nightmare (as it is the familiar nightmare of those of us who lived as adults through World War II), it is their parents nightmare. To come of age as.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Copyrint 1977, by the Daily Racing Form, Inc. Saturday, Oct. I. 30th day. Weather cloudy for four races, rainy thereafter; track fast for seven races, sloppy thereafter.

title: Jennifer Richardson Bride of Abbott de Rham
description: In the Rockingham (Vt.) Meeting House yesterday afternoon, Jennifer Page Richardson, daughter of Thomas F. Richardson of West Redding, Cann., and Chester, Vt., and Mrs. de Clairmont Richardson of New York, became the bride of Abbott Bradford de Rham of Manchester, Vt. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David P. de Rham of Farmington, Conn.

title: Bangladesh Says It Has Put Down An Armed Coup
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Sunday, Oct. 2;Junior officers tried to overthrow the military Government during crucial talks for the release of scores of hijack hostages today, but the authorities reported that the uprising had been crushed.

title: In Natural Settings
description: THE Country Tavern and the Land n Lake Inn share something: Both are in idyllic surroundings, a bit off the beaten track, and offer stunning outdoor veranda views of Connecticut's autumn beauty.

title: Oklahoma Beats Kansas On Running of Lott,249
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 1 (UPI);Oklahoma's junior quarterback, Thomas Lott, played without injury for the first time this season and rushed for 102 yards and three touchdowns today as the Sooners earned a 249 Big Eight Conference victory over Kansas.

title: Any Settlement Must Recognize That Oil Is Still a Big Weapon
description: PARIS;As the Carter Administration steps up its quest for a Middle East peace settlement, it must take account of a significant economic development in its diplomatic calculations. This is the danger that the growing dependence of the United States and its allies on the Arab countries for oil, money and trade, could make the West more vulnerable to a new oil embargo or other forme of Arab pressure.

title: Levittown 30 Years Later
description: LEVITTOWN WITH this, the first Levittown, celebrating its 30th anniversary, William J. Levitt is at work on the latest Levittown. But the latest Levittown is being built in Iran and the next one probably will go up in Nigeria or perhaps Venezuela. Despite their success, there will be no more Levittowns in the United States.

title: Country Fairs Try
description: NIKOLA BARICEVIC doesn't own a horse or a plow. His backyard in Mount Sinai isn't large enough to accommodate either. But that isn't stopping Mr. Baricevic from practicingmentally, at leastto take firstplace honors in plowing at next weekends Long Island Fair.

title: Catherine H. Toye Sets Autumn Bridal
description: Catherine Helene Toye and Frank John Suslavich Jr., who expect to graduate next month from the Duke University College of Medicine, will be married Nov. 26.

title: Dance: Variety
description: Saeko Ichinoe is impossible to typecast as a choreographer. She draws upon her traditional Japanese background at times and as quickly selects some aspect of American dance culture to work with. One is never quite sure whether the model will be balletic or modern dance, in as mutt as she has tad some success with each. Friday evening at Marymount Manhattan Theater, she presented five works that were done in the last two years.

title: Kenyan Trying to Put Game to Use as Food
description: ATHI RIVER, Kenya;Dr. David Hopcraft stands in the dust and dry grass of this typical East African plain and admires the first stretches of his homemade chainlink fence that, in a matter of weeks, will run more than 30 miles, enclosing 20,000 acres of rolling grassland dotted with thorn trees and umbrellashaped acacias.

title: Engagements
description: AtkinsRoseberry Mr. and Mrs. Jack V. Roseberry of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. announce the engagement of their daughter, Debra to Bruce L Atkins, son of Mr. & Mrs. Norman J. Atkins of Emerson, N.J.A May 20th wedding is planned.

title: Halpern, Second in Race. Wins Powerboat Title
description: RIO DEL REY, Calif., Oct. 1Joel Halpern of Bronxville, N.Y., finished second in the Marina Del Rey Offshore Powerboat Race today and earned enough points with the finish to win the 1977 national offshore powerboat championship.

title: Ohio State Routs S.M.U., Stealing 7 Passes, 357
description: DALLAS, Oct. 1 (AP)Joel Payton, a freshman fullback, scored twice and Ohio State swiped seven Southern Methodist passes tonight and beat the Mustangs, 357.

title: OpiateLike Substances in Brain May Hold Clue to Pain and Mood
description: The discovery of a surprising similarity between substances produced by the human brain and by the opium poppy has opened up a new realm of body chemistry, offering clues to the nature of pain, pleasure, the emotions and, perhaps, such.

title: Remembering Kent State
description: At Kent State, the issue has been resolved but the protests continue. After months of litigation, construction of a gymnasium annex has begun near the spot where four students were killed by National Guardsmen on May 4, 1970. And last week, thousands of students from dozens of colleges gathered on the campus; a number of them, in masks, ripped down the wire fence around the construction site and threw rocks and bottles at watching policemen. Another mass rally is planned.

title: News Summary
description: The aims of a Mideastpeace conference were outlined in a joint statement by the United States and the Soviet Union. The peace conference, the statement said, should insure the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people and establish normal peaceful relations in the Middle East. The statement released in New York by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and in Moscow by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gro. mvko, was intended to accelerate efforts to convene the Geneva meeting by the end of the year. It was regarded as certain to arouse considerable controversy, particularly in Israel. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Woolfolk's Long Runs Keep Westfield on 15Game Tear
description: Harold Woolfolk rushed for 218 yards and four touchdowns in 15 carries as Westfield stretched its unbeaten streak. to 15 games by defeating Union, 430, in Westfield. Woolfolk now has scored seven touchdowns in Westfield's two victories this season.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Yankees close the regular season with a 2 o'clock game against the Detroit Tigers at Yankee Stadium today. On Wednesday at 3:15 and Thursday night at 8:15 at the Stadium the Yankees play the first two games of the American League championship series against the Kansas City Royals. The winner of the playoff goes on to the World Series, against either the Los Angeles Dodgers or the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: HIRSCN;Donald, M.D. A Memorial Ser. vice will be held al Jewish Community N.Y Soundview Ave., While Plains. N.Y. on Sunday, October 2nd at SPM.
