description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Leslie Gleason Wed to Christopher Frost
description: Leslie Hope Gleason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Carlyle Gleason of Sewickley, Pa., and Rumson, N.J.. was married yesterday afternoon to Christopher Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Frost of Wilton. Conn.

title: Soviet Looks to the Carter and Breihnev Talks
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters);Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko indicated today that Moscow wanted a meeting between President Carter and Leonid I. Brezhnev, but was reluctant to push ahead until major agreements were ready to be signed.

title: Gen. Zia Cancels Vote in Pakistan Set for Oct. 18
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 1;Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq, the head of Pakistan's military Government, tonight canceled the parliamentary election that was to have taken place Oct. 18 and extended martiallaw rule indefinitely.

title: CRIME
description: Here we go again. As suggested last week, terrorists are definitely in with suspense novelists. And so we have THE TRITON ULTIMATUMby Laurence Delaney (Crowell, $8.95) and THE JUDAS. SQUADby James N. Rowe (Little, Brown, $8.95).

title: Dennis James Umbro Weds Maria Angela Gatti in Jersey
description: Maria Angela Gatti, an activity coordinator at the McLean Hospital Children's Center in Belmont, Mass. was married yesterday to Dennis James Umbro, a corrections officer at the Suffolk County House of Correction in Winthrop. Mass.

title: Going On With the Dance
description: WHILE audiences at the 15th New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center are watching James Ivory's movie, Roseland, it will be business pretty much as usual at the reallife setting.

title: L'Ecole Freudienne
description: ABOUT five years before Freud summarized his observations and theories to his Vienna medical colleagues in the series of lectures published as the Introductory Lectures, a Swiss professor in Geneva gave a course of lectures that became the foundation of the science of structural linguistics. By hindsight it seems unfortunate that Freud did not know Ferdinand de Saussure's work, although it is questionable whether his theories would have been seriously affected by it if he had.

title: The Magic Beasts of Stonington
description: AWOMAN named Melisande sits in a manywindowed house and looks out at the sea while she makes up fairy tales. In another room man named Daniel sits at a table and makes large, strange beasts from paper and rubber gloves and hoses and curtains and underwear. Sometimes the beasts go out to play, and people in the town are not astonished when they see a blue satin lobster dancing with a rooster with a giant poisonberry in its beak, or an eggplantbaby conversine with a seahorse.

title: Governor Byrne Is Behind in the Contest With Mr. Bateman
description: The campaign for Governor of New Jersey, now in its last five weeks, finally has produced some heat, and in the process seems to have awakened the state's volatile electorate to the elements of high drama present in this contest:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: VICTOR BORGE ; The unmelancholy Dane returns to Broadway for four weeks of comedy and music, opening tomorrow night at the Imperial.

title: Chicago 7 to Washington
description: John R. Froines, acivil rights and antiwar activist during the sixties who was one of the defendants in the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, has been appointed to the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Mr. Froines, who has a doctorate in chemistry from Yale University, has been serving as Vermont's occupational health director. Mr. Froines was ultimately acquitted of the conspiracy charge, though he did serve two weeks in jail for contempt of court. I haven't changed, said Froines. I'm still working in areas that have social and political implications.

title: HOUSE NEARS VOTE ON REORGANIZATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. IThe House of Representatives is trying to get organized, again. The latest in a series of proposals for change, this time on the administrative and financial affairs of Congress, has passed through the committee stage and should reach the floor within a week or two.

title: Pelham Mapmakers
description: PELHAM SATELLITES may chart remote areas of the earth's surface by means of laser readings and sophisticated computer analyses, but the Sanborn Map Company here takes a downtoearth approach to cartography.

title: CON ED'S FUEL CELL WINS COMMUNITY BOARD 6 VOTE
description: A Consolidated Edison Company plan to build a 4,8megawatt demonstration fuel cell at 15th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive has received the qualified approval of Community Board.

title: Freed Hostages' Son Overjoyed
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP);The son of John Gabriel, a banker from suburban Montebello, who was freed along with his wife by hijackers in Bangladesh late today, said he and his family are relieved and without proper words to e??press our joy that my father and mother have been released.

title: Fudge and Flamenco
description: ICE CREAM is still America's favorite fun food, and a new ice cream parlor at 297 Main Street in Fort Lee has developed a large following. The place is called the HaagenDazs Dessert Shoppe and it is run by Bill Bromley, a Hackensack lawyer, and Steven Eller, the head of a Rockland County janitorial service.

title: Pele's Legacy to His Fans: Nobody Did It Better
description: Pele is to soccer what Shakespeare is to the English language: he puts all together.

description: DINING OUT

title: ART VIEW
description: The name of Henri GaudierBrzeska is far better known to most of us than the small body of work which this unfortunate artist produced in his very short lifetime. The reasons for this are interesting, and have something to tell us about the nature of artistic fame and influence in the early days the modern movement. For as it happens, GaudierBrzeska only now having his first oneman show in New York;more than six decades after his death in World War I. It is currently on view in the new quarters of the Gruenebaum Gallery, East 57th Street, through Oct. 29.

title: WESTCHESTER WEEKLY
description: WESTCHESTER WEEKLY

title: Behind the Best Sellers: J. R. R. Tolkien
description: Here is the word from Middleearth about. 1. R. R. Tolkien (18921973) and The Sdmarillion, its Elves, Dwarves, the Blue Mountains, the Dark Lord and the Hobbits and Fellowship of the Ring. But it is not the last word.

title: 3 Scores by Merklinger Save Seton Hall
description: John Merklinger, a sophomore run ning hack who was pressed into action by an injury to Len Jones. rushed for three secondhalf touchdowns yesterday to rally Seton Hall to a 226 victory over Bergen Catholic at South Orange.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: BRIDGEPORTSculptureby John Matt, paintings and drawings by Thomas Cornell, Installation by Peter Berg. Final week. Carlson Gallery, Bernhard Center, University of Bridgeport. Weekdays II to 5, weekends 1 to 5. Free.

title: Where's That Will to Win?
description: DOES L.I. stand for Loser Island? Last month the Island lost the world capital of racing to New Jersey as Meadowlands outdrew both Belmont Park and Roosevelt Raceway. The month before, we lost the Nets, and we face the possibility of losing the Apples.

title: Businesses Fear Major Problems From Later Age for Retirement
description: The threat of an end to an entrenched custom;mandatory retirement at 65;has left the business community shaken and insisting upon exemption and delay.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sunday, Oct. 2 (AP) The first black ever to campaign seriously for Mayor of New Orleans led a crowded field of candidates yesterday and now heads into a runoff with a white opponent in the race to succeed Mayor Moon Landrieu.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: THE American economy has emerged from its summer slowdown and is gaining momentum as the normally busy final quarter of the year begins. The pattern in various industries or sectors of the economy, however, is quite mixed, and the uncertainties on both the domestic and the international fronts are so large and menacing that doubts have been rising about the vigor and longevity of the domestic business expansion. There is even greater gloom about the foreign economic situation, despite evident progress to some places during the last year.

title: Susan Dorf Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Dorf of Old Tappan, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Patricia Dorf, to Michr.,4 Thomas Kijowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Kijowski of Milltown, N I. Miss Dorf is a serror at Rieer Collere, from which her fianc graduated cum laude. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Berg & Dorf. Mr. Kijowski's father is supervisor of product design for the Carborundum Company in Keasbev. N. J.

title: An Enduring Place for Horses Amid the Urban Welter
description: Twelveyearold Maureen De Franco beamed as she brushed her sorrel pony, Happy, in the back yard of her Staten Island home and said, yes, it was just wonderful own one's own horse.

title: Imagine Strange Events: You'll Find Them Here
description: D ance lofts are spaces where choreography takes place;unofficial choreography, said Michelle Berne, who along with Kevan Cleary, con ceived and organized the first Loft Dance Festival, which began on Friday and will run through Oct. 31 at 18 SoHo performance sites.

title: United Press International
description: FIERY LAVA, SUDDEN HALT: Lava had spewed as high as 400 feet in the air from Hawaii's Kilauea Volcano yesterday came to a sudden halt as it approached evacuated village of Kalapana. Scientists said eruption's end might be near.

title: Associated Press
description: MCRATED PITCHER: Al Oliver, left, of Pirates presenting ball to John Candelaria, pitcher, after last out as the Pirates defeated the Cubs, 31, Friday night at Pittsburgh. The victory was Candelaria's twentieth, making him the Pirates first 20game winner since 1960.

title: Showdown Set As Greenwich Romps by 410
description: Stamford Catholic and Greenwich remained undefeated by posting shutout victories yesterday and set up a big meeting next week for possession of the F.C.I.A.C. Western Division lead.

title: 8 SUITS STILL PENDING IN PARIS PLANE CRASH
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP);More than three years after 346 persons were killed in the crash of a DC10 jetliner near Paris, eight of the more than 200 lawsuits anisinz from the wreck remain unsettled.

title: 411 Proud Birdie Captures Marlboro Cup at Belmont
description: Forego s absence and a dreary rain dampened yesterday's $279,600 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park, but a longshot named Proud Birdie struck parimutuel spark for the cigarette people's promotion by winning the race at odds of 41 to 1.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: IS the generation which closed down the campuses in'the 60's producing an army of literary scholars, of pedants even? Former activists who chanted Off the Pigs in the Vietnam era are joining creative writing courses in which the new status symbol is impeccable syntax. Militants who once occupied libraries are now combing the stacks for the uncut version of Tristan and Yseult to deepen their grasp of Western mythology. And the excesses of sexual liberation are leading former communards to delight in the moral srictures of Mphardson, Fielding and Austen.

title: Junipers Can Adjust to Anything
description: JUNIPERS are among the most versatile plant groups, as anyone who visited the recent Garden Festival at the Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains had an opportunity to see.

title: TOXIC POLLUTANT DECLINES IN LAKE MICHIGAN SALMON
description: LANSING; Mich., Oct. 1 (AP) ; In what may be the start of a new trend, the amount of a toxic pollutant known as PCB found in Lake Michigan coho salmon has decreased for the first time since monitoring of the chemical began in 1972.

title: Youths Stage Protests In Major Italidn Cities Over Death of a Leftist
description: ROME, Oct. 1;Scattered violence erupted in Rome, Turin, Milan, Bologna, Florence and other Italian cities today as many thousands of young leftists took to the streets to protest the slaying yesterday of one of their comrades by members of a neoFascist party in a Rome suburb.

title: Meadowlands
Suffolk Expected to Outgrow Nassau
description: BY 1980, Suffolk County will have passed Nassau, the Bronx and New York County (Manhattan) to become the third most populous county in New York State, according to population trends shown in newly available Census Bureau projections. And this will be true although the county's total population gain between 1970 and 1980 may only be about 250,000, compared with 440,000 between 1960 and 1970.

title: Crown Is Achieved in Clubhouse Amid Delay for Rain
description: The Yankees, who some people thought should have won the American League's Eastern Division championship even before the season started in April, finally won it in October yesterday while they sat in the clubhouse watching television.

title: Michel Revyn to Wed DianeMarie Savoye
description: DianeMarie Savoye, a credit officer with the New York agency for the Bank of Nova Scotia, and Michel Revyn, an engineer with Sidmar, a steel manufacturer in Ghent, Belgium, plan to be married next month.

title: Key Issues in the Dock Dispute
description: The International Longshoremen's Association represents 35,000 dockworkers along ports in the North Atlantic, from Maine to Hampton Roads, Va., and 15,000 dock workers along South Atlantic and Gulf ports. The employers'steamship companies, stevedores and companies that move general cargo over piers and marine terminalsare tokinesented by the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations. The council is composed of port rrrouns from Boston to Hampton Roads.

title: The Now York Ttmesaohn Lou Little, who guided Columbia to a Rose Bowl victory in 1934, getting an ovation from the fans at Baker Field yesterday
description: The Now York Ttmesaohn Lou Little, who guided Columbia to a Rose Bowl victory in 1934, getting an ovation from the fans at Baker Field yesterday

title: FLORA WERNER HARRIS
description: Flora Werner Harris, author of OneBurner Cookery and other books on cooking, died Friday at her home in Sarasota. Fla. She was 80 years old.

title: $1 Million Settlement Reported In Lawsuit Over 72 Pajamas Fire
description: DOVER, N.H., Oct. 1 (AP);The parents of a child who was severely burned when her untreated cotton pajamas caught fire five years ago said yesterday that they had made a $1 million outofcourt settlement in their suit against two companies.

title: Military and Government Workers Receive a 7% Salary Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI);Some 3.4 million military employees and whitecollar Government workers got a 7.05 percent pay increase today under a plan designed to keep Government salaries in line with those in private industry.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Issue Is Types of Shot
description: Waterfowl hunting seasons will begin soon in the Northeast, and the areas in which steel shot, in lieu of conventional lead pellets, must be used have expanded.

title: What Will Hair Say to the 70's?
description: Hair, billed as the tribal loverock musical, opened at the Biltmore Theater in April, 1968. Now, almost 10 years and over $80 million later, Hair is back at the Biltmore. It opens Wednesday night, and most of the people who helped to create the original are involved in the revival.

title: Yachting
description: Etchells22 Class (13 started)1, William Lynn; 2, Robert Carroll; 3, William Biltzer; 4, Robert Shattuck; 5, Robert Hull. Shields Class (4)7, George Jacoona and William Rich; 2, Petrls Skullns; 3, Robert Prosser; 4, Donald Tomlin and Paul Fitzgerald.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: HALF a loaf is better than none, but how about 10 percent? That can be a satisfying slice, too, according to Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., who has been spearheading a complicated fight for still more Federal aid for hardhit, older urban areas such as Newark and Jersey City.

title: U.S. Panel Accused Of Secrecy on Fault Under Nuclear Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1;The Justice Department has charged that highranking officials in the Nuclear Regulatory Commission covered up information ahriut a geologic fault that exists under a nuclear power plant in Virginia about 75 miles south of the capital.

title: Danish Prime Minister Shuffles 3MonthOld Minority Governmenl
description: COPENHAGEN, Oct. 1 (Reuters);Prime Minister Anker Noergensen today shuffled Denmark's eightmonthold Social Democratic minority Government and created an extra ministerial post.

title: How to Remove Burn Marks From Furniture
description: WHEN a careless smoker allows a match or cigarette to fall on a piece of finished furniture, the black, scarred mark that remains is usually quite an eyesore. Fortunately, in many cases, it can be removed successfully by the patient doityourselfer so that the damage is scarcely visible, or at least much less noticeable.

title: OUTLOOK BRIGHTENS FOR NIAGARA FALLS
description: The economic outlook for Niagara Falls, which came close to default last year, brightened last week with the announcement that a large chemicals corporation planned a $275 million expansion program in the area.

title: The Ultimate Collection: a Village
description: EAST HADDAM SOMEpeople collect antiques. Raymond C. and Carole Schmitt have collected an entire antique village. In 1965 the Schmitts bought a 100acre 19thcentury mill town, Johnsonville, Conn., part of East Haddam, from one of the last Johnson descendants.

title: Nepotism Charged At County Colleges
description: PASSAIC THE phenomenal growth of the countycollege system in New Jersey is being threatened by increasing pressure by some Freeholders and college trustees who want to recommend who should be hired, according to administrators of the schools.

title: Greenburgh Agency Defuses Electric Heat
description: IT'S that time of the year when people appreciate being able to turn on a little heat in their homes, and Annie Maple is no exception. When she wants to heat her fivebedroom home at 67 Secor Road, she reaches for switch in the tiny laundry room off her kitchen and turns on the electric radiators.

title: Talk With Rebecca West
description: DAME REBECCA WEST lives in Kensington, in an apartment full of pictures and books; there are geraniums and petunias on her balcony, and the late afternoon sun lights up the tops of the trees that fill the view from her drawingroom windows. It is more than five years since she was the United States; the first time she was in New York was in 1923, when she was 31. It was then the cleanest city she had ever seen: The buildings glittered and the crystals shone. She was lecturing, and overtired, and unhappy for personal reasons, having just broken her 10year relationship with H. G. Wells, but I loved the place. She stayed with Fannie Hurst, who was very good to her, and met Willa Cather, whom she admired enormously: a great slow sort of genius. I wish I had known her better. Fannie Hurst's own writing rather puzzles Dame Rebecca; she feels about her, as she sometimes has felt about other writers, that she never disclosed half her life, that she would have written better had some impediment been lifted away.

title: Solar Heating: From Novelty to Reality
description: HAUPPAUGE WHEN someone phoned Gerald Cain recently to ask if he could bring some people over to Mr. Cain's house, he said, Sure. A short while later, two school buses pulled up in front of his home. and 82 neonle filed out.

title: Sen. Culver Says States Fail To Keep Runaways Out of Jail
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) ; Senate hearings have shown that many states are still locking up runaways and other noncriminal youths with hardened criminals despite a law designed to end the practice. Senator John C. Culver says.

title: All of Europe Will Examine Its French Connections
description: PARIS;The way Prime Minister Raymond Barre put it was there is a new political landscape in France. The breakdown of the alliance of the left has reopened the fundamental questions of French politics, changing the odds and the relations, creating possibilities which haven't existed for a generation, and necessarily provoking a ripple effect bound to be felt throughout Europe.

title: Robert Koppe, Engineer, Marries Eleanor Lewis
description: Eleanor Reed Lewis and Robert H. Kiappe, a nuclear engineer with the S. M. Stoller Corporation in Boulder, Colo., were married yesterday in the Big Moose (N.Y.) Community Chapel. The Rev. Samuel H. Hartman performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Soccer: Mounting Losses Put Nyack Coach at Loss
description: In his 28th year as soccer coach at Nyack in Rockland County, Frank Nelson is encountering a problem and doesn't know the solution.

title: Valfrid J. Palmer, 19, Killed In Traffic Accident in South
description: Valfrid J. Palmer, 19yearold son of Valfrid E. Palmer, formerly general manager of The Daily News and recently named director of operations for the parent Tribune Company in Chicago, was killed Friday in an automobile accident in Raleigh, N. C. Four other students were injured.

title: Suffolk Expected to Be State's 3d Most Populous County by 1980, According to Census Projections
description: WASHINGTON ; Suffolk County will have passed Nassau County, Bronx County and New York County (Manhattan) to become the third most populous county in New York State, according to population trends shown in newly available Census Bureau projections. And this will be true although the county's total population gain between 1970 and 1980 may only be about 250,000, compared with 440.000 between 1960 and 1970.

title: Topics
description: President Carter appears to be ready to propose cutting half the corporate tax deduction allowed for business lunches, and Manhattan restaurateurs are crying foul. So are their expenseaccount clients. Said one, It took me all my life to get into the eating class and now they want to take it away. The Carter proposal would not, in fact, take it away. It would reduce the Federal subsidy for business lunches from about 50 cents for each dollar vent to 25 cents. If employers are willing to pay the remaining 75 cents per dollarand we assume many will ;the business lunch will continue.

title: 1 Slain, 2 Hurt in Chinatown
description: Ayoung man was shot to death and two others were wounded yesterday in aChinatown theater in what the police called a gang incident. Page 43.

title: Nancy Elizabeth Hoy Plates April Wedding With M.D. Sherwood
description: Nancy Elizabeth Hoy Plans April Wedding With M. D. Sherwood

title: CARTER SEEKS BILLION FOR PUBLIC TV, RADIO
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1;In a move to strengthen noncommercial television and radio and to increase domestic program production, President Carter will introduce a bill next week that would authorize more than $1 billion for public broadcasting over a fiveyear period and make drastic organic changes in the system, according to White House sources.

title: Three Novels
description: Jim Mundy, a North Carolina farm boy and child of the Confederacy, is swept away to war at 17. He faces endless horrors in five important Eastern campaigns, survives long hours of bombardment when the earth turns to jelly, becomes familiar with great mounds of severed legs and arms by hospital tents; has old friends killed right and left and his own eye blown out, is taken prisoner and sent to the notorious Federal prison on Johnson Island, escapes to Canada in a coffin on Lake Erie during a cyclone, and is battered for nearly 400 pages of grim, rich detail as the Civil War grinds on with an everdeepening screech to its final and losses.

title: REFERENCE BOOKS
description: HUDDLED over a pile of a dozen volumes of the World Book Encyclopedia, a child scrabbles up a motley mess of facts. In an athletic tumble through the pictured tomes, he learns the height of Everest, the plangent names of the rare earths, the numbers of toes of sloths, the dogmas espoused by the Cathari and Parsees and Mugwumps, the meaning of antidisestablishmentarianism. Nominally grown up now, I retain that juvenile lust for potted knowledge, for the illusion of omniscience that encyclopedias and other reference books excite.

title: Permission Is Denied
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) The Czechoslovak Government has refused permission for the family of Martina Navratilova to come to the United States, the sponsors of a tennis charity said today.

title: Power Plays
description: The Senate's first oldfashioned filibuster in 13 years was being staged last week over a crucial element of the Carter energy package, natural gas pricing, and the days of endless amendments, midnight roll calls and torturous parliamentary maneuvers left the Senators exhausted and shorttempered.

title: Ellen Thalmann Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Thalmann of Suffern, N.Y., have anounced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Anne Thalmann, to Joel Puleo, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Puleo of Buffalo. Miss Thalmann and her fianc are students at the Duke University School of Medicine. The wedding is planned for April.

title: Bayside, Clinton, Jefferson Falter On Road to Gaining Playoffs Again
description: There was a revolt In the Public Schools Athletic League yesterday as three of the four semifinalists from last season's playoffs were overthrown.

title: The 4 Octaves of Phoebe Snow
description: TEANECK PHOEBE SNOW, a young jazzrockfolk singer from this Bergen County town, flared into national prominence three years ago. Audiences and critics alike were caught by the strength of her inventive songs, her ability to slide easily back and forth between different genres and her powerful, fouroctave voice.

title: THE DEFINITION OF PARTRIDGE
description: LANDSCOVE, England. As though created by Dickens, the lanky and aged party who describes himself as Eric Partridge reclines on his venerable bed, wrapped in an old dressing gown, a nightcap perched snugly atop his sparse white hair. Every now and then he pauses to cough, as though punctuating an account he fears may be all wind unless there are bursts of percussion.

title: NO Buf for the Briefalo
description: THEREare at least two distinct types of laughter that the writing of S. J. Perelman produces in the reader, the Honk and the Yurble. Of these, the Honk is the more frequent. It might be the effect of a line of dialogue (He opened a vein in his bath. I never knew baths had veins.) or one of his intricately bizarreopenings (Every so often, when business slackens up in the bowling alley and the other pin boys are hunched over their game of bezique, I like to exchange my sweatshirt for a crisp white surgical tunic, polish up my optical mirror, and examine the corset advertisements in The New York Herald Tribune) or one of his allpurpose endings (We bashed in his conk and left him to the vultures.). The Yurble Is caused by Perelman's linguistic cobbling, as for example when a panoply of porn becomes a pornoply or he asserts I hold no buff for the briefalo or he gathers a cast that includes Gonifson, Hornbostel and Groin, and the atmosphere begins to resemble that of Nighttown with Leopold Bloom cruising through its surreal precincts.

title: Congressional Committees Discuss Conflicting Philosophies
description: WASHINGTONThe technical name for Social Security is Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance. On W2 forms and many paycheck stubs, the money withheld for Social Security taxes is listed under the heading F.I.C.A., for Federal Insurance Contributions Act. But the extent to which Social Security should be considered an insurance sys.1 tern, rather than a form of welfare, is a matter of longstanding debate. It is one of several philosophical questions that bedevil Senators and Representatives every time they try to write a new Social Security law.

title: Sounding a Call for an Ambulance Corps
description: MINEOLA SETIING up a volunteer ambulance corps in a community may seem to be a simple affair. The facts suggest otherwise. It calls for a blend of vision, determination, perseverance and untiring zeal in steering the proposal through a maze of governmental regulations and paperworkas William Morgan, a 21yearold Mineola resident, is finding out. And that's just to get the project going.

title: Archer Ties Course Mark On 63 and Captures Lead
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP);George Archer, undisturbed by a threeputt bogey on the first hole, rallied with 10 birdies and tied the course record with 63 today. That performance gave him a fourstroke lead after three rounds of Napa's $200,000 professional golf tournament.

title: Beginning a series,
description: Its engines whining in the early morning stillness, an overnight jet touches down at Kloten Airport in Zurich, Switzerland. The waiting armored truck pulls up, is loaded, and in brief minutes ten thousand gold coins are on their way to the private safe deposit boxes of Western Europe.

title: Natural Gas Is Out of Reach for Texas Town
description: CRYSTAL CITY, Texas, Oct. 1;Isbel Valdez doesn't know the difference between new gas and old. To her, as to many Americans, interstate and intrastate rates are a mystery and deregulation iust a fivesyllable word.

title: United Pross International
description: At right, Pele being embraced by Cosmos teammate, Carlos Alberto, during emotional moment at Giants Stadium as renowned soccer star played final game. Section 5.

title: Ties to the Land
description: COOPERATIVEExtension is an odd combination of words, but for homeowners, farmers, gardeners, youths and community developers, the words mean professional help. Extension helpers are part nearly every county in the country where the specially trained staff extends their knowledge to solve problems in agriculture, home economics, 4H and community resources.

title: The Case for Preservation
description: NEW HAVEN THE STORY behind the plight in which New Haven's. City Hall now finds itself is long, depressing and highly instructive.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: A Journey to a New Way of Life
description: CAN a group of collegeeducated New Yorkers who gave up city living, quit their jobs and turned their backs on the 9to5 workday world find happiness down on the farm in East Quogue?

title: Overseas Spending
description: The recession (which hit most foreign countries harder than the United States), a cheaper dollar and fears about growing nationalist and socialist sentiment abroad have all taken a toll on American direct investment abroad in recent years. Spending by American companies abroad actually declined percent last year to $26 billion.

title: THE LURE OF SURF FISHING
description: Na bay beach of Nantucket Island there is an isolated spot to which the local fishermen refer ; rarely around strangers but always with deference;as the Bathtub. Most of the beach water tends to be shallow but here the bottom drops off sharply and smoothly. When the tide is running, the pale green current sweeps around the Bathtub, like water around a drain, carrying with it shrimp, crabs, baitfish and sand eels which are doted upon by the star game fish of the midcoastal Atlantic, the striped bass and bluefish. This is not, of course, a continuous engagement. In winter, the majority of these fish migrate to warmer waters. Even in spring, summer and fall, they most often seek their delectables elsewhere. But at certain times. especially in the early fall, when the several elements of wind, water and food supply act in mysterious union, the Bathtub is a very good place to fish.

title: Gordon Burns, Marie F. Kelly Are Married
description: The Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marie Frances Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Kelly of Rye, N.Y.. to Gordon MacKay Burns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Lincoln Burns, also of Rye.

title: Not So Much a Whodunit as a Whydoit
description: LONDON Just 25 years ago an unconsidered trifle by Agatha Christie called The Mousetrap crept into the West End, and the rest, as they say, is history. It has outlived both its author and the professional careers of those critics who slighted it, and no doubt it will still be snaring customers in the year 2002: an indestructible, unstoppable machine, unslakable in its hunger for human flesh and, if ever released by the mad scientists who keep it oiled, all too likely to gobble up the galaxy. Replacements for this scifi behemoth have been tested, but they have all been found wanting. Dame Agatha herself had no other remotely comparable stage success, and those who have tried to clone her novels into dramatic shape have.

title: The Nation
description: During his election campaign, President Carter often derided the nation's maze of tax laws as a disgrace to the human race and more loophole than law. Audiences applauded, but in'the absence of a strong, wellorganized constituency for revision, tax law changes remain politically difficult and particularly vulnerable to specialinterest pressures.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: ON page 38 of Endangered Species, Sandra Hochman uses the phrase a holocaust of laundry. I am so taken with the phrase that 1 would like to use it too: This is a holocaustoflaundry novel. The most common meaning of holocaust is great destruction or disaster: the author's narrator, Kathy Kahn, has brought out all her laundry and turned it into a disaster.

title: Right Nuclear Question, Rash Answer
description: The White House Council on Environmental Quality has made a startling proposal about nuclear power. The threemember panel recommends that, unless the problem of storing nuclear wastes can soon be solved, the Government should stop licensing any more nuclear power plants. That is a radical prescription and it seems to us radically premature. But the council's concern, as articulated by one of its members, A. Gustave Speth, justifiable.

title: Food
description: By far the most talkedabout dish in Manhattan today is a creation of Italian origin that flourishes.in one of the most popular of the city's luxury French restaurants, Le Cirque, at 58 East 65th Street. It is an inspired blend of pasta and crisp, tender vegetables, such as zucchini and mushrooms and broccoli and green beans, plus cheese, cream and toasted pine nuts. These are tossed hot and crowned with a delicate fresh tomato sauce. Although the dish is called spaghetti primavera ; spaghetti with a springtime air;it is served all year long at Le Cirque. It can be reproduced easily in the home.

title: Yesterday's College Football Scoring and Statistics
description: PEN;Guaoet 1 run (cick fairer)

title: Liberation for Men, Too
description: ASMALLgroup of men who formed the nucleus of the men's liberation movement in New Haven seven years ago were, as they said, trying to deal with our wives ;they had all become feminists and we were having serious troubles with our marriages. That is according to Steve Dworkin, a social worker and counselor who teaches a course he originated two years ago called Men's Changing Roles at Southern Connecticut State College in New Haven.

title: A Synagogue Holds Benefit For the Hopis
description: The haunting hollow tone of a wooden flute, played by a halfHopi Indian. filled the sanctuary of Gramercy Park's Brotherhood Synagogue. The man, whose straight black hair was tied with a red sash and whose blue satin tunic was laden with heavy silver necklaces and girded with a belt of silver and turquoise medallions, was playing an ancient Hopi lullaby and love song.

title: Wine
description: This time of year, there are two important crops in the wine world. One, of course, is grapes. The other is students who flock to wineappreciation classes. Harriet Lembeck, who runs one of the best of them in New York, told me the other day that her 15week course was sold out long before the first session last month and that she is already doing a brisk business signing up people for classes starting in February.

title: Mary Freeman, Lawyer, Bride of Mel Z. Tarr
description: Mary Elizabeth Freeman, an associate with the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell, was married yesterday to Mel Zachary Tarr of New York, head of his own public relations company.

title: Time for a Tactical Retreat?
description: It is increasingly unlikely that the current multilateral trade negotiations will result in a significant liberalization of international trade. In the aftermath of the oil price explosion and worldwide recession, protectionism in one form or another has again taken on a degree of political respectability.

title: NUCLEAR EXPERT CRITICAL OF WESTINGHOUSE PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP);An expert for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has questioned the safety of 23 nuclear power plants built by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, but a commission spokesman said that the agency believed they were safe.

title: Lauda Is Only One Point From Formula I Crown
description: There are many courageous men;and now women;in motor racing, but you always have to come back to Niki Lauda, the Austrian. Today he can wrap up his second Formulaone world championship in three. seasons.

title: Regulating Genetic Research
description: HARTFORD EXCEPT for some nagging ethical and political considerations, there may be no limits to the things that can be done for the human condition through recombinant DNA research ; a perplexing new field of scientific inquiry in which the genetic messages that control all life processes are deciphered and put together in different combinations.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: BUFFALO Any city that produced two presidents has some claim to fame. In the case of Buffalo, they were Grover Cleveland and Millard Fillmore, which gives the city a bit of an image problem. Neither had much style. Since last winter's monumental snows, Buffalo's image has suffered further, but this is a city that deserves more than its reputation as the Arctic outpost of New York State. It has one of Frederick Law Olmsted's finest park systems, buildings of national stature by America's three greatest architects, Henry Hobson Richardson, Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright, and broad streets of attractive, substantial houses of the decades from the 1880's to World War I;probably the time when this country produced more good homes than at any period of its histoIt also has some of the country's best endangered landmarks. The Richardson and Sullivan buildings have very uncertain futures.

title: Argentine Navy Reports Seizing Fishing Boats Of Soviet and Bulgaria
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 (Reuters);Argentina seized two Soviet and two Bulgarian trawlers today after the Argentine Navy opened fire on a fleet fishing inside the country's 200mile territorial waters.

title: Design
description: It's called knockdown (or KD) furniture In the trade. Which means that you buy it unassembled in kit form, take home and put it together yourself.

title: Paying the Nuclear PiperIII
description: Known American reserves of uranium, which provides fuel for nuclear power generation, can support 117 nuclear plants of 1,000megawatt capacity each for their useful lifetimes. As of September 1975, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had granted operating licenses, construction permits or limited work authorizations for plants totaling 120,000 megawatts ;or more than known domestic uranium reserves will support, if all those nuclear plants are completed.

title: Manhattanville: The Road Back
description: PURCHASE WHEN Mlnhattarwille College serirated from the Religious of the Sacred Heart in 1966 and became secular', workmen walked through the hallways and ti,,.,zrooms. taking down all the crucifiv.%.

title: Fordham, Led by Davis, Rolls Past Hofstra, 330
description: Fordham University, ranked third among the East's Division III football teams as a result of the first Lambert Bowl voting last week, dominated Hofstra before a crowd of 2,500 at the Rams Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday. When the game was over, the Flyng Dutchmen, eighth in the balloting. had suffered a 330 rout.

title: Roberta Peters, Durable Star
description: WHEN the Metropolitan Opera opens its 93d season a week from tomorrow, it will be the beginning of the 27th consecutive season that Roberta Peters has been with the company. The diva is set to sing in 10 performances as Zerlina in Mozart's Don Giovanni, role that requires arduous preparation.

title: It's a Whole New Ball Game
description: THE surge of interest in soccer, national phenomenon, is having its greatest impact in the suburbs, where thousands of new players and hundreds of new teams are and high school sports programs and creating a shortage of playing fields, coaches and referees.

title: William C. Crooks And Karin Johnson, Lawyers, Are Wed
description: Karin Brinton Johnson and William Clayton Crooks, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Timothy Pickering, the rector.

title: Love! Love! Love! Cries Fele to 75,646 in Farewell
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 1;It was his day, and everyone was properly respectful. When the diplomats and sporting celebrities were introduced, they waved to the crowd and remained silent in deference to his presence; even the unretiring Muhammad All stood mute.

title: WHY WE CAN'T LEAVE KOREA
description: Albert Wohlstetter once remarked that not the least of the tragedies of Vietnam would be the lessons we learned from it. More dryly, historian James C. Thomson made the same point. The only, lesson we should learn from Vietnam, he said, is never again to fight a nationalist movement dominated by Communists in a former French colony. Unfortunately, all the indications are that President Carter's sudden and fateful decision to withdraw the United States Second Infantry Division from South Korea stems from a Vietnam trauma that still has the President and many of his younger aides in its grip.

title: A Lake for All Seasons
description: LIVING by a lake is something never planned or even imagined. When unforeseen events brought me to an apartment overlooking . take Carnegie in Princeton, the presence of water beyond my windows came to me immediately as an unexpected dividend, a gracious largesse. As time flows and the seasons turn, I realize that it is a gift given daily, daily enhancing other aspects of life.

title: PALESTINIANS WEIGH GOVERNMENT IN EXILE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1;Palestinian leaders are considering the feasibility of forming a government in exile as a step to help settle a problem of Palestinian representation at Middle East peace talks, it was reported here today.

title: Temptations Will Go Into Garbage. Truck
description: NORTH OLMSTED, Ohio, Oct. 1 (UPI) ;Members of a Southern Baptist Church have chosen a garbage truck instead of a bonfire to rid themselves of temptation.

title: The New Intimacy Of Solo Jazz
description: Improvising alone on a stage, without supporting players or familiar structural guidelines, is perhaps the most demanding task a jazz musician can undertake. It challenges his stamina, his invention, and the most basic conceptual underpinnings of his artwhy he uses a specific stylistic vocabulary, how he organizes phrases and solos. Ultimately, the soloist must ask himself who he really is, and after he has confronted this question he faces others which may be even thornier. Can an evening of solo music satisfy the musician without taxing the attention span of his audience? Can any musician improvise on a single instrument for more than an hour without both?

title: Teaching Teachers About Sexism
description: SINCE all Long Island school districts receive either Federal or state aid, often both, they are earnestly attempting to cornply with the letter of Federal and state bans on sexual discrimination within school districts. But are they complying with the spirit of the bans? More importantly, do they have the knowledge and personnel to carry out the changes need to comply with the spirit of the bans?

title: Retirement Age of 65 Was Arbitrarily Fixed
description: There never was any scientific reason for picking 65 years as a normal retirement age.

title: ARGENTINE REPORTING GAIN ON GUERRILLAS
description: BL ENOS AIRES, Oct.1;Argentina's security forces say they have killed or jailed SO percent of the leftwing guerrillas engaged in subversive operations since the armed forces took power 18 months ago.

title: Nassau Stage Troupe Perks Up Elderly Who Can't Get to Show
description: It's not easy for actors to perform when there's a pillar in the middle of their stage and when the stage is half the size they are used to. It takes a little extra effort when most of those in the audience are over 80, some cannot hear, some fall asleep and some get up and leave in the middle of the performance. Concentration is difficult when bells ring every 15 minutes and nurses patrol the aisles in swishy plastic aprons.

title: Serious Shortages Forcing Vietnam To Cut Rice Ration
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 1;Vietnam is facing a serious food problem, with a shortage this year estimated by analysts to run to as high as two million tons of rice, or almost 20 percent of the country's normal rice crop.

title: Dr. Richards Beaten
description: PALM HARBOR, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP) Laura DuPont, the United States claycourt champion, defeated Dr. Renee Richards, 76, 61 in the quarterfinals of the $35,000 Florida Federal open tennis tournament last night.

title: Football Scores
File and Forget
description: A television network that pays $4 million for a heavyweight championship fight is understandably eager to please both its sponsors and its viewers. Toward this end, National Broadcasting Company arranged to let viewers read the scorecards of the three officials after each round of Muhammad Ali's seance with Earnie Shavers Thursday night. It seemed mildly promising idea, a small added attraction to brighten the interludes between sales pitches for beer and deodorants. It probably wasn't At least, a sampling of reaction among members of the saloonliving. room bloc indichted that knowing the score diminished their enjoyment of the show instead of heightening it. These comments were typical:

title: Court Awards a Widow in Buffalo $9 Million in an Insurance Case
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1 (UPI) ; In a settlement believed to be the largest levied in New York State against an insurance company, the widow of a Buffaloarea realestate developer has been awarded judgment of more than $9 million as the result of an alleged insurance swindle.

title: Vincent Mulchrone Dies at 58; Longtime British Journalist
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP);Vincent Mulchrone, a longtime British journalist and one of Fleet Street's bestknown writers, died today at the age of 58 after a long illness. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: The QuinnipiacTeheran Connection
description: ALTHOUGH Connecticut is half a world away from Iran, an educator at a small Hamden College has committed himself to helping that ancient Middle Eastern nation develop the resources and train the personnel it needs in health and medical technology.

title: Coast Chinatown Seeks to Still Fears
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 ; Businessmen in Chinatown began this week to try to erase the fears of violence aroused by the Golden Dragon killings by using an ancient dragon that represents harvests, not killings.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE MAY BE PROSECUTED
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 1;The South African Police Commissioner, Gen. Gert L. Prinsloo, strongly hinted today that charges would be brought against some of the police officers who detained and interrogated Stephen Biko, the country's foremost young black leader, before his death in custody Sept. 12.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: Detroit 10, New York 7.

title: COAST SCHOOLS SPLIT ON PROFICIENCY TESTS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 1The complexities of backtobasics, a slogan that has mushroomed into an educational movement, are being illustrated as California school districts struggle to produce staterequired proficiency examinations for high school graduation.

title: Parents of 3 Retarded Girls Fight Hospital Refusal to Sterilize Them
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 1;In a suit that runs counter to the widespread efforts of the public, courts and government in recent years to halt all sterilizations for children and the retarded, the parents of three severely retarded girls are waging a fight here to have the operation performed on their children.

title: IN AMERICA
description: WASHINGTON. In a daydream recently, Senator Robert Dole imagined himself standing before the Republican convention in 1980. The massed delegates were all waving signs and shouting, What about the Panama Canal? The Kansan isn't normally given to visions but this one lodged in his mind. Not long afterward, he asked an assistant to run check with the Library of Congress on the parliamentary tactics that sank the League of Nations treaty.

title: U.S.C. Trounces Wash. State, 417
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP);Charles White and Dwight Fora combined for 246 yards and four touchdowns rushing and Rob Hertel passed for 182 yards last night as the University of Southern California overpowered Washington State, 417, in a Pacific8 Conference game.

title: Deborah Doyle Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Deborah Marie Doyle to Robert Taft Hennes Jr., son of Mrs. John L. Gray of Rye, N. Y., and Mr. Hennes of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew C. Doyle of Rye.

title: A Pleasant Change
description: NEW DELHI;Six years ago, when Kenneth B. Keating was the United States Ambassador in India, he found himself in the position of disagreeing strongly with his Government's support for Pakistan in the war with India. He protested;quietly and to no availthat the decision seriously threatened the relationship between Delhi and Washington. Three years later, Daniel P. Moynihan, Mr. Keating's successor, concluded rather glumly that the relationship between the two countries was in an equilibrium state, a kind of stable perception of one another. The next man in the job, William B. Saxbe happened to have a term as ambassador that almost coincided with Indira Gandhi's rigorous emergency rule, and on Washington's instructions he avoided publicity.

title: Norwich Artists Take to the Streets
description: NORWICH'S Youth Services Bureau was taken aback when its application for a Federal grant for an arts program was not only approved, but the bureau was given more money than it requested.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: BLOOD AND MONEY,by Thomas Thompson. (Dell, $2.50.) The daughter of a Texas oil millionaire dies under mysterious circumstances. The indictment and mistrial of her surgeonhusband\b}b}b}and his execution by a contract killer f011ow. This skillfully reported account of a 1971 cause clbre was a hardcover best seller.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: MOST things in my town run right. Not all, but most. Our colorcoordinated school buses provide terrific service, our tennis courts are fairly flat and welllighted and our new traffic light, although it waits an interminable length of time to change to green, seems to be functioning well.

title: FISHING
description: BLUEFISH and striped bass have rebounded after last week's storm, and New Jersey fishermen can now look forward to some excellent angling, both from the surf and from boats on the inshore grounds.

title: Events Today
description: East Side Festival: antiques, food, entertainment; 9 A.M. to dusk; Third Avenue from 65th Street to 93d Street.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACEJacquesBrel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris. Wednesday Saturday, 8:30 P.M.; next Sunday, 2 P.M. (through Oct. 23). $5.50, except Saturdays, $6.50. Special rates for groups, students and the elderly on Wednesday, Thursday and Sunday. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6281169.

title: British Football Results
description: Arsenal 3, West Ham 0. Aston Villa 0, Birmingham I. Bristol City 2, Queens Park Rangers 2. Chelsea 1, Leeds 2. Coventry 1, West Browfich 2. Derby 4, Middlesbrough 1. Everton 1, Manchester City 1. Ipswich 2, Newcastle 1. Manchester United 2, Liverpool O. Nottingham Forest 1, Norwich 1. Wolverhampton 3, Leicester 0.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A strike deadline against the Long Island Rail Road by 17 unions has been poistponed from midnight today to Oct. V.

title: Trunk, Tail, Feet of the Universe
description: UNTIL THE SUN DIES The Story of Black Holes. By Isaac Asimov. 204 pp. New York: Walker and Co. $8.95.

title: A Philosophic Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate's performance on the energy bill has sounded recently like something out of the theater of the absurd, but the outlook may not be quite as bleak as it appears.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters);The Soviet Union urged China today to abandon what it called its hegemonism and bigpower chauvinism and settle the differences dividing the two countries.

title: In New York, the Yankees And Royals Start Rematch
description: While the Boston Red Sox and Baltimore Orioles were chasing the New York Yankees into October in baseball's last pennant race, one thing was certain in the American League: Whoever won, they would find the Kansas City Royals waiting in strength when the playoff opened.

title: Explosive Patriots in Town For Jets 2d Home Opener
description: Shea Stadium the beleaguered place where December's winds will reach 50 miles an hour, where the Jets want out of, where the United States Olympic Committee did not see fit to play.

title: Those Missing the Boat. Can Catch It in Classes
description: If you had difficulty this summer separating nuns from cans, or were reluctant to cast offfor distant ports because you weren't sure you could find your way back home, boating people say now is th etime to act. They suggest that neophytes take a boating course.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayWestbury K.C. 55th show. Hofstra University campus. Hempstead, L.I.; 2,178 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: What's Doing Around ALBANY
description: IMAGEIn the fall, the Capital District of New York State is at its best. The colors of the changing foliage are vivid and the farm stands in the nearby orchard country are burgeoning with baskets of different varieties of apples. In Albany itself, the streets and restaurants are less crowded because the State Legislature has gone home. The city, which is about 150 miles from Times Square, is too far for a oneday visit but a twoday trip offers opportunities not only for foliagewatching and appleeating but a chance to inspect the governmental center of New York State, the monumental 32 billion Empire State Plaza, known as the Mall, and one of the earliest permanent settlements in World. Albany is the home of many major public institutions that affect the lives of all state citizens: the State Education Department, the State University, the Court of Appeals, the State Library and the State Museum as well as the State Legislature, the state bureaucracy and the Governor. Like most American cities, it also has slums, a decaying center, a downtown parking problem, a flight to the suburbs, shopping strips on the periphery and racial problems. But for visitors Albany and the surrounding area have a peculiar charm because they are treasure houses of varied architectural styles that reflect the history of the nation.

title: Showdown Set As Greenwich Romps by 410
description: Stamford Catholic and Greenwich remained undefeated by posting shutout victories yesterday and set up a big meeting next week for possession of the F.C.I.A.C. Western Division lead.

title: Cornering the Cezannes That Shaped Modern Painting
description: In the fashion of any large and expensive spectacle, the longheralded Cezanne: The Late Work which opens Friday at the Museum of Modern Art presented its producer, William Rubin, with real cliffhanger. After much delay, would the Italian Government committee that must approve the lending of important works even by private citizens grant the loan of a key Cezanne painting requested a year ago from a collection in Milan?

title: Realty News
description: The Mack Construction Corporation of Secaucus, N. J., has bought the Diamond Shamrock Company's property at 350 Mount Kimble Avenue in Morris Township, N. J., for $6 million.

title: Reuters Names New Executive
description: Desmond Maberley, a longtime Reuters newsman and executive, has been named managing editor of the news service's North American operations, it was announced yesterday. A former assistant manager in the North American headquarters in New York City, Mr. Maberley succeeds Mel Beiser, who resigned, the announcement said. Mr. Maberley, w4o joined the Britighbased organization in 1957, held a variety of international editorial and marketing posts before being assigned to New York in 1965. A native of Colchester, England, he lives in New York City with his wife and daughter.

title: Bruins Prevail, 107, on Score in Last Minute
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 1;It took Brown's codefending Ivy League football champions 59 minutes and 8 seconds to overcome Princeton's surprising Tigers today and score the winning touchdown to gain a 107 victory.

title: Robin Lieberman to Wed
description: The engagement of Robin Jill Lieberman to Lieut. R. Gregory Curtis, U.S.A., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Lieberman of Woodbridge, Conn., parents of the future bride. Lieutenant Curtis, who graduated with the class of 77 from the United States Military Academy, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Curtis of Smyrna, Ga. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Owen Gillespie Is Bride Of Terry Leon Provence
description: Owen Gillespie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Gillespie of Essex, Conn., was married there yesterday, in the First Congregational Church to Terry Leon Provence, son of Col. Edward L. Provence, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Provence of Albuquerque, N.M. The Rev. Joshua L. Crowell performed the rerenionv.

title: Six Oriole Homers Eliminate Boston at Fenway, 87; Mets 8, Cards 4 (1st) Cards 4, Mets 2 (2d)
description: BOSTON. Oct. 1 ;The Boston Red Sox, who lived by the homer all season. were critically wounded today by the long ball and were finally ousted from the American League East penriant race when Eddie Murray's ninthinning single enabled the Baltimore Orioles to carve an S7 victory that assured the New York Yankees of their second straight division title.

title: Tracy Austin Beats Riggs
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Oct. 1 (AP);Tracy Austin, the 14yearold Californian, beat Bobby Riggs, 81, today in a tennis exhibition at the Greenbrier resort. Riggs, former Wimbledom and United States champion, is 59.

title: Chutists Win a Place In State's Sports World
description: LAKEWOOD

title: State Eases Law On Sex Education
description: TRENTON UNDER new regulations approved recently by the state's Board of Education, local school districts in New Jersey with can now offer courses dealing human sexuality in optional separate classes for boys and girls without violating the law prohibiting the segregation of students by sex.

title: A Director's Enormous Task
description: THEMPSTEAD THE directorship of a museum used to be a cushy position. All the director was supposed to be was a calm, dignified esthete who knew the history of art, could casually discuss the artistic virtues of Titian or Michelangelo and could occasionally. add significant examples to the museum's collection. He was expected to keep the institution as an esthetic stronghold against the outside world, a place where scholars, connoisseurs and various others of the initiated would come to worship in uninterrupted silence and reverence their favorite canand sculptures of the past.

title: Bishop Supported
description: The Episcopal Church's House of Bishops supported the right of the presiding bishop to retain office though he opposes women as priests. Page 24.

title: More Active Role Urged for Parks
description: FREDERICK LAW OLMSTED, the great landscape architect who conceived and designed New York's Central Park and other famous and spectacular parks, once called the parks the lungs of the city. At one time, the phrase had strict applicability to the parks of the densely populated urban areas where an open expanse of green provided relief from gray stone and black asphalt.

title: POSTMAN MAINTAINS A STANDARD OF GIVING
description: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 1;While widespread attention is focused on the middleclass family that cannot seem to get by on $20,000 or more, a black postal worker here has become a philanthropist on $16.000 a year.

title: RISE IN PRESCRIPTION ADS IS TERMED DISAPPOINTING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI);The nation'r, drugstores are still not doing much advertising of prescription prices, even though the Supreme Court has overturned laws prohibiting such advertisements, a government study says.

title: Lewis C. Perkinson, Former Officer Of American Cyanamid, Dies at 75
description: Lewis C. Perkinson, former financial vice president of the American Cyanamid Company, died on Thursday at St. Mary's Hospital, West Palm Beach, Fla., following a short illness. He was 75.

title: President of Rutgers Looks at the Bright Side
description: ACADEMIC people, college presidents among them, perhaps may be pardoned if they tend to lapse briefly each fall into a mood of euphoria in which nostalgia and anticipation blend. The campus has come to life again, filled with students and the sense of new beginnings.

title: ROBERT C. PAGE, 69, INDUSTRIAL DOCTOR
description: Dr. Robert Collier Page, an authority on industrial medicine and a leading exponent of preventive medicine programs for companies, died Thursday night at his home at Ocho Rios in Jamaica, West Indies. He was 69 years old.

title: ADLAI STEVENSON AND THE WORLD
description: The Life of Adlai Stevenson.

title: Clifton Rolls As Ingram Shows Way
description: Clifton, considered to be one of the strongest teams in New Jersey, cruised to a 306 victory yesterday over Passaic Valley in Little Falls, powered by Jerome Ingram, a senior tailback.

title: Gifts Made By Hand
description: LIKE the aroma of homemade bread, the gift that is handmade or personalized is hard to resist. Not everyone is creative at cui sine or crafts. However, most of us can satisfy our taste for the homespun at various fairs, shows or bazaars.

title: Japan Disappointed Over Its Minor Role in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 1;The Japanese here are observing the 21st anniversary of their country's admission to the United Nations, but they are not celebrating the occasion. In fact, they seem to be pretty alum.

title: Notes: Ulster Seeks a Return of Tourists
description: Is Northern Ireland sale for visitors from North America? A delegation from the Northern Ireland Tourist Board, headed by its chairman, the Lord O'Neill of Shane's Castle, County Antrim, was in New York a week ago to express the conviction that lit is once again safe for Americans to travel to the six counties of Ulster. After announcing plans for a campaign to attract tourists, in which the Republic of Ireland'f. Natitmai T4urist Office and the British Tourist Authority will be joining, the delegation left to spread the word in other cities of the eastern United States.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: When you've seen one Tartuffe, you've seen exactly one Tartuffe; you certainly haven't seen them all. I discovered this at a relatively tender age, having quickly come across variant playings of the famous underthetable scene. A brief rundown, in case it's slipped your memory: the pious fraud, Tartuffe, has been trying and trying to seduce the wife of his benefactor, who simply will not believe the candid report his wife gives him; to prove that what she is saying is so, the lady orders her spouse to crawl beneath the table in the center of the room and wait till Tartuffe approaches her, whereupon he will hear lust rampant, deceit on the march. She does make a provison if matters should threaten to get out of hand, her husband is pop out of his hiding place in time to perserve her virtue. scene for actors and directors to dine upon, obviously.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: During the summer The Times published an article reporting on the youth problem in Pleasantville. Because we are a progressive and sensitive community, we have taken a number of positive steps to remedy a situation, albeit disturbing, not at all unique to Pleasantville. Vandalism, rowdy behavior and drinking in public are countywide, indeed statewide problems, though Pleasantville seems to have by far the best press coverage.

title: Lawyer Weds Sarah K. Ellis
description: Sarah Kane Ellis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Ellis Jr. of Jenkintown, Pa., was married yesterday to Gregory Scott Meredith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester F. Meredith of Shawnee Mission, Kan. The Rev. Arthur B. Jellis performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church of Germantown, in Philadelphia.

title: MARY FORD, 53, DIESSANG WITH LES PAUL
description: Mary Ford, who with her husband, Les Paul, made up one of the most popular musical duos of the 1950's, with such hit songs as How High the Moon and Smoke Rings, died late Friday in Los Angeles from complications of diabetes. She was 53 years old.

title: White Plains Rips Scarsdale, 3822, as Donohue Excels
description: White Plains, pegged as one of the top scholastic powers in the county, opened its football season yesterday with a 3622 victory over Scarsdale. Torn Donohue, a senior quarterback, ran for two touchdowns and passed D yards to Ricky Edwards for a third White Plains score.

title: Giving the Game of Tennis the Old College Try
description: IT WAS while watching Jimmy Connors win his umpteenth tournament on a recent Sunday afternoon that I was suddenly reminded of my own tennisplaying days. Jimmy was backpeddling toward the baseline in anticipation of an overhead slam when his feet went out from under him and he wound up on the seat of his shorts.

title: Cruelty Vs. Compassion Among the Comics
description: Iremember seeing You Bet Your Life the first time it was broadcast in the 1950's. A recent rerun brought that show again to the surface of memory, and with the remit passing of Grtiucl..o Marx, I ruminate over its significance An old man and a young girl were the two contestants. Afier a few moments of dutiful badinage with the sweet young: thing, Groucho lashed out at the old fellow.

title: HannahCronin Plans Wedding on Oct. 29 TO Claude A. Balliet
description: Prof. and Mrs. Grover Jeremiah Cronin Jr. of Pelham, N. Y., have anMemorial Hospitals in New London, and daughter, Hannah Savage Cronin, to Claude Asa Balliet. The wedding is planned for Oct. 29. in Pelham.

title: and Fizzing Over Bayer's Bid for Miles Laboratories
description: By the time the last bell had halted trading for the week on the New York Stock Exchange, some of Wall Street's high rollers;a nervy band of professionals known as arbitrageurs ; had bought up practically every share of Miles Laboratories in sight.

title: COURT EXTENDS RIGHT OF PRESS TO FILMING
description: A Federal court has ruled that under the First Amendment, documentary film makers are entitled to the same protection of their confidential sources of Information as newspaper reporters and other members of the press.

title: WORDS OF THE WORD KING: A PARTRIDGE SAMPLER
description: I think your policemen are wonderful has, by newspapermen, been credibly attributed to celebrities, not unnaturally female, visiting Britain: since the 1930s. From being a visitors clich it rapidly became a British catch phrase, usually jocular and occasionally ironic.

title: E. HOWARD HUNT SUES HIS WATERGATE LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1;E, Howard Hunt Jr. filed a civil suit yesterday against his former attorney, charging him with legal malpractice and asking for $10 million in damages.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market, drawing encouragement from Signs that the economy is improving, rose moderately last week in accelerated trading.

title: CONNECTICUT PANEL ASKS CHANGES IN SENTENCING
description: A Connecticut legislative commission has recommended sweeping changse in the way criminals are punished in the state, including the elimination of parole and a reduction in the discretion that judges may use in imposing sentence.

title: Yesterday's Results in Scholastic Sports
description: Nassau

title: Kelleher Runs Pace Upset by Middletown No
description: Middletown North rallied from a one touchdown deficit to surprise Toms River South, 2114, yesterday in Toms River. Dan Kelleher, who scored early on a 1yard burst, plunged 1 yard in the third period and John Cunningham's placement brought North even at 1414.

title: Dangerous Drugs Found in Dump Sold to Rockland County Youths
description: NEW CM, N.Y.;A large number of prescriptiontype drugs with potentially serious side effects were taken from public dumping site and sold to youths in Rockland County as amphetamines and barbiturates in recent months, according to the county's District Attorney, Kenneth Gribetz.

title: A Classic Start For Musicians
description: ALL RIGHT, who's the next victim? joked a darkhaired bearded man when he opened the heavy door in the cavernous basement of the County Center. Kathleen Wright, 12 years old, of Katonah, picked up her violin'and music and shyly entered the center's music room to audition for place in the Westchester Junior String Orchestra. As soon as she started playing she sounded authoritative and confident.

title: The Now York Timns/Larry Morris
description: HAIL AND FAREWELL: Billy Martin, Yankees manager, celebrating in clubhouse after team clinched American League East title by virtue of Red Sox's loss to Orioles.

title: The Dream House
description: The intractability of the depressionlevel unemployment rates in the black community is emerging as a major cause for concern by the Carter Administration. Although it appears to be an issue with a slow fuse, it could turn explosive overnight, and the President is well advised to address it sooner rather than later.

title: Lawrence Overcomes Grief and Massapequa
description: Tradition, Tevye told us in Fiddler on the Roof, is the key to happiness and success. Two eager young coaches in Nassau County football are singing the sa.ne tune.

title: Old Knicks Show New Tricks in Victory Over Bucks
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1;John Havlicek sat at the press table tonight and watched some old Knicks move in some new directions.

title: Basketball, Drugs and the Black Schoolboy
description: A friend recently sent me Watt Frazier's views on the black athlete, the black child and the media's glamorization of sports. It brought back memories of my boyhood as a black athlete.

title: PAUSE IS RECORDED IN 3YEAR DECLINE OF U.S. GAS OUTPUT
description: The threeyear decline in natural gas production in the United Stares unexpectedly paused during the first six months of this year, according to reliable but still unpublished figures from the Bureau of Mines.

title: A bruzzo: Wild Heart of Italy
description: A hot summer Sunday in Civitella Alfedena, a village high up in the Apennine Mountains in the Abruzzi region of central Italy. In the tiny piazza in front of the Bar del Lupo. some kids are shooting baskets with a soccer ball. The ball takes a weird rebound from the netless rim, heading for high chainlink fence at the edge of the court, but one of the boys makes an unusually fervent hinge and punches the ball back before it goes over. He throws a quick glance behind him as he returns to the game and his friends applause. Beyond the fence, a little way down the hillside. three wolves turn for a moment at the sound, and then return to their business, finishing off the carcass off.

title: Music: Randy Newman Returns With a More Sophisticated Art
description: In most outward respects, the Randy Newman who returned to the New York concert stage after three years absence Friday night at Avery Fisher flail wasn't all that different from the lovable old Randy Newman of yore. He still sang his quirky semibitter ones in his hoarse but affecting buione, accompanying himself on the piano; he still dressed in jeans and a inlaid shirt and made wry remarks bebet ween songs; and he still gave a performance that made him one of the very finest ; if more idiosyncratic ;performers in presentday popular music.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: A consensus seems to be emerging in economic circles that the nation's soaring trade deficit will set a record in the neighborhood of $30 billion this year and that it might be just as wide next year, but opinions diverge on the deficit's impact.

title: McCutcheon Again Takes P.S.A.L. Run
description: Jesse McCutcheon of Martin Luther King High School clearly distinguished himself from the rest of the field yesterday when he raced to victory, for the second straight year in the Public Schools Athletic League group crosscountry run at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Highly Regarded Colorado Puts Army to Rout by 310
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 1;Colorado's wellrounded football squad, coming from its milehigh campus in the foothills of the Rockies, found no difficulty in adapting to the much lower elevations of Army's rainswept plains today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON;H. Johannes Witteveen is a trimwaisted, tapered Dutchman who belongs to a religious sect in Holland devoted to the principle of the brotherhood of man. As managing director of the 131nation International Monetary Fund, formed in the aftermath of World War II, Mr. Witteveen has labored to foster a sense of brotherhood in the realm of international finance.

title: Jean Katherine Cadogan Wed
description: Jean Katherine Cadogan and Alden Rand Gordon, doctoral candidates in art history at Harvard University, were married yesterday in the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford. The service following an order for marriage of the proposed Book of Common Prayer was performed by the Rev. Dr. Alan C. Tull, chaplain at the college, with the Rev. Johl Hurley. a Roman Catholic Driest. ar d Rabbi Bruce Goldman.

title: Prose Is the Leading Lady
description: SUCCESSis wellknown to be a risky business for writers: sometimes the mere fact of social mobility is enough to maroon a talent. In America, of course, acclaimed novelists can repair fortresses girdled by moats and electric fences. In England, they don't have the cash;but they get to know people who do. Fay Weldon's novels have so far moved pretty confidently up the social scale. From the girlstogether scruffiness of The Fat Woman's Joke and Down Among the Women, she has progressed via the TVexecutive and careerperson stratum of Female Friends to the stockbrokers suburbia of Remember Me. In this, her fifth novel, Miss Weldon finally strikes it rich, and is ushered into the presence of her first millionaire.

title: In Summary
description: Nuclear weapons control and human rights have been the main points of friction between the United States and the Soviet Union in recent months, so it was not surprising that Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, addressed both in a speech to the Unit. ed Nations last week. The audience differed over whether the Russian's remarks were more, less or as polemical as usual. Outside the General Assembly, however, there were definite conciliatory signs.

title: J. H. Perkins Weds Elizabeth Robinson
description: Elizabeth Trenchard Robinson and James Flandasyd Perkins were married yesterday in Bethlehem, Pa., in the garden of the home of Mr. and Mrs. Derrick Patrick Moore Robinson, the bride's parents. The Rev. Van Santvoord MerleSmith performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: A Subtreasury of Traditional Wisdom
description: E.F. SCHUMACHER was a Germanborn Britisher who was economics adviser of England's National Coal Board froM 1950 to 1970. Until his death last month he worked as a ruraldevelopment consultant in poor countries. Schumacher achieved sudden fame and became the intellectual champion of many ecology enthusiasts and advocates of simple living a few years back with the publication of Small Is Beautiful. There Schumacher argued eloquently;if somewhat singlemindedly;against the grandiose scale and pretentious complexity of the modern industrial world. In that book, subtitled.

title: Red Cross Meeting in Bucharest To Weigh Organization's Future
description: GENEVA, Oct. 1 (Reuters);The Red Cross will try to prove at its conference in Bucharest next month that it is not dying.

title: In Memoriam
description: LANDAY;Bernice. October 4,1,66. Greatly loved, sadly missed. Joyce, John and Mindy.

title: On the 5:59: A Rump War on Seat Hogs
description: THERE'S a growing menace on our commuter trains, and don't like it one bit. It's creeping squatterism, a trend on the part of otherwise wellbred men and women to turn into Genghis Khans the moment they board a car and seize not just the seat to which their tickets entitle them, but two or three seats, even five. Any evening now I expect to see a blurred figure dash aboard the 5:59 to Harrison, slam the door behind him and capture car.

title: The Region
description: In the increasingly heated regional competition for Federal funds, the Northeast, particularly New York City, won a significant victory last week. Senate and House conferees adopted a formula for allocating housing and community development funds that wouln give the nation's older urban areas more money than they are getting now. For the Northeast, this comes to a 71 percent increase.

title: Major League Scores
description: E;RAndrews, Harris, Almon, Ashford, Winfield, [vie, Thmasson. DP;San Diego 1, San Francisco 1, LOB;San Diego 7, San Francisco 7. 1B;Almon, Thmasson, Ashford, Ivie. HR;Evans (16). SBThmasson, Thomas, SF;Winfield, Harris.

title: U.S. Naval Chief Meets Shah
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct 1 (Reuters);Adm. James L. Holloway, the United States Chief of Naval Operations, met here today with the Shah of Iran. The Iranian Navy chief, Adm. Kamal Mir Habibliahi and the United States Ambassador, William H. Sullivan, also attended the meeting, which a United States Embassy spokesman said was part of a factfinding tour of the area by Admiral Holloway.

title: Alice Einhorn Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harvey P. Einhorn of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Elizabeth Einhorn, to Andrew I. Adler, qon of Majorie Adler of New York and n. Daniel Adler of Westport, Conn.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to close debate On pending proposal to deregulate natural gas, required a threefifths vote of the Senate for passage and passed, 77 to 17, Sept.
