title: Kissinger, Redford In Crowd
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 1;Henry Kissinger was here to root for his favorite defenseman, Cosmo Franz Beckenbauer. Muhammad Ali, wearing black trousers and a tight black shirt, came in an electric golf cart and was walked around the perimeter of The field to a mixed reception of cheers and hoots, which the heavyweight champion appeared to accept with uncharacteristic soberness.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Critics are not exactly normal people. For example, your average music critic has heard more performances of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony than the composer could possibly have envisaged anyone ever hearing. A music critic toddling along to see a new production of The Marriage of Figaro will have literally seen dozens of earlier performances of the opera either;and this depends on the critic obscuring his path, or, more hopefully, illuminating his way. Even in drama, an art that depends less on its classic history than some other performing arts, your average drama critic seeing a new Hamlet, would see it with background of some 20 or so other productions in his past. But with danceah, there the situation is almost grotesque.

title: The Father Of American Musicology
description: To many listeners, and even to some performing musicians, the work of the musical scholar appears arcane, unrelated to the vivid sounds of concert hall and theater. But this irrelevance is only apparent, for is the work of scholars that makes older music available to performers and tells them how it was played and sung when it was new. The enormous expansion of the preBach repertory in the last few decades is a primary case in point;a development that could hardly have come about so fruitfully without the work of Gustave Reese, who died on Sept. 7 at the of 77.

title: Columbia Beats Penn, 42
description: Columbia took first place in the Ivy League soccer race yesterday by defeating Penn, 42, at Baker Field. The unbeaten Lions lifted their league wonlost mark to 20 and their season record to 401 with their first triumph over Penn since 1969.

title: Lakewood Center Caters To Jumpers
description: LAKEWOOD GEORGE SHARPE is 62 years old, runs in the Boston Marathon and dives out of airplanes. His age and his penchant for plunging headfirst from planes at 10,000 and 11,000 feet qualifies him for membership in POPS, an acronym for group of daredevils aged 40 and over that means, with some indulgence for phonetic spelling, Parachutists Over Phorty Society.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Stra n ge how we always return to Mozart. Fashions change, but the little man from Salzburg remains a constant. Even during the last six years, when Pierre Boulez carefully avoided the overworked Beethoven symphonies and concertos, the New York Philharmonic gave us plenty of Mozart;as, indeed, the orchestra is doing this season. The programs are especially strong on the piano concertos. Time was that pianists cattle to the Philharmonic with big, splashy numbers;the Tchaikovsky B flat minor, the Liszt E flat. Today everybody want: to play Mozart, and play Mozart they do, to the delight of everybody.

title: Merchants Demand Aid on Blackout
description: It was a gathering of the hopeful and the aggrieved in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last week as 100 merchants met at a catering hall to demand that the city take action to keep their neighborhood from becoming an economic and social no man's land as result of the devastation of the July 1314 blackout.

title: Israel Reacts to Statement
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Oct. 2;Israels initial reaction early this morning to the SovietAmerican statement about convening a new Middle East peace conference was that it would harden Arab demands and diminish the prospects of talks between the Arabs and the Jews:

title: 6 Killed in 3Car Oklahoma Crash:
description: McALESTER, Okla., Oct. 1 (AP);Four members of a family from Lowell, Ark., and two other persons were killed and seven were injured yesterday in a threecar accident just north of here, the authorities said. Two of the cars collided head on on a steep hill on U.S. Route 69, where the road narrows from four to three lanes, and the third car crashed into the wreckage shortly after 5 P.M., the authorities said.

title: fovce Holzman Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Holzman of Newton Center, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughters Joyce Meryl Hozman, to Neil Steven Lieblich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Lieblich of Lake Success, L.I.

title: Skateboard Titles At Stake at Shore
description: ASBURY PARR HUNDREDS of teenagers will literally go up the wall here today, not in anger over some dressingdown by their parents but because they will be participating in a championship skateboard event at the Casino Arena Skateboard Park.

title: With Jersey's Aid, Tenants Buy Homes In Old City Areas
description: New Jersey's Neighborhood Loan Program, a new state effort to encourage home ownership in the cities, is now six months old, and early processing of the mortgage applications that have been accepted is already presenting an interesting profile of the buyer.

title: Filling the Gaps In a Fall Wardrobe
description: No one in his right mind;and that includes fashion designers;is going to suggest that women throw out their old clothes and start from scratch when a new season rolls around. That sort of thinking was irreparably damaged when women took a good long time getting around to longer skirts after the miniskirt was declared passe at the end of the 1960's.

title: Stumpp's Aerials Lift Patchogue to Victory
description: Al Stumpp passed for two touchdowns and two extra points as he led Patchogue to a 167 victory over Huntington yesterday in AAA2 action.

title: TV VIEW
description: The ingredients have been adjusted, but the general product remains as mediocre;if not as tasteless ;as ever. The new television t;eastai has been delivered to the American consumer with the usual accurnpanirnent of selfserving fanfare. Just about all of the regular weekly series have been unveiled for sarripling, and broadcasting executives, eyes darting nervously at all potential threats, now are huddled in their offices waiting for the almighty ratings. Much has changed, and everything remains the same.

title: Tessie Holladay Duane Wed to Roger Loft
description: Jessie Holladay Duane, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard B. Duane Jr. of New York, was married in Locust, N.J., yesterday to Roger Loft, son of Mrs. Louis Tetunic of New Rochelle, N.Y., and the late Louis Loft. The Rev. F. Reid Isaac 3d, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York, performed the ceremony at the home of Richard Bathe Duane, grandfather of the bride.

title: An Oriental Blessing in Lyndhurst
description: PERHAPS it's the name. Whatever it is, now two states are blessed with restaurants called Hunan Garden. One, down on Mott Street New York City's Chinatown, is an established restaurant, one of the best in that area. The second;no relation and visited several times;is relatively new and is housed in a stonefaced storefront a short turn in from the eastbound Route 3 service road onto Ridge Road.

title: Saving Jobs in Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT THE SITUATION in Bridgeport, the labor union official said, looked grim. But he asked that his name not be used because he did not live or work in Bridgeport and he didn't want to look like an outsider criticizing something that was perhaps unavoidable. He said that under the circumstances he did not see what else the unions could have done.

title: DINING OUT
description: IF you're willing to go to Sergio's and have paglia e fieno, a pasta, as your entree, you may well have a threestar dinner. Still, with melon and prosciutto to start, and a cappuccino to finish, you'll pay about $14 without tax, tip, a drink, or wine. That kind of arithmetic leads us to rate Sergio's with only one star. The restaurant seems too expensive for the results achieved.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Resort Hotel Rates Found Outrageous

title: Sunday Observer
description: It is very hard not to be corrupt. It may even be eccentric. I speak from lifelong experience at avoiding corruption. It has been difficult. It has earned me little but the curious stares of my fellow Americans and the insolence of bureaucrats. Sometimes I wonder if it has been worth it.

title: Eugene Mlhaesco
description: Eugene Mlhaesco

title: Europe for Five: One Month, $5,500
description: I cannot resist a bargain, and the fare was tempting: $329 a person round trip by charter to Zurich for four weeks. Moreover, there would be no hotel expense for one week, since we would stay with a sisterinlaw in Geneva.

title: RED CROSS IS ACTIVE IN SOUTH OF LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 1;A pale blue Peugeot van flying a Red Cross flag moved across the front lines Thursday to test the ceasefire in southern Lebanon; not a shot was fired.

title: Marijo Murphy, Lawyer, Wed to Charles Appel 3d
description: Marijo Murray Murphy, a lawyer, was married yesterday to Charles Francis Appel 3d of Warminster, Pa., owner of a small shopping center there. The Rev. Robert Abamo, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Bondville, Vt.

title: Man in Paris Falls 56 Floors to Death
description: PARIS, Oct. I (AP) A young man today leaped 56 floors to his death from the Montparnasse Tower, Europe's tallest office building. Witnesses said he had climbed over a barrier on an observation terrace. He was not immediately identified. It was the first suicide since the tower opened in 1974.

title: An Old Mystery Captures Author
description: GREENPORT THERE'S a bay that faces Shelter Island at the end of the block 4.Ihere Sandra Scoppettone lives here, in a colonial house with a screenedin front porch and tasteful antique furnishings. But she does not go down there much these days, retiring instead to her own backyard for a dip in the swimming pool she built last spring from the $375,000 sale of paperback rights to her new novel, Some Unknown Person, about the rise and tragic fall of a famous flapper, Starr Faithful!, who was turned into an unwilling party girl by circumstances beyond her control.

title: Gypsy Sizzles In Elmsford
description: ELMSFORD'S An Evening Dinner Theater has welcomed fall with a big fat hit. The show is Gypsy, and to make it into the steamroller the musical can be requires top professional hands working at their ton form. An Evening has them.

title: South Africa's New Interracial Sports Policy: Is It a Fraud?
description: Last November, I had lunch with Tsietsi Mashinini, the then, 19yearold militant black student from South Africa who spearheaded the children's demonstration in Soweto the previous June. I have been trying to help build a tennis complex in Soweto, and Mashinini, in exile in London, politely told me: We [black Smith Africans] don't want tennis courts. We want our land back.

title: Antigua and U.S. Sign New Accord For Military Facilities on Island
description: ST JOHN'S, Antigua, Oct. 1 (Reuters);Antigua and the United States have signed an 11year agreement allowing the Americans to continue using military facilities on the Caribbean island.

title: SELECTION
description: IT all began with a misunderstanding. Swirling was going through the drawers of his wife's desk looking for an airmail envelope when he came across some pages in her handwriting that first aroused his curiosity, and then finally, as their contents dawned on him, struck him forcibly as nothing less than a eulogy, or at least some rough notes for a eulogy, to be delivered over his remains in the foreseeable future. His eyes bulged, and his lips pursed in a low whistle of amazement. There was certainly no mistaking the elegiac note struck by such passages as, We are all on loan to one another, to be foreclosed who knows whenthis short day of frost and sun, as Walter Pater calls our lives  KalamazooIf he suspected how serious his condition was, he never&sparing us that to the verycourage an example to all of us.

title: YONKERS TEACHERS END 4WEEK STRIKE
description: Striking Yonkers public school teachers last night ratified a new contract with the Yonkers Board of Education that gives them wage increases totaling 13.2 percent over two years. Their vote of 938 to 73 ended a bitter fourweek walkout at New York's fourth largest city. The teachers will return to work tomorrow.

title: Births

Named in loving memory of her paternal greatgrandfather, Dr. Abraham Casden. Grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Hopkins and Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Casden. Greatgrandparents are Mrs. Rose Casden and Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Bernstein.

title: State Government Getting a New Look
description: HARTFORD THE FIRST TWO key pieces of the sweeping reorganization of Connecticut's state government fell into place yesterday, at the start of a process that is meant by the first day of 1979 to consolidate the whole cumbersome structure of government into a more responsive, more efficient mold.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HOME CLINIC

title: Bees Are Good Company for Gardeners
description: Late summer and early fall are the seasons of honey, that luscious natural syrup which has inspired so much admiration for the honey bee. Gardeners have another, equally cornyelling reason to appreciate this insect. the h'neybee's industrious lifestyle makes it responsible for pollinating most of our common crops. Cucurbits, squshes, melons, fruit trees and berry bushes are especially dependent upon the honeybee though all flowering crops benefit from its services.

title: Ballet: Swan
description: Can a lake be dusty? Can it crumble rather than ripple? The questions are not rhetorical;although some element of rhetoric probably intrudes;but were in fact prompted by the sight Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House of the American Ballet Theater's production of Swan Lake.. This was the first of four performances of the ballet scheduled to bring down the curtain on Ballet Theater's brief, selfstyled Encore Season, which at times seemed to stress the encores at the expense of the season.

title: Excursions Into History
description: BRIDGEPORT THEsmall brown and gold cat slipped across Brewster Street, paused momentarily to licks its paws and then darted effortlessly behind a fence and out of sight. Here in the quiet Black Rock section of this city, time has behaved in much the same way, silently slipping by, while the residents cherish the area's past.

description: PEKING, Oct. 1 (Reuters)China has stressed that people should be paid ascording to the work they do.

title: Making Peace With the Noise Monster
description: CHANTILLY, Va.The word that most readily comes to mind as one drives into this community in prosperous Fairfax County is bucolic. There are great fields here where corn is grown, meadows where horses and cattle graze, and woods where the maples and elms have just begun to take on their autumnal colors.

title: Indictments Expected in Inquiry By U.S. on Bank Fraud in Jersey
description: A Federal grand jury is expected to 4nd up indictments shortly growing out qt a multistate investigation of suspected bank fraud at the Trust Company of New Jersey, the fourth largest statechartered commercial bank in the state.

title: Massachusetts Wins Meet
description: BOSTON, Oct. 1 ; The University of Massachusetts won a quadrangular crosscountry meet today at Franklin Park, scoring 31 points to 49 for Northeastern, 50 f'r St. John's and 104 for the University of Rhode Island. John Flora of Northeastern won the fivemile race in 23 minutes 55 seconds. Dave Callaghan of St. John's finished third in 24:07.

title: Film Festival: Omar Sketches Striking Picture of Algerian Life
description: Omar Gatlato, an intriguing Algerian film at the New York Film Festival, is billed as a human comedy, and, indeed, its opening recalls Annie Hall, even if the jokes don't entirely translate. A small, vaguely comicallooking man in his late 20's begins speaking directly to the camera, explaining the routine of his daily life and introducing his friends. Every day, he tells us, he must grudgingly stop and talk with the neigborhood butcher so he wont slip me any ewe meat.

title: Lynn Breitmaier Becomes Fiance Of John Peixotto
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gottlob Breitmaier of Huntington Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Rutin Breitmaier, to John H. Peixotto, son of Col. Roland E. Peixotto, U.S.A., and Mrs. Peixotto of Fort Lee. Va.

title: HAS THE MAFIA PENETRATED THE RB.12
description: On the evening of last Feb. 10, Frank (Bomp) Bompensiero, 71, the beefy, baldish consigliere of the Mafia family that covers Southern California, received a phone call at his apartment in the fashionable Pacific Beach section of San Diego. Shortly afterward, he left the apartment and headed toward a public telephone booth, two blocks away, which he was in the habit of using as an office to avoid wiretapi. In his pocket he carried a notebook filled with coded loanshark balance sheets and coded telephone numbers of other public phones across the country through which he spoke regularly with fellow Mafiosi.

title: Kathleen Elizabeth Best Wed, To Daniel Huntington Ginnel
description: The bride is a daughter or mrs. A. Forrest Louks of Bridgeport, Conn. and Robert J. Best of Bedford. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Brown Ginnel of E Mford.

title: A Generous Sampling
description: RARAPHRASING an observation of Proust's, Rebecca West writes in the prologue to Black Lamb and Grey Falcon about the tendency of a banal action to become wonderful if it is performed long enough: a simple walk down hundred yards of village street is wonderful if it made every Sunday by an old lady of eighty. So is with many writers who go on performing after fashion into old age. Too often, a celebration the sort represented by this volume is a patronizing tribute to longevity rather than to the sustained high quality of an author's work. Fortunately, it is impossible to condescend in this way to Rebecca West, who was born in 1892. Whatever the weaknesses of her writing (and there are a number, along with great strengths), banality has never been among them. Nor is there the slightest sign of any diminution of her intellectual and artistic vitality. The hitherto unpublished excerpt included in A Celebration from her novel in progress, This Real Night, seems to me more supple, more intimately at ease with its characters and situation than any of her previous fiction. I shall not be surprised if the completed novel turns out to be her best, surpassing The Fountain Overflows (1956), to which it is a sequel, and The Birds Fall Down (1966), written when she was already in her 70's.

title: 1,439 Terriers in Pennsylvania Show
description: All the best terriers will have their day on Oct. 9 at the Montgomery County Kennel Club's 43d show on the Temple University Music Festival grounds in Ambler, Pa. The recordbreaking entry totals 1,439 representatives of 24 terrier breeds News and varieties from 44 states of and Canada. John T. Marvin of Doylestown, Pa., show Dogs chairman, believes that the 1977 show will feature the greatest number of terriers ever assembled in the world at one gathering.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: WEALTHY people about town facing a large tax bite this year are investing money in books as tax shelters. The traditional tax shelters, of course, are oil wells, cattle farms, motion pictures and the like, but reforms in the Internal Revenue Code last year have made books (also master records and song copyrights) suddenly attractive.

title: Protectionism Plagues FreeTrade Talks
description: GENEVA;The moment of truth is fast approaching for the industrial nations of the world in their efforts to forge a reduction in international trade harriers.

title: Senate Backs Jail In HealthCare Fraud
description: WASLIINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) ; The senate has passed a bill that could mean prison terms of up to five years for doctors and nursing home operators who were convicted of fraud in dealing with Medicare or Medicaid patients.

title: The Personal Touch in Levittown
description: WE just expected this place to be our port in the storm, said Stephen Kalman, sinking into the comfort of his black leather easy chair and gesturing around the living room of his threebedroom Levittown bungalow. We never expected to stay here. In fact, when we first moved in we just rented the place. For us, like lot of other couples, it was just a place to hang hat.

description: As efforts are being made to find adoptive homes for what are termed unadoptable children, state, city and private childcare agencies are finding that black boys over 7 years of age are the most difficult to place.

description: WESTBORO, Mass. ; Edson D. deCastro was restless. So the 29yearold engineer, a systems designer at fastgrowing computer company, gathered together some colleagues and some capital and went into business for himself.

title: The Wild Romance Of Hector Berlioz
description: Hector Berlioz's music stubbornly resists conventional categorization. Probably of all the highRomantic European composers he was the most innovative in matters of form as well as contentvirtually everything he wrote sets its own rules and proportions with only passing references to the classical forms of the preceding generation.

description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 (UPI)The New York Mets shelled the Cards 20game winner, Bob Forsch, for four runs in the first inning in a 64 triumph in the season finale today.

description: PLANT CITY, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP)At least 10 people were killed tonight when an Amtrak passenger train collided with the pickup truck in which they were riding, the authorities said. An ambulance supervisor said that there was a search on for more victims.

title: The Episcopal Strain: 3 Parishes
description: Three Episcopal churches addressed themselves in different ways yesterday to the rising dissension in their denomination, stemming largely from its willingness to ordain women. In West Palm Beach, Fla., a congregation refused to bear Bishop James Duncan, above, beam it voted overwhelmingly to secede from the church. In Plainfield, N.J., the priest of secessionist St. Stephen's Church, forbidden in officiate by court order, stood by the altar while another priest prayed that diocesan bishops might come to their senses about women's ordination. And in Manhattan, the Church of the Ascension celebrated its 150th anniversary with a tacit affirmation that for the future, as Donald R. Goodness, the rector, said, If the church is here, it will be part of the Episcopal Church. Articles on the three parishes appear on Page 61.

Mr. McLauchlan has been known mostly as a solo artist, often with a shifting assortment of sidemen, in the folky singersongwriter vein. Now he is part of a band called the Silver Tractors, and, hence, is presenting his material in a louder, more uptempo context.

title: Red Smith
description: It was Wednesday, Aug. 10, and the outlook wasn't brilliant for the Yankee ten that day. The best team money could buy was feuding and fumbling in third place, five games behind characters who didn't rate a distant nod from Dun & Bradstreet. Then in a rousing defense of the capitalistic system, the Yankees won 38 games while losing 12, clawed to the top of their division and clung there under the severest sort of pressure until last Saturday's rainstorm interrupted the nexttolast game on the schedule. While they watched television and waited for the rain to abate, the Boston Red Sox lost to Baltimore and the race in the American League East died with a whimper. In baseball parlance, this is known as backing into a championship, only in this case it's a halfchampionship. We can crawl in, said Billy Martin, leader of the band, and I'll take it.

title: What Price Progress in the Fields?
description: History has not dealt kindly with the Luddites, the English textile workers who sought to save their jobs 160 years ago by physically destroying new laborsaving machinery. Although they may have been trying to stop the Inevitable, the Luddites had a point in dramatizing the injustice caused by new machinery that ruined the lives of the affected craftsmen. Why was not a portion of the social gain devoted to easing their transition to other jolts?

But that doesn't mean they aren't here or that they aren't being heard from.

Truancy Rate Tied to Welfare Rise
description: The Economic Development Council said yesterday that a 9.9 percent truancy rate among New York City's 1.1 million publicschool students increa unemployment, welfare rolls and possibly, youth crime. Calling truancy one of the major hidden drains on the economic health of the city, the council said it had cost the city $72 million in state aid. Excused absences, the group said, cost the city $92 million additional.

title: 'Julia' Tries to Define Friendship:Jane Fonda Stars With Vanessa Redgrave
description: Friendship is the most difficult of all relationships to define in films that are not caper movies or adventure melodramas, in which action is the emotion, or in romances that lead to sexual fulfillment. Friendship is profound and mysterious. It defies close examination. In a movie, friendship is anticlimactic.This is the principal difficulty that faced Fred Zinnemann, the director, and Alvin Sargent, who wrote the screenplay, when they came to adapt "Julia," one of the stories from Lillian Hellman's best-selling memoir, "Pentimento.""Julia" is Miss Hellman's moving recollection of her childhood friend who was a rebel in the nursery, an angry recorder (with her Brownie) of the peasant's unfortunate lot when she toured Egypt as an adolescent, and a full-fledged anti-Fascist by the time she was a young woman studying medicine in Vienna when Hitler came to power."Pentimento" moves back and forth in time and place as we do in good conversation, without self-consciousness, the main thread (and the real urgency) being the need to get some grip on feeling and, possibly, the truth.Removed from this frame, the story of Julia, a rich young woman with a heedless, title-marrying mother and venal grandparents, becomes an illusive narrative fragment in desperate need of further amplification. Mr. Sargent and Mr. Zinneman have amplified the story with solemn care, in good taste (which is not always desirable), and have come forth with a film that is both well-meaning and on the side of the angels but with the exception of a half-dozen scenes, lifeless."Julia," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 1, tells us both too much and not enough. It opens with the mature Lillian Hellman, played by Jane Fonda, her back to the camera, recollecting her friendship with Julia as a little girl, alternating with later recollections of them both before Julia went off to study at Oxford and then Vienna. When Vanessa Redgrave plays the grown-up Julia to Miss Fonda's grown-up Lillian, in their comparatively few scenes together, the movie begins to build some emotional momentum.But this more or less contemporary story, which has to do with Lillian's attempts to help Julia, the freedom fighter in the late 1930's (and particularly in a good cloak-and-dagger bit when Lillian smuggles $50,000 to Julia in Hitler's Berlin), is constantly interrupted by further flashbacks meant to demonstrate the relationship of the two girls.Only one film maker I know of (Carlos Saura in his recent "Cousin Angelica") has successfully managed to suggest on film the complex bundle of associations that an adult brings to the memories of childhood. Mr. Saura's way was to have the adult actor play those scenes as if he had wandered into a place where everyone else had been frozen in time. The middle-aged Saura character thus played scenes with parents younger than he was.This isn't the only way to handle such a problem, but almost anything might be better than the conventionally styled, soft-focus flashbacks that Mr. Zinnemann and Mr. Sargent employ with child actors who look and behave like numbingly literate, talking dolls, always ready to say or do something that has an immediate, weighty relevance to the present. This sort of thing hasn't much to do with good moviemaking and less to do with childhood.To flesh out the story further, Mr. Sargent has included some sequences dramatizing Miss Hellman's long, tumultuous, sometimes agonizing relationship with Dashiell Hammett, who was her lover, friend and most severe critic. With Jason Robards as Hammett, these scenes are so good and occasionally so tough that one wishes the film were about Hellman and Hammett rather than Lillian and Julia, the meaning of whose friendship mostly escapes the movie.There is a single exception, the meeting between Lillian and Julia in Hitler's Berlin, just after Lillian has successfully brought the $50,000 through Nazi customs to deliver to the now-crippled but still valiant Julia. Miss Fonda and Miss Redgrave are marvelous and true, and even the small echoes of English speech cadences one hears in Miss Fonda's voice are moving, as if she were in some fashion bowing to her English co-star (though Miss Redgrave's Julia is supposed to be an American).There are two other memorable moments. In one Maximilian Schell, as a courier sent by Julia to reach Lillian in Paris, seems actually to have reduced himself in size to play a man of physical frailty and immense courage. The other scene, in which Lillian is having dinner with Sammy (John Glover), a gross, drunken friend from her childhood, does more to suggest the social, economic and emotional backgrounds of Lillian and Julia than all of the flashbacks combined. In addition it's very funny.This may be hair-splitting but I also found the very elegance of the physical productionincluding the well-upholstered period sets and costumes and automobilesto be at war with the film's subject. The movie looks soft, which has nothing to do with the Hellman flintiness, guts, self-mockery, wisdom, above all, impatience with cant. As Julia might have said, "Something else is needed.""Julia," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some violence but young children will probably fall to sleep long before anything untoward is shown on the screen.

title: Fact, Fabrication and DocuDrama

Unless they are aware of more than the TV movie told, the audience can only have concluded that yes, he was guilty, and yes, he was part of a conspiracy that involved President Johnson, the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, antiCastro Cuban exiles, the Mafia and only ABC knows who else.

Mortgage loans closed during the last month totaled $10.7 billion, up 41 percent from August 1976 and 12 percent higher than the July level.

title: The Geneva Express (Via Moscow)
description: The first and most important question about the new SovietAmerican statement on the Middle East is, why? And then, why now? There are other questions too about this brief but tortured piece of prose which seeks to define somethough not allof the issues to be, negotiated within the framework of a Geneva confer. ence. But a formal agreement with Moscow is no mere procedural invitation to a conference. Given the sensitivities in Israel, the passions of Israel s supporters the United States and the importance of Israeli confidence in American backing and guarantees, President Carter must, once again, explain the motives of his diplomacy more effectively than his spokesmen have so far done.

title: 12 Deaths From Legion

Of 2,046 children horn out of wedlock in 1976 to mothers under 18, about 92 percent were nonwhite. Two years ago the illegitimacy rate for all nonwhite children was five out of every 10, and today it is six of 10. Among whites, one out of every 10 children was born illegitimate, up slightly from 1974.

title: Notes on People
description: There'll be consternation in Dogpatch, U. S. A., and points north, east, south and west, when the word gets out that Al Capp, who created the denizens of his L'il Abner comic strip in 1934, is (sob!) retiring and calling quits for the strip. Abner, Daisy Mae, Mammy and Pappy Yokum, Hairless Joe and Lonesome Polecat, Available and Stupefyin Jones and,,all their ilk will cease to live in the funnies Sunday, Nov. 13. At one time they brought mirth to the pages of 900 newspapers, and about 400 still carry the strip, which The Daily News in New York dropped it some months ago. Mr. Capp, who is 68 years old, lives in Cambridge, Mass., and could not be reached yesterday for comment on the demise of L'il Abner. Don Michael, his editor at The Chicago TribuneNew York News Syndicate, said that no attempt would be made to continue the strip with other cartoonists. No one, he said, can replace Al Capp.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LITTLE ENGLAND During World War II, the then British colony of Barbados reportedly sent a communiqu to the mother country telling her not to worry, Little England is behind you. Barbados is a Caribbean nation half the size of New York City and advertises itself as a smile wide.  Attractive beaches attract many visitors. Its 250,000 residents, most of African descent, are among the world's most literate and are regarded by other West Indians, as conservative Anglophiles. wayne Clark, a photographer, was born in Barbados and now lives and works in New York. He returned to Barbados, he said, to capture childhood scenes before the old ways are eclipsed by modern tourism. His pictures are on display at the Fourth Street Photo Gallery in a show called Barbados: Faces and Places.

title: 'Hot Tomorrows' Is Grim Film
description: The best thing about "Hot Tomorrows" is its title, which is so full of promise and urgency but has precious little bearing upon the film at hand. Martin Brest's first feature, which he wrote, produced and directed on a minuscule budget, is a 72-minute black-and-white portrait of a young man who is so artily obsessed with death that he decorates his room with a life-size Grim Reaper.Michael (Ken Lerner), the young man, is not quite as ghoulish as this might lead one to imagine, and so he has friends. His closest buddy, a Bronx alumnus named Louis (Ray Sharkey), joins him for a night-long adventure in Hollywood one Christmas Eve. The two of them travel to the Paradise Ballroom, which is deserted except for a few carefully chosen oddballs, and then they head for a mortuary, where Michael encounters his first corpse. At the club, an eerie-looking combo in heavymakeup is playing "St. James infirmary," and en route to the mortuary Michael and Louis hear traffic-fatality predictions on the radio. Nothing in "Hot Tomorrows" happens without its being more than adequately preordained.After Michael finally experiences the close brush with death toward which the film has been ponderously building, he wanders around dumbstruck, finally arriving at a nursing home, where the sight of a group of elderly women only amplifies his grief and arouses his horror. Michael seems an extraordinarily humorless and self-absorbed soul, and Mr. Brest's direction all too effectively echoes his character's insensitivity.Incidentally, Michael is a writer ("Right now, I'm working on a couple of short stories about my great-aunt and her encounters with death") and a movie buff; one thing that interests him about film is that it offers the opportunity to watch people, like Laurel and Hardy, who are actually dead. "Hot Tomorrows" concludes, in a flash of unexpected originality, with a Bushy Berkeley-styled musical number in which the deceased are reunited with the living.On the same bill at the New York Film Festival, is "My Grandmother," a 1929 Russian film that has only recently been recirculated. The title is a colloquial reference to patronage, and the film is about the foibles of various one-dimensional bureaucrats, including a corrupt, hook-nosed production manager who is dismissed and tries to regain his job through favoritism. A Lenin-like party representative, photographed from the ground up so that he looks 10 feet tall, reprimands this bourgeois nogoodnik at the film's end."My Grandmother" is most interesting as a compendium of every type of trick photography that could be executed at the time it was made, and for the startling.

Public television executives have suddenly seen the operatic light.

Particularly those cooks with a desire to entertain guests. The need is for a dish, subtly seasoned and tempting, that could be made hours or even days in advance, or, for that matter, frozen and defrosted on schedule.

title: Italy's Reigning King of Pasta Cooks, Writes and Eats
description: ALTHOUGH ITALY has not officially been a monarchy since 1946, it does have a reigning King of PastaVincenzo Buonasslsi. One of the country's leading food writers, who also writes about travel, music, opera and television, Mr. Buonassisi has held his title since 1973 when his boo)c, Il Codice della Pasta (The Codification of Pasta), was published by Rizzoli Editore. With its 1,001 recipes for pasta variations, all codified by the food on which the sauce was based (fish, red meat, white meat, dairy products, vegetables, game, etc.), the beautifully illustrated book is a mouthwatering paean to what may well be the worlds most popular food product.

title: JAPANESE PREDICT A SHARP REDUCTION IN STEEL SHIPMENTS
description: Officials of several large Japanese trading companies said yesterday that the Treasury Department's finding of dumping would severely cut imports of steel from Jaiianese producers.

title: Carter's Hometown Plains (Ga.) Food
description: PLAINS, GA.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended Aug. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on The New York Stock Ea change, (A) American Stock Exchango and (0) overthocounter.

title: Connecticut's Bonds Upgraded by Moody's
description: Moody's Investors Service disclosed yesterday that it had raised its rating of Connecticut's bonds to Aa from A1 because, it said, the state's finances had shown steady improvement.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Anthony Carminati, indicted in 1975 after an 11month police infiltration into organized crime, pleaded guilty in loansharking and to four counts of conspiracy, including three counts involving separate plots to bribe an undercover police lieutenant.

title: Stein and Wagner Trade Charges On Wagner's G Endorsement
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein and Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. exchanged charges and countercharges yesterday over the manner in which Mr. Wagner, a Democrat who narrowly lost the Democratic primary to Mr. Stein last September was endorsed by the Republican Party.

title: Parr Meadows Outlook Is Bleak; Board to Vote on License Today
description: An official of the State Racing and Wagering Board said yesterday he considered it unlikely that Parr Meadows would be able to retain its quarterhorse racing license for the balance of the year because of the Long Island track's financial d'fficulties.

title: Sunny Opener Forecast
description: Sunny and mild weather, with temperatures in the 70's was forecast for today's opening game of the American League playoffs between the Yankees and Kansas City Royals. The weatherman said there was virtually no chance of rain.

title: Article 5    No Title
50 of 60 Reporters on Post Protest Slanted
description: Fifty of the approximately 60 reporters who work for The New York Post have petitioned its publisher, Rupert Murdoch, expressing what one of them described yesterday as disquiet over slanted news coverage during the political campaign.

title: Tokyo Hit by 3 Light Quakes
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4 (AP)Three earthquakes struck Tokyo and the surrounding area within an hour early today, the Meteorological Agency said. The police said three persons had been injured slightly when they were hit by falling advertising signsin downtown Tokyo. Japan National Railways said some trains had stopped running briefly.

title: ABC Acquires 3 Publications
description: The American Broadcasting Companies Inc. has acquired three publishing properties from the CHC Corporation for about $10.1 million. They are Los Angeles an& the American West magazines and National Insurance Law Service, a publication of insurance codes and regulations. The company said they would be excellent addition to our roster of publishing activities.

title: Some in Albany Wonder if Carey Is Minding Store
description: In the redleatherette surroundings of a hotel meeting room in Buffalo last week, Goiernor Carey found himself under verbal siege by a group of labor leadersangry about unemployment. If you give us work, one of them shouted at him. we'll keen you in Albany forever.

title: A Remembrance of Hot Dogs Past
description: There have been more scholarly treatises on the hot dog than this, I'm certain. Reports on its evolution and its composition are many, and so are scary accounts of the dyes and chemicals that are used these days to color, flavor and preserve them. Debates have raged hotly over the relative merits of hot dogs containing pork, those that are all beef and those new sort which are made ofHeaven forbid!chicken.

title: Technology
description: The market for highfidelity audio cassettes is in technological turmoil. In the last two years, the original highperformance tapes that helped make cassette recorders serious equipment among audiophiles have lost a lot of ground to a newer strain of tapes that cost more but may not necessarily give better performance. Now, manufacturers of the original tapes are countering with some innovations of their own.

title: Son of Late Governor Is Arrested In Stabbing of Denver Councilman
description: DENVER, Oct. 4 (AP)A city councilman was stabbed in the stomach and chest early today outside an apartment building, and the police later arrested the son of a late Colorado Governor in the case.

title: Stopping APlants
description: SEABROOK, N. H.In August, the 32d anniversary of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings was marked by rallies, film showings and civildisobedience actions at more than 100 nuclearpowerplant construction sites across the country. The protests involved 150 arrests and came in the wake of the April 30 mass occupation of the site of the proposed nuclear plant Here, when more than 2,000 people marched into the construction area and sat down. More of the same is coming at other sites this fall.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Election Commission Sues N.E.A. Over Collection of Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)  The Federal Election Commission has sued the National Education Association in an attempt to stop the teachers group from continuing a system of collecting political contributions trom members.

title: Tropical Wave Moves West
description: MIAMI, Oct. 4 (UPI)A tropical wave i caused heavy showers today in the northern Windward and Leeward Islands as moved over the Lesser Antilles into the eastern Caribbean Sea. The National Hurricane Center here said that the wave I was moving west at 10 to 15 miles an hour and showed no signs of strengthening. A depression in the central Atlantic about 1,200 miles eastsoutheast of Bermura also had shown little change since yesterday forecaster said.

title: Save a Genuinely Select Committee
description: In the euphemistic world of the United States Senate, select, as applied to a committee, does not mean that it is preferred, only that it is temporary. Thus, the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs is temporary. For eight years it has led in the war against hunger among the nation's young, old and poor. Now it is also embarked on a campaign that addresses the dietas well as the guiltof wellfed America. It has earned the right to be regarded as select in the more general sense. Nonetheless, unless the Senate acts promptly, this committee will have to go out of business at the end of the year. If it does, both those who have too little to eat and those who eat too much will be the losers.

title: An Eclectic Crowd Applauds Gres Show
description: Thirteen years ago when the first Gres collection was shown in New York as a benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, most of the women in the audience wore Chanel suits. Yesterday, the view from the stage was far more eclectic. There were stoles, peasant outfits, challis prints and the blouses with tiny ruffles at the wrists and neck, all signatures of the current season.

title: Chinese Minister, in Canada, Says MoscowWashingtonDetenteaSha me
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 4 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China told Canadian officials today that dtente and moves toward disarmament were shams engineered by the United States and the Soviet Union, sources close to the talks said.

title: Bateman Would Scrap Plans to Extend PATH Line
description: TRENTON, Oct. 4State Senator Raymond H. Bateman said today that if elected Governor he would scrap plans to extend the PATH commuter line to Plainfield and use the money to upgrade the Jersey Central Railroad and undertake other mass transit projects.

title: Mrs. Carter Entertains the U.N. Family
description: While her husband discussed state affairs here yesterday, Rosalynn Carter threw a, little party. She entertained about 200 womenand one manfrom the United Nations family at a moving buffet luncheon in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Measuring Helsinki at Belgrade
description: A steady stream of reports will reach us over the next few months from the Review Conference on the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which opened yesterday in Belgrade. The purpose of Belgrade is to assess Helsinki, where the original conference culminated on Aug. 1, 1975, in a set of accords then only dimly understood. With the hindsight gained over the past two years we can digest the coming reportsthough not the title of the conferenceif two things are kept in mind.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Deaths
description: AARTSJohn. The Board of Gover nors and members of Alpine Country Club sorrowfully note the passing of Mr. John Aarts, father of Jerry Awls, our club manager. Jerome Strauss, President

title: Gullett and Splittorff Opposing Pitchers
description: The Yankees must be serious about the American League pennant playoffs they start against the Kansas City Royals today: Reggie Jackson returned to the field at, Yankee Stadium after the team workout and meeting yesterday and took extra outfield practice.

title: Child's World
description: Thrift Shopping

title: Money
description: Tuesday, October 4. 1977

title: PETER SPRAGUE
description: Peter Sprague, a partner in the New York City law firm of Sprague and Sprague, died Sunday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 65 years old and lived at.15111 85th Avenue in Briarwood, Queens.

title: U.S. NAMES 12 CITIES IN JERSEY IN JOB BIAS
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4The Federal Government charged today that the New Jersey Civil Service Commission and 12 major cities in the state discriminate against blacks and Hispanic people in hiring and promoting firefighters.

title: SENATE, 5046, VOTES TO DEREGULATE GAS; CARTER ASSAILS STEP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4After more than two weeks of delay and debate, the Senate approved a controversial proposal today that would free newly discovered natural gas from price controls.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Carter Is Said to Offer Livingston L. Biddle Jr. Arts Endowment Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4President Carter has offered the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Arts to Livingston L. Bo'cldle Jr., staff director of the Senate's subcommittee on education, arts and humanities, administration officials reported today. It is expected that there will be a formal White House announcement as soon as the necessary backaround checks have been ccmpleted.

title: Jacoby Helps To Build Up East Tennis
description: The Eastern tournament season now hardly pauses throughout the year, thanks to such ambitious, energetic young promoters as Alan Jacoby. In two years he has established his prizemoney Bancroft series for men and women with such expertise that people are predicting he'll be running the United States Open some day.

title: Gunmen Rob Campus Bookstore At Stony Brook and Take $15,000
description: STONY BROOK, LI , Oct. 4The bookstore of the State University at Stony Brook was held up at gunpoint last night, and three robbers made off with $15,000 in cash. It was the fourth armed robbery at the university in six monthsrobberies that have caused total losses of more than $31,000.

title: About Education
description: The University of California, already one of the nation's most selective public institutions of higher education, is proposing to become even more difficult to enter.

title: Careers
description: What is the best United States city to live and work in? Is Boston an attractive place in which to live? Will New York cost too much? What about Seattle's cultural opportunities? How strong is the MinneapolisSt. Paul public school system?

title: Mormons Fear Leader of Polygamous Sect Will Revive Hostility Against Their Church
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 4As 10,000 Mormons poured into this clean mountain city over the weekend to celebrate their faith at the church's 147th semiannual general conference; much of the private conversation revolved around a violent offshoot of a longoutlawed Mormon practice, polygamy.

title: PANEL VOTES TO RAISE SOCIAL SECURITY TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The House Ways and Means Committee voted today for increases in Social Security_ taxes in the next several years that would fall primarily on people earning more than, $16.500 a year.

title: Food Conference Opens
description: CHICAGO

title: Carter Signs $69.3 Billion Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)The White House announced today that President Carter had signed a bill providing $69.3 billion for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Veterans Administration, the National Aeronautics and Space Administraton, the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Science Foundation, the Treasury Department's Office of Revenue Sharing and several other small agencies.

title: Traffic Agents Return to Duty To Ease TieUps
description: Twentyfour traffic control agents have been assigned to expedite the flow of vehicles in the Queensboro Bridge area as the first step of a new cleanair plan for Manhattan, Alexander J. Mautner, the City Transportation Commissioner, announced yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: A declarer who is trying to complete a mental picture of an opponent's distribution can often succeed by reviewing the actions of that player in the bidding and play. With certain distributions, he would perhaps have bid differently or played differently.

title: About Real Estate
description: The expectation in housing circles is that when President Carter enunciates an urban policy, the emphasis will be on jobs and the need for economic development. Housing will take a back seat. But when he does speak of shelter, he will probably put the emphasis on neighborhood stabilization and rehabilitation rather than rozw construction.

title: John Jardine Dies in Auto Plunge; Was Retired From Canadian Press
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 4 (AP)John Jardine, who recently retired as day traffic chief in the Vancouver bureau of the Canadian Press, died last night when his car left the road and plunged into the Fraser River. He was 65 years old

title: BREZHNEV COUNTERS WEST ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 4Leonid I. Brezhnev said today that the Western press and prominent leaders of the capitalist world were using the humanrights issue in an ideological crusade to sow distrust and hostility toward the Communist countries.

title: CARTER SAYS THE U.S. IS WILLING TO SLASH ATOMIC ARSENAL 50%
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4President Carter, calling on all governments to share in curbing the arms race, told the General Assembly today that the United States was willing now to cut its own arsenal of nuclear weapons by as much as 50 percent if the Soviet Union would do the same.

title: Dollar Rallies, Except Against Yen
description: The dollar rallied against most major world currencies in active trading yesterday, partly recovering from its steep losses Monday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Labor Leaders in France Relieved at Breakup of Leftist Alliance
description: THIONVILLE, France, Sept. 30Serge Valli, a Communist labor leader in this economically depressed steel town in Lorraine, says he has a recurring nightmare.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 5, 1977

title: Best Buys
description: ACUP OF COFFEE might be an appropriate toast this week, following a report by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs of the second decline in two weeks of the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City.

title: Digital Resources Gets Contract For Computer Units From China
description: The Digital Resources Corporation, Texas subsidiary of the Applied Devices Corporation, has received a $3.7 million contract from China for four seismic datakrocessing computer systems.

title: Market Place
description: Gold stocks, the market's standout group in inflationrampant 197374 when the sky was falling for most other issues, have regained some of their lost luster.

title: BROWN SAYS SOVIET CAN FELL SATELLITES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 4Defense Secretary Harold Brown disclosed today that the Soviet Union had developed the operational capability to destroy some American satellites in space.

title: Article 3  No Title
JOHN LEWIS CRADDOCK
description: John Lewis Craddock, a former copy editor at The New York Times who also worked for other publications, died on Sept. 24 at his home in Tryon, N.C., after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Topics
description: An increasingly popular advertising technique these days is to make invidious comparisons between one brand and another, naming names instead of resorting to evasions like Brand X. The trendin ads for automobiles, cigarettes, drugshas brought on attacks of nerves in the business community, where it is feared that outright criticism by competitors may breed suspicion among consumers.

title: Cosmos
description: The European tour that the Cosmos had been planning for some time and that was supposed to start next week has fallen through, and the Peleless Cosmos maintain it was their decision.

title: Britain Reports a Heavy Inflow Of Reserves During September
description: LONDON, Oct. 4Another $2.32 billion poured into Britain's foreignexchange coffers last month an inflow so great that it may foice the Government to take steps to choke it off.

title: Futures in Silver Continue Upturn
description: Silver futures prices rose yesterday, continuing a recent upturn that reflected in part the weakness of the United States dollar abroad and the nation's recent poor trade balance figures.

title: Koch Mideast Protest Draws Carter Snub
description: Annoyed at Representative Edward. I. Koch's plan to hand him a letter challenging the Administration's stand on the proposed Middle East peace talks, President Carter delivered a series of snubs to Mr. Koch yesterday during the President's visit to speak at the United Nations.

title: P.BA ASKS UNIFORMS FOR ANTICRIME UNIT
description: The president of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday called on Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd to return to uniform all 4Q0 plainclothes anticrime officers until guidelines could be set to protect them against what he termed false accusations.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, OCTOBER 4, 1977

title: Parties: Apple Jack and Musical Chairs
description: The Big Apple has, on occasion, been baked, sliced, fried, and even stewed in its own juice, but, nevertheless, it's all ours and therefore the best. So it goes almost without saying that Bonwit Teller's benefit for The Association for a Better New York was a sure thing. Maybe not a billioudollar sure thing, but a 400peopletimes$50 sure thing, because that's how many people bought tickets and that's what the tickets cost.

title: SHIPPING COMPANIES CALLED TO MEETING
description: Major steamship companies and shipping associations affected by the fourdayold longshoremen's strike have been asked to meet in Washington tomorrow with the Government's chief mediator, Wayne L. Horvitz.

title: JAVITS SAYS U.S. APPEARS TO TILT TOWARD THE P.L.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Senator Jacob K. Javits accused the Carter Administration today of appearing to tilt toward the Palestinian Liberation Organization in itsjoint statement with the Soviet Union on the Middle East.

title: Wells Fargo Bank Raises Prime Rate From 71/4 to 71/2%
description: The Wells Fargo Bank, the third largest bank in California and the 11th largest in the nation, yesterday raised its prime lending rate to 71/2 percent from 7% percent.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AT A LITERARY cocktail party not long ago, William Rossa Cole asked a young novelist editor about her 11yearold boy. He's home, she replied, selfsitting.

title: Open Marriage Isn't a Closed Book
description: SHORTLY after Nena and George O'Neill wrote a controversial best seller called Open Marriage, they became an item in the gossip columns. Is it true, the gossips asked, that Mr. and Mrs. Open Marriage are divorcing?

title: The Labor Scene
description: The State Department is trying to delay for a year America's withdrawal from the International Labor Organization. Page D7.

title: A Drive to Keep U.S. in I.L.O. Until 1978
description: Armed with pledges of support for United States objectives from 30 foreign governments, including the nine member nations of the European Economic Community, the State Department is lobbying hard to delay for a

title: Democrats Warn Curb on Debate May Hurt Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4  Defeated Democrats predicted today that the tactics used yesterday to break the filibuster against deregulation of national gas prices would hurt both the Carter Administration and the Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia.

title: Around the Nation
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 4 (UPI)The machinists at the Boeing Co. yesterday called their first strike in 12 years against the company, and picketing began early this morning after a breakdown in negotiations.

title: DAILY FAT AND CHOLESTEROL FOOD SCORE
description: How to use this chart: For each portion of fatcontaining foods consumed during a day, record the appropriate score. The goal is to keep your daily total score to 10 or less.

title: Zuckerman Wins at Chess
description: MENTOR, Ohio, Oct. 4 (AP)  International Master Bernard Zuckerman of Brooklyn upset Grandmaster Leonid Shamkovich of the Soviet Union yesterday in the sixth round of the United States Chess Championship. That gave Zuckerman 3 points, with one adjourned game. The defending champion, Walter 3rownc of Berkeley, Calif., has 31/2 points and two adjourned games.

title: $25 Top for The Act
description: THE ACT, the new musical starring Liza Minnelli, will have a boxoffice top of $25, the highest price yet charged for a Broadway legitimate show during its regular run. The musical, a Shubert Organization presentation of a Cy Feuer and Ernest H. Martin production, is scheduled to open at the Majestic Theater on Oct. 29, following its current engagement in Los Angeles.

title: Carter ,Dayan Reach Agreement On Procedures for Geneva Talks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Wednesday, Oct. 5Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan said early this morning after more than six hours of talks, that he had reached agreement with Pregident Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on working paper outlining procedures to govern a new Middle East peace conference in Geneva.

title: Ophthalmologists Pick Jersey Man
description: DALLAS, Oct. 4 (AP)Dr. Alfonse R. Cinotti of Jersey City was elected today to the presidency of the American Association of Ophthalmology for 1978. The organization, holding its annual convention here, represents many of the nation's eye physicians and surgeons. Col. Bud Appleton of Washington's Walter Reed Army Medical Center was elected treasurer and Dr. Lawrence A. Winograd of Denver was elected secretary.

title: Bronx Mental Unit Called Insensitive At Senate Hearing
description: A woman whose son committed suicide in July after he was released from the Bronx Psychiatric Center accused officials of the state institution yesterday of insensitivity at a public hearing there by the State Senate Mental Hygiene and Addiction Committee.

title: Advertising
description: The Simmons Company, the Atlanta mattress maker, is reviewing its agency relationships, has already decided to leave Young & Rubicam and may split with the J. Walter Thompson Company. Simmons spent about $3 million in media advertising last year.

title: Young Winners to Face Each Other on Nov. 8
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 4Ralph J. Perk, who has been this city's Mayor since November 1971, was defeated tonight in his effort to win a fourth twoyeai term.

title: People in Sports
description: Rollie Fingers of the San Diego Padres received a sterling silver fireman's cap before the opener of the National League championship series in Los Angeles last night as winner of the league's lopreliever competition for 1977: The 31yearold righthander's 35 saves were the most in the major leagues since John Hiller's 38 for Detroit in 1973.

title: 12 Jersey Cities Accused Of Racial Discriminatimi In Fire Department Jobs
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4The Federal Govern ment charged today that the New Jersey Civil Service Commission and 12 major cities in the state discriminated againg blacks and Hispanic people in hiring and promoting firemen.

title: Philippine Volcano Isle Evacuated
description: MANILA, Oct. 4 (Reuters)Residents of Taal Island, just south of Manila, were ordered to evacuate their homes becauss of volcanic eruptions, a Philippine Volca'. co Commission spokesman said today. The Taal volcano, in the middle of a lake about 63 miles south of here, began shooting ashladen clouds into the sky yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today
Open Interest
description: Tuesday. Oct 4, 1977

title: Mitchell, Haldeman, Ehrlichman Win Reductions in Prison Terms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Federal District Judge John ,,, J. Sirica sharply reduced the prison sentences of three principal figures in the Watergate case today after all confessed in tape recorded statements that they were guilty of wrongdoing and said they were sorry for what they had done.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Freed From Custody; Court Calls Corruption Case Weak
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 4Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was released from police custody this morning, less than 24 hours after her arrest on two char; es of official corruption.

title: Drug Ring in Jail in Queens Alleged
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens announced yesterday that his office had uncovered a highly organized narcotics ring at the Queens House of Detention in Kew Gardens. Seven persons, including a corrections officer and five inmates were arrested.

title: CAMBODIAN OFFERS EVACUATION MOTIVE
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 4Cambodia's Communist rulers ordered the evacuation of the country's cities at the end of the War there in 1975 to break up what they believed were enemy spy organizations, according to Cambodia's newly identified leader.

title: Yen Continues Its Advance
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4The yen continued to climb today against the dollar, which remained under heavy speculative selling.

title: Car Sales Off 6.7% As September Ends
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4Newcar sales by the domestic manufacturers slumped 6.7 .percent during the final selling period of September below the same period a year ago, as dealers continued clearing their lots of 1977 models.

title: Burton.In Trouble All My Life
description: IT WAS LATE AFTERNOON, and the shoppers were beginning to straggle in. In twos and threes they strolled through the lobby of the small, elegant midtown hotel, walking into the bar and sitting down to order. Then they began to stare, or giggle. Do doubletakes. Poke one another in the ribs. And point, to a table in a corner. There sat Richard Burton, looking debonair and sipping tea.

title: Woman, 62, Files Suit Charging A Gravestone Crushed Her Leg
description: NEWARK, Oct. 4 (AP)A woman has filed suit against a cemetery, contending that a gravestone that marked the graves of her parents and brother fell over and crushed her lee.

title: Episcopal Bishops Clash Over $100 Million Fund Drive
description: PORT ST. LUCIE; Fla., Oct. 4A proposed major capital funds drive today became the focus of conflict over priorities and leadership that have sharply divided bishops of the Episcopal Church in the United States, who are meeting ere.

title: SmithKaunda Meeting Sets Off Wave of Speculation
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 4The recent acknowledgement by Zambia that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia flew there for a secret meeting with President Kenneth D. Kaunda on Sept. 25 has astonished Western and African diplomats and prompted a wave of speculation.

title: Berman Ordered to Serve Additional Year's Term
description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator who served a fourmonth Federal prison sentence for Medicaid fraud, was ordered yesterday to serve an additional oneyear state sentence for bribery.

title: PhiHies Defeat Dodgers in Opener, 75; Yankees, Royals Start Playoffs Today
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4Neither Tommy John nor Steve Carlton, the lefthanders who were expected to stage a pitching duel; were around at the finish or involved in the decision tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Los Angeles Do'dgers, 75, in the opener of the threeoffivegame playoff for the National League pennant.

title: Quebec Leader Confronts 500 Foes on Language Issue
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 4For the first time since he took office last November at he head of a government dedicated to the rights and independence of Quebec's Frenchspeaking majority, Premier Rent Ltvesque braved a direct confrontation last night with the province's alienated and angry Englishspeaking minority.

title: A Baseball Team Named Jackson
description: George M. Steinbrenner, the Grand Old Man of Baseball, and Billy Martin, the practically peerless leader, protested last week when they were denied special dispensation to fill a vacant place on the Yankees roster. They said it was unfair to make them oppose Kansas City's 25man squad in the American League pennant playoff with only 24 men on their side. The mention of 24 New York players would have confused a casual visitor in Yankee Stadium yesterday while the Yankees were loitering through a final ritual of batting, throwing and running. A stranger would have got the clear impression that the league's Eastern Division was going to be represented by a single player, muscular individual named Reginald Martinez Jackson, who speaks as freely as he swings a bolt of mountain ash.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Polyunsaturated Guide to Fats
description: THE HIGHFAT American way of eating is undergoing a slow but certain change. As increasing numbers of Americans hay.; become calorie and cholesterolconscious, millions have switched to leaner cuts of meat and lowfat milk products and replaced lard, butter and bacon fit with margarine and vegetable oils.

title: Ceremony for Aircraft Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The Dwight D. Eisenhower will be formally commissioned as the nation's third nuclearpowered aircraft carrier in a ceremony Oct. 18 attended by the late President's wife in Norfok, Va., the Pentagon said today. Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense, will be guest speaker at the commissioning of the I,092foot Eisenhower, which took seven years to build. Eisenhower's widow, Mamie, christened the ship when it was launched in 1975.

title: How Ethical Is the Page One Novel'?
description: FACT: The Alice Crimmins Case is the title of a nonfiction book by Kenneth Gross, a journalist, that will be published by Ballantine Books next month. It is an account of a notorious wom an, accused of murdering her two small children. After various trials and a conviction, described in the book, Miss Crimmins, a former cocktaillounge hostess in Queens, served time, was on a workrelease program, and remarried. She was recently granted parole.

title: Head of the Casino Control Agency h Given Extraordinary Powers
description: TRENTON, Oct. 4The Casino Control Commission, which will regulate gambling in Atlantic City, gave its chairman, Joseph P. Lordi, extraordinary powers today as the panel held its first meeting in aless than amiable atmosphere.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: If there is never enough of a good thing, custom greetings must be a very good thing, because the number of people doing them is apparently tndless. But each has his or her own personal style and in the case of the latest, B.G. Binder Art, it is their own personal style because it's run and done by Stephen and Bonnie Gail Binder. The Binders paint greetings for any event or occasion. They also custom design Tshirts for groups, organizations and teams. The price of the framed watercolor sentiments ranges from $30 for a 5inchby7inch size to $140 for a 20by24inch one. Unframed art work is about 20 percent less. There is an additional shipping and handling charge that averages about $4. The address is 3074 Yost Parkway, Oceanside, L.I. 11572 and the telephone number is (516) 7664445. The Binder work can also be seen and ordered at Lord & children's

title: $80 MILLION COMPROMISE VOTED ON REACTOR PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)HouseSenateconferees agreed today on a compromise $80 million authorization for the plutoniumproducing Clinch River breeder reactor project in east Tennessee, making major concessions to the Carter Administration.

title: Rangers Beat Islanders
description: UNIONDALE, L.L. Oct. 4In their second and last meeting of the exhibition season, the Rann ers won the bragging rights to the Wollman iceskating rink in Central P;rk with a convincing 63 victory tonight over their eastern neighbors, the Islanders, at the Coliseum. Using a combination of youth and old age, the Rangers scored three times in the final period off Glenn Resch, the Islanders third goalie.

title: Poulet au Kari
description: (Curried Chicken)

title: Jackson Wins 2d Term in Atlanta Contest
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 5Mayor Maynard Jackson, riding a wave of popularity among white voters as well as 12Iacks, inundated six other candidates yesterday to win reelection to a second term as the black officeholder with the largest constituency in the South.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner

title: Books of The Times
description: YOUTH, THE BEKITLES, Norman Mailerthese are just a few of the controversial subjects Richard Poirier has addressed in his previous essays and books. Now, in a major work, he has turned his attention to the poet Robert Frost, and the first question that occurs to a prospective reader is: How does Frost fit into this company? It is true that he was more complicated than the chuckling appjeorchard philosopher his enormous public once perceived him to be, or to put it more precisely, that certain unsympathetic critics perceived his public as perceiving him to be. That has long since been established by Lawrence Thompson's threvolume biography, in which the image of the li'lold coiner of Down East proverbs was dispelled by a surprisingly proud, cantankerous, ambitious figure of a man. Still, one has to wonder upon taking up Robert Frost: The Work of Knowing: What do Robert Frost and the Beatles have in common that would prompt Mr. Poirier to include them in the focus of his interest?

title: A Glittering Exhibit at Natural History Museum
description: Something very strange just had to come out of Peru. What other country has a tumultuous coastline where it never rains and a desert plain on which is incised the profile of a gigantic humming bird? Where else was money unknown and accountancy a matter of knots tied in colorcoded string? They were really a very peculiar people, those ancient Peruvians, and they could hardly have lived in a more peculiar place.

Does a team coached by Don Shula ever surprise when it is doing well? The quartet that has About dismayed its followers is made up of the Cincinnati Pro Bengals, the New England Football Patriots, the St. Louis Cardinals and the Chicago Bears. Some of the reasons are obvious. Bud Goode, the sports analyst, scurried to the numbers produced by the Univac sports computer and these items were flagged.

title: Books: Last Tycoon
description: THE UNFINISHED NOVEL we read as The Last Tycoon is engrossing in several special ways. Fitzgerald's last book, it is at once more mature and more cynical than his early writing; it deals with Hollywood and its personalities, to whom Fitzgerald was attracted and by whom he was simultaneously repelled; and the novel, so far it goes, is a thinly disguised portrait of Irving Thalberg, who became, in death, a film immortal. Finally, The Last Tycoon has always tantalized readers because Fitzgerald's intentions for it were seemingly still hazy when he died in December 1940.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The House today narrowly approved a $52 billion increase in the national debt ceiling. The vote was 223 to 194 to approve a Senatepassed measure and send the measure to President Carter for his signature.

PURISTS may argue that curry powder is not a proper ingredient for dedicated cooks. I demur. I have dined at several Indian tables both in private homes and in restaurants where the food has been something to marvel at. And yet I see nothing wrong with a firstrate commercially blended curry powder, if it is not used on a static, daybyday basis.

title: Private Lives
description: THIS MUCH must be understood about the way they live. Dmitri is a plodder and slogger. He performs one task at a time, from beginning to end, with the utmost seriousness. There is a time to read and a time to write and a time to change light bulbs. If he is sent to the grocery store, it is best that he be asked to fetch only a few items, and these should be all of one category, like soda crackers or asparagus. To ask him to bring back asparagus and, say, hair shampoo or masking tape is to violate his sense of mission, the purity of the act. While he has been known on Sunday afternoons to combine the watching of professional football with the skimming of a week's batch of magazines, he is not serious on Sunday afternoons. More often, you'll find him in his room, finishing whatever he has started.

title: Notes on People
description: AYEAR ago yesterday, Earl L. Butz resigned from Gerald R. Ford's Cabinet, after a protest over racial and scatalogical remarks made public at the height of Mr. Ford's unsuccessful Presidential election campaign. He may be gone from the Department of Agriculture, Where he was Secretary, but he's not forgotten. A $5,000 oil portrait of Dr. Butz, commissioned at public expense, is about to be hung with those of his predecessors in the Agriculture Department. The portrait, which will cost another $750 for framing and lighting, was painted by Everett Wayne Kinstier of New York. Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland has overruled a top aide and invited Dr. Butz to be on hand for the ceremonial hanging of the portrait. The aide had suggested that it be done without fanfare, but Mr. Bergland said, Let's Butz in.

title: Hannah and Gray Report To Patriots on Deadline
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 4 (AP)The New England Patriots two allPro linemen returned to the team today meeting the deadline that had been set by a National Football League committee.

title: CARTER DENIES STOCK ROLE AFTER BECOMING PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The White House has denied a report that President Carter was involved in the management of private stock portfolios, including those of his father, for some six months after taking office.

title: Associated Press
description: RESCUE EFFORTS FAIL: Workers dig in a vain attempt to rescue two construction workers, trapped when the wall of a 15footdeep trench they were digging collapsed ale buried them in Exton, Pa. Both men died.

title: The Frankfurter Evolution
description: Say your hot dog just doesn't cut the mustard anymore? For some frankfurter lovers the juicy sputter, spicy zing and nostalgic aroma of old has been replaced by a product that may be shriveled, scorched, oversalted and full of steamtable fatigue. For others, staunch hot dog defenders, the old American standard is one of the few foods that still tastes the way it did the day they took their first bite at baseball's season opener.

title: Pilot CoaltoOil Plant Gets Reactor Vessel
description: A reactor vessel that will convert 600 tons of coal per day to either synthetic crude oil or a premium boiler fuel has been installed at a pilot plant in Catlettsburg, Ky. The plant is scheduled to start up in the fall of 1978. With an output of 2,200 barrels of synthetic oil a day, it will be the biggest of several experimental coal liquefaction facilities in the United States.

description: BUDAPEST, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The Hungarian Government has announced a drive against bootleggers as part of its campaign against alcoholism, the official press agency reported today. Authorities found 1,585 illegal brandy stills last year and the number of arrests for brewing or selling homemade liquor rose by almost 50 percent, the agency said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There are two cooking procedures I am curious about. One is scallops, which are back in season, and the other is mushrooms. Every time I cook either of them in a skillet they wind up being stewed instead. How do you prevent the liquid from coming out?

Production of distillate oil, meanwhile, was unchanged at 3,3 million barrels a day from the weekago period.

The concert was sold out well in advance.
