title: Film: 2 'Women' With Same Sorrow
description: WHEN her mother dies at the beginning of Marta Meszaros's reflective quietly intelligent "Women," Mari (Marina Vlady) is pained but she barely cries. Man is a big, beautiful, fortyish woman with an air of unnatural serenity and almost no lines on her face, and the film has little interest in explaining how she came to be that way. Instead, it wakes up along with her, in an empathetic and purposefully somnolent style, as Mari's friendship with a younger and less patient woman helps her to realize how much of her life has parsed her by.The important thing about the friendship, as it is presented here, is its galvanizing effect. Juli (Lili Monori) is a high-strung young mother who has left her husband and moved into the workers' hotel managed by Mari, and something about Juli's presence makes the older woman begin to wonder about her own 20-year marriage. Mari's husband is a dull and thoughtless sort"Now you'll believe me when I say you're far from old," he observes, when his wife confesses she has been kissing another man.Juli's husband is a handsome young alcoholic, and their affair is still, after several years, too hot to handle. Though their situations may seem opposite, the two wives turn out to have more in common than they at first realize. Whatever their reasons they both assume the same tearful, terribly resigned stare when they make love."Women" is set in clean, antiseptically modern places that have a frustrating effect rather then a revealing one; the film deliberately stays within the boundaries of its characters' imaginations, articulating their malaise rather than explaining it Miss Mszros's direction is correspondingly stern: The film looks so beautiful, and yet so barren, that the women's deprivation becomes palpable after a while. The characters, settings and script are beautifully integrated, working together to demonstrate that sometimes numbness is the worst kind of pain.Miss Mszros's approach has certain limitations, particularly when it comes to the husbands. Janos (Jan Nowicki), married to Juli, is as clearly drawn as she, but Mari's husband Feri (Miklos Tolnay) is one of those soulless male ciphers who can give women's films or fiction a partisan air."Women" doesn't have a happy ending; it hardly has an ending at all, just a hint of what the future will be. Both women take a few tentative steps away from their mates, but the breaks are not decisive. Still. Juli is unwilling to visit her husband in an alcoholics' clinic, so Marl goes instead, taking Juli's little daughter. Afterwards, Mari assures Juli that everything is fine. "It isn't," cries the little girl, startlingly. "You all tell lies."

Screen: 'Lacemaker' Studies Passivity
description: BEATRICE (Isabelle Huppert), the young heroine of Claude Goretta's new French film, "The Lacemaker," lives at home with her widowed mother and works in a Parisian beauty salon as an apprentice, sweeping up hair, running errands for tips, with the hope of one day be coming a hair stylist.It's not an especially strong hope. Beatrice doesn't have any passions of her own. She's not coldshe's undiscovered, to herself as well as to others. She's also very pretty in an idealized way, having the sort of looks that are so undefined they accept any interpretation. In an earlier era, she woud have been a D. W. Griffith heroine.In "the Lacemaker," Mr. Goretta's third film (after "The Invitation" and "That Wonderful Crook") to be seen in this country, the Swiss director has made a rather solemnly beautiful film to expose the dark side of what is, essentially, a silly, romantic notion."The Lacemaker" will be shown at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center at 9:30 and tomorrow evening at 6:15. It will begin its regular commercial engagement at the Fine Arts Theater Saturday.The film is the story of Beatrice's inevitably unhappy affair with Franois (Yves Beneyton), a tall, lanky, decentmannered university student who wins Beatrice's maidenhead and subsequently comes to realize, with a sinking heart, that she only exists for him to be around him, to reflect his love.Beatrice has no ambition, no interest in the world, no identity except as an ideal, an abstraction, someone who says the film's epilogue, a painter would have made the subject of a genre painting, as a seamstress or a water girl or a lacemaker.Beatrice is a blank canvas, which as Mr. Goretta seems to be saying may be fine for painters but leaves something to be desired as the companion of one's life. She seldom talks or expresses any feeling except affection. As Franois says in frustration at one point, "I don't know what goes on in your mind . . . you never ask questions."It's not difficult to understand why Franois decides they have to splitliving with her is like living with a sweet-natured mannequina decision she accepts with her usual passivity and that ultimately leads to tragic consequences.Just what Mr. Goretta is up to here I'm not sure. As he has shown in his earlier films, he is a director of delicacy who appreciates the odd variation on conventional behavior, the unexpected wisdom within the banal pronouncement."The Lacemaker," though it is nicely acted and set, is only interesting and moving in a theoretical way. Miss Huppert is all too believable as a figure of idealized innocence who would drive, any ordinary man out of his mind with boredom and then, in a final irony leave him feeling guilty for not having sufficiently appreciated the rare gift that briefly had been his.

description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 6,1977

title: The Last Married Couple in Connecticut
description: IT'S BEEN RAINING in Connecticut and all our friends are divorcing. We're worried, my wife and We don't want to be sticks in the mud, the only married persons in the neighborhood. It's a troubling situation from many angles. Ecologically, for example, all these divorces could spell disaster. With everyone pulling up roots, the whole area may wash away.

title: The Right Reaction to Clinch River: Veto
description: The Clinch River breeder reactor, a demonstration power project that could become the Edsel of the nuclear industry, appears to have survived its latest journey through Congress. House and Senate conferees have agreed to authorize about $80 million for the project in fiscal 1978. That figure is being described aS a compromise to avoid a veto by President Carter, who has staked considerable prestige on stopping the project. But the proposed funding would only give momentum to a probable technological and diplomatic fiasco. If the Clinch River item remains in the bill authorizing energy research, as seems all but certain, it would make an excellent target for Mr. Carter's first veto.

title: Justice Dept. Acts to Bar A Federal Judge in Utah
description: DENVER, Oct. 5 (AP)A Federal judge in Utah has been accused of improper judicial conduct, insulting United States attorneys and ignoring all rules of judicial procedure in a Justice Department move seeking to bar him from presiding over Federal cases.

title: Hearing on Johnson Scheduled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to begin public hearings next, Tuesday on the nomination of Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. of Alabama to be Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Palestinians

Almost as much as by the terrible scars of war in downtown Beirut one is struck by relatively insignificant changes. Nearly everyone seems to be wearing either an oversized cross or a replica of the Koran around the neckostentatiously announcing not a religious conviction but a political assertion.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Senate Filibuster Soon Forgotten
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5By 3:55 0'clock yesterday afternoon, it wag almost as if the Senate had not endured two weeks of arguments over natural gas, a determined filibuster, the first allnight session in 13 years and pronounced changes in traditional Senate procedures.

description: VENTNOR, NJ., Oct. 5 (AP)A pet crow attacked a 10yearold girl apparently without provocation in an incident reminiscent of The Birds, the Alfred Hitchcock film.

title: Film: 'Lincoln Conspiracy'
description: IT IS the contention of "The Lincoln Conspiracy," which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters, that traditional beliefs about the assassination of Abraham Lincoln are wrongthe result of a high level cover-up.True, John Wilkes Booth shot and mortally wounded the President. But the movie, whose makers maintain that their thesis is the product of costly new research, depicts Lincoln as the target of another, concurrent conspiracy.This one involved, among others, Secretary of War Edwin Stanton, Col. Lafayette C. Baker, the head of what today would be the Secret Service; a Senator and a Representative  all united by opposition to Lincoln's emphasis on post-Civil-War unification and their fear that his reconstruction policy would lead to Democratic domination of Congress.To that end, the movie has it, they decided to remove Lincoln from the scene by kidnapping him. Although Booth was involved in a similar plot, he was regarded as a bungler. Warned off by the Stanton group, he nevertheless "proceeded to move against the President: and uring his escape, he left behind a diary containing incriminating evidence against some of the Stanton group.It then became necessary for them to insure that Booth never lived to testify. The movie maintains that a man believed to be Booth was killed; and once word that Booth was dead had been flashed to the public, the Stanton plotters had no recourse but to abandon the hunt and to proceed to frame the individuals they had already seized as Booth's co-conspirators.The movie says that Booth was ultimately traced to New York, where his trail vanished.As a movie, "The Lincoln Conspiracy" is a competent enough piece of work. Low-key and tending toward ponderous exposition (it employs both a narrator and a noticeable amount of explanatory dialogue), it can boast a cast of tried and true professionals: Bradford Dillman as the determined but inept Booth; John Dehner as Col. Baker, the prime mover in the events depicted; Robert Middleton, beneath a flowing chinpiece, as Stanton; and John Anderson as Lincoln, radiating compassion and homespun dignity under his makeup.The trouble with "The Lincoln Conspiracy" is that, as film, it is a one-sided case. Although a documentary sources list is provided at the conclusion. "The Lincoln Conspiracy" cannot help but leave anyone seriously interested in the subject wondering about the tangible proofs for the arguments it advances. A book on the subject has been issued in conjunction with the release of the movie, and this may be one case where ten thousand words are worth one picture.

description: Failure to find sperm inside a victim of rape does not necessarily mean that the woman was not raped, according to results of a study being published in medical journal today. The reason, it was said, was that many rapists apparently have abnormal sexual functions.

Sixhundred ashtrays are stolen every month from Maxim's, said Maggie Vaudable, wife of Louis Vaudable, president of Maxim's Limited and Air Maxim's, the holding company that owns all the Maxim's food enterprises in French airports, railways and highway service areas. For the ashtray, we are very tolerant, she said last week, but not for the rest of the things. When people leave with forks and knives, Mr. Roger, the director of the restaurant, says to them, I beg pardon.

title: Film: Vital Nureyev Upstages 'Valentino'
description: THERE'S ONLY one scene in Ken Russell's "Valentino" that is as viscerally offensive as Mr. Russell, at his best and most headstrong, can be. Midway through the movie, Valentino is arrested and forced to spend the night, in a jail cell where the jailer denies him bathroom privileges and the other prisoners maul him and taunt him about his virility.This episode is very much in the mode of Mr. Russell's most overpowering moments those that have simultaneously provoked admiration and outrage, but it has no place in an effort as a typically tame as this one. "Valentino" is Mr. Russell's least disturbing movie since "The Boy Friend": That should come as a relief to his distractors and as a slight disappointment to those who respect and appreciate his abrasive energy.To a large extent, the film's relative ordinariness is attributable to Valentino's. For all of his glamour, he was a bland figure, more of a star than he was an actor, and Mr. Russell's best films have been about artists, such as Henri Gaudier Brzeska in "Savage Messiah" and Tchaikovsky in "The Music Lovers," whose lives were governed by their unruly talent. Valentino's greatest dream was to leave Hollywood and became an orange grower, so there isn't room for the grandiose ambition that animated "Tommy." Valentino's sexuality was nil, at least as far as Mr. Russell's interpretation is concerned, so these is no place for the tortured erotic wrangling that amounts to another Russell specialty.The most intriguing thing about Valentino, as he appears here, is his old-world notion of manly honor, but even that poses minor problems. When Oliver Reed, as a besieged priest in Mr. Russell's "The Devils," was subjected to public humiliation, he looked properly humiliated. When Rudolf Nureyev, who plays Valentino with a fierce sense of style, is abused or insulted, he looks magnificent. The screenplay represents Valentino as a fairly meek character but, as played by Mr. Nureyev, he seems positively to thrive upon affronts to his dignity.The best parts of the film are those that pit Valentino against Hollywood, which both he and Mr. Russell seem to see as the biggest affront of them all. Whether he is courting a starlet (Carol Kane) who serves a huge tureen of French fries and ketchup on a silver tray, or dressing up in a Yale sweater and knickers in hopes of being cast as me all-American boy. Valentino is surrounded by (and a party to) the most aggressive kind of vulgarity. The screenplay, by Mr. Russell has no ear far American speech. "Everyday is Halloween in Tinseltown," says one charactertwice.The dialogue is compounded by Mr. Nureyev's uncertain accent (mostly Russian, but he hums a few bars of "O Sole Mio" from time to time). Mr. Nureyev has trouble delivering snappy patter with much conviction, and so do the other European members of the cast. Michele Phillips, suitably steely-eyed as Valentino's conniving wife, Natasha Rambova, often sounds even less authentic than these others.But Leslie Caron, as Valentino's benefactor Alla Nazimova (there also seems to be a touch of Pola Negri to the role), copes admirably with the script's strangeness by reading her lines more peculiarly than is necessary, shouting and waving her arm all the while. There are a number of excellent small performances hereCarol Kane's dopey chorine, Felicity Kendall's studio liaison, Seymour Cassel's plain-suited shysterbut Miss Carol's is the most enjoyable outlandish of the lot.And Mr. Nureyev's is, of course, the most graceful. It should certainly come as to no surprise that Mr. Nureyev is incapable of making an uninteresting gesture, whether he is daily sipping a vanilla malted out of a champagne glass or reeling dizzily in a boxing ring. More surprising is Mr. Nureyev's malleability, and the apparent effortlessness with which he adapts himself to fit into the film's varied tableaux. He is at his most stunning as he tangoes in a dimly lit nightclub of the film), and fighting for his life in a noisy, crowded area one wall of which hangs a tattered American flag.These are only two of the better looking sequences in an extremely handsome film, whose look of overripe 20's opulence provides an ironic running commentary upon its characters. Even when Mr. Russell's verbal wit is not up to snuff, his visual jokes are alive and well. As Valentino and Rambova squabble with a studio head (played by Huntz Hall), a ridiculous little western is being filmed in the background. When Valentino attempts to seduce Natasha in his movie-set sheik's tent, the two shed their wraps and then Natasha, as is her wont, begins carping about business matters. But the couple continue to behave so romantically, and so incongruously with their real thoughts, that the scene becomeswell, ravishingly funny.

title: Bridge:
description: Conversations between leading tournament players around New York this week have usually begun with a strange question: Have you heard about the ten of hearts? And the answer has usually been affirmative because the grapevine has been very active.

title: Phils Beaten by 71 Grand Slam Hit by Baker in Fourth

description: PEOPLE who love these things are people with fresh eyes, said Sergio Bustarnante. The Mexican architect turned sculptor and painter was speaking of his tjungle of extraordinary animal figures that are currently populating the fifthfloor gallery at Bloomingdale's.

description: A New York man died in a fall while climbing the Palisades at Englewood Cliffs, the police said. The victim, Charles Bernstein, 45 years old, of Belle Harbor, Queens, a stockbroker, was hiking Tuesday with his two children when he lost his footing while tfying to help his I2yearold daughter.

title: OntheSpot Morality
description: President Carter's rollercoaster tour next month to eight countries on four continents in 11 days was hardly dreamed up by his White House publicrelations advisers to divert attention from Bert Lance's resignation 48 hours earlier as Director of the Office of Management and Budget; but it is difficult to think of any other good reason for making the announcement at that timeor in fact for making this kind of trip at any time.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 (AP)The MarlboroughBlenheim Hotel, which has graced the Boardwalk for most of this century, will close in three weeks, a victim of the coming casino era.

title: Redwood National Park Expansion To Be Held Up by Panel in House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI)A prol posal to expand the Redwood National Park in California has been bottled up in the House Rules Committee at least fore the rest of the year.

title: 3 New York Theater Companies Get Ford Grants
description: THE FORD FOUNDATION is making a $1.4 million investment in theaters that generate and produce new American plays. The bulk of the foundation's theater grants this year will go to three of New York's enterprising companies that operate away from Broadwaythe Circle Repertory Company, the Manhattan Theater Club and Playwrights Horizon. Each will receive approximately $250,000 in outright and matching grants to be spread over a period of three years.

title: Cook Industries Reports Net Profit of $18 Million
description: Cook Indatries Inc., one of the nation's largest grain, and cotton merchandisers, repored yesterday that in the three months ended Aug. 31 it had g net profit of about $18. million, or $4.87 a share. This is in contrast to a $13.5.million loss forth year earlier period.

title: The Geneva Express (Via City Hall)
description: Out of the recent tumult of diplomacy over the Middle East, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan now has what he wanted, Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko has what he wanted, President Carter has them both more or less where he wanted, and Candidate Edward Koch has a problem. That still leaves Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Lebanon and assorted Palestinians to be heard from. But Geneva can resume planning for a likely conference this year, Washington has regained its balance and, surely, in time, New York City will, too.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These arethe most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: F.B.I. CRIME INQUIRIES REPORTEDLY TAINTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation looking into organized crime have placed illegal wiretaps and used the information produced by the taps in false affidavits presented to Federal courts over the last five years, key law enforcement sources say.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Opposition in Korea Asks Inquiry on Tongsun Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 5South Korea's major opposition party submitted legislation today calling for a special parliamentary committee to investigate fully the Tongsun Park influencebuying scandal in Washington because it has come to affect South Korea's national security.

title: House Unit Drafts Bill to Protect Social Security System for 30 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5The House Ways and Means Committee completed drafting today a bill intended to protect the financial integrity of the Social Security system for at least 30 years.

title: Royals Belt Three HomersGullett's Shoulder Sore
description: The New York Times/Barton Silverman

title: A Psychiatrist Finds Son of Sam
description: A psychiatrist retained by the prosecution to examine David R. Berkowitz, the Man accused of being the Son of Sam, has found him mentally fit to stand trial in Brooklyn for murder.

title: Califano  Urging Overhaul of Law On Drug Safety
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 5Joseph A. Cali fano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, called today for a complete overhaul of the Federal law regulating 100,000 prescription drugs and 250,000 overthecounter formulations now sold in the United States.

title: West Coast Pickets Block a Ship
description: OAKLAND, Calif.,sOct. 5 (AP)A ship that faced pickets of the International Longshoremen's Association at Long Beach harbor met another picket line after palling into Oakland today.

title: VELEZ GROUP ORDERED TO STOP FUND RAISING
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has ordered Puerto Rican Parade Inc,, whose president is Councilman Ramon S. Velez, to stop raising funds pending a hearing next Wednesday on cancellation of its registration as a charitable organization.

title: Carter Signs Bill Raising Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI)President Carter today signed a bill temporarily raising the national debt ceiling to $752 billion. The move restores the Government's authority to borrow money and pay itsbills.

title: Two Jerseyans Pressing for Federal Expansion of Aid to Drug Addicts
description: NEWARK, Oct. 6A former Assemblyman, George Richardson, and a former public relations counselor, Ingrid Frank, cofounders of the National Committee to Declare War on Drugs, have presented plans to Dr. Peter Bourne, White House director on drug policy, which they hope will lead to a National Social Health Corporation.

title: BYRNE AND BATEMAN HOLD SIXTH DEBATE
description: NEWARK, Oct. 5  Governor Byrne's record during the last four years and the fiscal program proposed by his opponent, Senator Raymond H. Bateman, were debated by the candidates tonight during onehour television session before 1,200 business and industry leaders.

title: Notes on People
description: Labelle Lance said yesterday that only two weeks after the resignation of her husband, Bert Lance, as President Carter's budget director, things were looking up all over. Bert has all kinds of wonderful offers, she said, everything from book and movie contracts to business. Mrs. Lance said in Atlanta that she was grateful to a lot of people, particularly Yolande Betbeze, a former Miss America, who owns the house the Lances rented in the Georgetown section of Washington for a reported $8,000 a year. Her landlady tore up our last two months rent checks and canceled our lease, said Mrs. Lance, She did that and then said she was proud to have the Lances in her house.

title: Senate Moves to Require Electric Utilities to Offer Lifeline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. The Senate adopted an amendment tonight that would require utilities to offer lifeline electricity rates for senior citizens as a cushion against increasing electric charges.

title: Ithaca Leads Lambert Voting
description: Ithaca College, which won its third consecutive game by beating Alfred, 178, last weekend, continued as the leader yesterday in the weekly voting for the Lambert Bowl. The trophy is awarded annually to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outstanding Division III football team in the East.

title: The New York Times/William E. Sauro David L. Moffitt, the superintendent of Liberty Island, with his wife, Carolyn, and their children, Michael, 7 years old, John, 11, and Andrea, 13, aboard Liberty II, the historic island's staff boat.
description: Moving to New York City was an anxious prospect of exchanging a lifetime of friends and places for a city notoriously roughedged and anonymous. But here were the sons, John and Michael, on their new island home in the Upper Bay lifting a plank out of the graygreen sea for their clubhouse, only nine months later. And the cat they brought with them from Massachusetts was still alive, too.

title: 2 Hell's Angels in Bridgeport Are Shot and Stabbed to Death
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 5 (AP)Two Hell's Angels motorcycle club members were shot and stabbed to death in a bar here early today.

title: Albany Democrats Shift Strategy on City Notes, Planning to Take Up All Fiscal Issues This Fall
description: Adopting a new strategy, the Democratic leaders of the New York Legislature announced yesterday that they wanted to consider in a special session this fall a full range of fiscal issues facing New York Cityincluding an eventual replacement for the Emergency Financial Control Board.

title: Sound
description: SIMPLICITY is rarely simple to attain in life, but the results are usually worth it. The same holds true for turntable design. The simple, obvious way to spin a turntable is to put a motor directly under it. But it couldn't really be done that way, till some recently developed complexities helped simplify the situation.

title: Bouncing on the Couches at Conran's
description: IT TOOK Terence Conran, the British merchantdesigner, to show New Yorkers how to apply the American concept of the supermarket to home furnishings.

title: Tow Trucks Held Peril on Streets In Assembly Hearing on Licensing
description: Tow trucks racing to automobile accidents are themselves often the cause of accidents and have become a peril on city streets, according to testimony yesterday before a State Assembly hearing.

title: Good Life
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 5More and more welfare recipients are moving to Suffolk County from New York City, Hassau County, Puerto Rico and other places in search of the same things that lure the middle class, according to figures released today by the county. They are looking, the county said, for better schools, cleaner air, less crime and the promise of a house with a yard.

title: Moss Bids S.E.C. Lift OffBoard Trading Restrictions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Representative John E. Moss. chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the securities industry, today urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to lift the controversial offboard trading restrictions in January as the agency has proposed.

title: 3Hour Outage Hits Downtown Boston; City Reported Calm
description: BOSTON, Oct. 5Shortly before 10 P.M., a power outage cut off all electricity in a threeby fivemile corridor of the downtown section here, affecting some 25,000 to 30,000 people. Three hours later, power had been restored to nearly all the area except for several blocks in the Back Bay section.

title: Suspect Lettuce in the Lasagna
description: A cache of $17,200 in $50 billsbelieved to be part of money allegedly stolen from an abandoned trunk by two former warehouse employees has been discovered by detectives between the lavers of frozen lasagna.

title: Express Mail to Become Permanent U.S. Service
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UN) The Postal Service announced today that its express mail service, used experimentally since 1970 to provide guaranteed sameday or nextday delivery in selected cities, would become permanent starting Sunday.

title: Nobel Selection Due In Literature Today
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 5 (AP)The Swedish Academy, in a departure from previous practice, announced today that it would award the annual Nobel Prize in Literature tomorrow.

title: NEWSPAPERS ON COAST REVIVE COMPETITION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24There are hints of a return here to competitive newspaper publishing to the sort that mice had four dailies at each other's throats.

ROLE AS MODEL STATE GIVES COSTA RICA LIFT
description: SAN JOSE, Costa RicaHaving long felt isolated in a continent dominated by rightwing military regimes, Costa Rica is basking in its reputation as one of Latin America's rare social democracies, where elections are clean and human rights are respected.

title: NEW &
description: Bedside Tea, Automatically One of the nicest things about visiting England is being served early tea. As all Anglophiles know, the hotel chambermaid or steward raps gently on your door at a predetermined morning hour and glides in with a tray holding a steaming pot of hot water, fragrant pot of freshly brewed tea, milk or lemon, and sugar. Now the British have arranged it so that you can have early tea (or instant coffee, if you insist) at your own bedside. The magic is accomplished by a device that's been around for decades in England but is new here: the Teasmade. The white plastic box: shaped machine comes with a metal teakettle that sits on an electric element and is activated by a builtin alarm system. You set the alarm for the time you want to be awakened. Twelve minutes before the buzzer goes off, the electricity goes on and the kettle starts to heat. First the steam and then the boiling water is ejected through a narrow spout into a white earthenware teapot that sits alongside it (the cut tea or teabags have already been put in the teapot, of course). By the time the alarm awakens you, the tea is ready. The alarm section of the unit can be used separately, as can the builtin night light. There's also a button you can push to make tea at any time. The Teasmade is $100 in Bloomingdale's housewares and

title: Biography Of Garbo Planned
description: A biography of Greta Garbo by Antoni Gronowicz, a New York novelist and playwright, will be published by Simon & Schusterafter her death. A clause in the contract for the book specifies that it is not to appear during her lifetime. We hope she will live for years and years because she's a wonderful lady, the spokesman for the publishing house said.

title: Builder Guilty in Bribery
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 5 (AP)A builder in Morris Township has been found guilty of bribing a former regional health officer in exchange for approvals of two septictank permits and a landsubdivision application. The builder, Morris Zudick, 64 years old, was convicted by Judge Robert Shelton of Superior Court of two count, each of offering and paying bribes. Mr. Zudick was charged with paying Warren King, a former health officer, $2,500 and $1,000 in exchange for the approval of tip permits and an appliction to subdv??e land in Randolph and Denvil? townships.

title: Bomb Scare Diverts A 747 to Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 5 (Reuters)A Pan American jumbo jet on a flight from San Francisco to Tokyo made an emergency diversion to Canada tonight after a note was discovered warning that there were bombs on board.

title: KOCH AND PRESIDENT APPEAR RECONCILED
description: President Carter and Representative Edward I. Koch made peace overtures to each other yesterday after Mr. Koch's encounter with Mr. Carter on Tuesday blossomed into a fullblown controversy.

title: Dow Rebounds With Rise of 4.76; Strength in Retail Sales a Factor
description: Stock prices rebounded yesterday, benefiting in part from strong chainstore sales gains reported for September. This was a sign to investors that the consumer, regarded as a critical factor in the present edgy economy, remained in spending mood.

title: I.R.S. to Lift Mileage Allowance
description: The Internal Revenue Service plans to increase to 17 cents a mile from 15 cents the tax deduction it allows people to claim when they use their personal cars for business travel, sources close to the I.R.S. said yesterday.

title: Soviet Grain Purchases in U.S. Can Total 15 Million Metric Tons
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  With huge stockpiles of wheat and corn on hand, the United States has informed the Soviet Union that the latter country may buy up to 15 million metric tons of grain in the coming year, a senior Agriculture Department official said late today.

title: Tactical Nukes
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear forces in Europe are largely an anachronism. These tactical nuclear weapons, socalled because they are intended for use on or near the battlefield, now number several thousand, many of them larger than those mounted on strategic missiles and bombers. They reflect a long and convoluted history, not careful analysis of NATO's current needs.

description: The largest baseball crowd of the year in Yankee Stadiumnumbering 56,230 at a $9 tophooted and yelled and littered the field last night as the New York Yankees tied the playoff for the American League pennant at 11 and escalated their grudge against the Kansas City Royals.

title: JERSEY ISSUES PLAN TO CONSERVE ENERGY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 6Joel R. Jacobson, the New Jersey Energy Commissioner, announced today an emergency energy allocation plan for natural gas, electricity, gasoline and home heating oil should an energy shortage develop this winter.

title: Grocery Chains
description: The nation's two largest supermarket chains, Safeway Stores Inc. and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, yesterday reported substantial declines in quarterly earnings.

title: Doctors Say Israeli Premier Will Leave Hospital Next Week
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Prime Minister Menahem Begin of Israel will be released from a hospital early next week his doctors said today.

title: Two Quakes Shake California
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 6 (UPI)Two light earthquakes shook southern California communities early today, but there were no reports of injury or damage. The first quake was felt in the Los Angeles suburb of Montebello. The second quake, described by residents as a series of three shocks, shook the Santa Maria area 180 miles north of Los Angeles.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6The United States and the Soviet Union sidestepped a direct confrontation today in their opening statements at the 35nation conference being held here to review progress on human rights, European security and economic cooperation.

title: New Face: Hector Jaime Mercado
description: Judas stands alone on stage, scorned and rejected, the deed of betrayal done. He stares in disbelief at the purseful of silver pieces he holds clenched in one hand. Then, as the music quickens, he hurls himself into a frantic, furious dance, lunging, rolling and leaping in response to his inner agony.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: THIS YEAR'S Frederick Wiseman event on public television is Canal Zone, which is not only the first of his documentaries to venture outside the United States, but is also, whether by design or chance, unusualy topical with its portrait of life and love and power and drab survival in and around the Panama Canal. Like all Wiseman productions, this new WNET/13 presentation, tr, be shown tonight at 9 o'clock; uses no narrator, is filmed in blacK ana white, and runs at its own leisurely but always subtly calculating pace. Canal Zone is about three hours long.

title: CRITICS RUE HANDLING OF THE GANDHI CASE

Chops, a jazz terms, means technical proivess. It is often used approvingly, as in the phrase he's got a lot of chops, but just as often it expresses limitation: He's got a lot of chops but he isn't saving anything.

title: US STUDY DISCOUNTS STEEL IMPORT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Council on Wage and Price Stability in an eagerly awaited report to President Carter, says that, while the nation's steel industry has been subjected to aggressive price competition from European and Japanese mills, import restraints would not significantly improve its economic position.

title: Museum Tower and Bridge Market Win Approval of Estimate Board
description: A plan to build a 42story residential tower over an extension of the Museum of Modern Art and a proposal to put a market under the Queensboro Bridge easily won approval yesterday from the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Dr. Goldmark to Head State Medical Society
description: Dr. Carl Goldmark Jr. of New York City has assumed the presidency of the Medical Society of the State of New York, following the close of its 171st annual convention, held at the Americana Hotel. Dr. George T. C. Way, a Poughkeepsie obstetriciangynecologist, was chosen as presidentelect of the 27,500member society.

title: G.E. Gets Navy Contract
description: The General Electric Company has been awarded $71.1 million in Navy contracts for nuclear power plant components and replacement parts.

title: Senator Says Soviet Merchant Fleet Will Be Largest in World in 2 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. (Reuters)The Soviet Union has the fastestgrowing merchant fleet in the world and will replace Japan as number one within two. years, Senator Daniel K. Inouye'said here today.

title: Critics Notebook: The Role That Filmgoers Play
description: AUDIENCES that have been packing Alice Tully Hall for the programs of the New York Film Festival are, like the audiences at film festivals everywhere, unreliable. They have any number of reasons for behaving the way they do, only some of which have to do with whether they like the film they're watching.

title: Women Relay the Movement's Torch From Seneca Falls to Houston
description: Suzy Chaffee, former captain of the Olympic ski team, is carrying a torch for the women's movement. So is Cheryl Toussaint, Olympic silver medalist. And Katherine Switzer, the first woman to finish the Boston Marathon officially.

title: LEVITT GIVEN AMEX POST; COMMODITY BOARD NAMED
description: As expected, Arthur Leintt Jr., presmenL of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc., was elected yesterday vice chairman of the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Levitt, who was named to a twoyear term on the Amex board of governors in 1976, is chairman of its programs and policies committee and a member of the committee to recommend a new chairman for the securities and ontions exchange.

title: Dole Says State Department Tried to Intimidate Him
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Senator Robert Dole acimsed the State Department today of trying to intimidate him because he had made public a confidential cablegram quoting a Panamanian negotiator as disputing the United States interpretation of its rights under the new Panama Canal treaties.

title: Ricci, Paganini's American Friend
description: As far as musicologists can guess, Paganini's Violin Concerto No. 6 was composed around 1815. The concerto was never published, and a manuscript of it was not recovered until five years ago. It was later printed by an organization called Paganiniana Publications in Neptune, NJ., which had asked the violinist Ruggiero Ricci to edit the violin part and supply cadenzas. Mr. Ricci has had a monopoly on its performance ever since, and he will be the soloist when the concerto is played for the first time in New York on Sunday afternoon in the American Symphony Orchestra's 3 P.M. concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Music: Lloyd Invokes Past
description: ALAN LLOYD, a composer often associated with Robert Wilson (he did some of the music for Mr. Wilson's The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin, among other projects) and with Mr. Wilson's longtime choreographic associate. Andrew deGroat (he's providing music for deGroat dance program Oct. 15 and 16 at the Cunningham Studio in Westbeth), gave a concert of his music Wednesday night at the kitchen. It was a curious affair.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 6Although more than 300,000 people were out of work for most of 1976, New Jersey ranked second among the states in percapita income last year, according to figures compiled by the United States Department of Commerce and released today by the state's Department of Labor and Industry.

title: Dutch Cabinet TalKs collapse
description: THE HAGUE, Oct, 6 (Reuters)Talks on forming a new Dutch coalition government collapsed today for the third time since an indecisive election in May when the three parties involved failed to agree on how to divide Cabinet seats.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: LAST SEASON, Christopher Hampton's Savages had its New York premiere at the Hudson Guild Theater in Chelsea. This year, his play Treats begins the season at the Hudson Guild; the show is in previews and opens Sunday. In town for his play, the 31yearold British dramatist traced the seed of Treats back to 1971 and a previous visit to New York. That season he had two plays on Broadway, The Philanthropist and his adaptation of A Doll's House, starring Claire Bloom.

title: The Past Haunts Brothers Who Own Convicted Sports Empire
description: BUFFALOOver the years the neighborhood around Main and Tupper changed; what was once this city's heart became its soul. A number of stores began advertising Afro wigs, others offered instant credit and many simply stood vacant. The movie theaters showed the latest in KungFu films. At night, you walked these mean streets at your own risk.

title: Solitary Poet in the Spotlight
description: When the telephone began to jangle yesterday in Vicente Aleixandre's Madrid villa, he left it off the hook. When a television crew asked to film an interview, he declined, saying that he was going to bed to conserve his strength for his writing.

title: Latest Growing Court Sport
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 6Tliere was a time when racquetball players had to fight the handball players to get a court. But that was 40 years ago. Now the racquetballers have their own courts in gleaming glass and chrome centers and a $250,000 professional tour across the country.

title: CITIZENS UNION GIVES ITS SUPPORT TO KOCH
description: The Citizens Union gave its backing yesterday to Representative Edward I. Koch for Mayor of New York City in the November election and to his Democratic running mates, State Senator Carol Bellamy, for Council President, and to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is seeking another term.

title: Islanders Send Hansen, N.Y. Native, to Minors
description: The only native New Yorker to play for the New York Islanders has been sent to the minor leagues. Richie Hansen, who played in four National Hockey Leagues games last season and scored a goal against the Rangers in his debut, will report to Fort Worth of the Central Hockey League. Last season at Fort Worth he played in 74 games, scored 30 goals and was credited with 47 assists.

description: DETROIT, Oct.6 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation is raising prices on its new cars an average $354, or 5.8 percent, from comparably equipped 1977 models, the third biggest United States automaker announced today.

description: NO, JOLEY IS NOT ABOUT one of the Gabors; it is about Al Jolson, and it is supsupposed to go into rehearsal at the end of January and open sometime in the spring. Bert Convy is to star in it, which means he plays Jolson, and Jay Harnick, who, among many other things, is Sheldon Harnick's brother and Barbara Barrie's husband, is to direct it. Herbert Hartig has done the book and lyrics, and Milton DeLugg has done the music. Actually, Mr. DeLugg, who accompanied Jolson the last few years of his life, has done only half the music for the show because you cannot have a musical about Al Jolson without having a lot of old Jolson songs in it. Joley, therefore, has Swanee, California, Here I Come and so on in its score, and sometimes they are used as counterpoint to Mr. DeLugg's new music. The producer of all this is Jeff Britton.

title: N.F.L. Suspends Umpire For Error in Bills
description: The National Football League confirmed yesterday that it had suspended an official, Gerry Hart, for two games because of an error that cost the Buffalo Bills the last six seconds Sunday in their 1714 loss to the Colts in Baltimore.

title: Bearing Steel's Burdens

In a move designed to reduce Congressional pressure for tougher protectionist measures, the Treasury ruled that Japanese producers were selling carbon steel plate in the United States at less than cost, and were thus subject to tariff penalties.

title: The Shortest Shortstop: 54 and 140
description: The gags follow Freddie Patek everywhere. Hey, say his teammates on the Kansas City Royals, get off your knees. Opponents shout, Get that kid off the field. And during the American League playoffs at Yankee Stadium, a fan yelled, What do you want to be when you grow up? Freddie Patek is nearly 33 years old now, but he enjoys all those gags, especially that fan's question. He supplied the answer long ago. Freddie Patek is only 5 feet 4 inches and 140 pounds the shortest and smallest player in the major

Lee of Red (Spots) Sox Has Faith in K.C.
description: Bill Lee, the pitcher from Boston who is known as Spaceman, was at Yankee Stadium last night on assignment to write a story on the playoffs for The Boston Phoenix, a weekly newspaper. Around the batting cage before the game, Lee told some people about how he ate Jamaican mackerel on Wednesday night, and that it had disagreed with him; it violently disagreed with him. He said his throat began to swell, his face broke out in hives and his entire body began itching.

title: It's Murder All Weekend At Waldorf
description: If you hear screams, shots and moans in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel this weekend, it will not mean more mayhem in the diamond trade. It will not be the board meeting of a television network with slumping ratings. It will not be an Arab sheik who was served gefilte fish by mistake.

title: Court of Appeals Rules Concorde Can Start Kennedy Flights at Once

description: AMES. Iowa. Oct 6Watching ice not sound like much of a pcziitcr sport but it's what a lot of people at Iowa State University here doing this week.

title: INDIAN SAYS CARTER CONFERS WITH DESAI
description: The Foreign Minister of India said yesterday that a new chapter of friendly relations had opened between his country and the United States, accompanied by many messages between President Carter and Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai on important world issues.

title: ARMY DATA DESCRIBE LSD TEST ON SOLDIER
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 6On June 12, 1961, a 23yearold American soldier stationed in Orleans, France, was administered LSD without his consent or knowledge in an effort by an Army intelligence team to determine the whereabouts of classified documents the soldier was suspected of stealing, according to recently declassified Department of Army documents.

title: ANDERSON ASKS DELAY IN FISCAL BOARD VOTE
description: ALBANY, Oct. 6Taking issue with his Democratic, counterparts, the Senate majority leader Warren M. Anderson, said today that he did not want the State Legislature to consider extending or replacing the Emergency Financial Control Board for New York City until its regular session next year.

The paintingshowing the Soviet leader at his Kremlin officereplaces traditional headandshoulders photograph that Mr. Brezhnev posed for some years ago. Name of painter was not immediately available.
RICHARD MORTON
description: Richard Morton, a sales representative for Scientific American, died unexpected ly Sunday night in his home in Hilton Head. S.C. He was 63 years old.

title: Mayor of Jersey City Plans to Fight A New State Center in Liberty Park
description: NEWARK, Oct. 6 (AP)The Mayor of Jersey City, Thomas F. X. Smith, has said he will go to court if the state attempts to develop any part of the Library State Park.

title: PARENTS / CHILDREN
description: Parents frequently want their children to be like themto go to the same college and then on to the same kind of joband they feel rejected if a child chooses otherwise. It may be that these parents are working from a misunderstanding: they seem to think that what they do as parents strongly influences the development of a child's interests.

title: Nets 94, Pacers 89
description: PISCATAWAY, N..1,, Oct. 6 (UPI)The New Jersey Nets opened the new Rutgers University Athletic Center tonight with a 94.89 N.B.A. exhibitiongame victory over the Indiana Pacers before a crowd of 2,130.

title: Pakistan: Politics and the Prisoner
description: The army chief of staff who reluctantly seized power in Pakistan last July to end rioting over a disputed election has been drawn deep into the political quagmire he hoped to avoid. When Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq took control, he promised new elections in three months. He was holding to this resolve as recently as two weeks ago, when Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the Prime Minister he displaced, was jailed on charges of conspiring to murder a political opponent. General Zia declared then that the elections would nevertheless proceed as scheduled on Oct. 18. Now he has reconsidered and has postponed the polling indefinitely. The idea behind elections is to avoid violence and change the government through peaceful means, he said in a broadcast. But in our country it is just the reverse. Whenever it is election time, we find that violence and lawlessness take over.

title: U.S. Said to Propose Referendum For Population of Disputed Ogaden
description: UNITED NATIONS: N.Y., Oct. 6 (UPI) Diplomatic officials said today that the United States had proposed a United Nationssupervised referendum in Ogaden to settle the conflict between Ethiopia and Somalia.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Publishing: Authors Making the Rounds
description: VAUDEVILLIANS no longer play the road, but authors still do. This autumn some of the book people are holding up their jackets so the television cameras can zoom in on the titles, doing four radio chats a day, autographing their works in bookstores and even talking about present and future books with journalists of what the television folk quaintly call the print media. Here are some of the things they've been saying to an oldfashioned pencil and notebook.

The sitin was orderly and without incident.

title: Recital: Jane Allen, Pianist, Aims High
description: EVERY ARCHER knows that if you don't aim somewhat above the target you won't hit it, gravity being one of those harsh old laws that still has not been nullified by popular request. So more power to a musician who shoots high, as Jane Allen did in her piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night. Unfortunately, the targets she chose were sometimes so far above her abilities that she missed them entirely.

title: Looking for A Parlor Car?
description: GREAT AUCTION SEASONS have started with less activity, and poor ones have opened with more than what is scheduled for the weeks ahead at galleries in New York and around the world. It is, of course, too easily to defermine whether the art and antiques auction season now moving into high gear will be memorable. What is clear in reviewing the events announced so far is that the pace of public sales has definitely quickened.

title: Page, Commuter on the L.I.R.R., To Guard Tradition of Morgan
description: These days, the new chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company rides the Long Island Rail Road to work, but he still represents a bank whose patrician traditions probably rule out lending money to any of the other commuters on the 7:46 from Cold Spring Harbor.

The other was Li Fusheng, a student at the People's Liberation Army Institute of Physical Culture in Peking.

title: Ailing Puerto Rican in 1954 Attack On Congress Is Freed by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)The Puerto Rican nationalist Andres Figueroa Cordero was released from prison in Springfield, Mo., today, three hours after President Carter cut his sentence to the 23 years he has already served for his part in an armed attack on Coneress in 1954.

Also participating in the procelebrity tournament will be Alan King, a comedian; United Nations Ambassador Andrew Young; two television newsmen, Walter Cronkite and Harry Reasoner, and two former basketball stars, Dave DeBusschere and Oscar Robertson.

title: BURMESE THEATER: OUTLET FOR DISSENT
description: NYAUNGU, BurmaAll public expression in Burma is censored, and the press is uniform in its praise of President Ne Win's 15yearold Burmese way to socialism. But recently, press censorship has tightened to the point of not only prescribing to editors what they must not print but also what they must print. The range of optional items has become narrower than ever.

title: Flora and Fauna Join for Day
description: The New York Botanical Garden and the Bronx Zoo will stage a Flora and Fauna Festival tomorrow and Sunday, featuring an animal parade, a plant sale, exhibits and entertainment. An admission charge of $1.50 for adults, 75 cents for children will cover the daylong activities at both places.

title: MAJOR CHAIN STORES REPORT LARGE GAINS IN SEPTEMBER SALES
description: Major retailers reported yesterday that consumer buying in September rose sharply across the nation, giving some of the chain stores their biggest monthly sales gains of the year.

title: A Loan and Some Sweat Equity Create an Oasis Amid Desolation
description: Three years ago, the tan brick apartment house at 1186 Washington Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx looked so much a part of the square miles of desolation around it that city officials were loath to lend $310,000 to the young people who wanted to restore it.

title: Carter Assures Representatives On Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6President Carter assured a delegation of Jewish members of Congress and supporters of Israel today of his commitment to Israel and he also made a gesture of friendship toward Edward I. Koch.

title: Prisoner in Manhattan Escapes for Third Time, but Is Recaptured
description: A prisoner who had escaped from custody twice before got away yesterday from a detective who had brought him to the Manhattan District Attorney's office for questioning. The prisoner made his escape after spraying ammonia in the detective's face and seizing his revolver.

title: Aerosol Ruling Favors Ruder &
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that an aerosol manufacturer could not recover damages from a public relations firm that first mounted a campaign against aerosol products through a related public relations firm and then tried to obtain the account of the manufacturer in order to combat adverse publicity.

title: SENATE PANEL DROPS MAJOR TAXES SOUGHT BY CARTER ON ENERGY

title: Both Feldman and His Opponent Willingly Discuss Senator's Bribe
description: TEANECK, Oct. 6As Senate President Matthew Feldman moves into the last four weeks of his reelection campaign, he does not shy away from discussing his admission last November that he made $6,400 in cash payments to a restaurant chain to insure $240,000 in sales to his family's liquor business.

title: Coal Mine Owners Warn Union as Talks Open on New Contract
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6With a warning from the mine owners that a failure to reach a growth labor contract could bring the extinction of the nation's oldest union, leaders of the expansionminded coal industry and the United Mine Workers of America opened negotiations today on a new ware aereement.

title: TOP TITO AIDE FINDS U.S. TIES IMPROVING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5Edvard Kardelj, the putative successor of President Tito of Yugoslavia, said yesterday after a week of talks here that YugoslavUnited States relations were better than ever before, in part because of a shift in American attitudes.

description: Alexander's Inc, one of the metropolitan's largest retail chains, reported yesterday a fourthquarter net loss of $384, 000 against an operating net profit of $397,000 in the 1976 period, mainly due to the promotional need to stimulate apparel sales that resulted in reduced margins.

Santucci, the Queens District Attorney, announced yesterday.

It is not so Much that he is unGerrated or overrated as that he is not rated at all. For several years he has been in that limbo that is reserved for painters who make al;great stir when they are very young and then don't seem to affect people very much one way or the other.

description: Schenley Industries, one of the natign's largest distillers and importers of was accused yesterday of paying $500,000 in kickbacks and rebates to its distributors in New York State.

title: Closing the Oil Import Gap
description: Americans are paying little attention to their dwn leaders warnings about the impending energy crisis. Perhaps they will listen to warnings from abroad. The energy ministers of the main industrial nations, assembled in Paris, find that their countries are navigating treacherous and dangerous shoals. In the view of the 19nation International Energy Agency, increased oil imports since 1973 have made the industrial democracies, and especially the United States, more vulnerable to another Arab oil embargo. Meanwhile, the flow of oil from the North Sea, Alaska and Mexico, though it cannot assure adequate supplies for more than a few years, has brought widespread public complacency.

title: Episcopal Bishops Rebuke Dissident, But Censure Fails
description: PORT SAINT LUCIE, Fla., Oct. 6The Episcopal House of Bishops acted today to combat the growing schism in the church by passing a resolution that deplores and repudiates the efforts by retired Bishop Albert A. Chambers to aid the separatist cause.

title: Management
description: Though more and more women are serving on corporate boards of directors, even at the present rate of increase, it will take many years for women to win a significant percentage of corporate directorships, a recent survey by BursonMarsteller, a publicrelations from shows.

title: .What You See Is the Real You
description: it _was, I believe, the distinguished Nebraska financier Father Edward J. Flanagan who professed to having never met a bad boy. Having, myself, met a remarkable number of bad boys, it might seem that either our experiences were drastically different or we were using the word bad differently. I suspect neither is true, but rather that the Father was appraising the inner man, while I, in fact, do not acknowledge the existence of inner people.

Too small, said the bank.

title: Back To Basics

After being preoccupied for months with personalities, bank balances, filibusters and other trivialities, the capital of the United States is finally talking again about the fundamental problems of national and world politics.

title: How to Get There
description: From New York City, the best way to get to the party in Albany by car is up the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, about 140 miles, to Exit 23, where signs will point the way to free parking lots. Free shuttle buses will be available there and at parking lots on the periphery of the city, at the State Office Building campus on Washington Avenue, off Exit 24 of the Thruway, and at the SterlingWinthrop plant on Route 9, on the east side of the Hudson River in Rensselaer. No public parking will be allowed at the Mall on Saturday.

title: Two U.S. Attorneys Named

title: Anton Schutz, 83, Started Graphic Society in 1925; W ell Known for Etchings
description: Anton Schutz, founder and former president of the New York Graphic Society whose etchings of American cities appeared in The New York Times Magazine and other periodicals 50 years ago, died yesterday at the White Plains Hospital after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 4 Heathcote Road in Scarsdale. N.Y.

title: STAGE Zoe Dominic Jessica Tandy and Hume Cronyn in D. L. Coburn's play, The Gin Game,
description: IT IS A fine and deadly mechanism of destruction that The Gin Game sets up for the man and woman who have come to their final shelter in an old people's home.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: DURING THE LAST two decades, when vibrant communities in many parts of New York City have declined, sometimes into virtual wastelands, a section of northwest QueensAstoriathat was beginning to slump, has been turned around and is now booming. New homes have arisen, and old ones have been renovated. Empty stores have become prosperous businesses, and desolate buildings have become thriving factories.

title: U.S. Says New York Is Maintaining Thousands of Segregated Classes
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare accused the New York City public school system yesterday of maintaining several thousand illegally segregated classrooms, and ordered the school authorities to submit within 45 days plan for desegregating them.

title: The Past Haunts Brothers Who Own Convicted Sports Empire
description: BUFFALOOver the years the neighborhood around Main and Tupper changed; what was once this city's heart became its soul. A number of stores began advertising Afro wigs, others offered instant credit and many simply stood vacant. The movie theaters showed the latest in KungFu films. At night, you walked these mean streets at your own risk.

title: Dollar Falls Sharply Against Yen
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6The yen rose in value today against the dollar and for the first time since February 1973 the dollar closed below 260 yen, a level that had been considered a barrier to the dollar's decline.

title: WEST SEES AN OIL CUT AS NO BAR TO GROWTH
description: PARIS, Oct. 6The Western industrial nations can curb their oil consumption without abandoning plans for faster economic growth and lower unemployment, a meeting of energy ministers concluded here today.

title: Around the Nation

title: Abortion Is Top Issue for A.C.L.U.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has decided to make its top priority for the coming year a campaign to preserve the right of women to obtain abortions if they choose.

title: 4COUNTY UNIT FEARS ATOM PLANT MISHAP
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 6The head of a committee representing four New Jersey coastal counties said today that because they fear an accident at the proposed floating nuclear power plant off this resort could adversely affect tourism, they plan to ask the Federal District Court in Camden to prohibit the plant's construction unless the utilities post bonds. These bonds, he said, will have to be sufficient to cover losses that might be incurred by any private property owner.

title: Ballesteros Is Victor Over Watson by 5 and 4
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. {UPI)Severiano Ballesteros of Spain defeated Tom Watson, 5 and 4, today in the 36hole quarterfinals of the $225,000 World matchplay golf tourhament.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 3.9%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17 InIlion tonmiles, up 3.9 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 494,728 cars, up 2 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5.1 percent from a year ago.

title: FILM Leonard de Raemy/SVema Dominique Sunda in Bernardo BertoluccPs film 1900,
MUSEUMS Paul Cezanne's Portrait of Ambroise Vollard from an exhibition of the artist's late work at the Museum of Modern Art. See Page C19.
description: FOR THE LARGE PUBLIC nowadays interested in modern painting, there is one name above all that reverberates with a special powerone name that sounds with an almost religious resonanceand that is the name of Paul Cezanne (18391906). In the classroom and in the museum, among both specialists and amateurs, and in the hearts and minds of innumerable living artists, Cezanne's is the art that seems to stand at the center of everything. What Matisse once said of himthat he was the father of us all"posterity has eagerly and abundantly confirmed in each subsequent generation.

title: Ailing Puerto Rican in 1954 Attack On Congress Is Freed by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)The Puerto Rican nationalist Andres Figueroa Cordero was released from prison in Springfield, Mo., today, three hours after President Carter cut his sentence to the 23 years he has already served for his part in an armed attack on Coneress in 1954.

title: Notes on People
description: Kitty Kallen, the singer who had a long list of hit recordings in the 1950's, won a $300,000 judgment yesterday against a dermatologist and the drug company whose product he prescribed for her. Miss Kallen, perhaps best know for her renditions of Little Things Mean a Lot and In the Chapel in the Moonlight, contended in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that in 1966 she consulted Dr. Norman Orentreich for treatment of certain small wrinkles in her face. He precribed

title: Music: British Night at the Philharmonic
description: IT IS ONE of those immutable rules formulated by Aristotle or somebody: British conductors conduct British music. Thus Andrew Davis, at last night's New York Philharmonic concert, devoted the first half of the program to music of his compatriots. There was, first, Sir Edward Elgar's In the South, and that was followed by the Violin Concerto by Benjamin Britten.

title: Arntrak Derailment Explained
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)The derailment of an Amtrak train that injured 93 persons near Ralston, Neb., last year was caused by the lateral movement of a rail as the train moved through a curve, the National Transportation Safety Board said today. The locomotive and II cars1 derailed on the Burlington Northern railroad last Dec. 16, Three of the cars tipped over and slid 40 feet down an embankment.

title: A Strong Signal for Public Broadcasting
description: The Carter Administration's proposed bill on public broadcasting, designed to encourage American programming and reduce bureaucratic bickering, opens up a fresh prospect for noncommercial television and radio. Over the past decade, public broadcasting has brought many hours of pleasure and enlightenment to millions, but it is still far from realizing its potential.

title: A Loan and Some Sweat Equity Create an Oasis Amid Desolation
description: Three years ago, the tan brick apartment house at 1186 Washington Avenue in the Morrisania section of the Bronx looked so much a part of the square miles of desolation around it that city officials were loath to lend $310,000 to the young people who wanted to restore it.

title: Politics With Toughness

title: CEMETERIES
CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.4% IN AUGUST, 0.E.C.D. SAYS
description: PARIS, Oct. 7 (Reuters)  Consumer prices in the major industrial countries increased by fourtenths of a percent in August, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

title: Carey Lists $1.5 Billion in New York City Projects Pending Bond Issue
description: Governor Carey yesterday released list of projects totaling $1.5 billion that he said could be built in New York City if the state's proposed economicdevelopment bond issue was approved by voters next mpnth. His announcement immediately led Mayor Beame to warn that the city might have been shortchange.d.

title: People and Business
description: Count Otto Lambsdorff was appointed yesterday by President Walter Scheel of West Germany to be Economics Minister, succeeding Hans Friderichs. Mr. Friderichs announced last month that he would resign to become a director of the Dresdner Bank in Frankfurt, filling the vacancy left when the bank's chairman, Jiirgen Ponto, was fatally shot by terrorists in an attempt to kidnap him from his Frankfurt home on July 30.

title: Martin Looks Past Game
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct 7After we beat Larry Gura tomorrow, I'll come back with my bestand that means Ron Guidry, croaked Billy Martin tonight in a voice made raspy and all but inaudible from shouting at umpires.

title: The Screen: 'Oh, God!' Is a Joke
description: "Oh, God!" is either a one-joke movie or a two, depending upon how you feel about John Denver's acting debut. The Lord, in the form of George Burns, chooses a Tarzana, Calif., super-market manager (Mr. Denver) to spread the message that "what we have down here can work." Mr. Burns, who makes a number of house calls, wears a fishing cap and tennis shoes and says things like "so help me, me" when he is sworn in at a concluding trial sequence. Mr. Denver, when he is asked why the Lord chose him as a messenger, says things like "God only knowsI mean . . ." Though it isn't much of a contest, Mr. Burns readily emerges as the funnierIn all fairness, neither actor has the kind of part that can be played strictly for laughs. Mr. Denver, who is compared by the screenplay with Moses, Jesus, Einstein and Joan of Arc, asks some decidedly unfunny Big Questions: "If you're so involved with us, how can you permit all the suffering that goes on in the world?" Mr. Burns doesn't exactly supply the corresponding Big Answers, but he does provide a modicum of spiritual guidance. "You have the strength that comes from knowing," he tells his protg.Mr. Burns also makes a lot of wisecracks, which aren't entirely compatible with the movie's underlying sanctimoniousness. God doesn't look forward to Doomsday, Mr. Burns says; there will be "a lot of yelling and screaming, and I don't need that any more than you do."As directed by Carl Reiner, "Oh, God!" is an uneasy amalgam or inconsistent attitudes, without enough humor or zaniness to divert attention from its questionable premise. But Mr. Burns is amusing even when his material is substandard. And Mr. Denver, though he is unable to convey any emotion more complex than enthusiasm, is obviously trying.Mr. Reiner has marshaled an impressive supporting cast, including Ralph Bellamy as a trial lawyer and Teri Garr as Mr. Denver's frazzled wife, who lives with him in a cluttered suburban house where all the domestic debris looks brand new. The religious leaders of the world are played by Barry Sullivan, Donald Pleasence, Jeff Corey and Paul Sorvino, but of these only Mr. Sorvino has been given anything to do. He plays an evangelist in white shoes who boasts of having "personally . . . been chosen to render the benediction at this year's Super Bowl."The film's only other dashes of genuine levity come when Mr. Burns scares up a rainstorm inside Mr. Denver's compact car and when Mr. Denver appears on the "Dinah Shore Show" and tries with the help of a police artist, to come up with God's portrait."Oh, God!" is rated PG "Parental Guidance Suggested") because Mr. Burns made a few harmless jokes about Adam and Eve, and because Mr. Denver appears barechested several times. These latter scenes are not likely to be mistaken for erotica.

title: STEELMAKERS CITED AS INFLATION SOURCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7A comprehensive Government report on the steel industry has characterized the beleaguered industry as a source of serious inflationary pressures in the American economy.

title: Carter Asks Democratic Leaders To Help Him on Panama Treaties
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Carter, conceding for the first time that ratification of the proposed Panama Canal treaties was in doubt, called on the Democratic Party leadership today to help him win over Congressional and public support on this most controversial of subjects.

title: Senate Votes Labor Law Changes, Including Higher Minimum Pay
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Senate turned back today a series of efforts to fix a lower minimum wage and then voted to accept major amendments to the Fair Labor Standards Act, including higher minimum wage. The vote was 63 to 25.

title: PHILIP L. WELLENS
description: Philip L. Wellens, who retired in 1438 as an assistant New York City corpori.lion counsel, died this week in Glengariff Nursing Home, Glen Cove, L.I. He was 70 years old and lived at 353 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Rev. Louis R. Gigante has decided to appeal the ruling of Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court that he must answer questions before a grand jury regarding his alleged efforts to gain special privileges for an organizedcrime figure in city correctional facilities.

title: RADIOACTIVE GAS LEAKS AT NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP)The Nuclear Regulatory Commission reported today that a small amount of radioactive gas was leaked into the atmophere earlier this week at three times the rate permitted at the Philadelphia Electric Company's nuclear power plant near York, Pa.

title: ALL CARGO IS HALTED IN NEW ORLEANS PORT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 7While other Atlantic and Gulf ports are experiencing a selective strike preventing the handling of containerized cargo, this Mississippi River port, the nation's second largest port, is in the grip of an unauthorized walkout that has halted the movement of all cargo.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS FELL FROM 7.1% IN AUGUST TO 6.9% IN SEPTEMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The nation's unemployment rate dropped slightly to 6.9 percent in September, the Labor Department reported today, but Government officials said that there was little longterm improvement in the situation, particularly for blacks.

title: House Inquiry Into Tongsun Park Subpoenas O'Neill's Rent Records
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The House ethics committee has authorized a subpoena for the rent records of the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, in an investigation of an allegation that his rent had been paid by Tongsun Park, the fugitive Korean political agent.

description: GENEVA, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Negotik tors from morethan 70 countries tonigfit approved the text of a new internation agreement to bring world sugar supplies into line with demand and to raise tlia present depressed freemarket price.

title: Wolfgang Rose, Pianist and Teacher Accompanied Elman and Olevsky
description: Wolfgang Ros, a New York pianist and teacher, died Sept. 6 while vacationing in Bad Tatzmannsdorf, Austria. He was 70 years old.

title: Rikers Escapee Holds Wife Hostage 9 Hours
description: Anthony J. Ricco, a convicted rapist who escaped from Rikers Island prison Sunday night, held his wife hostage for nearly nine houri on East 108th Street yestrday. Left: Mr. Ricco and his wife, Yolanda, peer out of their apartment window. Above Mrs. Ricco hands her husband's gun to police on fire escape. Right: Mr. Ricco being led from building after giving up. Page 36.

title: 7 PBS Stations Reject Klansman and Nazi Interview
description: Publictelevision stations in Chicago, Illoston, Atlanta, St. Louis, Dallas, Miami and Detroit, among other major cities, have rejected a controversial episode of Black Perspective on the News on which the leaders of the Ku Klux Klan and the American Nazi Party, as interview guests, make racist and antiSemitic remarks.

title: Japanese Criticism Stirs Dismay in Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 7Is the Canadian labor force overpaid, short on productivity and inclined to strike? Are corporate taxes too high? Environmental laws too strict? Is the United States better place for foreign investors?

title: United Press International
Rembrandts Are Badly Damaged In Acid Attack in West Germany
description: KASSEL, West Germany, Oct. 7 (AP)Vandals threw acid on three paintings by Rembrandt in a gallery here today, badly damaging them, officials said.

title: Jersey Plans to End Dumping of Sewage Into Ocean by 1982
description: TRENTON, Oct. 7Officials said today that within four years the state would end the dumping of sewage sludge into the waters off New Jersey and Long Island that is blamed at least in part for recent fish kills and the fouling of beaches.

title: Mixed Reaction on Holocaust Study
description: The new Holocaust curriculum for the New York City school system was sharply criticized yesterday by Arab and German groups and highly praised by Jewish and black organizations.
