title: Justice Reimposes Concorde Ban
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the United States Supreme Court yesterday reimposed the ban on flights of the supersonic Concorde airliner to New York to give the full court a chance to deal with the matter.

title: Jersey Track Seeks Trots In January
description: TAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 7Meadowlands racing officials have decided to ask for a return to harness racing at the start of 1978. They have the alternative of resuming the current thoroughbred meeting in January but will instead request harness dates as more practical for winter racing.

title: Oct. 7,1777: The Beginning of the End at Saratoga
description: The German mercenaries were firing steadily from their redoubt. From the rear came the crack of rifles. A general mounted and, his sword flashing, led the riflemen into the redoubt. German resistance collapsed. The Battle of Saratoga was over.

title: 2 Convicted of Passing $ 1 Million in Bad Bills
description: Two men were convicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of having headed a ring that produced and distributed more than $1 million worth of counterfeit $20 bills.

title: Folklore Alive and Contemporary at Smithsonian Festival
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  Several years ago, the Smithsonian Institution salvaged an entire classroom from the Dunham School in Cleveland as it was being demolished and set it up as museum exhibit here. This week, five former students and teachers from the Ohio school came to Washington as part of the Smithsonian's annual Festival of American Folk Life.

title: Alaska Oil Transit Expected To Aid Panama Canal Tolls
description: PANAMA CITYThe Panama Canal Company is looking to Alaska oil heading for the East Coast to increase its revenues in expectation of a new canal treaty that will require vastly increased payments to be made to the Panamanian Government.

title: Soviet Adopts a New Constitution With Little Change
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7The Soviet Union today adopted a new Constitution, which, apart from minor changes in language, is essentially the same as the draft made public in June. The subsequent months of a carefully orchestrated discussion in the controlled press appear to have made little substantive difference in the final adopted version.

title: 16 Artists Perform at Met Benefit
description: The Metropolitan Opera does not officially open its season until Monday evening, but the house was buzzing with activity and resounding with music Thursday night. The occasion was the Met's third annual marathon drive for money and 16 Met singers donated their services.

title: Pinch Hits in Ninth Key 3Run Rally With 2 Outs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7Down to their final out, trailing by two runs, hurt by their own errors and far from the comfort of their Hollywood cheerleaders, the Los Angeles Dodgers suddenly scored three runs in a wild ninth inning today to upset the Philadelphia Phillies by 65 and move within one game of the National League pennant.

title: Schmidt to Buy Rheingold
description: The Chock Full of Nuts Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a contract to sell its Rheingold Breweries division, which makes beer in Orange, N.J., to C. Schmidt & Sons Inc. of Philadelphia, also brewers. In addition to Rheingold beer, the division makes Knickerbocker and Gablinger brand beer. No terms were disclosed.

title: Business Records
Europe Is Pressed On Single Currency
description: PARIS, Oct. 7The President of the Common Market Commission launched new drive today to give the nine member countries a single currency that could rival the dollar as a pillar of the internetional monetary system.

title: DISABLED POLICEMAN TO HEAD BOMB SQUAD
description: A police sergeant whose body is still riddled with fragments from the explosion last year of a terrorists bomb was named commander of the New York City Police Department's bomb squad.

title: 3 Iniured Players Return
description: Three Jet regulars who had been expected to miss Sunday's game may start. If not, they can play if needed.

title: MCA PREPARING OFFER FOR COAST COCACOLA
description: MCA Inc., the huge entertainment company, disclosed yesterday that it was prepared to pay about $140 million in cash for the CocaCola Bottling Company of Los Angeles.

title: Billions Are at Stake in California As LandWater Fight Nears End
description: BRAWLEY, Calif., Oct. 5In this hot dusty corner of America, where, as by alchemy, men, mules and water from afar turned a wasteland into one of the world's richest agricultural valleys, a long and bitter battle over land and water is nearing a decision.

title: Futures in Copper Gain Strength; December Closes at 57.30c a Pound
description: Copper futures, which have been in the doldrums recently, managed to show some strength yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. The December delivery closed at 57.30 cents a pound, up sixtenths of a cent. This compares with its contract high of 75.60 cents on July 6, 1976 and a low of 53.20 last Aug. 16.

title: About New York
description: On the classroom blackboard there were chalked rows of ideas like M 2xX3 + 3xy.2. A visitor could only thank Pythagoras that this was left over from a simpler science and was not the lesson plan of Stephen Berger in his attempt to explain how the wonderful world of politics regularly gives us such phenomena as the fiscal crisis and the Nelson Rockefeller era.

title: Nixon Gives a Political Speech
description: CORONA DEL MAR, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)  Richard M. Nixon, in what may have been his first political speech since he resigned the Presidency three years ago, has told group of Republicans that fighting spirit is more important to a political candidate than money,

title: Dying Whistle for WhippanyToonerville
description: WHIPPANY, Oct. 7.Old engine No. 148 is nearing the end of the line. Each summer and early wall weekend for the last 12 years the 57yearold steam locomotive has plied the five miles of track between here and Morristown as the chugging, smokebillowing showpiece of the WhippanyToonerville Railroad, a fourcar remembrance of railroading's bygone excursion era of the early 1900's.

title: British Lending Rate Is Pared 1/2% to 51/2%
description: LONDON, Oct 7, (Reuters)The Bank of England today reduced its minimum lending rate by onehalf percent to five and a half percent one year to the day after it was raised to an unprecedented 15 percent at the height of Britain's financial crisis.

title: Cuomo Urges Panel on Racial Makeup of Teachers
description: Mario M. Cuomo said last night that if he was elected Mayor he would seek to resolve a growing controversy over the reassignment of public school teachers by race by appointing a citizens panel to find the least disruptive means of balancing the racial composition of the 51,500member teaching staff.

title: A Feast ThatWon't EatUp Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7So you want to save on your energy bills? Try making apple butter over an open fire. Or stuffing sausage by hand. Or baking your bread in woodburning beehive oven that looks like a tiny igloo.

title: NEW HOME PRICES ROSE  BY 6% IN 2D QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)The average price of a new house, buoyed by high demand, soared 6 percent to $54,700 between April and June of this year, the largest quarterly jump in four years, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Zaire Is Cited By ExIm Bank As a Defaulter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7John L. Moore Jr., head of the United States ExportImport Bank, disclosed today that Zaire had not paid $10.3 million in interest or fees on its $435 million debt to the bank since August and that prospects for repayment of principal on the loans in the near future were not promising. At the same time, Zaire has been making payments on its debt to commercial banks, he said.

title: ParisTokyo Nuclear Reprocessing Pact Is Viewed as a Blow to Carter
description: PARIS, Oct. 6An accord signed by Japan to have its used nuclear fuel reprocessed in a French installation appears to be another major challenge to President Carter's uphill campaign against the use of plutonium as a reactor fuel.

title: HAROLD F. NORTON
description: Harold F. Norton, who retired in 1965 as a partner in Norton, Lilly & Co., A New York shipping concern founded by his grandfather, John Norton, in 1841. died Thursday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 64 years old.

title: Senate Majority Leader Proposes Moratorium on Arms Sales to Iran
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 7  Senator Robert C. Byrd. calling the Carter Administration's record on curtailing arms sales somewhat disappointing, today urged an immediate moratorum on sales to Iran.

title: EXPOLICEMEN GIVEN $1 FINES IN SLAYING
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 7An allwhite jury in Huntsville. Tex., today imposed $1 fines and probation on two former Houston police officers accused of murder in the drowning death last May of Joe Campos Torres, a 27yearold Chicano.

title: CITY ON COAST IS PUZZLED BY ATTACKS ON PROPERTY
description: PETALUMA, Calif., Oct. 7A series of attacks directed against the property of city officials and culminating in an attempt to burn down a school where Mayor Helen Putnam is principal has puzzled investigators here.

title: Dr. Claude E. Heaton, Gynecologist, Teacher and Medical Historian
description: Dr. Claude E. Heaton, who retired In 1967 as professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University School of Medicine, died Sept. 30 in Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., He was 80 years old and lived in South Orleans, Mass.

title: Shift in Defense Slated
description: The trick in stopping O.J. Simpson, says John Ebersole, is to slow down and take it easy.

title: Miss Alcott Cards a 68, Takes Lead by a Stroke
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Amy Alcott shot a fourunderpar 68 today to take the firstround lead in a $50,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Around the Nation
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Oct. 7 (AP)The. deaths of three Scottish travelers in Spain four years ago are the first confirmed cases of the socalled legionnaires dis, case outside the United States, the National Center for Disease Control has reported.

title: Fiberglass Makers Rush To Meet Insulation Need
description: When energyconscious and comfortoriented homeowners try to find a way to insulate themselves from the harsh realities of the changing seasons they discover that 7 feet of brick equals 15 inches of wood or 6 inches of fiberglass.

title: Carter and the Dock Strike
description: The most arresting thing about the dock strike that has crippled shipping in ports from Maine to Texis for a week is the lack of any direct White House move to halt it.

title: Colgate Expected to Stay Undefeated and Unnoticed
description: When Colgate gained revenge by beating Rutgers, 230, in the Red Raiders first game this season, Coach Fred Dunlap of Colgate said, Now that that's over, let's get on with the 1977 season.

description: Incoming

title: ANDREW HAGSTROM, MAKER OF MAPS, 81
description: Andrew Gunnar Hagstrom, founder and retired president of the Hagstrom Map Company. 450 West 33d Street, died Sept. 24 in a hospital in St. Thomas, V.I.. after a brief illness. He was 87 years old. He had an estate in Englishtown, N.J., but had lived in St. Thomas in recent months.

title: Editorial Article 1  No Title
description: Thanks to an end run by a determined woman named Carolyn Pitts around the city fathers of Cape May, N.J., that community awoke one morning six years ago to find itself on the National Register of Historical Places, the official Federal listing of protected sites and buildings of architectural and historical value. Not just an old house or two, but the whole town. Surprise and consternation, to put it mildly, reigned at City Hall. Political lines were set in motion in an effort to have the designation quashed in Washington. Nothing availed; the listing remained.

title: Mandel Sentenced to Four Years, Suspended as Maryland Governor
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 7Gov. Marvin Mandel, convicted in Federal District Court six weeks ago of mail fraud and racketeering, was sentenced today to four years in prison.

title: Mrs. King Posts Upset Of Miss Navratilova
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 7 (AP)Eighthseeded Billie Jean King upset secondseeded Martina Navratilova by 64, 61 tonight to advance to the semifinals in the $75,000 Wyler Classic. Chris Evert, seeded No. 1, also gained the semifinals by defeating Ann Kiyomura, 6.2, 62.

title: Trenton Topics
description: The State Energy Commissioner, Joel R. Jacobson, said yesterday that despite optimism on the part of suppliers of natural gas that there will be enough fuel this winter, he was, nevertheless, concerned.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 7 (AP)The High Court here agreed today to hear a Government petition challenging the unconditional release of Indira Gandhi after her arrest earlier this week. But it did not set a date for the hearing, and court sources said it might be weeks before one is held.

title: Despite Conviction, of Youth, Debate Over TV Violence Continues
description: MIAMI, Oct. 7Ronny Zamora has been convicted, but the jury is still out on television, which, in the minds of many, was the codefendant in his muchpublicized trial here.

title: Texas Takes Futurity Trot
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 (UPI)Texas, showing his noted stamina, won the $100,000 Kentucky Futurity at the Red Mile today by taking the third and deciding heat.

title: ReCreations of Battle Set for This Weekend
description: Two mock recreations of the battle of Saratoga are to be held this weekend. More than 300 militiamen are expected to participate.

title: VATICAN AIDE ASKS REDS TO END CURBS ON RELIGION
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7 (AP)The Vatican representative at the European security conference today criticized religious restrictions in Communist countries and asked freedom of worship for Eastern Rite Catholics in the Soviet Union.

title: Time to Fight the City's Budget Bulge
description: It's hard to keep budgets in trim, and the gap in New York City's fiscal 1979 budget is bulging already. Only three months ago, it appeared that the next mayor would start his first budget exercise with an $86million deficit. Now the prospective figure is almost $400 million, and many uncertainties remain to be faced.

The first book printed in hyphenated NewYork was entitled: A Narrative of an Attempt Made by the French of Canada Upon the Mahaques Country, with a subtitle explaining that the Indian tribes in this area were under the protection of their Majesties Government of NewYork.

description: Brooks Kerr. who is reputed to have known every Duke Ellington composition by the time he was 8 years old and is now a ripe old 25, opened an engagement of indefinite length Thursday night at Larson's, 1160 Third Avenue, at 68th Street. Two Ellington alumni, Russell Procope on reeds and Aaron Bell on bass, and a drummer, Shelton Gary, are in his band. Mr. Kerr tends to settle into engagements for long periods, and if this one lasts as long as the others, Larson's will bear repeated visits.

title: HardRock Concert by Iggy Pop Is One of the Finest in Memory
description: Iggy Pop, who appeared Thursday night at the Palladium, is widely regarded as one of the main forebears of presentday punk rock. With the Stooges he made raw, theatrically crude rock in the late 1960's and early 70's, when that was hardly a popular thing to do. After a couple of years retirement, the victim of a collapse induced partly by drugs, he returned to recordmaking and live performing under David Bowie's aegis. Yet for all of this, the accidents of scheduling made Thursday's the first performance by Iggy that this reporter had ever seen.

title: Political ShakeUp Strengthens Hold of Burma's Leader
description: RANGOON, BurmaA major political shakeup is under way in this oneparty nation of more than 30 million people, but the power of the leader, President Ne Win, appears unthreatened.

title: ExPlumbers Union Aide Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA Oct. 7 (UPI)A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted James J. O'Neill, retired business manager of Plumbers Union Local 690, on charges of accepting $88,000 in kickbacks, evading income taxes and filing false statements.

title: 'Piece of the Action' Is on Side of the Angels
description: Sidney Poitier has done it again. What he has done again is his hit movie "To Sir, With Love." But he has done it with a difference, an obvious social purpose and a new name: "A Piece of the Action."This movie, which opened yesterday at the Criterion, 86th Street East and Eastside Cinema theaters is, at heart, a candy-coated training film, four-square in favor of industry, honesty, courtesy, matrimony and culture; dead-set against wasted lives, ignorance, defeatism, sloth, senseless impudence, drugs and organized crime.The candy-coating consists of a caper plot that enmeshes Mr. Poitier and Bill Cosby as a pair of independent, ingenious and hugely successful thieves with angry and vengeful underworld victims and with crooked and manipulative police.Set inside the candy-coating is the training film: "To Sir, With Love," recycled for domestic identification and trans-shipped from a school in a London slum to a black-operated community center in a rundown neighborhood in Chicago.There, Mr. Poitier and Mr. Cosby, each blackmailed by an unknown man who apparently knows enough about their crimes to send them to prison, find themselves reluctant volunteer members of the staff.Mr. Cosby works in the administrative end, where he finds a good deal of amelioration of his plight in the form of Lila French, the center's director, vivaciously portrayed by Denise Nichols. And Mr. Poitier, thanks to a coin flip, finds himself in a familiar classroom.Here are 30 rambunctious young black men and women for whom he and Mr. Cosby must find jobs although they are clearly less than prime candidates for employment.Well, Mr. Poitier has been here before. As star and director, he knows precisely what to do with them, He uses them for little performing tours de forceto frighten and wound with their toughness; to amuse with their street talk, their irreverence, their flippancy; to wrench tears with their vulnerability; and, of course, to bend to his will, absorb his lessons about self-esteem and consideration for others and ultimately to serve as illustrations that adversity can be overcome.When all the didacticism threatens to reduce the pace to that of sludge, Mr. Poitier takes advantage of several options: he can concern himself and Mr. Cosby with unraveling the mystery of their blackmailer (it gives away nothing to reveal him to be James Earl Jones, playing a retired policeman whose late wife founded the community center); he can strike a slightly grudging blow for matrimony by arranging for an unexpected visit from the dismayed, religious parents of the woman he has been living with; he can espouse culture by tossing in a dressy night on the town that takes him, Mr. Cosby and their dates to a performance by the Dance Theater of Harlem; or he can stir up suspense by looking in on the Mafia types who are determined to kill him for robbing them.In short, Mr. Poitier has provided something for just about everyone, including those who might be concerned about the question of all this moralizing coming from a character who is introduced as a criminal."A Piece of the Action" is firmly on the side of the angels. It is possible to criticize its lack of originality and its transparent slickness; but these are flaws that must be balanced against its evident craftsmanship, its entertainment and its social conscience.The PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested" rating seems primarily attributable to the street language.

He said nine male cadets have been implicated and the investigation is ongo. ing. The spokesman, Will Ketterson, said he did not know whether the cadets, who were not identified, had been charged in connection with the raid.

title: Clifford Brown Lives in a Tribute
description: The Tribute to Clifford Brown at New York University's Loeb Student Center on Thursday was a happy event, musically and extramusically. In the latter category, it was gratifying to see the first Highlights in Jazz concert of the season sell out, although more than 100 fans were turned away. And it was a moving experience to hear Max Roach, who coled a celebrated quintet with Clifford Brown before Mr. Brown's untimely death in an automobile accident, reminisce about his departed friend.

title: Film Festival: 1900
description: Bernardo Bertolucci's 1900 is a fourhour, fiveminute (plus intermission) movie that covers approximately 70 years of Italian social and political history, from 1901, the year Verdi died and peasants were still in bondage to the landowners, to the 1970's, when capitalist movie producer would put up millions of dollars to make a film such as 1900, which is essentially a Marxist romance. This is progress of a very particular sort.

title: Rudolph Bochco, 77, Violinist; Appeared With Top Artists

Of Russian extraction, he was born in Poland and was brought to the United States when he was 3 years old. He studied with the famous teacher Leopold Auer and toured extensively in the 1920's and 1930's, frequently appearing with such artists as Titta Ruffo, baritone; Arthur Rubinstein, pianist, and John McCormack, tenor.

title: Notes on People
description: A Government spokesman confirmed reports in Stockholm that extraordinary efforts were being made to persuade Ingmar Bergman to return to live in Sweden, which he left last year after saying the tax authorities were harassing him. The spokesman said that SanErik Wikstroem, the Minister of Education and Culture, met secretly with Mr. Bergman in Stockholm last month at the home of Harry Schein, director of the Swedish not Institute. Mr. Wikstroem called Mr. Bergman one of Sweden's foremost cultural personalities and said. It is therefore very distressing that he will not work in Sweden. Mr. Bergman sold his assets in Sweden after he was accused of tax evasion, and moved to Munich to live and work.

title: Dance: Boston Group Appealing

This is the Concert Dance Company of Boston, and Thursday night it made its New York debut at the American Theater Laboratory on West 19th Street. It is a neat and tiny model of how such companies should be regulated.

title: Books of The Times
description: With the waning over recent decades of serious infectious and nutritional diseases as major killers and health problems in the industrialized countries, we now face the impact from the more than 2,000 known genetic or hereditary diseases. About one person in 10 in Western society, or 22 million Americans, is seriously affected by genetic disease, mental retardation or birth defect. Up to 30 percent of admissions to the major children's hospitals in this country are due to genetic diseases. Some are known at birth or in infancy, while the symptoms of others may not strike until the fifth or sixth decade.

title: East Is East and West Is Ahead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7  In one town, Frank Sinatra throws out the first pitch, television cameras panning the stands linger on the cameo features of Don Rickles, and the customers come to the park partly for baseball and partly to see Beautiful People who come to be seen. In the other town, the first ball is thrown out by Paul Owens, former first baseman for Olean, N. Y., and the customers are involved in the game almost as intimately as the pitcher. The manager in Los Angeles is gabby, ebullient, an idolator of celebrities who revels in the tinsel and makebelieve of Hollywood and Sports Malibu. of The Philadelphia manager is a big, slowThe Times moving guy with a slouching gait and name that would fit a hillbilly in a comic strip. There aren't two cities in America less alike than Los Angeles and Philadelphia Or two men in the National League more dissimilar than Tommy Lasorda and Danny Ozark, but their teams played the same kind of baseball todaytacky.

title: WONDERS OF IRISH ART
description: It's a long way from Tipperarynot to mention Dublinbut some of Ireland's foremost art treasures have made the trip and this week will go on view at the Metropolitan Museum. Seventy objects, ranging from armlets and shields of the Bronze Age, a trumpet and a boar from the Roman era. shrines, brooches, crucifixes and manuscripts from Early Christian to Gothic times, have been lent by the National Museum of Ireland, Trinity College in Dublin, and the Royal Irish Academy for an exhibition that will tour the U.S for more than a year after it closes at the Metropolitan on Jan. 15.

title: BOOK ENDS

She was in black, and her stance had a disturbing mixture of both rejection and accusation. The woman in that dream, Mr. Fowles always assumed, had a white face. Now he thinks that interpretation was incomplete.

title: Cruel Treatment
description: KAREN ANN is a story that might have been written by Franz Kafka. An ordinary middleclass family, whose young daughter is trapped in an irreversible coma induced by unknown causes, decides that maintaining her life by an artificial respirator is a pointless and needlessly cruel treatment. Following the advice of their parish priest, they ask that the treatment be terminated and their daughter be permitted to die with dignity. Note well: they do not ask that she be killed. They merely ask that she be permitted to die.

title: Homeland, for Example, Is Fraught With Special Meaning in the Mideast
description: For a brief moment last week, the Carter Administration's patient efforts to reconvene a Geneva conference on the Middle East seemed to hang on a single word. A communiqu produced over the weekend by the United States and the Soviet Union included a reference to the Palestinians' legitimate rights. The Israelis, and their supporters in the United States, were alarmed because Washington had previously spoken of Palestinian interests. The change, they were convinced, meant the Carter Administration was once again siding against them.

But such a showdown game is a rare occurrence.

title: ART VIEW
description: CHICAGO The art of the 1970's is going to present future art historians with some very knotty problems. Painting, sculpture and drawing will be able to be dealt with more or less as they have been in the past, and even some of the newer mixed media hybrids, to the extent that they result in objects or con structions that can be preserved and seen more or less intact, are unlikely to offer any special challenge. But there are now whole areas of artor what, in our reluctance to impose restrictive definitions, we agree to call art even if we do not always experience it as suchthat are very far both in conception and execution from anything the art historian has ever had to face in the past. In the case of certain forms of Conceptual art, for example, there will be little or nothing left for the future art historian to examine. Other branches of this art will leave behind a large quantity of literary documentation, acres of photographic materials, certain items of hardware, and immense bibliographies. But what will be left to look at? That will be the knottiest problem of all.

title: Rosalyn Tureck's 40Year Search for Bach
description: Rosalyn Tureck could not have foreseen as she crossed the Town Hall stage on Nov. 8, 1937, that she was about to begin something bigger than a series of six allBach recitals. She did know that some of the big New York promoters considered it almost suicidal to present a Bach marathon. And she knew that Bach, at that time, was too much feared and too little loved, as one critic put it, by concert audiences.

title: Alice Under Ground
description: he manuscript of Lewis Carroll's Alice's Adventures in Wonderland has been with us now for over 113 years. Charles Lutwidge Dodgson (Lewis Carroll's real name) wrote the story down in a notebook and gave it as a Christmas present in 1863 to 11yearold Alice Liddell, for whom he first invented the tale. Sixtyfour years later the famous Alice sold the manuscript book, and for 20 years after that it led a peripatetic life: it crossed the Atlantic twice, was twice sold at public auction and passed through the hands of many eminent dealers and collectors. In 1948 it finally, came to rest in the British Museum. It is almost impossible to believe, but it seems to be true, that through all those years that Alice owned the manuscript and through the 20 years of its travels it concealed a secret; one that Dodgson apparently carried to the grave when he died in 1898. It seems appropriate in the year when Lewis Carroll's suppressed wasp in a wig episode from Through the LookingGlass has been published for the first time that this secret should also come to light.

title: A HUGE OVERPAYMENT ON MEDICAID CHARGED
description: More than $30 million in improper, unacceptable and, above all, spendthrift duplicate payments from Medicaid funds were made to 27 diagnostic and treatment centers in New York State from 1971 to 1976, the Acting State Welfare Inspector General charged yesterday.

title: Congress Report Brings Dispute on Rail Efficiency
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Alice Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office, has clashed with mass transit officials in a dispute that could influence Congressional decisions on investment in transportation.

title: Dubrovnik: City Of 1,000 Years On the Adriatic
description: I was standing on the city's walls, sections of which go back more than a thousand years. Off in the distance were 700yearold monasteries, 500yearold fountains, 300yearold homes. The roofs of red, orange and brown tile sprouted television antennas. In what was once a moat were parking meters; children played ball against the medieval walls; and a Pan American 707 prepared to land at the airport.

title: Turnabout in Norwalk
description: NORWALK THE ELECTIONyear platforms of local political parties tend to be visionary pronouncements on increasing services while reducing taxes; they often dissolve in administrative and fiscal limitations after Election Day. The winners than switch to somber talk of hard realities and difficult decisions.

title: N.L.R.B. Bill: The Battle Rages On
description: WASHINGTON  The laborbacked bill to strengthen the National Labor Relations Board has triggered what George Meany, 83yearold president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., describes as the toughest legislative fight I have seen since I came to Washington almost 38 years ago.

title: Riggins and Green Help Glen Cove Stun Bethpage
description: Bethpage, unscored upon for the first 10 periods of its Nassau Conference HI season, yielded twice yesterday, the second time just 40 seconds from the end, and lost to Glen Cove in the process, 168.

title: Frazier Deal Is Set
description: The Knicks completed the deal yesterday that sent Walt Frazier to the Cleveland Cavaliers as compensation for the signing of Jim Cleamons, a free agent.

title: Tsetse Fly Spreading in WarTorn African Areas
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 8The tsetse fly, the scourge of African cattle and carrier of human sleeping sickness, is reportedly spreading over vast African regions where wars have interrupted campaigns to control it.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: VIRGINIA WOOLF AND HER WORLD, by John Lehmann. (HBJ/Harvest, $4.95.) An introduction the life and work of Virginia Woolf (18821941), the brightest ornament of the Bloomsbury Group, the coterie that illuminated British literary life from 1907 to World War II. A dispassionate, lucid discussion by a man close to it all, supplemented by more than 125 illustrations.

title: Politics and Love
description: THINGS THAT I DO IN THE DARK Selected Poetry. By June Jordan. 203 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $7.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: Actor Writing
description: NO, this is not just another movie star's memoir of those Great Hollywood years when everyone spouted San Goldwynisms. The author is Dirk Bogardenot merely a star but a marvelous actor. who in recent years has tended to choose roles in films that, while being doubtful at the box office, have had pretensions to art. His book may be accused of courting the same fate.

title: Deaths
description: ADELMANIda G., On October 4, mother of Brenda Weisman, grandmother of Julie Sara and Michael Peter. Services and Interment were private.

title: Where We Stand
description: Dear Jack: I was very surprised and disappointed to see your statement this week dealing with the agreement between the New York City Board of Education and the HEW Office for Civil Rights.

title: Marsh Conquers Floyd, 5 and 3, in Final
description: VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 8 (AP)Ray Floyd scoffed at the suggestion that an anonymous threat against his safety could have affected his play in a 5and3 loss to Graham Marsh of Australia in today's 36hole final of the world matchplay golf championship.

title: British Manufacturer Is Planning To Light Up 100 Million Cigarettes
description: LONDON, Oct. 8One of Britain's major cigarette manufacturers, Wills, is planning to make a bonfire next week of 100 million cigarettes containing a cellulose substitute for tobacco.

title: Suburban Myth, Mrs. and Ms.
description: LIKE the weather, everybody is talking about the plight of the suburban woman, but doing little if anything about it. Not any more, though, insist the organizers of an ambitious lecture series currently making the rounds of Long Island libraries.

title: DogControl Crisis Confronts the County
description: IN image and in fact, the dog is an ubiquitous part of life in the suburbs. The final fillip in the stereotype of a suburban family with several children, a house and a station wagon is a dog. In reality, the suburbs are home to dogs owned by families, young singles, the elderlyall types of peopleand to many dogs who have no owners at all.

title: Power Balance Tips to Congress From President
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The erosion of Presidential power and the ascension of Congress, begun by Democratic Congresses when Richard M. Nixon occupied the White House, has continued in the first nine months of the Carter Presidency, in the view of experts at both ends of Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: National Hockey League Preview: Canadiens Powerful Again
description: As the National Hockey League's 51st season opens Wednesday, the question is not whether the Montreal Canadiens will win the Stanley Cup for the third straight season, but rather in what manner they will do it.

title: Sutton Urges New York Return to CivilRights Tactics
description: Declaring that he is outside of the system now, and does not want anything from New York City, Percy E. Sutton, a defeated mayoral aspirant, is calling for a return to the tactics of the civilSights movement of the 1960's.

title: Court Settles Dispute Between Painters' Union and Its Head Office
description: A long dispute involving Painters District Council 9 here and its parents international organization has been settled by a court order that continues a trusteeship of the council but also directs that James D. Bishop remain as Secretarytreasurer.

title: Taking Stock of FuelSavers
description: BEDFORD HILLS MOSTLY fall days, although crisp and delightful, also remind most homeowners of the horrendous fuel bills to come. But Gene Podhurst, a horticulturist and a former teacher, is offering us chance to turn our backs, at least partly, on the oil companies and Consolidated Edison.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: Say you and a fellow tennis player have 30 minutes or an hour to spare and you decide to spend the time polishing your games rather than playing a set. How can each of you get the most out of this practice session?

title: Russians Lose Day Off Under New Charter
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7Most Soviet citizens will lose a holiday this year as a result of the adoption today of a new Constitution.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT WAS simply Gun Day, I guess. There I was, sitting home reading about the sheriff in Middlesex Countyhe had taken the guns away from 36 of his officers because they couldn't shoot straightwhen my wife asked if I'd like to go with her to one of her favorite fish markets.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON AN exhibition of nearly 150 drawings at the Princeton University Art Museum is a splendid tribute to the accomplishment of Italian draftsmanship. Most of the works are by masters of the Mannerist, Baroque and rococo styles, and these particular examples are outstanding endeavors.

title: Moorhead Helps Unbeaten Greeley Post 86 Triumph Over Scarsdale
description: Rick Moorhead, a senior quarterback, scored from 1 yard out with 10 seconds left to tie the score, and Moorhead then hit Paul Fleming with a conversion pass as Horace Greeley (30) turned back Scarsdale, 86.

title: Cynthia Vietor, Teacher, Bride
description: Cynthia Stewart Vietor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Vietor of Houston, was married there yesterday to George Kent Kahle, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Hermann Kahle of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Maurice M. Benitez performed the ceremony in St. John the Divine Episcopal Church.

title: Army vs. Notre Dame: The Way It Was
description: FOR 30 years now sentimental sports fans, myself included, have felt a singular twinge of sadness every fallever since the continuity of the traditionsteeped series of football games between Army and the University of Notre Dame was broken in 1947.

title: THE WAR THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: BEIRUT. The beautiful people are back at the swimming pool at the St. Georges Hotel, sauntering about in their string bikinis and fat gold chains. A waterskiing contest was held in the billowing Mediterranean a while back, and Julio Iglesias, a Spanish crooner, packed them in at the flashy Casino du Liban, which is located on the Christian side of Beirut. The backdrop for all this gay life has changed, though. The swimmers cannot enter the St. Georges building, which is scarred and brickedup at the windows; on the other side of Rue Ahmed Chaouqi, which a year ago was one of the nastier sniper's alleys in the city, rise the grayish battered wrecks of the Phoenicia Intercontinental and the Holiday Inn, fiercely contested in the civil war. At the Casino du Liban, a drunken man shows off his postwar chain of gold: It is made of fillings that he proudly says were extracted from the teeth of Palestinians killed during the 52day siege of the Tell Zaatar refugee camp. The rubble of the camp has been bulldozed flat; the deserted, shellblackened factories at Mkalles, where the Palestinians once worked, are dotted with weatherworn Lebanese flags.

title: New Hyde Park Scores Key Victory Over Carey
description: New Hyde Park defeated Carey yesterday, 207, in what could be the decisive game of the Nassau Conference IV season. The victory left New Hyde Park in sole possession of first place with a 30 wonlost record.

title: Who Says There Are No New Leading Ladies?
description: Once upon a time, they were discovered pret tily sipping sodas at Schwab's drugstore. IT doesn't happen that way any more; today, budding stars are more likely to be picked from drama classes, Broadway choruses, Off Off Broadway experiments and from the ?? gins, young and appealing women will never go out of style in Hollywood  though audiences may have suffered serious doubts over the past few seasons as they witnessed the passing parade of movies dwelling on male camaraderie.

title: Mary Wetmore Engaged
description: The Right Rev. J. Stuart Wetmore Suffragan Bishop of New York, and Mrs. Wetmore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Frances Wetmore, to John N. Bohun. son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bohun of Yonkers. The bridetobe, whose parents live in Scarsdale, N.Y., and her financ plan to be married next April.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The 27th annual St.. John's University interscholastic meet will be run at 10 A.M. Saturday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx with 2,100 athletes. They represent 120 high schools in New York. New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, Massachusetts, Vermont and New Hampshire. There will be three races for boys' varsities, four for boys' junior varsities and two for girls.

title: Waltrip Stock Car Victor As Chevrolets Dominate
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 8 (UPI)Darrell Waltrip won a duel from Donnie Allison to take the rainshortened 300mile Late Model Sportsman stock car race today at the Charlotte Motor Speedway. The top five cars in the race were Chevrolets.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE wise homeowner who devotes a day or two to giving the house a fall checkup each year will find that the time spent can go far toward lowering repair bills and operating costs and helping make the home more comfortable and troublefree in the winter.

title: Book Review October 9, 1977
GALLERY VIEW
description: The decorative arts are difficult. They demand of us a combination of qualities which not everyone can muster: knowledge, patience and the kind of imaginative participation that makes us understand why certain pieces were made at certain times. All this is very different from the swoon of enjoyment with which we sometimes drift through a picture gallery.

title: Senator Byrd's Strongest Belief Is In the Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senators had been shouting at him, interrupting him. Some were familiar antagonists from the past, who had opposed him in the past, but others were juniors not known for picking fights. Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, warned he was creating a dictatorship in the Senate.

title: MUSIC
description: TWELVE years ago, two groups of music lovers at opposite ends of the county came to independent conclusions that their communities deserved, and would support, firstquality chamber concerts. It took a lot of hard work, but their faith was justified. Now as the Association for the Performing Arts prepares to begin its new season in Yorktown Heights, and the Hudson River Museum dusts off its Yonkers auditorium for the opening musicale, it is nice to be able to salute them both.

title: Plight of the Suburban Woman Is Subject Of a New Lecture Series in L.I. Libraries
description: Like the weather, everybody is talking about the plight of the suburban woman, but doing little if anything about it. Not any more, though, insist the organizers of an ambitious lecture series currently making the rounds of Long Island libraries.

title: GARDENING
description: THE window gardener with a welldeveloped collecting instinct will have more fun specializing in some homogeneous group of plants than collecting hit or miss. (I do both.) But, whatever the method, your choice of plants is finally determined by the amount of light you can provide.

title: Polygamy, Growing in U.S. West, Is Encountering Little Opposition
description: DRAPER, UtahIn a big, old house in this small town south of Salt Lake City lives a sweetfaced, silverhaired retired schoolteacher. Rhea A. Kunz, 71, proudly shows off the pictures of her grandchildren on the wall of her cozy, untidy study. There are more than 70 of them, since Mrs. Kunz and her eight children are adherents of polygamy.

title: Entry for Ramapo Show Up 600 Dogs From '76
description: When a metropolitan allbreed show is the only one in the area but faces competition from a tough southern circuit, the committee has to be doing everything right to come up with almost 600 more entries than in the previous year. This is the 1977 Ramapo Kennel Club story with a total count of 1,777 dogs, compared with 1,190 in 1976. The date is Oct. 16 and the site, for the second year, is the scenic campus of Ramapo College of New Jersey in iRngwood, with parking for 2,000 cars.

title: Bali Again Shaken by Tremors
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 8 (UPI)Tremors today again shook Denpasar, capital of Bali, in the third quake to be registered in two days, the Antara news agency reported.

title: Exercise Girls No Longer the Exception Astride HalfTon Belmont Thoroughbreds
description: ELMONT. L.I.When Mary Ryan and Jill Gordon began galloping horses at Belmont Park about seven years ago, they were considered exceptions because most trainers were reluctant to let a woman handle a halfton thoroughbred worth thousands of dollars.

title: New England Sanctuary Planned
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 7 (AP)Civil De. fense. officials are developing plans to transform parts of New Hampshire, Vermont and Maine into a sanctuary for other New England residents if the United States: is threatened by nuclear attack. Under the program, called the crisis relocation plan, persons who live in more populated risk areas, such as southern New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Connecticut, would be evacuated to less populated host areas in northern New England.

title: Home Style
description: It is the idiot box, the boob tube and chewing gum for the eyeballs. But it is also our most popular piece of furniture or accessory. Nearly ninetenths of all American families have at least one working television set.

title: BUSSINESS CREDIT PLAN GAINS CABINET FOES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Many of the Carter Administration's urban policymakers are challenging an important component of the proposed tax reform package that they argue would accelerate industrial flight from older cities and undermine the Administration's commitment to urban development.

title: Levitt Audit Criticizes Operation Of a Palisades Park Commission
description: A New York State audit report on the operation of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, which runs Bear Mountain and 16 other parks in Orange, Rockland and Ulster Counties, gave the agency good marks yesterday for maintenance and recreational services, but said many financial practices neded to be improved.

title: U.D.C. Counsel Resigning
description: Edwin C. Cohen will leave his post as executive vice president and general counsel of the New York State Urban Development Corporation Oct. 15 to become a principal in McKinsey & Company, an international management consultant concern with offices at 245 Park Avenue. Mr. Cohen was appointed to the U.D.C. in June 1975 by Governor Carey, whose spokesman said yesterday that no decision had been made about his replacement.

title: Deaths
description: FORBESLula sister of Jan Juta, grandmother of Elizabeth GyleThompson Peeps, died in England Sep t 1977 after a short illness. Memorial Service Saturday, Oct 22, St. Bernard's Church, Bernardsville, N.J., 4 p.m.

title: On Toward Geneva
description: WASHINGTONFrom the outset, the Carter Administration's approach to Middle East diplomacy has seemed to stutter at times, to suffer from fits and starts followed by retreats and redefinitions. Indeed, it has had its blunders, but beneath the surface, it has been pursuing a far more purposeful line than outsiders have often been aware. And, behind the smoke, such was the case last week.

title: Letters: Plumbing in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Choate Sets Back Andover on RennetttoCroke Passes
description: Choate's outstanding passing combination of Jerryl Bennett, quarterback, and Paul Croke, split end, was too much for Andover to handle yesterday the visiting Connecticut eleven continued undefeated with a 2813 victory.

title: NADJARI, SANTUCCI BATTLING TO FINISH
description: On a drizzly afternoon last week Maurice H. Nadjari, once the most powerful prosecutor in the state, strode into a church gymnasium and told 50 elderly women gathered there for lunch why he should be the Queens District Attorney.

title: Success Story
description: David Sarnoff helped to change the way we live. He came from Russia to America in 1900; joined the American Marconi telegraph company at the age of 15; rose in the ranks of the Radio Corporation of America to become its chief executive for more than 40 years; and presided over the formation and growth of the first of the principal American broadcasting networks.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE wise homeowner who devotes a day or two to giving the house a fall checkup each year will find that the time spent can go far toward lowering repair bills and operating costs and helping make the home more comfortable and troublefree in the winter.

title: DEMOCRACY'S FUTURE UNDER A MICROSCOPE
description: ATHENS, Oct. 8A remarkable international assortment of leading politicians, historians, writers and other thinkers have just concluded an intensive threeday symposium here on the future of democracy with the conclusion that there definitely is one.

title: Exercise Girls Find Their Track
description: Elmont WHEN Mary Ryan and Jill Gordon began galloping horses at Belmont Park about seven years ago, they were considered exceptions because most trainers were reluctant to let a woman handle a halfton thoroughbred worth thousands of dollars.

title: Elderly Are Sharing Housing For Financial and Social Gain
description: WANTAGH, L.I.Until recently, Nettie Heule considered herself a lonely person. Although happily married, Mrs. Heule, after her husband left for work each morning, found herself constantly craving companionship in a community she moved to a year ago.

title: Winter Forecast: COLD
description: NEW BRUNSWIC THE annual survey of the unconventional weather experts is in, and the signs from the wooly worms, the bears, the squirrels, the skunk cabbage and the migrating teals point to another cold winter for the state. And one conventional expert, James Carr of Rutgers University, is inclined to agree, but for different reasons.

title: L.I. Legal Clinic Is Helping to Fill The Lawyer Gap
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.After his arrest for foraging in restricted waters, the amateur clammer was in a dilemma: He could not afford a lawyer, but he did not qualify for help from the statesupported Legal Aid Society.

title: A Great Neck Tennis Pro's Spaghetti Racquet Causes Opponents to Become Unstrung
description: GREAT NECK, L.I.You never know about Michael, said Peter Fishbach with a laugh. He comes and goes. I think he played recently in Iran. You can be sure he'll produce excitement wherever he is.

title: LETTERS
description: As a Juil'lard master's degree holder and as a human being, I think they did a good job of choosing the Earth's Greatest Hits (by Anne Druyan, Sept. 4). However, I am somewhat puzzled by our critics deciding against including more rock music. It's true that in comparison with other forms of music rock occupies a rather short period in our musical history, but it's also true that the music of the Beatles alone has been listened to and enjoyed by more human beings than the music of any other composer and perhaps all other composers combined in the recorded history of humankind. Admittedly, the population explosion and the machine age are responsible, but facts are facts, and the selectors may not have done the Earthlings of 1977 justice, factually or esthetically speaking.

title: South Africa Says Biko Was Part of Terrorist Threat
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 8The South African Government, facing mounting suspicion that the country's foremost young black leader was beaten to death by the police, may have launched a political counteroffensive designed to convince the public that the black consciousness movement the victim founded and led was part of a growing terrorist threat demanding stringent countermeasures.

title: Victoria's Bloomers Auctioned In London
description: LONDON, Oct. 7A pair of Queen Victoria's voluminous bloomers were auctioned here today for $280. They were catalogued by Bonham's, the auctioneers, as a pair of kneelength linen drawers with Royal Cypher on waistband.

title: Jets Remain Underdogs Against Bills
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 8It is a secret society, forming in a corner of the Jets' locker room where the offensive linemen hang their Tshirts marked X Large.

title: Frazier Deal Surprises Few Teammates, Foes
description: His uniform shirt, No. 10. still hung limply in the locker of the Knicks' dressing room last night, and the water bucket he had used to soak his aching feet after a game was shoved under his stool.

title: One Down, With Several to Go
description: STOCKHOLMThe Nobel Prizes, now in their 77th year, have established themselves as the world's most coveted and prestigious awards. Yet they are not without their critics. With the Nobel season at hand once more (the Prize in Literature was announced last week, and the other awards are due this week) some old questions are being raised again. Why is the selection procedure so secret? Why do the selecting bodies fail to recognizeor wait so long before recognizingseemingly obvious achievements? Why aren't more fields of endeavor honored?

title: Catholic Schools Attain Stability In Urban Cores
description: Diane Sanchez is a widow with two children who supports herself by working as a paraprofessional at St. Paul's Elementary School on 118th Street in East Harlem. Out of her income of $6,300 year, which includes Social Security benefits, she spends $1,100 in parochial school tuition and fees.

title: Islanders Tied by Flames, Ending Preseason at 343
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Oct. 8Coach Al Arbour was far from pleased tonight after the New York Islanders closed out their National Hockey League preseason with a 11 tie against the Atlanta Flames.

title: New York City Is Told to Tighten Its CollectiveBargaining Rules
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board has notified New York City that its collectivebargaining procedures must be change to provide for the suspension of union membership dues deductions in strikes by city employees.

title: White Councilman in New Orleans Wins Place in the Mayoral Runoff
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct 7Councilmanat large Joseph V. DiRosa, who has made high utility rates his major issue in 12 years on the City Council, has gained a spot in the runoff for Mayor. After a recount, Mr. DiRosa emerged as the No. 2 man in last Saturday's nonpartisan primary and will face a State Appeals Court judge, Ernest N. Morial, a black who was the clear frontrunner.

title: Cleveland Teachers May Skip Pay While School Board Seeks Funds
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 7 (AP)Cleveland schoolteachers may work without pay to keep the schools from closing after next week.

title: Alabama Withstands Rally And Upsets U.S.C., 2120
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (AP)Tony Nathan, an Alabama halfback, ran for two touchdowns in the fourth quarter today, and the Crimson Tide withstood a furious rally by the University of Southern California in the final seven minutes to post a 2120 college football upset.

title: Two Psychology Professors
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8On the itinerary issued to the Yankees for this visit to the heart of America, the message was prematurely optimistic. If we win on Saturday, proclaimed the itinerary, we will fly home right after the game. Have your luggage packed and in the lobby before you go to the park.

title: POLITICS
description: THE nice thing about publicopinion polls is that there is usually something in them for everyone. In the race for Governor, Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican candidate from Somerville, was generally conceded by everybody, including Governor Byrne, to have the early lead, at least up to the end of September.

title: Erie Cocke, 82, ExChief of F.D.I.C.
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 8 (AP)Erie Cocke Sr., a former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and past president of the American Bankers Association, died here yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Debra Lividini Is Married To John Di Betta in Harrison
description: Debra Lividini, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Xavier S. Lividini of New York and Harrison, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to John Di Betta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Di Betta of Harrison. The Rev. William E. Williams performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great in Harrison.

title: A Venture Afield Unites a Family On a Golden Day
description: There were two cars, each loaded down with people and vacation gear: water skis sticking out of windows, duffle bags full of swimsuits, tennis rackets and golf clubs. As the cars moved out of the driveway, a neighbor asked about our destination.

title: This Round, at Least, Was Mrs. Gandhi's
description: As she had predicted, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was arrested fast week on charges of official corruption. But even Mrs. Gandhi must have been surprised by the reaction to the arrest. In an implicit rebuke to the new democratic coalition Government, a magistrate ordered her release because he said there were no reasonable grounds for believing the accusations. Demonstrations in her support were held in many parts of India and the reading newspaper, Times of India, said the affair had seriously undermined the credibility of the Janata Government.

title: The Wheel of Fortune: Turnabouts for 3 Men in the Public Eye
description: The fortunes of three men in the public eye experienced abrupt turnabouts last week when a movie mogul resigned under a cloud, a television executive quit and a wheelerdealer West Coast tax lawyer was exonerated in court.

title: Goodman Sets A Drive to Buy RadioTV Time
description: New York Political Notes

title: Jeffrey Dunlop Weds Frances C. Glennon
description: Frances C. Glennon and Jeffrey F. Dunlop were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. by Msgr. Thomas V. McMahon.

title: IRVING BLUM
description: Irving Blum, deputy collector of the Customs Service in New York City from 1945 to 1955, died Friday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived at 142 Laurel Hill Terrace in Washington Heights.

title: John P. Polychron Weds Adrienne Lecraw
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury, L. I., yesterday, Adrienne Lecraw, a flight attendant with Pan American World Airways, was married to John Philip Polychron, president of Popsicle Industries, a division of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, in Englewood, N. J. The Rev. Herbert H. Beardsley performed the ceremony.

title: CARTER RESTATES DECISION TO CANCEL THE B1 BOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)President Carter has reaffirmed his decision to cancel the B1 bomber in reply to a move in the House to restore $1.4 billion in B1 production funds to the budget.

title: H.E.W. WORKERS WARNED OF REDUCED PAYCHECK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare today notified more than 100,000 of its employees to expect reduced paychecks next pay day, Oct. 18.

title: Audit Questions Use of College Fund
description: New York State auditors have charged that the La Guardia Community College Association spent more than $85,000 from a special fund of student fees and auxiliary commissions with little, if any, direct benefit to the students.

title: Mobile ICBM Held Less Vulnerable
description: NAPLES, Italy. Oct. 8Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, on a visit to Italy, has said that development of a new mobile missile system in the United States could buoy American defenses and make the nation's strategic arsenal much less vulnerable to attack in the 1980's.

title: THE TROUBLED WORLD OF MIKE BURKE
description: Here we are on the lip of the big sports season at the Garden and this guy wants me to believe that Mike Burke is in trouble. Any day now, the guy says, Mike Burke is liable to be called into one of those wraparound offices atop the Gulf and Western building and told that his services as president of Madison Square Garden, president of the New York Knickerbockers, chairman of the New York Rangers, impresario of boxing, grand master of Holiday on Ice, are no longer considered to be in the best interests of Gulf and Western Industries Inc.

title: Michigan High Court Restricts Local Limits on Pornography
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 8 (AP)The Michigan Supreme Court has severely restricted the power of local governments to regulate pornography.

title: Alternatives to Prison
description: PEOPLE grow strange when no one values them. The simple, basic need to feel like somebodynever mind love, compassion and understandingwhen withheld, leaves people with an affliction more insidious than any physical disease we can imagine. Yet every day we take people who have offended us personally and collectively and for punishment we inflict the nonperson status on them.

title: Israelis Doubt Peace Parley in 1977
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8 (Reuters)An Israeli Government official said today that the United States was overly optimistic about the chances of convening a Middle East peace conference in Geneva this year.

title: America's Finest MaybeRock NonBand
description: Steely Dan is not America's best rock group, despite the claims of its ardent supporters. It probably would be America's best ruck group if it was a rock group, but. it isn't. Steely Dan is a conceptual umbrella for the work of Donald Fagen and Walter Becker, a pair of enormously gifted and almost unfailingly acerbic songwriters, and if the two do not exactly constitute a rock group, they do make the best rock records being produced in Americaprovided one accepts their music as rock.

title: R.B. Ferrell Fiance Of Jeanne Gregory
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Gregory of Holmdel, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanne Hampton Gregory, to Richard Bradley Ferrell, son of Col. Robert M. Ferrell, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Ferrell, of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: Seoul Puts Down Campus Protest
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 8The South Korean Government quelled a disturbance at Seoul National University, the country's largest campus, last night when 1.000 students began shouting demands for direct election of officers to student bodies.

title: 18 Held in Vermont For Refusal to Quit Nuclear Plant Site
description: VERNON. Vt, Oct. 8Eighteen meinbers of a group called the Vermont Yankee Decommissioning Alliance were arrested here today and charged with unlawful trespass in a clemonstratron at the Vermont Yankee Nuclear Corporation atomic plant.

title: Connors, Gottfried Advance To Final in Hawaii Tennis
description: KAANAPALI, Hawaii, Oct. 8Is Jimmy Conners still the world's premier men's tennis player?

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: A year ago Joseph Frank gave us the first volume of his superb biography of Dostoevsky. Now from the same press (which is also responsible for an enlightening work on Dostoevsky by the Russian critic Konstantin Mochulsky) we are fortunate to have Michael Holquist's scholarly consideration of the great Russian novelist. Here are excellent, useful and detailed readings of specific texts, discussed in the context of the developing form of the novel in the 19th century.

title: Dana Weber to Wed Joan Hiltz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Hiltz of Devon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Joan Hiltz, to Dana Mark Weber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Weber of Wayne, Pa. Miss Hiltz, who it known as Joan, and her fianc plan to be married in the summer.

title: Maryland Beats Syracuse; Substitute Passer Stars
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Oct. 8 (AP)A substitute quarterback, Larry Dick, directed Maryland to 17 points during a sevenminute span as the Terps beat Syracuse, 2410, today and ended a threegame losing streak.

title: P.S.C. Speeding Hearings On PhoneRate Proposal To Meet Oct.16 Deadline
description: ALBANY, Oct. 8 (UPI)In light of an adverse ruling by the Court of Appeals, the Public Service Commission will speed its deliberations of the New York Telephone Company's request for a $392.3 million rate increase to meet an Oct. 16 deadline, a commission spokesman said yesterday.

title: Secretary Vance Gets Wish: Chinese Tie Cosmos
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 8With Pel, China's chief delegate to the United Nations and other diplomats and soccer personalities at his side, Secretary of State Cyrus Vance made a revelation this afternoon. He said he wished that the soccer game between the Cosmos and China's national team ended in a tie.

title: A Certain Racial Imbalance in City Schools
description: The New York City school system came under fresh attack last week for alleged discriminatory treatment of minority students in the classrooms and for its new program of assigning teachers to schools by race.

title: Margaret Drabble: A Double Life
description: IF Vanessa Redgrave had ever missed a performance in 1960, Margaret Drabble might not have become a novelist. This is a bit of an oversimplification, but the fact is that, as a hopeful 21yearold actress with the Royal Shakespeare Company, Miss Drabble spent much of her time understudying Miss Redgrave. Bored with waiting, tired of doing occasional walkons (as a fairy in A Midsummer Night's Dream), she began to write a novel in her dressing room.

title: Article 1  No Title
Going to War With Pigeons And Losing
description: Pigeons are the bums of the suburbs, and the only way to deal with them is to keep them moving.

title: Rivers Trade Request In New Yank Tradition
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8Mickey Rivers, having stroked four hits in the victory that kept the New York Yankees from being eliminated in the American League playoffs, shrugged aside routine interviews. He simply let it be known he wants to be traded.

title: Queens Man Guilty Of Gun Possession; Trial Witness Slain
description: A 57yearold Queens man was convicted yesterday of a weapons charge in a case in which a major witness against him was murdered hours after he had testified.

title: State's Festival Draws Crowds To Albany Mall
description: ALBANY, Oct. 8Thousands of people who love New York State enough to defy gray, threatening skies and the chill Albany air today embraced some of what it has to offer in a daylong extravaganza of food, crafts and entertainment here.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Food
description: Chicken pot pie

title: How to Get to the AirportA Variety of Ways
description: How to get to the airport if you don't drive or have a chauffeur?

title: DINING OUT
description: BRUNO VALEO began his career by making spaghetti upstairs over a Jersey City tavern called Hillman and Rountree. The placeit was on Hudson Boulevardbecame a hit with the political crowd, so much so that Bruno was able to open his own establishment, Bruno's, on Mother's Day in 1946.

title: Sarah S. Rockefeller Married to Forester
description: Sarah Stillman Rockefeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller of Rye and Paul Smith's, N. Y., was married yesterday to Philip Michael Bogdanovitch, son of Comdr. Philip M. Bogdanovitch, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Bogdanovitch of Bridgewater, N. J., and Dickinson, N. Y.

title: The Aristotelian Method
description: ARISTOTLE ONASSIS By Nicholas Fraser, Philip Jacobson, Mark Ottaway and Lewis Chester. Illustrated. 372 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. P. Lippincott Co. $12.50

title: DANCE VIEW
description: American Ballet Theater whooshed through the Metropolitan Opera House for two weeks this September like a man with a train to catchhardly stopping long enough to say hello, let alone to shout goodbye. Two weeks was all it took, as kind of hors d'oeuvres to the opera season proper. It is not a bad idea to start the season's proceedings in this fashion, and it helps to integrate Ballet Theater's activities into the general plan of the opera house. The company will, as earlier announced, be back at the Met for its regular season during the summer.

title: CHINESE RAISE PAY TO BOLSTER ECONOMY
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 8Chinese workers will soon get their first wage increases since the late 1950's, officials say, as part of Peking's major efforts to revive the country's economy and to speed modernization.

title: Peter F. Anstett And Leslie Hunt, Legal Aide, Wed
description: Leslie Hunt, a legal assistant with the New York City law firm of Donovan, Leisure, Newton & Irvine, was married yesterday to Peter Fleming Anstett, who is in the controller's office of U. M. C. Industries in Stamford. Conn.

title: Wall Street's Merger Mania
description: Five years ago 500 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange were open for business with the public. Today there are only 379. The 25 largest survivors account for almost twothirds of the total capital of the member firms and more than half of total securities commission revenues.

title: A Historian for Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT JUST WALK into the reference room, turn left, and look upyou can't miss him, said the guard at the front entrance of the Burroughs Public Library in Bridgeport. And he was right. Who could help notice the man clinging to a 14foothigh scaffold. He was attracting quite a crowd.

title: 'Quakes Fans Select
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. (UPI)The San Jose Earthquakes season ticketholders have selected Lauri Calloway, one of the original Quakes in 1974 and a fouryear starter at the left defender position, as the team's most valuable player for 1977. Prior to his San Jose career, Calloway, now 32 years old, played in more than 400 games in his native England, including three seasons with the Wolverhampton Wanderers.

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have a snake plant which is 10 years old. To my astonishment and delight, this week it bloomed. Can the flower be used to propagate new plants? Mrs. E.G.N., Ventnor, N.J.

title: FILM VIEW
description: As I write this, the 15th New York Film Festival still has one more week to go but by the time you read the piece, the festival will be in its last day. Perhaps, then, it isn't too early to declare a ban of at least six months on any further use of the word accessible in connection with movies, especially the movies of people like Marguerite Duras, Werner Herzog. Pier Paolo Pasolini or Robert Bresson.

title: U.S. Rugby Team Bows In Match in England, 1812
description: NEWCASTLE, England, Oct. 8 (AP)The Eagles, America's first national rugby union team to make an overseas tour, lost by 1812 today to Gosforth, a Newcastle team

title: First Sputnik Created a Celestial Traffic Jam
description: In the aftermath of Sputnik I, which ushered in the space age two decades ago on Oct. 4, 1957, a panel of American scientists prepared a report for President Dwight D. Eisenhower entitled Introduction to Outer Space. It was part primer, with sections on why satellites stay up and how rockets work, and otherwise cautiously prophetic.

title: Court Curbs CarTowing Pirates in the Chicago Area
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 8Chicago's private cartowing concerns, which have towed more than 15,000 cars away from private property so far this year and charged their owners $50 to $65 to recover them, may be on the way out.

title: Adele C .S. Daniels Is Bride
description: In St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Charleston, S. C., yesterday afternoon, Adele Conner Simons Daniels, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Ball Daniels of Charleston, became the bride of Krome Doyle George, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Krome George of Pittsburgh and Chatham, Mass. The bridegroom's father is chairman and chief executive officer of the Aluminum Company of America.

title: Students Cool
description: NEW HAVEN WHEN 1,100 of Yale's bluecollar workers threw down their ladles and mops at 6 o'clock on the morning of Friday, Sept. 30, to protest the universlty administration's unwillingness to accept union proposals for increases in job security, benefits and wage packages, thousands of Yale students were suddenly faced with the novel prospect of filling their own empty plates and cleaning their own bathrooms.

title: 2 Die in Bus Accident in Michigan
description: ALLEN PARK, Mich. Oct. 8 (UPI)Two men were killed and four other persons were seriously injured today when a Greyhound bus slid off Interstate 94 here and rolled over several times. Six persons were on the bus, from Chicago to Detroit.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Letters column of Sept. 11, the price of a Paddington bear from Hamleys, 200 Regent Street, London W1, was incorrectly given in dollars rather than pounds sterling, because of an editing error. The price is 13.42 plus 4.65 for postage and packing, a total of 18.07. In dollars, Hamleys sells the bear for $35, which includes bank charges and handling but omits the valueadded tax.

title: W.H.A., Merger Plans Rejected, Optimistic About 8  Team Format
description: Howard Baldwin is an indefatigable optimist. After seeing the summerlong effort at merger between the World Hockey Association and the National Hockey League collapse, the new president of the W.H.A. has contained his initial ire and has bright predictions for his league, which opens its sixth season Wednesday.

title: ENCOUNTER
description: Be sure to visit the Mayan ruins at Copan, a friend insisted the day before I left for Guatemala. Mayan ruins were what had attracted me to that country in the first place, so I investigated. I learned that Copan, the southernmost ceremonial center of the Mayas, is built on a Honduran plateau, nine miles from Guatemala border and some 145 miles from Guatemala City. I also learned that there is no regular train, plane or bus service to the archelogical site. Travel agents run special tours, but only for groups of five or more.

title: Deaths
description: DICKSONCharles E.,131 Bennett Road, Teaneck, N.J. died at St. yincent's Hospital, October 8, 19 77. At the ape of 61. Survived by wife, Joy, a daughter Jonine Sofer, sons Franklyn and Robin. Also survived by his sisters, Mrs. Yvonne Pierre and Rosette Beyacar.. Also survived by six grandchildren. Mr. Dickson was cofounder and Chairman of the Board of Ray Bloch Productions, N.Y.C: Mr. Dickson was Past Master Darcy Lodge No. 187 of the Masons, and a member of the Teaneck Camera Club, Photographic Association of America, and Executive Association of New York. Services at GuttermanMusicant Funeral Home, Hackensack, N.J., 12:45 P.M. on Sunday, October 9.

title: Soccer: South Side Goalie Outscoring His Opponents
description: The main reason South Side in Rockville Centre, LI., hasn't allowed a goal after five league games this season is its senior goalkeeper, 16yearold Hal Goldstein,

title: CRIME
description: Nominally, THE NICE MURDERERS by David Delman (Morrow, $7.95) is a Lieut. Jacob Horowitz mystery. He is the big Nassau County homicide cop who still speaks with the ripe Yiddish inflections of New York, and he has appeared in several prior Delman books. Horowitz is dogged, tough and incorruptible. Smart, too. But he is not the central figure of The Nice Murderers.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, OCTOBER 9, 1977

title: Buying That Pleasure Boat Is Made Easier by Sullivan
description: As another boating season draws to a close in metropolitan waters, perhaps you've wondered whether now is the time to trade in your old boat. Or, if after spending the summer ashore and wishing you were afloat, you think this might be the winter you do something about it. In any case, it is reassuring to know that in addition to the pleasure boats can offer, they also tend to be good investments. Certainly, there are pitfalls and some boats are better investments than others, but there are guidelines for charting a financially safe course through the marine market.

title: Michael Prigoff, Lawyer, To Marry Robin Brinn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray L. Brinn of Roslyn Heights, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Leslie Brinn, to Michael Lebson Prigoff, son of Mr and Mrs. Milton Prigoff of Alpine, N. J.

title: Controversy Boils on Spaghetti Racquet
description: GREAT NECK YOU NEVER know aboutMichael, said Peter about Fishbach with a laugh. He comes and goes. I think he played recently in Iran. You can be sure he'll produce excitement wherever he is.

title: IN AMERICA
description: WASHINGTON. The invitation, coffeecolored lettering on buffcolored vellum, has a fashionable look and a baffling message. An illeducated recipient surmises it's in Latin, then tries to decode it. Washingtomensis at least suggests a place. Rite Inaugurandom could be an inauguration ceremony. Sahaat ??one Confecta hints at refreshments; sounds like confections, right? (Wrong. The refreshment, it turns out, comes with the collatio. Cardinale Erninenlisqmo translates easily, the makedo classicist figures, as eminent cardinal. Ergo, as we say, it's an ecclesiastical affair. Luckily, there's a name in the middle of the lines of chastely blocked type that suggests what kind: Reverend( Palm Francisc?? Xaveru MurphyF.X. to some of his friends, Murph to othersis having a bash.

title: U.S. Team Is Named For GrecoRoman Event
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 9 (AP) Four Olympians will lead the United States team in the world GrecoRoman wrestling championships Friday through Oct. 17 in Gteborg. Sweden.

title: NUTRITION COMMITTEE GAINS SENATE FAVOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)With Congress near the end of the current session, attempts are quietly being made to have the Senate reverse its decision to abolish a separate committee on nutrition.

title: Boost by Carter Knock by Koch
description: Both as a campaigner and as President, Jimmy Carter has shown an affinity for quick responses to criticism, whether large or small. Last week a large criticism was involved and Mr. Carter parried with a dramatic flourish. On foot and by car, he toured the moonscape of the South Bronx, hoping to underscore that they still have to know we care.

title: FISHING
description: A FINE run of blackfish appears to be shaping up around the Island. After the slight, and in some areas nonexistent, spring run, the return of the blackfish in force is heartening. Also known as tautog, blackfish should be a good bet through October, increasing in size each week.

title: Social Policy Also Before The Congress
description: While the struggle over an energy bill preoccupied Congress and the White House, two major proposals affecting social policy were making their way through the capital last week, with mixed results. The scorecard:

title: Guide to Animal Services
description: Central Westchester Humane Society Inc., South Saw Mill River Road, Elmsford. LY27334. Open 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. seven days a week. 24hour emergency service through local police departments. Nonprofit organization serving White Plains, Elmsford and Ardsley. Takes in abandoned and owned animals, picks up strays from police department, investigates animal complaints, has lostandfound files and service for animals. Adoption fees $20 to $25.

title: Briton Reported Slain in Uganda
description: LONDON, Oct. 8 (UPI)Robert Scanlon, believed to have once been a friend of President Idi Amin of Uganda, was beaten to death with a sledgehammer in a Kampala prison three weetks ago, The London Observer said in its Sunday issue. In a dispatch from Nairobi, Kenya, it quoted a refugee Uganda official as a witness to the killing. Mr. Scanlon, a Briton who took Uganda nationality, disappeared, four months ago and Uganda said he had been charged with spying.

title: STUDIES ON HUMANS RAISE CONTROVERSY
