description: ALBANY, Oct. 8By its account, the State University of New York here merely allowed some graduate psychology students to conduct routine tests to see how small children play with forbidden toys and how college students perceive mild electrical impulses.

title: Women Compile a Guide for Out Here
description: WHAT'S happening way out here? is a question that East End residents have long since become accustomed to. Now, thanks to the efforts of three local women who have compiled a new directory for women on the East End, many persons will have more to say when they are asked that question.

title: Beauty
description: For the working woman, beauty is a serious investment. The way we look indicates how we see ourselves and our careers. The female financier who works on Wall Street seldom makes herself up to look like a showgirl  and vice versa. These six women were photographed on the run to work, at various hubs of New York. Each has created an image that she feels suits her, her job and the people she works with. Ultimately, they all agree, beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

title: Koch Backs Testing Plan to Increase Minority Teachers in the City
description: Representative Edward I. Koch said yesterday that if he is elected Mayor of New York he would insist on an equitable testing system that will expand the opportunities of members of minority groups to teach in our schools.

title: Alyce E. Kilpatrick Married to Banker
description: Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Alyce Eugenia Kilpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ringland Fisher Kilpatrick Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla., and Rumson, to Jatries Randall Van Wagner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Van Wagner of Rumson and Tequesta, Fla.

title: Carey Names Advocate for Disabled
description: ALBANY. Oct. 8Harold Unterberg, a New York City lawyer, has been appointed New York State's Advocate for the Disabled, a post set up earlier this year by Governor Carey in an effort to improve conditions for the handicapped.

title: Soviet Says It Will Send Ethiopia Medical Supplies and Other Aid
description: MOSCOW, Oct, 8 (Reuters)The Soviet union is to send medical supplies and other emergency aid to Ethiopia to help those who have suffered as a result of the fighting there, the official press agency Tass said today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TOKO By Ryokichi Ozawa. 32 pp. Plattsburgh, N.Y.: Tundra Books. Distributed by Scribner's. $2.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Mark Blasch Fiance Of Barbara Overby
description: Barbara Coe Overby and Mark Edward Blasch, who graduated with the class of 76 from Kenyon College, plan to be married Nov. 26.

title: AROUD THE Garden
description: Hopefully, most gardeners are learning to be tidy. This may sound a bit prissy, but the better the cleanup job done now, the better the chances are for a clean troublefree garden in the spring. Insects and diseases have a way of hanging around on garden debris and living through the winter months. Gardeners often wonder where their troubles come from.

title: Robin Weathers Bride of Glenn Hudson
description: Ellen Cushing Weathers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot B. Weathers of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married yesterday to Glenn Buker Hudson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Hudson of Sunapee, N. H. The Rev. Frederick Buker, a Baptist minister and uncle of the bridefroom, performed the ceremony in Sayborn Meadow in Woodstock, N. H.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD COLLEGE, Franklin and Fremont Streets, BtootnfieldHedda Gaer, in an Actor's CafeTheater production in its new home. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through Oct. 22). $2.9044.90; students and the elderly, $1.90$3.90; group rates. (201) 9297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Baseball Strategy: How John McGraw Destroyed a Pitcher
description: A pitcher is in a tight game, and the batter makes a hit. Another follows and some fan back in the stand cries in stentorian tones:

title: Notes: Cuban Team Seeks Direct Flights
description: Cubana the Cuban airline, hopes to operate weekly charter tours to Havana from Washington's Dulles Airport, starting in December, and an American tour operator plans similar charter trips, using a United States airline's planes, from New York from January. These projects have been disclosed following the visit of a fiveman Cuban delegation to Washington and New York last month for talks with members of the Carter Administration and airline and hotel executives, travel agents and other industry people.

title: Trees: The Biggest Is Near Blairstown
description: TRENTON IT IS, said Santiago Porcella 3d of the state's Bureau of Forestry, a statement that can't be successfully challenged: A sycamore near Blairstown, in Warren County, is New Jersey's biggest tree.

title: DYSON OPPOSES PLAN ON RECYCLING PLANTS
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8In the latest of a number of public feuds with fellow officials of the Carey administration, John S. Dyson, the New York State Commerce Commissioner, has charged that the Department of Environmental Conservation's approach to establishing regions for recycling solid waste would hinder the development of a growing solidwaste industry in the state and result in more public debt.

title: Correction
description: In the bibliographical data preceding a review in the Oct. 2 issue two titles were transposed. They should have read The Collapsing Universe by Isaac Asimov, published by Walker and Co. and Until the Sun Dies by Robert Jastrow, published by W. W. Norton. In the same issue the availability of a cloth edition of The Art of Nancy Ekholm Burkert. edited by David Larkin, was not mentioned; the edition is published by Harper & Row at $15.

title: Exploration of Antarctica May Not Be Good for It
description: Antarctica, discovered by Europeans 150 years ago in their search for whales and seals, is finally becoming the abject of commercial exploitation with possibly profound implications for the frozen continent's fragile environment.

title: Bruce Gillespie Plans to Wed Gale Sanson
description: Martha DeWitt Sanson of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Henry Bright Sanson of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Gale Sanson, to Bruce Acker Gillespie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Gillespie of Haverford, Pa.

title: Man Guilty of Shooting a Porpoise
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 8 (AP)A 58yearold man pleaded guilty in Federal court here yesterday of shooting a porpoise in the Gulf of Mexico last summer. James C. Smith of Seminole, the first person ever charged under a criminal law protecting marine mammals, was arrested last June for shooting into a school of bottlenosed porpoises in the Gulf. He can be sentenced to a maximum of two years probation or a suspended fine of $50,000.

title: Ramapo Continues On Unbeaten Path
description: Ramapo's prospects of winning its first Rockland County P.S.A.L. championship appeared a bit brighter yesterday after a 276 victory over Tappan Zee. The unbeaten and untied Gryphons have overpowered three opponents, scoring 110 points and relinquishing only 23.

title: Comeback on the Sound
description: THE gradual cleanup of Connecticut's waters around Norwalk has permitted the conditional opening of what state authori ties say are several square miles of rich oyster beds.

title: How Retirement Should Work
description: The graying of America has transformed politics and it is about to transform the nation's retirement policy. Last month, with uncommon speed and nearunanimity, the House voted to lift the mandatory retirement age from 65 to 70 and to eliminate mandatory retirement altogether for employees of the Federal Government.

title: Suited Up to Storm the Boardroom
description: Ever wonder why women are having so much trouble getting into the executive Suite? For one thing, they haven't a thing to wear. Or so say the mostly male clothing consultants who are suddenly counseling businesswomen on how to dress for power.

title: Making Your Own Hard Cider
description: Vermont autumn cider is sweet cider, the juice freshly squeezed from one or more varieties of apple; its taste ranges from delicate fruitiness to tangy robustness, its color from pale straw to deep amber. The manufacture of hard cider in Vermont is a small, private operation, and only the maker and his family and friends drink the result.

title: C.I.A. SEES A DANGER TO AMERICANS ABROAD
description: An analysis of the background of a major increase in terrorist attacks on American business representatives and concerns abroad has led the Central Intelligence Agency to conclude that there is a real danger that the attacks will become more frequent in the future.

title: ABRAMS QUITS RANKS TO ENDORSE WAGNER
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx broke Democratic Party ranks yesterday to endorse City Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr., the RepublicanLiberal candidate for Borough President of Manhattan.

title: The Spectacular Rise and Ignoble Fall of Richard Sorkin, Pros' Agent
description: Three weeks ago, in the babble of a Nassau County courtroom in Mineola, a wheyfaced 37yearold agent for professional athletes stepped forward to plead guilty to seven counts of grand larceny. The man, Richard Sorkin, admitted he had stolen money he was supposed to have been keeping in trust for his clients, including some of the stars of the Islanders, the Rangers and the Nets. More than 50 professional hockey and basketba41 players were the victims, and authorities have put the losses at about $1.2 million.

title: Natural Gas And the Filibuster
description: WASHINGTONFilibuster is an extended debate, generally in the United States Senate, which, because of its rules, allows unlimited debate for those who can count votes well enough to know that their side will lose should a vote be taken on an issue. Historically, filibusters have been the exclusive province of Southerners who have sought to prevent or to weaken civil rights legislation and, more recently, improvements hi antitrust laws.

title: Why New York City Failed to Get the Olympics
description: Two weeks ago, I participated in New York City's presentation to the United States Olympic Committee at Colorado Springs. New York and Los Angeles sought the committee's blessing to bid for the 1984 Summer Olympics. Through it all, I learned a few things about our city and our state.

title: INTERVIEW
description: VALHALLA DR. JOSEPH A. CIMINO was preparing to leave his Westchester Medical Center office last week for what he said was terminal leave. It sounded more like an incurable disease than a vacation, but he seemed quite relaxed, buoyed perhaps by the knowledge that he would be replaced by three persons.

title: DINING OUT
description: WESTON COBB'S MILL Inn in Weston has rustic appeal, a picturesque waterfall, a country store gift shop and a large sign at the entrance recounting its colorful history. It's a stereotypical New England inn with one important exception: unlike many of its counterparts, it does not rely only on its charm, but makes a special effort in the kitchen. And the results show.

title: Talk and Laments
description: IS it because Jews relish talk that they are better known as novelists than poets? Be that as it may, Irving Layton, a Canadian Jew, has written 30 volumes of poetry, and even his Selected Poems reveals what some might call a discursive element. In his elegy, Lillian Roxon, tough, vigorous talk sounds good as love: The woman's weighty sloshing is in the second line; her liquid breathing hisses in the third. The last stanzawhere she is freed of her tremendous earth softly breaks your heart. This talk is measured, controlled by its music but, like the woman, unavailingly. In the tiny relation of the last two words, talk triumphs, soars beyond measure.

title: Washington Suburb Seeks Minor League Franchise
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)Mayor Frank Mann of Alexandria, Va., is trying to convince minor league baseball officials that his suburban Washington community would be a good place for a Class AAA team.

title: Upstate Dude Ranch Roundup
description: Tall in the saddle, reins held loosely in my left hand. I gaze out across dappled hills. Below, a dozen Indians water their Pintos in the limpid stream, peaceful, decorative and kind. The sound of approaching hoofbeats makes me turn. It's John Wayne. Together we ride off into the sunset, back to the ranch.

title: Yanks Win, 64, Forcing 5th Game, Dodgers Take Flag
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8The Los Angeles Dodgers won the National League pennant in a small monsoon tonight when Tommy John, the man with the rebuilt left arm, pitched them to a 41 victory over Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: TOM SAWYER lives! I seem to have bamboozled the neighborhood children into mowing my lawnand for free! It started soon after I moved to suburbia from the city.

title: Two Novels
description: Here are two senior and admirable English writers, each with a symbolic tree in her title. The Danger Tree is an Egyptian sequel to Olivia Manning's Balkan Trilogy, published in the 60's, and it blessedly brings back Guy Pringle, one of the last of the attractive heroes in modern literature. Guy is sweetnatured, altruistic to strangers, a protg collectorand inconsiderate to a fault where his wife is concerned. He is an English instructor attached to an organization rather like the British Council. He and his wife Harriet are caught in the fear of Rommel's advance. Though they have escaped from Athens just in time, it seems to Harriet that she will spend her life escaping. They could both get out of Egypt, but Guy will not budge: he has two students, both Arabs, whom he refuses to let down. Harriet is a finely drawn character, strongminded, resourceful, longsuffering, but admittedly resentful of some of Guy's altruistic antics.

title: Rutgers Announces Woodland Tours
description: Rutgers University has announced a schedule for conducted tours of the William L. Hutcheson Memorial Forest, a 65acre tract of uncut hardwood in Franklin Township

title: Mary K. Goldsmith Is Married To James Stevens, a Banker
description: Mary K. Goldsmith and James W. Stevens were married yesterday by the Rev. Gerald Rigg, a Presbyterian minister, in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Kellogg in Darien, Conn.

title: Deaths
description: Adelman, Ida

title: Jamesport: A White Elephant?
description: NOR many years ago environmentalists were scorned when they opposed, unsuccessfully, the Long Island Lighting Company's first nuclear power plant at Shoreham. Recently both the Suffolk County Legislature and the Nassau County Board of Supervisors tabled resolutions opposing the construction of nuclear generating facilities for Jamesportbut legislative bodies indicated that they wanted to study the issue more closely and explore exactly what the costs of Jamesport would be for Lilco customers This is a major step forward for foes of nuclear energy on the Island.

title: The Senate and the Energy Alarm
description: An energy alarm bell is ringing, loud enough for all intelligent citizens to hear: Foreign oil producers already have the power to strangle our economy any time political motives move them. Whether they squeeze or not, they are already draining away our dollars$36 billion for oil imports last year, an estimated $45 billion this year. The President heard the alarm; that's why he rushed a National Energy Plan to Congress last spring. The House heard the alarm; that's why it speedily debated, modified and enacted its version last summer.

title: What's Doing in TOKYO
description: THE CITYIt is generally accepted that Tokyo is the largest city in the nonCommunist world. Actually, it is the largest collection of small cities in the nonCommunist world, a sprawling 224squaremile conglomeration of communities each with its own personality, traditions and festivals. Tokyo, literally, eastern capital, is a kind of WashingtonNew YorkChicago megalopolis with a pop ulation of 11.6 millionin short, Japan's Big Apple.

title: LABORINDUSTRY GROUP ASKS HEALTHCARE REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)A unionmanagement group working under former Labor Secretary John T. Dunlop today urged a series of reforms to reduce soaring costs of health care, including the elimination of requirements that patients be hospitalized to qualify for medical insurance coverage

title: Field Goal by Tata Gives Middies 107 Edge
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 8Bob Tata Jr., a small man by football standards but a large one by Naval standards right now, kicked a 25yard field goal with 41 seconds remaining today and gave Navy an exciting 107 victory over the Air Force in a typically hardfought serviceacademy battle.

title: Deaths
description: HAASJack H., on Oct 7, 1977, beloved husband of Selma (nee Schwabe), devoted father of Marion and the late lise Selowsky, grandfather of Sandra, Carol, Lauren and Leonard. Services Sunday, Oct 9, 1:30 PM, The Riverside, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Sunday Observer
description: While standing outside Elaine's straining for a glimpse of famous celebrities, whom do I see but Desdemona. Naturally, I am surprised since, the last I heard, she has just been murdered by Othello in the last act.

title: Rushing Man Never Trails In Winningat Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 8Rushing Man, the roan gelding who won the first thoroughbred stake race run at the Meadowlands on Sept. 6, proved that his victory was no fluke tonight as he won the $54,500 Jersey Blues Handicap.

title: Mistrial Is Ruled as Jury Mulling Salerno Tax Case Reports Deadlock at 11 to 1
description: A deadlocked jury produced a mistrial yesterday for Anthony Salerno, a reputed organizedcrime figure, who was charged with tax evasion involving hundreds of thousands of dollars that he allegedly spent on a lavish life style.

title: SECRET REPORT CITES LUCIANO ON WAR AID
description: A report of an intensive New York State investigationordered in 1954 by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, and long suppressed at the request of the Navycredits Charles (Lucky) Luciano and other underworld leaders with a wide variety of valuable aid to the Government in World War II.

title: Too Poor for a Lawyer;
description: HEMPSTEAD AFTER his arrest for foraging in restricted waters, the amateur clammer was in a dilemma: He could not afford a lawyer, but he did not qualify for help from the statesupported Legal Aid Society.

title: Editors' Choice
description: ADLAI STEVENSON AND THE WORLD, by John Bartlow Martin. (Doubleday, $15.1 The second and concluding volume of Martin's prodigiously researched biography.

title: Brock Praises Lower Speed Limit As Major iLfeSaving Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)The 55mileanhour speed limit is the largest single lifesaving factor among Transportation Department programs, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams told Congress today.

title: MEXICO, IN RARE STEP, ARRESTS EXOFFICIAL
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 8For the first time in a century, a Mexican has been jailed and accused of having been involved in corruption while he served as a Cabinet minister. But it is still unclear whether the Government of President Jos Lpez Portillo made the arrest for legal or political reasons.

title: India Again Fights for Prohibition
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 8As the nation observed the 108th birthday of Mohandas K. Gandhi last Sunday, the Indian Government haltingly began a fouryear campaign against drinking, a cause that was dear to him.

title: Young in Spain Adopt El Ingles As Heroat 83
description: ALAHURIN EL GRANDE, SpainIn this shining, whitewashed town in the dry hills above Malaga, he is known simply as Brenan, el ingls. With a mixture of familiarity and deference, the man in overalls at the gas station points the way up the steep dirt track to the isolated white house where lives, by the account of many Spaniards, the foreigner who has understood them best.

title: Coldest Big City to Think Warm
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 8 (UPI)The nation's coldest large city has embarked on a civic campaign to look and think warm this winter.

title: Ethnic Cleveland Ousts Longtime Champion
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 6Strike the bum out! He wasn't good enough to play in Cleveland! a man yelled at the television set as Graig Nettles, once a Cleveland Indian but now a New York Yankee, stepped up to bat in the American League playoffs.

title: Offices With Views Adapt to Save Fuel and Share the Scenery
description: The view from the top is being tailored. What people in offices see when they look up from their desks is being framed differently to conserve energy and accommodate new structural systems. And it is being made more accessible as open office landscaping is democratizing panoramas.

title: Penn Downs Brown, 147, On Ground
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8The University of Pennsylvania's football team, which ruined Brown's try for an undefeated season and an outright Ivy League championship last year, stopped the Bruins again today, 147, before a crowd of 6,327 in Franklin Field.

title: Catholic Prelates Pledge to Help Hispanic People
description: Four cardinals and 48 bishops of the Roman Catholic Church pledged their support to the Northeast's Hispanic population at a threeday meeting last week at the Cardinal Spellman Retreat House, 5801 Palisade Avenue, the Bronx.

title: ART
description: SOUTHPORT BECAUSE of its easy homespun name and any notions or memories that it might elicit, folk art might seem more familiar to us than it really is.

title: Port Agency Offers Three Noise Plans, One Allowing SST
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey proposed three alternative noise standards yesterday for the major airports in the metropolitan area, including one plan that would permit test landings of the Concorde supersonic jetliner for three months at Kennedy International Airport.

title: 20 Years and 25 Books in 234 Pages
description: THIS is William Pritchard's description of the plan embodied in Seeing Through Everything: ... a book, neither survey, history, nor intensive treatment of two or three writers, which attempts to move more or less chronologically through the period and come to terms with its most significant and enduring literary monuments. The period in question is the years between the wars, roughly 191840 And English means English, not American (exception being made in favor of T. S. Eliot but not in favor of Ezra Pound) or Irish (no Yeats, no Joyce). The chapters on the 1920's deal?? mainly with Arnold Bennett, Shaw, Wyndham Lewis, Eliot, D. H. Lawrence, Virginia Woolf, Lytton Strachey, Ford Madox Ford, E. M. Forster, Aldous Huxley and Robert Graves. The low, dishonest decade, W. H. Auden's phrase for the 1930's, is studied by copious reference to Evelyn Waugh, Auden, Spender, Anthony Powell, George Orwell and F. R. Leavis. Mr, Pritchard's major figures are Wyndham Lewis and Eliot.

title: Trees for All Seasons To Plant This Fall
description: When selecting a specimen tree for the landscape, why not consider one with multiseasonal interest? Too often a plant is selected merely for a splashy flowering period which may last only five or six days. Any tree planted in a prominent area of the yard should, if possible, hold its appeal all year through.

title: Real Madrid Defeats Providence for Title
description: MADRID, Oct. 8 (AP)Real Madrid captured the Intercontinental Cup basketball tournament today by defeating Providence College, 10390, in a final round game of the fiveteam tournament.

title: This Time, Maybe, Reform of Teamster Fund
description: WASHINGTONCharges have circulated for years that the Teamsters Central States Pension Fund was an underworld machine, oiled by kickbacks, for showering loans on shady characters while Teamsters were denied benefits they worked years to earn. The fund has shrugged off Congressional hearings, indictments and even convictions those associated with it. It has resisted reform steadfastly.

title: The Excision of An Energy Plan
description: The Senate Finance Committee has all but dismantled President Carter's energy tax package, leaving only bare bones and an unavoidable question: Is the Carter program dead? It is too early to tell, but the answer probably is no. Parts of the package may be revived on the Senate floor, and perhaps even by the committee before finishes its work sometime this week. Further restorations are possible later when the Senate tries to work out its differences in conference with the House, which has passed the President's plan largely intact.

title: Fame Comes to Miss Frances of Plainfield
description: PLAINFIELD SHE forgot to meditate for 10 days. She missed her Monday night bowling game. And if she looked a little abstracted at recent meetings of the Town and Country Bridge Club and the Scotch Plains Women's Corn munity Club, no one blamed the woman who has become known as Miss Frances of New Jersey. It isn't every day that one's daughter wins the Democratic nomination for City Council President of New York.

title: Lance Bank Reported Aided by U.S. Deposits
description: Records of the Comptroller of the Currency show that the National Bank of Georgia, in which Bert Lance, the former budget director, owns 233,000 shares of stock, had more than $1 million in Federal Government funds on deposit, the Long Island newspaper Newsday reported in its Sunday editions.

title: Carter And the Lobbies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  President Carter is in deep trouble for the first time since he entered the White House, but, In fairness, he is in trouble because he has had the audacity to face up to the most difficult national and international problems of our time.

title: A Tale of Three Sisters
description: ORANGE SINCE long before Chekhov, it has been generally conceded that the one thing not to expect from three sisters is that they agree on anything more than the weather.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: After alarums, excursions and a real scare, the Metropolitan Opera will raise its curtain tomorrow night on Boris Godunov. For a while, during the labor negotiations, it seemed there was a real possibility of a strike. It is a fact of life these days that the participants in a labor dispute make terrible faces at each other up to the last moment, but this time the Metropolitan was serious. It was in a perilous financial situation and its very existence was threatened.

title: Laurie Kahaner Betrothed
description: Laurie Jill Kahaner and Roy Ira Greenblatt, graduates of the University of Miami, plan a winter wedding. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Morton Kahaner of Brooklyn, parents of the bridetobe, whose fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Greenblatt of Roslyn, L. I.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: In regard to the Copper Beech restaurant in Ivoryton, described in your issue of Sept. 11 as having an atmosphere of supercilious arrogance:

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: HONE CLINIC
description: THE wise homeowner who deotes a day or two to giving the house a fall checkup each year will find that the time spent can go far toward lowering repair bills and operating costs and helping make the home more comfortable and troublefree in the winter.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: In everincreasing numbers, New Jerseyans now live in condominiums, many in senior citizentype retirement condominiums. It is time now to amend the existing condominium law so as to insure protection for condominium owners and buyers.

title: World News Briefs
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, Oct. 8 (Reuters)Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese Moslem leftists began a gradual withdrawal today from advanced positions in parts of southern Lebanon, abiding by an agreement to reduce tension in the area close to the Israeli border.

title: Ethnic Votes May Be Key to Election
description: TRENTON WHEN Raymond H. Bateman of Somerville marched up rainswept Fifth Avenue last Sunday in New York City's annual Pulaski Day parade, he was doing more than paying tribute to the great Revolutionary hero. Casimir Pulaski. He was acknowledging the increasing importance of the PolishAmerican vote in New Jersey politics.

title: Film Festival: 'Obscure Object':Bunel Work Triumphantly Funny and Wise
description: Every film festival should end with a new film by the incomparable Luis Buuei, whose latest work, the triumphantly funny and wise "That Obscure Object of Desire," will be shown at Lincoln Center tonight at 8:30 to close the 15th New York Film Festival.After one has sat through hours and hours of films by directors who don't know when to stop (and some who should never have started), seeing a work of such perfect control and precision has the effect of magically clearing the mind. It restores one's common sense and one's appreciation for the fantastic, and it reminds us of the profound possibilities of film in the hands of someone we now acknowledge to be an authentic master."That Obscure Object of Desire" is Buuel's "Don Giovanni." It combines the effervescence and gaiety of "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie" with the dark wit of "Tristana." and though it continues to explore themes we recognize from these and other Buuel films, it is something quite other.Most obviously, I suppose, "That Obscure Object of Desire" is an upside-down romance in which love, Buuel seems to be telling us, is "a devastating act of subversion." The setting is the easily recognizable contemporary world, but a world that is a half-degree off its axis and fast going to pieces, though everyone displays the fastidious manners of the members of a society that will last forever.Just beyond the horizon of the film, which is set in Paris and in Seville, chaos reigns. Through newspaper headlines and radio broadcasts we learn. that terrorism is rampant. Planes are being hijacked and innocents slaughtered. A mysterious virus is nearing Barcelona and a guerrilla group that calls itself the Revolutionary Army of the Infant Jesus has attempted to assassinate the Archbishop of Sienna. Even the Communists are outraged by the anarchic state of things.Seemingly unruffled by all this (though he is impatient when a booby-trapped automobile in front of his explodes and forces his car to make a detour) is the charming, literate, wealthy Mathieu (Fernando Rey), Bufiuel's Don, a French businessman whose life is in perfect order until the day that the beautiful Conchita enters it, dressed as a maid.Though he has been a widower for seven years, Mathieu is no ordinary lecher. As he tells his brother, the judge (Julien Betheau), Mathieu can count on the fingers of one hand the number of times he has ever made love to a woman whom he didn't love passionately. From the minute he sees Conchita, Mathie is in the throes of an uncontrollable passion.Conchita, though, is not someone whose measure he can get, and who eludes him even he gets her into bed. Conchita flees his house, only to turn up a few months afterwards traveling through Switzerland with a group of musicians. Later Mathieu makes a deal with Conchita's pious mother to set up Conchita as his mistress. Again she runs away. Each time they meet again, she leads him further into the recesses of his obsession, always promising him the moon (in the form of her virginity), then suddenly changing her mind.As Mathieu sees her, Conchita is so changeable that Buuel has cast two lovely new actresses to play herCarole Bouquet, who looks a little like a young Rita Hayworth, as the coolly enigmatic Conchita, and Angela Molina as the earthy, flamenco-dancing Conchita whom he follows to Seville.Poor old Mathieu. The night he succeeds in getting Conchita to his country house, where she has promised to be his mistress, the Conchita who goes into the bathroom to change, changes not only her clothes. Miss Bouquet goes in but Miss Molina comes out.Mathieou huffs, puffs and groans in his agony. He leaves Conchita a dozen times but always is lured back. At one point he persuades her to live with him and to share his bed, though no sexual contact can be made. When the judge asks his brother why he doesn't marry her, Mathieu answers earnestly that if he married her, he would be helpless. At another point, when Mathieu upbraids Conchita for her maddening ways, she answers, "You only want what I refuse. That's not all or me. . . ."Who really loves whom? Though Conchita at first seems to be the classic coquette, she becomes, as the film progresses, the true lover, while Mathieu becomes the coquette, a reversal of roles that is, nevertheless, not to be taken as the last word."That Obscure Object of Desire" is beatifully played by its small, impeccably chosen cast, beginning with Mr. Rey who, at this point in his career, is virtually a projection of Buuel's artistic personalitygentle, polite, self-aware incapable of the superfluous gestures, and driven. Miss Bouquet and Miss Molina are enchantingI don't think Buuel has ever before been so successful with neophyte actresses.There are further delights in the performances of Mr. Bertheau (who played the "worker bishop" in "The Discreet Charm"), of Andre Weber, as Mathieu's all-wise valet, and of Pieral, a dwarf who plays the psychologist to whom Mathieu pours out his sad story on the train from Seville to Paris, which provides the frame for the film."That Obscure Object of Desire" is a lot more open-ended and surreal than I've indicated, but these are pleasures that one should discover for oneself. To attempt to interpret them in this sort of review would be as gross as giving away the ending of a whodunit. One particular prop, though, I would suggest that you watch out for. It's an ordinary, but apparently well-stuffed burlap sack that the always-well-groomed Mathieu carries with him.With an effortlessness matched by no other director today, Buuel creates a vision of a world as logical as a theorem, as mysterious as a dream, and as funny as a vaudeville gag. I especially like the response of a waiter in a posh restaurant when an insect turns up in Mathieu's martini. "A fly," the waiter exclaims. "I've been after that one for days, and he had to fall into your glass!"

title: City U. Teachers Union Assails a Travel Course For Barring CubanBorn
description: The union that represents professors in the City University system has protested against a study and travel course on Cuba being offered at Hunter College, on the ground that people born in Cuba were barred from taking it.

title: PropertyTax Aid Is Urged by Goldin For Small Homes
description: Major changes in New York City's system of reducing propertytax assessments were proposed yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. who said current procedures worked for the benefit of the fewthose who hake money and power rather than for all the people.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Daguerreotypes, the world's first and most fragile photographs, are emerging as among the most coveted and collectible examples of the medium.

title: Donald Boucher Fiance Of Sarah Jean Meredith
description: Sarah Jean Meredith, a social worker at the Worcester, (Mass.) Children's Friend Society, and Donald R. Boucher, an engineer with Corometrics Medical Systems of Wallingford, Conn., plan to be married July 8.

title: They Make Music Together
description: GREEN BROOK THE power of music is the greatest dynamic force on the human temperament, said Roman Mochrnmk, a visually impaired violinist and music therapist who speaks with contagious enthusiasm. He reached out to touch the hand of his wife, Known professionally as CarolleAnn Craigie, and she put her hand into his.

title: THEATER
description: THE new show at Bridgeport's Downtown Cabaret Theater, LeadIns . . . like everything that has preceded it, is the creation of Claude McNeal. According to a release distributed by the theater management, the idea behind the show, essentially a revue, is to take a satirical look at how historical events could have inspired certain popular songs. I quote the theater more to reassure myself than to inform the reader, because frankly, there were many moments that didn't seem to fit in with the theme announced. Actually, one should be grateful for that because the leadin idea is essentially a onejoke affair that can lead at best to brief snorted laughter when the sketch moves from historical situation to contemporary song. But if you're going to state your theme in the title of your show, it seems to me you've got to stick with it, even if, as things turn out, are grateful that they don't.

title: SEA WATCH AWAITS TOTAL SOLAR ECLIPSE
description: ABOARD S.S. FAIRWIND, in the Pacific, Oct. 5On Wednesday the moon will pass directly between the earth and sun, causing a total solar eclipse in a narrow band that crosses part of the Pacific Ocean and touches South America.

title: GROUP OPPOSES RENAMING OF LEGIONNAIRES' DESEASE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (UPI)Despite grumbling in the ranks, the American Legion is opposed to a change in the name of the deadly legionnaires' disease.

title: The Wicked Pickett's Beat Goes On
description: I've always wanted to be a star, said Wilson Pickett. He clapped his hands and fell back into a deck chair on the patio behind his house in Englewood, N. J. His handsome face was all smile. You know what I was looking for when I went into this business? A miracle, man, a miracle. He laughed at the thought. I'm 36 now and I got started about 1959; I was 17. How long is that, 18 years? Seems like yesterday.

title: China Appeals for Rail Efficiency
description: PEKING, Oct. 8 (Reuters)China today called for better management of its railway network and far greater efficiency in loading and unloading freight cars to overcome a shortage of rolling stock. A newspaper said the siutation on the railways had improved during the last year, but added that there was still great room. for improvment, The railways were seriously affected by factional strife during the Cultural Revolution of the late 1960's and between 1974 and 1976.

title: Meat and Poultry Survey Planned To Trace the Extent of Aflatoxin
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Agriculture Department plans to survey meat and poultry products in six states in the Southeast to determine whether aflatoxin, a cancercausing substance now contaminating much of the region's corn harvest, is showing up in cattle, swine, chickens and eggs.

title: The Economy's Health: An Uncertain Prognosis
description: Despite a clutch of fresh economic statistics and indicators from Washington, Detroit and New York last week, little light was cast on the muddled underlying trend of the economy.

title: The Prophetic Anguish of August Strindberg
description: On a March evening in 1889, a rehearsal of a oneact play, The Stronger, is in progress at the Dagmar Theater in Copenhagen. The play's author, August Strindberg, is present, together with Siri von Essen (his estranged wife), Siri's friend Marie David, and the Danish actor Viggo Schiwe. The play they are rehearsing is based on a crisis in Strindberg's marriage, involving himself and the two women. During the rehearsal, the old reallife hostilities rise once again to the surface.

title: Article 2  No Title
Majestic Light Triumphs In Man o' War at Belmont
description: Attendance at Belmont Park continued to sag yesterday, but the chairman of the New York Racing Association did manage to find one silver lining in the bleak afternoon.

title: LIBERALS IN QUEBEC ATTEMPT TO REGROUP
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 8Nearly a year after the Liberal Party's stunning defeat in the Quebec election, it is slowly and painfully trying to devise an effective opposition to the Parti Qubcois and its policy of taking the province out of Canada.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Article 8  No Title
Dance: Richard Bull Tries Loft
description: There is, it seems, a loft festival going on in New York City. Splendid. Lofts of the city unite, you have nothing to lose but your skylights. As part of this festival Friday and last night, the New York Chamber Dance Group, directed by Richard Bull, staged an improvisation dance called, with a certain paucity of semantic imagination, Loft Dance. It took place in the loft owned by the Frances Alenikoff Dance Theater on Lower Broadway. I went along Friday night.

title: Quotas, Jobs And Prices
description: The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced recently the layoff of 5,000 workers at its plant in the Mahoning Valley of Ohio. Last week, National Steel Corporation furloughed 600 employees at two plants near Detroit. And U. S. Steel, having laid off 1,200 blue collar workers, has started the layoff of 5 to almost 10 percent2,500 to 4,500  of its salaried employees.

title: WARMTH OF POWER PLANTS TO MELT ICE IS REJECTED
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 8 (AP)Engineers and others studying possible ways to extend the Great Lakes navigation season were advised to give up the idea of using warm discharges from electric generating plants to melt winter Ice.

title: Educating Women About Credit Rights
description: At some point in their lives, 85 percent of the women who are now married will become single again, either through divorce or the death of their husbands, according to the United States Census Bureau. And when that happens, if they have never had credit card, checking or savings account in their own name, financial survival may be a struggle.

title: West Virginia Woman Accepted As the First to Head Mine Local
description: RUM CREEK, W. Va. Oct. 8It is with some irony that Mary Maynard speaks of the refusal of her father, a mine superintendent, to take her into a coal mine because women were thought to bring bad luck underground.

title: A Compleat Actress Leaps From Tart to Tartuffe'
description: Sooner or later, if you play your cards right and you're any good at the game you've chosen to play, it all comes together in a winning hand. Well, in career terms, Patricia Elliott has just gathered in a royal flush, and the exultant actress is still savoring her luck.

title: 3 Obscure Passing Stats Reflect Strength of Team
description: The best way to separate winners from losers in pro football is not to use a needle or consult old tea leaves, but to attend to the most important statistics. That is the conviction of Bud Goode, a noted sports analyst from Los Angeles, and he makes it sound simple. Goode believes that the best way to compare teams is by using three passing statisticsyards per pass attempt, and the difference between the two. The comparison determines how many more yards (or less) a team averages when passing than when defending against the pass.

title: Guidry Appears Unenthusiastic Over Starting Role
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8Ron Guidry has been chosen by Manager Billy Martin to pitch the 167th and deciding game of the American League pennant race for the Yankees tomorrow night. One might expect a 27yearold rookie, who barely made the team in spring training, to be thrilled, excited, nervous or delighted with such an assignment, but Guidry's response to questions about it made a quite different and surprising impression after the Yankee victory that tied the playoff series at 22.

title: Auburn Is Loser, 1715, To North Carolina State
description: AUBURN, Ala., Oct. 8 (AP)  Ted Brown, who has amassed more than 100 yards 14 times as a backfield star at North Carolina State, set a school career rushing record today as the Wolfpack posted a 1715 victory over Auburn.

title: COSTA RICA WINNING BATTLE ON BIRTHS
description: SAN JOSE, Costa RicaCosta Rica, which in 15 years has reduced its population growth from 3.9 percent a year to 2.3 percent, is today held up as one of the success stories of family planning.

title: Port Authority Confirms Aide Hired Relatives
description: Despite his earlier denials, the manager of food services of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey put at least three sons and two other relatives on cash payrolls of authoritysponsored sightseeing cruises, the agency confirmed yesterday.

title: Triumphs and Turmoil at the Cliburn Competition
description: Fort Worth is not known for music. It has a sleepy opera company and a symphony inthemaking. It is, instead, an art town, with several important museums and Philip Johnson's joyous water gardens. Yet every four years, music dominates art in this oilandcattle town, when it turns itself inside out to host the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition.

title: O'DonnelltoO'Donnell Act Rips Verona
description: Steve O'Donnell completed 19 of 22 passes for 302 yards, and his brother, Mike, a split end, caught four of them for touchdowns as unbeaten Madison Borough beat previously undefeated Verona, 3613. Steve has tossed 12 touchdown passes in Madison's three victories, with nine of the scores going to his brother Mike. Chris Jilleba plunged 1 yard to put Madison ahead, and the O'Donnells combined for touchdown passes covering 20 and 23 yards. Verona (21) interrupted the assault with Tom DiNapoli's 2yard sneak, but the O'Donnells collaborated from 50 and 16 yards out in the third and fourth periods, respectively.

title: Christine Bowie Married to Christopher Dove
description: All Saints Episcopal (lurch in Chevy Chase, Md., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Christine McGregor Bowie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Somervell Bowie of Chevy Chase, to Christopher Collier Dove, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Orland Dove Jr. of Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles Edward Berger, who was assisted by the Rev. Malcolm Marshall.

title: QUEEN MARY SHOWS GAIN IN ATTENDANCE ON TOURS
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 8 (UPI)The doughty old liner Queen Mary is plowing through one of the stormiest passages of her historic career while moored in Long Beach harbor.

title: GARDENING
description: NOW that the last of the vegetable harvests are coming in, it's time to do a little looking backsort of a greenthumb inventory.

title: For the Discount Addict
description: DISCOUNT shopping is not a game for the fainthearted. Those who are put off by crowds, a certain amount of rudeness, the inability to exchange or return purchases, communal dressing rooms, and a general absence of concerned sales personnel, may not be suited to the sport. While only a sampling could be included here, and the discount boutique business is proliferating, only one of the shops covered made a serious attempt at offering personal service to all customers.

title: The Sound of Broadway Music On Record
description: The first steps into the new musical season on Broadway have turned out to be revivalsMan of La Mancha and Hair which might be an ominous sign that nothing is really stirring creatively this season. But, at the very least, it means the season has actually started as opposed to last season which was virtually over before its first viable book showsI Love My Wife and Annie appeared in April.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Lawrence Sanders
description: Somerset Maugham once told an admirer Madame, all the words I use in my stories can be found in that dictionaryit's just a matter of arranging them into the right sentences. So, if you play your words right, you wind up living on the beach in Pompano, overlooking the Florida Atlantic, which is where we reached Lawrence Sanders the other day. He had just come in from a swim and was busily engaged in counting his blessings, the most recent of which is The Second Deadly Sin.

title: Still, the Russians Have Their Doubts
description: MOSCOWAfter months of deterioration, dtente is showing signs of revival, The Washington meetings between President Carter and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union have produced some rapprochement in two important areas of SovietAmerican contention: the Middle East and the negotiations to limit the deployment of longrange nuclear weapons.

title: MARKETS
description: Stock prices formed a sawtooth pattern last week and finished on a weakening trend, while prices in the bond marketthe ultimate refuge for a growing army of investorsalso moved lower.

title: Slapping a Penalty on Japanese Steel
description: After years of appeals by American steel makers for protection against lowpriced imports, the Treasury Department last week issued its first ruling in memory against dumping by five Japanese steel makers and Ordered that they immediately begin posting a bond equivalent to a dumping duty of 32 percent.

title: Car Insurance Based on Age, Sex and Area Questioned
description: BOSTONThe first fullscale examination of the practice of charging drivers more for their automobile insurance if they are young, male or live in a congested area got under way here last week as the Massachusetts Insurance Department opened hearings on proposals that could radically alter the established ways of pricing auto insurance.

title: W.H.O. Study Finds Lung Cancer Deaths Are Rising
description: Deaths from lung cancer are increasing worldwide, with the sharpest increase among women, and are unlikely to drop in the near future, according to a study by the World Health Organization.

title: Mary Baxter Bride Of Paolo E. Colombi
description: Mary Catherine Baxter, an assistant in the publicity department of Dodd. Mead, publishers, was married yesterday to Paolo Emilio Colombi, a prod uct specialist for the Olivetti Corporation of America in New York City. The ceremony was performed in the Altamont Reformed Church by the Rev. James Reid.

title: SELECTION: BUILDING AXEL'S CASTLE
description: Dear Perkins: Here is a description of the book of literary criticism of which I was telling you:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Undefeated Michigan Tops Michigan State by 2114
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 8 (AP)Rick Leach passed for one touchdown and ran for another today as undefeated Michigan took a 2414 Big Ten victory over Michigan State.

title: CHESS
description: Whenever you alter a key move in a standard formation, regardless of how desirable your objective may be, it is necessary to see whether you are not also simultaneously giving up something.

title: A Man of Letters
description: ALMOST everyone looked up to him. Writers and critics looked up to him, both those for whom he served as mentor and those ambitious enough to take him as model. So, too, did a company of cultivated readers who knew that regularly Edmund Wilson would come bearing gifts: Read Kipling, even if you detest his politics; read Ulysses Grant's memoirs, even though he was a brute of a general and a dolt of a President; read Agnon. read Dawn Powell, read Pushkin (hopeless as he sounds in English translation), read the Haitian novelist, Philippe ThobyMarcelin. The whole sweep of world literature seemed in Wilson's grasp, to be sifted, judged, protected. He could sometimes be difficult, even haughty, but in his work he was profoundly the democrat, eager to share every pleasure of literary discovery.

title: Vermont Cider: A Lingering Flavor of the Past
description: They're almost all gone nowquaint rarities from our receding rural pastthe hand presses that stood under the Northern Spy apple trees every October, their whirring gears drowning out the buzzing of yellowjackets drunk on windfalls. Gone, too, are the itinerant applepressmen who traveled from village to village with their presses in the backs of wagons. Even the apple orchards are different, as the flavorsome but cranky older varietiesBaldwins and Astrakhans, Sheepsnose and Pippins, Russets and Winesapsgive way to the blander McIntosh and Delicious.

title: Big 4 Auto Makers Try a BuckleUp Campaign
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8The Big Four domestic automobile producers have put approximately $2 million into a buckle up media campaign in Michigan that they hope will result in increased use of seat belts.

title: FLORIDA TRIES KILLING PROBLEM ALLIGATORS
description: GAINESPILLE, Fla., Oct. 8Since the month began a Sarasota man has died as the result of an alligator attack and another man, 150 miles away at Port St. Lucie, lost a hand. In neither instance was the alligator protecting itself.

title: Jorge Manchego, 55, Was Editor Of the United Nations Yearbook
description: Jorge Manchego, editor of the United Nations Yearbook, died Thursday of lung cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: Playhouse Seeks a Financial Encore
description: SINCE apparently nothing succeeds like success, the Performing Arts Foundation Playhouse itself in the enviable position of having to grow to keep up with its success as the Island's only resident professional theater.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The Solomon Islands will issue seven new coins and three new banknotes, plus commemorative stamps, on Oct. 24, to celebrate their upcoming status of full nationhood. They are a group of mountainous volcanic islands and coral atolls northeast of Australia. The largest islands are Bougainville and Guadalcanal, the sites of furious jungle warfare in World War II.

title: Scientists Are Working on Poppy That Does Not Produce Morphine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Agriculture Department scientists are working on a poppy that will not easily produce the raw material for heroin, a House committee on drugs was told today.

title: Cider Touring
description: Below, a listing of 16 western Vermont mills between Bennington and Grand Isle, where the local product may he sampled. Follow the bouncing apple.

title: Marianetta Porter Is Engaged to Minister
description: Lieut. Col. Marion Thomas Porter, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Porter of Warner Robins, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianetta Porter, to the Rev. Martin Edwards Bolton of Detroit, where the wedding is planned for Nov. 6.

title: Post's 2d Straight Shutout Crushes Wagner by 430
description: C. W. Post rolled up 448 yards, 357 on the ground, as it scored a 430 victory over Wagner at the loser's field yesterday.

title: Drought Aid in the Last Year Cost U.S. Government Nearly $2 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Another year of drought, the third in a row for some farmers and ranchers, has cost the Federal Government nearly $2 billion in disaster grants and loans.

title: Jane Beckman, C. F. Baird Jr. To Wed Dec. 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Beckman Jr. of Margate, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter. Jane Beckman, to Charles Fitz Baird Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baird of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Events Today
description: Battle of Pell's Point: re enartment of Revolutionary War battle, crafts exhibits, 11 A.M.; Pelram Bay Park, Bronx

title: Amanda Barney Is Married to John G. Layng
description: Amanda La Montagne Barney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Weir Barney of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to John Gardiner Layng, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Gardiner Layng of Chebeague Island, Me., and Nanles, Fla.

title: Garden to Induct Reed
description: Willis Reed, the new coach of the New York Knicks and the only player in the National Basketball Association to win mostvaluableplayer honors in the playoffs, regular season and allstar game in one year, will be inducted into the Madison Square Garden Hall of Fame tomorrow at the Garden's Hall of Fame Club.

title: The Day in SportsAnd in the Stands
description: The Yankee's beat the Royals, the Cosmos and a Chinese team battled to a tie and the Secretary of State passed the hot dogs.

title: Chinese Recall 1976 Violence In Major City
description: HANGCHOW, ChinaThis omportant industrial city and traditional seat of culture was placed off limits to foreigners for many months last year because of disorder and violence arising from the power struggle directly preceding Chairman Mao Tsetung's death.

title: A Kind of Champion
description: Vicente Aleixandre is not much known in our parts, Lars Gyllensten, secretary to the Swedish Academy, said last week. Nevertheless, Mr. Aleixandre, a Spanish poet, 79 years old and physically ailing, was awarded the 1977 Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: Greenwich and Catholic Play To 77 Draw
description: In a battle of Fairfield County Western Division unbeaten teams, Stamford Catholic and Greenwich High School battled to a 77 deadlock yesterday.

title: GULF DOCKERS BACK A GENERAL STRIKE
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8 (UN)Dock workers at this port, the nation's second largest voted today to continue a strike that has virtually shut it down, disobeying International Longshoreman's Association leaders who wanted only a limited strike.

title: LETTER TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: We read with great interest your article in the Sept. 18 issue concerning the derivation of the names of several Westchester communities. However, the community of Goldens Bridge is quite proud of its two bridges over the Croton River and I wish to correct the part of your article which stated, There's no bridge here now.

title: The Americanization of VW
description: NEW STANTON, Pa.,  The office walls are hung with posters admonishing the workers to new levels of qualitt. Each of the plant supervisors, including $40,000ayearmen, has been told he'll have to demonstrate his ability to tear down and reassemble one of the new productssinglehandedly. And last week a small group of employees, Rabbit logos on their white hard hats, began putting together practice models of the new Americanbuilt car.

title: Social Green Book In the Capital Lists Some New Arrivals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI)Washington's social list was of today, and Jody Powell, Hamilton Jordan and the rest of the Georgia folks were among the honored.

title: Arms Talk, Arms Race
description: Ever since the nuclear arms race began, politicians have been talking about stopping it. The race and the rhetoric continued last week.

title: Storytellers Revive a Lost Art
description: ONCE UPON A TIME, storytelling was the chief art of entertainment. Fairies and devils, heroes and dragons, castles and princesses were part and parcel of a child's experiences.

title: MUSIC
description: MAYBE nobody does anything about the weather, but hundreds of concerned neighbors all over the state have been doing a great deal about their own cultural enrichment. They have formed arts councils and chamber music societies and orchestral auxiliaries and opera companies and concert associations, and through their efforts lovers of the performing arts now find an extraordinary array of talent right at their community doorsteps.

title: Connecticut Reverberates to the Soccer Boom
description: SOCCER, the fastestgrowing youth sport in the country, is scoring heavily in Connecticut. It is drawing boys and girls away from traditional sports and changing the patterns of community and school sports programs. Inspired partly by televised soccer games and the drama of the Brazilian star Pel, who retired Oct. 1 from the New York Cosmos, the boom is having its greatest impact in suburban towns and villages where playing fields may now have goals with nets instead of only goalposts or baseball diamonds.

title: Lyle Shines in Relief, Stopping Royals on 2 Hits in 5 Innings
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 8The Yankees, an endangered species, trimmed the Kansas City Royals, 64, today and forced a fifth and final playoff game here tomorrow night.

title: Headliners
description: A South African newspaper says that Steve Biko, the leader of the South African Black Consciousness movement whose death in prison last month caused an international furor, may have suffered brain damage before he died. The report is based on interviews with six doctors who examined Mr. Biko in the week before his death. The Rand Daily Mail account said there were no apparent signs that Mr. Biko had been on a hunger strike before his death, as had been claimed by South African authorities. The Government has responded by issuing a formal complaint against The Mail, a step some South African journalists fear is the first toward future restrictions on the press.

title: Conversion of Millionaire Estates on L.I. to Country Clubs Pleases Both Owners and Village Neighbors
description: Wroughtiron gates that once guarded the magnificent mansions of millionaires on Long Island are now wide open for wellheeled working people. Monumental maintenance expenses, deaths and taxes have led to the replacement of the little, subdued estate signs bearing such names as Whitney and Vanderbilt by slightly larger but still tasteful guides that read Old Westbury Golf & Country Club, Pine Hollow Country Club and Woodcrest Club.

title: Gov. Harriman Salty Views On SALT, Etc.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Governor came to breakfast with some newspaper reporters this week and, as usual, provided the frankest and saltiest show available in a town where neither frankness nor saltiness is exactly in surplus.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Of Special Interest

title: Putting a New Face on Baby
description: As admiring parents know  and often will say  babies are a lot smarter than most professional baby watchers have acknowledged.

title: Dartmouth Wins, 30, From Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8.Hold em defense was the command from the Dartmouth side and the Green defense did as it was told on its 3yard line in the last minute of the game against Yale today to win by 30.

title: If You Go . . .
description: ... to Dubrovnik, you can teach the city by plane, boat (ferries from Italy and Greece), car (Adriatic Highway from Trieste), and bus. To find your way around, get a map from the Atlas travel agency (Pile 1, tel. 27333).

title: Article 7  No Title
Clifton Wins As Ingram Stands Out
description: Jerome Ingram rushed for two touchdowns and caught a 13yard pass from Bob Holley for another as undefeated Clifton (30) trimmed Ridgewood, 3514. Ingram opened the scoring with a 16yard run in the opening quarter, snatched Holley's touchdown pass early in the second period, and rammed across from 4 yards out just before halftime. Holley tossed a 56yard touchdown strike to Bob Kuchta in the third period for Clifton.

title: Social Announcements
description: ShawErdheim

title: Keep the Judiciary Independent
description: CONNECTICUT'S judicial branch of government is facing a crisis of public confidence because of a series of highly controversial cases this year. Some of the cases and some of the controversy have come out of the courtroom of Superior Court Judge Simon S. Cohen.

title: Josephine P. Bree, 75, Dies; Classics Professor at Magnus
description: Josephine P. Bree, professor of classics at Albertus Magnus College, New Haven, for 45 years and chairman of its classics department until her retirement in 1971, died Wednesday in Bristol, Conn. She was 75 years old.

title: It's Auction Time at Lyndhurst
description: TARRYTOWN A WOMAN who donated a small dressing table she disliked was stunned when it brought in a final bid of $5,000. Of course, she hadn't realized she had given away a rare piece of Duncan Phyfe, one of America's finest early cabinetmakers.

title: Article 10  No Title
It Began 200 Years Ago; There Are 13 Immunizations
description: BETHESDA, Md.Federal scientists late last month reported development of a vaccine effective against one type of meningococcal infection, moving them one small but important stp closer to producing a single vaccine to protect against the three most common forms of bacterial meningitis.

title: Bears Won Title, 730
description: The Chicago Bears defeated the Washington Redskins, 730, in the 1940 N.F.L. championship game and two years later lost to them, 146, for the same title,

title: THE MANY FACES OF A BROWNSTONE
description: Up until the 40's, the turnofthecentury house on New York's West Side was a regal mansion. But, vulnerable to private whim and public trend, it was gradually reduced to a rundown tenement. Now the wheel has turned full circle, and the house is once more a cherished, gracious home.

title: Keeping the Onassis Empire Afloat
description: ATHENSWhen Aristotle Onassis died in early 1975 at the age of 69, his empire was floundering in the worst shipping depression since he entered the business in 1931. Today the shipping business is even worse, and supertankers, which make up 80 percent of the Onassis tonnage, have been hit the hardest. The question: Can his daughter, Christina, now captain of the enterprise, keep it afloat?

title: Cookbook Author
description: TEANECK JUNE ROTH'S first cookbook, The Home Freezer Cookbook, was published in 1963 and is still in print. She is currently working on her 24th cookbook.

title: The Sub Rosa Sub Affair
description: LET'S get one thing straight from the start: the C.I.A. is not filled with amateurish bunglers in dark glasses, sending each other secret messages written in lemon juice. They are not feckless, clumsy, innocent, pedestrian, sentimental, easily deceived, impetuous, spendthrift or dim.

title: Tiny Plants Grow in Small Places
description: Aland crab named Escargot has made himself quite at home in one of Mrs. Anita Baldwin's prizewinning terrariums. Happily, he is content to nibble on dry dog food and peat pots and he does not disturb the plants.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: SOME people in Washington are calling it the battle of the bogs and barrens because of the developing dispute over preserving and enhancing New Jersey's sprawling Pine Barrens as a major wilderness area.

title: GALANTE TO GIVE UP TO U.S. AUTHORITIES
description: Carmine Galante, who has been identified by law enforcement authorities as a leading organizedcrime figure in New York, will surrender to Federal authorities here Tuesday morning in answer to a warrant for his arrest, United States Attorney Robert B. Fiske said yesterday.

title: Westfield and Woolfolk Keep Rolling
description: Harold Woolfolk scored three touchdowns, giving him 10 for the season, as undefeated Westfield coasted to a 310 victory yesterday, its third, over Elizabeth at Elizabeth.

title: A New Way of Looking at a New World
description: SOUTHAMPTON IT is still somewhat befuddling that many art institutions with generally liberal policies balk at abstract art. They might be able to accept the most outrageous forms of realist representation, but they cannot adjust to the special imperatives of abstraction.

title: Manned Spacecraft Launched in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, Oct 9 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today launched its latest manned spacecraft, Soyuz 25, to link with the orbiting space station Salyut 6, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: Carter to Work on Tax Plan
description: THURMONT, Md., Oct. 8 (AP)Presiyesterday at this Presidential retreat at Camp David in the mountains of western Maryland, and promised to spend it working on a plan to change the tax system. He predicted a substantial reduction in the overall tax burden for Americans. He said he would discuss his choice of options with his key advisers next week.

title: In Newark, Music At the Cathedral
description: NEWARK THE Cathedral of the Sacred Heart is as large as Westminster Abbey and has the majestic FrenchGothic architectural details of Notre Dame in Paris.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: YUKIKO and The Big Day illustrate, all too neatly in my opinion, two contrasting attitudes toward the novel, two unrewarding corners into which quite a few authors have painted themselves. MacDonald Harris writes a dogged, slogahead prose under the assumption that his story is irresistible enough to grip and hold the reader. Barry Unsworth offers impressive style and technique that overwhelm the thin and rather stale idea behind his novel.

title: Author Celebrates
description: VINCENZO Buonassisi loves to talk about food and when the subject is pasta, his face lights up. I am mad about it, he says. Proof of his passion is Pasta (Lyceum Books, 1977), his book of 653 pasta recipes, some with variations. This useful volume is a resource capable of providing a different dish for lunch and dinner every day of the year.

title: It's Time for More Energy in Music, Say the Rolling Stones
description: Well, here we are in the middle of the softrocking 70's, and the Rolling Stones just won't go away. They're still making the same crude, rude and raw rockandroll they always made. They're attacked by the punks for being plutocrats even as their lead guitarist, Keith Richard, is being held up once again by the Establishment as an evil example for youth (this time by Canadian. authorities, who have charged him with possession of heroin and cocaine).

title: CAMERA
description: As home color printing becomes more and more popular due to the simplification of the process, many home darkroom enthusiasts wonder whether their old blackandwhite enlargers must be sacrificed for one of the new crop of color enlargers.

title: INTERVIEW
description: ONE day in March 1976, a man named Tam Mossman, an editor at PrenticeHall, brought a couple to meet his friend Jay Anson, who had participated in making a film documentary about the making of the movie The Exorcist.

title: Sanders and McCutcheon Excel As 5,000 Runners Hit the Trails
description: Odis Sanders outdueled John Gregorek, Jessie McCutcheon set a Public Schools Athletic League record, and unbeaten Red Bank Catholic of New Jersey won the unofficial girls' Eastern championship yesterday in the Manhattan College interscholastic crosscountry meet at Van Cortlandt in the Bronx.

title: Miss Cameron Becomes Bride
description: Frances Craven Cameron and David Busby Edwards were married yesterday in Edgartown, Mass., where the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Steele Cameron, also of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have a summer home.

title: A Concept Looking for a Home
description: THE public schools in this nation are fast becoming community treatment centers for the young, with education merely one of several programs. Enormous pressure is on the schools to diagnose every child who is having difficulty and to provide a wide range of remedial projects; however, many of these emerging programs are alien to traditional education and raise anxieties that warrant frequent reassessment and interpretation.

title: Realty News
description: CMC Laboratories Company, suppliers of building, cleaning and maintenance equipment, has leased 20,000 square feet of space or the entn e sixth floor in the 17story building at 180 Varick Street.

title: A Giant Merger On Wall Street
description: Hardly a day goes by in Wall Street without rumors of another merger involving major brokerage houses. For with rising costs and falling revenues, profits have become elusive, and many leaders of the securities business believe only the largest and strongest firms will survive.

title: CONVERSATION WITH FINGERS
description: Istomin: You are a wellknown and, I'm told, respected musician. When and why did you become a baseball nut?

title: Fall Foliage Show:
description: IT IS fall foliage time, and the woods throughout New Jersey are alive with a rainbow of colors as the leaves turn from green to red, yel low and gold. The annual spectacle attracts thousands of visitors to state parks and to highways, where they can view or photograph the gold, scarlet and orange leaves of the colder northern sections of the state and the yellow, reddishpurple and bright reds of trees in the southern areas.

title: 23 Million Consumers, Ignored
description: They represent the fastestgrowing segment of the population23 million men and women, 11 percent of the whole, and their number will be rising to 17 percent over the next three decades. Yet, for most of the marketing community, Americans in their 60's and older don't exist. They are, in the words of one advertising man, an invisible market.

title: The Mauling of the Market: A Capital Question
description: Beyond the news spewing from stock tickers, beyond the frustrations of individual investors, the performance of the stock market for most of the last decade poses a fundamental question:

title: Nancy Pomerene, Editor, Married to Gary McMillan
description: Nancy Lynch Pomerene, the senior editor of Boston magazine, and Gary W. McMillan, a reporter with The Boston Globe, were married yesterday afternoon in Old North Church (Episcopal) in Boston. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Golledge, the vicar, performed the ceremony.

title: Great Estates Retire to a CountryClub Life
description: WROUGHTIRON gates that once guarded the magnificent mansions of millionaires on the Island are now wide open for wellheeled working people. Monumental maintenance expenses, deaths and taxes have led to the replacement of the little, subdued estate signs bearing such names as Whitney, Vanderbilt and Burden. Now the portals are marked by slightly larger but still tasteful guides that read Old Westbury Golf & Country Club, Pine Hollow Country Club and Woodcrest Club.

title: No Passengers on Bahrain Flight
description: LONDON, Oct. 8 (UPI)A British Airways supersonic Concorde flew to the Persian Gulf island of Bahrain yesterday without a single passenger aboard.

title: Fear for Abducted German Grows
description: BONN, Oct. 8West German Cabinet Ministers and high police officials held a special meeting here today to consider a new letter from HannsMartin Schleyer, the kidnapped industrialist, and were described as increasingly worried because of its contents.

title: Music in Review
description: Gomda Hsi, who made her New York recital debut last Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a Chinese singer who has studied in Taiwan, West Germany and the United States.

title: A Lyrical Interpretation of History
description: THE new show at Bridgeport's Downtown Cabaret Theater, LeadIns . . ., like everything that has preceded it, is the creation of Claude McNeal. According to a release distributed by the theater management, the idea behind the show, essentially a revue, is to take a satirical look at how historical events could have inspired certain popular songs. I quote the theater more to reassure myself than to inform the reader, because frankly, there were many moments that didn't seem to fit in with the theme announced.

title: Carter Will Continue Stockpiling Of Material for 3 Years of War
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The Carter Administration will continue to stockpile enough strategic materials to meet military and industrial needs for the first three years of a major war.

title: Cadets' Touchdowns in Last 2 Minutes Top Villanova
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8It was BeattheClock at Michie Stadium today as Army outscored Villanova, 3432, with a pair of touchdowns in the final two minutes.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IN the salty setting of Port Jefferson, on the shores of Long Island Sound, the shops are villagey and quaint, with oldtime names and signs. Among them, however, is the neat and precise Harbor Aquarium, which is just thatan aquarium store on the harbor.

title: IN BRIEF
description: SOCIAL SECURITY withholding increases were voted by the House Ways and Means Committee. The wage base on which the Social Security tax is levied would rise to $19,900 in 1978 and to $27,900 by 1981 from $16,500 at present.... The Senate adopted an amendment to require utilities to offer lifetime electricity rates for senior citizens as a cushion against increasing electric charges.... Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland announced temporary 3.5centapound subsidy payments to American sugar growers. The move Is expected to hold down retail prices for the next two or three months.... The House approved a Senatepassed emergency measure allowing a $52 billion increase in the national debt ceiling to give the Treasury continued borrowing power....

title: Martha Staniford, Banker, Wed
description: Martha Simpson Staniford; a second vice president in the corporate banking department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, was married yesterday in Old Saybrook, Conn., to Reid James Dickinson Dabney, a securities analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. The Rev. Joshua L. Crowell, minister of the First Congregational Church in Essex, Conn., performed the ceremony in St. Mary'sbytheSea Chapel in Fenwick.

title: Long Island This
description: AMAGANSETTSecond Annual Women's Photography Exhibition, with works by Mary O'Conor, Jay Hoops and Pingree Louchem ; 11 A M. to 5 P.M Thursdays through Saturdays through Oct. 17; Gallery East, Main St. Reception today 2 to 4 P.M.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: What broke the audience habit of going to nothing but the season's smash hits and avoiding like the plague all those entertainments that were known not to be selling out? Phrase the question another way. What broke every man's passion for trying to get into the shows he knew he couldn't get into while loftily, studiously, resolutely ignoring the plays and musicals that had seats ready and waiting for him? I raised the matter in a few paragraphs at midsummer, confessing at the same time that I hadn't a really plausible explanation for the change of heart that's taken place, only to receive a number of quite sharp rebukes in the next possible mail. I quite deserved them.

title: City Bars Con Ed From Using Fuel With More Sulfur
description: The Consolidated Edison Company's application to burn fuels with higher amounts of sulfur in its generating plants within New York City was rejected yesterday by Robert A. Low, the city's Environmental Commissioner.

title: Oklahoma Bows to Texas In Duel of Unbeatens, 136
description: DALLAS, Oct. 8 (AP)Texas's thirdstring quarterback, Randy McEachern, came in as a substitute and threw accurate passes to help the Longhorns beat Oklahoma, 136, in a battle of undefeated teams. Earl Campbell supplied the running power in the triumph.

title: Bronx Parochial Schools Score School Board for BookAid Delay
description: Principals and parents from 85 parochial schools in the Bronx joined Assemblyman John C. Dearie last week in protesting what they called the failure of the Board of EducatiOn to provide money for textbooks.

title: Fashion
150 Descendants Turn Out to Honor Man Often Called the Founder of Southampton
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 8About 150 descendants of Edward Howell, described frequently as the founder of the Town of Southampton, gathered here today to dedicate a tombstone at his grave, replacing one that had long since disappeared.

title: BRIDGE
description: The last survivor of the Austrian team that won the first world championship 40 years ago was Karl Schneider, a notable figure in the history of the game. Before he died a few months ago he knew that his countrymen were making a mark on the European bridge scene for the first time in many years.

title: POLITICS
description: THE Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, is trying to run the sprawling county government with at least half a dozen commissionets is whose tenure is in jeopardy or who are responsible to the Democraticcontrolled County Legislaturenot to him.

title: An Alternative to Forest Lawn
description: THOUGH colonial Andover, Mass. had a very low mortality rate, a newly married couple in that town had to know that two or three of their children would die before age 10. When smallpox struck less healthy Boston in 167778, onefifth of the population died; in 18 months the city lost the proportional equivalent of one and a half million New Yorkers today. The Pequot War of 1675 killed a larger percentage of the population than any later war in American history.
