The program proper was preceded by Stokowski'sgravely Wagnerian transcription of Bach's Komm, susses Tod, after which the audience was asked to rise and stand sillently.

title: 6 Independents in Mayoral Race Offer New Yorkers a Dissident Alternative
description: A total of 84,374 petition signatures has put six independent candidates for Mayor of New York City on the Nov. 8 ballot, giving them an opportunity to offer appeals different from the four majorparty candidates.

title: Bell Seeks Way To Get Around E.R.A. Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the Justice Department was trying to determine whether it would be possible to extend the ratification period for the equal rights amendment past its deadline of March 22, 1979.

title: Colts, Down by 18 Points in 2d Quarter, Then Shut Out Dolphins and Win, 4528
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9The Baltimore Colts have had a number of great days, and this day was the equal of any. In a clash of unbeaten teams of the Colts fell 18 points behind the Miami Dolphins during a wild first half in which 52 points were scored but came all the way back to win an exceptional game by 17 points. The score? Baltimore 45 Miami 28.

title: Deaths
description: ADESNIK Morris, beloved, husband of Klara, dear brother of Charles, Sarah Abramowitz, adored father of Ira, Milton and Barry, loving grandfather of Ryan Merrick, Marcle Ann, Rayna Meredith, Arlei David. Service was held October 9. For information contact Brettschnelder Funeral Home, 2543818.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: DAYLIGIIT SAVING TIME

title: Carter Approves Plan to Change The Way U.S. Issues Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9President Carter has approved in principle a plan to change the way the Government prepares and issues the regulations that affect virtually every aspect of American life.

title: Bonnie Five Triumphs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 9 (UPI) The St. Bonaventure University basketball team of Olean, N.Y., defeated Celje of Yugoslavia, 118116, in overtime last night, Clenn Hagen led the Bonnies with 35 points, followed by Tim Waterman with 22.

title: Utah Couple Are Freed on Bail In Killing of Polygamist Leader
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 9 (UPI)A husband and wife suspected as part of a team that killed Rulon Alfred, a polygamist leader, were arraigned and freed on bail in an unusual afterhours city court session.

title: Dr. John Clifford, 46, Retired Dean Of Student Affairs at St. Francis
description: Dr. John Clifford, who retired this spring as dean of student affairs at St. Francis College in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack on Thursday on the campus of St. John's University. He was 46 years old and lived at 25513 East Williston Avenue in Floral Park, Queens.

title: Moynihan Criticizes Carter
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan charged yesterday that the Carter Administration was creating an atmosphere for legitimizing the Palestine Liberation Organization. He said President Carter himself was softening his own campaign promises to uphold Israel's safety and security.

title: Miracles Reported by Pilgrims at Tomb of Saint
description: ANNAYA, Lebanon, Oct. 9Thousands of the faithful gathered on this austere rocky peak of Mount Lebanon to honor the peasant monk who was canonized today at a Vatican ceremony as Lebanon's first saint.

title: TORRIJOS SAYS U.S. RIGHTS ON CANAL ARE NOT DEFINED
description: PARIS, Oct. 9 (AP)Panama's head of government, Brig. Gen Omar Torrijos Herrera, said in an interview published here today that the United States right of intervention is not clearly defined in the new Panama Canal treaty and the pact is thus dangerous.

title: Policing the GeneSplicers
description: Efforts to control possibly hazardous genetic research are foundering. Not long ago we were being warned that recombinant DNA research, a new laboratory technique for splicing genes, was both a blessing and a curse. The technique held great promise for yielding new knowledge and better ways to produce drugs and vaccines, grow crops and treat disease. But concerned scientists warned that the research might inadvertently create disease agents that could cause devastating epidemics or produce new organisms that could disrupt the evolution life. Scientists voluntarily halted their work, the National Institutes of Health drew up safety guidelines, and Congress began considering legislation to regulate the research.

title: Miss Alcott Victor With 70208 in Texas
description: CROSBY, Tex., Oct. 9 (UPI)Amy Alcott, who led since the first day, shot a final round of twounderpar 70 toclay to win a $50,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament by five strokes with a 54hole total of 208.

title: Canadians Climb Himalayan Peak
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 9 (Reuters)The leader and three members of the first Canadian mountaineering team ever to attempt to climb a major Himalayan peak reached the 23,422foot summit of Mount Pumori last Friday, the Foreign Ministry announced tonight.

title: Saturday's College Football Scores
description: Preseason Hockey

title: Options Bolster Brokerage Revenues
description: Options are the hottest game in town for investors and speculatorsand also one of the most lucrative parts of the business these days for brokerage firms.

title: DAYAN THREATENS A GENEVA WALKOUT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that his nation would walk out of any Middle East peace conference where the creation of a Palestinian homeland was suggested by Arab nations.

title: Colombia's Coffee Exports Are Down in Volume, but Up in Value
description: BOGOTA, Colombia (UPI)Coffee ex Ports from Colombia fell by 1.7 million sacks in the year ended September because of the reduction in consumer demand, but their value rose by $549 million, according to the National Federation of Coffee Growers.

title: Panel Will Study Foster Child Care
description: The establishment of a privately financed 20member commission to investigate the problems of 350,000 children in foster care was announced yesterday by the Edna McConnell Clark Foundation.

title: MOST CITY TEACHERS WHO WERE LAID OFF REJECT RETURN OFFER
description: Two out of every three laidoff New York City publicschool teachers who were asked last month to return to the classroom rejected the opportunity, citing the fear of future layoffs, enthusiasm for newfound careers and anger over the assignment of teachers by race.

title: Memorial Services
description: DUNNJohn, father of Brien B. and Mango Dunn,brother of Alice T: Ryan,beloved of Marie Dunn. Memorial service will be held it The Moravian Church Lexington Ave & 30 St.at 6PM,on Tuesday,Oct11.

title: CARTER AIDES DEVISE EXPANDED TAX CUTS TO SPUR INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Increasingly concerned about the sluggish pace of inVestment, Administration planners have expanded the proposed tax reduction for business that President Carter is likely to advocate to Congress as part of a broader tax reform package, Adminis tration sources said today.

title: Richard Steingesser Weds Miss Goulder
description: Alison Goulder, who works in the specialeducation program of the Newton, Mass., schools, was married yesterday to Richard H. Steingesser, who teaches English at the University of Massachusetts in Boston and the Rhode Island School of Design in Providence.

title: Yankee Clubhouse Engulfed At Last With Joy and Spirits
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 9There were two classic scenes: the Yankee clubhouse explosive with joy, champagne and beer sloshing in all directions, smiles, shouts, wisecracks; the Kansas City clubhouse silent, tense with choking disappointment, rows of halfdressed men sitting with their elbows on their knees and their heads down, mostly alone but in a few cases giving pointless answers to pointless questions quietly asked.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A community liaison aide to Mayor Beanie charged yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had resisted appeals by two Congressmen and the city's Orthodox Jewish community to enter the investigation of a diamond broker's disappearance in the days before he was found dead last month.

title: Investigators in Hughes Case Seek Grand Jury Aid on Drug Sources
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9Investigators plan to use a Federal grand jury in Las Vegas, Nev., to try to determine the sources of Howard R. Hughes' supply of drugs, which he might have obtained illegally, according to sources familiar with the case.

title: Janie Sue Ednick Is Married To Ens. Peter Pagano, U.S.N.
description: Janie Sue Endick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Endick of Manhasset Hills, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to Ens. Peter J. Pagano, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Pagano of Delmar. N.Y.

title: Paradox in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9The failure of the SovietAmerican statement on the Middle East to win significant support on Capitol Hill or from the American public at large has underscored the serious problem the Carter Administration faces in trying tco improve relations with Moscow. President Carter and his top foreign affairs aides seem to have learned in the last week that it is easier to gain a solid base of political support when the United States is at odds with the Soviet Union than when the two countries agree.

title: Official Urges Caution On Teaching Career
description: Despite some improvement in the job market for elementary and secondary schoolteachers, the director of personnel for the Board of nucation cautioned students not to switch to the education field in the hope of finding jobs.

title: Seattle Employees Need Not Retire, But Most Are Quitting at 65 Anyway
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 6Robert Stoy, a civil engineer, could have stayed on the job after his 65th birthday; which was two months ago, but he did not.

title: Dogs Lead 14 Blind Persons on a Soaking WalkaThon for Charity
description: Fourteen blind persons, their ponchos snapping in the wind and rain, made their way around a state nark in Westchester County yesterday in what turned out to be a wet trek for the first national walkathon for the Guiding Eyes for the Blind.

title: The Program
description: SURVIVAL, a South African play with music written and performed by Fana David Keicana, Selaelo Dan Maredl, Themba Ntinga, Seth Sibanda. Originally directed Mshengu, who Is also a coautohor; additional staging by Dean Irby; setting by Clyde Kuemmerle; music by Mr. Maredl. Presented by Mr. Kuemmerle In association with the Negro Ensemble Company. At the Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street.

title: Lance Questions Report on Deposits Held by His Bank
description: CALHOUN, GA., Oct. 9 (UPI)Bert Lance, the former budget director, questioned today the accuracy of an article printed by Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, that said more than $1 million in Federal savings deposits, an unusually large amount, was placed in Mr. Lance's National Bank of Georgia earlier this year.

title: World News Briefs
description: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 9 (AP)The Basque separaist organization E.T.A. claimed responsibility today for the killing of a high provincial official and his two police bodyguards.

description: The terms of an agreement between the Bangor Punta Corporation and ChrisCraft Industries Inc. to settle the controversy over the control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation were announced Friday.

title: Montresor Magic Flute Returns to the City Opera
description: When Beni Montresor's production of The Magic Flute was introduced at the New York City Opera 11 years ago, it caught the otherworldly spirit of Mozart's work more truly and more consistently than did many a more loudly trumpeted version. The Montresor decor evoked, remarkably often if not invariably, the magic theater mood that must govern an opera that is continually swinging from childlike fun to dark solemnity. set BULLET

title: Soderstrom Concert Is a Brilliant Occasion
description: For anyone who loves fine singing and the musical sound of the human voice communicating on the highest, most immediate and meaningful level, the recital given by Elisabeth Soderstrom Saturday night at the 92d Street Y was a very special occasion.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Oct. 9A solution to what officials describe as critical insurance problem in New Jersey will be sought at a special meeting in Trenton on Friday.

title: Riot at Tokyo Airport
description: TOKYO, Oct. 9 (AP)About 30 student radicals stormed into the new Tokyo International Airport at Narita, 50 miles northeast of here, early today and firebombed airport guards' quarters and nearby parked vehicles, the police reported. No causalties or arrests were reported. Construction of the airport has been opposed by farmers whose land was condemned to make room for it and by other residents of the area who believe it will damage the environment.

title: West Berlin Police Remove a Nazi Flag
description: WEST BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP)The police today removed a Nazi flag flying from a scaffolding around Victory Column, a leading tourist attraction in West Berlin.

title: Foreign Bank Loans in U.S. Rise Although Business Demand Slows
description: MELVIN VILLAGE, N.H.Lending in the United States by foreign banks has been growing despite a period of poor demand for business loans that has resulted in a decline In domestic commercial and industrial lending by major United States banks, according to statistics released by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston at a conference here.

title: Scheckter Wins At Mosport in Canadian Car
description: MOSPORT, Ontario, Oct. 9 (AP)Jody Scheckter drove the firstever Canadian Grand Prix entry to victory in the Canadian Grand Prix today.

title: Cabdriver, 63, Shot in the Head By Gunman in Long Island City
description: A 63yearold cabdriver was shot yesterday by a man who stepped up to his cab while the driver was discharging a passenger in Long Island City, Queens, the police said.

title: Dr. Irving Linn of Yeshiva Dies at 65
description: Irving Linn, a professor of English at Yeshiva College and a member of its faculty for 40 years, died Wednesday of an apparent heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street.

description: JONESBORO, Tenn., Oct. 9For 51 weekends a year, this serene little enclave of 1,700 people, nestled in the East Tennessee hills, is just another mountain town, distinguishable from its neighbors only by its age and the richness of its history.

title: Nuclear Shift By Pentagon
description: The Carter Administration's plan to proceed with full development of the mobile MX intercontinental ballistic missile may signal a significant change in Pentagon's philcsophy of nuclear war. Until now, the basic emphasis has been on deterrence of war: Peace is Our Profession is an Air Force slogan.

title: Koreans' Churches Provide An Introduction to America
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6The building used to be a supermarket, and, in a sense, it still is, though now it purveys a culture.

title: Wife of Kidnapped Industrialist Appeals to the Bonn Government
description: BONN, Oct. 9The wife of the abducted industrialist HannsMartin Schleyer appealed to the West German Government today to do what was necessary to obtain freedom for her husband held by urban guerrillas since Sept. 5.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the terms of a proposed settlement involving control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation were given incorrectly in The Times Saturday. A corrective article appears on Page 47.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1977

title: Robert P. Morningstar, Chemist And Research Center Founder
description: Robert P. Morningstar, chief chemist for Morningstar Paisley Inc., potatostarch manufacturers, and founder and owner of the Robert P. Morningstar Research Center, with offices here and a laboratory in Milford, Pa., died Saturday at Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old and spent much of his time at his home, Friendly Acres in Milford.

title: Levitt Audit Criticizes Operation Of a Palisades Park Commission
description: A New York State audit report on the operation of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, which runs Bear Mountain and 16 other parks in Orange, Rockland and Ulster Counties, gave the agency good marks Saturday for maintenance and recreational services, but said many, financial practices neded to be improved.

title: TV: Nazi Features Pose Dilemma
description: Channel 13 seems to have wriggled into one of those absurd positions that defy logical explanation. The public television station is doing its public relations best to avoid carrying a controversial edition of Black Perspective on the News featuring an interview with an American selfstyled Nazi and an Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. Yet at 9 o'clock this evening, it will present Leni Riefenstahl's The Triumph of the Will, the notorious documentary enthusiastically glorifying Hitler's Third Reich.

title: Mozambican Leader Visits Cuba
description: HAVANA, Oct. 9 (Reuters)President Samora Machel of Mozambique arrived in Cuba today for an official visit that is erpected to strengthen the close ties between the two Marxist nations. According to diplomats here the visit is apparently aimed at maintaining highlevel contacts with Cuba and to repay a visit to Mozambique by President Fidel Castro in March.

title: LIQUIFIED GAS IS FOUND TO PRESENT FIRE HAZARD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)Existing firefighting methods could not extinguish a large fire of liquefied natural gas on water, according to a report to be I released tomorrow by th6 Office of Technology Assessment.

title: Bridge:
description: The United States has a wealth of highly talented players, and only a tiny minority ever reach the summit by qualifying to play in the world team championship. If the experts were polled and asked to pick the best players who have never had the chance for the highest honors New York would have many players high in the standings.

title: Ruth Teitelbaum Is Bride
description: Ruth F. Teitelbaum, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Teitelbaum of Hewlett Harbor. T.I., was married yeserday to Andrew D. Washton, son of Mrs. Ruth Washton of Brooklyn and the late Samuel Washton. Rabbi Stanley Platek of the HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Center performed the ceremony at the Middle Bay Country Club in Oceanside, L.I.

title: Pedersoli Takes Formula 3 Race
description: VALLELUNGA, Italy, Oct. 9 (UPI)Italy's Oscar Pedersoli won the final two of today's three heats to take the Vallelunga Formula 3 race. Driving a Ralt, he completed the 32 laps in 40 minutes 30.4 seconds for an average speed of 94.24 m.p.h.

title: Parsons Reaches $1 Million Mark
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 9 (AP)Benny Parsons became only the sixth driver in the history of Grand National stock car racing to collect more than $1 million prize money, doing it in style today with an overpowering victory in the $250,000 National 500.

title: Sports Today
description: FOOTBALL

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)An experimental juryselection system that is being tested could save jurors the frustration and personal expense of hanging around the courthouse day after day while waiting to serve at a trial.

title: Nobels Go tot Ulster Women And to Amnesty International
description: OSLO, Oct. 10Two women who ignored danger in campaigning for peace in Northern Ireland were today belatedly named winners of the 1976 Nobel Peace Prize. At the same time. Amnesty International was named winner of the 1977 prize.

title: Notes on People
description: Leonel J. Castillo, who heads the ImMigration and Naturalization Service, took a personal hand in capturing 19 Men suspected of illegally crossing the Mexican border. Mr. Castillo; who is of Mexican descent, was in San Diego over the weekend to appear on a radio talk show when he decided on the spur of the moment to join the Border Patrol in one of its latenight searches for illegal bordercrossers. He operated a searchlight from a helicopter while agents on foot scoured the countryside and flushed out the illegal aliens.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Land Safely Alter Failure of Linkup Mission
description: MOSCOW, Tuesday, Oct. 11 Two Soviet astronauts, forced to abandon their mission only a day after being launched into orbit, returned to earth this morning, according to. Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: News Summary
description: Details on arms negotiations were disclosed by officials in Washington, who said that the United States and the Soviet Union had made substantial concessions in previous positions in seeking to achieve a new accord limiting strategic weapons by the end of this year. The major changes involve Washington's effort to curb Soviet deployment of large missiles and Moscow's attempt to limit airlaunched cruise missiles aboard American bombers. The proposed changes are expected to create controversy in the Pentagon and Congress. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Callaway Reaches Accord in Suit For Libel Over Newspaper Article
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., Oct. 10 (AP)Former Secretary of the Army Howard H. Callaway has reached an outofcourt settlement in his $620,000 libel suit against a local newspaper here, his attorney said today.

title: Dana Profit Rose 17% in Quarter
description: The Dana Corporation, manufacturer of parts for trucks and automobiles, announced yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 30 increased 17 percent from the yearago period. The board raised the cash dividend to $1.20 year from 84 cents to shareholders of record Nov. 29.

title: Scores Up to the Inning Available at 9991313
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: Two Nobel Awards
description: The Nobel Peace Prize is, most often, given for battles not won, for controversies not resolved, for struggles not over. That is the case for the awards announced yesterdaythe 1976 prize to Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams, the leaders of Northern Ireland's largest peace movement, and the 1977 prize to Amnesty International, the Londonbased worldwide organization devoted to securing freedom for prisoners of conscience in all lands.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: American Dance Festival Advised to Seek New Site
description: An advisory panel has recommended that the American Dance Festival, a fixture for 30 years during the summers at Connecticut College, leave the New London campus for a new site next summer. The panel has narrowed the future choices to Duke University in Durham, N.C.; the University of Massachusetts in Amherst and the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee.

title: Israel Radio Editors Stick to Terminology
description: JERUSALEM, Oct 10 (Reuters)News editors of the stateowned Israel Radio today rejected a Foreign Ministry request that they stop using terms such as occupied Arab territory, and refer to Jewish settlements in such areas as legal.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Halt Mission As Linkup to Space Station Fails
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10Two Soviet astronauts had to abandon their mission in space after an unexplained docking failure today and made ready to return to earth, only a day after being launched into orbit.

title: Reducing Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON  In an unprecedented action, the Carter Administration has released for public comment the draft of an executive order to revamp the classification system through which the Government withholds information related to national security.

title: BUILDING IN MIDTOWN IS SOLD TO EUROPEAN
description: In a $24 million deal. a West German investor has taken over one of the major midtown office buildingsthe 25story Pershing Square Building at 100 East 42d Street. at Park Avenue.

title: Carter Adviser Urges Bigger Science Role
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10 (AP) President Carter's science adviser says scientists should explore new paths to help resolve economic and social problems throughout the world.

title: A.A.U. Votes to Revamp Olympic Sports Program
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 (UPI)The Amateur Athletic Union voted at its national convention today to restructure its organization, granting full authority to its 11 supervising committees governing Olympic sports.

title: Gold Gains Sharply In Zurich, London; Dollar Off in Europe
description: LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP)The price gold soared nearly $3 an ounce today on the two major bullion markets as the sagging dollar continued its downward slide against all European currencies except the West German mark.

title: New York City's Quiescent Fiscal State
description: A spate of developments affecting New York City's finances has taken place peacefully in the last few weeks, but those closest to the action say the quiet is misleading. They say the city's fiscal situationwhich has been likened to a roller coaster that has moments of emergency and calm  is reaching a new phase, which can be compared to the roller coaster cars themselves ratcheting slowly up a steeply inclined plane, ready to go over the top.

title: LANDES IS ENDORSED BY AIDE TO CARTER
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 10President Carter and Governor Carey today endorsed Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes of Great Neck for the post of Nassau County Executive.

title: Records of College Football Teams and the Schedules of Their Remaining Games
description: Oct. 15Arizona St. 22At Baylor 29Boston Col. Nov. 5Army 12Vanderbilt 19At Notre Dame

title: TV: Two Programs Tonight Deal With Music One Is Ridiculous, the Other Sublime
description: The sound of music projects is suddenly cluttering the airwaves, Wand the uneven results are decidedly jarring. Among the worst is the debut of a public television series called Music, which can be seen tonight at 7 o'clock. Among the best is a public television presentation called A Good Dissonance Like a Man, a dramatized biography of Charles Ives, tonight at 8.

title: Graceful Farewell
description: If there had been any tears, they had long since dried; anyway, this certainly wasn't the place for them, not at the news conference that he himself had called. This was a time for conciliation and humility, a time for a graceful exit.

title: Belmont Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A major contract has been awarded to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, by Morocco, for the development and installation of a modern integrated air defense system, Westinghouse announced. A spokesman for the company said the value of contract was in excess of $200 million.

title: Futures Prices Fall On Trader Concern Over Dock Strike
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (AP)  Concern about the dock strike at New Orleans and commercial hedge selling whittled soybean and grain futures prices today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Gullett Is Ready to Face Sutton of Dodgers As World Series Opens at Stadium Tonight
description: The baseball world will gather its spent emotions, its spent players and its spent public tonight for the final fling of a season that began six months ago when the New York Yankees and Los Angeles Dodgers open the 74th World Series for all the remaining marbles.

title: Tonight's Series Contest Will Be 77th at Stadium
description: Tonight's game will be the 77th World Series game played in Yankee Stadium since it opened in 1923. Only the Polo Grounds, no longer in existence, was the site of even half that many (47). Of the 426 World Series games played, 157 have been played in New York City, including Brooklyn. This is the 31st Series for the Yankees. They have won 20, lost 10, and their record in games is 9969 (with one tie) for a percentage of .589.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses lisaed in order of post positions

title: Ruth Elder Dies at 73; Won Fame In 1927 Attempt to Fly to Paris
description: Ruth Elder, who captivated two continents a halfcentury ago after her unsuccessful attempts to become the first woman to fly across the Atlantic, died in her sleep Sunday in San Francisco. She was 73 years old.

title: Nine Hurt in Exotic Metals Blast
description: ALBANY, Ore., Oct. 10 (UPI)Nine persons were injured, one critically, last night in an explosion and magnesium fire in a secret processing building at an exotic metals plants. The Oregon Metallurgical Corporation, where the blast occurred, processes exotic metals for space and defense operations.

title: Steelers Run Short of Quarterbacks
description: The worst disaster short of an airplane crash that can befall a pro football team is to lose two quarterbacks through an injury in the same game. It happened to the Pittsburgh Steelers, and their head coach. Chuck Noll, while losing at Houston on Sunday. The immediate future for the team is at best uncertain.

title: Alexandre Allegrier Dies in Paris; Owned LucasCarton Restaurant
description: PARIS, Oct. 10Alexander Allegrier, owner and director of one of Paris's bestknown restaurants, LucasCarton, died here last night at his home. He was 78 years old.

title: Goldin Asserts 940 Were on Aid Rolls Alter Their Deaths
description: Supplemental Security Income checks were mailed by the Social Security Administration to about 940 New Yorkers for at least four months after their deaths, the city's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, said yesterday.

title: Player Cards (No Gum) Extol Fordham Football
description: Fordham's football team finally has returned to a significant spot of prestige in the world of sportsnot because the Rams have a 41 wonlost record so far but because the Fordham publicity department is now handling out Packages of 45 player cards with a picture of a Ram player on each card. Something is missing, however  the bubble gum.

title: Hundreds of Youths Roam Midtown In Rampage of Robbery and Assault
description: Hundreds of marauding teenagers, turned away from an overflow rock concert at Madison Square Garden, stormed through midtown Manhattan last night in a rampage of robbery and assault that continued until scores of police reinforcements were rushed to the area in response to a riot call.

title: About New York
description: The physician reached up with the gently bent arms of a violinist and lovingly aped a patient. Doctor I have such a pain across here. The chest. And a funny thing comes and goes back this way. Angular sweep toward the left shoulder. And then I'm awake all night. Sigh. Helpless hands, Pietstyle.

title: Deaths
description: ADESNIKMorris. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the passing of the father of its member, Dr. Milton Adesnik, and extends to him & the family Its heartfelt condolences.

title: SherryNetherland Hotel Is Robbed; Loot Put in Hundreds of Thousands
description: Four conservatively dressed robbers rifled 73 of the 110 safedeposit boxes, in the SherryNetherland Hotel of an estimated total of several hundred thousand. dollars in cash, jewels and other valuables before dawn yesterday after handmiffing the night manager and three other employees.

title: Action to Ease Pressure on Carter Tied to Moves by Other Countries
description: ROME, Oct. 10Europe's principal steelmakers, in a bid to ease the pressure on President Carter to close the American market to imported steel, offered today to limit their exports to the United States for up to three years, if other big foreign suppliers do the same.

title: CREDIT UNIONS READY TO ISSUE BANK CARDS
description: Credit unions, which have become increasingly involved in traditional banking services, could soon be offering bank credit cards.

title: ARMS SALES ABROAD ASSAILED IN REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 10A report made public today by a Senate subcommittee said President Carter's declared goal of cutting arms exports had fallen a victim of its own rhetoric with no sign of any meaningful restraint.

title: Christians Report Palestinians Reinforce Units in South Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10 (AP)The commander of Christian forces in southern Lebanon says the Palestinians are reinforcing their forces in violation of the recent ceasefire and he called on the United States to send observers to the area.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Most banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day. Securities exchanges were open in the United States, but closed in Canada in observance of that nation's Thanksgiving Day.

title: Cardinal and Bishop Voice Anxiety Over City and Criticize Candidates
description: The two Roman Catholic bishops of New York City, Terence Cardinal Cooke and Francis J. Mugavero. yesterday criticized the city government's performance in education, housing and criminal justice, and the mayoral candidates for failing to talk specifically about these problems.

title: In China, Tight Curbs Woven Into Social Fabric Limit Rights
description: PEKINGTwo or three times a year, a middleaged Chinese man walks into a post office carrying a letter he has written to relatives who are living in Japan.

title: Nobels Go to 2 Ulster Women And to Amnesty International
description: OSLO, Oct. 10Two women who ignored danger in campaigning for peace in Northern Ireland were today belatedly named winners of the 1976 Nobel Peace Prize. At /he same time, Amnesty International was named winner of the 1977 prize.

title: 15,000 Strike at 3 Lockheed Plants
description: BURBANK, Calif., Oct. 10 (UPI)More than 15,000 machinists struck three Lockheed aircraft plants today as a result of a breakdown in negotiations over company and fringe benefits.

title: 30 Arrested in Spain in Campaign Against Terrorists of Right and Left
description: MADRID, Oct. 10 (UPI)Police officials said they had arrested more than 30 persons today, including a revolutionary chief and a group of suspected members, in a campaign aimed against leftwing and rightwing terrorists.

title: Galbreath Filly Wins Beldame At Belmont
description: Offering solid form for the realists and an Italian angle for the hunch bettors, Cum Laude Laurie led the Columbus Day parade at Belmont Park yesterday by winning the $133,375 Beldame Stakes.

title: Yale Picks a Swimming Coach
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10Paul Katz, a graduate of Seward Park High School in New York City, has been appointed interim head coach of the men's varsity swimming team at Yale University. Katz, a 1971 graduate of Yale, is 27 years old. He replaces Ed Bettendorf, who resigned unexpectedly last month. Katz served as an assistant swimming coach at Yale last season.

title: After 14 Years, Koch Is More Than a Face in the Parade
description: Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, Bess Myerson, the comanager of his campaign, marched up Fifth Avenue handinhand yesterday in the Columbus Day parade.

title: F.D.A. Plans Preservative For Eye Cosmetics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration said today that it planned to require inclusion of an antibacterial preservative in mascara and other eye cosmetics to prevent infections that can produce blindness.

title: Guest Falis 7 Stories to His Death; Note Left in West 43d Street Hotel
description: A man described by the police as despondent plunged seven stories to his death at 1 P.M. yesterday from his room at the Times Square Motor Hotel on 43d Street near Eighth Avenue.

title: Bomb Set Off at Nuclear Plant
description: RAINIER, Ore., Oct. 10 (AP)A bomb blast shattered windows today at the visitors' center outside the gates of thee. Trojan nuclear power plant, the authorities said. No injuries were reported and damage was not extensive. The facility has been the site of peaceful demonstrations by groups opposed to nuclear power.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: A new acronymOMAhas entered the lexicon of international businessmen and political leaders. The coined word stands for order y marketing agreement, and it is a kind of quota that governments arrange between themselves when a sudden surge of imports of a specific product by one nation jeopardizes employmeat, production and sales of the other country's industry. themselves when a sudden surge of imports of a specific product by one nation jeopardizes employmeat, production and sales of the other country's industry.

title: Oslo Inquiry Cites Human Error And Poor Planning in Oil Blowout
description: OSLO, Oct. 10A Norwegian Royal Commission investigating the spectacular oilwell blowout in the North Sea last April said today that workmen ignored two warnings that should have led them to stop work on the well and close it down.

title: It Was an Exciting Day for New York: Yankee Fervor...
description: The triumphant homecoming of the New York Yankees yesterday with their second consecutive American League pennant created a mood of excitement that had an inimitable New York City cachet.

title: Amnesty Unit, 16 Years Old, Gains Ends by Pressure and Publicity
description: Amnesty International, the Londonbased group that won the 1977 Nobel Peace Prize, began with a newspaper article 16 years ago calling for formation of such an oragnization.

title: ...and Metropolitan Opera's OpeningNight Glamour
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its 93d season last night on a cool, clear New York evening that allowed those who were so inclined to parade their finery. But the occasion was deliberately more somber and businesslike than some past Met openings, and the reason was not only in the choice of the opening opera, Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov.

title: The U.N. Today
JOSEPH BURNHAM, 57, OF MARSHALL FIELD
description: Joseph A. Burnham, chairman and chief executive officer of Marshall Field & Company. Chicago, the nation's largest independent departmentstore chain, died early yesterday apparently of a heart attack at the Community Hospital, Geneva, Ill.

title: Somalia Trys to Live by Both the Koran and Das Kapital
description: MOGADISHU, SomaliaTwo years ago, when it was pressing a campaign to emancipate women, the Somali Government was vexed to find conservative religious leaders preaching against equality of the sexes and supporting their arguments with readings from the Koran.

title: Union Insurance Looting Linked to Federal Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)A Florida insurance department official told Congress today that secrecy among Federal agencies was partly responsible for failure to prevent the systematic looting of union insurance premiums.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, OCTOBER 10, 1977

title: Jazz: Pianist of Tristano School
description: Lennie Tristano, the jazz pianist, composer and theorist who was a center of controversy during the late 1940's, has been heard from in recent decades principally through the work of his disciples. Of these, the saxophonists Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh have gone their individual ways, although both continue to pay homage to Mr. Tristano from time to time. Sal Mosca, a pianist, is perhaps the most gifted musician who continues an overt association with the Tristano school, and it was Mr. Tristano who produced Mr. Mosca's solo piano concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday evening.

title: Blumfield Back at Keyboard
description: Coleman Blumfield, a pianist who has not been active on the concert stage for some time; gave his first New York recital in 16 years Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall. It was in some ways an impressive return, though ultimately disappointing in its lack of interpretative insight and depth.

title: DOCK STRIKE IN 10TH DAY, WITH NO SIGN OF CONTRACT
description: The strike of longshoremen on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. went through its 10th day yesterday with no indication of an early settlement.

title: $45 BILLION OUTLAY PROPOSED BY AMTRAK FOR A5YEAR PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Amtrak announced today a S4.5 billion fiveyear operating and improvement plan that would provide new highspeed passengertrain corridors and new equipment, including 150mileanhour trains for the BostonNew YorkWashington line. But the railroad corporation is expecled to face a tough struggle in geting Federal authorization for the program.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FREE AND LIMBER The Versatile Edward Villella, who not long ago leaped into the theater as Pal Joey, is also a reputable communicator in his special art of dance. In a program tonight at 8 P.M. to which the public is invited, Mr. Villella, a principal dancer of the New York City Ballet, will give a lecturedemonstration on physical dynamics and the relationship between dancing and athletics, centering on a film that he himself made.

title: Opera: Kord Conducts Godunov
description: Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov, which caused quite a stir in its new staging at the Metropolitan Opera several years ago, came back last night as the opening of the Metropolitan's 197778 season. In some respects it was a sober choice for an opening. Boris Godunov is not one of those operas with surefire arias and wellknown tunes, and some in the audience were decidedly restive.

title: U.S. to Cite Soviet Rights Violations
description: BELGRADE, Oct. 10The United States is preparing to start bringing up precise cases of Soviet and Czechoslovak human rights violations at the European security conference when its chief representative speaks in private session here tomorrow, official American sources said tonight.

title: Dow Off 0.09; Holiday Cuts Volume
description: Increasing concern over higher interest rates sent the stock market down slightly yesterday in the slowest trading session in 21 months.

title: Dr. Lyndon Peer, Plastic Surgeon
description: Dr. Lyndon A. Peer, a pioneer of plastic surgery who developed a method for using the natural healing abilities of the human body to build ears, died Saturday. night in his home at Boca Raton, Fla. He was 78 years old and had retired five years ago from his practice in Newark to live in Boca Raton.

title: Bhutto Foe Urges Military To Set Election in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 10, (AP)Former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto's chief political opponent called on the military Government today to lift its ban on political activity immediately and set a date for elections.

title: Senate, 851, Approves Bill to Bar Use of Minors for Pornography
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight legislation that would make it a crime to use minors in producing pornography or to sell or distribute material depicting minors in sexually explicit acts, whether or not those acts were obscene.

title: Somalis Said to Start Ethiopia Push
description: DJIBOUTI, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Somali guerrillas have begun a drive to capture the mountains of eastern Ethiopia and are advancing along a railroad to the Ethiopian town of Diredawa, informed sources said.

title: How Not to Ease the Tuition Squeeze
description: It is called the Tuition Tax Credit Plan and at first glance it looks socially just and politically irresistible. Steadily mounting school bills now face millions of middleincome taxpayers who lack the means of the rich and the access to scholarship aid of the poor. Private education is hardpressed and needs financial help. What, then, could be more welcome than the new proposal give tuitionpaying taxpayers a tax credit of up to $500 per student? That approach, say its advocates, Oregon's Republican Senator Packwood and New York's Democratic Senato'r Moynihan, would not only help families; it would permit consumers to choose freely from the supermarket of educational institutions. It would apply to every full or parttime student who pays tuition in an accredited elementary or high school, college, university, trade or vocational school.

title: Queen Lib, $9.40, Scores
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 10 Queen Lib won the richest race for New Jerseybred thoroughbreds tonight at the Meadowlands. Owned by Reeve Schley Jr., board chairman at Monmouth Park, the 2yearold Queen Lib scored by two lengths in the $68,090 New Jersey Futurity.

title: U.S. Finances Study On Rationing of Gas With Credit Cards
description: A New York public accounting firm said yesterday that it had received a Federal contract to determine the feasibility of a gasolinerationing plan that would involve the use of credit cards rather than coupon books.

title: Gin Game Author Lives a Miracle
description: The Gin Game, the new twocharacter play just arrived at the Golden Theater, costars Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, is directed by Mike Nichols, and is written by D. L. Coburn. Who is D. L. Coburn?

title: Marjorie T. Lee Wed To Charles Steadman
description: The marriage of Marjorie T. Lee of McLean, Va., to Charles W. Steadman of Palm Beach, Fla., and Washington, chairman and president of the Steadman Security Corporation, took place yesterday at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington. Only members of the, immediate families attended the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Dr. Louis Evans.

title: Applause for Mrs. Carter
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Oct. 8 (AP)Rosalynn Carter was loudly applauded when she tried out her Spanish on arrival here today in Puerto Rico. Then she switched to English and promised to work in any way that I can to further her husband's commitment to human rights.

title: OPEC DEMANDS ROLE IN REFINING INDUSTRY
description: VIENNA, Oct. 10 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is prepared to take action to gain a larger role in the refining and petrochemical industries, an OPEC official said today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Education officials in Matawan planned to open the schools for halfday sessions today while continuing to negotiate with striking teachers.

title: Ocean Research Finds Nothing Supernatural
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (AP)A Soviet research team has returned from the Bermuda Triangle, a patch of the Atlantic Ocean in which there have been many ship and aircraft disasters, with the belief that nothing supernatural is responsible for the area's high accident rate.

title: Preacher Who Pioneered DriveInReligion Gains Followers With His Upbeat TVShow
description: GARDEN GROVE, Calif. For 47 years I was doing nothing, just floating, Bill Vassis said. But in the last year, my whole life has been turned around.

title: Legion Disease Present Before Vermont Outbreak
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., Oct. 10 (AP)Blood tests by the National Center for Disease Control indicate that the legionnaires' disease was present in the Burlington area before the recent outbreak, the Medical Center Hospital of Vermont said today.

title: VENEZUELA TO SELL $150 MILLION IN NOTES
description: As the kickoff for a substantial volume of Yankee bond financing this month, Venezuela is scheduled to sell $150 million of notes tomorrow amid signs that demand for such securities isn't all that robust and that interest rates are headed higher.

title: Books of The Times
description: TRUE CONFESSIONS. By John Gregory Dunne. 341 pages. Henry Robbins/ Dutton. $9.95.

title: MAJOR CONCESSIONS BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON ARMS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The United States and the Soviet Union, in an effort to achieve a new pact limiting strategic arms by the end of the year, have made substantial concessions in their positions, Administration officials said today.

title: A.M.A. Skips Health Care Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI)On advice of its legal counsel, the American Medical Association declined to appear today at Senate hearings on competition in the health care industry. An A.M.A. spokesman said that the organization's lawyers and outside legal counsel had advised against appearing at hearings by the subcommittees on health and in antitrust and monopoly since the organization was involved in litigation with the Federal Trade Commission over the same issues.

title: Bridge:
description: An amicable divorce was brought about here unobtrusively last month when the NassauSuffolk Bridge Association broke away from the Greater New York Bridge Association. For more than 20 years Long Islanders have been the junior partners in the organization, but their leaders recently decided that they could serve their members more effectively by operating independently.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Caprice Waltzes on Themes of Strauss, Tausig; Slavonic Dance No. 6, Dvorak; Overture to La Poupee de Nuremberg, Adam; Moment Musical, Rachmaninoff; El Salon Mexico, Copland; Dance: OvertureWaltz, Shostakovich.

title: Briton, in Soviet, Sees Brezhnev on Detente
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary David Owen of Britain today met for 80 minutes with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to discuss how the two countries could work together for disarmament and detente.

title: Market Place
description: In a landmark decision, the highest court in Delaware has ruled that minority shareholders may not be squeezed out in a merger without regard to underlying considerations of fairness.

title: Israel Approves Six New Settlements on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10The Israeli Government has approved six new Jewish settlements in Israeli military and police bases ringing the Samarian hills in the occupied West Hank of the Jordan River, Israel's Deputy Defense Minister said today.

title: G.O.P. Governors Give Lessons On Increasing Their Ranks in '78
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Oct. 10Members of one of the world's more exclusive political clubs, the Republican Governors Association, convened here today to lament the current low ebb of their party's fortunes and to develop A strategy to increase their number in 1978.

title: Article 3  No Title
Two Battlers for Peace
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams now look like a match made in heaven, but they were a distinct long shot for the Nobel Peace Prize when they met 14 months ago in Belfast.

title: NATIONALIST'S RETURN SPURS ISLAND DEBATE
description: SAN JUAN, P. R. Oct. 10Andres Figueroa Cordero came home to Puerto Rico to die, but his return has given impetus to the seemingly endless debate about this Caribbean island's relationship with the United States.

title: ILLEGAL USE OF FILES IS LAID TO DOCTOR
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 10A state agency has found that the medical director of the methadone clinic here showed the Police Commissioner the personal medical files of a woman who had accused the Police Department of failing to investigate a murder complaint involving Frederick W. Cowan, the gunman who later killed six persons and threatened her life.

title: Los Angeles Schools Plan Busing Amid White Flight
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10  After more than a decade of legal battles over integration the nation's second largest school system is edging toward mandatory busing for thousands of children via the freeways of this farflung city.

title: Phillips Reports Safety Progress
description: Phillips Petroleum said yesterday that valuable lessons have been learned in the North Sea blowout and would be applied diligently to attempt to prevent other accidents in the future.

title: New Knick Hopeful
description: Jim Cleamons said hello to New York yesterday without a trace of the flair of Walt Frazier, who said goodbye to New York and its nightlife, several blocks from Madison Square Garden.

title: Letter: On Westway
description: To the Editor:

title: Humphrey Has New Tests
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 10 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey underwent new cancer tests today and his physician. said that no statement on the former Vice President would be given until the results had been evaluated. The Minnesota Democrat underwent surgery in August and doctors found terminal cancer in the pelvic area. Since then, he has undergone radiation treatment and chemotherapy.

title: U.S. Ability to Cope With Gas Shortage In Winter Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)A Senate subcommittee issued a report today that said the new Department of Energy had seriously overestimated the Government's ability to cope with natural gas shortages if there is another cold winter.

title: MAJOR CONCESSIONS BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON ARMS REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The United States and the Soviet Union, in an effort to achieve a new pact limiting strategic arms by the end of the year, have made substantial concessions in their positions, Administration officials said today.

title: For Edna O'Brien, Writing Is a Kind of Illness
description: LONDONEdna O'Brien is a fertile woman, having birthed eight novels in 10 years, plus one play, two sans, two volumes of short stories and one book of nonfiction. Her new novel, the first in five years, Is a slim volume of plump fantasies, told in the first person, of a 40ish woman's love and subsequent murder of a young man.

title: No Panic Button Yet
description: Is it yet time for those who have wished him well to press the panic button about the performance of a President Carter who seems, as the months go along, more and more inept, inexperienced and unwilling to stand behind his own professions?

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Costume Jewelry Liberated at Last
description: Discreet gold chains and circle pins have little to do with today's voluminous freeform clothes. Costume Jewelry, generally, has been fairly boring lately, according to Gloria Fiori, Jewelry buyer for Bonwit Teller.

title: Tubas Are the Law of Gravity
description: Gravity, which is performing at Axis in SoHo every Sunday in October at 6 and 7:30 P.M., is the latest of a succession of tubadominated ensembles led by Howard Johnson. Although it is nominally a jazz group, playing in a gallery largely given over to new jazz, there is nothing experimental about the band except its instrumentation. Gravity boasts six tubas and a rhythm section, but the music it plays is as close to oldtime blues and rock as it is to contemporary jazz.

title: Ballet Stars Tour the Other Manhattan
description: MANHATTAN, Kansas, Oct. 9There is nothing, it might be thought particularly peculiar about Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins, of the New York City Ballet dancing in Manhattan. But think again, for this was not Manhattan the island, but Manhattan the city, tucked away in Kansas.

title: Westward, Lo, How Strange the Shores
description: Columbus waded ashore. I hereby discover America he said. An official asked what he thought he was doing. When Columbus told him, the official asked to see his discovery permit.

title: U.S. Plan to Assist Inmates of States Provokes Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10In an action that has touched off a constitutional controversy, a House subcommittee has unanimously approved legislation to enable the Federal Government to initiate and intervene in lawsuits to protect the rights of inmates of state institutions.

title: Pain in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 10The pain was worse because this was the second time, in nearly identical fashion, that disaster had struck. When the New York Yankees snatched the American League pennant out of the hands of the Kansas City Royals in the ninth inning of the final game 51 weeks ago, this midAmerica baseball community felt stunned and unhappy.

title: Dayan Lists Points Termed Essential For Mideast Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 10Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that a Middle East settlement would have to insure Israel's security and also safeguard its rights of freedom of navigation in the waterways of the area and its use of the vital waters of the Jordan River.

title: Pure Oxygen System To Aid Elderly Scored
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 10 (UPI)A new medical study says that a costly fountain of youth oxygen technique for perking up mentally sluggish elderly people probably produces no more stimulation than a couple of martinis.

title: Steel Earnings For 3d Quarter Expected to Fall
description: Analysts unanimously are revising downward their projections for thirdquarter steel company earnings, and their estimates for 1977 as a whole.

title: A Judge Orders Bell to Subpoena Times Reporter on Article Source
description: A Federal judge in Miami has ordered Attorney General Griffin B. Bell to subpoena Seymour M. Hersh, a New York Times reporter, and determine his source for an article last January on a sealed grand jury report dealing with a controversial Federal tax investigation.

title: Chicago Board of Trade Selects Crocker Official as Its President
description: After a highly secretive sixmonth search, the Chicago Board of Trade, the largest commodities exchange, yesterday elected Robert K. Wilmouth as its president.

title: Excerpts From Debate Between Bateman and Byrne on Issues in Gubernatorial Campaign
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between two major candidates for Governor of New Jersey Governor Byrne, Democrat, and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, Republican  before editors and reporters of The New York Times:

title: Thousands Gather at New England Summit
description: JAFFREY, N.H., Oct. 10 By the time a raw gray dawn had broken over the golden woods of southern New Hampshire, 19yearold Vance Geldart and his brothers and friends had already made it to the top of Mount Monadnock here. The group, from Amherst, Mass., managed to avoid the crowds.

title: Carter Wellhead Tax: Does It Make Sense?
description: As the battle over President Carter's proposed crude oil tax rages, attention is focusing on a theory, espoused by a growing numbs of economists, that the tax will never do what it is intended to doraise the price of oil products and thus promote conservation. This same theory holds that existing price controls have in fact failed to hold down the price of gicioline and other petroleum products. It suggests that, because of quirks in the controls, the oil industry has been legally pocketing enormous sums in savings that should have been passed along to consumers.

title: Socialists' Offer to Talk Rebuffed by French Reds
description: PARIS, Oct. 10 (UPI)The French Communists today rebuffed a Socialist proposal for negotiations to patch up a quarrel that is threatening to split their alliance and lose voters to the Government of President Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: New Chairman at Gulf States
description: Directors of the Gulf States Utilities Company of Houston have designated W. Donham Crawford to succeed Floyd R. Smith as chairman and principal executive officer. Mr. Smith, who is 64 years old, will be retiring next year. Mr. Crawford, 55, has been president since 1969 of the Edison Electric Institute, a trade association.

title: East Germany Is Said to Hold Thousands of Dissidents
description: LONDON, Oct. 10 (AP)Thousands of political, religious or cultural dissidents are being held as political prisoners in East Germany, Amnesty International said today in a report on human rights violations.

title: It Was an Exciting Day for New York: Yankee Fervor
description: The triumphant homecoming of the New York, Yankees yesterday with their second consecutive American League pennant created a mood of excitement that had an inimitable New York City cachet.

description: BEIRUT. Lebanon. Oct. 10Syria insisted today that the Palestine Liberation Organization be represented at the Geneva peace talks.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (Reuters)Two highranking retired military officers warned today that failure of the Senate to approve the neW Panama Canal treaties would cause rejoicing in Moscow, but their views were disputed by another leading exmilitary figure.

title: U.S. Beats China in Soccer
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP)Fred Pereira scored late in the final half to give the United States national soccer team a 10 victory over China tonight at Atlanta Stadium. A crowd of 15,003 watched the Chinese mount three mild scoring threats. However, the United States goalie, Arnold Mausser, stopped two shots while the other went wide of the goal.

description: The Rev. Dr. Herbert G. May, a Bible scholar and emeritus professor of religion at Oberlin College since 1970, died Saturday of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Oberlin and Jacksonville.

title: End to Medicaid Abortion Funds: A Change in the Social Landscape
description: As the SenateHouse deadlock over the restriction on Federal aid for abortions drags on, at least one outcome is certain: Far fewer abortions will be paid for by Medicaid, and abortions will thus be significantly less available to poor women than they have been in the past.

Bateman acknowledged yesterday for the first time in his campaign for the New Jersey governorship against Governor Byrne that if the state's economy failed to rebound sharply in 1978, it would cause tremendous problems for his plan, to run the state without an income tax for the next four years.

title: Amnesty Chief For U.S. Sees Long Struggle
description: He had fully intended to take Columbus Day off, David Hawk was saying yesterday, and then someone called with the news that Amnesty International had been awarded the 1977 Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Laurence Bunker, Was Aide to And Charter Member of John Birch Society
description: Laurence E. Bunker, a retired Army colonel who served as Gen. Douglas MacArthur's chief aidc and later became a leading member of the John Birch Society, died yesterday at New England Baptist Hospital iii Boston. He was 75 years old and had been under treatment for cancer for the last five weeks.

title: Article 1  No Title
YankDodger Tradition: Eight Memorable Series
description: This is the ninth YankeeDodger World Series, and all eight of their previous meetings have produced something especially memorable in baseball history. No other two teams have been paired as often in World Series play. But it is only their second meeting since the Dodgers moved from Brooklyn to Los Angeles 20 years ago. Here is a summary of what happened in those Series:

title: Shakespeare's World Series Staff
description: Assignments. gentiemen, assignments, William Shakespeare said. We've finally got a World Series worthy of us all, the World Series we've been waiting for all these centuries  the Yankcees and the Dodgers, the best team money can buy against the best team money can develop. It's too big for the sportswriters. It demands a literary treatment. And we've got the staff to handle it the way it should be handled, the way nobody else can handle it. I know you would all like to get a crack at this, but I had to be very selective in my assignments. The right man for the right subject. Please forgive my slang, gentlemen, I've been watching too much TV lately. But seriously, gentlemen, I've thought about these assignments very carefully. If anybody has any objections, I'll take questions later. But this is the way I see it. Big Julie, I know you prefer being a war correspondent, but I've got iust the man for you, a combination of Ghengis Khan and Adolph Hitler, a man you can really appreciate, Big Julie, a man whose gall is divided into three parts  win, win and win.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUMENTHALMimi. Put out my eyes & I can see you still & with no cars I can hear you yet. You live in my heart with all my love dear Mimi.

description: The New York Rangers added another goalie to their swollen corps yesterday, acquiring Wayne Thomas from the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League's first waiver draft.

title: A CoverUp in South Africa
description: The South African Government has always made much of its devotion to the rule of law. You may not agree with our policies, Pretoria's spokesmen have said with reference to the rigid racial segregation which permeates every aspect of South African life, but you cannot accuse us of running a police state which denies people due process of law. Given the recent developments in the case of Stephen Biko, the young black leader who died in police custody a month ago, that claim must be seen as patently false.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., President Carter's nominee for Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, suffered what was described as a minor relapse from abdominal surgery and returned home to Alabama today, one day before the scheduled start of confirmation hearings.

description: Over the years, the Internal Revenue Service has confused, annoyed, and angered thousandsperhaps millionsof taxpayers, because of snarls and delays in its replies to their inquiries about such routine items as lost refund checks or billins notices.

description: ATLANTA, Oct. 10Senator John G. Tower called on the Carter Administration today to produce an expanded plan to assist mass transit as soon as possible or risk having its program become lost in the budget process next year.

description: CHICAGO, Oct. 10 (AP)Bob Avellini hurled three long touchdown passes 70 and 72 yards to James Scott and 29 yards to Greg Lattaas the Chicago Bears upset the Los Angeles Rams, 2423, tonight.

But the occasion was deliberately more somber and businesslike than some past Met openings, and the reason was not only in the choice of the opening opera, Mussorgskys. Boris Godunov.

title: OffDuty Policeman and a Suspect Are Shot in Bar in Williamsburg
description: An offduty police officer was shot in the chest early this morning at a bar in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, the police reported.

title: Mail Volume Increases; Rate Rise Likely to Be Slowed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP)A trend toward less use of the mails has been turned around, and officials say the result is that postal rates now are not expected to rise as fast as had been predicted.

title: The Yankees as New Yorkers
description: For much of the year, the metaphor for New York City has been the Mets. Discouragement. The loss of precious assets, like Tom Seaver. Defeat. When things were at their gloomiest, you could look over to the Bronx for diversion but not much inspiration. The Yankees were a gang of gaudy, greedy, brawling geniuses, haggling over their millions between innings and churning up such storms you never knew from day to day whether Billy Martin was still the manager, or who was playing right field. They were certainly not the classy pinstripe gentlemen that Joe McCarthy or Casey Stengel led. Still, they won 100 games (while the Mets were lucky not to lose 100) so they became at least interesting. And finally, incredibly, they were more than interesting. For at the climax, they found the power and the money failing them. At the chastening edge of disaster they somehow mustered those special qualities of scrounging and hustle that distinguish New York, and they became a team for this place and this time. Let Los Angeles have the Olympics in 1984. Bring on the Dodgers, now.

title: Yeshiva in Forest Hills Is Closed Until It Can Pay Salaries of Staff
description: A Jewish parochial school in Forest Hills, Queens that has been in financial difficulty for a number of months was closed yesterday after its 60 teachers refused to work until their overdue October salaries were paid.

description: A fur coat used to be a security blanket when the temperature plummeted, or a rewardlike a service stripeon an anniversary for having stayed married to the same man for 10 or 20 years.

description: Al McGuire, who retired from coaching after his Marquette University basketball team had won the National Collegiate championship last season, has been hired as a commentator by NBC Sports, it was announced yesterday.

Yesterday, in the league draft, the Apples selected John Newcombe, Evonne Goolagong, Arthur Ashe and Dick Stockton. All except Ashe have previous W.T.T. experience: Newcombe with Houston in 1974 and Hawaii in 1975, Miss Goolagong with Pittsburgh from 1974 to 1976 and Stockton with Houston in 1974.

Ct. Mrs. Walter E. Robb, Ill of Sherborne, Mass. Also survived by b grandchildren. title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: WHEN it is a question of speedcooking, that is to say in less than an hour, the advantages of boneless cuts of meat are obvious. And of all those boneless cuts there are few with more flavor than veal. Veal, on the other hand, requires a bit more knowledge of meat cookery than does, let us say, beef, lamb or pork. Whereas beef and lamb may be cooked rare or well done or some point in between, according to taste, the cooking time is fairly easy to manipulate. Pork, of course, must be cooked to a fairly welldone state because of the nature of the meat (and there is something to be said, even, for pork that has been long cooked on occasion until it is fork tender).

title: Police Added After the Rampage By Turnaways at Rock Concert
description: Seventy policemen, more than twice the normal contingent, were assigned to the Madison Square Garden area for last night's rock concert, to prevent a recurrence of the Monday night rampage by youths who were turned away from a soldout concert, Last night's performance was not sold out, and there were no incidents or arrests, in contrast to Monday night.

title: Scores Up to the Inning Available at 9991313
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

description: Mayor Beanie yesterday welcomed a move by three major corporations to New York City and a longterm lease renewal by a fourth company. The three new corporations are expected to provide 750 jobs.

description: Bernard Bergman, the nursinghome operator who pleaded guilty to Medicaid fraud and bribery charges, yesterday won another delay of his oneyear prison sentence.

title: Books of The Times
description: Like any country, the real India is only as real as the people in it. But the Indians, unlike the people of most countries, are tremendously diverse. The Aryan origins of most northerners and the Dravidian origins of most southerners are completely different. The majority of Indians are Hindus, but there are more than 60 million Moslems and millions of Sikhs, Buddhists, Christians and Parsis. There are at least 15 major languages, some of them related to others, but some distinctly separate.

title: Thiokol and Hoover Ball Plan a Merger
description: The Thiokol Corporation and the Hoover Ball and Bearing Company announced merger plans yesterday in a stock deal that would involve some $181 million for Hoover Ball shareholders.

title: At Frankfurt Fair, Eyes Are on Books With Legs
description: FRANKFURT. Oct. 11This year, even more than in the past, the 29th annual book fair that opens tomorrow in Frankfurt am Main is a political, commercial and, if you look hard for it, literary event. Seventyfive nations from Afghanistan to Zaireare exhibiting, which is just over half the number of states in the United Nations. It is still a record. More than 4,500 publishing houses are displaying 280,000 books. Germany, Britain and the United States lead in the number of booths, with 375 American publishers represented. Only a Jean Monnet or PaulHenri Spaak would understand the dynamics of the international common market that takes place here, said Stewart Richardson, editor in chief of Doubleday & Company. It's a game of show and tell raised to the level of literature. Frankfurt is the third and the largest of the international book fairs held in 1977, topping the earlier Jerusalem and Moscow fairs. In a literary sense, its size and commercialism are troubling.

title: Haywood Gets 27 as Knicks Beat Celtics
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 11 (AP)Spencer Haywood scored 27 points and grabbed 12 rebounds tonight to pace the New York Knicks to a 113109 exhibition basketball victory over the Boston Celtics.

Whatever the outcry over these scientific disputes, an essential element in this debate is largely missing: What ought to be our national investment in our scientific future?

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The National Academy of Sciences, in a twoyear study of ipvietAmerican scientific exchanges. has concluded that although in many fields Soviet scientists benefit more than Americans, the 18yearold exchange program has been highly valuable and should be expanded.

title: Boeing Strike Talks Scheduled

title: 4Nation Import Ban Set On Horses for Breeding
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The United States has banned imports of horse breeding stock from France, England, Ireland and Austria because of outbreaks of a newly discovered venereal disease, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

title: Europe Revives School Debate: Which Students Go to University
description: PARIS, Oct. 11The old debate over who should go on to university education and who should be relegated to bluecollar employment has been revived with a new vigor in Western Europe in recent months.

title: Escaped. Murderer Captured
description: BEALLSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP)Russell Shoates, a convicted murderer whose escape from prison Sept. 14 terrorized parts of western Pennsylvania and prompted at least two school closings, was captured last night by the state police. The police said the fugitive was found in the back seat of a car stopped by the police on a Washington County highway after he had apparently taken the driver hostage.

title: BODY OF GEM DEALER BELIEVED TO BE FOUND
description: The badly charred body of a murder victim resembling a missing New York City diamond dealer, Abraham Shafizadeh, has been found in Puerto Rico, officials there said yesterday.

title: Progress on Rhodesia Is Discerned
