description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of Los Angeles, one of the biggest softdrink bottlers in the country, said yesterday that its directors had rejected a $410 million takeover bid by MCA Inc., the big entertainment company, as inadequate.

title: MINORITY GROUP STUDENTS UP 16.8% AT U.S. COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The number of minority group students at United State; colleges went up 16.8 perent from 1974 to 1976, and now minorities make up 15.2 percent of the total enrollment, according to a survey released today.

title: Colts' Jones: Best Passer In N.F.L.?
description: Who is today's best quarterback? Those who saw his proficiency last Sunday in Baltimore's Memorial Stadium, and the audience included yesterday's best, John Unitas, could hardly choose any other than Bertram Hays Jones. The Unitas heir this season will leave his competitors  Ken Stabler, Roger Staubach, Ken Anderson and Fran Tarkenton  in his prominent shadow.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Punch's Departing Editor Finds Humor Not So Droll
description: When he was invited to become editor of Punch, nine years ago, William Davis called Malcolm Muggeridge, the departing editor,and asked his advice. Mr. Muggeridge said the magazine's owners were no laughing matter, but journalism, after all, was an adventure. Mr. Davis plunged.

title: Punch's Departing Editor Finds Humor Not So Droll
description: When he was invited to become editor of Punch, nine years ago, William Davis called Malcolm Muggeridge, the departing editor, and asked his advice. Mr. Muggeridge said the magazine's owners were no laughing matter, but journalism, after all, was an adventure. Mr. Davis plunged.

title: Tired of Losing, Giants' Tucker Seeks Trade
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 11Bob Tucker, understandably, wants to leave his frustrations and the Giants behind.

title: Beame to Be Given Award
description: Mayor Beame will be the recipient of a Golden Bucket award on Saturday afternoon at a concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in appreciation for the efforts of 600 city workers who helped rehabilitate the building after a broken water main last Sept. 5 flooded the institution's playhouse and opera house.

title: JAMES KENNETH HUNTINGTON
description: James Kenneth Huntington, a general insurance broker who was president and chairman of the New Rochelle Agency, died yesterday at New Rochelle, N. Y., Medical Center. He was 81 years old.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: TONIGHT'S GAMES

title: Lester M. Levin, 67; Admiralty Lawyer Falls to His Death
description: Lester M. Levin, a lawyer who served in the Department of Labor in the early years of the National Labor Relations Board, died Monday morning in a fall from the apartment building at 25 East End Avenue, where he lived. Detectives of the 19th Precinct listed the death as a suicide

title: High Court to Study Chicken Farm Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the producers who market more than 95 percent of the nation's broiler chickens are farmers and thus exempt from some antitrust laws.

title: A Chemist Told How Life Could Defy Physics Laws
description: Ilya Prigogine's life work, for which the 60yearold Belgian was honored yesterday with a Nobel Prize in Chemistry, has given science an explanation as to how life could have come into being on earth in apparent defiance of the classical laws of physics.

title: 2 Players Tied for Lead In Women's Senior Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 11 (UPI)Harriett Glanville of Long Beach, Calif., and Mrs. Winslow Grant of Bangor, Me., each shot a 78 today to tie for first place in the opening round of the Women's North and South senior golf tournament.

title: Connally Terms Record of Carter Poorest I've Seen in My Lifetime'
description: BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Oct. 11John B. Connally. sounding more like a Presidential candidate than ever, today denounced President Carter's first nine months in office as the poorest job of running the country I've seen in my lifetime.

title: Two Skillful Meany Victories in Congress
description: For those who wonder how, decade after turbulent decade, George Meany maintains absolute control over the levers of Power in organized labor, the dexterity he displayed in piloting two fiercely contested labor bills to topheavy victories in Congress last week should prove instructive. In winning passage of a bill making it easier for unions to organize and stiffening penalties against recalcitrant employers, the Meanyled forces had to overcome the most intense counteroffensive industry has mounted on Capitol Hill in the 30 years since it bested labor in the fight to pass the TaftHartley Act over President Harry S. Truman's veto. That law, which unions promptly dubbed slavelabor act, restricted gains they had made under Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal.

title: U.S. ACCUSES SOVIET OF BLOCKING MAILS
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 10The United States today brought up four Soviet and Czechoslovak actions that it said reflected a continuing pattern of disrespect for the pledges we have all made on human rights.

title: A Correction
description: In Prof. Saul B. Cohen's letter published Oct. 11 the word only was inadvertently omitted from the sentence The proposed canal treaty between the United States and Panama is not only in the best interests of all parties concerned but does away with a glaring hypocrisy in United States foreign policy.

title: Grocery Carts: Watch That Child
description: WASHINGTONThe Consumer Product Safety Commission has proposed that Warning labels be voluntarily put on grocery store carts to alert parents to the possible dangers of leaving children unattended in the carts.

title: World Series Schedule
description: Yankees vs. Los Angeles

title: Dollar Near World War II Low Against the Yen
description: The dollar dropped to its secondlowest level against the Japanese yen since World War II in foreign exchange trading yesterday, but fared better against most European currencies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Tory Party at Odds On the Closed Shop But Averts a Split
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 11The Conservative Party survived today the threat of a divisive split over the question of its relationship to the trade unionsthe question that brought down the last Conservative government in 1974.

title: Pop: Steve Goodman Fills Folk Air Brightly
description: STEVE GOODMAN has sustained his career in the last few years with his live performances; even when his records were not selling particularly well, he could count on a steady income from club and collegeconcert dates. His appearances Monday night at the Bottome Linethe first of which was broadcast live by WNEWFM showed that he had hardly lost his grip on an audience. The club was packed both times, and the crowds gave every indication of loving anything Mr. Goodman turned his mind to.

title: With More Than a Little Bit of Luck
description: OVER at the Juilliard School where he is a freshman, the lanky, smiling violinist is known as Jimmy, but now that he has won his first international contest, he would prefer to be known professionally by his own name: ChouLiang Lin. There probably are professions in which a Jimmy could be success, but Mr. Lin feels that a virtuoso of the violin requires something more formal.

title: The Object of Their Suspicion
description: An object of grave suspicion in Yankee Stadium last night was the left arm of Donald Edward Gullett, the Yankees $2 million pitcher. The arm is the only suspicious part of Gullett, a young man of such high repute that the law didn't even look his way this summer when 800 marijuana plants were found under cultivation on his farm near Lynn, Ky. The cops took it for granted that he wasn't the culprit, and they were right. The arm, though, has been known to betray its owner. It gave out after two innings in the first game of the American League playoff last Wednesday and Billy Martin, the Yankees' practically peerless leader, said Gullett might not pitch again this year. The fivegame playoff took so much out of Martin's pitching corps, however, that he turned to Gullett in desperation when the WorldSeries began.

title: Conference Standings
description: N.F.L. Standings

title: Train Derailment Releases Gas
description: BLOOMINGDALE, Ind., Oct. 11 (UPI) A Baltimore & Ohio freight train derailed near Bloomingdale early today, releasing volatile propane gas and fumes from denatured alcohol. Four members were hospitalized in good condition.

title: MacKinlay Kantor Is Dead at 73; Won Pulitzer for Andersonville
description: MacKinley Kantor, the prolific writer whose powerful depiction of life and brutality in a prisonerofwar camp of the Confederacy during the Civil War was portrayed in the Pulitzer Prizewinning novel Andersonville, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla. Mr. Kantor had been ill with a heart ailment for many months. He was 73 years old.

title: Seewagen Beats Fromm
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Oct. 11Butch Seewagen, the 30yearold Columbia coach, defeated Eric Fromm, his No. 1 varsity player, 62, 63, in the final of the Bancroft indoor tennis tournament last night at the Cove Racquet Club.

title: EGYPT SAID TO WEIGH REDUCING BLACKLIST
description: The Egyptian Government will try to remove several major American corporations from the Arab blacklists so far as investments in Egypt are concerned, according to the forthcoming issue of Mideast Report, a political and economic tions from the Arab blacklist so far as newsletter.

title: Court to Consider Death for Helping A Murderer Flee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether the death penalty could be imposed on a person who participates in a serious crime that results in murder but is not involved in the actual killing.

title: Nigeria, Revisited
description: There has been a dramatic improvement in relations between the United States and Nigeria, the richest and most populous nation in black Africa. Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, the chief of state, is visiting Washington this week and President Carter will pass through Lagos on his whirlwind tour next month.

title: SPENDING BY CONSUMERS TO STAY AT HIGH LEVELS
description: Consumer spending through the Christmas season will continue at high levels although there will be some slowdown in the rate of increase, the University of Michigan Survey Research Center reperted yesterday in its latest Survey of Consumer Attitudes.

title: Bank Earnings Listed for Quarter
description: For period ended Sept. 30. (N) Indi?? stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, A American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Congoleum Makes Offer
description: The Congoleum Corporation and the Curtis Noll Corporation said a Congoleum subsidiary would offer $25 a share, or a total of $59 million, for any or all Curtis shares. Congoleum announced plans for the offer Sept. 19. Congoleum makes floor coverings while Curtis markets auto supplies.

title: Friendly Frost Says Directors Will Sell Stock
description: Friendly Frost Inc., a chain of appliance stores, announced that several of its directorofficers have agreed in principle with a private investor, which it did not identify, to sell in a private transaction an aggregate of about 250,000 shares, or 25 percent of the total outstanding shares, at a price of $6 a share over three years.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in late editions of The Times Saturday reported erroneously that two former Houston police officers, Stephen Orlando and Terry W. Denson, had been fined $1 and put on probation by a jury in Huntsville, Tex., in the drowning last May of Joe Campos Torres in Houston. The jury found the former officers guilty of negligent homicide, a misdemeanor; imposed sentences of a year in jail and fires of $2,000 each, and then suspended the sentences.

title: Q&A
description: Q. As a child in the South I was accustomed to eating what were known as selfrising breads, including biscuits. Is anything like selfrising flour sold on the market today?

title: The PointyHeaded FloodPlains Law
description: Missouri's Senators and Representatives were outraged last spring at what they considered dictatorial Federal browbeating of the town of Cassville, Mo. (pop. 1,900) and other communities. They complained that Federal bureaucrats had declared half of Cassville a flood hazard area even though it had never suffered serious floods. The designation made it impossible to finance new construction unless the town fathers passed strict floodplain ordinances they were unwilling to adopt. And then, to make matters worse, there was that pointyheaded bureaucrat who allegedly called opponents of the Federal flood program rednecks. So the Missouri Congressmen attached to a major housing bill the pointyheaded bureaucrat elimination amendment. That amendment, which was adopted by Congress and now awaits President Carter's signature, will probably vitiate a valuable national program to restrict construction in floodprone areas. It is hasty, illconsidered lawmakinga case of throwing out the baby with the floodwater.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Joan Mondale Speaks Out for the Arts
description: Joan Mondale, the arts advocate in the Carter Administration, journeyed deep into the heart of Brooklyn yesterday to visit two cultural institutions and to assure a group of women artists that the White House had their best interests at heart.

title: NN Proposes Merger
description: The NN Corporation, an insurance holding company, and Continental Western Industries, which also has insurance interests, said their chairmen had agreed to recommend to directors in the next two weeks a taxfree merger. Each Continental shareholder would have a choice of receiving $20 of NN stock or onehalf a share of a new NN preferred paying a $3.60 annual dividend, for a total value of $39.2 million.

title: Venice Is Flooded and Waves Batter Riviera as Storms Continue in Italy
description: VENICE, Oct. 11 (AP)Sea water flooded St. Mark's Square today while on the west coast of Italy heavy waves battered the Riviera and storms continued to plague much of the country.

title: Chess:
description: MENTOR, OhioGrandmaster Walter Browne, held to draws by International Master Bernard Zuckerman in the eighth round and by International Master Dumitru Ghizdavu in the ninth, nevertheless retained his lead with a 63 score in the United States Championship Tournament here in the Mentor Inn.

title: Struggle for Ivy's Crown Is Dotted With Surprises
description: The race for the Ivy League football championship, at this stage of the campaign, is about as murky as the weather on recent Saturdays. Undefeated Dartmouth (40 over all and 20 in the league), occupies first place along with Harvard (22 and 20), and neither was expected to be there, according to preseason polls. More surprising are the positions of Yale and Brown, the defending cotitleholders. The Elis have a 11 wonlost mark in the league and Brown is in fifth place with a 12 record. And even more surprising than that is the position of Penn (21). The Quakers beat Brown for the second successive year last Saturday to move into third place.

title: REV. WILLIAM H. PICKFORD
description: The Rev. William Henry Pickford. rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Broadway and 71st Street, for 35 years, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived an Trinity Pass, Pound Ridge, N Y.

title: CARTER IN NEW BID FOR CANAL BACKING
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 11 (UPI)President Carter tried to persuade a group of influential senators today to support the Panama Canal treaties, but the Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., said afterward, I don't think anybody changed his position.

title: Citicorp's Center Reflects Synthesis of Architecture
description: If anyone had suggested a 914foothigh building of glistening aluminum with a sloping roof on top and a cluster of stores, a church and a plaza at the bottomto Citicorp when it built its first uptown headquarters in 1961, he would probably have been dismissed as hopelessly irrational. But that is what the city's largest bank has just built on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street.

title: Continental Airlines Expects Profit to Rise
description: Robert Six, chairman of Continental Airlines. said the carrier would report a record profit this year and may resume paying dividends next year after a sevenyear lapse.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: KILLINGS OF CHICANOS BY POLICE PROTESTED
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 11It was nearly nine years ago, after extensive hearings, that the United States Civil Rights Commission asserted that there is evidence of widespread patterns of police misconduct against MexicanAmericans in the Southwest and cited incidents of excessive police violence against MexicanAmericans.

title: Califano Declares Dispute on Abortion Is Unfair to Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., said today that it was grossly unfair to hold the vulnerable people of our nation and thousands of Federal and state employees hostage in a dispute over paying for abortions for poor women.

title: FRANK J. REED
description: Frank J. Reed, who retired a year ago as vice president of SSC&B Inc., 1 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, died Sunday in Manchester (Conn.) Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived on Crescent Beach Road, ??ine Point, Rowayton. Conn.

title: Honda Confirms It Plans To Build Plant in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct., 11 (AP)The Honda Motor Company confirmed today that it would build its first motorcycle assembly plant in the United States about 30 miles northeast of here and hopes to expand it to include automobile production.

title: 3 Festive Evenings With a Touch of Fantasy
description: If there is one thing Vita Citron never worries about, it's looking like everyone else. Which is perhaps why she wasn't just another face in the crowd at the Foundation for Research in Heart Disease benefit at Regine's Monday night. First of all, there was absolutely no one else around with face framed in a tight beaded cap, with silver metal ear flaps that could have come out of the Star Wars wardrobe. And then, as one's eyes traveled south, there wasyou must believe meone. beaded breast.

title: PRINCESS SAYS IRAN'S SHAH WILL NOT YIELD TO TERROR
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Princess Ashraf Pahlavi, the twin sister of the Shah of Iran who survived an armed attack on the French Riviera last month, said in an interview published yesterday that terrorists would, gain no concessions by killing or kidnapping any member of the royal family.

title: Article 4  No Title
Pershing and Wood, Struthers Are Sought by Donaldson, Lufkin
description: Another big Wall Street merger was proposed yesterday when Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. announced that it planned to acquire Pershing & Company and Wood, Struthers & Winthrop.

title: Rebels Kill Filipino General and Aides at Truce Site
description: MANILA, Oct. 11A general, 5 top aides and 28 other soldiers were killed by Moslem rebels on a southern Philippine island yesterday during what was supposed to be a truce meeting, the Government said today.

title: Yanks To
description: The faces were different and the names were different, but the drama and memories were the same last night when the New York Yankees beat back the Los Angeles Dodgers, 43, in 12 innings as the old rivals opened baseball's 74th World Series in Yankee Stadium.

title: DETECTIVES SEARCH HOTELTHEFT AREA
description: Detectives searched the area near the SherryNetherland Hotel yesterday in hopes of finding a delivery man or passerby who saw the departure of the four robbers who looted the hotel's safedeposit boxes Monday morning.

title: REP. MURPHY TRIED TO GET IRANIAN HELP FOR SOMOZA PROJECT
description: Activities of Representative John M. Murphy of New York in attempting to facilitate an oil deal between Iran and Nicaragua during the oil embargo of 197374 have come to light in documents made available to The New York Times.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Excnange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: N.H.L. Opens Play Tonight After a Rowdy Preseason
description: Having got off on the wrong foot with a raucous exhibition season, the National Hockey League was hoping to get down to the serious business of starting its 61st regular season tonight.

title: Commodores Attain Eminence in Soul Field
description: THE COMMODORES, who performed at Madison Square Garden on Monday and Tuesday nights, have made a slow but steady climb to their present eminence in the soul field. The last time they played in New York they were at the much smaller Beacon Theater, and even that engagement came after almost 10 years on the road.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Interest rates climbed sharply yesterday as the credit markets continued to worry about a big increase in the money supply this week.

title: Rights Unit Hints It Opposes Bakke
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The United States Commission on Civil Rights today endorsed affirmative action programs in professional schools, including the use of numerically based admissions programs.

title: Martin Luther King Sr. Reflects on Rights
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. seemed tired at times yesterday as he talked of his efforts in the civilrights movementand, at 77, fatigue was understandable. But there were moments, too, when his eyes widened to punctuate a point and his voice surged like the sea.

title: The Case for Staying in the I.L.O.
description: In less than a month, the Carter Administration must tell the International Labor Organization whether the United States will remain a member. A Cabinet committee met last August to review the issue and adjourned without a decision. It meets again this afternoon. The case for staying in the I.L.O. was strong in August. It even stronger now.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 12, 1977

title: U. S. BIDS NATO SHARE THE RESPONSIBILITY FOR NEUTRON WEAPON
description: BARI, Italy, Oct. 11The United States urged the Atlantic Alliance today to share responsibility with it for the neutron bomb and said that the controversial weapon would only be deployed if the Europeans wanted it.

title: Profiles of 4 Nobel Prize Winners
description: Ask Ilya Prigogine any question about the laws of thermodynamics and he will begin a long, excited discourse on the common principles underlying almost everything from the chemical origins of life to the invention of cities to the design of internstonal science policy. I am interested in the origins coherence, said the 60yearold Professor Prigogine, who won this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry and who is described by associates as an outgoing Renaissance man.

title: Senate and House Meet on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Senate and House leadership will meet tomorrow in an effort to reach an agreement that would allow conferences to begin over the different versions of the President's energy package passed by the two groups.

title: President of Yemen And Brother Slain, Official Radio Says
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 10 (AP)Unidentified assassins killed President Ibrahim alHamdi of Yemen and his brother, Col. Abdullah Mohammed Hamdi today, according to a radio report from Sana, the capital of Yemen. It said President Hamdi's associates in the ruling command council were continuing to govern the country.

title: Yanks Survive Gullett's Wildness and Blair's Confusion on Bunt
description: Despite the fact that Don Gullett was hyped in the first inning and Paul Blair was confused in the last, the Yankees prevailed in the first game of the World Series last night.

title: U.S. Customs Service to Reduce Number of Surveillance Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)The United States Customs Service plans to drastically reduce the number of airplanes used in looking for smugglers along the Texas border, a spokesmen said today.

title: Hong Kong Accepts 43 Vietnamese
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Hong Kong authorities today allowed 43 Vietnamese refugees to land here after they had been rescued at sea by a West German vessel, a Government spokesman said. The refugees were granted threemonth temporary visas and are now in the care of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees pending their settlement abroad, the spokesman said.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DOUBLE DIP American audiences will be introduced tonight to Penca, the art of selfdefense as practiced in Sunda, West Java, by a troupe of four male dancers and three musicians from Panglipur. Joining the martial display will be performers of Topeng Babakan, Sunda's maskeddance theater with its own ancient tradition. The Javanese artists are appearing at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall as part of a national tour sponsored by the Performing Arts Program of the Asia Society. Tickets are $4.50 to $10.

title: Technology
description: Let computers run the factory. Technology has been urging that notion on American industry for some time now, with mixed success. Industry seems impressed by breakthroughs in this area, but, by and large, really sophisticated computerbased manufacturing systems have been slow to take root in the nation's factories.

title: WARNKE VOICES CONFIDENCE ON OUTCOME OF ARMS TALKS
description: GENEVA, Oct. 11Paul C. Warnke, the United States arms negotiator, voiced confidence today in the successful conclusion of the talks with the Soviet Union on the limitation of strategic weapons and a ban on nuclear explosions.

title: Americans Going Back to Beirut, Showing Confidence in Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11The Americans are coming back to Beirut, and the return is like an injection of hope for the Lebanese capital, still half stunned from the devastating civil war.

title: A Borough Presidency Is a Prize, But Precisely Why Is Unclear
description: Both comments are true, depending on the person in the job.

title: Morris Blake, Buyer, Dies at 54; Principal of Magerfield, Chernoff
description: Morris Blake. a principal and dress buyer of Magerfield. Chernoff Associates, a New York resident buying office, died Monday night at his home in Coop City, the Bronx. He was 54 years old.

title: Reprise
description: UNCOMPROMISING ON ABORTION  The House will vote tomorrow on a proposal crafted by its members of a conference committee who were instructed three months ago to find a compromise with the Senate on Federal abortion policy. The proposal before the House, however, is no compromise.

title: Carter's Information Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The Carter Administration is now trying to work out a new communications policy for mail, radio, television, newspapers and magazines. It is an ambitious and complicated program, but the President's aides are dealing with it separately, haphazardly and politically, and without any clear philosophy of the general public interest.

title: Federal Officials Hear Executives Give Views of Urban Problems
description: Carter Administration officials came to New York yesterday to ask corporate and other executive views on a White House Irban conferenceand were told by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Careers
description: Job opportunities for research analysts with Wall Street brokerage firms and other New York basedfinancial institutions have apparently sharply decreased this year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Custom Crosties

title: Meadowlands Results
description: Time1:12 315. ScratchedNorth Star, Cary Street, Freedom Train. *Finished second but was diseaualifled and placed third.

title: Great White Way in Spotlight
description: Five symposiums on the past, present and future of New York's Great White Way will be sponsored by the Graduate School of the City University of New York and the New York Council for the Humanities, beginning Oct. 18.

title: Memorial Services
description: BellEsther Hope (Lovell) August 24Of East Chop, Martha's Vineyard and Darien, Ct. Wife of John Boyle Bell of East Chop, Martha's Vineyard. Mother of John Boyle Bell, Jr. of Greenwich, Ct, Mrs. Walter E. Robb, Ill of Sherborne, Mass. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Noroton Presbyterian. Church, Post Road, Darien, Ct. on Thursday, Oct 13 at 4 PM.

title: What Spring Holds in Store
description: Designers working on spring collections show an affinity for the following trends:

title: Best Buys
description: THIS seems to be the week for putting a chicken in every pot and a few in the freezer. Both State Department of Agriculture and Markets and the City Department of Consumer Affairs are in agreement that right now, with the World Series in progress, it's time for the shopper to have a fowl ball.

title: Advertising
description: The theme that business executives would most like to see but feel they are not seeing in corporate advertising is that the advertiser is an honest company.

title: Books: Eight Men Out Recalls Baseball's Big Strikeout of 1919
description: CURRENTLY, with free agents and multimilliondollar players' contracts, it is difficult to imagine majorleague baseball players' attempting to fix a game. It is just not financially feasible for a top player to become involved. But in Eight Men Out, an account of the infamous Black Sox scandal of 1919, Eliot Asinof clearly demonstrates why it was not always so.

title: 2 From U.S. Among 4 Nobel Science Winners
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11The 1977 Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded today to two Americans and a Briton, and the Nobel Prize in Chemistry went to a Belgian scientist.

title: Kenyans Fighting to Save Forest From Developers
description: NAIROBI, KenyaConservationists in the heart of East Africa are engaged in a lastditch battle to rescue a remnant patch of natural forestnot from marauding elephants or encroaching deserts and other hazards common to this exotic land but from a luxury housing development.

title: CITICORP HEAD DENIES DUMPING CITY NOTES
description: Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, accused the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday of distortions and omissions in its report on the New York City fiscal crisis and denied that the banks had acted in bad faith in their marketing of city securities in 197475.

title: ISRAELI CABINET BACKS U.S. WORKING PAPER FOR TALKS IN GENEVA
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 11  The Israeli Cabinet tonight unanimously approved an agreement reached by Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan and President Carter last week on procedures for a new Middle East peace conference in Geneva.

title: Cuomo Finds City Worse Off Than in '75
description: New York City is worse off today than it was when the fiscal crisis hit in 1975, Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday. Only a Mayor free of political commitments, he said, will be able to avoid the Band  Aid solutions, gimmicks and tricks that have been used thus far.

title: Article 3  No Title
U.S. to Push Trade Talks And Attempt to Aid Steel
description: Robert S. Strauss, the president's special representative for trade negotiations, said yesterday that he and Mr. Carter were determined to press forward with new multinational tariff and trade agreements, but would seek meanwhile to ease the steel industry's adjustment to import competition.

title: Tennis
description: AT MADRID

title: Recipe Adaptations From the Banquet
description: No home cook should attempt to approximate this complete dinner without at least three or four assistants to ensure everything's being done to perfection and at precisely the right time. It would, however, be perfectly possible to prepare one or two of the dishes and surround them with simpler accompaniments. With that in mind, we have adapted the key dishes from the banquet menu at La Chemaillere. The poached bass in sauce nantua is a classic preparation that can be found in any good traditional French cookbook: the same is true of the quenelles, but in making the veloute sauce, poach two dozen oysters in the fish stock before using it for the sauce. Reserve whole oysters to be added as garnish.

title: Deaths
description: AKE  Kenneth Whittier of 202 Highland Rd, Rye, NY on October 9, 1977. Beloved husband of M. Corinne Drain Ake and devoted father of Mrs. Russell (Nancy) Cecil and Kenneth W. Ake, Jr. Funeral services and interment private.

title: Yonkers Drivers
Diary of a Feast: 7 Days to Dinner Hour
description: BANKSVILLE, N.Y. ALTHOUGH THE GUESTS were expected at 7 P.M. on Sept. 27, the preparation for the dinner really began a week earlier in the kitchens of La Crmaillre, the gracious French country restaurant in this Westchester County community, about 80 minutes by car from New York City.

title: People and Business
description: Charles L. Schultze, the Administration's chief economic adviser, said yesterday that he saw no major distortions or imbalances In the economy that might precipitate a downturn or prolonged pause. But he conceded that the outlook beyond mid1978 has become more uncertain because by that time the current economic stimulus program will no longer be adding fresh impetus to the recovery.

title: Article 1  No Title
Carter Greets the Leader of Nigeria, Symbolizing a New Relationship
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 11Nigeria's leader began a state visit to the United States today, meeting with President Carter, who will visit him in Lagos next month. The exchange of state visits, is seen in Africa as a sign that the Carter Administration views Nigeria as the most important black country in Africa and as pivotal for influencing events throughout the continent.

title: Privacy: Battles With the Computer
description: WASHINGTON LAST MONTH I moved back to the United Slates after a few years abroad. When I applied for an oil company credit card, I was, much to my horror, refused. Fearing The Computer would destroy my credit rating, I quickly dashed off a letter to the company in question. I found myself telling it everything from the terms of my father's will to my children's high test scoresshowing they could eventually support us, or at least win scholarshipsin an effort to change The Computer's mind. I didn't like revealing family secrets to a machine but I was protecting myself against a potential credit disaster.

title: TV: 3 Fine Kiddie Shows
description: THE WOMEN from Action for Children's Television, one of the more sensitive and effective lobbying groups for better programming, have come a long way in a hardnosed industry. Several years ago, when first organized, they were dismissed contemptuously as those Ladies from Boston. Today, especially when ABC wins another award for its series of After School Specials, they are praised as courageous pioneers.

title: STEELWORKERS SEEK U.S. AID FOR INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The president of the United Steelworkers of America, asserting that our union has been suffering the most dramatic loss of jobs in the union's history because of importz, called today for immediate remedial action from the Carter Administration.

title: Czechoslovak Airliner Is Ordered to Germany; Hijackers Seek Asylum
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 11 (AP)A man and woman brandishing pistols hijacked a Czechoslovak airliner on a domestic flight today, surrendered a few hours later in Frankfurt and asked for political asylum.

title: Bomb Blast Responsibility Claimed
description: RAINIER, Ore., Oct. 11 (UPI)  A branch of the New World Liberation Front has claimed responsibility for a predawn bomb blast at the Trojan Nuclear Power Plant's visitor center. No one was hurt, and yesterday's blast did not affect theoperation of the plant a half mile away.

title: About Education
description: Colleges and professional schools are vigorously engaged in affirmativeaction admissions programs, and any restrictions on their freedom to use race as a criterion for acceptance could substantially reduce the participation of minority students in higher education, according to two officials of the Educational Testing Service.

title: China, for Want of a Formal Legal Code, Looks to Community to Reeducate Offenders
description: PEKINGIn the summer of 1973, a young man named Chang accompanied his girlfriend to an outoftheway place in their factory where they proceeded to make love. Some fellow workers happened upon them in the middle of their lovemaking.

title: Gold and Silver Continue Climb
description: The demand for precious metals futures, much of it from abroad, continued to buoy gold and silver prices on the Comex in New York and the smaller metals exchanges yesterday.

title: DOW DECLINES BY 7.88 TO ITS LOWEST LEVEL SINCE DECEMBER 1975
description: Fears of rising interest rates and a slackening economythe worst of all worlds for a discouraged stock marketsent the Dow Jones industrial average down nearly 8 points yesterday to its lowest level since December 1975.

title: In the Lake Country, Fine English Food
description: WINDERMERE, ENGLAND It was in the Lake District that Wordsworth found his host of golden daffodils that were tossing their heads in sprightly dance, and Ruskin came to believe that the spirit of God is around you in the air that you breathe, His glory is in the light that you see.

title: Jeweler's Body Believed Found
description: The badly charred body of a murder victim resembling Abraham Shafizadeh, a missing New York City diamond dealer, has been found in Puerto Rico, officials there said yesterday.

title: Personal Health
description: THE MILK of human kindness ... a land flowing with milk and honey ... the milk of Paradise.... Nearly all of us grew up believing that milk was a wondrous substance, the nearest thing to a perfect food, nourishment for body and soul for life. Recent evidence suggests, however, that many of us were misled. One by one, the myths of milk are being exposed, and the child who refused to drink his milk may turn out to have been the wisest of us all.

title: DiMaggio Balks at 1st Pitch After Hassle Over Tickets
description: Joe DiMaggio, one of the great stars of the past for the New York Yankees, was scheduled to throw out the first ball of the first World Series game last night, but instead he watched the New YorkLos Angeles opener on television.

title: Faure a la Philomusica
description: THE MUSIC OF FAURE is lovely, but it can be strangely frustrating. A work such as his Piano Quartet No. 2 in G minor (Op. 45), which was performed on Monday night's New York Philomusica program at Alice Tully Hall, seems to be speaking a langauge we all understand but continually find the precise meaning of the sentences escaping us. This elusiveness, of course, is what gives Faur music its hold on the imagination.

title: Trucking Concern Ordered By Court to Pay 46 Blacks $1.8 Million in a Bias Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)Judge Luther B. Eubanks of Federal District Court today ordered an Oklahoma City trucking company to pay more than $1.8 million to 46 black persons who were found to be victims of the company's policies of racial discrimination.

title: I.T.T. Unit Gets Order
description: ITT Grinnell Industrial Piping Inc., a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said it had obtained a $23 million order for piping for nuclear reactors in Taiwan from Overseas Bechtel Inc.. a unit of the Bechtel Power Corporation.

title: JohnsManville Strike In Ohio Is Ended
description: The JohnsManville Corporation announced that the 102day strike at its fiberglass plants in Defiance, Ohio, had ended with ratification of a new contract and that the strike would cut previously expected 1977 earnings by about $7.5 million, or 35 cents a share.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Citicorp's Center Reflects Synthesis of Architecture
description: If anyone had suggested a 914foothigh building of glistening aluminum with a sloping roof on top and a cluster of stores, a church and a plaza at the bottomto Citicorp when it built its first uptown headquarters in 1961, he would probably have been dismissed as hopelessly irrational. But that is what the city's largest bank has just built on Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. And if the new Citicorp Center proves anything, it is that the rules of architecture have changed enough in the mid 1970's so that even the most conservative of clients have now leered that a plain glass box does not, by itself, a good urban building make.

title: A Penthouse Where Dining Is a Science
description: For most of us, a penthouse suggests either a magazine or a plush way to live. For Doris Howes Calloway, the 54yearold chairman of the nutritional sciences department at the University of California at Berkeley, the Penthouse is a laboratory atop Agnes Fay Morgan Hall where six ablebodied men drink liquid formula four times a day for three months and long for food.

title: First Group Starts Metabolic Study
description: BERKELEY, Calif. The first of three groups of six women has checked into the Penthouse of the University of California at Berkeley's Nutritional Science Department Oct. 4 as subjects in a study of the nutritional needs of pregnant women.

title: P. & G. Predicts Gain
description: Edward Harness, chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company, told the annual meeting in Cincinnati that earnings for the 1978 first fiscal quarter, which began July 1, would exceed the yearago level. In the yearago first fiscal quarter, the company earned $1.63 a share on sales of $1.83 billion. Mr. Harness also forecast higher firstquarter sales.

title: President Seeking To Merge U.S. I. A. And Cultural Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11President Carter submitted to Congress today a plan to combine the United States Information Agency and the State Department's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs into a single Agency for International Communication to direct American information and cultural exchange programs.

title: Okla. State Hearing Put Off
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 11 (UPI)The National Collegiate Athletic Association postponed today a hearing on alleged rules infractions by Oklahoma State University because of a misunderstanding over persons qualified to attend, a spokesman for the athletic governing body said.

title: An Assist for Unripe Fruit
description: ANYONE WHO has ever stashed a bunch of greenish bananas in a brown paper bag to ripen, only to forget about them until they turned into a soggy mass will be pleased to note a special fruit ripening bowl new to the market. Called the RipenRight Fruit Bowl and developed at the University of California at Davis, the fruitshape, clearplastic container works to ripen fruit evenly and quickly at room temperature.

title: Colgate Leads Cup Voting
description: Colgate University's football team, attempting to go undefeated for the first time since 1932, continued as the weekly leader in voting for the Lambert Trophy. The trophy is awarded annually to the outstanding National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I team in the East. Colgate, which is 50 wonlost, received 69 out of possible 70 points in the balloting., Secondplace Penn State (31) has 60 points. New Hampshire (50) is the unanimous leader for the Lambert Cup, presented to the top Division II team, while Fordham (41) leads the balloting for the Lambert Bowl, symbolic of the top Eastern Division III team.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, October 11, 1977

title: Manyak and Machine in the Kitchen
description: We thought we knew everything there was to know about the friends with whom we were to share a summer house. But what we could not predictsince our families had been living in different cities for some yearswas that Donald, an old buddy of my husband's, had turned into a variety of man yak.

title: Jets. Improving Under Todd's. Readership
description: HEMPSTEAD. L. L, Oct. 11Richard Todd flew out to Chicago yesterday to see Joe Namath, who was starring on Monday Night Football.

title: Caribbean Delicacies At the Old Navy Yard
description: Each weekday at noon hundreds of hard hats pour out of the old Brooklyn Navy Yard faced with complex culinary questions. It's not merely the need to choose between a Sabrett with mustard and onions or a Sabrett with sauerkraut. Rather, the day's selection might include anything from a golden, spicy goat curry to a hearty beef stew with sweet potatoes and hot sauce. All piping hot, homemade and served up in giant portions from peddler chefs lining the sidewalks of the old Navy Yard entrance at Flushing and Clermont Avenues.

title: Dodgers in Opener, 43
description: In baseball, all the action supposedly happens on the field, but before the Dodgers played the Yankees at Yankee Stadium last night, not all the players got anywhere near the batting cage.

title: Market Place
description: Competition among brokerage houses to recruit Wall Street's top salesmen has led to offers of frontmoney premiums and other incentives by wouldbe raiders.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Boom In Little Items
description: After closing his jewelry store for the day Ernie Levy retreats to the basement of his home in Liberty, N.Y., to do what he likes best  make furniture. Very special furniture.

title: 2 New Products For Creamer/FSR
description: The hot streak for Creamer/FSR is continuing. The agency announced two new pieces of business yesterdayChef Pierre Pies Inc. and Penn's Choice. The former markets frozen fruit pies and the latter, detergents.

title: Belmont Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post Positions. Letter designates OTB listing. FIRST$9,000, CI., 3YO and UP, 6f.

title: Blanco Leads Sailing Series
description: PALAMOS, Spain, Oct. 11 (UPI)The current European Finn Class champion, Joaquin Blanco of Spain, won the first race of the Finn Gold Cup today. Mauro Pelaschiar of Italy was second in a field of 133 and Antony A. Hermann, of the United States, after taking an, early lead, finished third.

title: Preseason Basketball
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Growing Unrest in Bethlehem, Pa., Reflects Crisis in Steel Industry
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 8Bethlehem Steel is like a dinosaur, and a dinosaur is so big that sometimes he thrashes his tail around without realizing he's knocking things down.

title: Garvey Believes He Was Safe at Home, Contends Umpire Was Out of Position
description: Six innings and about two hours after jsteve Garvey had been called out at the plate midway in the Dodgers' 43 loss to the Yankees in last night's jworld Series opener, the controversy still simmered as the primary topic of conversation in the Los Angeles clubhouse.

title: For Designers, It Might as Well Be Spring
description: JOHN ANTHONY is exhilarated about two new sewing machines that will enable him to make clothes look lighter and more airborne than they ever have been before. Bill Blass is returning to ruffles, Ralston is concerned with the new romanticism and Calvin Klein thinking in terms of combining jacquards with crepe de chine.

title: A Chapter In a Very Old Story
description: SPETSAIS, GreeceTantative arrangements are now under way to start exploring the seabottom wreckage of a great naval battle which changed the strategic balance In the Mediterranean here more than seven centuries ago. The littleknown battle was between this inland sea's two great fleets, those of Genoa and Venice.

title: City Council Votes to Regulate Peddlers of General Merchandise
description: Over the ??busive shouts and protest of 100 peddlers in the gallery, the New York City Council pessed a bill yesterday to license and regulate both food and generalm??chandise vendors. The vote was 33 to 1.

title: 3 Winners Laid Basis for New Branch of Physics
description: By dispelling some of the magnetic and electrical mysteries of solid materials, the winners of the 1977 Noble Prize in Physics laid important theoretical foundations upon which an exciting new branch of solidstate physics is being built.

title: Squirrels Losing Home In White House Park
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)A shortage of peanuts is sending 100 squirrels from a park in front of the White House to a new home.

title: RCA's 3dQuarter Profits Soar 88%; Earnings Increase 50% for 9 Months
description: The RCA Corporation reported yesterday an 88 percent jump in its thirdquarter earnings and a 50 percent increase for the first nine months of the year.

title: Opera: Boris Opens the Met
description: MUSSORGSKY'S Boris Godunov, which caused quite a stir in its new staging at the Metropolitan Opera several years ago, came back Monday as the opening of the Metropolitan's 19771978 season. In some respects it was a sober choice for an opening. Boris Godunov is not one of those operas with surefire arias and wellknown tunes, and some in the audience were decidedly restive.

title: Article 2  No Title
Third Quarter's Merger Plans Rose to a Record Since 1969
description: Merger announcements in the third quarter climbed to 616, a 22 percent increase over the 506 recorded in the 1976 quarter, W. T. Grimm & Company, Chicagobased merger specialists, announced. This was the highest quarterly merger count since the second quarter of 1976 and the largest quarterly percentage increase since the fourth quarter of 1969.

title: College Football
description: WRITERS' POLL

title: About Real Estate
description: I can't tell you how deplorable it was, said H. Laurence Reinhard 3d. He proceeded, nevertheless, to describe how deplorable it was at the 17story loft building on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 14th Street when it first camp to his attention in 1970.

title: Bridge
description: One of the most satisfying experiences for a defender at the bridge table is the play that diverts a declarer from a winning plan to a losing one. A simple but elegant example of this matador technique was played at the Cavendish Club by the late John Percy, a lawyer who contributed many interesting deals to this column.

title: Stein and Wagner Trade Charges on Fathers' Roles
description: The political dealings of their fathers and trafficking with the Republican Party were once again raised as key issues in the campaign for Manhattan Borough President yesterday by Andrew J. Stein and Robert F. Wagner Jr.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)The Army estimated today that it had on hand $118.5 million less in clothing and other equipment than it thought it had.

title: Art and Architecture in Entente
description: THERE IS an admirable goal to the exhibition Art and Contemporary Architecture at the David Findlay Galleries, 984 Madison Avenue. Put simply, it is to encourage better integration of art and architecture, which far too often do battle with each other instead of acting as mutual supporters.

title: Racism Charges Stir Site of Bakke Case
description: DAVIS, Calif., Oct. 7This town and the adjoining campus assume nearmystical status for many of their residents, who speak of the place as an oasis of serenity and civility in a world of conflict and confusion. The pace here is so leisurely that some townspeople speak of snood limits for th bicycles, which reportedly outnumber humans. On some of the wide lanes of the nearly carfree campus, bikes are already banned to protect pedestrians.

title: A Cast of Millions Swarms on Screen
description: BURBANK, Calif. ON SOUNDSTAGE 2 at the Burbank Studios, there's an omnipresent buzz in the air these days. Live bees seem everywhere  in hives, in a towering screened enclosure and, much of the time, on the faces and bodies of actors and actresses. Meanwhile, Irwin Allen, who destroyed a skyscraper in The Towering Inferno, and sank a ship in The Poseidon Adventure, is trying to master the art of directing queen bees.

title: Triplet Girls Born In Bay State
description: NATICK, Mass., Oct. 12 (AP)Triplet girls, apparently identical were born yesterday at Leonard Morse Hospital here, doctors announced today. The three girls are in incubators and were reported doing well. They were born over an eightminute span to Elaine Goldberg, a resident of the Greater Natick area. She has two other children, 11 and 10 years old. The triplets have been tentatively named Samantha Lee, Jessica Lynn and Tabatha. They ranged in weight at birth from 3 pounds 13 ounces to 4 pounds 12 ounces.

title: It Was a New York Night In and Out of the Stadium
description: It was a night, like every night in New York, of small battles and small victories. It was a night of an illegally parked helicopter, of a Naval Reservist feeling a chill as he held the American flag, of a boy attempting to re

title: Bank Reports Listed for Quarter
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Exchange and (0) OvertheCounter.

title: Ariane C. Danlos Bride In Paris of Peter Dodge
description: Ariane C. Danlos and Peter Mapes Dodge, both of New York, were married yesterday in Paris. The Episcopal ceremony was performed in the American Cathedral by Canon Frederick Northup.

title: Calendar of Events for House and Home
description: The South Orange Neighbors are sponsoring a tour of nine houses, each chosen to demonstrate the diversity of the community, on Saturday, Oct. 15, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Russia and Japan Report Discovering Sakhalin Oilfield
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12 (UPI)A SovietJapanese oil drilling venture said today that it had located a significant oilfield off the Soviet island of Sakhalin. Sado Kobayashi, president of the Sakhalin Oil Company, said oil deposits there could be the largest in Asia, surpassing those of Indonesia.

title: Coffee Futures Prices Tumble Cocoa Declines 6 Cents Daily Limit
description: Reports that Brazil has abandoned attempts to prevent the export of coffee for less than $3.20 a pound sent futures tumbling in New York yesterday. The declines ranged from 1.90 cents on the near delivery to the limit of 4 cents on the deferred contracts.

title: Notes on People
description: THE woman who almost inadvertently inspired the bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., 22 years ago says she is surprised that people in her home town are trying to raise $50,000 for her. I am not having any direct financial trouble, said Rosa Parks, who has lived in Detroit for several years. The fundraising campaign was started last weekend by Luther Oliver, a Montgomery City Councilman, who said. The time is past due, that we, the people of Montgomery, help our saint, Rosa. Mrs. Parks, because her feet were tired one evening, took a seat in the whites only section of a city bus, and after being arrested challenged city and state segregation laws. Her action prompted other blacks to boycott the bus line for more than a year until separate seating laws were held unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. Mrs. Parks's husband died in August, and she cares for her invalid mother.

title: Miss Evert Sidelined
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 12 (AP)Tracy Austin. the 14yearold Californian, toppled Francoise Durr, 60, 63, in the first round of the $75,000 Thunderbird tennis tournament tonight.

title: Steel Towns Hit by Layoffs Face Hard Times
description: CAMPBELL, Ohio, Oct. 12Michael J. Katula, the mayor here, is bracing for hard times. The old Campbell Works is closing, and with it will go another 4,000 jobs and nearly onethird of the town's municipal revenues.

title: JEWELERS MURDERS PROMPT NEW INQUIRY
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 12Police officers here began a new and concentrated investigation today into the murders and disappearance of three American diamond dealers after the charred body of a man believed to be a missing New york diamond merchant was found.

title: High Tides Around New York
SecondGame Scoring
U.S. Agrees to End Lockheed Loan Limit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Government agreed today to lift its $250 million loan guarantee to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation because of the company's improved financial position.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Many of the other Yankees were dressed and departing for their chartered jet to Los Angeles last night when Catfish Hunter finally arrived at his locker. He had showered and shaved and he wore two towels, one around his midsection, another draped over the shoulders of the righthanded pitcher who once upon a time had been a standup World Series performer for the Oakland A's before he took $3.5 million to join the Yankees nearly three years ago.

title: Delightful AllBach By Tureck
description: ROSALYN TURECK made her New York debut 40 years ago in Town Hall playing a series of Bach programs. To cele brate that event the keyboard artist gave a special program in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, playingwhat else?Bach. She put on a spectacular of sorts: She played the Goldberg Variations on the harpsichord, allowed a relatively brief interval for dinner, then played the same, work on the piano.

title: J. P. Morgan Operating Profits Increased 9.7% in Third Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that operating earnings in the third quarter rose by 9.7 percent from a year earlier, to $54.98 million or $1.35 a share, from $50.11 million, or $1.24 a share.

title: BYRNE SEEKS TO PUSH PROMOTION OF BLACKS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12Ten months after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that minority quotas for state government jobs were illegal, Governor Byrne signed Civil Service Commission, in effect, to reinstitute quotas that emphasize promotions of woman and minoritygroup: people.

title: Dodger Sluggers Prove Even Yan kee Stadium Can't Fence Them In
description: The Dodger hitters, their manager says, can hit the ball out of any park, even the Grand Canyon.

title: Advertising
description: It was bound to happen. After all, George Lois isn't accustomed to working for an ad agency that doesn't have his name in the title. (Witness: Papert, Koenig, Lois and Lois, Holland, Callaway.) So what could have been predicted when he joined Creamer/FSR last March became a fact yesterdayCreamer Lois FSR. And the new logo drops FSR onto line two.

title: Around the Nation
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 12 (UPI)Hal Hansen, the state of Hawaii's star witness in the bribery trial of Mayor Frank Fasi of Honolulu, was indicted today on three counts of falsifying Federal income tax returns, an action that could have major effect on the Fasi case.

title: CARTER PLANS DRIVE FOR PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR ENERGY PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  President Carter, sensing that public assessment of his first year in office largely rides on the outcome of his energy program in Congress, has ordered an allout campaign to swing public opinion behind the Administration's efforts to rescue the program from the battering it has taken in the Senate.

title: Letters
description: Of a Time Passed

title: Interest Rates Continue to Climb As Fed Signals Higher Funds Cost
description: The upward sweep of interest rates continued yesterday as the Federal Reserve again signaled that it wanted to raise the cost of borrowed funds. The climb in rates extended from shortterm Treasury bills, which rose to their highest levels in a little more than two years, to longterm taxexempt bonds, which rose to their highest levels of 1977.

title: KODAK PROFITS ROSE BY 10% FOR QUARTER
description: Advance in the Third Period Was First Rise for 1977Sales Increased by 9%

title: New Feud For Jackson And Martin
description: Reggie Jackson, having collected only three hits in 22 postseason times at bat, was expressing doubts after last night's secondgame World Series loss to Los Angeles that he would play in the third game.

title: Esposito Sparks Rangers to a 63 Victory in Opener
description: Against the sorry competition of the Vancouver Canucks, the New York Rangers made a bright beginning for the National Hockey League season last night with a 63 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: Vietnamese Recalls Agonies of Tunnel War
description: CU CHI, VietnamAs Lieut. Col. George A, Eyster lay dying from Vietcong sniper bullets on a jungle trail, he said to me, Before I go I'd like to talk to the guy who controls those incredible men in the tunnels.

title: Personal Beauty
description: PHILIP KINGSLEY is a trichologist. A what? Most people in his native London know what the word means, but it's a speciality rather new to these shores, at least under that name. The dictionary defines trichology as the science dealing with the hair and its diseases.

title: Home Base for Tom Seaver Is a Busy ExBarn
description: See Page C8

title: Excerpts From Arguments Made in the Supreme Court in the Case of Allan Bakke
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Following are excerpts from oral arguments made today in the Supreme Court in the Allan Bakke case:

title: $680,000 Awarded Boy
description: A jury has awarded $680,000 to a boy who was born with brain damage after hospital nurses allegedly failed to give insulin to his diabetic mother. The case began 14 years ago when the boy, Stephen Slotkin, was born in Brookdale Hospital in Brooklyn. He and his mother now live in Wanamassa, N.J. The jury awarded the damages against the Citizens Casualty Company of New York and others on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: El Al Will Cut Atlantic Fares For Passengers Forgoing Meals
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 12 (Reuters)El Al, Israel's national airline, plans to introduce cutprice seats on Atlantic flights for passengers willing to forgo meals and some other extra services, the airline's director, Mordechai Ben Ari, said today.

title: Radio
description: Music.

title: Senate And House Agree to Begin Talks on Energy Program Versions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Senate and House leadership agreed today to begin conferring as early as next week on reconciling conflicting versions of President Carter's energy program passed by the two bodies

title: Muslim Sect Protests a Plan for Housing on Site of Its Harlem School
description: More than 300 members of the Allah Nation of Five Percenters filled a City Hall hearing room yesterday to protest a plan to build housing on a Harlem site where the group has operated a school since 1967.

title: A Horse Player And an Emigre Hit Long Shots
description: A selfproclaimed inveterate gambler from Queens won $1,000 a week for life yesterday in the New York State lottery, and a Pennsylvania hospital worker won the same amount in the New Jersey lottery.

title: Tucker's Bitterness and Desire to Be Traded Appears Spreading on the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ., Oct. 12Bob Tucker continued his bitter campaign to get away from the Giants today and the bitterness might be catching.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Conservatives in Manitoba Win Majority in an Election Upset
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Conservatives under Sterling Lyon ousted Premier Edward Schreyer's eightyearold New Democratic Party government with an upset victory in Manitoba elections yesterday.

title: U.S. Plans Copter Sale to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Defense Department notified Congress today of the proposed sale to Israel of $51.6 million worth of AH1S Cobra helicopter gunships armed with TOW wireguided antitank missiles. The craft are the latest model.

title: Dorothy Loeb Millstone, 70, Dies;  Retired Planned Parenthood Aide
description: Dorothy Loeb Millstone, who retired in 1972 as director of publications of the Planned Parenthood Federation of New York, died yesterday in her home on Head of Pond Road in Water Mill, L.I., after an illness of two years. She was 70 years old.

title: After Carter's South Bronx Visit, His UrbanAid Effort Is Being Watched
description: The President viewed scenes of terrible urban desolation and was appalled. There could be no more searing symbol of governmental inability to act, he said, than those rubblestrewn lots and desolate, decaying buildings, once a vital part of a community's life and now left to rot. That was not Jimmy Carter in the South Bronx last week, but Richard Nixon in Washington in 1969 after he had walked up Seventh Street, just 30 blocks from the White House, and had viewed the devastation left by the rioting that had erupted after the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. As a result of what he saw President Nixon ordered that action be taken on Seventh Street and in similiar areas around the country.

title: G.M. Recalls 330,000 Trucks.
description: DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP)  General Motors Corporation issued a recall order today for 330,000 Chevrolet and GMC 1976 and 1977 model lightduty trucks for replacement of the accelerator pedals. The automaker said that one minor accident but no injuries had been reported as a result of the faulty accele rator.

title: After the Amaryllis Blooms
description: Those who followed the rules and kept their amaryllis foliage green and growing all summer must now send it into semiretirement. Don't water it for a week or so to allow the soil to dry off gradually. Then place the pot in an outoftheway placebehind some furniture, in the basement or a warm garageand the leaves will start to yellow.

title: Byrne Acts to Get Higher State Jobs For Blacks, Women
description: TRENTON, Oct. 12Ten months after the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that minority quotas for state government jobs were illegal, Governor Byrne signed an executive order today directing the Civil Service Commission to, in effect, reinstitute quotas that emphasize promotions of women and minoritygroup people.

title: Prosecutor Rejects Police Bid to Retry Reilly for Murder
description: A Connecticut State's Attorney yesterday refused a request from the state police to reopen the murder case against Peter A. Reilly, whose conviction in the slaying of his mother four years ago had been overturned.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The board of directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority is expected to give formal approval today to the largest package of coal contracts in the T.V.A.'s history.

title: In London, It's Lyle's For Antique Pricing
description: LONDON ON NOV. 1 the annual Lyle Official Antiques Review will be published for the eighth year. Within hours of its appearance, antiques dealers all over Britain will be rushing to change price labels on their stock.

title: Woman at Cornell Underlines Rise of New Breed of Veterinary Student
description: Julia Wilson is 23 years old and on the threshold of a chosen career in veterinary medicine. The brunette is so attractive she could be mistaken for model, but she is representative of new, emerging type of career woman. Close to 300 students are enrolled at the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University and women account for an astounding 42 percent of the population.

title: Marathon's Ban on Wheelchairs Is Opposed
description: The rejection of entrants in wheelchairs for the New York City Marathon has stirred a controversy among officials and competitors affiliated with the Oct. 23 race.

title: JEWELERS' MURDERS PROMPT NEW INQUIRY
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 12Police officers here began a new and concentrated investigation today into the murders and disappearance of three American diamond dealers after the charred body of a man believed to be a missing New York diamond merchant was found.

title: Japan to Launch Satellite in Florida
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12 (Reuters)Japan's National Space Development Agency will launch its first experimental communications satellite from Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Dec. 9, it was announced here today. The satellite, will be carried aloft by a United States National Space and Aeronautics Administration Delta rocket.

title: Tito in Paris for TwoDay Visit; French Accord Him Full Honors
description: PARIS, Oct. 12 (Reuters)President Tito of Yugoslavia arrived here today for a twoday official visit during which he is expected to express concern at the continuing arms race and slow progress in EastWest detente.

title: Baseball. A Guy Could Get Hurt Out There
description: Thurman Munson takes a rather aggressive tag to the chin

title: People in Sports
description: It's nice to be back in football, John Brockington said yesterday after signing a oneyear contract with the Kansas City Chiefs. The former Ohio State allAmerican out of Brooklyn's Jefferson High School was waived by the Green Bay Packers at the end of training camp this summer and became a free agent when none of the other 27 teams claimed him. It's been a long time since I spent three straight Sundays watching football games on television. he said.

title: U.S. ADMITS IT LAGS ON ADATA TO ALLIES

description: SAIGON, VietnamYou still fly here by Air Vietnam, but from North Vietnam only. The fuelstarved airline is forced to use those economical relics of the French colonial era, DC 4's. There was no copilot on our flight, and as the aircraft droned southward the flight attendant sat next to the pilot and sang Vietnamese songs over the intercom after serving a meal of green bananas, oranges and Russian brandy in plastic cups.

title: A Rock Opera About Der Fuhrer
description: Adolf Hitler seems an unlikely candidate to figure in a musical, but two young Hamburg composers have done the unthinkable and made the Nazi leader the star of their new rock opera. Fittingly entitled Der Filhrer and designed for eventual stage production, the work has just come out in a tworecord version, produced for the Electrola Company by the composers, Walter Quintus and Lothar Siems, two rock musicians in their late 20's.

title: Hers
description: ONE OF the myths that is long overdue in the shatter department is the exaggerated joy of working at home, a fate which falls more often to women than men. To be sure, there are some gloriously redeeming values to it, like being able to take a hot bath at 11 A.M., or stretching out on the sunlayered refectory table in the living room for a secret nap. But all in all it requires an exhausting selfdiscipline that levels the lesserand greateramong us.

title: September Retail Sales Off 1.2%; Furniture and Autos Led Decline
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Commerce Department said today that the nation's retail sales in September declined by 1.2 percent Sales had gone up by a revised 1.5 percent in August and by eighttenths of a percent in July.

description: I just want to play, said, Larry Carbone, a 13yearold high school freshman at St. Francis Prep in Queens.

President Carter suggested today that as many as 100,000 American troops might he needed to protect the Panama Canal from civil unrest if the new treaties on its ownership and operation were rejected by the United States Senate.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Seventhday Adventist Church said today that it had paid $650,000 to settle a Federal Government charge that it discriminated against women teachers in Adventist schools, ending what could have been a major confrontation in churchstate relations.

title: Marijuana: A Cloud of Misinformation Amid Lighter Penalties

title: Music: Cotel's Virtuosity
description: THAT MORRIS COTEL is a composerpianist of unusual capabilities seems beyond question. For his recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, he had memorized a group of Scriabin Preludes, Schoenberg's Five Piano Pieces (Op. 23), Webern's Variations, Messiaen's Modes de valeurs et d'intensits and Xenakis's Herma to play as the first portion of the program. The second was given over to the premiere of Mr. Cotel's own Piano Sonata (1976).

title: Blackout Could Have Been Ended 4 or 5 Hours Sooner, Panel Is Told
description: Last July's blackout in New York City and Westchester County could have been shortened by four or five hours and the backbone of the system restored before 5 or 6 A.M., according to testimony yesterday to the city's special commission of inquiry. Power was out in some areas for as long as 26 hours although isolated sections started getting service within four hours after the blackout began at 9:36 P.M. on July 13.

title: Three Lawyers Arguing the Case Diverse in Style and Backgrounds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The style and backgrounds of the three lawyers who argued the case of Allan Bakke before the Supreme Court today were almost as diverse as the nation.

title: A Private Airplane Seized on L.I. With Marijuana Faces Confiscation
description: Federal officials in Brooklyn have begun legal proceedings to take possession of a twinengine Beechcraft airplane seized Sept. 15 at the Suffolk County Airport in Westhampton, L.I, with more than 500 pounds of marijuana aboard.

title: Pelleas Both Ways
description: IN THE PRACTICAL WORLD of opera production, one can hear arguments over whether Pelleas et Mlisande should be presented as a, pale and ephemeral nocturne or a violent household drama. The Metropolitan Opera, which brought Debussy's only completed opera back into the repertory on Tuesday night, has traditionally tended toward the former conception, while the New York City Opera in recent seasons has opted for vivid realism in Frank Corsaro's production. The fascination of Pe1leas is that both concepts are valid and need to be woven together ingeniously if Debussy is to be given his due.

title: Justices Hear Bakke Arguments But Give Little Hint on Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The case of University of California v. Bakke, the longsmoldering dispute over whether preferential treatment for minorities can reduce educational opportunities for whites without violating the Constitution, was finally argued before the Supreme Court today.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: Museum stores have grown in the last two decades from purveyors of postcards to fullscale establishments carrying everything from art reproductions to tableware and furniture. Now a guide has been published, The Shopper's Guide to Museum Stores (Universe; $6.95), that offers information, with photographs, on over 700 products that can be mailordered from more than 100 museum shops in the United States and Canada. This wellorganized book was compiled by Shelley Hodupp, head of merchandising services at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, who limited the guide to objects from museum collections or things made for the museum. Available in most major bookstores and in museum shops.

Angeles Rams, was in stable condition at Centinela Valley Hospital yesterday with a gastrointestinal disorder. A nursing supervisor said Kerlan's condition was not serious. Kerlan, 55 years old, also has worked as physician for the Los Angeles Lakers, the Los Angeles Kings and the San Diego Padres.

Those in the know are finding it a handsome adjunct to a Fire Island deck or Jersey shore patio, and a yearround alternative to a swimming pool. They're also discovering its virtues as a conversation pit, as a component of the spacious gardentype bathrooms coming into vogue or as aqua therapy after a stressful day.

title: Books of The Times

I found the famous trendspotter in a brown study with a green shade over his eyes and scissors and paste in hand. Hi, Mn Packard, I said. What are you viewing with alarm this year? The People Shapers, he replied. It was the peopleshapers he was worried about these days. He was surrounded on all sides by shelves piled high with magazines, books, periodicals and newspapers. All over his desk were letters from wellknown experts and leading authorities. The floor was cluttered with conflicting opinions.

title: Design Notebook
description: TRINITY CHURCH has held sway over the corner of Broadway and Wall Street for more than 130 years. Once, it was the tallest building in Manhattan; then skyscrapers made it seem to shrink. But the enormous structures that came to surround it did nothing to diminish the church's landmark qualityits Gothic spire still anchors the vista at the western end of Wall Street's canyon with remarkable and moving power.

title: Martial Law Is Imposed by Yemen

description: RIO DE JANEIRO. Oct. 12Brazil's Army Minister, considered one of the two top contenders to succeed President Ernesto Geisel in 1979, was dismissed by the President today.

title: The Attack on the Wellhead Tax
description: A seductive idea is gaining currency, one that challenges the core of President Carter's energy program and even implies that heand wehave wasted everybody's time with a case that collapses before elementary economic logic. The champions of a freemarket solution to the energy problemlike our colleagues at The Wall Street Journalhail the new idea as proof that Government had best get out of the business of managing energy. Senators who have already gutted the Carter package applaud the new pretext for inaction. There is insight in the study, by two Rand Corporation economists. It does suggest a somewhat different diagnosis of America's energy ills than that presented by Dr. Carter. But it does not confound the prescription. The case for the wellhead tax remains compelling.

title: Film: Portugal's Blocs Vie in 'Class Struggle'
description: SCENES from the Class Struggle in Portugal," the new documentary feature at the Whitney Museum of American Art, may be of more cinematic than political interest here, having been directed (with Philip Spinelli) by Robert Kramer, the young man who made two impressive fiction films ("Ice" and "The Edge") dealing with America's militant left in the late 1960's and early 70's.In Portugal, where nearly 50 years of a fascist dictatorship was over-thrown in 1974, Mr. Kramer found the sort of revolutionary struggle in progress that "Ice" and "The Edge" predict (so far, fruitlessly) for the United States. There was something extremely invigorating going in Portugal, but alsothis film seems to say without being entirely aware of itsomething that wasn't following the neat plans of the theoreticians.In Portugal, where the film is being distributed as a kind of teaching tool in factories, on farms and in neighborhoods, the title is "Will the Revolution Triumph?" The American title better describes the movie's content for those of us who aren't knowledgeable about the power blocs struggling for control in Portugal.It is a film of isolated scenesinterviews, newsreel footage, demonstrations, paradesall designed to present the case for one of the most militant of Portugal's political parties, the Proletarian Revolutionary Party, with no attempt to hide the film makers' biases. If one doesn't share the film makers' particular Marxist way of looking at the world, much of what the two narrators (one man, one woman) tell us is likely to be received with skepticism, though their analyses of Portugal's past seem sound enough."Scenes from the Class Struggle" means to inform, not to entertain. Even so, it's a handsome film to look at, a collage of footage in color, in blackand-white and in monochromes. Its tone is meant to be as high and firm as the clenched fist of the Communist salute, but the final effect of the pictures we are shown is one of chaos, confusion, of people being polarized into political positions they don't even understand.
