title: Spark of Yankees Brilliance
description: In his distinguished career with the Yankees, Sparky Lyle has sat on birthday cakes in his birthday suit. He has arisen from a coffin, his face powdered a ghostly white, in the middle of a team meeting. And he has limped on to the field on the first day of spring training with a cast on his left arm and a cast on his left leg, when there was nothing wrong with the arm or the leg.

title: Foriegn Medical School Graduates Are Found to Lag on Specialty Test
description: American and alien doctors who graduated from foreign medical schools and then trained in American hospitals fared far worse on certification tests than did doctors who graduated from American medical schools, according to results of a study being published in a medical journal today.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE FLIES TO FASTEST LANDING
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 12The space plane Enterprise dropped steeply out of a translucent desert sky this morning and executed what project engineers call the most important landing test yot for the multibilliondollar space shuttle program. For the first time, the craft was landed, exactly as it would be after a trip in space.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Oct. 13

title: Record77 Crops In Corn, Soybeans Expected by U. S .
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The 1977 corn harvest now under way is estimated at a record 6.3 billion bushels, a huge supply of animal feed grain that will help dampen consumer food prices in the coming year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: GARDENING
description: THERE IS HOPE for those who believe they have brown thumbs. It's called an amaryllis bulb. With practically no care at all, the bulb will flower in about eight weeks. And if there is an occasional flop, it's usually because someone cared too much.

title: Ship Officials to Meet on Dock Strike
description: Shipping company representatives from North Atlantic ports are scheduled to meet with Gulf Coast officials in New Orleans today for further discussions of a common approach in settling the 12day dock strike.

title: The Bakke Argument
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Allan Bakke's lawyer, Reynold H. Colvin, was halfway through his argument when Justice Byron White asked him about the objectives of the minority admissions program that he said kept his client out of the California Medical School at Davis. The university said it wanted to increase the number of black and other minority doctors, and get a more diverse student body. Did he agree, Justice White asked, that those were compelling interests for society?

title: A 2D BANK EXPLAINS POLICY ON CITY NOTES
description: The chairman of the Chemical Bank acknowledged yesterday that the bank decided in January 1975months before the extent of New York City's fiscal difficulties became widely knownto liquidate its holdings of city shortterm notes by not replacing those that were to mature in the months ahead. But he asserted that the decision had not been based on any inside knowledge of the city's finances.

title: The U.N. Today
Sussex Couple Charged
description: A Sussex County couple has been charged with recruiting teenage girls for prostitution in the couples home. Frank Barone, 57 years old, and his wife Diane, 25, were arraigned before Sussex County Judge Frederic Weber and released after posting $2,500 each and a $20,000 property bond on their house.

title: Finding a Tub
description: Hot tubs and kits are available locally from:

title: About New york
description: From across the way in Manhattan, the ballpark beckons in cream and blue, like a saucer of light next to dark ribbons of water. The confidence of outsiders is such on a World Series night that they are willing to park their cars across the river on the streets of Harlemdown West 164th Street toward the Caroline Club on Eighth Avenueand walk over the McCombs Dam Bridge to the Bronx and Yankee Stadium.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday. October 12. 1977

title: The Return of Urbank
description: The urbank is back. Urbank: the term has sailed around like a Flying Dutchman for nearly a decade, catchy shorthand for an elusive idea that has never quite come to rest, a solution waiting for a problem. When Harvard Law Professor Charles Haar first proposed an urbank, an urban development bank, in 1968, he had in mind a Federal agency to help communities, especially aging suburbs, build needed facilities. Since then, others have conceived of an urbank as a cornucopia for grants to distressed central cities; or as a place for them to borrow when the traditional municipal bond market is closed to them; or as a way to supplement that market and to dispense not just money but also discipline and technical assistance.

title: Bridge:
description: When a convention becomes popular in tournament play it is not long before its practitioners experiment with modifications. This has recently been the fate of the splinter bid, which allows a player to show a singleton or a void, a good fit with partner's suit and slam ambitions by jumping to a meaningless level.

title: The Tip & Leon Show
description: WASHINGTONWhen House Speaker Tip O'Neill was faced by a revolt of young Congressmen embarrassed by the footdragging on the Koreagate investigation, he turned to a Certified Media Sacred Cow, Texas Democrat Leon Jaworski, to put on a big show of prober's probity.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThe Carter Administration's new antitrust chief, Assistant Attomey General John H. Shenefield, has suggested that a possible way to expedite antitrust suits that drag on for years might be to segregate profits during the trial.

title: CUBA FREES C.I.A. AGENT FROM JAIL AFTER 8 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Cuba has released an admitted agent of the United States Central Intelligence Agency from prison where she had served nearly half of a 20year sentence for espionage, the State Department announced today.

title: Second Series Box Score
description: Double playLos Angeles 1. Left on baseLos Angeles 2, Yankees 4. Twobase hitSmith. Home runsCey (1), Yeager (1), Smith (1), Garvey (1).

title: HOUSE VOTES CHANGE IN STAND ON ABORTION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12In a concession intended to break a threemonth deadlock on Medicaid abortions, the House voted today to allow Medicaid financing for medical procedures, such as dilation and curettage, for some victims of rape and incest.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST PEOPLE wait until a leak develops or shingles are blown off in a storm before thinking about a new roof. But the wise homeowner will periodically check his roof so that repairs or replacements can be made before serious structural damage is done to interior ceilings, walls and other parts inside the house.

title: O lost, and by the wind grieved, ghost, come back again
description: For a couple of days and nights now, it has almost seemed like old timesthe Yankees vs, the Dodgerswith the D train an elbowrubbing parlor car for ticketholders as it coursed under the Harlem River to the Stadium stop at 161st Street. But it isn't old timeseven Joe DiMaggio has a hard time getting Yankee Stadium tickets.

title: Home Beat
description: Enthusiasts of walking china, the footed English pottery that is designed by Danka Napiorkowska and her husband, Roger Michell, will be happy to know that there are some new feet in their line this season. The Long John Silver pieces haveinstead of two feet eachone foot and one pegleg, plus a parrot on the shoulder, Since the 3yearold twoshoes collection has been the most popular group of products at Jenny B Goode, the Lexington Avenue boutique that has sold thousands of the walking china pieces, there should be a readymade audience for the arrivals.

title: Total Eclipse of Sun in Pacific Is Seen by Only a Few
description: ABOARD S.S. FAIRWIND, in the Pacific, Oct. 12At 1:48 P.M. today, (2:48 P.M. Eastern daylight time) the shadow of the moon swooped down onto the Pacific Ocean midway between Hawaii and Japan, and this year's only total eclipse of the sun began.

title: Backgammon:
description: For decades, Oswald Jacoby has been known worldwide as a master of many games. He has been in the forefront of international bridge competition since the 1930's, and he has collected numerous bridge and backgammon titles, including the World Backgammon Championship in 1973. In addition, he has written authoritative works on canasta, gin rummy and poker, as well as the first outstanding modern backgammon book. Now in his 70's, he still maintains a pace that frequently wears out younger opponents. To Jacoby, trained as an actuary, mathematical probabilities in games are second nature.

title: A Refreshing Violinist
description: ERICK FRIEDMAN presented the first of three recitals Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y devoted to various aspects of the violinsonata literature (the others, accompanied by James Dick and Ivan Davis, respectively, are scheduled for Nov. 15 and Jan. 24). Mr. Friedman is not a perfect violinist, in that his playing is not so compelling that he makes you forget all else. But his program, his playing and the playing of his Tuesday accompanist, Nadia Reisenberg, all gave enormous pleasure nonetheless.

title: Yale Cuts Aid to Aged As Employees Strike
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12 (AP)  Yale University is phasing out a food program that serves 6,000 elderly people in the New Haven area because the Yale employees who staffed it are on strike, a Yale spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Sends Arabs Mideast Talks Plan For Their Reaction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The United States sent to Arab capitals today for their consideration the working paper for convening a Geneva conference on the Middle East. The paper was formally approved by Israel's Cabinet yesterday.

title: Borg, Dibbs, And Orantes Are Victors
description: MADRID,Oct. 12 (UPI)Bjorn Borg recovered from a firstset loss against Belus Prajoux of Chile and went on to a 36, 60, 61, victory in the third round of the $100,000 Madrid Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: I Love a Clean New York Seems to Be Weak Love
description: The I Love a Clean New York campaign to put 25 men with trashbarrel carts on New York City's midtown sidewalks during lunch hours has, after a flashy opening parade two weeks ago, become invisible.

title: Palestinian Assails Plan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12The head of the military department of the Palestine Liberation organization today denoupnced the new United StatesIsraeli procedural plan for reconvening the Geneva peace conference as an expression of the Israeli view and not a neutral attitude.

title: Shipyard Workers End Strike
description: QUINCY, Mass., Oct. 12 (Reuters)Workers at the General Dynamics Shipyard here ratified today a new threeyear contract, ending an 11week strike that had slowed construction of 12 giant, liquefied natural gas tankers.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Scores Up to the Inning Available at 9991313
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and finalscores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: Balloonists Fail in Bid To Cross the Atlantic
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)Two Colorado men abandoned their attempt to be the first to fly to Europe in a balloon and made a controlled descent today into the Atlantic 50 miles southeast of the Nova Scotia coast. A spokesman said that he did not know the reason but that it wasn't an emergency.

title: 15% OPEC PRICE RISE URGED BY ALGERIAN
description: VIENNA, Oct. 12An Algerian official called today for a 15 percent increase in the price of crude oil in each of the next few years.

title: Slayer's Execution Ordered
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 12 (UPI)The Nebraska Supreme Court today ordered the execution of Erwin Charles Simants in the electric chair Jan. 21, 1978 for the murder of six members of the Henry Kellie family. The court stayed his execution last June to allow defense lawyers to petition the United States Supreme Court for a review. The petition was denied.

title: LUTHER J. POLLARD
description: Luther J. Pollard, a retired Chicago advertising executive, died Sunday at his home in Chicago after a long illness. He was 99.

title: Canadian Books Push South
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 12 That long, undefended border between Canada and the United States is about to be breachedby books. That is one of the upfront as well as behindthescenes revelations emerging from the 29th annual international book fair in Frankfurt, where 75 countries are showing their publishing wares and flags National prestige is very much factor here. Why else would Albania and Papua New Guinea, not noted for their literature, be exhibiting in Frankfurt for the first time?

title: Going Out Guide
description: LEST WE FORGET The public is invited to a free program of films and discussions titled Sacco & Vanzetti: Fifty Years. The 50th anniversary tribute to the two Italian anarchists executed in 1927 is being presented at City University's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. Tonight, at 6:30. there is a screening of the Italian film Sacco and Vanzetti (1971).

title: Bateman Sells Company
description: State Senator Raymond H. Bateman, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, has sold his publicrelations and advertising concern.

title: Lafleur Leads Canadiens to A 73 Triumph
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 12 (UPI)  Guy Lafleur, the National Hockey League scoring champion, tallied two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens opened their defense of the Stanley Cup with 73 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Eastern Airlines Blames Television For $1.6 Million Ruling by Jury
description: MIAMI, Oct. 12(AP)Eastern Airlines, contending that jurors had rendered a spectacular verdict because they wanted to see themselves on television, is trying to reverse a $1.6 million judgment against it.

title: Soviet Emigre III After Fasting
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)Victor Tsitlenok, a 24yearold Jew who emigrated from the Soviet Union and was on a hunger strike outside the Soviet Embassy here for 17 days, fell unconscious today and was taken to a hospital. Mr. Tsitlenok camped outside the embassy as a protest against the exile to Siberia of his brother, Boris.

title: News Summary
description: Cruise missiles are vital to the defense of the continent, European members of the Atlantic alliance told Defense Secretary Harold Brown at the Nuclear Planning Group meeting in Bari, Italy. They expressed concern at the Carter Administration's plans to limit the missile's range in strategicarms talks with the Soviet Union. [Page Al, Column 6.]

title: An Aging Steel Town Provided The Good Life for Many Families
description: CONSHOHOCKEN, Pa., Oct. 12 There are things here that people search for all their life, Thomas McCann said, explaining to a stranger why the town has such a special meaning to its people.

title: Giving Full Scope to Nuclear Safeguards
description: In warning against the proliferation of nuclear technology at the United Nations last week. President Carter Slipped a small but pregnant phrase into his policy; Fullscope comprehensive safeguards are necessary, he said, and thereby hangs a mildly encouraging tale.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Chief Calls for a Delay On MandatoryRetirement Changes
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, yesterday asked the United States Senate to postpone for one year any changes in the permissible mandatory retirement age.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal's tax package has been on the President's desk for a few weeks now, but Mr. Carter, though he was involved at many stages in its development, has not yet given it his blessing. And Mr. Blumenthal has stressed that, no matter how many elements in the tax package may have leaked out, no one can count on any of them until the President sets down his seal of approval. Indeed, Mr. Blumenthal came out of a fivehour meeting with Mr. Carter the other night and told newsmen, The President hasn't made up his mind on any of the issues.

title: 1,700 Steelworkers to Get Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Labor Department today certified 1,700 Pennsylvania steelworkers eligible for special Federal benefits on ground that their jobs were eliminated due to competition from increased steel imports. The decision applies to 1,500 workers at the United States Steel Corporation plant in Rankin and 200 at a United States steel plant in Homestead.

title: $92,500 Awarded for Rail Injury
description: ELIZABETH, N.J. Oct. 12 (AP)A Union County judge has awarded $92,500 in damages to a 15yearold Elizabeth youth who lost part of a leg after being struck by a train. The judge, James Coleman Jr., rendered the judgment Tuesday against the city of Elizabeth. The youth, Ernesto Torna, was awarded compensation for legal fees and medical expenses,

title: Abandoned School Burns in the Bronx
description: A fire raged through an abandoned elementary school in the Melrose area of the Bronx last night, causing no injuries but providing spectacular viewing for television fans of the game at Yankee Stadium.

title: LABOR CHIEF IS LINKED TO MORTGAGE FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)A convicted labor leader helped finance a fraudulent mortgage deal that had the effect of milking almost $2 million out of a Florida insurance company, Senate investigators charged today.

title: U.S. AND CHICAGO SIGN ACCORD FOR SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12After 12 years of maneuvering and offandon negotiations, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and the Chicago Board of Education have agreed on a citywide plan for desegregating public school faculties and providing bilingual education for children whose English is deficient.

title: Negotiator Says Canal Pacts Give U.S. Right to Protect Waterway
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP)Sol M. Linowitz, one of the United States negotiators of the Panama Canal treaties, says the accords will not eliminate the United States right to keep the waterway open and neutral.

description: BARI, Italy, Oct. 12European nations of the Atlantic alliance, declaring that cruise missiles are vital to the defense of the continent, expressed concern today to Defense Secretary Harold Brown about the Carter Administration's plans to limit the range of the weapons in strategicarms talks with the Soviet Union.

description: MILAN, Oct. 12 The big guns of the fashion world rolled in today in full force, marking Milan's coming of age as an international fashion center rivaling Paris and New York.

title: Bronx Woman and Two U.S. Men Share the Nobel Prize in Medicine
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 13Three Americans, including a woman from the Bronx, were awarded the 1977 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine today for their pioneering research in the role of hormones in the chemistry of the human body.

title: Hijackers Force West German Airliner to Mideast, Demanding Freedbm for Terrorists in Bonn's Jails
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Friday, Oct. 14 (AP)Arabicspeaking gunmen demanding the release of comrades in West German jails hijacked a jetliner with 92 people aboard yesterday, made three refueling stops in the Mediterranean area and the Middle East and then landed in neighboring Dubai, officials here reported.

Douglas Dillon, Pam and Roswell Gilpatric, Jayne and Charles Wrightsman and a lot of emissaries from the Ould Sod. Not Yankees, not Dodgers, but not exactly bush league either.

title: Jan Zrzavy, Czech Painter, 87; Survived Communist Disfavor
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 13 (AP)Jan Zrzavy, who survived official disfavor during the 1950's to become the dean of Czechoslovak painters, died after a long illness, it was reported today. He was 87 years old.

title: HighRisk Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13At some point it was clear that President Carter, with his noble yearnings, gentle manners and political ambitions, would have to decide whether to yield to his opponents or fight them on energy control, arms control and the Middle East.

title: RISE IN PHONE RATES IS GRANTED BY P. S C.
description: The New York State Public Service Commission granted a temporary $245 million rate increase to the New York Telephone Company yesterday, but rejected its request to raise a payphone call to 20 cents from the current 10 cents.

description: College Results

title: CARTER OFFERS HINTS ON SOUTH BRONX PLAN
description: Federal officials coordinating the Carter Administration's plans for the South Bronx said yesterday that Washington's efforts would be based on existing programs and would not involve new legislative efforts.

title: Tagliavini Returns To Sing for the World
description: If I sing at La Scala, I sing for Italians. If I sing at the Teatro Colon, I sing for the Argentinians, but if sing at the Metropolitan, I sing for the whole world. I have been reproached at La Scala for saying this, but I repeat it to you now.

title: ROBERT O. BALLOU
description: Robert O. Ballou, a retired editor of Viking Press in New York City, died Tuesday in the Veterans Hospital, in West Haven, Conn., after a lengthy illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 101 Milwaukee Avenue, Bethel, Conn.

title: Watts to Open 25th Season Of Queens Symphony
description: Andre Watts will be at the keyboard when the Queens Symphony Orchestra opens its 25th anniversary season with three concerts this weekend.

title: Sports Authority Approves Arena in Meadowlands
description: it is constructed, and the Authority expects to begin negotiations now on a lease for the team. Until its new home is finished, the team, which has officially changed its name to the New Jersey Nets, is playing its home games at Rutgers University's new gymnasium in Piscataway.

title: Winston H. Pickett Is Dead at 63; ExPublic Affairs Counsel at G.E.
description: Winston H. Pickett, public affairs counsel for the General Electric Company, Fairfield, Conn., died yesterday in his home, Stoneleigh, Alger Court, Bronxville, N.Y. after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Average Closes at 818.17 After 5.81 Fall, Lowest Since Oct. 7,1975
description: Worries about rising shortterm interest rates and an explosion in moneysupply growth rocked the stock market yesterday and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a twoyear low.

title: Islanders Bow To Sabres, 32, In Opener
description: Continued From Page A21 larseason and playoff competition. And they had been knocked out o fthe Stanley Cub playoffs in the quarterfinals by the Islanders the last two seasons.

title: At the Movies
description: WILL DUSTIN HOFFMAN gobble down his spinach in time to rescue Lily Tomlin from the lascivious brute who has her squriming in his sweaty grip? He will if Ro???????Evansa producer celebrated for his gumptionhas his way. Mr. Evans has been deep in negotiation for the last few weeks with the actor and the comedienne to play the gravelvoiced sailor and his stricking sweetheart Olive Oyl in a musical version of Popeye. Although a composer has yet to be selected, Mr. Evans is crossing his fingers that John Schlesinger will be finished with Yanks in time to sign aboard as director. In the meantime, Jules Feiffer, who recently raided the Paramount vaults containing the Popeye cartoons from the 30's and 40's, is now fashioning a screenplay that should be ready to sail before the camera next fall.

title: Stage: The Subject Is Strindberg
description: THOSE three fine actors Max Von Sydow, Eileen Atkins and  Bibi Andersson are not ,simply miscast'.ant dubiously, directed in The Night of the Tribades. As Per Orlov Enquist's play about August Strindberg unravels. upon the stage of the Helen Hayes 'Theater, where it opened last night, they are virtually bushwacked.

title: Market Place
description: T. Rowe Price, the acerbic money manager whose investments in growth stocks were highly successful during a halfcentury career, is retired at 80, but hardly silent or inactive.

title: Stein Assails Carey for Backing Wagner, Calling Him a Meddler
description: Andrew J. Stein assailed Governor Carey yesterday for his endorsement of Robert F. Wagner Jr. in the race for Manhattan Borough President, calling Mr. Carey a meddler who has dabbled so much in local politics that he is neglecting the major business of the state.

title: Commodity Spot Price index Rose To 205.2 From 203 Last Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 205.2 from 203 last week.

title: Lakshmi Shankar to Play Indian Songs at Cathedral
description: A program of North Indian classical vocal music will be presented by Lakshmi Shankar tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock in St. James's Chapel of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1977

title: Article 4  No Title
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to examine whether the American Telephone and Telegraph Company should be allowed to continue offering its privateline telegraph service, used mainly by newswire services, brokerage houses and alarm companies, although the service loses money.

title: Walkout Over Container Shipping Traced to Ruling by Labor Board
description: The fuse that set off the strike that closed down container shipping operations from Maine to Texas on Oct. 1 was ?lit almost two years ago by a ruling of the National Labor Relations Board on a suit brought by two small freightpacking companies, according to shipping industry sources.

title: Congress Acts on Health Care Fraud
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 UPI)Congress approved today legislation to crack down on fraud in health care for the elderly and the poor. Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, called the bill a loud warning to thieves and crooks.

title: Tories Hotly Debate Rhodesia, Assail Encouragement of Interference
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 13The Conservative Party conference roused itself from the doldrums today with a heated and uncharacteristically impolite debate on Rhodesia.

title: About Real Estate
description: Nine new settlers are on their way to Riverside Drive: a banker, a psychologist, a psychiatrist, two high school teachers, two Columbia University faculty members and a graduate student. Six are singles. Three are in twoperson families. No children.

title: Loan Fraud Is Laid To Dunes Operator
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused Morris A. Shenker, operator of the Dunes Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, of fraudulently obtaining nearly $29 million in loans for a California resort that closed last winter after losses of more than $20 million.

title: Lebanese in South Hide From Shells and Await Army
description: BINT JBAIL, Lebanon, Oct. 13The last remaining families in this town on the border with Israel crowded today into a flour mill to seek shelter from artillery and said their only hope was that the Lebanese Army would soon arrive.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions. Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Bank Earnings Reported
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchage, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Reserve Report
Columbus Ave. Hails Its Coming of Age
description: Alfresco dining and shopping, crafts booths, strolling , musicians, jugglers and mimes will all help perhaps 100,000 guests discover Sunday why Columbus Avenue has become the new prize of the Upper West Side.

title: MartinJackson Feud Heats Up on the Road
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13Billy Martin and Reggie Jackson, star performers in the Yankees version of Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, escalated their soap opera into a major war of words today.

title: Mondale to Visit New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 13 (AP)Vice President Mondale will visit New Hampshire Nov. 11 to raise money for the state's Democrats. Joanne Symons, the state Democratic Party chairman, said yesterday that Mr. Mondale would be the key speaker at a $10aperson reception in Concord at the Highway Hotel.

title: Top Swiss Court Rules Women Civil Servants Rate Same Pay as Men
description: GENEVA, Oct. 13In a decision that women's organizations are hailing as major victory, the Swiss Supreme Court has ruled that women civil servants have the right to the same pay as men for equal work.

title: Results of Series Games
Ship Groups Meet To Seek a Solution In Docks Walkout
description: Officials of Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping companies met in New Orleans yesterday in a new attempt to devise a formula for settling the 13dayold dock strike that has tied up 95 ships and sharply curtailed import and export activity.

title: Books of The Times
description: I SHOULD DECLARE an interest. For several years, under the name of Cyclops, I. moonlighted as a television columnist for Life magazine. They were the last several years of the magazine. My editor there was David E.Scherman, who has edited Life Goes to War, as, previously, he edited Best of Life and Life Goes to the Movies. In my opinion, Mr. Scherman is a prince. It would have been impossible for him to put together a bad book. With the help of Frank K. Kappier, he has in fact contrived a very good one.

title: I.B.M.,NCR and Burroughs Show Record ThirdQuarter Earnings
description: Computer industry profits rose sharply in the third quarter, with three of the four companies that reported yesterday showing record earnings.

title: Contract for Birdsboro
description: The Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation and its 91 percentowned Birdsboro Corporation unit said they had been awarded a $50 million contract to install two steel fabrication mills in Jujuy, Argentina. The contract was awarded by Direcci?n General de Fabricaciones Militares, an Argentine Governmentowned corporation. The project is to be completed over the next three years.

title: Art: Modernists Brake for Tradition
description: IN THE VISUAL ARTS today, the express train of history is slowing down, and a lot of artists want to get off and have a look at the terrain that has already been bypassed. The appetite for unknown, and perhaps unknowable, destinations is diminishing. The modernist tradition, with its heroic flights of innovation and invention, is perceived to be only one tradition among many, and artists no longer feel bound by its restrictive covenants. They draw rrom its achievements, as they draw from those of earlier traditions. whatever suits their need.

title: Monroe Rallies Knicks To Triumph Over Nets
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 13 (UPI)Earl Monroe scored 5 points in the final 1 minute 33 seconds tonight to rally the New. York Knicks to a 9693 victory over the New Jersey Nets'in preseason basketball game at the Capital Center.

title: Strategy: How Rival Managers Use the Ins and Outs
description: LOS ANGELES,Oct. 13The troops are out there between the foul lines, to succeed or fail ultimately with physical skills, no matter how much thought they apply. But the two managers, Billy Martin of the Yankees and Tommy Lasorda of the Los Angeles Dodgers, play the World Series only with their minds. Like field marshals in battle, they are confined most of the time to their headquarters inside the dugout, only rarely venturing into the arena to change a pitcher, to argue with an umpire, to check on an injured player.

title: Books: Unequal Rights Advocate
description: THE WHOLE FABRIC of the lives of American women has changed profoundly in the last decade as a result of the women's movement. Once an overwhelmingly urban and professional concern, feminism has touched women on all levels and in all corners of the country, however unconscious the level of communication. And as the pace of the movement has quickened and its ideals become clarified, the intensity of the opposition has grown.

title: Art: Dig He Must
description: EARTHWORKS came to pass during the 60's at a time when the talk was all of wresting art from the middlemen and bnnging it to the people, as it were, live. Since then, this form of Conceptualism has languished somewhat, probably because it has usually been effected in parts of the world too remote for the people to visit. But the reappearance of one of the movement's grand old men, Walter de Maria, in his first solo since Bed of. Spikes at the Dwan Gallery in 1969, proposes that dirt is still a viable medium. Indeed, Mr. de Maria has caused the Heiner Friedrich Gallery (141 Wooster Street) to be filled with it. It is the third such gesture by this artist, the others having been made in 1968 and 1974 in West Germany, and it is also, at 220,000 pounds, the heaviest.

title: Donald Slesinger, a Psychologist And ExLaw School Dean, Is Dead
description: Donald Siesinger, an analytic psychologist who once served as the dean of the University of Chicago Law School, died yesterday at the Carlsbad Hospital in California after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: VW Of America Lifts 78 Car Prices 3.2%
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP)Volkswagen of America Inc. has announced an average price increase of $145, or 3.2 percent. on its 1978 models.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, Friday, Oct. 14 (AP)Graziella Ortiz Patino, the kidnapped fiveyearold grandniece of a Bolivian tin magnate, was released for a ransom of $2 million, the Geneva police reported today. They said she was apparently in good health after 10 days in captivity.

title: Carter Choices for Energy Posts Drawing Opposition in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Carter Adm'nistration's choices for three important energy posts have run into opposition, with Congressional staff aides and energy lobbyists raising the possibility that at least one of the nominees could be rejected by the Senate.

title: Management
description: In the age of everrising fuel costs and everincreasing population density outside cities, commuting costs and commuting time have become more and more important to management thinking.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Thursday, Oct. 13, 1977

title: MIDEAST PLAN TEXT DIVULGED BY DAYAN
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 13In a surprise move, Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan divulged at a public session of Parliament today the contents of the secret working paper outlining procedures for convening a Geneva peace conference on the Middle East.

title: Full Production Approved For F16 Fighter Plane
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced that Charles Duncan, the acting Secretary of Defense, had approved the recommendation of the Defense Systems Acquisition Review Council (DSARC) to begin full production of the F16 fighter plane.

title: Italy Moves to Aid Women
description: ROME, Oct. 13 (AP)The Senate gave unanimous approval today to a bill to ban discrimination against women in jobs. Labor Minister Tina Ansehni, Italy's first woman Cabinet minister, said the legislation would not bring immediate equality for women workers but would help erase flagrant injustices.

title: MONDALE CAMPAIGNS ON STREETS FOR KOCH
description: Manhattanbound subway commuters, accustomed to having local political candidates accost them as they rush to board their morning trains, were somewhat surprised yesterday at the terminal of the IRT Flushing line in Queens when the hand thrust at them was that of Vice President Mondale.

title: 800 Flee Fire in Rahway Prison
description: RAHWAY, Oct. 13 (UPI)A fire in a cell at Rahway State Prison today caused the evacuation of 800 inmates into the recreation yard. No injuries were reported. Nine bedridden inmates in the prison hospital were among those evacuated.

title: Supersonic Plane, Supralegal Governor
description: Listen to the Governor of New York: If the Federal Government orders that plane in, they'd better have the 82d Airborne with it to keep the people from choking up the airport.... If I make a judgment that this aircraft is injurious to the health and security of the homes in this state. I don't believe the [Supreme] Court can stand against the Governor on that point.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: HORMONE RESEARCHES OPENED UP NEW FIELDS
description: The research for which Dr. Roger C.L. Guillemim and Dr. Andrew V. Schally shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine yesterday is credited with opening up a whole new realm of knowledge of the brain's control over the chemistry of the body.

title: LegalAssistance Agency Picketed By Staff as It Observes 10th Year
description: Inside the majestic, Colonialstyle auditorium of the New York County Lawyers Association, 100 prominent lawyers and advocates for the poor gathered yesterday to celebrate the 10th anniversary of Community Action for Legal Services. They discussed the history, future and philosophical underpinnings of providing free legal services to the poor.

title: Soviet Government Letting More Jews Emigrate
description: VIENNA, Oct. 13The number of Jews being allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union has significantly increased in recent weeks.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: first Peciod1, Boston. ????? (???? miller), 1:16 2, Atlanta. Piert 1 (Lysiak), 6:06 PenaltiesZahariko, Att. 9:15: ???? bench, served by Plett, 11:40. Foster, Boss, 19:51.

title: SLAIN MAN IDENTIFIED AS DIAMOND DEALER
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 13The brother of a missing New York diamond dealer today identified the charred body of a murder victim as that of his brother, Abraham Shafizadeh.

title: TRANSIT CLERK IS RAPED OUTSIDE GRAND CENTRAL
description: A 50yearold woman employee of the Transit Authority was severely beaten, raped and robbed at about 11 o'clock last night at a deserted exit of the Grand Central Terminal subway station, Transit Authority employees reported.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Etude in Csharp minor, arr. for Orchestra, Scriabin? Flute Concerto in G, Pergolesi; Overture to Russian and Ludmilla, Glinka; Fete Polonaise from Le Roi Malgre Lui, Chabrier.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Thar's Gold in Puccini Horse Opera
description: Even in the realm of Italian grand opera, few enduring works of the lyric theater are as easily ridiculed as La Fanciulla del West (The Girl of the Golden West), the 67yearold Puccini melodrama that the New York City Opera will stage Sunday night at Lincoln Center for the first time in the company's history.

title: Navy's Sea Control Is at Stake in Dispute Over Plane, Planners Contend
description: The Navy's future effectiveness in sea control, one of its primary missions, may be at stake, military planners believe, in a littlenoticed dispute within the Department of Defense over the development and acquisition of VSTOL, or VerticalShort Take Off and Landing, aircraft.

title: In Memoriam
description: MINTZBeniamin, In loving memory of a dear brother. DAISY & JACK

title: Coody Leads by One Stroke on 63
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 13 (AP) Charles Coody, returning to the Professional Golfers Association tour after a threeweek layoff, shot a sparkling sevenunderpar 63  one stroke shy of the course recordand took the first round lead today in the $150,000 Texas open.

title: QuickStriking Dolphins. Pose Problems for jets
description: A day after he broke his hand in practice, Lawrence Pillers told the Jets yesterday he was ready to return at defensive left end Sunday at Miami.

title: For Children
description: DISCOVERY ROOM, a permanent facility with a weekend program designed for six to 12 year olds, with discovery kits created by the American Museum of Natural History's Department of Education to introduce youngsters to a variety of human and scientific experiences, at the Museum, Central Park West at 79th Street. Young visitors, who must be accompanied by an adult, may stay up to 35 minutes. Discovery Room, which accommodates 25 people at a time, is open from noon to 4:30 P.M. Starting at 11 A.M., free tickets are distributed at the first floor Information desk. 8731300.

title: Letter & Reply: On Radioactive Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Series Standing, Figures
Steel Leaders, at the White House, Are Promised Relief on Imports
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 13  President Carter told a White House conference on the steel industry's troubles today that he would reject what he characterized as simplistic import curbs but added that free trade has got to be fair trade.

title: Auctions
description: FOR THE SECOND TIME in less than six months, Christie's and Sotheby Parke Bernet, the giants of the international artauction market, are competing in New York with major sales of Impressionist and modern art.

title: Bridge:
description: In many bridge deals it is possible to assess accurately the prospects of any contract. This process is easier if the contract is a highlevel one: If the contract is, say, one notrump, the projection is usually very difficult.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Glimpsing Staten Island's Gracious Past
description: There was a time, Just about a century ago, when Staten Island seemed to be well on its way to being the Newport of New York. Mansions and gracious villas dotted the shoreline, churches and boat clubs were built, and beautiful gardens created. Then came industrialization, pollution and the Hamptons, and the island's affair with the haut monde was over.

title: G .O .P . Faces Aggressive Challenge In Central Jersey Assembly Race
description: SOMERVILLE, Oct. 13The Democratic and Republican State Senate and Assembly incumbents in the 16th, 18th and 19th Legislative Districts, a central Jersey mixture of urban, suburban and rural landscapes, are likely to retain their seats in the November elections, but Timothy L. Carden, an aggressive young Democrat, may possibly drive a small wedge into solidly Republican Somerset County.

title: Jersey Sports Authority Approves A $45 Million Meadowlands Arena
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 13The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority formally approved today plans to build a 20,000seat aren, within the shadow of its lucrative yearold Meadowlands Race Track and Giants Stadium. The action opened a third major area of competition between the authority and New Yorkbased facilities for the sports and entertainment dollar.

title: Indian Heading Indian Bureau
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) With a Crow victory song in the background, two Indians escorted Forrest Gerard today before Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus to be sworn in as Assistant Secretary of Interior for Indian Affairs.

title: Watergate Burglar, Despite Low Score, Gets Job in Miami
description: MIAMI. Oct. 13Bernard Barker. the convicted Watergate burglar. has been hired here by the city As a building inspector. He was selected over two other applicants with higher Civil Service test scores and more construction experience.

title: Medieval Days Live Again In a Modern Paris Square
description: PARISIn the square around the assertively modernistic new Georges Pompidou National Center of Art and Culture on the Plateau de Beaubourg, a medieval tradition has been revived.

title: A Bronx Landlord's View on Cause of Urban Blight
description: An experienced owner and manager of Bronx apartment houses drove a visitor through the devastated South Bronx this week and said that the only hope for renewal was to focus on occupied housing in stillfunctioning neighborhoods. The landlord, Eli Cooper, said the essential first step to halt blight was to reform the rentpaying system for welfare tenants.

title: Celeste Holm Featured In John Brown's Body
description: Celeste Holm, Wesley Addy and James Pritchett will open the York Players eighth season this weekend at the Church of the Heavenly Rest,2 East 90th Street. in Stephen Vincent Benet's Pulitzer Prizewinning dramatic poem John Brown's Body.

title: RUDD PLEADS GUILTY TO A LESSER CHARGE
description: Mark Rudd, the leader of the 1968 student revolt at Columbia University who spent seven years in hiding and who surrendered last month, walked out of Criminal Court in Manhattan a free man yesterday. He was given an unconditional discharge after pleading guilty to criminal trespassingfor having unlawfully remained in a building owned by the university.

title: A Variety of Companies Release Their Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter

title: Ajemian Sisters Holding A Musical Reunion
description: Difficult though it is to remember these days, some creative women were flying high in their professions long before Erica Jong took her first plane ride or Gloria Steinem bought her first pair of aviator glasses. Marro and Anahid Ajemian, to name two, began imprinting their names on the history of modern music about 30 years ago. In 1948, they formed a pianoandviolin duo and began to play new works by their friendscomposers such as John Cage, Alan Hohvaness, Lou Harrison, Ben Weber, Henry Cowell, Wallingford Riegger, Carlos Surinach and Andrew Imbrie.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 11%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales in the latest week was an estimated $13.97 billion, up 11 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.6 billion. Department store sales were about $1.5 billion, up 15 percent. from last year's $1.3 billion.

title: Publishing: Seamy Side Of the Iron Curtain
description: FRANKFURT

title: Dow, Off 18% in 77, Hits 2Year Low
description: The Federal Reserve confirmed the worst fears of Wall Street's moneymarket analysts yesterday and reported that M1, the nation's basic money supply, increased a massive $4.9 billion in the week ended Oct. 5. The broader money supply called M2 mushroomed $6.5 billion.

title: China Ties Industrial Future to Taching Oil Plant
description: TACHING, ChinaEvery day 3,000 to 4,000 workers and managers from every part of China arrive at this great oilfield to learn from Taching techniques that Chairman Hua Kuofeng hopes will lead his country into the modern era.

title: Theater: Man and Beast In Feedlot at Circle Rep
description: PATRICK MEYERS'S Feedlot, a new play that opened the season at the Circle Repertory Company last night, has a raw muscularity and a quiet intensity. It has its unsteady moments, but it deals forcefully with some provocative subjects: heroism, cowardice, and complicity in violence; aggressive masculinity and fear of homosexuality.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Giants49ers a Tossup; Jets Are the Underdogs
description: What games will be on television Sunday? The Glant and Jet games, as usual. The Denver Broncos and the Raiders, both unbeaten, play at Oakland, and also unbeaten, takes on Washington. These games are on national television but will not be shown here because of the National Football League rule forbidding the broadcasting of an extra game when a home team is at home. The Giants meet San Francisco in New Jersey (Channel 2, 1 P.M.), and the Jets play the Dolphins in Miami Channel 4, 4 P.M.). The Giants are rated even against the 49ers, who have not won, while the Jets are decided underdogs. The Monday night game will be Cincinnat at Pittsburgh (Channel 7, 9 P.M.). Previews of all games follow. with wonlost records in parentheses.

title: PRESIDENT ATTACKS OIL INDUSTRY FOR OPPOSITION TO ENERGY PLAN; COMPANIES RESPOND WITH ANGER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Carter tried to put new life into his badly mangled energy program today by angrily accusing the American oil industry of being uninterested in solutions to the nation's energy problems and intent on staging the biggest ripoff in history.

title: Around the Nation
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 13 (AP)The Allied Chemical Corporation and the state of Virginia announced today that the corporation would pay $5.25 million to cover some of the damages resulting from contamination by the pesticide Kepone.

title: Queens Criminal Lawyer Accused Of Practicing While on Suspension
description: A criminal lawyer with a very, very active practice and a familiar figure at the Queens Courthouse in Kew Gardens was arrested yesterday and charged with practicing law while under a suspension imposed by the Queens County Bar Association nearly 10 years ago.

title: Hair Revival to Close
description: Hair, the revival of the 1960's tribal rock musical at the Biltmore The ater will close after Sunday night's performance. It was performed 79 times in previews and 15 times in its regular run.

title: Opera: An Extraordinary Boheme
description: AFTER EXPLORING some of the less conventional works in the repertory for the first two nights of its new season, the Metropolitan Opera fell back on the comfortable familiarity of Puccini's La Boheme on Wednesday night. The company was not content with a rehash of past performances. It recast some of the main roles, put in a new conductor and saw that the production was well rehearsed. The Puccini masterpiece took on a freshness that restored all its charm and poignance.

title: Charles H. Bonesteel 3d, Army General Who Lead U.N. Command in Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Gen. Charles H. Bonesteel 3d, who served as commander in chief of the United Nations Command in Korea from 1966 to 1969, died today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: Aluminum Users Notified Quietly Of Rise in Price
description: Ignoring its custom of informing the press and the Washington inflation monitors before raising prices, the aluminum industry has quietly notified its customers that prices on about a third of its products will increase by 4 percent next Monday.

title: Foreign Exchange: Hectic Business
description: The dollar was skidding, and Joseph Natoli thought he knew enough about why to bet $5 million that the slide would stop before lunchtime.

title: Car Sales Up 15.1% For Early October
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13Sales of new cars by the nation's big four car makers for the first 10day period of October were. up 15.1 percent from the level of sales for the same period a year ago, according to industry reports released here today.

title: RISE IN PHONE RATES IS GRANTED BY P. S. C.
description: The New York State Public Service Commission granted a temporary $245 million rate increase to the New York Telephone Company yesterday, but rejected its request to raise a payphone call to 20 cents from the current 10 cents.

title: Bail Is Denied ExBlack Panther In Appeal of Murder Conviction
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13 (AP)Lonnie McLucas, whose murder arrest with 13 other Black Panther workers became a cause for liberals in the late 1960's, was denied bail today in Federal District Court in Hartford. His $20,000 state bail is scheduled to be revoked tomorrow because of the recent refusal by the United States Supreme Court to hear his appeal.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates forThursday.

title: HELICOPTER ACCIDENT LAID TO LANDING GEAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)A wornout landing gear caused the fatal helicopter accident at the heliport atop the Pan An Building in midtown Manhattan last May 16, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Out of Stagflation Swamp
description: The tangled struggle in the Senate over his proposed new energy taxes has caused President Carter to delay presentation of his general tax reform proposals, which are reported to be linked to about $22 billion in tax reductionincluding $7 billion for corporations. The delay may be a good thing, since there are serious questions as to whether such a conventional economic stimulus would work any better than it has in the recent past.

title: Faulting Carter
description: The President of the United States is the national leader, and it is really no pleasure, even for the leader of a beleaguered Republican minority in the House, to criticize him for his actions in that capacity. But eight months of the Carter Administration reveal a pattern of uncertainty and ineptitude, compounded by a moral blindness and a lack of understanding of the very processes of government, that bode no good for the nation's economic health or for the state of its defenses.

title: Parents/ Children
description: The school term is several weeks old and any day now the first report cards will make their way home. Out of the code of letters or numbers or comments some parents will decipher the same message: Their children are faltering.

title: Unemployed Housepainter Is Given 20 Years to Life For Killing L.I. Girl, 10
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 13A 32yearold unemployed housepainter was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life for the murder of a 10yearold girl last March.

title: Results of Series Games
description: BatteriesSutton, Rautzhan (a), Sosa (8), Garman (9), Rhodes (12) and Yeager, Grote (9); Guilett, Lyie (9) and Munson. Winning pitcherLyle. Losing pitcher Rhoden. Home run: Yankees, Randolph.

title: The Political Equivalent of War?
description: The battle reports have been mixed since President Carter exhorted us last April to wage the moral equivalent of war on the energy crisis. On the one hand, after weakening it somewhat, the House promptly enacted Mr. Carter's energy plan. On the other hand, the public seems to have no taste for conservation; the volumeand the immense costof oil imports are going up. And what the Senate has done to the Carter plan comes close to aggravated assault. So now the President has escalated: In his news conference yesterday, he appeared to declare the political equivalent of war.

title: People and Business
description: Angelo R. Arena, who was scheduled to become president of Marshall Field & Company of Chicago Nov. 1, was named by the board of directors yesterday to the additional post of chief executive officer and will take both posts Monday.

title: La Petite Ferme
Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: CRUDE IMPORTS OFF IN WEEK 1 MILLION BARRELS A DAY
description: Imports of crude oil fell to 6.2 million barrels a day in the week ended Oct. 7, compared with 7.2 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: Wave Hill to Begin Fall Chamber Series
description: The fall chambermusic series at the Wave Hill Center for Environmental Studies in the Riverdale area of the Bronx will open tomorrow night at 7:30 with a concert by Kinuko Shirane on the koto, a Japanese stringed instrument.

title: Carey Seeks to Revive Memory of Al Smith
description: The first Irish Catholic Governor since Al Smith, Governor Carey, linked himself to the last one last night as he relivered the principal address at the annual Alfred E. Smith Memorial Dinner.

title: Dole Reports He Hears Panama Chief Is Linked To Smuggling of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON.Oct. 13Senator Robert Dole, a major opponent of President Carter's Panama Canal treaties, charged today that he had received allegations that the chief of the Panamanian Government was involved in smuggling drugs into the United States.

title: Composite Box of Two Games
description: Double playsLos Angeles 1 Left on baseLos Angeles 10, New York 16. Sacrifice FlyCey. Hit by pitchby Gullett (Baker). by Sutton (Jackson). UmpiresChylak (AL), Sudol (NL), Moody (AL), Dale (NL), Evans (AL), McSherry (NL). Attendance56.668 (1st game), 56,669, (2d game). Time3:24 (1st game), 2:27 (2d game).

title: U.S. to Sell Arms to Yugoslavia And Widen Military Cooperation
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13The United States, seeking to cement relations with Belgrade, agreed today to expand military ties with the Government of President Tito.

title: BROADWAY PRODUCER REINDICTED IN FRAUD
description: State officials charged yesterday that Adela Holzer, the Broadway theatrical had defrauded investors in foreign, nontheatrical business ventures of more than $2.3 millionalmost three times the sum cited when she was originally indicted three months ago.

title: Board of Education Sends Eyes and Ears to Washington
description: WASHINGTONHer job is to represent a large outoftown organization here, both on Capitol Hill and in the bureaucracy. She is charged with keeping watch over decisions involving hundreds of millions of dollars, money that can make the difference between success and disaster for her employer.

title: Nationwide Insurance to Drop Its Operations in New Jersey,
description: Nationwide Mutual Insurance Compahies, one of the major automobile, fire and commercial insurers in New Jersey, said yesterday that it would phase out its operations in the state because of chronic operating losses and no prospect for improvement in the foreseeable future.

title: Deaths
description: KAMERLINGElliot. Beloved husband of Lina, devoted brother of Reber Kamerling and Rose Fedel. Services today at 12:30 PM at The Riverside 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S. Again Criticizes Soviet Bloc at Belgrade Talks
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 13The United States again criticized Eastern European countries at the Belgrade conference today for violations of the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreement on European security and cooperation but again refused to cite specific incidents or nations officially.

title: Off Off Broadway
description: ELLEN STEWART'S La Mama is an international treasury of theater. There are affiliated La Mamas around the world and the New York base (at 74A East Fourth Street) frequently plays hostess to visiting foreign companies and also to local companies whose roots extend to other cultures. Currently, Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Repertory Theater is in residence for a sixweek season.

title: Rock: A Twilley Surprise
description: THE DWIGHT TWILLEY Band has been something of a mystery for the last couple years. The core of the group is Mr. Twilley, who plays guitar and keyboards, and Phil Seymour, who plays drums. Together they have put out records from their Tulsa, Okla., base, sometimes working with a guitarist named Bill Pitcock 4th, but mostly overdubbing everything themselves. The recordsa vital, fresh kind of rock built on 1950's and 60's models (especially British models)  have aroused a lot of critical attention. But the Twilley Band has been fairly denture about showing itself in person.

title: 1Month Record Purchase by Hertz
description: The Hertz Corporation announced that it is buying a record 12,000 new 1978 model cars during October, eclipsing the previous onemonth record of 10,000 cars bought last January following an auto strike. Craig R. Koch, vice president for fleet and operations, said Hertz would feature two allnew models in its 1978 rental fleet, the Ford Fairmont and Mercury Zephyr. He said they would be equipped with new sixcylinder engines for fuel economy.

title: Midwest Stores Warn Customers On Badly Processed Tomato Juice
description: HOPKINS, Minn., Oct. 13 (AP)Red Owl stores are advising customers who purchased 46ounce cans of Harvest Queen tomato juice not to drink the product because it was incorrectly processed.

title: Saturday
description: Two Bronx neighbors who share a 500acre parkthe zoo and the New. York Botanical Gardenhave joined forces for a twoday harvest celebration this weekend. Their flora and fauna festival, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Saturday, aims to entertain the entire family. At the zoo, you'll find Oktoberfest food and music, hayrides, pumpkin carvings, flying bats, a pet table and more. At the Botanical Garden, there will be nature walks, demonstrations of canning and preserving vegetables and an autumn. plant sale. Each afternoon at 2, animals and flowerbedecked pony carts will parade from the zoo to the garden. Tickets cost $1.50 for adults. 75 cents for children (available at either place, and good for admission to both). ??? car, take the Bronx River Parkway to the Fordham Road Exit or Bronx Zoo Exit; by subway, take either the Lexington Avenue IRT's No. 4 line or the IND's D train to 161st Street and continue by free transfer on the 55 bus northbound to Bedford Park Boulevard and Webster Avenue. Information: 2208700.

title: Genesco Sells 2 Units for Cash
description: Genesco Inc., which had a loss of $135.7 million in its fiscal year ended July 31, announced in Nashville the sale of two of its divisions for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Mrs. Theresa De Fina, 87, Dies; MotherinLaw of Bob Hope
description: Theresa DeFina, motherinlaw of Bob Hope, died on Wednesday at Mr. Hope's home in North Hollywood, Cal., after a long illness. She was 87 years old.

title: FUNDS AUTHORIZED FOR 2 DEPARTMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Congress authorized today a continuation of funds through Oct. 31 for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, whose payrolls and services had been imperiled by a threemonth deadlock over abortions paid through Medicaid.

title: $1 Million Is Missing From a Chicago Bank
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP)The First National Bank of Chicago said today that $1 million was missing from its vaults.

title: S.E.C. Settles Case With l.T.T., Lazard
description: WASHINGTON,Oct. 13The Securities and Exchange Commission today settled carges against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and Lazard Freres & Company stemming from the agency's sixyear investigation into I.T.T.'s acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance company.

title: GOV. GRASSO ORDERS REILLYCASE INQUIRY
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut yesterday ordered an investigation of a sharply criticized state police report that called for the reindictment of Peter A. Reilly, the youth whose conviction for the slaying of his mother four years ago was overturned.

title: Scores Up to the Inning Available at 9991313
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores wilt be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: A Few Places to Call if a Tutor Is Needed
description: There are many sources of information on tutoring and on remedial programs. Here is a sampling of them.

title: Senators Critical of President's Energy Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Senate leaders of both parties criticized President Carter's comments today on the reasons his energy program had been suffering setbacks and instead blamed the White House.

title: China's Central Bank Seeks Foreign Cash
description: PEKING, Oct, 13 (UPI)The Chinese central bank, in a surprise move, has announced its willingness to accept foreign cash deposits to help finance the country's foreign trade.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSSamuel J. Beloved husband of Leona. Adored brother of Jean Dennis, Isidore. Services at BoulevardPark West 115 West 79th St. Sunday, Oct. 16th,1 PM

title: Red Smith
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13Two thousand eight hundred twentyfive highway miles from where it started in the South Bronx, the big rounders tournament proceeds tomorrow in this earthly paradise. Having split two decisions in New York, the Yankees and Dodgers will play the next three matches for the championship of North America in an abandoned goat pasture called Chavez Ravine. Then, if necessary, baseball's annual road show will return to the $100 million playground that New York's taxpayers built fOr George Steinbrenner of Cleveland. All the Dodgers, probably, and at least one member of the Yankee cast, would prefer not to return. Indeed, Graig Nettles, one of the best players on the best team money could buy, would welcome an opportunity to spend the rest of his baseball days in Southern California, preferably with the San Diego Padres, whose base is closest to his home in El Toro.

title: Letters
description: To WEEKEND:

title: Spain's Future: Storm Signals
description: MADRID, Oct. 13Four months after Spain proudly held its first free elections since 1936, the nation has begun to sink into a mood of. despondency and uncertainty.

title: President of Yemen And Brother Buried; Army Plot Is Hinted
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 13The assassinated President of Yemen and his slain brother were buried in the Yemeni capital today as large crowds of mourners called for vengeance.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1977

title: Anaconda Mine Cutback
description: The Anaconda Company said operations at its Yearington, Nev., copper mine would be curtailed 40 percent, effective Dec. 31. The company said that monthly copper production would be reduced from 5 million pounds to 2.7 million pounds in 1978 and thatthere would be a reduction of 125 hourly and 25 salaried employees at. the openpit mine. Anaconda said the curtailment was being made because of the severely depressed conditions in the copper industry.

title: From Their Isle to Our Isle, A Treasury of Irish Art
description: TREASURES OF EARLY IRISH ART at the Metropolitan Museum is ideally compact: 69 items in all. Everything in it is of the highest quality. An ingenious design has insured that even the smallest of the many small objects in the show can be seen in closeup. The catalogue (given away at $7.95) is one of the most sumptuous things of its kind, thanks to Lee Boltin's photography and some very succulent colorprinting by Arnaldo Mondadori in Verona, Italy. No one tries to tell us what to think. Export exhibitions of national treasures can end up looking like an ethnic thrift shop, but in this case we walk out bemused, bedazzled, hungry for more and duly grateful to the SCM Corporation, which picked up the tab.

title: SOME APPREHENSIVE
description: The oil industry, the target of the sharpest Presidential attack on business since President Kennedy assailed steelmakers in 1962 reacted yesterday to President Carter's sweeping denunciation with anger and touches of apprehension.

title: Brock to Apologize To New York G .O .P . On Antilabor Letter
description: Bill Brock, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is expected to send letters of apology today to the New York State and Nassau County Republican chairmen for an antilabor letter distributed on Sept. 9 by the national committee's finance chairman. Ted Welch.

title: Ballet: New Season, New Romeo at Joffrey
description: IT IS NEARLY a year since the Joffrey Ballet was last in its home town, for its customary spring season was canceled because of the company's financial difficulties. Last night at the City Center 55th Street Theater it opened its new fiveweek season, a season that, incidentally, celebrates the 21st anniversary of the Joffrey Ballet.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  President Carter tried to put new life into his badly mangled energy program today by angrily accusing the American oil industry of being uninterested in solutions to the nations energy problems and in on staging the biggest ripoff in history.

description: BOSTONFive years ago, one of the more unlikely newspapers in this country came into being. The Boston RecordAmerican, a splashy Hearst tabloid, merged with the moribund Boston HeraldTraveler, the old Yankee Brahmin paper, and became The Boston Herald American.

description: If you like your football on the ground, take a look at Westfield of New Jersey or Boys and Girls in Brooklyn. These two teams are finding success by running the ball, but the dullness that often accompanies a ground attack is missing.

description: YORBA LINDA, Calif., Oct. 13 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon's birthplace may be purchased by a nonprofit group that wants to open the home to tourists as a historical sight, The Nixon Birthplace Foundation announced yesterday that it planned to offer the Yorba Linda School District $125,000 for the former President's first home.

title: Profiles of Two Who Won Nobel Prizes for Medicine
description: Roger Charles Louis Guillemin has fought with the Resistance in France in World War II and has discovered some notebooks of the French scientist Claude Bernard in a Paris attic in the 1960's. Yesterday he was awarded a Nobel Prize in Medicine for major contributions to knowledge of the brain's chemical control over the body.

title: Quarter Operating Net Up 16.2% For Chemical New York Corp.
description: The Chemical New York Corporation said yesterday that its thirdquarter operating earnings rose 16.2 percent from a year earlier due in large part to continued growth in overseas lending, increased holdings of United States Government securities, a lower provision for possible loan losses and continuing cost control programs.

title: Robert Hacha, an ActorDirector; Made Mark as Shakespearean
description: Robert Hacha, actor and director, died at his home in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., on Oct. 9. He was 54 years old.

title: Music: Mozart Grounded
description: AMONG THE MANY music series being offered by the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. this season is one called the Intimate Mozart Series, which comprises two fall concerts of Mozart's Viola Quintets played by the Fine Arts Quartet, with Walter Trampler as guest violist, and two spring concerts by the Salsburg Mozarteum Quartet.

title: H.U.D. Plans 20th Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The Department of Housing and Urban Development, which has been reorganized 19 times since 1969, was ordered reorganized again today.

title: Film: New Thinking In Mao's China
description: THERE IS a heated confrontation near the end of "Breaking With Old Ideas," a 1975 feature made in China and now at the Film Forum, that is as familiar in tone as it is foreign in substance. One night, the students at a rural branch of the Communist Labor College are worrying about the next day's big exam when they receive word that insects are devouring the rice crop. Should they keep on studying, like good little crypto-bourgeois bookworms, or should they take practical action?One student leader, a pretty young woman who never seems to stop frowning, makes an impassioned plea for the latter option. In this situation, she insists, fumigation would be in accordance with the teachings of Chairman Mao. With that, the group is won over, and the sequence ends happliy: Everyone marches out to the fields and commences spraying."Breaking With Old Ideas," reported to be the first Chinese feature released here commercially, is fascinating in its often-successful efforts to combine didacticism with entertainment. In order to explain the Party's attitude toward educationan attitude that has been substantially altered since this film was made, by the waythe film tells the story of Principal Lung, who in 1958 is appointed head of an agricultural college in a mountainous region. Lung believes in Mao's notion that education should be freely available to everyone, and that it is important for students to acquire both practical and political knowledge, "to become both Red and expert."But some of the older, stuffier faculty members resist the changes Lung institutes, upholding their older, stuffier ideas about entrance exams and course requirements. They teach Lung's all-peasant student body about the functions of a horse's tail instead of how to cure a sick water-buffalo. They don't entirely renounce the elitism of Confucius. They aren't even smart enough to schedule their lessons on seedlings for crop-planting time.One of the more amusing things about the film is the way it treats its villains. These reactionary teachers scheme and connive like the wickedest of fiends, but a film about the joys of enlightenment can't advocate revenge without seeming small-minded. So at the finale these soreheads publicly confess to the error of their ways, and the students forgive them. Then Mao sends a letter telling the students they were right all along, and everyone cheers euphorically.Shot in fading color and translated rather strangely at times ("'How did you get here so quickly?' 'I came at great-leap-forward speed'"), "Breaking With Old Ideas" is a lot more warm and animated than it may sound. The characters are sketched broadly, without much human detail, and en masse they tend to shout things in unison, like the students at Billy Jack's Freedom" School. But their ferver is so palpable, and their earnestness so affecting, that there is almost as much liveliness and drama here as there is propaganda.

title: Bhutto Litigation to Be Long
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Oct. 13 (Reuters)Court cases against former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto are expected to last at least five months, Pakistan's martiallaw administrator, Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq said today. General Zia gave his assessment after meeting leaders of the antiBhutto Pakistan National Alliance to plan the country's political future following his postponement of next Tuesday's elections.

description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has said that one of the S.E.C.'s main accusations against the banksthat they sought to reduce their holdings of New York City securities in 197475was a staff interpretation based on facts that might lead others to a different conclusion.

title: Aides Say Carter Plan for Bronx Will Focus on Existing Programs
description: Federal officials coordinating the Carter Administration's plans for the South Bronx said yesterday that Washington's efforts would be based on, existing programs and would not involve new legislative efforts.

description: TOKYO, Oct. 13 (UPI)The Hankyu Braves beat the Lotte Orions, 42, in the fourth game of the Pacific League playoff today and evened the threeoffivegame series at two games apiece. The Braves, defending league and Japanese champions, took a 32 lead in the eighth inning on Hideji Kato's homer off the Orions ??? hurler, Choji Murata.

description: Neighborhood polling places will be open throughout New York State tomorrow for the last day of registration for voting in the general election next month. Those who are not permanently registered, who have moved or who have not voted in the 1975 or 1976 general elections must register to be eligible to vote.

title: Singapore Concorde Flights
description: LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP)Brittsh Airways and Singapore Airlines are close to agreement on a joint Concorde service that could start by the end of the year and would cut by half the present 17hour flying time between London and Singapore, it was disclosed here today.

title: Advertising
description: Keeping track of social change and predicting its effect on the marketplace is Florence Skelly's bag. And, she said yesterday, sniffing out social changes and profiting from them is one mark of the successful company.

description: The ColgatePalmolive Company, a worldwide producer of household, and personalcare products as well as golf and tennis equipment, yesterday reported a 6 percent earnings gain for the three months ended Sept. 30 on a 9.7 percent sales increase.

I'm going to buy me a case of Windex and get the concession to polish the mirrors on that big solar son of a gun.

Carloadings in the same period totaled 468,431 cars, off 0.6 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5.4 percent from a year ago.

title: No Time to Hunt in Space
description: I find that somewhat troublesome, Defense Secretary Brown remarked the other day wean he reported that the Soviet Union has developed a hunterkiller satellite. Well he might. The new Soviet space device threatens the system of surveillance satellites on which both Moscow and Washington rely for assurance against military surprises from each other. There is no evidence that the Soviets have enough killer satellites to interfere with American surveillance; and defensive measuressuch as irregular orbitscould be adopted. But the Soviet step is disturbing. Under the SALT agreements, the two countries pledge not to interfere with the national technical means of verification of the other party. Now the Soviets have developed a way to do exactly that. It is hardly a way to bring the arms race under control; more likely it will send American hawks into orbit.

title: Energy Rebuff: Who's at Fault?;
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Behind President Carter's tartly worded,attack on the oil industry today is a recognition within the White House that he have to make major compromises on parts of his energy program if he is to succeed in persuading Congress to pass a broad energy package this year.

title: World Series Schedule
Notes on People
description: The House of Representatives, following the Senate's lead, passed yesterday and sent to President Carter a bill naming a new building belonging to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. After the Senate vote, it took Mr. Humphrey, noted for his loquacity, 345 words to tell his colleagues that he had been left speechless by their gesture. He warned his fellow senators not to think his acceptance of the honor meant he was ready to assume the role of elder statesman, and he let Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, know that just because the building would be named for him, it would not mean that he'll be free from my finger tapping his shoulder on matters that I believe could be handled better or more quickly by his department.

title: 6 Groups Fight Quebec Separatists
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 13Six major citizens groups that are trying to preserve Canadian unity announced today that they would coordinate their activities to help defeat the Quebec government's efforts to achieve a popular mandate for independence.

title: Friday
description: Winter clothes are coming out of storage, but suddenly it's springtime in Bryant Park, where the ninth annual free flower show opens this morning for nine days of midtown decoration. You'll find two yellow and white tents in the park, behind the library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Streeta big tent housing displays of plants, flowers, bonsais and herbs sponsored by the Audubon Society, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the New York Horticultural Society and other groups; and a smaller tent set up for a series of four daily lectures and demonstrations from 11 A.M. to 2:45 P.M. (today's schedule takes up house plants, chrysanthemums and shrub pruning). The show closes at 2:30 P.M. next Thursday and reopens at 5 o'clock that afternoon for a sale of everything. Information: 75701915.

The charming, simple and original French restaurant, La Petite Ferme, an entrenched if minuscule Village landmark for the last seven years, moved uptown about six weeks ago to Lexington Avenue between 70th and 71st Streets, to slightly larger, if no less crowded, and noisy quarters.

title: Fire Kills I, Injures 3 During Construction Work On Bronx Water Tunnel
