title: Musicians Picket Hartford Symphony Society
description: The first strike in the history of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra went into its third day yesterday with musicians picketing the offices of the Symphony Society of Greater Hartford, its owner. A Frenchhorn player, Michael Thompson, in concert dress of white tie, ruffled shirt and tails, meanwhile, asked passersby to sign a petition protesting reductions in the number of concerts by the orchestra this year.

title: Hanoi Is Running Into Problems in Bringing the South Under Control
description: SAIGON, VietmanThere are still an estimated 150,000 former South Vietnamese officers in the socalled reeducation camps, many living in conditions that are primitive and may be brutal, but the policy toward the south appears to remain one of reconciliation.

title: MCA Files Countersuit Against CocaCola Unit
description: MCA Inc., the big entertainment company, which has been sued by the CocaCola Company of Los Angeles after MCA made a $140 million takeover bid, filed a countersuit against the West Coast bottler.

title: Dollar Slides in Nervous Trading
description: MONTREAL, Oct 13 (Reuters)The Canadian dollar today dipped to 90.89 United States cents a one point, its lowest value against the American currency since the start of World War II, but later recovered to close at 91.17 cents.

description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13For all the talk about the best team money can buy, the New York Yankees, like all teams before and after them in major league baseball, can go exactly as far as their pitching takes them.

description: HOT GROG, postponed opening from Oct. 10, written by Jim Wann and Bland Simpson. Directed by Edward Berkeley. Presented by The Phoenix Theater. At the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street, at 6:45.

title: Torn by Apartheid
description: MONTCLAIR. N. J.During my last months in South Africa, I felt that men there were beginning to lose control Of the social order. Unreason engulfed complex problems of blacks and whites, leading the country toward great violence.

title: Sunday
description: The Rockland Arts Council has invited about 100 artists and craftspeople to show and sell their work at its big annual event, Rockland Arts Day, scheduled for Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. The aim of the day, says the council, is not to register sales, but to provide a showcase for new artists. Besides the arts and craftswhich the council says represent every imaginable medium  there will be amusements for the whole family: performances by woodwind and brass quintets, poetry readings, magic shows, kite flying and international foods. There will also be demonstrations of sculpture, painting and mosaic making. On the campus of St. Thomas Aquinas College in Sparkill, N.Y. By car from New York City, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway to Exit 5, then Route 303 north; turn right at the first light and follow Route 340 to the college. Admission is $1 (halfprice for students and the elderly). Information: (914) 3525777.

description: TRENTON,. Oct. 13Paul H. Arbesman of the Slate Department of Environmental Protection said today that a consent judgment signed this week by officials of the Stauffer Chemical Company of Falls Township, Pa., was the ultimate weapon in stopping interstate air pollution.

title: Hijacking of Jet With 91 to Dubai Linked With German Kidnapping
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Saturday, Oct. 15  The hijackers of a West German airliner with 91 people on board were promised fuel for the aircraft today in exchanges for some of their hostages, including some believed to be ill.

title: First Chicago's Earnings Up
description: The First Chicago Corporation, which owns the First National Bank of Chicago, reported yesterday that operating income in the third quarter rose 10.4 percent to $27.55 million, or 70 cents a share, from $24.96 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Hectic Week for the Dollar: Uncertainties Drive It Down
description: One of the most hectic weeks in foreign exchange trading in some years came to an end yesterday with the dollar at lows or nearlows against almost all the world's major currencies. The movement of funds was unusually heavy.

title: Seagram Discloses Payments
description: Questionable payments and political contributions approaching $1 million were disclosed here yesterday by the Seagram Company after an eightmonth investigation still under way.

title: New Lawyers Named for Harrises In Patricia Hearst Kidnapping Case
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP)William and Emily Harris, Imprisoned for a sports store shootout accompanied by Patricia Hearst, are to be arraigned next month on charges of kidnapping her three and a half years ago.

title: Unsettling the West Bank
description: Whatever the Israelis are doing about new settlements in the West Bankand who can be sure any longer?it carries the risk of diplomatic mischief, or worse. The Government of Prime Minister Begin seems determined to assert sovereignty over the strategic territory, wrested from Jordanian control in 1967, and, at the least, to deny sovereignty to any other nation in the forthcoming Middle East negotiations. But no peace agreement will be possible without substantial Israeli concessions on the West Bank, whose future must therefore be the subject of goodfaith bargaining.

title: Ehrlichman May Go Free in Two Weeks As Sentence Is Cut
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 14 (UPI)John D. Ehrlichman today was granted a reduction in his sentence for the plumbers breakin and may leave Federal prison in two weeks.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Federal grand jury in Newark has indicted 10 men on fraud charges stemming from a twoyear undercover investigation of organized crime on the New Jersey waterfront and in the trucking industry. The defendants were among 29 suspects arrested by state and Federal authorities last month.

title: Arbitration for N.B.A. Rosters
description: The National Basketball Association and its players association agreed yesterday to submit the question of 11 or 12man rosters this season to binding arbitration. Peter Seitz, basketball's impartial arbitrator, will make the decision. A hearing has tentatively been set for next week. However, until Seitz has ruled, the rosters will remain at 12 players, which virtually every team adhered to last season.

description: BONN, Saturday, Oct. 15The West German Government; saying it was taking very seriously the death threats of the hijackers of a Lufthansa plane, sent a minister of state last night to Dubai to negotiate with them.

title: Swedish Bank Stock Tied to Price Index
description: A large Swedish bank announced here yesterday that it raised the equivalent of $18 million of equity capital by selling a new kind of stockcalled index sharesthat will pay dividends linked directly to the country's consumer price index.

description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14A group of the nation's top business leaders strongly criticized the economic policies of the Carter Administration here last night and urged enactment of a permanent tax cut of as much as $23 billion by next July 1 to insure the economy's continued growth and to create more jobs.

title: Yankee Egos and Tommy John
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14  When the World Series resumed tonight, the Yankees were in midseason form, meaning their egos were producing obnoxious fumes again. Billy Martin and Reggie Jackson were snarling at each other. Thurman Munson was hoping to be traded and protesting his ticket locations at Dodger Stadium this weekend. To the Yankees, those are serious problems. But that's only because they've never had serious problems. Out on the mound as the Dodger starter in tonight's third game, Tommy

title: Carter Sets a Day of Prayer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI)President Carter today proclaimed Dec. 15 National Day of Prayer and asked all Americans to join him that day in asking God's help that we may see and understand our responsibilities.

title: Cairo Paper Says Yemeni Killers Dressed as Women to Elude Guard
description: CAIRO, Oct. 14 (AP)An Egyptian newspaper said today the assassins of the Yemeni chief of state, Lieut. Col. Ibrahim alHamdi, were three men who disguised themselves as women to elude security guards; Yemeni tradition forbids stopping women on the street for identity checks.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Title  Fight Postponed
description: MILAN, Italy, Oct. 14 (AP)Next Wednesday's World Boxing Council lightheavyweight championship fight between the Argentine titleholder, Miguel Angel Cuello, and a Yugoslav challenger, Mate Parlov, was postponed today. Cuello has a sprained thigh that has been healing slowly. The injury was cited as reason for the postponement.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Six Flags Corporation plans to purchase Great Adventure, the 1,500acre amusement park and wildanimal habitat in Jackson N.J., for approximately $37 million.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1977

title: A Body Is Exhumed in Gem Case To Make a Dental Identification
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 14The charred body of a murder victim resembling a missing New York gem salesman was exhumed today in an effort to make a definitive identification.

title: Deaths
description: AUGSPACHPaul H., The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Eastern States Bankcard Association, Lake Success, N.Y. extend their sincerest condolences to the family, of Paul H. Augspach of Westbury, N.Y. Mr. Augspach, a vice president, Passed away on October 12. He will be gravely missed by all who knew him.

title: Queen Begins a Visit to Canada
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 14Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, arrived in Ottawa today on a sixday Silver Jubilee visit that is expected to be used by the Ottawa Government to bolster national unity, now severely strained by the secessionist movement in Ouebec.

title: Pasatieri's Washington Square Opera States Its Case
description: Although Thomas Pasatieri is prolific composer of operas whose works have been seen widely around the country and even on television, he has not, until now, had one of has fulllength operas produced in New York.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$6,000, el., 3Y0 and up, 6f.

title: Sir Edmund Hillary Is Taken III; Rescue in Himalayas Postponed
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 14 (AP)Bad weather forced an Indian Air Force helicopter to turn back today before it could rescue Sir Edmund Hillary,who is suffering from an undisclosed illness at his camp in the Himalayan Mountains, the New Zealand High Commission reported here.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONGordon Gould, a physicist, was granted an important laser patent this week, for which he first applied IS years ago. It covers optically pumped laser amplifiersincluding the ruby laserwhich are widely used in this country and abroad.

title: First Class Treats Reacts to A Doll's House
description: Christopher Hampton, the talented young British playwright, has indicated that his play Treats, at the Hudson Guild Theater, was written as a reaction to A Doll's House. His heroine, unlike Nora, does not get away from her impossible domestic situation. She is trapped, and her entrapment becomes a call to arms to victimized  and selfvictimizing  women. Treats could be considered feminist play written from the male point of view. It is comic, but it has a certain underlying sadness.

title: Bertil Ohlin
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14To the average Swede, Bertil Ohlin is far better known for his dashing good looks and for his 23year stewardship of the Liberal Party than as a formulator of heady economic theory. A child prodigy who flamboyantly entered the national economic scene at the age of 21 and, by 30, was engaging Maynard Keynes in international debate over Germany's World War I reparations, Pro fessor Ohlin, pornounced ooLEEN, published what is perhaps his major work, Interregional and International Trade in 1933, and had made most of his major economic contributions before taking over the helm of the Liberal Party in 1944. It was a role he held until 1967, a span of time in which he brought the party to its peak of popularity. By the time he handed over the reins, the party ranks had once again diminished, but he was never the man to succumb to the disappointment of never having reached the political pinnacle.

title: Mars Camera Observes 3 Eclipses of Sun
description: ABOARD U.S.S. FAIRWIND, in the Pacific, Oct. 14At least three eclipses of the sun have been observed on Mars by the camera of the Viking 1 Lander on the Plain of Chryse. The eclipses occurred as Phobos, the small inner moon of Mars, passed between the Lander and the sun.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS NEW ENERGY TAX BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Senate Finance Committee, which earlier rejected President Carter's major energy tax proposals, approved a revised program today that would save substantial amounts of oil but would cost the Treasury $32 billion over the next eight years.

title: Martin's Purchased By Seedman Group
description: Martin's, one of the last remaining frmily owned women's apparel specialty stores in New York, was purchased yesterday for an undisclosed amount of cash by the Seedman Merchandising Group, which.operates the Times Square department stores.

title: Paul Takes Turmoil Of Yankees in Stride
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14Gabe Pe??, executive producer of the Yankees smash hit soap opera, spoke out today in support of controversy and Manager Billy Martin, but stopped short of saying that the Yankees would bring Martin back for another year as a costar in the continuing saga.

title: SHIP COMPANIES END TALKS IN DOCK STRIKE
description: Losses from the Longshoremen's strike in Gulf and East Coast ports mounted into the hundreds of millions of dollars yesterday, according to Government estimates, as container shipping operations from Maine to Texas remained shut down for the 14th straight day.

title: Healy's Talk Restores Pep to Rivers's Batting
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14Fran Healy, not used on the field, continued to use his psychiatrist's couch in the clubhouse tonight in contributing to the Yankees thirdgame victory in the World Series.

title: After Long Slump, Newfoundland Fishing Enjoys a Boom
description: QUIDI VIDI, Newfoundland Abroad smile creased Jim Ring's sunreddened fisherman's face as he helped heave buckets of live squid from his boat to A dock in this tiny fishing village, an enclave in the Newfoundland capital city of St. John's.

title: Scores Up to the Inning Available at 9991313
description: The New York Telephone Company will provide inningbyinning scores of the World Series games to fans calling 9991313. The scores will be updated after each halfinning and final scores will be carried for several hours after the end of each game.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 15, 1977

title: A Lost Rossini Fascinates
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 14 Despite the many revivals of early 19thcentury bel canto operas that have taken place in the last two decades, few have ever been performed in editions based on scholarly musicological research. There is still a great deal of work to be done in this area, and the Houston Grand Opera made a commendable start with its opening production of the season Thursday night, Rossini's Tancredi in new critical edition prepared by Philip Gossett under the auspices of la Fondazione Rossini.

title: 2 Tiny Caribbean Isles Just Can't Find Place in the Sun
description: SWAN ISLANDS, HondurasThere is something a little sad about a potential world trouble spot that never made the grade.

title: Crosby Set Style for an Older Age and Led Way for Rock
description: Young Americans are used to pop stars who are angry, sexy and rebellious. Bing Crosby answered different needs for a different age. He did so with a grace that was typical of his entire career, and in his own subtle and unassuming way, he left a mark on American popular music that many more flashy performers would find hard to match.

title: Nixon Shrine Is Sold
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)The Yorba Linda School District has agreed unanimously to sell former President Richard M. Nixon's 1.3acre birthplace to a nonprofit corporation for use as a historical landmark. The district sold the land, house, flagpole and monument last night for $125,000 to the Nixon Birthplace Foundation. The house was built in 1912 by Mr. Nixon's father.

title: Vase Is Returned to Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 14 (Reuters)A 2,000year old Corinthian vase stolen from the Villa Giulio Museum here 22 years ago was returned to Italy from the United States, the Foreign Ministry said. The richly decorated red and black vase, painted with tigers, lions and sea animals, disappeared from the museum in 1955. It later turned up in a museum in Los Angeles. Italy had sent a special delegation to the United States to convince authorities that the vase had been illegally imported, the officials said.

title: British Parties Come Out of Parleys With Wounds Healed, Set to Fight
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 14Margaret Thatcher, the Conservative leader, brought her party's annual conference to a rousing close today with a pledge to halt the creation of what she called 'a Britain modeled on Eastern Europe.

title: Bill Voted to Allow Payment Contracts Tied to Gold Value
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 14(ReuterlThe House of Representatives completed Congressional action today on legislation that would allow United States citizens to sign contracts tying payments to the value of gold.

title: Search Intensifies for Aged: Woman
description: WHITE PLAINS. Oct. 14More than 100 volunteers will spread out through the woods tomorrow morning in a search for 77yearold Sarah Brownlie, who went for a walk last Friday and did not return.

title: Study Sees 12% Economic Growth; Warns on Debate Over State Taxes
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14The state's Economic Policy Council today reported a modest business upturn in New Jersey in the last 10 months and said the economy would expand by 12 percent next year unless industry became nervous because of the uncertainty over taxes.

title: Lillian Carter To Throw Out 4thGame Ball
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14Lillian Carter, mother of President Carter, was scheduled to throw out the first ball before the fourth game of the Series tomorrow. Glenn Campbell will sing the national anthem. A moment of Silence was observed before tonight's game in memory of Bing Crosby, who died today. Crosby was a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates board of directors.

title: Another Nightwear Chemical Causes a Safety Controversy
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted last April to ban Tris, the chemical most commonly used to render fabrics flameresistant, from children's sleepwear because it was found to cause cancer in laboratory animals. The ban was subsequently lifted as the result of a lawsuit, but the commission claimed the authority to restrain individual stores from selling Tristreated garments.

title: Yanks Win, 53, and Take 21 Edge in Series
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14Just when people were suggesting that brawling in public would bring them to no good end, the New York Yankees put aside their family feuds tonight, overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers by 53 and took a lead of two games to one in the 74th World Series.

title: U.S. Industrial Production Rose 0.4% in September
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.14 (AP)Reversing a onemonth decline, output of the nation's industry increased fourtenths of 1 percent in September, the Government reported today.

description: STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 14 (AP)Three fraternity brothers building a display for the Oklahoma State University homecoming celebration were electrocuted today when their scaffolding came into contact with a high voltage line, fire officials said.

description: F. Jerome Tone, who retired in 1959 as executive vice president of the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, N.Y., died Thursday in General Hospital, Binghamton, N.Y., after a short illness, He was 76 years old and lived in Mountain Lake, N.Y.

title: Today's Probable Pitchers

Won 16 games, lost seven, compiled 2.82 earnedrun average and pitched five shutouts in this, his first full season in major leagues . . . . Threw threehitter in winning second game of playoffs, against Kansas City Royals . . . . A Cajun who lives in Lafayette, La., where he was born. . . Attended University of Southwestern Louisiana for 2 years. . He and wife, Bonnie, have one child, a daughter, 10monthold Jamie.

title: ExYonkers Officer Arrested by F .B .I. In $1 Million Theft
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 14The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest in Miami of Vincent Joseph Anderson, a former Yonkers police captain, in connection with the theft of $1 million in cash and nonnegotiable checks from the Hudson Valley National Bank in Yonkers last February.

title: Park's Weather Data Curtailed
description: The National Weather Service has stopped repairing the sensitive instruments it keeps in Central Park because, it says, five minutes after the devices are repaired, vandals wreck them again.

title: Two Japanese Gunmen Hijack Commuter Bus
description: NAGASAKI, Japan, Saturday, Oct. 15 (Reuters)  Two masked men, one armed with a sawedoff shotgun, took over a commuter bus with about five or six passengers aboard here today, the police said.

title: High Court Delays Concorde Edict
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (Reuters)The Supreme Court today put off at least tin:. tit Monday an announcement on whether will extend a stay that has prevented the Concorde supersonic airliner from the randing at New York's Kennedy International Airport.

title: Penn Puts Lafayette to Rout. 427
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (UPI)Tom Roland hit a split end, Nelson Johnson, with a 26yard touchdown pass in the second period, and Bob Nix returned an interception 22 yards for a score 15 seconds later, leading the University of Pennsylvania football team to a 427 rout of Lafayette tonight.

title: CARTER AND TORRIJOS AGREE ON U.S. RIGHT TO DEFEND THE CANAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14In an effort to facilitate approval of the Panama Canal treaty in both the United States and Panama, President Carter and Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera said today that the United States had the right to act against any aggression or threat directed against the Canal.

title: 'Rolling Thunder' Film, Few Claps
description: After spending eight years in a Vietcong prison camp, Maj. Charles Rane (William Devane) returns home to a small town in Texas to be greeeted as a hero with a Cadillac convertible and couple thousand dollars in silver dollars (donated by a supermarket), one for each day of his imprisonment, plus one for luck. He accepts the car and the money in much the same manner as he accepts his wife's news that she's fallen in love with another manimpassively.Nothing seems to move Charlie, though he cares for his young son and he is something of a physical fitness nut. He tells himself that it's as if he'd died when he was captured. One survives years of torture, he says, if "you learn to love the ropethat's how you beat them."Charlie, as written in the screenplay by Paul Schrader and Heywood Gould, and as acted by Mr. Devane, is such a tough, complicated, explosive character that one keeps wishing that "Rolling Thunder," the film that contains him, were a match for him. It isn't. The movie, which opened yesterday at the Cincerama I and other theaters, has some good things, but in the way it has been directed by John Flynn it moves so easily and sort of foolishly toward its violent climax that all the tension within Charlie has long since escaped the film."Rolling Thunder," written in 1973, a year after Mr. Schrader wrote the screenplay for "Taxi Driver," gives evidence of having once been something much more complex than the neo-"Death Wish" this film is. There are a number of similarities between Charlie, the seemingly cool, unnervingly collected vet of "Rolling Thunder," and the psychotic Travis Bickle of "Taxi Driver." Within each is a small vial of nitroglycerine ready to go off.The event that detonates Charlie is a brutal holdup in which a gang of thugs invades his house looking for his silver dollars. Not knowing Charlie's secret for survival, they torture him. They grind up his right hand in the garbage disposal unit, then murder his wife, his son and, they think, Charlie.The manner in which Charlie, now equipped with a metal claw for a hand, goes about tracking down the murderers is such a model of efficiencyand he seems so cheerful about the taskthat the complicated, seething character of the film's opening sequences appears to have become not much more interesting than the fellow played by Charles Bronson in "Death Wish."I can't believe that it was Mr. Schrader's idea merely to have Charlie reliving his Vietnam duty (and, anyway, Charlie was a flier, not a ground soldier) when he sets up the bloody series of executions that conclude the movie. This, however, seems to be the point. Something is missing, but what it is, I'm not sure.Though "Rolling Thunder" appears to have been made primarily for what is loosely called "the action market," which will take violence, blood and gore over sex any day, it has a nice feeling for the way small-town America looks and sounds and it has several excellent performances.In addition to Mr. Devane's, there are those of Linda Haynes, as a young blond cocktail waitress who manages simultaneously to look beautiful and slightly ravaged (something that it took Ava Gardner years to achieve), and Tommy Lee Jones, as a fellow who shared Charlie's time in the P.O.W. camp and effectively suggests a man who, though he pretends to be like anyone else, now lives in a small closet in the back of his soul. Like Charlie, he is haunted but ever-alertand armed to the teeth.

title: Notes on People
description: ?t ceremonies marking the opening of Amsterdam's new subway system yesterday, a man threw a plastic bag of orange paint at Crown Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands. A news photographer shoved the 39yearold Princess aside and the paint missed her. But it spattered over the suit of her husband, Prince Claus, and drenched the Minister of Transport, Tjerk Westerterp. The paint was thrown by a 31yearold man who was dragged away by the police and charged with assault. He threw the paint as members of the Princess's entourage made their way back to their cars after the dedication ceremonies. The paintthrower was one of several persons demonstrating against demolition of homes to make way for the 48mile subway network.

title: Debt Cancellations Stir Debate on Aid to Poor Nations
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 14Newly announced Swedish and Canadian plans to cancel nearly a half billion dollars in debts owed by thirdworld governments have, diplomats here believe, put into sharper focus The often bitter debate on economic issues between industrialized and developing countries.

title: Music: Lincoln Chamber Society
description: Autumn time, and the livin is easier, thanks to the return of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. This admired organization, now in its ninth year, has as usual assembled some of the best musicians around, worked up a series of interesting programs,and is performing everything with style and polish.

title: BELL TO STEP UP WAR ON CRIME IN SUNBELT
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 14Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that a Federal organized crime strike force office that was deactivated in New Orleans last year would be reopened, and that smaller suboffices would be opened in Sunbelt cities in an effort to combat organized crime throughout the region.

title: SUMMER FOOD INQUIRY LEAVES UNPAID BILLS
description: Many vendors and suppliers for the federally financed Summer Food Service Program for Children in New York .City say Federal investigations have stalled millions of dollars in payments, plunging them into debt, creating chains of unpaid bills and leaving them in financial limbo.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)The House and Senate conferes agreed today to raise the nation's minimum wage to $3.35 an hour by 1981 from the current $2.30. The current minimum would go to $2.65 an hour next Jan. 1.

title: Jon Hassell, Trumpeter, Opens Vistas
description: Jon Hassell, who performed at the Kitchen on Thursday night, advertised his program as a new crossover music. New is an imposing word; in music it usually is shorthand for a new combination of traditional elements, and this is what Mr. Hassell offered. But he has transferred techniques from one musical idiom into another with such skill, and combined ethnic strains, electronics, minimalism and jazz so intelligently that one cannot begrudge him his use of new. His synthesis opens up new vistas rather than simply rearranging the components of old ones.

title: 2 Nobel Laureates Theories on Trade
description: Economists will be pleased that this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science has gone to James Meade of Britain and Bertil Ohlin of Sweden. Both have done outstanding scholarly work in the field of international trade and finance. Each man has demonstrated that those who are best in pure science are often outstanding policy advisers and public servants. And both have been prolific discoverers of new theories and empirical patterns in divers topics of modern political economy that transcend international exchange.

description: WASHINGTON,Oct. 14It was dark, dark, dark, the poet Andrei Voznesensky said, moving his hands in the manner of one who cannot see. It was about 7 o'clock. was impossible to find him. I began to write.

title: Voznesensky Composes an Elegy For Robert Lowell by the Grave
description: Continued From Page 25 particular and individual languages? Mr. Voznesensky is a slight man with a turnedup nose, a broad, expressive mouth and a face as changeable as water. It expressed amiable disbelief at the question and an eagerness to explain what clearly was obvious to him.

title: Briton, Swede Get Nobel Prize For Economics
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14  Two pioneers in international trade theory, one Swedish and the other British, won the 1977 Nobel Memorial prize in Economic Science, it was announced here today.

title: Despite the Remonstrance, ABC Espouses Trust in Cosell
description: Despite a torrent of complaints from viewers around the country about the verbal excesses and melodramatic style of Howard Cosell during the World Series telecasts, officials of ABC Sports said yesterday they had no intention of relieving him of the assignment.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Back on Political Trail
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 14From several eight, airy rooms in her modest onestory home here, former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is working hard to engineer political comeback.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Unconventional Treatment Center for Alcoholics to Open in Paramus
description: HACKENSACK, Oct. 14Bergen County will open a detoxification center for alcoholics Nov. 1 to provide them with a calm, relaxed homelike environment during the withdrawal phase of their treatment rather than the clinical, and sometimes intimidating, atmosphere of a hospital.

title: Chorus Strikes the Philharmonic
description: Because of a strike by the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents professional chorus members, the New York Philharmonic dropped. Schubert's Mass in G from Thursday night's program, substituting a Mozart symphony and a suite from Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier. Guild pickets outside Avery Fisher Hall passed out leaflets explaining that the union and the management were deadlocked over the Philharmonic's insistence on a right to employ amateur singers in some instances. To dramatize the union's stand, the leaflets said, Richard Westenburg will conduct 100 striking singers in the Schubert Mass on the Lincoln Center Plaza tonight at 7:45 P.M.

title: WINDDRIVEN RAINS LASH JERSEY COAST
description: A gale pounded the East Coast yesterday with 50mileanhour winds and raised eightfoot tides that caused flooding in many areas, forcing the removal of residents from some New Jersey shore communities.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Spending Rent on Housing
description: When society gives needy people welfare allowances big enough to cover their rent, it should be able to expect that rent is what the money will be used far. But experience has shown that many welfare families, in New. York and elsewhere, fail to turn their rent allowances over to their landlords. Sometimes they are threatened with. eviction, sometimes government pays their rent a second time, but most often the owner simply takes in less money. That means he can't afford to keep the building from dilapidationand, often enough, simply abandons it.. Diversion of welfare rent thus hurts everyone, notably welfare recipients.

title: Dow Is Up 3.47 to 821.64 as Stocks Stage Timid Rally in Dull Trading
description: The stock market produced a timid rally in relatively slow trading yesterday one session after interestrate fears had hammered the Dow Jones industrial average to a twoyear low.

title: Today's Football at a Glance
description: COMMENT

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Long Island Rail Road's 10 nonoperating unions have asked the Metropolitan Transportaion Authority Chairman, Harold Fischer, to participate in roundtheclock negotiations to avert a strike of 6,200 employees on Oct. 20.

title: People in Sports
description: After serving five months of a oneyear prison sentence for violating probation, Marvin Barnes was released from the Rhode Island Adult Correctional Institution in Cranston, R. I., yesterday morning and flew to Buffalo to join the Detroit Pistons for an exhibition game against the Braves.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: MEMORY LANE Tomorrow's twohour walking tour through Greenwich Village leaves at 2 P.M., with the group meeting in front of the Old Homestead Restaurant at 14th Street and Ninth Avenue. The guided trek is being led by Felix J. Cuervo,president of the Native New Yorkers Historical Association. Among the stops will be the narrow house at 75 Bedford Street where Edna St, Vincent Millay lived in 1924, the White Horse Tavern, the house at 82 Jane Street where Alexander Hamilton died after his auei with. Aaron Burr in 1804, and the Gansvoort Street Pier, where Herman Melville served as a Customs inspector for 20 years. The tour tab is $2.

title: Airliner Production Is Threatened By Boeing and Lockheed Strikes..
description: BURBANK, Calif.,Oct. 14 Strikes against the Lockheed Corporation here and the Boeing Company in three cities threaten to halt much of the nation's output of airliners just when the slumping aerospace industry has been enjoying resurgence of orders for jet transports.

title: MAN, 82, KILLED WIFE BY DEFENDING SELF
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 14An 82yearold man accused of strangling his 76yearold wife testified today that he had killed her in selfdefense during an argument over her boyfriends in which she had fought like a wildcat.

title: A $750Million Question for New York
description: Despite austerity, and in the name of economic recovery, Governor Carey wants New York State to borrow $750 million over the next three years. If the voters approve on Nov. 8, the money raised in the bond market would be disbursed to localities at the rate of $250 million a year for projects that qualify for large Federal subsidies and which can be broadly shown to stimulate growth and employment.

title: Jersey Man Hurt in Fire
description: MARGATE, N.J.,Oct. 14(UPI)A threealarm fire today swept, the top floor of a small motel in this coastal town, critically Injuring Irwin Schweer, 20years old, of Margate. He was taken to the Atlantic City Medical Center in critical condition. The police said the cause of the fire at the Beacon Motel was under investigation.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates steel Is traded on The New York Sock Ex. change, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: James Edward Meade
description: LONDON, Oct. 14The voice of Prof. James Edward Meade, quiet and authoritative on matters of international economics, seemed startled today by his Nobel recognition. I am completely overpowered, he said this afternoon. AS yet I Know absolutely no details.

title: Hair Will Stay Open
description: Michael Butler, producer of Hair, said yesterday that he had invested $200,000 more ha the revival of the tribal rock musical to keep it running at the Biltmore Theater. Its future had been uncertain after a closing notice that would have become effective tomorrow was posted at the theater Tuesday. Box office business started to rise, the producer said, and we decided to take the notice down on Thursday night.

title: Turkey Rejects Demands
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 14 (UPI)The Turkish Government today rejected the hijackers demands for the release of two Palestinians held in Turkish jails.

title: TILLMAN REINSTATED BY PORT AUTHORITY
description: John Tillman, who was suspended without pay Aug. 29 by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey after admitting he had faked his expense accounts for three years, was restored to the payroll yesterday after reimbursing $1,600 to the authority, according to Peter C. Goldmark Jr. executive director of the authority.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST $10,000, mdn., 3Y0 & up. 6f.

title: Scheuer Named to Head Panel On Problems of Population
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill announced today the appointment of Representative James H. Scheuer, Democrat of Brooklyn, as chairman of a new select committee on population. Mr. Scheuer was the principal sponsor of a resolution, passed by the House Sept. 28, to set up the new committee

title: KENNETH J. MULLANE, A NOTED LAWYER, 68
description: Kenneth J. Mullane, a wellknown lawyer who was a specialist in cases involving wills and estates, died in Doctors Hospital Thursday after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 468 Riverside Drive.

title: Music: Gilbert and Sullivan Treat
description: There are several organizations that dabble occasionally in the Gilbert and Sullivan repertory, but the true keeper of the flame is the Light Opera of Manhattan. It keeps going week in and week out at the tiny Eastside Playhouse at 334 East 74th Street.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: From Failing sight, a Book And a New Way of Writing
description: Eleanor Clark has written a memoir: Good news, for those who have followed her through Rome and a Villa, The Oysters of Locmariaquer and Baldur's Gate. There is more to her story than reminiscences of a literary life. Since 1974, when her last work, a collection of stories, was published, Miss Clark has lost most of her sight.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the serendipitous advantages of using the Lightner slam double is that it prevents players from making foolish doubles based on general strength. If the double means that an unusual lead is required, normally in dummy's suit, a player cannot be tempted into doubling because he has some high cards and is hoping for a onetrick defeat. Such doubles are mathematically unsound and sometimes help the declarer to make his contract.

title: JOSEPH W. CENTOLA
description: Joseph W. Centola, who retired Iast May as treasurer of the Cowles Communications, with which he had been associated for 35 years, died Thursday in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old. He is survived by his wife, Gulli: a son, Frank; two brothers, David and Anthony; a sister, Mrs. Gilda Ornott, and two grandchildren.

title: Carter Entertains 500 in Peanut Brigade
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14With food simmering over open fires and candles flickering in the chill night breezes, President Carter played host last night to the Peanut Brigade500 Georgians who campaigned for him when he was just Jimmy who?

title: Third Series Box Score
description: YANKEES (A)

title: BOOK ENDS
description: J R. R. TOLKIEN'S The Silmarillion is currently the fastestselling book in the stores, and trailing in its wake are several other books in what is called the fantasy adventure genre. The Tolkien vogue began on the campuses; first, when the Houghton Mifflin hardcover edition of The Lord of the Rings trilogy became a cult book on Ivy League campuses in the 50's, and then when the paperback version achieved masscult status in the 60's.

title: The Awarding Last Week of Nobel Prizes to Two Women Who Lead the Peace Movement Couldn't Hurt
description: DUBLINThe award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Northern Ireland peace movement leaders, Mairead Corrigan and Betty Williams, comes at a time of optimism that the 'troubles may soon end, But peace hones have been dashed so often since the outbreak of violence in 1969 that there's understandable official reluctance even to speculate about the possibility of a ceasefire by the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, and sources in the group describe the rumors as propaganda. However, the speculation persists, particularly in Belfast, fueled mainly by antiterrorist duccesses by security forces on both sides of the border betiveen the North and the Republic of Ireland.

title: LETTERS
description: With reference to Barbara Gelb's excellent article ('Ten Days That Shook Me Up in Russia, Sept. 18), I think a disservice is done to the cause of Soviet Jewish activists when they are called dissidents. A clear distinction must be drawn between activists and those Soviet citizens who are are politically oriented and wish to change the present system of Soviet government.

title: Exposition to Promote Hackensack Mall
description: HACKENSACK WITH the advent of a weeklong promotion extravaganza that gets under way here tomorrow the shopping mall will have come full circle back to the village green.

title: LETTERS
description: On Sept. 18, the Westchester Weekly carried an informative article on the unveiling of a monument to Major John L. Polerecky. We are pleased with the writeup, but nowhere in the article is there any mention of the SlovakAmerican Cultural Center whose Working Committee for the Unveiling of the Monument to Major John L. Polerecky labored for two years under adverse conditions, without a penny to start with, and bringing many personal sacrifices in order to honor a Slovak who helped to build this great country.

title: England Beats U.S. In Rugby
description: TWICKENHAM, England, Oct. 15Inelegant and disorganized, the United States rugby team lost badly today to England, 3711, at the stadium in Twickenham.

title: 123 Dogs Are in. Obedience Regional
description: Moreland's Golden Tonka will head a cast of 123 performers at the 1977 Eastern Regional dog obedience championship, which is scheduled for Sathrday and Oct. 23 at Rockland Community College Fieldhouse in Suffern.

title: Equipment Fault Delays Launching Of U.S.European Satellite Project
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 15 (AP) A faulty part in the guidance system of a Delta rocket has caused a twoday delay in the launching of a scientific satellite by the United States and European space agencies.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WOMEN drive motorcycles and Mack trucks. They manage drugstores and department stores. They are college presidents, tree surgeons and even undertakers. But, the way Penelope Hastings sees it, the trouble is that men still control the money business.

title: Hurricane Fading in Atlantic
description: MIAMI,Oct. 15(UPI)The hurricane that had been codenamed Evelyn was downgraded, to a tropical storm today as it moved north from eastern Nova Scotia to the tip of Newfoundland, losing strength along the way. Evelyn's life as a hurricane had lasted barely 24 hours.

title: The Miles and The Money
description: Costs: Construction, $164,536,697; rightofway, $50,838,792; supervision, $21.536.494. Total. $236.911.883.

title: Mr. Carter's Domestic Performance Is Sluggish, at Best
description: WASHINGTONA strange place, this town, where Newton's laws are often challenged, Where action does not necessarily result in reaction, either equal or opposite, and where Presidential motion does not always reduce inertia.

title: New Views of Mark Twain
description: HARTFORD

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: During the last few years, the troubles of the banking industry have surfaced on a global scale...

title: A Museum Looks for Contents
description: THE Corbin Wheeler building, a house built more than 150 years ago in the architectural style of the Federal period, is sitting patiently on school grounds in Glen Cove waiting to be fully restored to its former state.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: AT LEAST once each year, the utility companies come out in full force and lobby vigorously for hefty rate increases. While I have nothing personal against them (other than that they control too large a share of our yearly income), I do find myself taking a long, hard look at the telephone and the stranglehold it seems to have on my life.

title: The Recent HighLevel Visits Between the U.S. and Yugoslavia Point to Closer Ties
description: WASHINGTONAfter much hesitation and uncertainty, the United States and Yugoslavia appear near to establishing closer ties than any point in a decade. After a fiveday visit to WaShington, Edyard Kardelj, a member of Yigoslaia's collective Presidency, declared this month that AmericanYugoslav relations were better than ever. Last week, in the first visit ever of an American Secretary of Defense to Yugoslavia, Harold Brown arrived in Belgrade for a threeday visit that focused . on the resumption of United States military assistance to the Communist regime. This diplomatic activity pointed toward the expected visit of President Tito to Washington next spring and, in the longer term, to the possibility of conflict with the Soviet Union when the venerable Yugoslav leader dies.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Diamond King Moves in Realm Unlike 47th St.
description: Harry F. Oppenheimer, the most powerful person in the world's diamond industry, has never been to the block on West 47th Street that is the nation's diamond mart and where he is regarded with such awe that many vendors of his glittering merchandise are convinced, mistakenly, that he is a member of the Rothschild family.

title: Design
description: In fashion, black is a basic. It's a safe color, a neutral. But in interior design it has been shunned since the twilight Art Deco. Now, however, many interior designers, while admitting that black is a challenge, say it can work anywhere. Its successful use depends on textures as well as light and its reflection. Matte black, used liberally as an accent with natural woods, produces a restful effect. Lacquered black walls, ceiling and/or furniture, highlighted with chrome, give drama and modern glamour.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Meet the People: Dr. George Sternlieb, director of the Center for Urban Policy Research, Rutgers University; Victor Marrero, chairman of the City Planning Commission; Xavier Rodriguez, chairman of Community Planning Board 3 in the South Bronx.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It was question time after a lecture on campus. A question was asked: How do you tell a good dancer? I gulped back a temptation to reply: How do you tell a good dancer what? and found myself stutteringly staggering into the midst of basic esthetics or something dangerously similar. How do you tell a good dancer? What is a good dancer? What is the difference between a good dancer and a bad danceror, more pertinently perhaps, what is the difference between a good dancer and a mediocre dancer? Very soon one would find oneself pondering on what dancing itself was all aboutand, headily, I knew that that way lay only madness.

title: 3 Bayonne Children Are Shot to Death; Father Is Charged
description: An unemployed Bayonne, N.J.. man. apparently disturbed over marital problems, shot his three children to death and critically wounded his wire yesterday, according to the police.

title: Byram's Slovaks Remember
description: GREENWICH

title: Nyquist Among Noted New Appointees to Posts at Pace
description: PLEASANTVILLE PACE UNIVERSITY began as a small business institute in downtown Manhattan 71 years ago and now has nine schools, nearly 20,000 students in New York City and Westchester, and a growing reputation as an educational institution. Searching for teaching and administrative talent to match its growth, it has recently come up with a series of noteworthy appointments.

title: Upstate Training School Where  Youth Was Killed Urged to Make Changes
description: The board of visitors of a New York State training school for juvenile delinquents, where a 13yearold boy was stabbed and beaten to death by other youths and a female employee was raped last June, recommended a broad program last week for improving conditions at the upstate institution.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homes have screenedin porches or partly enclosed sunrooms along the side or back of the house that are unheated, and thus unused, during the winter. Since these porches only have screens to enclose them, winddriven rain and snow accumulates on the inside, and anything stored out there takes a beating from the weather.

title: African Nations Using Roadblocks As a New Tool of Foreign Policy
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 14Kenya and Uganda barred each other's heavy trucks from crossing their common border last week in another instance of the growing use in black Africa of the disrupting of transportation as an instrument of foreign policy.

title: No title
description: No title

title: Travel Windfalls for a Few: I. Bumped Into First Class
description: One is vulnerable to nostalgia at unexpected moments. At 35, I am old enough to remember when transAtlantic flights were pleasantly stippled with luxury, even in economy class. I recall an AirIndia flight with a rose on every dinner tray, B.O.A.C. flights with complimentary champagne. The planes were spotless, The menus titillating, the passengers dressed up in anticipation of what would clearly be an occasion.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE PLUNDERED PAST, by Karl E. Meyer. (Atheneum, $5.95.) A journalist whose avocation archeology reports on the theft and smuggling rare paintings during the recent pasta story that ranges from Turkey, Italy and Central America to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art. A basic text that reads like a detective story.

title: Pro Basketball Preview: Wholesale Shifts Cloud N.B.A. Pictures
description: During the offseason, so many players changed uniforms about the only thing that remained stable in the National Basketball Association was the height of the baskets. When the 32d season opens Tuesday night with three new coaches, including Willis Reed of the Knicks, the 22team league will have approximately 90 players on new teams or off the rosters.

title: EARTHDAY BACKER PLANNING SUN DAY
description: WASHINGTONDenis Hayes, a 32yearold environmental activist who was a leading promoter of Earth Day on April 22, 1970, is now planning Sun Day, an effort to galvanize public opinion in favor, of solar energy, on May 3 next year.

title: Notes: Getting Chamber Musicians Together
description: Eugene Rosov believes that chamber music in America is where dance was a few years ago, that it is ready to experience. the same kind of growth if properly nourished and if something is done to stimulate people's awareness of it. As founder and executive director of the Center for Chamber Music at Apple Hill Farm in Nelson, N.H., he has, as he says, spent the last eight to 10 years of my life working out the relationship between economics, education, composition and chamber music.

title: 4 Politicians Unite To Assail as Weak Carey Bond Issue
description: An unusual political coalition yesterday urged the defeat of Governor Carey's proposed $750 million bond issue at the polls next month, calling it a grab baga wish list of projects that may or may not be built and stating that it would not have the intended effect of permanently improving the state's economy.

title: Helen T. Platt Married to Geoffrey Booty
description: The marriage of Helen Todd Platt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Platt 2d of Newtown, Conn., and Block Island, R. I., to Geoffrey Rollen Booty, son of the Rev. and Mrs. John E. Booty of Concord, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford.

title: How Nancy Hanks Successor Was Chosen
description: The formidable lobbying support for Livingston L. Biddle Jr., recently selected by President Carter as the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, re flects the growing political involvement of the arts community.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The first free flight of the manned space shuttle is being commemorated this month by a limited edition 10carat gold medal. The medal shows the Enterprise, the first of a planned fleet of reusable space vehicles (they hope to get 100 trips out of each one between overhauls).

title: And Hearings This Week May Show if Motion Equals Progress
description: WASHINGTONIn his first public meeting with the House ethics committee in August, Leon Jaworski spoke sternly of the compelling need to expedite the committee's investigation into allegations that Congressmen had taken bribes and other illicit favors from South Korean agents. But he also cautioned that speed must always yield to our highest priority, that of thoroughness.

title: How Real Is the Gap Between Operatic And Pop Singing?
description: There are few voices in popular music that pack quite the sheer visceral impact that Rod Stewart's does. The British rocker has had a varied career, and one that didn't always live up to the potential within his throat. But whatever you may think of his artistry and his taste, it is for his wonderfully high, raspy, affecting tenor that one looks forward to his Madison Square Garden appearances Thursday and Friday, and to his abouttobereleased new album, Foot Loose & Fancy Free.

title: Dorothy Albano Married
description: Dorothy Albano and Guido Bertucci were married yesterday in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Vincent Resta performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. Adriana R. Albano of Pelham Manor. N. Y., and the late Edmond Albano are the parents of the bride, whose husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Umberto Bertucci of Vercelli, Italy.

title: Music: Reunion
description: From 1948 to 1962 Maro and Anahid Ajemian formed a pianoandviolin duo that contributed worthily to the local music s??ne, particularly with their performances of contemporary works. After that their personal lives kept them apart as concert artists, until Friday night, when there was a welcome reunion of the sisters at Town Hall in a program at violin sonatas.

title: On the Sly, Alydar Victors at Belmont
description: The richest program in American racing history produced one big surprise and a mild one at Belmont Park, yesteday as Balmak Stable's On the Sly captured the $346,800 Jockey Club Gold Cup and Calumet's Alydar won the $134,000 Champagne Stakes,

title: Comeback Pays Off for Exeter
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 15  Exeter, down by 207 after the first period and seemingly headed for its third straight defeat, rallied and downed Mount Hermon, 2720, today. Joe McGillivray's 33yard scoring run in the fourth period gave the home team its first triumph.

title: AGENTS IN MAINE SEIZE A TON OF MARIJUANA
description: BOOTHBAY HARBOR, Me.,Oct. 15The State Police reported today the seizure of a ton of marijuana on the Maine coast, which is the third large confiscation of marijuana in the state in recent months.

title: RAO JR. CONVICTED; OF LYING TO JURY
description: Paul P. Rao Jr a lawyer and the son of a United States Customs Court judge, was convicted by a New York State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday of lying to a grand jury in 1974. when he denied having created a phony defense for a client charged with robbery.

title: Groucho Redivivus
description: ISOMETIMES wonder whether since Peter De Vries began writing novels the American people have become more and more De Vriesesque, imitating his characters foibles and giving expression to his exquisite sneers, just as (surely this apparent?) people developed Oedipus complexes and hysterical handwringing after reading Freud. It could be argued that the acquisitions department of the Museum of Modern Art is full of De Vries fans who have wilfully misunderstood his ironies by paying through the nose for Susan Rothenberg's Untitled (a kindergartner's goofy horse with a head like a woodpecker's), other craftsmen's celluloid pajamas, rusty bicycle sprockets or rather inferior cookie jars.

title: Kathleen Marie Tierney Is Bride of Craig M. Snyder
description: In St. James Roman Catholic Church in Red Bank, N.J., yesterday afternoon, Kathleen Marie Tierney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Moran Tierney Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., became the bride of Craig Michael Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Orville Snyder Jr. of Spring Lake, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Sheehan performed the ceremony.

title: Prayer Services on the 7:08
description: SUBWAYS may be for sleeping, but is a Long Island Rail Road train a place for praying? Yes, according to Rabbi Noach Valley of the Jewish Center of Ocean Harbor in Oceanside.

title: 100Mile Run Mark Broken
description: LONDON, Oct, 15, (Reuters)Don Ritchie, a 33yearold teacher from Scotland, broke the world record for running 100 miles tonight. His time of 11 hours 30 minutes 50 seconds clipped 8 minutes 33 seconds from the previous record, set by another Briton, Gavin Woodward, in 1975.

title: Suffolk Police Mark Property To Cut Thefts
description: YAPHANK, L.I.Armed with a slim, fourinchlong electrical etching tool, the Suffolk police have begun an attack on the increasing number of burglaries in the county14,545 last year and 10,846 as of Aug. 31 this year.

title: GARDENING
description: SUCCESS stories are good to tell. One that was the talk of Cos Cob last summer was the display of zinnias in the shopping area.

title: The Working Mother: Frustrations and Solutions
description: A SHORT time after we moved from Brooklyn to Great Neck five years ago, I discovered that despite its wealthy image, Great Neck was a townlike so many otherswith an increasing number of working mothers.

title: Tenants Try to Hold Back The Abandonment Tide
description: In the southwest corner of Harlem, on the flat land below Morningside Heights, there is a stately, turnofthecentury apartment house that came close not long ago to the ultimate misfortune that can befall any good building short of destruction: abandonment.

title: A Friend of Women
description: JOHN STUART MILL, who before he met Harriet Taylor had never so much as looked at female creature, not even a cow, in the face, ound himself opposite those great dark eyes, that were flashing unutterable things while he was discoursin the utterable concernin all sorts o high topics'so said Thomas Carlyle to Charles Eliot Norton: Carlyle exaggerated: but Mill became Harriet's slave for life, and it is their relationship that at the core of Josephine Kamm's new book.

title: Irwin Shoots a 64 and Kite a 65, Share Lead at 199 in Texas Golf
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 15 (UPI)Hale Irwin and Tom Kite shot subpar rounds and charged to 11underpar 199's today to share the lead of the $150,000 Texas open.

title: II. She Won a $1,500 Cruise and Took Her Dad Along
description: Champaigne glass in hand, I looked up through my eyelashes at the handsome Dutch ship's officer and felt like Cinderella. The scene: the captain's cocktail party aboard the Rotterdam, on the eightday voyage from New York to Nassau and Bermuda. The price: zip. I'd won the $1,500 cruise for two in a contest.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. American Jewish Pioneers.

title: The Nation
description: Military maxim: Don't fight a war on two fronts at once. President Carter's energy program is in trouble,a lot of it, and so last week he decided to delay presenting his already overdue tax proposals to Congress.

title: Crosby Will Be Buried Tuesday; His Songs, in Tribute, Aired Anew
description: The entertainment world and millions of people who loved Bing Crosby's songs mourned the singer's death as plans were made yesterday for a private funeral in Los Angeles on Tuesday and for more elaborate memorial services in London today and New York City tomorrow.

title: Labor Pact at Nuclear Plant.
description: CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 15 (UPI)A, labor dispute that has delayed construction of the cooling tunnels at the nuslear power plant in Seabrook has been resolved, according to a lawyer involved in the negotiations. Christopher Gallagher said that the Concord Monitor laborers accepted a wage cotnract calling for $9.50 an hour. The laborers had sought about 30 cents more an hour.

title: Heavens Sets Rush Mark Before 72,594
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 15Notre Dame and Army moved their famous football rivalry to a new location today and played in the plush, modern setting of Giants Stadium at the Jersey Meadowlands. But the result was the same old thing that has been the trend of this matchup ever since its inception in 1913Notre Dame won handily. 24 0and this time a crowd of 72,594 was on hand to witness the victory.

title: Food
description: Havana is still a city of traditions. Every night at 9 P.M. a cannon shot signals the time for the giant gates in the city walls to be shut tight, just as they were colonial times. To the Salas family, it also signals the start of Sunday dinner.

title: Four Novels
description: THREATENED with imminent middle age, Eliot Warren, novelist, critic and professor at an experimental California university, slipping, as Sports Car Menopause opens, into moodiness and taciturnity, writer's block, and marital doldrums. After a quarrel with his wife of 15 years over a broken washing machine, he sets up temporary residence over a colleague's garage, which will shortly become the headquarters for an affair he will conduct with one Nina Aliencraig, nubile 19yearold student who organizes nudeins on campus and first approaches Eliot requesting an independent study on Goya, Otto Rank and Norman Thomas. In addition to his affaire de coeur, Eliot must also contend with students who submit fiction to him promoting what they describe as nonlinear communication and the warp and woof of word texture, and an unbalanced graduate student who latches onto Eliot and harangues him with withit pronouncements like consciousness celebration is what college is all about. With its hilarious observations on contemporary academic life and its Incisive and affecting characterizations, this delicious novel wittily assesses the clichs of our advanced culture without violating its own spirit of exuberant compassion. Mr. Stegner's is an expansively intelligent and brilliantly comic book.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The relationship between water and architecture has always been one of poetry and magic. Fountains are meant to transcend utility. The jet d'eau is the grande geste of the architect ; the sight and sound of water brings buildings and spaces to a special kind of life.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN the last year or two, there have been many stories in newspapers about problems in the new County Courthouse in White Plains, including faulty elevators and poor construct lion; one problem that caused a great commotion for a while was the appearance of a large crack, running several stories high, in the facade of the building.

title: Trial of 4 Czechoslovak Dissidents Begins Tomorrow
description: VIENNA, Oct. 15One of Czechoslovakia's foremost playwrights, Vaclav Havel, and three other intellectuals are due to go on trial in Prague Monday on charges of subversion and other criminal activities against the foundations of the republic, the Czechoslovak Government has said.

title: FISHING
description: THE outlook for New Jersey fishermen this week is good. The bluefish action is holding up, blackfish are showing well along the patches of rocky bottom inshore and there are reports of a solid line of bluefin tuna in the Mud Hole.

title: Retail Sales: Weaker Than Expected
description: Sales by the nation's retail stores declined by 1.2 percent last month, down from revised gains of 1.5 percent in August and eighttenths of a percent in July. The September drop, to a seasonally adjusted $59.02 billion, indicates more weakness in the consumer sector than I would have expected, said Courtenay Slater, the Commerce Department's chief economist.

title: Income Tax Fails to Help State' s Cities
description: PRINCETON

title: IN AMERICA
description: NEW YORK. Andrew Young was at about the threequarter mark in the marathon of his day. had started at dawn with an earlymorning TV interview and would now run into the morrow, for he had just allowed a tennis court to be booked for midnight in his name. The former pastor who does most of his preaching these days at the United Nations is ofteneven typicallybehind schedule, but this evening he was to be blamed at all, it could only be in an indirect sense. Conceivably, had his appeal in the afternoon to the Security Council for support on the latest Rhodesia initiative been less fervently in the idiom of the socalled Third World, the Russians and Chinese might not have looked so discomfited, might even have found a way to respond. Instead, wary of each other and unable to challenge the American's credentials on Africa, they had resorted to delaying tactics. So Young now had to scratch a Brazilian reception and hurry to a British cocktail party, if he wasn't to be unpardonably late for a dinner with the Egyptian Foreign Minister.

title: Martin and Jackson:All' Well That Ends Well
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15It might be more believable if David and Goliath, the Hatfields and the McCoys, and the Montagues and the Capulets had formed mutual admiration societies.

title: For That Big Model, Try a Used Car
description: LOS ANGELES

title: On a Cruise With a View Of the Mississippi
description: We lean across the polished wooden rail, peering through the dock's orange evening light for someone to wave to. Calliope notes, like emanations from a hoarse monster flute, bounce off the Poydras Street wharf, filter out over the quiet river and hiccup back into unseen parts of New Orleans. A sparse crowd begins to wave and yell, filling the requisite of a traditional voyager's sendoff, as the whistle bellows, the smoke belches from chunky black stacks, the red paddlewheel begins to churn the brown water, and the steamboat Mississippi Queen casts off for another week's leisurely invasion of the Old South, from New Orleans to Vicksburg and back.

title: Harrison Yields 73 Yards in Blanking Eastchester
description: Harrison's hardnosed defense made the difference again yesterday as Coach Ted Coppola's Huskies defeated previously unbeaten Eastchester, 140, for their fourth consecutive victory.

title: CANCER STUDY SEEKS ENVIRONMENTAL TIES
description: Strong emphasis on the prevention of cancer and on determining its environmental causes will mark the future efforts of the National Cancer Institute, its new director. Dr. Arthur C. Upton, says.

title: The Threat of Politicalization of the Federal Arts Program
description: Aspecter is haunting the arts and the humanities in the United States todaythe specter of a catastrophic shift of government policy in cultural affairs. In mu seum offices and university conference rooms, in the inner councils of music, dance and theatrical organizations the country over, but especially perhaps in New York, and among the artists and scholars who have been the beneficiaries of Federal policy in the arts and the humanities for nearly a decade now, ever since the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities began dispensing their funds with uncommon intelligence and discrimination, there is a widespread anxiety that we have come to the end of an era.

title: Vigilance Urged in Report on Hijacking and Piracy
description: Twentieth Century Captain Kidds do exist, and their targets are recreational boatmen. The United States Coast Guard has issued a warning to boatmen to beware of the possibility of hijacking and acts of piracy in the Caribbean, Gulf of Mexico, as well as remote areas of the western Atlantic and eastern Pacific Oceans.

title: Midwife in Thai Village Takes Lead In Promotion of Family Planning
description: NOEUN PLUB WAEN Thailand, Oct. 6Soah Yuthanava is doing all she can to do herself out of her business and is happy about it.

title: Romance on the Hoof
description: SIDESADDLE riding is a gloriously romantic concept. I think of Natasha, in the Russian film verion of War and Peace, riding across the meadows, and my heart leaps. I simply had to learn to ride aside, said Barbara Tober, who spends five days a week as a magazine editor in Manhattan and her weekends in South Salem, N.Y., riding whenever possible, in the company of her husband, Donald. He, naturally, rides astride and she rides sidesaddle.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACEJacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Parts. Today at 2 P.M., Wednesday to Saturday at 8:30 P.M. and next Sunday at 2 P.M. $5.50, except Saturday, $6.50, students, children and the elderly $4.50, except Friday and Saturday. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6.6281169.

title: MUSIC
description: POLITICS and music do not always make the most compatible of companions, but they will be striding forth in happy conjunction on Oct. 29, when the Ridgefield Orchestra dedicates its opening concert to the Richmond arts and education bill now pending in Congress.

title: Lynn Ann Tomarazzo Wed To Michael B. Walsh on L.I.
description: Lynn Ann Tomarazzo and Michael Brandon Walsh were married yesterday in St. Mary' Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Charles F. Kohli performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Patrick Whitney.

title: 6 ExExployees Sue Magazine Publisher
description: DES MOINES,Oct. 15 (UPI)  A $600,000 lawsuit has been filed against the Meredith Corporation by six persons dismissed by the company because they refused to work on the publications because of their religious beliefs. They said they found the magazines to be irreverent, repugnant, pornographic and/or obscene.

title: FILM
description: Sometimes you can tell a book by its cover, but most times you'd be a fool to try. Take Roger Vadim's Memoirs of the Devil, by far the most tawdrylooking of this season's new film books: The lurid jacket photographs of Catherine Deneuve, Brigitte Bardot and Jane Fonda, accompanied by a drawing of Beelzebub wagging his tongue, promise taletelling of the most deliciously titillating ing kind. Vadim's story, however, which begins Once upon a time. is considerably less exciting than its packaging would indicate. The only instances in which Vadim is truly shocking are those in which he is being cranky.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: The engineer in my house informs me that the basic premise of this deeply serious warning to earth dwellers is a factual one: dental fillings do sometimes act as radio receivers. So there is no reason to doubt the story of young William, whose new filling soon takes him beyond listening to illicit radio programs after bedtime and into the midst of a sinister conspiracy. An extraterrestrial horde of fat men in plaid sports jackets, with crew cuts, tasteless ties and hornrimmed glasses, will invade the earth, strip it bare of junk foods (they won't touch lean meats or fresh produce), and force the enslaved populace to produce more and ever more hot dogs, potato chips, Twinkies, etc. We are grateful to William for his heroic warning that though the fat men have left (in pursuit of the largest potato pancake ever sighted in space), they will return. I am ashamed to admit that I laughed out loud several times while reading this gripping narrative. But do not be deceived. The enemy is everywhere. Already they have caused the real Daniel Manus Pinkwater's photograph to be removed from the book jacket and have replaced it with one of . . . a fat man in a plaid sports jacket with a crew cut, a tasteless tie and hornrimmed glasses.

title: The Many Virtues Of Daffodils
description: EVERYONE knows and loves daffodils. But not all New Jersey gardeners are aware that, with the proper selection of varieties, they can have daffodils blooming in their gardens for at least six weeks next spring.

title: Eleven Gothic Tales
description: ISAX DINESEN, as many people know by now, is the pen name of the Danish baroness Karen Blixen, best known for her classic memoir Out of Africa and for stories in a fantastic or generally

title: Big Green Toppled First Time, 3125
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15Harvard's aroused football team staved off a Dartmouth passing blitz in the final minutes today and upset the previously undefeated Big Green by 3125 in the Ivy League.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE history of literature shows that every poet has different generations of readers who accept one but not another period in his work... . writer must have the courage to disregard the tastes cf his admirers, to fly in the face of their instinctive desire to force him to go on repeating himself. There is no greater sign of courage in a writer than wake up one morning a pauper, free of everything. In this sense it is more important for an artist lose than to find. The reader is always more conservative than the poet. Boris Pasternak.

title: CARTER SENDS SADAT ASSURANCE ON POLICY
description: CAIRO,Oct. 15President Carter has assured President Anwar elSadat that he will continue his efforts to reconvene the Geneva peace conference and to reach a comprehensive settlement in the Middle East.

title: They'd Rather Eat Tahini
description: THE vegetarian is a culinary conscientious objector. In recent years, the movement has been gaining ground. It has been inspired by religious beliefs, such as Hinduism, that forbid taking life, prompted by humanitarian concern for ecology and the balance of foodstuffs on our crowded planet and encouraged by anxiety over the modern diet of highly processed, additiveladen foods. A preference for natural or organic ingredients is often relevant to vegetarianism.

description: Long Branch used a firstperiod lifety and a fourthquarter goalline stand to edge ,Asbury Park, 20, Both ?lubs had won their first three games. long Branch got its points when the center snap sailed over the head of the Asbury Park punter, Early Ford, and out of the end zone. Fred Jackson was stopped inches short of a touchdown on fourth down by the Long Branch defense late in the final period.

title: FalconsVikings a Sellout
description: ATLANTA, , Oct. 1 (AP)The Atlanta Falcons, off to a fast 31 start this year, report they have sold out their Oct. 30 home game against Minnesota, their earliest home sellout in five years. The National Football League team has sold 60,740 seats for the Minnesota game, and if all ticketholders show up they will set a homeattendance record, a team spokesman said.

title: Getting Down to Business With Economic Planning
description: THE economic future of Nassau and Suffolk Counties cannot be left to chance. Yet that is just what is happening today. History records the death of many communities; most decayed from within. The population and leaders began to believe in luck. They forgot to plan ahead, and they died.

description: The four principal candidates for Mayor denied yesterday that they were avoiding the major issues of the campaign, as charged last week by the leaders of New York City's two million Roman Catholics, Terence Cardinal Cocke and Bishop Francis J. Mugavero.

description: Permit me to express my support for Senator Stephen B. Wiley's recently introduced bill to establish a Department of Cultural Affairs in New Jersey.

description: BEIRUTArabs have generally welcomed the overt return of the Soviet Union to Middle East diplomacy, as exemplified by the issuance of a joint statement with the United States, for the simple reason that they believe when the chips are down the United States will side with Israel against them.

title: Yale Tops Columbia in Soccer

Six minutes into the final half, Charlie Perlwitz, a Yale forward, was ejected for kicking a Lion player. However, it 20;was the Elis who took advantage of the manpower difference. scoring three minutes later to lead, 31.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Did you know that professional party magicians especially like to play old folks homes? Hume Cronyn says they do in D. L. Coburn's The Gin Game, and I believe him. I believe him because he is a magician himself and ought to know. Indeed the only other person who knows more tricks, and takes more during the eveninglong exchange across the card table, is Jessica Tandy, who also happens be the only other person in the play.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball

title: Most Likely to Succeed
description: MENTAL health workers have always found it difficult to define precisely what normality or mental health means. Is the normal person characterized by being adjusted and attuned to those around him, or by the absence of psychological suffering or what? Freud, when queried, by someone attending one of his lectures, about what a normal man should do, gave that wonderful reply: Lieben and Arbeiten, love and work. Nevertheless, Freud's theory of the development normal and abnormal personality was derived from the reconstructed early memories of disturbed and suffering individuals. In the late 1930'swhen the Grant Study, upon which this book is based. was establishedthere was still relatively little information about people who are well and do well.

title: FISHING
description: HUNDREDS of dead and dying striped bass have been reported washing onto beaches and floating into coves and backwaters along the western half of Long Island Sound.

Truman, a likeable professional politician of modest abilities, was suddenly catapulted on April 12, 1945 into the Presidency of the nation that, in Churchill's words, stood at the summit the world.

description: AUTOMOBILES are such serious business nowadays. The Government says they can't be built without more gasoline mileage and less emissions, and the auto companies worry about things like interior space.

title: STATE SAVING ON COST OF AID FOR RETARDED
description: The average cost for the care of retarded patients transferred from the Willowbrook Developmental Center on Staten Island into small placement centers in other communities is $13,208 a year, a New York State study says.

description: MONTREAL, Oct. 15Swooping to their task like sharks at feeding time, the Montreal Canadiens did what almost everyone expected them to do to the New York Rangers tonight at the Forum.
