description: NEWARK

title: Joan Little, Figure In'74 Killing, Flees Prison at Raleigh
description: RALEIGH. N.C.. Oct. 15 (UPI) Joan Little, a black who was acquitted in 1975 of the slaying the previous year of her white jailer, escaped tonight from the' Women's Correctional Center where she was serving a sentence of seven to 10 years for breaking and entering.

title: Funding Culture, High and Low, And Calling it all Art
description: Fending the arts has become a growth industry in the United States, no more so than in New York where 27 million taxpayer dollars were dispensed this year by the New York State Council on the Arts, the most beneficent of 50 state arts councils charged with supporting the major cultural institutions of the state and with overseeing the current nationwide renaissance in community doityourself arts and crafts. A smaller replica of the federallysponsored National Endowment for the Arts, the State Council aids some 1,200 local dance companies, orchestras, historical societies, filmmakers, museums and other purveyors of culture, high and low. (Another $15 million was pumped directly into the state by the National Endowment.)

title: Dr. Franzanne Vreeland Bride of Paul I. Browne
description: Dr. Franzanne Vreeland, who is completing training in hematology at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, and Paul Joseph Browne, a marketing representative with Phone World Inc. in Providence, were married yesterday afternoon at the Warwick, (R.I.) Country Club. Associate Justice John E. Orton 3d of the Rhode Island Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title: Why America Sleeps
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15When the President of the United States and the Big Oil boys start tossing thunderbolts at each 'ther, thats the time to get out of Washington and across the continent as fast as possible.

title: Bit O Blue Harrisburg Pony Victor
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 15Irish Bit O Blue, who is only 3 years olda neophyte in the ringwon the grand pony hunter championship today at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: BanksCash Rich, Capital Poor
description: When a reform bill called the Safe Banking Act was introduced in Congress recently, many bankers reacted with outragenot so much over the substance of the measure as over its name. As seldom before, bankers are extremely sensitive about their image these days, and any implications that banks are not already safe raises their hackles.

title: Management Tunes in on Employee Gripes
description: Of all the dumb rules . . . . How stupid can a company get .. .. What a. lot of doubletalk . . . .

title: Ruth L. Eichling Engaged to Russell Pulliam

The wedding will take place at the First Presbyterian Church in Metuchen, N. J.

title: CRIME
description: When Gregory McDonald's Confess, Fletch came cut last year, there were those of us who wondered if we would ever come across Inspector Flynn of the Boston Police Department again. Flynn stole the show in that book. He was a big, cynical, smart, musicloving, domestic (wife, kids all over the place) cop with a wonderful gift of gab. A commanding, droll figure; in short, one who deserved to be around a,,ain. And so he is, in FLYNN (Avon, $1.95). McDonald, happily, is not going to let a good thing go.

title: Police Expenses a Main Issue in Suffolk Budget Plan
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.It was showandtell time for the Suffolk County Police Department last Tuedsay at the County Legislature's hearings on next year's county budget.

title: Winter Cruises: East, West and Gulf Coasts and Caribbean
description: At one time cruise passengers tended to come from areas near major East and West Coast ports, with comparatively few coming from the interior of the United States. Air travel has changed that, making vacations in distant places available to everyone, even people with limited time.

description: Dorren Mary Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Murphy of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Frederick Bisceglia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Bisceglia of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. James McGuire performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. The bride is an alumna of Resurrec'tion Academy in Rye and the State University College at Cortland. Her Father is president of MurphyJosephson Associates, manufacturer's representatives in the confectionary field in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Number of Hispanic Poor in U.S. Dipped in '76, but Black Poor Increased
description: The number of the nation's poor people with Hispanic backgrounds decreased last year, but the number of black poor rose, according to new Census Bureau samplingsabout which the Federal experts are expressing some cautions.

description: In the football dictionary at South Shore, the word pass is obsolete. The undefeated Vikings crushed Lincoln, 588, yesterday for their fourth Public Schools Athletic League victory, amassing 508 yards on offense, all on the ground.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L.L, Oct. 15Defense dominated the 20th game of Long Island's football rivalry as C. W. Post defeated Hofstra, I80, today.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 15 Closing powerfully in the stretch, Thomas P. Whitney's Hellas II scored an upset victory tonight in the $80,400 Queen Charlotte Handicap for fillies and mares at the Meadowlands.

description: In his New York debut recital Thursday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall, the Yugoslavian guitarist Dusan Bogdanovic proved to be a highly accomplished performer with a flair for dramatic music.

title: From Siberia to 47th Street, De Beers Is King of Diamonds
description: JOHANNESBURG,Oct. 15A visitor, pausing in the sunshine outside the Carlton Hotel, the graceful skyscraper that dominate' this city's skyline, found a stranger tugging at his sleeve. Master, master, the stranger said, unwrapping a crumpled handkerchief to reveal a tiny, sparkling stone. Master, a diamond for your madam?

title: Floods Make Johnstown a City of Survivors
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Oct. 15Despite the three floods in the last 88 years that have ravaged this unpretentious town set between steep hills and two narrow rivers, the people here still call their city floodfree Johnstown.

description: Article  No Title

title: Chief of House Unit On Taxes Counsels Against a Cut Now
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va.,Oct. 15  The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee said here today that he believed it would be a mistake to consider any kind of a quickie tax cut to stimulate the economy, apart from the tax reform proposals expected from the Administration some time this year.

description: Solomon Farb, a certified public accountant with a private practice in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 1056 Fifth Avenue.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Landowner Stirs Up Bedford
description: BEDFORD FOR years the Town of Bedford,a sprawling Northern Westchester community of fouracre zoning, large estates and residents who range from welloff to downright wealthy, has been steadily resisting the onslaught of suburban development in their exurban paradise. Lately the arguments have muted the theme of exclusivity and touched on the broader issues of environmental preservation and the need for open space.

title: Exploring Britain by Whim, Following the B B Route
description: Breakfast on the train to Manchester was colossal: fruit juice, cold cereal, fried eggs, fried kippers, gammon, sausages, broiled tomatoes, toast, excellent marmalade, coffee and tea. That menu was to be repeated, somewhat less sumptuously and minus the. kippers, with monotonous predictability everywhere we drove in England and Wales for the next 14 days.

title: Calcutta! Gets a Chance in Charleston, W. Va.
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 15The police stood by, helpless and wideeyed, in the Municipal Auditorium here last night as a traveling troupe that has been making waves in the provinces performing Oh! Calcutta! stripped, bumped, ground end shouted sexual jibes at Charleston's Mayor and clergy.

title: S.E.C. INQUIRY ON LANCE TURNS TO XBANK OFFICER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The Securities and Exchange Commissionis examining allegations made against former Budget Director Bert Lance by Bill L. Campbell, who is now serving a prison sentence for embezzling almost $1 million from the Calhoun, Ga., bank that Mr. Lance once headed, a source in the commission said today.

title: The Region
description: Teaching in the ,New York City school system is no longer the desired, rewarding, secure job it was even a few years ago. That is the sad but generally acknowledged fact. But this approaches the ridiculous: The Board of Education, which had to lay off 17,000 teachers in the last two years, has been trying to rehire 9,000 of them. The board expected four out of five to accept. Fewer than one out of three did.

title: A Calm Guidry Savors His First Series Start
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15Nervous? Who was nervous? Not Ron Guidry. Not before he pitched against the Los Angeles Dodgers today in the fourth game of the World Series. Bonnie Guidry. will tell you when Ron was nervous. Before a September game against the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium, that's when.

title: A New Body of Law: Judging Of the Judges
description: With judicial behavior being scrutinized as never before, judges are finding it harder to favor friends and relatives with impunity or accept favors themselves. If they act erratically; someone is likely to blow the whistle.

title: Several in Israel Hurt by Bombs
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 (AP)  Two bombs exploded in the Old City, here today, injuring several passersby, and another blew up harmlessly in the coastal town of Netanya, the police reported The Netanya explosion was at the entrance of a soccer field bomb shelter used as a sports club. A group called the Arab Revolutionary Movement claimed responsibility for the Netanya explosion, the police said.

title: New Firehouse In Centereach Biggest in State
description: CENTEREACH, L.I.If my father were alive today, he wouldn't believe it, said Coles Williams, a thirdgeneration volunteer fireman, as he walked through the nearly completed $2.5 million Centereach firehouse.

title: THAI MILITARY CHIEFS CHALLENGE PREMIER

description: WASHINGTON.Oct. 15 (UPI)George Meany said today that he has invited Andrei D. Sakharov and five other Soviet dissidents to the United States in a test Of the Soviet Union's commitment to human rights.

title: A MEMOIR
description: ON the afternoon of Tuesday, Sept. 13, I was in Naples, in the flagdraped auditorium the United States Information Center, meeting with a small group of university professors to talk with them about American poetry. Our informal conversation had scarcely begun when one of them leaned forward and said, Have you heard about Mr. Loveil? He's dead. Did you know him? I caught my breath. Did I know him! Yes, in a hundred phases, the myriad contradictions of one who was both Puritan and satyr, alternately silly and wise, modest and arrogant, tender and mean, generous and indifferent, masterful and helpless, depressed and manic.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Sixty years ago Americans lived in pseudocastles, hung Gothic tapestries on their walls and, in a few cases, collected arms and armor dating to the late Middle Ages.

description: MIAMI, Oct. 15The sign outside the Jet, locker room is pasted over a coffeeurnsized container that is filled with Gatorade.

But when 43yearold Allan Anderson returned to his elementary school, the Milton School here, he not only found the place the same as in his recollectionshe was there for the specific purpose of revamping it.

title: NEW REGIME IN INDIA TERMED VULNERABLE

title: Taking the Fears Out of Phobias
description: WHITE PLAINS WHAT are our phobias? asked Jean Esterbrook. I will tell you mine.I have had a fear of movement, a fear of walking without support. I have spent the last 10 years of my life confined to a wheelchair. Now, with the help of this group, I am walking again.

title: Deadline Nears For 87 Hostages On Hijacked Jet

description: EAST BERLIN. Oct. 15 (Reuters)East Germany yesterday accused the Western press, particularly In West Germany, of trying to make political capital out of clashes between youths and police officers at a rock concert in East Berlin last week.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homes have screenedin porches or partly enclosed sunrooms along the side or back of the house teat are unheated, and thus unused, during the winter. Since these porches only have screens to enclose them, winddriven rain and snow accumulates on the inside, and anything stored out there takes a beating from the weather.

description: After opening its season at the City Center55th Street Theater with its new production of the fullevening Romeo and Juliet, the Joffrey Ballet got down to the normal business of repertory Friday night with a program made up primaiily of works by its principal choreographer, Gerald Arpino. These included a New York premiere, Touch Me, a solo for Chrstian Holder first danced in June of this year in San Francisco.

title: GARDENING
description: SUCCESS stories are good to tell. One that was the talk of Cos Cob last summer was the display of zinnias in the shopping area. From the middle of June to just a week ago, the flowers were a parade of colors. Their huge petals in shades of yellow, orange, red, rose and white stood high above a walllike white picket fence of the Cos Cob branch of the State National Bank of Connecticut.

title: Dubai's Airport Is Strangely Quiet
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Sunday, Oct. 16There is a strange atmosphere of normality about this modern airport where a hijacked Lufthansa plane stands, but the hijackers appear to be in deadly earnest.

title: Paying Taxes by Sweat of Brow
description: AT A TIME of increasing financial burdens to taxpayers, the City of Hartford has set forth an innovative program to help qualified residents meet their tax obligations. In response to high unemployment and an equally high rate of inflation, the city established the InKind Services Program, whereby unemployed and underemployed residents can work off a portion (in some cases nearly all) of their property tax bills. Real estate and motor vehicle levies are included.

title: After 30 Years, a Reaction
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 14 (AP)After receiving obscene phone calls for the last 30 years, a local woman has finally made a formal complaint because the calls were getting too obscene, the police said. They said the woman. whose name was withheld, told them today that the man had been rather nice about it until recently, when the calls began getting more and more obscene.

After another moment of reflection, Andrew's son, Jamie, a solid artist in his own right, might come to mind

title: Wheelchair Sports: A Will to Win
description: EAST ORANGE IDID that first 440 in 1:28,"t said Garyat that first displeased with himself for letting mile steal away his breath. That's a good pace if I can keep it up. That could be a subsixminute mile, and a subsixminute mile is getting close to the national record.

title: Economics by Any Other Name
description: What is economics? Economists have difficulty in providing a satisfactory short definition of their subject. Hundreds exist, and every textbook author takes a crack at providing his own.

title: Colombia: Coffee Bonanza Boomerangs
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaWhat's good for the coffee market is good for Colombiaor so it would seem. In fact, as world coffee prices have soared to the highest levels in history, and Colombia has been grinding out hundreds a millions of dollars in new coffee wealth, the nation has been wracked by unprecedented inflation.

title: Many Federal Programs Are Based on Special Help to Minorities
description: WASHINGTONThe arguments before the United States Supreme Court last week dealt primarily with university admissions, specifically, with whether the University of California at Davis was within its rights when it denied Allan Bakke, a white man, a place in its medical school and accepted a number of blacks, Hispanic and AsianAmericans under a special program for disadvantaged minority students.

title: Teachers Continue Walkout as Board Rejects Proposal
description: SHRUB OAK, N.Y., Oct. 15The Lakeland School Board's rejection yesterday of a state mediator's proposal recommending a 15 percent wage increase is expected to send into its seventh week the teachers strike affecting nine schools in this northern Westchester County community.

title: House Expense Data Lists Rented Tuxedo
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)The first public accounting of a $2,000ayear expense account given members of the House shows that concert tickets, bar association dues, car insurance and even a rented tuxedo were paid for with tax money.

title: NEW WEEKLY IS PUBLISHED FOLLOWING PANAX FUROR
description: MAROUETTE, Mich., Oct. 15The Marquette Sunday Sun, a weekly tabloid newspaper, began publication this week as a result of a furor over the resignation in June of the editor of The Marquette Mining Journal and the simultaneous dismissal of the editor of the neighboring Excanaba Daily News.

title: Business Confidence: In Carter, in Business
description: Despite his assault on the oil industry, President Carter has tried diligently to boost the confidence of businessmen in his Administration. He pledged to balance the Federal budgeta conservative doctrine not heard in Keynesian Washington for decades. He dropped his plan for a $50 tax rebate lest the deficit grow. He ruled out wageprice controls. And he defied his friends in organized labor on common situs picketing and the minimum wage.

title: Rifle in Missouri Sniper Slaying Is Traced to ExOwner in Texas
description: RICHMOND HEIGHTS, Mo.,Oct. 15 (AP)Investigators have traced the rifle used in the sniper slaying of a Chesterfield, Mo.. man outside a Jewish synagogue to its former owner in Irving, Tex.

title: Miss Barzelay Is the Fiancee Of K. A. Stelson

title: Pearson of Kansas Quitting Senate
description: WASHINGTON,Oct. 15 (AP)Senator James B. Pearson, Republican of Kansas, announced today that he would not seek reelection next year. The 57yearold Mr. Pearson cited my own deep desire to return to Kansas and to resume private life as the deciding factors in his decision. He is ending his 17th year in the Senate.

title: Thousands Mourn Bing Crosby At Westminster Cathedral Rites
description: LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP)An estimated 2,000 people were at Westminster Cathedral today for a memorial mass for Bing Crosby, the entertainer who died Friday in Spain.

title: THE TWO MONGOLIAS ARE BITTER ENEMIES

description: The American steel industry is hurting: Sales are sluggish, profits are low. The industry has a painless solution for its problemspainless, that is, for its stockholders. description: The International String Quartet, which made its New York debut Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a threeyearold ensemble composed of graduates of Indiana University at Bloomington, where it is quartetinresidence.

title: CUOMO IS SWITCHING CAMPAIGN STRATEGY
description: Moving into the intensive, final three weeks of the long mayoral campaign, Edward I. Koch and Mario M. Cuomo have switched roles from those they held at the time of the Democratic mayoral primarya switch that has apparently produced a shift in the strategy of Mr. Cuomo but not of Mr. Koch.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Fame is hollow and fame is fleeting, we are told from childhood, but in at least one case it has also run out of cash. There are no longer any funds to maintain the Hall of Farme  the Stanford White colonnade containing the busts of great menon the former Bronx campus of New York University. now occupied by CUNY. The future is dubious for 97 distinguished Americans with names like Audubon, Emerson, Thoreau, Whitman, Bryant and Lincoln, immortalized by some equally illustrious American sculptors, including Augustus St. Gaudens, Malvina. Hoffman and Daniel Chester French. The marble likenesses fill a 520footlong, semicircular granite arcade built in 1901 atop a high cliff with a notable view at the western edge of the campus.

title: Israelis Fire Into Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Israeli artillery fired into southern Lebanon last week for the first time since the Sept. 26 casefire agreement, Israeli Defense Ministry sources said today. The sources said the Israelis had fired across the frontier after shells, apparently coming from Palestinian strongholds, fell close to the IsraeliLebanese border.

title: Proposal in Senate Could Forestall Some Cutbacks in Amtrak Service

But New Jersey still stands to lose some important services Involving a trimming of the New YorkPhiladelphia clocker trains, which make several stops in the state.

title: South Africa, Despite Promises, Still Enforces Petty Discrimination

The Rhodesian, smiling all the way, had outrun some of the country's best white distance runners.

Or, one should say, David Belasco's ideas, for the libretto was substantially derived from his smash hit of the early 1900's, The Girl of the Golden West.

title: Lagging Capital Spending And Investment Incentives
description: Business spending on new plant and equipment was dragging along at low rate, in real terms, even before President Carter made his vitriolic attack on the oil industry, which he has accused of trying to profiteer from the energy crisis. Mr. Carter's blast at oil producersthe sharpest by any President since John F. Kennedy attacked steel producers for raising prices in 1962, and one that was echoed yesterday by Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger has aroused fears that what was left of business confidence will now be shattered, and that capital spending by business will go into a tailspin.

title: New York City Bar Panel Scores State Group on Ads
description: The executive committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, in a report sharply critical of proposals of the State Bar Association and the American Bar Association, has recommended that lawyers be allowed to advertise as long as the information is not false, misleading or deceptive.

title: Esposito Leads Rangers 42 Defeat of Islanders
description: In a rousing contest that was missing the usual acerbic detractions, the New York Rangers defeated the Islanders, 42, by borrowing a little discipline and a little grit from their Patrick Division rivals. Never trailing, the Rangers jumped to a 20 lead in the first period, but the Islanders kept them uncomfortable throughout the night and nearly tied the game in a furious final few minutes. Walt Tkaczuk sealed the Ranger victory with an emptynet goal.

title: Free as the Wind
description: Most birds migrate in silence, but not wild geese. Whether you are walking down a city street, standing in a suburban backyard or working in a rural woodlot, you know when the geese fly over. First you hear the distant gabble, a faint clamor that seems to echo from the whole sky. Then you see them, flying high, marking a V almost like a dotted pencil line. You listen and watch, and the flight is so high it seems almost leisurely. If is a close V, in firm formation, it probably is Canada geese. If it is a looser V, rippling and waving, it is more likely the less common snow geese. Whichever, the flock's gabbling voice is like the restless voice of autumn, and the flight never wavers. On and on, over the hills and the towns and the city itself, to the far horizon, and still beyond, southward. And only that restless echo; faint and haunting, remains.

title: 1 Unbeaten, Untied Major Teams Dwindle From 10 to 4
description: At least one major college team has gone through the regular season undefeated and untied during each of the last 40 years. The 1927 and 1936 seasons were the only ones since the turn of the century when there was not one team with a perfect record. Three teamsPittsburgh, Maryland and Rutgersmade it through the 1976 regular season undefeated and untied. They were the only ones to survive from a group of eight major teams that reached the midway point of last season with perfect records.

Last winter's icy blasts convinced a lot of fencesitters that fur coats made sense, and with another cold season predicted resistance is toppling fast. Early sales point to a big year for men's fur coats.

description: BRISBANE, Australia, Oct. 16 (UPI)Vitas Gerulaitis captured the opening tournament of the Australian grass tennis circuit today. The New Yorker beat Tony Roche in the singles final, 67, 61, 61, 75, then combined with Billy Scanlon to win the doubles in the $50,000 South Pacific. They defeated the veterans Mal Anderson and Ken Rosewall, 76, 64.

But there have been a few slight changes in the direction, and the Metropolitan calls this a revised production.

title: Trial Opening Today Could Decide If Indians Own Land on Cape Cod
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16A trial that will determine whether the Wampanoag Indians of Cape Cod are a legally constituted tribe is to begin here tomorrow in Federal District Court. Hinging on the outcome will be the Indians right to second trial to determine how much of the town of Mashpee, if any, they are entitled to by law.

They went with Young & Rubicam.

title: BYRNE IS ATTEMPTING A POPULIST VICTORY
description: If Governor Byrne is to overtake State Senator Raymond H. Bateman in the closing weeks of the New Jersey governorship race, he will have to do it without the traditionally strong support of the powerful Hudson and Essex County organizations so essential to Democratic candidates.

title: 'Equus': Film of a Different Color
description: When "Equus," Peter Shaffer's psychological mystery play, was originally staged on Broadway, I was inclined to credit its great emotional impact to the stunning performances by Anthony Hopkins and Peter Firth and to the spectacular, highly stylized theatrical effects devised by Mr. Shaffer and John Dexter, who directed the production. On stage, "Equus" was a breathtaking experience of light, sound, performance and text, more or less, I thought, in that order of importance. Later, however, when I saw other actors take over the leads, the production suffered hardly at all.Now, after seeing Sidney Lumet's comparatively realistic film version, it's possible to appreciate Mr. Shaffer's text for what it isan extraordinarily skillful, passionate inquiry into the entire Freudian methodwithout being distracted by dazzling theatricality.My problem, though, doctor, is that as much as I respect Mr. Shaffer's script (and his screenplay), I like being distracted by dazzling theatricality. Indeed, I prefer it.This new "Equus," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East, is probably about as good as one can get on film. It represents intelligent decisions. It's beautifully, sometimes almost grandly acted, by Richard Burton as the troubled psychiatrist attempting to bring back to sanity a young man who, in a fit of furious passion, has blinded six horses in a riding stable where he worked.Peter Firth repeats his stage role as the boy, with Joan Plowright as his mother, Colin Blakely as his dad, Eileen Atkins as the judge who brings the boy to the doctor's care and Jenny Agutter as the pretty girl who indirectly triggers his furious breakdown. There's not a thoughtless or uninteresting performance in the film.Mr. Lumet manages to suggest some of the play's theatricality in the up-tempoed pacing of these performances and by retaining the doctor's agonizing monologues as speeches spoken directly to the camera. Yet something is missingspecifically, our need to use our imaginations to fill in the visual and emotional gaps in the stories of Dr. Martin Dysart, the psychiatrist, and Alan Strang, his patient.Although Mr. Shaffer's screenplay does not differ in any marked way from the play, the film seems to exclude us by doing all the work for us. It shows and tells us everything there is to know about the doctor and his patient. In great plays, what happens offstage demands our attention as much as anything that happens on.In Mr. Lumet's "Equus," there's no such thing as an off-screen space, no privacy that we can invade, in effect, at our own risk. Everything mentioned in the play's text, or recalled through a mimed, re-created moment, happens front and center, on the screen. The movie exhausts us with information. We see the unhappily married doctor with his dentist wife, though everything we have to know about her and their relationship is carefully evoked in dialogue or monologues. The images are redundant.We are shown young Alan's bedroom at home, a sacred place where he created his private religion devoted to the worship of Equus, the vengeful, demanding horse-god. When Alan takes off on his clandestine midnight rideshis psychosexual communion riteswe watch a naked young man riding a real horse bareback through a real countryside. We are as likely to worry about his catching pneumonia as to wonder about his emotional state.What once was poetic and mysterious becomes, when seen in this literal detail, banal, anticlimactic.Yet this may well seem like hairsplitting to anyone seeing "Equus" for the first time, for, behind all of this realistic scenery, the play remains intact, and it's a good one. It's the most interesting, most serious appraisal of psychiatry that we've ever had in a commercial filman appraisal that probably has infuriated quite as many psychiatrists as it has pleased. It's the terrible suspicion of Mr. Shaffer's Dr. Dysart that, by removing Alan Strang's demons, by returning him to "normal" life, he has removed the boy's passion forever, emotionally lobotomized him.Though the film is held together by the mystery of Alan Strang's behavior, the unraveling of which provides the narrative line, it's Mr. Burton's performance as the psychiatrist that dominates the movie, whether or not you agree with his fears that he cuts from his patients "their portions of individuality." This is the best Burton performance since "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" He receives excellent support, especially from Mr. Firth, but the film, which is otherwise in the siege of commonplace realism, becomes bigger than life in the presence of this self-mocking, troubled, still-searching miracle-worker.

description: The Consolidated Edison Company's lower winter rates went into effect yesterday and will reduce the average New York City consumer's utility bill by 7.9 percent, the company announced.

title: Party Conventions, BritishStyle: Issues Instead of Bands and Balloons
description: LONDON, Oct. 16The first thing that strikes an American political re porter, watching his first British party conferences after a dozen Presidential nominating conventions, is the absence of noise. The delegates actually listen to the speeches.

title: Five Nordic Nations Are Achieving Wider U.N. Influence as a Bloc
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16Espousing a belief that one vigorous voice can he more effective than five frail ones, the membership of the Nordic CouncilDenmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden  are working as a bloc at the United Nations and exerting unusual collective influence on a variety of issues such as human rights and world peace.

title: 13 Held in Racial Clash in London
description: LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuters)Thirteen persons were arrested today when fighting broke out as an antidiscrimination march led by a West Indian steel band moved through London's East End, where an increasing number of nonwhite immigrants are settling. Groups of counterdemonstrators shouted abuse as the 2,500 marchers, black and white, paraded through the streets.

title: Steel WoesHow Acute?
description: With mounting layoffs providing a dramatic backdrop, the steel industry's difficulties these days are being characterized as a crisis. But the steelmakers problems are clearly chronic, and they have been present to some degree for three decades. Furthermore, despite intimations of disaster, most experts agree that the industry is far from collapse. Orders from customers seem to be pick ing up, and some say the steel industry is likely to emerge from its present depressed state not only intact, but perhaps even stronger because of firings, layoffs and plant closings.

description: WASHINGTONThe debate about American energy policy intensifies in bitterness. But at its heart is a reality that no one can dispute: The United States has become, and is still becoming, even more dependent on imported oil.

title: A Spokesman for Toyota Foresees Leveling Off of 1978 Import Sales
description: CHICAGO  Sales of foreign cars in the United States, which skyrocketed for most of the year, are expected to moderate next year, according to officials of Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Toyota is by far the topselling foreign car in the United States. Imports as a group have accounted for about one in every five cars sold in the nation this year.

title: Company Is Planning to Restore Rail Line Through Adirondacks
description: BEAVER RIVER, N.Y.The white Chevrolet carryall trunk, which had been clattering along at 30 miles an hour on auxiliary steel wheels over the rusted tracks of Penn Central's abandoned Adirondack division, suddenly came to a stop.

title: Brooklyn Voters, Following Tradition, Seem Likely to Favor Democrats Again
description: According to an old Brooklyn tradition, passed from one generation of voters to the next, pulling the voting machine lever next to the name of a Republican candidate has been the political equivalent of blasphemy. With party regularity the cardinal rule, Democratic victories have been the inevitable result.

title: L. ETHAN ELLIS, AT 79; EXRUTGERS PROFESSOR
description: L. Ethan Ellis, former chairman of the department of history and Voorhees Professor of History at Rutgers University, died Friday at John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Edison, N.J. He was 79 years old and lived in Piscataway. N.J.

description: The New York Philharmonic had a hostess for the first time at its Young People's Concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday afternoon. She was Beverly Sills, the opera soprano, who joined the conductor, Erich Leinsdorf, in discussing a program called Music and Your Emotions.

title: Irwin Triumphs by 2 Shots For Third 77 Tour Victory
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 16 (UPI)Hale Irwin shot a 67 today for a 14underpar total of 266 and posted his third protour victory of the year in the $150,000 Texas open golf tournament. He won by two strokes, with Miller Barber second on 66268.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 16 (UPI)A fire in a transmission line leading to an electric generating plant knocked out power here tonight, leaving a million people without electricity.

title: Donuts to Be Served By Carl Ally's Shop
description: Carl Ally Inc. has picked up its fourth new account since May, Dunkin Donuts of America. The Randolph, Mass., company, which has over 900 mostly franchised locations, is spending $2.7 million on national advertising this year and says it expects to increase the budget substantially in 1978.

title: Market Place
description: The current bear market has pounded the Dow Jones industrial average, erasing 132 points, or 13.6 percent, from that popular stock market indicator in the 12 months since Sept. 30, 1976.

title: EDWARD P. WINTERS
description: Edward P. Winters, a former district manager of the New York Telephone Company in Flushing, Queens, died Saturday at Flushing Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Flushing House on Bowne Street. Mr. Winters graduated from LaSalle Academy and Manhattan College. He leaves two daughters, Ann Beecher and Ann Shershin, and five grandchildren.

title: News Summary
Mauceri Conducts Mefistofele
description: Saturday night's performance of Mefistofele at the City Opera had a new conductor, John Mauceri, who was making his debut with the company. A former assistant to Leonard Bernstein, Mr. Mauceri is not exactly a stranger to New York opera, having conducted Fidelio at the Metropolitan two seasons ago.

title: Police Press Search For Missing Woman
description: Efforts to find 77yearold Sarah Brownlie, who disappeared Oct. 7 while taking a walk near her home in North Salem, continued yesterday, with a search of the immediate area in Westchested County by dogs trained to detect the scent of any human in a specific sector of woods that has been cleared of people.

title: HARRY S. REICHENSTEIN, EXNEWARK CITY CLERK
description: Harry S. Reichenstein, the City Clerk of Newark for 40 years and founder of the International Municipal Clerks Association, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Florida after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Tagliavini, Displaying Old Ardor At 64, Sings to Delighted Throng
description: Except for a few celebrated cases such as Gigli, Schipa, Peerce and Roswange, tenors have not been noted for singing well in public in advanced years. Ferruccio Tagliavini, who made himself a popular figure at the Metropolitan Opera from 1947 to 1954, is now 64 years old and still making his admirers happy. The chubby Italian tenor returned for his second New York recital in as many years yesterday, serving up French, Italian, Spanish and Neapolitan songs for an appreciative audience at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Elizabeth Sheehan Takes Medal Class
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16The name was new. but the story was old in the national championships of the Medal Class equestrian competition today at the Pennsyvania National Horse Show.

title: Bill Gives New York WelfarePenalty Forgiveness
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Senate adopted a Houseapproved plan on welfare payments late today that includes a forgiveness provision saving New York City from an estimated $666 million in possible penalties for noncompliance with Federal regulations over the past eight and onehalf years. The vote was 800.

title: Sports Columnist Accuses Cosell of Assaulting Him
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (UPI)A sports columnist for The Philadlephia Daily News, Stan Hochman, today accused Howard Cosell of having assaulted him aboard an airplane preparing to leave Los Angeles for New York after yesterday's World Series game.

title: Confusion Marking Veterans Day to End In '78 Changeover
description: There has been confusion in the United States for years over precisely when the nation's 30 million former servicemen should be honoed with a day set aside fo them, but 1977 will be the last year in which the date of Veterans Day will vary from state to state and employer to employer.

title: Amid Turmoil of Series, Holtzman Sits and Sits
description: Fantasy: A sudden siege of injuries strikes the Yankee pitching staff before tomorrow night's seventh game of the World Series and Manager Billy Martin has no alternative. He must start Ken Holtzman. The heretofore invisible Yankee sheds that invisibility, dons his SuperYankee costume, shuts out the Dodgers and hits a home run that wins the game and the Series.

title: F.D.A.ORDERS WARNING ON ESTROGEN INTAKE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The Food and Drug Administration will require, beginning tomorrow, that pharmaceutical manufacturers provide a warning to women who receive estrogen prescriptions that they run increased risks of cancer and gall bladder disease.

title: Spanish Communist's Role: Suarez's Ally and a Model of Moderation
description: MADRID, Oct. 17Short of a majority in Parliament and struggling with contentious economic issues, Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez has discovered in the last four months that his centerright Government has an unusual ally: Santiago

title: Joyous Dances by Barbara Roan
description: Barbara Roan's October Parade explodes upon New York with exuberant regularity each autumn, combining the elements of a smalltown celebration with the authority of a vanguard theatrical sensibility. This year she has again assembled a highly diverse and enjoyable series of incidents that unfurl in long lines of movement, and she presented them at the American Theater Laboratory on Sunday.

title: An Expert BurglaryPrevention Service: All Free but Few Takers
description: The police say they are baffled over why most New Yorkers are not taking advantage of a service they have offered free for more than six yearssomething the police feel can sharply reduce crime rates, especially for burglary, the most prevalent crime in the city.

title: A Black Reports His South African Partner Was on List From U.S.Hired Companies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17A black entrepreneur, who was bidding for a Federal contract for railroad ties, selected a white South African partner from a list of approved experts supplied by companies hired by the Department of Transportation, Government sources said today.

title: CAL HUBBARD, 76; TWOSPORT CAREER
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 17 (AP)Cal Hubbard, the only man elected to both the professional baseball and football halls of fame, died here today of cancer. He was 76 years old.

title: Musical Hot Grog Is Warm Cider
description: Hot Grog is not hot, and grog suggests a lot more firepower than it possesses. It alternates between insipid and mildly refreshing, like cider on a warm day. About an inch of cider.

description: President Carter has yet to present his tax reform package to Congress. but already the preliminary version which has leaked out widely  is raising questions.

description: HOUSTON, Oct. 17On the day prior to his appearance here before the annual convention of the American Bankers Asseciation, more bankers have tried to put some distance between themselves and the banking activities of Bert Lance, who recently resigned as President Carter's budeet director.

title: Earnings Up Slightly for 2 Banks
description: Two of New Yorks largest bank holding companies reported slightly higher earnings for the third quarter compared with a year ago.

title: CBS Ousts 2 Top TV Executives; Splits Up Entertainment and Sports
description: In an extensive management shakeup. CBS yesterday removed John A. Schneider as president of the broadcast group and Robert J. Wussler as president of the television network. Both have been given new positions.

title: Bears Stillwell Sidelined
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (AP)Roger Stillwell, a defensive tackle with the Chicago Bears, underwent surgery on his left knee today and will be out of action indefinitely' Stillwell's knee was injured yesterday as the Bears lost, 2216, in overtime to the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Steelworkers: Troubled Union
description: The United Steelworkers of America is a union under siege.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two shots were fired at a chauffeurdriven Cadillac that was en route to pick up a commissioner of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Harold L. Fisher, and take him to work, the police said. The driver, Paul Colello, was unhurt, but the car's left rear window was shattered.

title: Voluntary Reorganization Sought by Parr Meadows
description: The Parr Meadows race track filed for a voluntary reorganization under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Laws yesterday.

title: Reckless Insurance for Wreckless Drivers
description: The insurancewise people in Massachusetts who first adopted the concept of nofault in automobile policies are stirring again. They are taking a close look at the categories of riskiness that insurance companies have devised for drivers and are finding them to be often arbitrary, bizarre and unfair.

title: ABC Expanding Pro Football Coverage
description: The National Football League and ABC issued a joint announcement yesterday, concerning an agreement that will mean more pro football on weekday nights in television primetime hours.

title: Jersey Assembly Votes to Require Some on Welfare to Work for Aid
description: TRENTON. Oct. 17The State Assembly today approved a measure to require ablebodied New Jerseyans on welfare who do not have dependent children to work about 48 hours a month cleaning streets or performing other public services to qualify for continued assistance. About 16,000 adults would be affected.

title: PRICES OF GOLD SOAR; DOLLAR DROPS AGAIN
description: The price of gold soared above $160 an ounce for the first time in more than two years yesterday in a day of fastpaced foreignexchange trading that saw further declines by the dollar abroad but some improvement by the close of the New York market, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ku Klux Klan Plans Border Patrol To Help Fight Illegal Alien Problem
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 17 (AP)The national director of the Ku Klux Klan says that Klan members plan a border patrol to help curb the illegal alien problem.

title: New Panel Pushes Canal Treaties
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 17 (AP)President Carter, rallying allies today in his fight for ratification of the Panama Canal treaties, told a new committee laden with veterans from past diplomatic battles that the American people did not know the facts about the accords.a

description: TRENTON, Oct. 17The State Assembly today approved a measure to require ablebodied New Jerseyans on welfare who do not have dependent children to work about 48 hours a month cleaning streets or performing other public services to qualify for continued assistance. About 16.000 adults would be affected.

title: AMERICAN MOTORS RAISES PRICES 2.7% ON 78 CARS
description: DETROIT, Oct 17 (AP)The American Motors Corporation said today that it had raised suggested retail prices on 1978 models an average of 2.7 percent and was joining the move to discounts on the West Coast.

title: Steelers Post 2014 Victory Over Bengals
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17This season of woe for the Cincinnati Bengals continued here tonight as the team expected by many to wind up in the Super Bowl lost its third game of the season and also its quarterback, Ken Anderson. The Pittsburgh Steelers were the victors by a score of 2014 and their wounded quarterback, Terry Bradshaw, got through the game intact with plastic cast protecting his fractured left wrist.

title: 22 SEIZED IN BOSTON IN ARSON CONSPIRACY
description: BOSTON, Oct. 17In raids that started before dawn today, the state police arrested 22 state and city arson officials, public adjusters lawyers and businessmen after a fourmonth investigation of what officials called the largest arson ring in the nation's history.

title: Missing Body Is Impeding Inquiry Into Disappearance of Gem Dealer
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 17Puerto Rican authorities, embarrassed by their failuro to locate the grave of a murder victim believed to be a missing New York diamond dealer, pressed their search of morgue and cemetery records here today, but were unable to find the charred remains.

title: U.S.Woman Officiates,Upsets Church of England.
description: LONDON, Oct. 17An American Episcopal priest has defied the Church of England by becoming the first woman to administer holy communion at a public service in Britain.

title: State Income Tax Is a Key Issue In 14th and 15th District Contests
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 17The 14th and 15th Legislative Districts, which occupy the western half of the state from the New York State border in the north to this community, are represented in part by the only three Republicans who voted for the final version of the state income tax passed last year.

title: U.S. May Levy First River Fees
description: ST. LOUIS  A stubborn dispute over replacing an obsolete set of locks near here  the busiest locks and the biggest bottleneck on the entire Mississippi  is breaching one of the oldest precepts in American commerce, the free use of the inland waterways.

title: Horsey Set Takes Movie Stars in Stride
description: HAMILTON, Mass.The horse people met the movie people over the weekend in this blueblood Boston suburb, and the only fawning that occurred was dune over the horses.

title: Leval Is to Succeed Judge Bonsai
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The White House announced today that President Carter would nominate Pierre M. Leval of New York City to be a Judge in the Federal District Court of Manhattan to succeed Dudley B. Bonsai, who has retired. Mr. Leval, 41 years old of New York City, got his undergraduate degree from Harvard in 1959 and law degree from Harvard Law school in 1963. From 1964 to 1968, he was assistant United States attorney for the Southern District. From 1969 to 1975, he was in private law practice in New York, and since 1975 he has been an assistant district attorney for New'York county.

title: NEW YORK FAILS IN BID TO BLOCK PARKING BAN
description: WASHINGTON,Oct. 17The Supreme Court rejected today New York City's reAuest that the Court overturn a fouryearold air pollution plan that could drastically restrict automobile traffic on Manhattan.

title: Stocking Stuffer in Lead For Hunter Crown

title: Drug Companies Accused of Lagging In Research to Curb Rare Diseases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)The widow of Woody Guthrie, the folk singer, and other members of a commission on Huntington's disease complained today that pharmaceutical companies did very little research on illnesses that affect small numbers of people.

description: Treasury bills climbed to their highest levels in more than two years yesterday amid signs that individual savers were switching their funds into these higher yielding shortterm securities.

description: Joseph Manetta, who performed in vaudeville under the stage name Joe Mandel, died Saturday at Dover (N.J.) General Hospial. He was 79 years old and lived in Lake Hopatcong, N.J.

title: David Klee, at 70; Investment Banker And Philanthropist
description: David Klee, an investment banker and husband of Anne Baxter, the actress, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital in New York after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 50 East 77th Street.

title: Sir Michael Balcon, 81, Producer Of Ealing Comedies Films, Dies
description: HARTFIELD, England, Oct. 17 (UPI)Sir Michael Balcon, producer of dozens of British films, including The 39 Steps, Goodbye, Mr. Chips and Tom Jones, died yesterday at his country home. He was 81 years old,

title: Martin and Lasorda Facing Tasks Very Different Yet Much the Same
description: While secondguessing the manager Is the accepted mode in spectator sports, few fans bother to try to read the manager's mind before something happens. And yet it may be more valid to speculate on what Billy Martin and Tommy Lasorda are thinking on the eve of the sixth game of the World Series than to assert what they should have thought after the result is known.

title: HOUSE, 37523, VOTES AN 18MONTH DELAY INBARRING SACCHARIN

title: Joe McCarthy in Hospital
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Joe McCarthy, the former New York Yankee Hall of Fame manager, was listed in satisfactory condition today after being hospitalized over the weekend at Millard Fillmore Hospital. A hospital spokesman said McCarthy, who is 90 years old, was suffering from a touch of pneumonia.

title: From Song To Sound
description: The grieving for Elvis Presley and the commercial exploitation of his death were still not ended when we heard of Bing Crosby's death the other day. Here is a generational puzzle. Those of an age to mourn Elvis must marvel that their elders could really have cared about Bing, just as the Crosby generation a few weeks ago wondered what all the todo was about when Elvis died.

title: Advertising
description: In some quarters there is the feeling that women's sports is the hottest topic since the Frisbee. Those quarters happen to be the headquarters of WomenSports magazine, which hasn't been doing very well since its first monthly issue was published in June 1974.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 17The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether prisons can discipline inmates by isolating them for indefinite periods without violating the constitutional ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

title: Lottery Winners Sought
description: Officials of the New Jersey lottery are looking for the holders of three weekly Jersey Jackpot tickets worth at least $10,000 each.

title: Notes on People
description: Sir Edmund Hillary, who suffered highaltitude sickness last week and was taken by helicopter to a military hospital, checked out yesterday to return to his 17,000foothigh camp in the Himalayas. A spokesman at the hospital at Bareilly, India, indicated that the 58yearold mountaineer wished to be on hand for the last phase of his expedition's attempt to climb Nar Parbat, the mountain on which he became ill. He apparently does not intend to join in the actual ascent, however. Sir Edmund, who with a sherpa guide conquered Mount Everest in 1953, came back to India as leader of an expedition up the Ganges from its mouth on the Bay of Bengal. He had hoped to trace the Ganges to its source in the Himalayas by jet boat, but was forced to move overland to Nar Parbat.

description: Fall Storm Lashes City

title: Figueroa Gives Yanks New Feud as They Go for Title Tonight
description: From summery Los Angeles to wintry New York, the 74th World Series switched coasts under extraordinary security yesterday as the Yankees once more tried to strike the coup de grace at the durable Dodgers.

title: News Agencies' Cooperation Sought
description: News agency reports of the landing of an aircraft carrying a West German commando squad yesterday at the Mogadishu airport, reportedly picked up by Israeli monitoring of radio exchanges with the control tower, were followed quickly by a request from the West German Government that the news be withheld lest it jeopardize the hostages' safety.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY,OCTOBER 18, 1977

title: Miss Somach Retains Touch 30 Years Later
description: Beverly Somach celebrated the 30th anniversary of her New York concert debut Sunday night in Alice Tully Hall. Actually, the violinist has been something of a stranger to the local concert scene since she retired to raise a family in 1963, and only recently has resumed her career on a regular basis.

title: Steinbrenner Plans to Keep Jackson With Yankees in'78
description: Reggie Jackson will be with the New York Yankees next season, George Steinbrenner said yesterday. He also said he would leave the decision to keep or dismiss Manager Billy Martin up to Gabe Paul, the club president.

title: Kenya Center Uncovering Secrets of Insect Life
description: NAIROBI, KenyaAmong the towering eucalyptus trees on the Masonga Wai River here stands one of the most remarkable, if least known, scientific institutions in the world: a complex of laboratories where more than 30 researchers from 17 countries are discovering the innermost secrets of the lives of insects. and their close allies.

title: World's Shipping Surplus Growing
description: LONDON, Oct. 17 (UPI)The world's shipping surplus is growing, according to figures published today by the General Council of British Shipping. The figures showed that 43.2 million tons of world merchant shipping were laid up at the end of August.

title: City Opera to State Plans for Spring Run
description: Julius Rudel, director of the New York City Opera, is planning to announce tonight that enough funds have been raised to make it feasible to proceed with the company's spring season. The announcement will be made during an intermisson of the live telecast on PBS of Massenet's Manon from the New York State Theater.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONIrving The beloved husband of Lilyan. Devoted father of Phyllis Katz Susan Levitt and Mi chael R. Dear brother and cherished grandfather. Services Tuesday 10AM at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel, Long Beach Road at Greystone, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Violence in Colombia Raises Specter of New Unrest
description: BOGOTA, ColombiaBanditry, corruption, political violence and social discontent are woven into the fabric of Colombia, a democracy that has been under state of siege for most of the last 30 years.

title: The Yankees MessedUp Heads
description: Shortly after the Yankees lost Sunday's fifth World Series game, Billy Martin, their manager with the clenched face, stopped by Lou Piniella's locker for a brief and private conversation. As the manager departed, the left fielder was heard to tell him, My head's all messed up. And he had played that way. During the first four games, Lou Piniella had been the Yankees leading hitter with a 400 average and he had robbed Ron Cey of a home run with a leaping catch above the leftfield fence. But on Sunday he went hitless and misplayed a catchable drive by Davey Lopes that went for a leadoff triple in the Dodgers 104 triumph. Lou Piniella's head had been messed up before the game by the Yankees newest tempests1, the various versions of what really happened in a July meeting that George Steinbrenner, the principal owner, had in Milwaukee with Lou Piniella and Thurman Munson, two of his principal players, regarding the future of Billy Martin, the principal manager; 2, the alleged threat by Reggie Jackson in midseason that he would not return to the Yankees next year if Billy Martin remained as manager.

title: Ballet: Tharp and Ashton on View at the Joffrey
description: Superficially, at least; it would be difficult to envisage two choreographers more different from each other than Sir Frederick Ashton and Twyla Tharp. If Sir Frederick is, as he is nowadays so frequently called, the Shakespeare of English ballet, then perhaps a similarly practically. random sobriquet, such as the Dorothy Parker of American dance, must be affixed to Miss Tharp. And, yes, they do seem that different.

title: DUCHESS D'UZES DIES IN AN AUTO ACCIDENT
description: The Americanborn Duchess d'Uzes, an oil heiress and wife of the premier duke of France, was killed early Sunday morning in an automobile accident in France.

description: Chest pains struck right there at the restaurant, like a lick of flambe from the netherworld. There was locked hurting and great anxiety. Was this the infamous iron crab of cardiovascular failure?

title: Birthday Party for Amy Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Amy Carter will celebrate her 10th birthday at the White House Wednesday with a Halloweenstyle party featuring pumpkins, a horror movie and hamburgers. About 14 boys and girls have been invited to the twohour party, which will begin at 5 P.M. with a showing of the original version of Frankenstein.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 17 (AP)Businesses built up inventories at a faster rate in August as their sales began picking up, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: Genesco Inc. has decided to call off its proposed recapitalization plan to convert all outstanding preferred stock into common because the majority of stockholders of some classes of preferred stock have indicated they will vote against the plan, the company announced yesterday in Nashville_ its home base.

description: LONDON, Oct. 17Gladys, the dowager Duchess of Marlborough, once the friend of Proust and Degas and Rilke, once the mistress'of Britain's most magnificent private house, died in obscurity last week at the age of 96.

title: Around the Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS,Oct. 17 (AP)Effects of the 15dayold dock strike on the East and Gulf Coasts have eased as a result of the agreement of New Orleans workers to handle, noncontainer cargo and the withdrawing of pickets on the West Coast.

title: GERMAN TROOPS FREE HOSTAGES ON HIJACKED PLANE IN SOMALIA; FOUR TERRORISTS KILLED IN RAID
description: BONN, Tuesday, Oct. 18  Ninety minutes before a threatened massacre deadline, a West German commando unit stormed a hijacked Lufthansa airliner on an airport runway in Mogadishu, Somalia, and ended a fiveday, 6,000mile hijacking episode by slaying the four terrorists and freeing all 86 hostages unharmed, the Interior Ministry announced early today.

title: Need for Definitive Statements by Carter
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va.Last weekend's meeting here of more than 100 of the nation's top corporate executives vividly confirmed the marked decline since last spring in the level of business confidence detected in two recent national surveys. Those soundings The by the Conference Board of Dun & Bradstreet dealt Economic with views of current eco. Scene nomic conditions and sales prospects. But in conversations here the businessmen indicated they were much more concerned over what they consider inconsistent, imprecise and unsympathetic policies in Washington.

title: DROP REPORTED IN EXPORT OF CRUDE OIL BY SAUDIS
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 17 (AP)Saudi Arabia's crude oil exports fell sharply in August to 8.1 million barrels a day from an average of 9.06 million in July and 8.8 million in June, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: Man With Chimpanzee Heart Dies
description: CAPETOWN. Oct. 17 (AP)The first man to have the heart of a chimpanzee ???????? into his body died this morning, three and a half days after the operation, Grime Schur Hospital announced. He was Benjamin Fortes, 59 years old, a Capetown accountant. The chimpanzee heart had been implanted alongside his own heart to provide temporary support until his heart became stronger or a human heart became available for transplant.

title: Jersey to Check TV Ads Of G.O.P. for Violations Of State's Funding Law
description: TRENTON, Oct. 17The State Election Law Enforcement Commission conducted private screenings today of Republican campaign commercials to determine if their production violated the state's campaign funding law and if the campaign of Senator Raymond H. Bateman should pay for them.

title: Giants Beau Geste: Give 2 Draft Picks for Csonka
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.,Oct. 17The Giants, who don't want to give away Bob Tucker, gave away two thirdround draft choices instead today to the Miami Dolphins as voluntary compensation for the signing of Larry Csonka.

description: BONN, Tuesday, Oct. 18  Ninety minutes before a threatened massacre deadline, a West German commando unit stormed a hijacked Lufthansa airliner on an airport runway in Mogadishu, Somalia, today and ended a fiveday, 6,000mile hijacking episode by shooting the four terrorists and freeing all 86 hostages unharmed, the Interior Ministry announced early today.

title: Some Stocks Up on Merger Bids, But Dow Declines 1.30 to 820.34
description: Merger offers sent several stocks sharply higher yesterdaywith Alcon Laboratories, the volume leader, rising 9 pointsas the general market drifted lower in slow trading.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Comeback Bid Splits Her Party Deeply
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 17Supporters of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that they were continuing the campaign to make her the president of the Congress Party, despite the setback they suffered at a party convention here over the weekend.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17The nomination of Dr. Kent Hansen to be a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was rejected today by a 7to4 vote of the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works.

description: Carol Adams had no trouble doing the required 15 situps in a minute's time or moving a 70pound dummy'a simulated body, according to the test description24 yards within the limit of 43 seconds. The speed and agility test, howover, was another matter.

description: OTTAWA, Oct. 17While Queen Elizabeth II lunched with leaders of Canada's numerous communities today, her husband, Prince Philip, at a separate luncheon with business and civic leaders, itssailed the evolution'of social permissiveness into what he called a dictatorship of license.

title: Thompson Net Soared 221.4% in 3d Quarter
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company had a darling third quarter, if you consider a 221.4 percent increase in net income darling.

title: RICHARD P. LIMBURG, 81, BROKER AND CIVIC LEADER
description: Richard P. Limburg, a limited partner In the brokerage firm of Stern, Lauer & Company and long active in civic and philanthropic work, died last Wednesday at his home on Banksville Road in Bedford, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Power Failure Hits San Antonio
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 17 (AP)A power failure that blacked out parts of the city for up to three hours yesterday was attributed by utility officials to snapped static line and failure of a backup generator for some freak reason.

title: Bromberg's Voice Falls Short of His Guitar
description: David Bromberg was once New York's reigning king of folk guitaristsfolk in this case accommodating idioms as diverse as blues, bluegrass, jigs and reels, western swing, and rockandrollbut now he has moved to California. Back in New York for a concert at the Palladium on Sunday, Mr. Bromberg showed that California hasn't really changed him very much. This is a good thing or a bad thing, depending on one's point of view.

title: Bridge:
description: The Philippines will be the scene of two major championships during the next month. The Bermuda Bowl, in which Sweden, Taiwan, Australia, Argentina and two American teams will fight for the world team title, begins Friday in Manila, and this will be followed by the Far East Championship.

title: Carey Now Asserts He Will Uphold Ruling on Concorde
description: ALBANY, Oct. 17Governor Carey, in an abrupt change of tone, said today he would uphold the rule of law and abide by the Supreme Court ruling that cleared the way for the Concorde to make test flights at Kennedy International Airport.

title: In Milan, the New Name Is Excitement
description: By the time the Italian spring/summer 78 readytowear collections ended in Milan last Friday, it was clear not only that Milan is a fashion capital of the world equal in importance to Paris and New York but that some of the more exciting talents anywhere are Milan based. For several seasons, sharp store buyers have been on to the Milan gold mine and have been increasing their orders accordingly. Now, in addition to those designers already well known in the States, such as Fendi, Missoni, Mila Schoen and Roberta di Camerino, there are Giorgio Armani, Gianni Versace, Muriel Grateau, Basile, Walter Albini, Jean Baptiste Caumont, Cesare Sciunnach, Guy Paulin and Laura Biagiotti. Some of them design for several different manufacturers. For instance, Versace (pronounced Versaachi) produces collections for three different companiesCallaghan, Complice and Jenny. But soon these names will be as familiar and easy to toss around as Saint Laurent, Kenzo, or Calvin Klein. Here are a few examples of the kinds of clothes they design for men and womencompletely modern, unstructured, uncluttered, in superb sheer linens, cottons, silks and wools that fall free as a breeze against the body. The clothes will start arriving in American stores in late January.

title: jam Displays Its Rock Energy
description: The most recent onslaught of the new British Invasion took place at CBGB's last weekend, when a rock trio called the Jam made its New York debut. Some call the mew invasion punk rock, but the Jam, dressed in identical dark mod suits with black narrow ties and matching haircuts, looked like something straight out of the last decade's British Invasion.

title: A Correction
description: In a recipe for browniesbrownies in the De Gustibus column yesterday, one of the ingredients was improperly given. Four ounces, or four squares, of unsweetened chocolate should be used.

title: White House Confirms That Carter Will Add Saudi Stop to His Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP)President Carter has added a stop in Saudi Arabia to his fourcontinent trip next month to hold talks with King Khalid and Crown Prince Fand on Middle East problems, aid to developing nations and energy, the White House press secretary, Jody Powell, confirmed today.

title: Capitol Drama: The Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17In a setting better known for the high drama of the Watergate or ArmyMcCarthy hearings or the failed hopes and reputations of long forgotten Presidential candidacies, what may well be the most involved and complex HouseSenate conferences ever will begin tomorrow afternoon. It is charged with putting the mangled energy bills back together.

title: Theater: E.L.T. Opens 35th Year
description: The Equity Library Theater, whose return each year is indeed glad tidings, has begun its 35th season with a revival of a 1951 comedy Glad Tidings.

title: Miss Evert M.V.P.
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 17 (AP)Chris Evert of the Phoenix Racquets was named today the mostvaluable woman player in World Team Tennis for the second straight year. The voting was by sports writers covering the league.

title: Gold and Silver Futures Advance; Coffee, Cocoa Up as Sugar Slips
description: The gold rush continued yesterday in the futures and cash markets for bullion. On New York's Commodity Exchange, all deliveries rose $2 an ounce, with the expiring October contract closing at $162.60 an ounce.

title: Iran Executes Embassy Slayer
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 17 (UPI)Iran has executed a man convicted of killing of an Iranian employee of the United States Embassy in Teheran more than two years ago, Government sources said today. Mohammed Reza Akhundi went underground after he shot and killed Hassan Hossnan, an embassy translator, in July, 1975. He was captured last year and sentenced to death by a military court.

title: One Defendant Wraps Up Case As 2d Prepares in Bolles Trial
description: PHOENIX, Oct. 17Lawyers representing Max Dunlap, one of the two men accused of murdering Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic, are wrapping up their case as lawyers for the other defendant, James Robison, are preparing to begin his defense.

title: Hearing Judge Backs Rate Rise for Lilco
description: A Public Service Commission hearing officer has recommended that it give the Long Island Lighting Company an electricity rate increase of $64.9 million a year.

description: A memorial mass for Bing Crosby held during the lunch hour in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday was attended by about 3,000 people who came from all over New York City and beyond.

title: Bald Eagle Protection Expanding
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (UPI)The Federal Government is about to expand to 43 states its protection of the bald eagle, the national symbol that has been threatened with extinction in the lower 48 states. The Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service with the next few weeks will publish final regulations proclaiming the halt eagle is endangered in 43 states and giving their habitat full protection under the Endangered Species Act.

title: In 3d Quarter and for 9 Months
description: The United Technologies Corporation, a diversified manufacturer, reported yesterday profit increases of 24 percent in the third quarter and in the first nine months.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to Manuel Cantarero del Castillo, who grew up in the youth organizations of the Falange and who became, in the last years of. Franco's long reign, one of Spain's leading social democrats: In Spain there has been a tendency, now on the decline, to think of politics much more as esthetics than as an attempt at the practical manipulation of reality in a positive determined sense. Spanish rationalism has been a rationalism of pure reason and not a rationalism of common sense, which is what is valid in politics. There has been no effort to fit political formulations to the exigencies of reality in its rambling process of change, but to adapt that reality to an a priori scheme of ideas totally conceived outside its conditions.

title: Clearing Passage for the Canal Treaties
description: The clarifying statement by Presidents Carter and Torrijos on the pending Panama Canal treaties should deflate the opposition in Congress and clear a path for their approval by the Senate. One can never be sure in this emotional realm what nationalistic or partisan dreams will next be imposed on so sensitive an exercise in diplomacy, but as Senator Byrd, the majority leader, has observed, the joint interpretation by the two leaders last Friday goes to the heart of the objections that have been raised and that can be raised.

title: One Term For Carter?;
description: People who think and talk about politics are beginning to ask each other openly: Is Jimmy Carter a oneterm President? The question may seem strange and premature, when the man has been in office less than a year; yet it has a certain validity.

title: I.R.S. to Cut Interest It Charges On Overdue Taxes to 6% From 7%
description: The Internal Revenue Service announced yesterday in Washington that it was cutting the interest rate it charges on overdue tax bills to 6 percent from percent, effective Feb, 1.

title: Never Can Tell Reveals A Shaw at His Minimum
description: You Never Can Tell, written in 1897, was early Shaw, one of his plays pleasant, to distinguish it from his more serious, socially conscious work. It was an attempt on his part to acknowledge the popular preference for fun, fashionable dresses, a little music, and even an exhibition of eating and drinking by people with an expensive air, attended by an ifpossiblecomic waiter.
