It is charged with putting the mangled energy bills back together.

title: COCACOLA ACCEPTS OFFER BY NORTHWEST
description: The CocaCola Bottling Company of Los Angeles. which only 10 days ago refused t $140 million takeover bid by MCA Inc.. the big entertainment complex, disclosed yesterday that its directors had voted to accept an offer of roughly $200 million from Northwest Industries, the Middle Western industrial corporation.

title: Television
GOLD
description: By The Associated Press

title: SUPREME COURT LIFTS KENNEDY BAN ON SST; JET DUE IN TOMORROW
description: The United States Supreme Court cleared the way yesterday for immediate trial flights of the supersonic Concorde airliner to Kennedy International Airport, and Concorde operators said thatbarring a legal maneuver that few thought could cause more than a slight delaythe first fight, without passengers, would be made tomorrow.

title: World News Briefs
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 17 (Reuters)Three members of Czechoslovakia's Charter 77 human rights group today pleaded not guilty to a charge of subversion.

title: Grapefruit Peel as Substitute
description: WESLACO, Tex.,Oct. 17 (UPI)The peel of a grapefruit may one day be more valuable than the fruit itself if saccharin is banned as an artificial sweetener, Dr. Calvin Lyons, a citrus specialist with the Texas A&M University agricultural extension service, says. He bases his prophecy on the potential of naringen, a bitter chemical found primarily in the skins of grapefruit, as a sweetener to replace saccharin in some products.

title: PORT AGENCY SCORED AT CONCORDE HEARING
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey pushed ahead yesterday with hearings for new aircraft noise regulations while its chairman, Alan Sagner, expressed the belief that there was no way to prevent the first testflight landing of the Concorde supersonic transport at Kennedy International Airport tomorrow.

title: Canada Starts TV From Parliament
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 17Regular live television coverage of the Canadian Parliament began today with a broadcast of the 60minute question period that traditionally opens each day's proceedings.

title: Clutter of War Still Disfigures Vietnam's Verdant Countryside
description: SAIGON, VietnamThe railroad line between Saigon and Hanoi, once the first stage of a direct rail route to Paris, is open again.

title: U.S.AND KOREA CONFER ON PARK QUESTIONING
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Oct: 18 Justice officials from the United States and South Korea opened formal talks here yesterday on the United States' desire to question Tongsun Park, the South Korean businessman who is the central figure in an alleged influencebuying scandal in Washington.

title: Research Vessel to Study Impact Of Radioactive Waste on Pacific
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 (AP)A small Canadian research submarine heading for a Pacific Coast dumping ground for radioactive waste to determine what impact the dumping has had on the ocean. Scientists will also be looking at some mysterious giant sponges that have crown in the area.

title: Martha Sheil Has Debut in Figaro
description: In the hierarchy of disparagement, the word mediocre is not always a euphemism for bad. The New York City Opera's performance of The Marriage of Figaro Saturday afternoon was generally mediocre. But it did the job in some basic sense, presenting a functional account of Mozart's masterpiece to a seemingly contented subscription crowd.

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Disaster Of Police Bungling in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 17The investigation by the Puerto Rican police into the murders of three diamond dealersa crime,story that nas attracted international attentionhas become a tragicomedy of errors.

title: Steinbrenner Plans to Keep Jackson With Yankeesin'78
description: Reggie Jackson will be with the New York Yankees next season, George Steinbrenner said yesterday. He also said he would leave the decision to keep or dismiss Manager Billy Martin up to Gabe Paul, the club president.

title: Andy deGroat's 13Dance Suite
description: Andy deGroat is an experimental choreographer whose work has reached its widest audience in Robeft Wilson's productions, including Einstein on the Beach, but whose dance pieces stand up very well by themselves in concert. On Sunday night at the Cunningham Studio at Westbeth, that point was made again in a highly engaging and original hourlong suite of 13 dances called  Angie's Waltz and Other Dances. It was performed by 12 men and women with a wide range of technique. Yet all were called upon to perform the same kind of movement. The vivid way wardness of the result had the brightness of a handful of colored marbles stubbornly scattered in all directions.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court voted yesterday to vacate a stay that enabled 35 teachers at Matawan Regional High School who were cited for contempt to stay out of jail. In a 4to3 vote at a private conference, the court voted to end the stay, effective noon, Friday.

title: G.O.P.'s TV Ads Checked for Funding Law Violations
description: TRENTON,Oct. 17The State Election Law Enforcement Commission conducted private screenings today of Republican campaign commercials to determine their production violated the state's campaign funding law and if the campaign of Senator Raymond H. Bateman should pay for them.

title: Carter Praises Raid By Bonn Commandos
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (Reuters)President Carter praised West German commandos tonight for their successsful rescue of 86 hostages held by four terrorists aboard a hijacked Lufthansa jetliner in Mogadishu, Somalia.

title: Kenya Center Uncovering Secrets of Insect Life
description: NAIROBI, KenyaAmong the towering eucalyptus trees on the Masonga Wai River here stands one of the most remarkable, if least known, scientific institutions in the world: a complex of laboratories where more than 30 researchers from 17 countries are discovering the innermost secrets of the lives of insects and their close allies.

title: CBS Ousts 2 Top TV Executives; Splits Up Entertainment and Sports
description: In an extensive management shakeup, CBS yesterday removed John A. Schneider as president of the broadcast group and Robert J. Wussler as president of the television network. Both have been given new positions.

title: Chase Sold Own New York Notes In 74, David Rockefeller Testifies
description: David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, acknowledged yesterday that Chase had sold New York City securities from its own portfolio in late 1974just as the city was having trouble issuing new notes to the public. But he said the bank had made the sales, including sales of municipal securities from cities other than New York, for business reasons, not because it feared the city might default.

description: CLAREMONT, Calif.Listening to a CBS Radio retrospective did to me what it must have done to everyone born before World War II: I found myself assailed by memories.

description: WASHINGTONBusiness and higher education have combined to oppose extension of Federal agediscrimination laws to persons beyond age 65. Their efforts led to adoption recently of two exemptions that would negate the proposed legislation's effect on executives and professors.

description: INDIANOLA, Iowa, Oct. 17 (AP)A 64yearold farmer who will be President Carter's host for the night on Friday says he has a few matters he would like to discuss with him, such as cattle, corn, wheat, drought and energy.

description: A memorial mass for Bing Crosby held during the lunch hour in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday was attended by about 3,000 people who came from all over New York City and beyond.

description: Yields rose on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 180day maturities.

description: A mother has the right to withdraw her daughter from a school that she considers racist, William M. Kunstler, the attorney, told the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Palma Toscani Sings In the French Vein
description: In the 19th century French was considered an international language in Palma Toscani's enterprising recital in cultural circles, a fact emphasized by Town Hall Saturday afternoon. All the songs were settings of French texts, but the composers hailed from a number of different countries, Including Germany (Handel and Wagner), Italy (Respighi), Russia (Tchaikovsky), Spain (De Fella) as well as France (Poulenc, Auric, Faur and Debussy).

Reggie Jackson gets a hit and Diana Munson cheers as loudly as. if not louder than, the rest.

title: Heroes, Presentand Past The Upright and the Fallen

And the starring combination in the final New York victory was made up of Billy Martin, the fiery coach, Reggie Jackson, the embattled superstar, and Mike Torrez, everfriendly professional.

title: Private Lives
description: WE ARE somewhere in northcentral Florida, one of several places airplanes go after they leave Atlanta. It is 6:30 in the morning in a new house with white walls, many windows and sliding glass doors. The sun, taking its time, won't be up for another hour or more, and so we can't see the trees, the plants in their tubs, the flowers in their buckets, the butterflies the size of pancakes, the volleyball net and the hammock that surround the house, nor the black cat with white paws on the roof, wearing what would look like a tuxedo if we snapped an aerial, infrared photograph.

title: Jersey Panel Votes A Limit on Casinos

The panel also proposed a rule forbidding nude dancers in casino revues.

title: ATLANTIC CITY GETS A POWERPLAN GRANT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18Mayor .70., seph Lazarow of Atlantic City said today that the Federal Government had ap: proved a $200,000 grant to study his community's plan for a single energy source to provide light and heat for the new gambling casinos and housing, with enough energy capacity left over to operate public transportation facilities.

title: The Moving Finder Writes, Etc.
description: It had to happen this way. It had been predestined since Nov. 29, 1976, when Reginald Martinez Jackson sat down on a gilded chair in New York's Americana Hotel and wrote his name on a Yankee contract. That day he became an instant millionaire, the big honcho on the best team money could buy, the richest, least inhibited, most glamorous exhibit in Billy Martin's pinstriped zoo. That day the plot was written for last nightthe bizarre scenario Reggie Jackson played out by hitting three home runs, clubbing the Los Angeles Dodgers into submission and carrying his supporting players with him to the baseball championship of North of America. His was the most lurid performance in 74 World Series, for although Babe Ruth hit three home runs in a game 1926 and again in 1928, not even that demigod smashed three in a row.

title: Testing the Concorde and New York
description: We welcome this morning not the Concorde but the triumph of fair and legal procedures in dealing with the emotional issues it poses. We celebrate Governor Carey's belated pledge to uphold the rule of law. We applaud the Port Authority's shift of attention from dilatory legal maneuvers to difficult technical evaluations. And we implore the residents around Kennedy Airport to recognize even at this late hour that they stand to gain more from constructive community action than from disruptive demonstrations.

description: In a Government financing that reflected the sharpest rise in interest rates so far this fall, the Treasury yesterday sold $3.5 billion of twoyear notes at an average rate of 7.27 percent, the highest rate of return for such securities since December, 1975.

title: On Trial in Prague
description: While 35 nations confer in Belgrade about how well the Helsinki accords on human rights are being observed, four Czech intellectuals have been convicted in Prague for activities against the foundation of the republic. One of them pleaded guilty to maintaining conspiratorial links with the Westwhich apparently means smuggling out contributions to emigre publications, in violation of official cultural policy; he was sentenced to three and a half years. The other three, including Vaclav Havel, a leading Czech playwright, pleaded not guilty: one was sentenced to three years, while Mr. Havel and the third received suspended sentences. Early this year, these three had signed Charter 77, an internationally publicized manifesto calling for more civil liberties in Czechoslovakia. Soon after, they were jailed. Other signers have been dismissed from their jobs, evicted from their homes, deprived of their passports and drivers licenses, and subjected to long and repeated questioning by the authorities. Some have reportedly been rounded up anew. Western delegates at the Belgrade meeting criticized the trial, but without naming Czechoslovakia. That, we suppose, is diplomacy. But surely in the court of human rights, governments like Czechoslovakia's are the defendants.

title: GATT, 30 Years Old, Opens Its New Offices

title: Stage: Too Shrill Viva
description: DIRECTNESS IS FINE for tracts, but art works by ambush. Eve Merriam used sardonic reversal to put across her thoughts about women in the play The Club, where the actresses appear dressed up as clubmen. In Viva Revive. she proceeds by straight lyrical affirmation. Perversely, the effect is not of sincerity or authenticity but just the opposite: It becomes a singing commercial for a thesis.

title: Terrorism: the Battle and the War
description: There are answers to terrorism and political hijacking. They are not easy answers, as West Germany's experience indicates. Bonn has won a major battle in its sixweek test of wills with German terrorists; but the war is not over. Industrialist HannsMartin Schleyer, kidnapped Sept. 5, is still missing. But the courage and skillful crisis management of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and West Germany's opposition leaders have paid off at Mogadishu airport. The successful assault there has shown, as did the Israeli attack at Entebbe, that daring and welltrained troops can storm hijacked aircraft with minimal casualties.

title: Net of 3 Big Wall St. Firms Declines
description: Thirdquarter and ninemonth earnings of parent companies of three major securities firmsMerrill LynCh & Company, the E.F. Hutton Group and Reynolds Securities International Inc.declined, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Credit Cards: In Name Only
description: If you own one of the nation's estimated 500 million credit cards and you have one with your address on it, don't discard itit just might become a collector's item as more and more department stores are phasing it out in favor of a name only card immune to the growing number of Americans who move each year.

title: Pistons 110, Nets 93
description: DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP)Ralph Simpson scored 23 points and Bob Lanier 22 tonight to pace the Detroit Pistons to a 11093 victory over the New Jersey Nets in the National Basketball Association opener for both teams.

title: Sadat Meets Arafat to Discuss a Formula for Geneva
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18President Anwar elSadat met today with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat for talks that opened Egypt's formal efforts to work out a unified Arab response to the formula proposed by the United States and Israel for a new Middle East peace conference at Geneva.

title: HOSTAGES DESCRIBE HIJACKER AS FANATIC
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 18The leader of the Lufthansa hijackersa mysterious man who identified himself as Walter Mahmoudwas described today by the passengers he held captive for four days as an arrogant, excitable, almost hysterical killer.

title: Article 3 No Title
description: Article 3 No Title

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Minister of State and chief troubleshooter, HansJrgen Wischnewski, played a prominent role in the action, which stretched over nearly five days. The United States, Middle East and African countries, Greece, Britain, France and even the Vatican were involved.

title: 40% More Deaths In Britain Indicated For Users of the Pill
description: A continuing study of 46,000 women in Britain has shown that those who use oral contraceptives face a substantially higher risk of pillrelated death than was previously thought.

title: Toasts Around the Table on the Algonquin's 75th
description: we were more than mildly amused, a few hours ago, to find ourselves part of the crush in the decorous, oakpaneled lobby of the Algonquin Hotel, where more than 200 theater people, writers, artists, publishers and other emissaries of the creative persuasions mingled at the invitation of The New Yorker, yes, The New Yorker magazine. The occasion was the 75th anniversary of the hotel, where the absence of such lightsoftheRoundTable as Dorothy Parker, Robert Benchley, Alexander Woollcott and George S. Kaufman was as keenly felt as the presence of such contemporary luminaries as Mayor Abraham Beame, S. J. Perelman, Jean Stapleton, Peter deVries and Victor Borge.

title: YANKEES TAKE SERIES; JACKSON EQUALS MARK OF 3 HOMERS IN GAME
description: With Reggie Jackson hitting three home runs in three straight times at bat, the New York Yankees swept all those family feuds under the rug last night and overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 84, to win their first World Series in 15 years.

title: A. BOYD HINES SR.
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 18A. Boyd Hines ?r., who was the national director of the Boys Clubs of America for five years before retiring in 1972, died Monday at his home in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: Shop Stewards at Leyland Support Management Plan To Centralize Labor Talks
description: LONDON, Oct. 18Shop stewards at British Leyland Ltd. voted today to support a controversial management plan to streamline the company's chaotic labor relations. The decision was seen as crucial in heading off dismemberment of the troubled automobile giant.

title: CAREY TO PUSH BILL ON NEW YORK NOTES
description: In a surprise move, Governor Carey announced yesterday that he would ask the State Legislature to reconvene before the end of this month to pass a law so that New York City can sell its own shortterm notes to the public in November.

title: Army to Shift More Men and Equipment to Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The United States Army today disclosed plans to strengthen its forces in Western Europe to counter a potential Soviet ground attack on short notice.

title: Television
description: 5:30(2)Jeanne Parr in the Morning (R)

title: YANKEES TAKE SERIES, JACKSON EQUALS MARK OF 3 HOMERS IN GAME
description: With Reggie Jackson hitting three home runs in his last three times at bat, the New York Yankees swepta 11 those family feuds under the rug last night and overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 84, to win their fisrt World Series in 15 years.

title: Their SST, And Ours
description: The fierce battle over the Concorde's landing at Kennedy International Airport may be overor at least lost for the moment. The BritishFrench onslaught to obtain landing rights for their supersonic transport has triumphed for now. The Port Authority and thousands of New York area residents are not the only losersso is the American workingman.

title: Supercarriers: A Naval Shift
description: The Navy commissioned the supercarrier Dwight D. Eisenhower yesterday and promised that another ship of the same class, the Carl Vinson, would join the fleet in 1980.

title: Duryea Proposes a $2 Billion Cut In State Taxes Over Next 5 Years
description: Perry B. Duryea, the Assembly minority leader and a leading Republican prospect for next year's gubernatorial race, called yesterday for a $2.15 billionayear reduction in state taxes to be phased in within the next five years.

title: Bateman Charges Byrne Has Got Secret Plan to Raise Income Tax
description: JAMESBURG, Oct. 18Senator Raymond H. Bateman, .the Republican candidate for Governor, charged tonight that Governor Byrne had a secret plan to Increase the state income tax next year to make up for an anticipated shortfall in tax collections.

title: 80 HAGGARD HOSTAGES ARRIVE IN FRANKFURT
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 18Eighty passengers and crew members freed from a hijacked West German airliner in Mogadishu, Somalia, early this morning arrived here this afternoon, the strain of their ordeal etched in their faces and their bodies.

title: 40% More Deaths In Britain Indicated For Users of the Pill
description: A continuing study of 46,000 women in Britain has shown that those who use oral contraceptives face a substantially higher risk of pillrelated death than was previously thought.

title: Q&A
description: Q. About 40 years ago my grand. mother made an excellent pre. serve she called citron. Several years ago my mother sent me the recipe and since then, off and on, I have been looking for citron in various places, including New York, without success. No one I have talked with has ever heard of it, except in the candied or preserved form. My recipe calls for fresh citron. Could you help me?

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  A House committee approved today $500 million to keep Saturday mail deliveries going and smalltown post offices open and voted to make the Postmaster General a Presidential appointee once more.

title: Tighter Controls Urged for Management
description: A new Federal law for more effective controls on the management of large corporations was urged yesterday in hearings held here by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Federal Aides Finish Tour of South Bronx
description: Winding up a twoday factfinding tour of the South Bronx yesterday, a Carter Administration group of White House and Housing and Urban Development aides focused on the borough's economic potential as a means of improving conditions.

title: Status of T ribe Is Argued in Court
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18The jurors in the Wampanoag Indian land suit trial heard two different versions of Indian history on Cape Cod today as lawyers for both sides delivered opening arguments in Federal District Court.

title: Cost of Taking PCB's From Hudson Soars
description: FORT EDWARD, N. Y.New York State has been advised that it will cost $150 million to dredge the toxic chemical compound PCB from a badly contaminated 35.7mile stretch of the Hudson River between here and Troy.

title: Israel Praises Bonn For the  Salvation Of Plane Hostages
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 (AP)The Israeli Government, the world's leading advocate of decisive; nocompromise action against terrorists, congratulated West Germany today on the success of the Mogadishu commando raid.

title: Tay Garnett, Film Director for Half Century, Dies
description: Tay Garnett, a director whose scores of films made over a half century told stories of high adventure and action and starred many of Hollywood's bestknown names, died Oct. 4 in the Wadsworth Veterans Administration Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 83 years old.

title: Scrappy, Controversial Yankee Manager; Alfred Manuel (Billy) Martin; I'm Insecure, Too; His Twins Win the Pennant
description: He used to be called The Kid, as in Billy the Kid, a symbol of American Western banditry. When he was in his 20's, Billy Martin played three infield positions for Yankee teams that were winning championships every year. He was also described as scrappy and street smart. His ability to play winning ball and occasionally star in World Series was regarded as an admirable example of a type his manager, Casey Stengel, liked best: a player of limited physique who could beat moretalented men by using his nerve, wits, concentration and determination.

title: Georgia Workers Strike Lockheed
description: MARIETTA, Ga., Oct. 19, Wednesday (AP)Picket signs went up at the LockheedGeorgia plant here at 12:01 A.M. today as members of Local 709 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers went on strike. They joined another 14,500 union members on strike against Lockheed plants in California and 24,000 union workers striking Boeing. facilities in Seattle, Wash.; Portland, Ore, and Wichita, Kan.

title: Mondale Hits Charge Of Politicizing Arts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Vice President Mondale, officiating today at the swearingin of Joseph D. Duffey as head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, spoke in vigorous defense of the Carter Administration's views and policy regarding cultureand, by inference, in defense of the Duffey appointment.

title: The Humble Cabbage: Full of Surprises
description: TO TURNOR TWIST, one might saythe words of Eugene O'Neill (Spring isn't everything . . . there's a lot to be said for autumn . . . and winter) to my own good use, there's a lot to be said for the first asparagus and fresh peas and new radishes and early shad. But cabbage has merit, too. Its virtues are many and splendid. It most assuredly can be humble. It can be elegant as well.

title: Jackson, the Player of the Series, Is Controversial and Charismatic
description: Reggie Jackson, an integral part of the Yankees seasonlong storm, rose to his inimitably dramatic best last night and hit three consecutive home runs in the sixth and final game of the World Series.

title: Barge's Owner to Pay New York $75,000 For an Oil Spill in St. Lawrence Seaway
description: ALBANY. Oct. 18New York State has received $75,000 in its first financial recovery for oilspill damage. The money came from a shipping concern in a settlement of litigation resulting from a 1976 oil spill in the St. Lawrence Seaway, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today.

title: Carter Sent Message To Barre Before Raid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The White House said tonight that shortly before West German commandos successfully stormed the hijacked Lufthansa airliner in Somalia yesterday, President Carter had sent a personal message to the Somali President asking his help in combating terrorism.

title: WithPoachedTurbot, Make Mine Handel
description: MUSIC and food! How well they can go together! What a distinguished history, shared by the great eaters, the great chefs, the great musicians! Music aids digestion, wrote an Elizapethan poet. No great banquet was given without music. No great lord would think of dining without his house musicians to entertain rum. important composers were commissioned to write music to eat by. Lully's music entertained the Sun King at table. Georg Philipp Telemann wrote reams of Tafelmusik'table musicin the early 1700's. And Telemann of Hamburg, as everybody at the time knew, was the world's greatest composer, far greater than that dry church organistwhat was his name? Bach?in Leipzig. Mozart wrote divertimentos for garden parties given by his friends, and Haydn wrote music to entertain his boss, prince Esterhazy, during and between meal courses.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Rosemarie DiPrima died in Bayonne Hospital yesterday of wounds inflicted when her three children were shot and killed in the family's apartment at 45 East 18th Street in Bayonne. Mrs. DePrima was shot once in the head with a 45caliber handgun and never regained consciousness.

title: Conference Highlights Problems of Typical American Couples
description: SOUTHBURY. Conn.

title: Cerporation Affairs
description: Major creditors of the H. Camp Company, one of the country's largest operators of leased millinexy departinents in stores, met in New York yesterday in preparation for the first formal court hearing on Camp's insol$ency on Nov. 1.

title: Losers Awed by Jackson; The Greatest in a Series
description: In the quiet of their clubhouse, the Los Angeles Dodgers appeared to be in awe of Reggie Jackson's three home runs in the Yankees 84 victory that won the World Series last night.

title: HARASSMENT ALLEGED OVER CODE RESEARCH
description: Computer scientists and mathematicians whose research touches on secret codes say they have been subjected by, the National Security Agency to growing harassment and the threat of sanctions or even prosecution for publishing articles about their work.

title: Music: Juana Zayas Fine Chopin Pianist
description: JUANA ZAYAS, a Cubanborn pianist who has studied in France and this country, played last night in Alice Tully Hall. Her program contained three of the supreme tests of any pianistRaves Gaspard de la Nuit, and both books of the Chopin Etudes. all 24 of them.

title: 4 Days of Fear, Then 7 Minutes For the Rescue
description: BONN, Oct. 18Almost from the moment that the Lufthansa 737 was hijacked over the French Riviera last Thursday afternoon, West Germany set in motion a complex domestic and international operation to rescue its 82 passengers and fivemember crew.

title: For Tough West German Force, Feat Capped Years of Training
description: BONN, Oct. 18When West German commandos stormed a hijacked Lufthansa Boeing 737 airliner at the dusty airport of Mogadishu, Somalia, early this morning, they saw action for the first time after five years of training and contingency planning.

title: U. S. Criticizes Trial
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 18 (UPI) The United States joined the French Communist Party today in condemning Czechoslovakia for putting four dissidents on trial.

title: Books: Rosalind Russell's Lively Feast
description: THE TITLE of this autobiography comes from a speech that Rosalind Russell made hundreds of times in the title role of Auntie Mame, which is likely to be her bestremembered part. In full, it goes, Live, live, live. Life is a banquet and most of you poor suckers are starving.

title: A Variety of Companies Release Reports for the Quarter, Covering Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: For periods ended Sept. 30 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounler.

title: SouthWest African, in U. N ., Asks Pullout
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y.. Oct. 18The leader of the SouthWest Africa People's Organization called on the United Nations today to impose an economic and military embarco if south Africa refuses to withdraw its military forces from SouthWest Africa.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: BATTLEFIELD dispatches from the war on litter: One morning not long ago, as he was entering the IND station at Bergen Street in Brooklyn, Edward Moran nearly tripped over a halfempty beer can inside a paper bag sitting on the step.

title: Philip Berrigan Eludes Policemen After a Speech in Connecticut
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP)The police said today that they tried but failed to arrest Philip F. Berrigan last night in connection with a 1975 demonstration. Mr. Berrigan, the activist and former Roman Catholic priest, slipped out a side door of a college building as policemen waited out front.

title: DR. MAY E. ROM, PIONEER IN FIELD OF PSYCHIATRY
description: Dr. May E. Romm, a pioneer In the field of psychiatry, died Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 86 years old.

title: School Food Hearings Announced
description: Individuals concerned about the nutrition their children are getting in school lunches and other Government programs will have an opportunity to discuss the subject with officials of the United States Department of Agriculture at hearings in New York City next Tuesday and Wednesday, Oct. 25 and 26.

title: Article 4 No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Evenings With Johann S. Begin Monday
description: The 10th anniversary of Evenings With Johann S. presented by Holy Tamity Lutheran Church, Central Park West at 65th Street, will begin Monday with a special Bach Festival Week, that will run through Oct. 30.

title: CARTER SIGNS WHALING BILL WITH BAN ON OIL TERMINAL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)President Carter signed legislation today barring commercial whaling within 200 miles of United States shores and the construction of any major oil pipeline terminal on Puget Sound in Washington State.

title: Rock: Trower Numbs
description: IF NO RECORDINGS of the heavy, bluesbased English rock of 1967 survivedno Cream, Jimi Hendrix or Jeff Beck group albums  Robin Trower would still be here as a reminder Mr. Trower, who was at Radio City Music Hall on Monday night, spent 1967 and the next few years playing restrained elegant lead guitar with Procol Harum, which, in its way, was a forerunner of some of today's artrock lands. But with his own group, he has pelrogressed, chronologically and, one suspects, esthetically.

title: Dow Up by 0.17, But the Market Lacks Direction
description: Newly issued earnings reports and possible takeover targets dominated the attention of Wall Street yesterday, while the general market remained about even in its closely watched indicators.

title: Episcopal Bishop to Bar Ordination of Homosexuals
description: Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York said yesterday that he would not ordain any publicly avowed, practicing homosexual until further study of the issue by a diocesan commission he had appointed.

title: Party Fashions: Past and Present
description: Nobody wears hoops skirts any more and nobody really misses them. Except that at the Best Bib & Tucker Monday night at the Museum the City of New York, they evoked some Wistful sighs and glances.

title: 3 JAILED GERMAN TERRORISTS REPORTED SUICIDES AS HOSTAGES FROM HIJACKED PLANE FLY HOME
description: BONN, Oct. 18Three West German terrorist leaders committed suicide early today in a maximumsecurity prison in Stuttgart hours after German commandos stormed a hijacked Lufthansa plane in Somalia and blocked an attempt to free them, Justice Ministry officials announced.

title: People and Business
description: William M. Batten, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that a pilot program to electronically link the trading floors of the Big Board and the regional exchanges could be in operation by next March or April.

title: Riverdale Battle: Condominiums or Trees
description: A plan to build a luxury townhouse complex in Riverdale finds some of that Bronx section's most influential residents in conflict over an estate and nature area in which $100,000 condominiums would rise next to quiet streets dotted with costly older houses and wellgroomed greenery.

title: DEAN P. TAYLOR, WAS 75; SERVED IN HOUSE 18 YEARS
description: Dean P. Taylor, who represented Troy and northeastern New York State in the House of Representatives for nine terms, from 1942 to 1960, and who was Republican state chairman in 1953 and 1954, died in Albany Sunday of an apparent heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: Technology
description: Where there's smoke, there's fire. True enough, but how much smoke and how soon? Those questions have a lot to do with a marketing battle now raging among makers of smoke detectors, the electronic devices designed to give early warning of fires in the home.

title: Indonesia Accused by Rights Group
description: Amnesty International, the humanrights organization that last week was awarded the 1977 Nobel Peace Prize, charged yesterday that Indonesia has held up to 100,000 political prisoners for more than a decade. The overwhelming majority, it said, have never been brought to trial.

title: Advertising
description: Members of the Advertising Research Foundation, as their twoday 23d annual conference opened yesterday, got some mouthwatering samples of the marketing information that could become available through the Universal Product Code and the supermarket checkout scanner.

title: On Parent Power
description: The following are excerpts from Ail Our Children: The American Family Under Pressure by Kenneth Keniston and the Carnegie Council on Childrsen:

title: TWO COUNCIL PANELS SEEK TO CURB ARSON
description: In a dual attack to curb arson, two New York City Council committees yesterday voted out a bill aimed at removing the profit motive and another offering a reward for the arrest and conviction of anyone on arson charges.

title: Bacon Hard Hit By Nitrite Curb
description: The futures market In frozen pork bellies (unprocessed bacon) was severely shaken yesterday by the Government's latest step to outlaw the use of nitrites by the pork industry.

title: MEXICO IS WORRIED THAT NEW U.S. RULES ARE CURBING LOANS
description: MEXICO CITY Oct. 18The Mexican Government is deeply worried that its ability to borrow in the United States is being restricted by growing pressure on United States banks to curb their lending to developing nations carrying heavy debt burdens.

title: Careers
description: With wine consumption by Americans continuing to expand, job opportunities at United States vintners are growing apace.

title: U.S. SHIFTING POLICY FOR CURBING AARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Carter Administration, in a subtle but significant redirection of its policy for curbing the spread of nuclear weapons, is beginning a major initiative to promote the development of nuclear power technology that would be more difficult to exploit for military purposes.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided in a closed session today not to travel as a group to Panama, but aides said individual panel members or a small task force might make the trip.

title: Deaths
description: BREVDAHerman. Board of Directors mourn the death of their esteemed mast President and Officer. Our condolence to family. Yale Brevda Benevolent Association Inc

title: Body of Gem Dealer Positively Identified
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 18A body exhumed by Puerto Rican authorities was identified by them tonight as that of Abraham Shafizadeh, a New York diamond dealer who vanished here on July 28. But the identification, made through dental records, raised new questions.

title: ESTIMATED LOSS IN 1977 FOR CONRAIL INCREASED
description: Edward Jordan, chairman of the Consolidated Rail Corporation confirmed yesterday that Conrail would lose approximately $338 million this year. $100 million more than projected by the United States Railway Associationthe Government agency that designed Conrail.

title: Personal Health
description: Jane E.Brody

title: ...In Its Satisfying NewTheater
description: HARTFORD WE DID NOT WANT culture palace, one of the staff members of the Hartford Stage Company told a visitor to its new theater the other day. What the company wanted, instead, was a workmanlike, straightforward building that would reproduce the sense of informality that had prevailed at its former quarters in a converted warehouse.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Should We Stop Blaming Parents? Are Parents ToBlame?
description: WHO is to blame if American divorce rates are soaring  and more than half the mothers of school children are working? Parents today are selfish and selfcentered, an angry parent wrote to the Carnegie Council on Children when we began to examine the needs of American children five years ago. They aren't willing to make ,sacrifices for their children, But that's what being a parent is all about, so is it any wonder that the children grow up on drugs?

title: Conference on Safeguards
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Oct. 18 (UPI)An international group of nuclear experts was told today that the security of radioactive material was directly linked to the money spent to protect it.

title: ARMY MOVING SLOWLY WITH LSD FOLLOW UP
description: SAN FRANCISCO,Oct. 18Two years ago when Congress learned that hundreds of Americans were given the hallucinogenic drug LSD under programs set up by the Army in the 1950's and 1960's, the Surgeon General of the Army promised to do followup tests on Army personnel who had been administered the drug.

title: Pearl in Mrs. Eisenhower's Life
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 18 (AP)The commissioning of the Dwight D. Eisenhower was welcomed here today by the former President's widow, Mamie Eisenhower, as one of the most moving events of her life.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Jobs, Crime and Income Tax Emerge as Top Issues In Both 34th and 35th Districts in Passaic County
description: PATERSON, Oct. 18Jobs, crime and deep opposition to the state income tax have emerged as the paramount issues in the legislative races in both the 34th and 35th Districts in Passaic County.

title: Deaths ,
description: FREYTheo. The Officers, Board of Trustees and Members of Central Synagogue deeply mourn the Passing of an esteemed member of many years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to all the members of the family.

title: House Inquiries on Korea Lobbying Are Moving Into New, Public Phase
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18With one Congressional hearing scheduled to open tomorrow and another shortly after that, the investigation of alleged Korean influencepeddling is moving Into a new, public phase that may have unsettling and perhaps even turbulent political and dip lomatic consequences.

title: Delirious Fans Run Wild As Some Violence Erupts
description: They had anticipated the last pitch better than the police had, and at the final out thousands of jubilant fans charged onto the field at Yankee Stadium last night, leaping beyond the grasp of dozens of policemen and unafraid of the five horses brought in especially for this mad moment. Despite the bizarre scene, watched by most of the 56,407 fans who stayed to see the celebration of the Yankees first World Series victory since 1962, there were, at first, only scattered incidents of violence.

title: Energy Conferees Put Off Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 18  After 25 minutes of promises of cooperation and earnest reminders of the nation's peril, the HouseSenate conference on energy legislation started arguing today over whether utilities should be allowed to insulate homes, fix furnaces and provide loans for insulation.

title: 3 JAILED GERMAN TERRORISTS REPORTED SUICIDES AS HOSTAGES FROM HIJACKED PLANE FLY HOME
description: BONN, Oct. 18Three West German terrorist leaders committed suicide early today in a maximumsecurity prison in Stuttgart hours after German commandos stormed a hijacked Lufthansa plane in Somalia and blocked an attempt to free them, Justice Ministry officials announced.

title: Phone Rate Rises In New York Take Effect in One Week
description: The New York Telephone yesterday filed a schedule of rates that will increase the basic monthly charge for a Manhattan customer with one telephone from $7.42 a month to $8.09. Bills to similar customers in other parts of the company's service area will go up by as much as 97 cents a month.

title: Ballet Classes for Children: What Should Parents Look For?
description: It used to be that piano lessons were de rlgueur for young ladies, but with the current popularity of dance many little girls go to ballet class, whether for posture or, increasingly, a chance at future stardom. But while the most damage an inept music teacher may cause is a lifelong aversion to Czerny, poor or premature ballet training can cause serious physical damage, according to experts.

title: CARTER AIDES OFFER NUCLEAR WASTE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Carter Administration unveiled a plan today for the Government to take over responsibility for the storage and disposal of spent fuel from atomic reactors, both in the United States and in foreign countries.

title: YOUNG MOST OPPOSED TO FORCED RETIREMENT
description: The strongest opposition to a mandatory retirement age is found among Americans under 25 years old, according to the results of a survey issued yesterday by the Conference Board.

title: How ABC Got to the Top
description: ABCTV, the new primetime champion that has knocked the rest of broadcasting into a tizzy of corporate reorganizing, has often been called, contemptuously but not unjustifiably, the juvenile network. Television observers had long contended that most programming was designed for 12yearolds. ABC appears to have brought the age target down to about 9, or perhaps even 8, on the shrewdly calculating theory that children will frequently determine which program the family watches in the early evening.

title: Canadian Dollar at New Low
description: TORONTO, Oct. 18 (UPI)The Canadian dollar fell to a new low today as traders on international money markets questioned the health of the nation's economy. In early dealing described as hectic by one trader, the dollar slipped below the level of 90 United States cents for the first time in nearly 40 years.

title: Deaths
description: ARONSONRose Beloved wife of the late Harry. Devoted mother of Harriet Burack and Lawrence. Loving grandmother of Herbert and Donna Burack, Hollace Goldsmith and Nancy Schapiro and great grandmother of Marissa and Matthew Goldsmith. Services at the Westchester Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Fleetwood, Mt. Vernon Thursday October 20 at 11 AM: In lieu of flowers please make contributions to the Mt. Vernon Chapter of Haddassah.

title: Arson Arrests in Massachusetts Laid to Victims Detective Work
description: BOSTON, Oct. 18The largest mass arrest since an arsonforhire epidemic years ago took place here yesterday bebegan sweeping the nation's cities three cause the arson victims banded together and did the basic detective work that arson squads across the country were unable or unwilling to do, Francis X. Bellotti, the Massachusetts attorney general, said here today.

title: PILOTS PLAN A STRIKE UNLESS THE U.N. ACTS
description: LONDON, Oct. 18The International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations called today for a 48hour strike, beginning at noon next Tuesday, unless the United Nations agreed to hold a meeting on ways to prevent hijacking and airborne terrorism.

title: Weather Service Decides, After Criticism, to Delay Change to Metric System
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)The National Weather Service has decided to delay a proposal under which temperature, wind speed, rainfall and other readings would have been converted to metric figures.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Enid Nemy.

title: Lance Draws Big A.B.A. Audience, But Little. Enthusiasm Is Shown
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 18Bert Lance was clearly the biggest drawing card at the American Bankers Association's convention here, despite some public and much private criticism by United States bankers of Mr. Lance's activities when he was a Genreia banker.

title: Food Stamps Good for a Meal Out
description: SALEM, ORE. Last week, Maurice Flood, a 62yearold arthritis sufferer, ate a hamburger, french fries and a piece of pie at a restaurant here.

title: Best Buys
description: WITH BIG holidays like Halloween, Guy Fawkes Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas still to come, the storekeepers seem to have mothballed their inventiveness in picking out sale items for food shoppers this wek.

title: Catholic Bishop Named in Texas
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 18 (ANPope Paul VI has appointed Bishop Bernard Ganter of Tulsa. Okla.. to be the new Bishop of Beaumont, Tex., Archbishop Jean Jadot, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, announced today. Bishop Ganter, 49 years old. succeeds Bishop Warren L. Boudreux, who was named last March to head the diocese of HoumaThibodaux, La.

title: Music: Balogh as of Yore
description: SEVEN SEASONS AGO, Endre Balogh, a Los Angeles violinist of Hungarian extraction, made an outstanding debut at Town Hall. One would have expected him to follow it up with another recital shortly thereafter, but it wasn't until Monday night that he made his second New York appearance, this time in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Books of The Times
description: AT THE END of this thoroughly beguiling biography of her grandfather, James A. H. Murray, the editor in chief of the great Oxford English Dictionary, K. M. Elisabth Murray makes the point that the dictionary had to be produced during the latter part of the 19th cen

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Tuesday, Oct. 13, 1977

title: KOCH VOWS TO GIVE CITY JOBS TO WOMEN
description: Women will get jobs at all levels New York City's government and there will be flexitime and parttime schedules for those whose family needs would conflict with unbudgeable work rules, Edward I. Koch said yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: THE new French Ambassador to the United States will be Francois Lefebvre de Laboulaye, official sources in Paris said yes terday. A former political adviser to the Foreign Ministry, he has also served in various diplomatic posts in Beirut, Ottawa and Washington, where ne was counselor at the Embassy. Mr. Lefebvre de Laboulaye will replace Jacques KosciuskoMorizet, who will retire from the diplomatic corps and run as a Gaullist candidate in the general elections next March.

title: A Growing Clamor for a WellFed World
description: THREE good years after the famous world food crisis of 1974, three years in which generally favorable rains have rolled back the specter of famine almost everywhere, popular interest in problems of the world food situation continues to grow and even shows signs of building into a longterm movement.

title: Music: 14thCentury Art
description: AS THE NOWVANISHED New York Pro Musics discovered years ago with The Play of Daniel and The Play of ????the most effective way of attracting audiences for medieval and Renciss Ince music's to incorporate in lavishly costumed theatrical presentations that involve movement on the part of the performers and, if possible, real or implied dramatic action.

title: Bing Crosby Buried After Private Services
description: CULVER CITY. Calif.,Oct. 18Bing Crosby was buried after daybreak today under a chilled, foggy sky after a requiem mass attended by his family and a few friends that began with an organ playing Too Ra Loo Ra Loo Ral and other Crosby hits.

title: Dollar Off Against Pound And Swiss Franc as Gold Tops $160 for Second Day
description: The dollar moved lower against a number of major currencies in foreignexchange trading yesterday, but the decline eased from the sharp and hectic selloff of earlier this week, The Associated Press reported.

title: O'HAGAN FREE TUITION UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: The New York City Investigation Department and the State Attorney General's office are investigating the relatianship between Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan and a Fire Foundation that paid for.his graduate studies at Columbia University.

title: Johnson Reportedly Prevented an Inquiry On Missing Uranium
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)Former President Johnson told Richard Helms, then Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, not to pursue an investigation cf why 400 pounds of bombgrade uranium was missing from a Pennsylvania fuel plant, the National Public Radio reported today.

title: Islanders, Kings Play to Scoreless Deadlock
description: UNIONDALE L.L, Oct. 18In New York's game with Los Angeles tonight the one played on iceneither team won. The Islanders and the Kings tripped and fumbled to the National Hockey League's first scoreless tie of the season: that came about because of fine. goaltending performance by Glenn Resch for, the Islanders and Rogie Vachon for the Kings rather then good defensive efforts. Resch .stopped 28 shots and Vachon stopped 41.

title: Music To Dine By
description: The music for a carefully cooked dinner should be selected as carefully and harmoniously as the various courses. Following is a suggestion for a program of music to accompany a formal dinner in the home. The name of the record ccmpany and the disk number follow the selections.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1977

title: What Drove CBS To Its Shakeup?
description: TWO NETWORKS now have answered their ratings deficiencies in the ritual wayby making what elevision executives call the inevitable human sacrifice.

title: About Real Estate
description: One day a guy came in and said, `I'm the new owner. rll fix up the lobby. I was all for it.

title: House Votes to Rescind Its Curb On Loans by International Banks
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 18The House of Representatives reluctantly reversed itself today and voted 229 to 195 to rescind its previous insistence that United States contributions to international banks not be lent to seven nations that have alIlegedly violated human rights.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 18 (AP)Ed Coester, port agent for the Sailors Union of the Pacific for 30 of the last 38 years, died here Sunday. He was 69 years old.

title: Toasts Around the Table on the Algonquin's 75th
description: We were more than mildly amused, a few hours ago, to find ourselves part of the crush in the decorous, oakpaneled lobby of the Algonquin Hotel, where more than 200 theater people, writers, artists, publishers and other emissaries of the creative persuasions mingled at the invitation of The New Yorker, yes, The New Yorker magazine. The occasion was the 75th anniversary of the hotel, where the absence of such lightsoftheRoundTable as Dorothy Parker, Robert Benchley, Alexander Woollcott and George S. Kaufman was as keenly felt as the presence of such contemporary luminaries as Mayor Abraham Beame, S. J. Perelman, Jean Stapleton, Peter deVries and Victor Borge.

title: Brzezinski, in Unusual Public Talk, Sees Soviet Relations on Upswing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  Zbigniew Brzezinski, the White House national security adviser, said today that relations with Moscow were on the upswing but he cautioned that the United States and the Soviet Union would remain competitors for a long time.

title: Dr. John H. Dunnington, ExHead Of Ophthalmological Society, at 83
description: Dr. John H. Dunnington, a past president of the American Ophthalmological Society who had been director of the Institute of Ophthalmology at the Presbyterian Hospital in the City of New York and head of that department at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died Monday at his home, 1120 Fifth Avenue. He was 83 years old.

title: SEPTEMBER WAGES CLIMBED $7.4 BILLION AS MINES REOPENED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP)Wages and salaries of Americans increased at faster pace in September as the coal strike ended and manufacturing payrolls grew larger, the Commer:e Department said today.

title: Jackson, the Player of the Series, Is Controversial and Charismatic
description: Reggie Jackson, basking in the adulation of his three home runs that helped he Yankees win the World Series last night, admitted in a tumultuous clublouse scene that there were times that this season was just too much for me.

title: F4 Phantom Jets Grounded
description: WASHINGTON,Oct. 18 (Reuters)The Air Force today grounded all its 1,800 F4 Phantom jet fighters while it checked for cracks and corrosion in tail stabilizer mechanism. The inspections were ordered after splits were discovered last weekend in the tail stabilizer sections of two Phantoms.

title: Gen. Ivan I. Fedyuninsky of Soviet Took Part in Defense of Leningrad
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 18 (AP)Gen. Ivan I. Fedyuninsky, who took part in the World War II defense of Leningrad and later was deputy commander of Soviet troops in East Germany, has died at the age of 77, Tass reported today.

title: ExPoliceman in Ulster Slain
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland. Oct. 18 (UPI)A retired policeman was killed today when suspected Irish Republican Army gunmen ambushed the taxi he was driving across a country bridge, the police said. The gunmen riddled the taxi with automatic fire at Keady, 40 miles southwest of Belfast, and it plunged into the stream below.

title: Deaths
description: MOOREThomas F. on Oct 17, 1977. Husband of Jane Amber Moore, father of Marian K. Morgan and Dennis C. Moore. Retired from Allied Chemical, Solvay Process Division. Services private. Contributions to the Scarsdale Volunteer Ambulance Corp.

title: No Progress Is Reported In L.I.R.R. Talks in Face Of a Threatened Walkout
description: MINEOLA, Oct. 18The possibility of a Long Island Rail Road strike Thursday remained alive today as no progress was reported, in talks between the line and its unions.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey's press secretary, James S. Vlasto, announced yesterday that he was quitting at the end of the year because he finds it difficult to get by on his $47,800 salary. Although Mr. Carey praised Mr. Vlasto as a trusted adviser and friend, it is known that the two men have had differences in recent months.

title: Leaders of Longshoremen Meeting in Florida Today As Dock Strike Continues
description: Thomas W. Gleason, president of the striking. International Longshoremen's Association, has called a meeting of the union's executive council and top officers for tomorrow in Bal Harbour. Fla.

title: Shipping Group to Pay $1 Million To U.S. for Oil Spill Off Nantucket
description: A shipping group's agreement to pay S1.1 million to the Federal Government was announced yesterday at the opening of a trial designed to determine why the Liberian tanker Argo Merchant ran aground last Dec. 15 off Nantucket Island.

title: Rockefeller Sale Stirs Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller is apparently shaking the dust of Washington from his feet at lastbut many of his neighbours don't like the fallout. He is planning to sell his 25acre estate, on one of the city's most verdant and affluent streets, for development in what one opponent described as a tickytacky, if highpriced, concept 90 to 130 houses set on checkerboard lots.

title: REV. HARRY SIEVERS, DEAN AT FORDHAM U.
description: The Rev. Harry J. Sievers, a Jesuit priest and dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Fordham University, died Tuesday night after collapsing in his office on the university's Bronx campus. He was 56 years old.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SILVER,SCREENINGS A real bargain for movie buffs is tomorrow's free midtown screening of Reunion in Vienna (1933)4 adapted from Robert E. Sherwood's Broadway hit, with John Barrymore and Diana Wynyard in the roles originated by Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne. The 7:30 P.M. event, which includes a discussion led by Stanley Kauffmann, the film critic, is part of the current program, 42d Street/Theater and the City, at City University's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. The screening will take place in the auditorium.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: CAIRO FIRM ON A ROLE FOR P.L.O. AT GENEVA
description: CAIRO, Oct. 19Egypt has proposed that a United StatesIsraeli formula for reconvening the Geneva conference on the Middle East be amended to specify that the Palestine Liberation Organization should be a participant.

title: Abducted German Industrialist Found Slain in France
description: BONN, Oct. 19The body of HarmsMartin Schleyer, the West German industrial leader who was kidnapped Sept. 5, was found today in the trunk of an abandoned Car in the eastern French city of Mulhouse.

title: ExRCA Chairman Gets Hearing Order
description: Anthony L. Conrad, former board chairman of the RCA Corporation, has been ordered to appear at a state hearing in Baltimore next month that will decide whether to grant a New York extradition request, New York State's Assistant Attorney General, Moses Weintraub, said here yesterday.

title: PhiladelphiaZoo Adds Flamingos to Exhibit
description: PHILDELPHIA,Oct. 19 (UPI)The Phildelphia Zoo, where 10 flamingos were stoned to death last spring, put on exhibit today 30 other flamingos the zoo has obtained from Kenya.

title: Nassau Sells Insured Bonds
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19 (UPI)Nassau County held its first insured bond sale today to raise $20 million for construction at Nassau Community College. The bonds, insured by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, were sold to a consortium headed by Bankers Trust Company at an interest rate of 5.5 percent.

title: Carey Doubts Any Action on Control Board This Year
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that a restructuring of the state's Emergency Financial Control Board, the fiscal monitor for New York City, might be too cumbersome for a special legislative session and, in any case, should wait for word from the new city administration.

title: FARMERS IN NEWYORK HURT BY HEAVY RAINS
description: ALBANY. Oct. 19Heavy fall rains have caused crop losses estimated at tens of millions of dollars in western New York State. Thousands of acres of potatoes, onions, sweet corn, dry beans and beets have been abandoned because farmers have not been able to go into soggy fields to harvest them and farm equipment has been mired in mud.

title: Concorde Lands at Kennedy As Its Proving Flights Begin
description: After a 19month battle, the supersonic Concorde airliner made its maiden flight into New York yesterday with modest noise, no organized demonstrators to greet it and nonpaying officials and test teams as its only passengers.

title: NEW &USEFUL
description: Pottery used to be a hobby for David Heger, while he was teaching Hebrew at the Dalton School. When the school cut down its language department and left him without a job, his hobby was a natural thing to turn to as a second career. Friends encouraged him to show his pottery to stores, and almost immediately he was launched. Mr. Heger's clay baskets, bowls and other containers are all taken from nature. He first makes plaster molds into which he impresses the texture of a cabbage leaf, say, or a piece of wood, and then presses the clay into the textured plaster. When the pieces are finished, the unglazed terra cotta containers look as if they have been fashioned out of a bundle of leaves or woven together with bark and twigs. His work ranges in price from about $5 to $100, and can be found at Accents & Images, 972 Second Avenue (between 51st and 52d Streets); Ed Stiffler, 1190 Third Avenue (between 69th and 70th Streets), and in the main floor Tabletops department at Henri Bendel.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced today the recall of 48,000 Mack trucks for replacement of engine colling fans. The agency also announced the Investigations of alleged safety defects in 197074 model MG Midgets manufactured by British Leyland Motors and in 197172 Mercury Capris manufactured in Germany by the Ford Motor Company.

title: TV: Interviewer Cayett Cute as Ever
description: DICK CAVETT'S back, public television's got him and now all someone has to figure out is what they're supposed to do with each other. As a joint venture of WNET/13 and Daphne Productions, The Dick Cavett Show, carried weeknights on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock, is a talk show in the familiar rut of minimum substance surrounded by plugs for guests latest ventures.

title: CLIFFORD L. PORTER, 61, AN EXPERT ON TAX LAW
description: Clifford L. Porter, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel and a leading tax authority, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I., after making his home, for many years in Fort Washineton. L.I.

Kent State Protester Is Recalled From Ohio Council
description: BARBERTON, Ohio, Oct. 19Alan Canfora, his right wrist long since healed from the gunshot wound of May 4. 1970, had just finished a dish of ice cream as he watched a television screen to see if the New York Yankees were going to reward the bet he had just made with a friend. But the slogan on his scarlet Tshirt told where his mind really was Long live the spirit of Kent and Jackson State! it proclaimed.

title: Triumphant Yankees Revel in Unabashed Adulation
description: Broadway, for nearly a mile from Bowling Green to City Hall, was a huge smile and triumphal shout yesterday as hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers staged one of the city's most memorable tickertape parades to honor the New York Yankees for their first World Series victory in 15 years.

title: Deak Faces Charges of Smuggling.
description: A Federal grand jury in San Francisco yesterday returned a 382count indictment against beak & Company of California, the West Coast arm of the currency exchange and investment banking firm. A former vice president of Deak of California was also named in the indictment.

title: LEON LOVINGTON
description: SHELTON, Conn.,Oct. 19 (AP)  Leon Lovington, who in 1914 founded the Lovington Aircraft concern on Staten Island, N.Y., with his brother, Joseph, died yesterday in Stratford. He was 81 years old. Mr. Lovington had worked as a mechanic and flight operations manager.

title: Latest Crop Reports Reflect Heavy Rains
description: ALBANY, Oct. 19Following is a summary of the latest reports from the western part of the state, as compiled by the New York State Crop Reporting Service and the Commissioner of Agriculture's office:

description: Carl M. Mueller, who was relieved as chief executive officer of Loeb, Rhoades & Company last August by John L Loeb, the 74 year old cofounder and chairman of the brokerage and investment banking firm, resigned as president on Tuesday to become vice chairman of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOSTON, BOSTON, Oct. 19The defense in the Wampanoag Indian land suit trial attempted to show today that the Indians second witness, who describes himself as a member of the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe, was actually descended from blacks and mulattoes.

description: MICHAEL DAVIS has shipped a gypsy caravan to Oklahoma, a Messerschmitt to Atlanta, and the bronze lions from Mentmore to Texas. He is an antiques shipper who has been trying to take the pain, suspense and financial guesswork out of importing antique? from England.

title: Corporate Status Index Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The Commerce Department plans to publish a social performance index for corporations to show how well they meet such social needs as minority hiring and environmental controls, the Secretary of Commerce, Juanita M. Kreps, announced today.

title: Agriculture Aide Warns of Harm In Certain French Liver Pastes
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 19 (AP)The Agriculture Department issued a warning today that consumers should be alert to some potentially harmful imported liver paste products from France.

title: DISSIDENT'S SON REFUSES TO ENTER SOVIET ARMY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 19The 18yearold son of Vladimir Slepak, a prominent dissident, refused induction into the Soviet Army today, thereby risking a threeyear prison sentence.

title: POLICE FOIL ESCAPE TRY IN COMMANDEERED BUS
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., Oct. 19 (AP A bus commandeered by several state prison inmates ran through three police roadblocks today before, being stopped at a fourth when shots were fired at the bus, the authorities said.

title: Backgammon:
description: Nothing is more exasperating in backgammon than to have a gammon within your grasp, only to be hit in the bearoff. By making the proper percentage play, the skillful player finds himself, less often bemoaning such accidents. The situation described here occurs frequently in practice, yet, surprisingly, few players know the correct procedure.

description: BONN, Oct. 19The body of HannsMartin Schleyer, the West German industrial leader who was kidnapped Sept. 5, was found today in the trunk of an abandoned car in the eastern French city of Mulhouse.

title: Taking a Lighthearted Step Toward Spring
description: SO WHAT'S in store for fashion this spring? Before many women have picked out their winter coats, the fashion industry is tooling up for the next season. Italian readytowear producers made their move in Milan last week. Next week, it's Paris's turn. But, sandwiched between the two, some Seventh Avenue houses opened their collections this week. There were to be more, but with all the action in Europe, some designers postponed their shows.

title: Body of Woman,77, Found In Woods Near Her Home In Westchester County
description: WHITE PLAINS,Oct. 19  Sarah Brownlie, the 77yearold woman who had been missing since Oct. 7 and whose body was found yesterday in a heavily wooded area about two and a half miles north of her North Saiem home, died of natural causes, the County Medical Examiner's Office reported today. She had apparently been dead at least a week.

title: West German Property Attacked in Italy and France
description: Radicals attacked West German property in cities across Italy and France yesterday to avenge the deaths of three terrorist leaders in their German prison cells.

title: Pilots to Picket U.N.
description: LONDON, Oct. 19A number of national pilots associations decided today to picket the United Nations in New York on Friday.

title: The Two Seasons of Reggie Jackson
description: Nearly three hours after his three home runs had won the World Series for the Yankees and redemption for himself, Reggie Jackson, like almost everyone else, appeared in awe of what he had accomplished. There's a part of me I don't know, he was saying softly at his locker. There's the ballplayer in me who responds to all that pressure. I'm not sure I hit three home runs but the ballplayer me did.

description: WEDNESDAY. OCTOBER 19. 1977

title: Yadin Party Moving to Join Begin
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 19 (AP)Prime Minister Menahem Begin won a political victory today when the leaders of a major centrist party voted to join his coalition Government.

title: HOUSE INQUIRY GETS MORE KOREA DETAILS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The longawaited hearings by the House ethics committee on its Korean investigation got off to a slow start this afternoon when witnesses went over previous evidence of the South Korean Government's covert plans to influence the American Congress.

title: Y outh,17, Hangs Himself In Adolescent Center Cell At Rikers Island Facility
description: A 17yearold Queens youth hanged himself yesterday in a Department of Correction building on Rikers Island, a department spokesman said.

title: Film: Goodbar Turns Sour
description: LOOKING for Mr. Goodbar, Richard Brooks's film version of Judith Rossner's novel, is about a lonely woman who hangs around singles bars and one night takes home a stranger who, after sex, stabs her to death because she won't let him sleep till morning. At least, that's what I think it's about because I doubt very much if Mr. Brooks would have made the movie. if the girl had been just as arbitrarily murdered on the street at 10 A.M. by a psychopath who didn't like the color of her pantyhose.

title: About New York
description: After a few geese were scared up and away from the runway by firecrackers, the Concorde left the sky and brought to earth an experience that was more asthetic than aural.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday reported Incorrectly that advance registration was not necessary to testify at hearings on school food scheduled for Oct. 25. Registration Is required and can be completed by calling, in New York, (800) 2579111, in Connecticut (800) 2251127 and, in New Jersey, (800) 7928088. The place of the hearings was also incorrectly reported. They will take place in Room 305A of the Federal Building at 26 Federal Plaza from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Fire Shuts Down Refinery
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Oct. 19 (UPI)The Chevron refinery here was shut down yesterday by a power failure. Officials said a short circuit had cut the power and had caused a small but smoky fire in a furnace.

title: World News Briefs
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Oct. 19 (Reuters) The military Government of Bangladesh has executed 37 members of the army and air force as having taken part in an unsuccesful coup Oct. 2, officials Sources said today.

title: CHARLES HARRIS COOKE, AUTHOR AND EDITOR, 73
description: Charles Harris Cooke, an author, magazine editor and former staff writer on The New Yorker, died Tuesday at his home in Cooperstown, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Drivers of mopeds, the popular motorized bicycles, will have to be licensed by the state, obtain insurance and be at least 15 years old under terms of legislation signed yesterday by Governor Byrne. Drivers will be required to take a test, under the law.

title: Jersey High Court Tells Officials To Observe Sunshine Law Strictly
description: TRENTON, Oct. 19The New Jersey Supreme Court, in its first definitive opinion on the state's socalled Sunshine Law, ruled today that to comply substantially with the law, which requires government to be in the open, is not sufficient, and that it had to be strictly observed.

title: Wife Denies Soviet Dissident Is Spy
description: Natalya Shteiglitz Shcharansky has not seen her husband, Anatoly, since she left for Israel the day after their Moscow marriage on July 4, 1973. But it is an absolute absurdity, she said here yesterday, that he is accused of spying for the C.I.A. and has been imprisoned for the last seven months.

title: Trunks Double Up And Pack It In
description: In the jet age, people travel light and leave their troubles at home preferably in a trunk. Whether in gleaming chrome or wicker or standard black, the trunk hasn't packed it in as a useful item. In fact, the welltravelled truck has come home to roost, enjoying a new lease on life as a space saver that can double as a table.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS LAUNCH MAJOR DRIVE
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 19Leftist guerrillas in Nicaragua have started a major offensive against the armybacked Government of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, whose family has ruled this Central American republic for the last 41 years.

title: New York Farmers Lose Millions As Fall Rains Flood Upstate Fields.
description: ALBANY, Oct. 19Heavy rains this fall have caused crop losses estimated at tens of millions of dollars in western New York State, according to state agricultural officials. Thousands of acres of potatoes, onions, sweet corn, dry beans and beets have been abandoned because farmers have not been able to go into soggy fields to harvest them and farm equipment has been mired in mud.

title: Courting Disaster in South Africa
description: The South African Government seems determined to create precisely those conditions that will transform its largely moderate black opposition into an extremist and violent force. In a concerted, nationwide predawn crackdown yesterday, South Africa's white rulers banned virtually every major black organization, closed the two leading black newspapers, raided the homes of black leaders and the offices of black movements and church bodies, detained more than 50 leaders, and ordered official ostracism for some of their white sympathizers.

title: 4% JOBLESS FIGURE DISTURBING TO CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Discussions between White House domestic strategists and supporters of the HumphreyHawkins full employment bill continued here today, nearly a month after President Carter promised to announce his endorsement within a week to 10 days.

title: Dance: Pearl Lang Opens Umbrella
description: THE DANCE UMBRELLA has found itself a new umbrella stand. This sheltering, but independent, cooperative for moderndance companies started its life at the Roundabout Theater on West 23d Street. Now it has moved farther downtown, to the Entermedia Theater on Second Avenue at 12th Street.

title: A.T.&T. PLANS OFFER OF 12 MILLION SHARES IN A SURPRISE MOVE
description: In a surprise move, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans for a public offering around Nov. 9 of 12 million common shares, an action valued at more than $700 million.

title: N.H.L. Fines Vancouver Coach
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 19 (UPI)The National Hockey League fined Arnie Brown, an assistant coach for the Vancouver Canucks, $100 today for screaming at a referee, Denis Morel, following the game between the Canucks and the Detroit Red Wings last night. A league spokesman said Morel had denied news reports that he was physically attacked by Brown. But Morel said Brown had engaged in verbal exchanges that continued until Morel reached his dressing room.

title: Newark Was Never in SST Running
description: NEWARKThroughout the controversy over whether the Concorde should land in New York, Newark International Airport, which would welcome the business, has never been a serious contender as an alternative site for the supersonic airliner.

title: LAWYER NAMED TRUSTEE FOR UNITED MERCHANTS
description: William Golub, a New York attorney, was named yesterday as standby trustee for United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., currently operating under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Friedman, president of Formica Corporation, has announced the company's new design program and the appointment of 17 leading American architects and designers including, from New York, Alan Buchsbaum, Charles Boxenbaum, Joseph D'Urso, Charles Morris Mount, Tony Moses, Billy McCarty, John Saladino, Barbara Ross and Barbara Schwartz, Paul Segal and Gamal ElZoghby. From out of town, there are Bruce Gregga, Richard W. Hobbs, Norton Juster, Margaret Larcade, Don Singer and William Turnbull Jr.
