description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing.

title: N.C. A. A. Opposes Parts of Sports Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 , (UPI)The National Collegiate Athletic Association objected today to proposed legislation aimed at making the United States Olympic Committee the coordinator for all domestic sports and providing ways to resolve disputes between sports organizations.

title: Let Next Year Wait
description: The perils of winter, strikes and municipal bankruptcy will chill us soon enough, but put it all aside. Let the Dodgers wait till next year; let next year wait. The Yankees have given us much to celebrate and to savor:

title: The Prize Is His, and de Groote Takes. His Detractors in Stride
description: STEVEN DE GROOTE entered a piano competition the other day and won not only the first prize of $10,000, but also two years of unemployment insurance. In the next two years, the South Africanborn musician will play concerts and recitals all around the world as part of the spoils he earned by capturing the Fifth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth. His datebook includes, for instance, solo engagements with 25 orchestras of major and not so major importance, a Carnegie Hall recital on Dec. 12, a London debut and tours of Europe, the Far East and Brazil.

title: Gerald Ford Urging Early Cut in Taxes
description: Former president Gerald R. Ford yesterday urged a $20 billion to $25 billion annual tax cut and called on the Carter Administration to seek action on it immediately, rather than wait until Congress reconvenes next January.

title: U. S. Assails Moves, Warns on Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Carter Administration said today that it was deeply disturbed about the crackdown by the South African Government on blacks and their supporters and warned that the latest actions had implications for future South African relations with the United States.

title: Some Experts Advice for Fearful Fixers
description: Large numbers of people repair their cars when they won't run and their toasters when they won't toast, but there are many who view doing it themselves with trepidation. A recent conference at Stanford University explored this, and offered ways of overcoming it.

title: Text of the South African Statement on Restrictions
description: JOHANNESBURG. Oct. 19Following is the text of Justice Minister James T. Kruger's statement on banflings and detentions of Government opponents issued today.

title: Waiting for Reggie Turns Out to Be an East Side Flop
description: The Chipmunk was waiting for Reggie Jackson. Jersey Joe was waiting for Reggie Jackson. John the Hog and Goosedown Gary were waiting for Reggie Jackson. The Playboy Club bunnies, Bunny Bander and Bunny Spill, were waiting for Reggie Jackson, and, once he'd got his cab precisely double parked so that it blocked both a Lincoln Continental and a ramshackle van, Michael J. Nolan, was waiting for Regaie Jackson, too.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Metropolitan Golf Halted By Lightning, Hail Storm
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 19Lightning and hail disrupted today the second round of the 51st championship of the Metropolitan section of the Professional Golfers Association at the Winged Foot Golf Club. The 54hole tournament now is scheduled to finish Friday instead of tomorrow.

title: Advertising
description: A business executive accustomed to making multimilliondollar decisions on the basis of consumer research would have left the twoday annual conference of the Advertising Research Foundation rather shaken. Just too much honest talk about error and the need for a code of ethics.

title: Senate Sends ForeignAid Bill, With Curbs, to the White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (Reuters)The Senate completed Congressional action today on a $6.7 billion foreignaid bill containing prohibitions on military and economic aid to various countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. The measure was sent to the White House for signature.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Officer Says It Weighs Bid to Congress For Wider Import Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Lane Kirkland, secretarytreasurer of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today that the Federation may ask Congress for new trade legislation imposing quota restrictions on a broad range of imports.

title: Carey Bond Issue on Economic Aid Is Ruled Illegal
description: Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds to promote economic development was ruled unconstitutionally broad and ordered off the ballot yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Albany.

title: International Bank Fraud Scheme Is Broken
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation says that Federal indictments have ended an international scheme that included attempts to defraud six United States banks, to buy a Kentucky coal company and to swindle the late Elvis Presley.

title: Godfrey Dewey at 90, an Educator; Got 1932 Olympics for Lake Placid
description: Godfrey Dewey, an exponent of simplified spelling and the man credited with bringing the winter Olympic games to Lake Placid, N.Y., in 1932, died Tuesday in Placid Memorial Hospital in Lake Placid. He was 90 years old and a resident of Lake Placid.

title: Bad Medicine for Medical Schools
description: Congress is groping toward a facesaving compromise on an issue that has the nation's medical schools in high feverthe Federal Government's insistence that the schools admit hundreds of Americans who enrolled in foreign medical schools after being rejected for admission here. Last year, with virtually no debate, Congress approved a bill that forces every medical school to accept its share of American students who have completed two years of foreign study and passed a written examination.

title: Chicago's Greeting to Charles Fit for a King
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19Charles the Prince of Wales began a 10day American tour here today with a generous helping of Middle Western hospitality as a throng of cheering and waving wellwishers jammed city streets to catch a glimpse of the heir to the British throne.

title: New Music Contest Has U.S. Note
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19In an effort to stimulate the performance of music written by American composers, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Rockefeller Foundation announced today the establishment of an annual international competition for musicians.

title: Triumphant Yankees Revel in Unabashed Adulation
description: Broadway, for nearly a mile from Bowling Green to City Hall, was a huge smile and triumphal shout yesterday as hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers staged one of the city's most memorable tickertape parades to honor the New York Yankees for their first World Series victory in 15 years.

title: Deal With Somalia Denied
description: BONN, Oct. 19The West German Government indicated today that it would continue furnishing equipment and other aid to Somalia, but denied reports in some European newspapers that such assistance was the price for the Somali consent to yesterday's West German commondo raid.

title: Police Trying to Unravel Mystery Of New York GemBroker Killing
description: Three weeks after the body of Pinchos Jaroslawicz was found stuffed in a box in the Manhattan office of a diamondcutter, New York City detectives are still trying to unravelwith no reported success so farthe mystery of who killed the 25yearold diamond broker and what happened to the $1 million in gems he was carrying.

title: U.N.Makes Plans Against Air Piracy In Face of a Strike
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19Diplomats and United Nations officials moved here today to try to galvanize the General Assembly to take more stringent measures against air piracy and the taking of hostages.

title: After the Terror
description: The world's airline pilots are considering a twoday strike next week unless the United Nations General Assembly puts air piracy on its agenda for early action. That is an understandable reaction to the wave of airliner hijackings that culminated Sunday in the murder of the captain of the illfated Lufthansa Flight 181. While the world cheered the spectacular rescue of its passengers and most of the crew, the pilots mourned their German colleague, Jiirgen Schumann, and rightly demand to be spared his fate.

title: BaaderMeinh of How Come? What's Next?
description: LONDON  The hijackers have failed; except for the Lufthansa pilot. their hostages have survived; Ulrike Meinhof hanged herself last year, and now Andreas Baader and the hard core of their gang are dead (and the German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, has earned just praise for his nerve and sense of responsibility from many Darts of the world). But two questions remain. One is, what next? It is a practical question and I for one am pleased that it is, in West Germany and elsewhere, in the hands of known defenders of freedom and the rule of law. The other question is, how could terrorism reach such proportions in West Germany in the first place? We are all groping, but unless we understand, we shall be unable to cope.

title: Montrealer Admits Counterfeiting
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 19 (AP)A Montreal man has pleaded guilty to charges of having counterfeited $2.5 million in United States money. JulesAime Simard, 38 years old, said he and five other persons had conspired to produce the counterfeit funds125,000 bills in denominations of $20between May 1976 and February 1977. Judge PaulEmile Fortin set sentencing for Dec. 19.

title: L.I. Man Is Called a War Criminal.
description: An Israeli witness in tightly guarded immigration hearing room in Manhattan pointed out a silent, bespectacled 73yearold Long Island man yesterday as the former Latvian guard he said he saw beating Jews at the Riga ghetto in the summer of 1941.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pler), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Nissan Lifts U.S. Datsun Prices By Average cf $148 Per Car
description: The Nissan Motor Company of Tokyo said yesterday that its United States subsidiary, to Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A., had raised the retail prices of its 1978model Datsun cars in the United States by an average 3.3 percent, or $148, per car.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WARNS ITS PRESS ON DISSENT
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19The telephone rang in Percy Qoboza's tiny bungalow in Soweto at 5:25 A.M. today.

title: Concorde to Tower: A Question on Noise

title: Kenneth G. Merriam, ExProfessor At Institute in Worcester, 75
description: Kenneth G. Merriam, professor emeritus of mechanical engineering at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, died Monday in his home in Worcester, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHAT IS THE ANSWER? The answer is protein. Well, then, what is the question? The question is: Why? Why war, sexism, the nationstate, the energy crisis, the Oedipus complex and everything else that makes us feel bad? According to Marvin Harris, a Columbia University anthropologist and the author, previously, of Cows, Pigs, Wars and Witches: The Riddles of Culture, we have been going downhill since the Stone Age. Paleolithic man (and woman) got along just fine on a combination of animal protein and infanticide, working just three or four hours a day. When, at the end of the Pleistocene epoch, the megafauna disappeared, not even an infanticide rate as high as 50 percent could maintain an adequate diet for all of the available people.

title: Rangers Take 39 Shots, Tie Penguins, 33
description: The Rangers played one of those games last night. You know, like a boxing bout where one guy throws a million punches and then gets knocked out with one punch, or a baseball game where one team outhits the other but ends up losing.

title: GARDENING
description: ONCE there was a lovely stand of aspen down by the stone wall on our south meadow. Last week, when my eyes wandered in that direction. I noticed that the grove seemed much thinner than before, and two of the trees were inclined at a most rakish angle. Now aspen are soft, brittle trees, and we've had quite a few windstorms in the past few weeks, but still. . . .

Cuomo drew applause for his support for special opportunities for persons who had suffered special oppression.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The more populous states of the North have emerged as the economic losers in the Senate's debate on how to reshape the President's energy proposals.

title: ExOpium Army Now Cultivates Tea in Thailand
description: MAE SALONG, ThailandOn this mountaintop in Thailand's northernmost corner, with Burma in sight and Laos not far away, Yee Tien Lwi receives visitors with cups of tea and Chinese dumplings.

Y., Federation of Teachers, pleaded guilty to charges of contempt of court during the second day of the trial in White Plains of eight Lakeland teachers. He said he had changed his plea because the Lakeland school board will not negotiate until I'm behind bars.

title: DOW DECLINES BY 8.31 TO 812,20, LOWEST SINCE OCTOBER 1975

description: The Dow Chemical Company, the nation's thirdlargest chemical compny, reported yesterday a 13.4 percent drop on thirdquarter earnings despite an 11 percent sales increase.

title: Expatriate Rejects Autumn in New York
description: WHY DID I move to the country, an overcivilized woman like me? my friend asks rhetorically. I suppose that, after the life I've led, I need air. You know when a woman faints in the street in New York, the policemen always push back the crowd and say, Give her air. Give the lady some air. My memories were beginning to crowd me out of my apartmentit was like an autobiographical warehouse. Now I can spread them out on the grass to dry. The country is the only place for nostalgia. For me, It's always autumn in Connecticut.

title: Democrats in Ocean and Monmouth Races Believe AntiTax Sentiment Has Faded
description: FREEHOLDWith a growing population of elderly and retired homeowning citizens among their constituents, most of whom benefit from the state income tax, Democrats in the legislative races in Ocean and Monmouth Counties are convinced that the strong sentiment against income tax that existed a year ago has been stemmed, perhaps reversed.

title: Targets of Curbs in South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19Following is a partial list of organizations banned by the South African Government and of individuals banned or detained. A full list was not released.

And for three players to have such an opportunity on the same trick could be unique. But it happened in the recent Summer Nationals in Chicago on the diagramed deal.

description: Housewife! Superstar!!, the oneman show by the Australian comedian Barry Humphries, gives new depths to the phrase Down Under. It is abysmal.

title: The Bakke Case: Old Allies Split
description: Now that the case of the University of California v. Bakke has been delivered to the minds of the nation's highest judges, blacks and their allies have begun to look back at the wreckage strewn along the road to the Supreme Court. They are most troubled by the splintering of many of the fundamental agreements about injustice in America that made the old, civil rights coalitions possible. The end of a general consensus on such issues whether affirmative action programs designed only to cure past discrimination as many whites believe, or whether, blacks insist, they are also needed to combat present discrimination, has made many black leaders pessimistic about the possibility of any early revitalization the old, broad civil rights coalition.

As home buyers often discover, the cheapest solution would have been to look for another house, or else to call in the demolition crew and build from scratch. But Joyce and Seward Johnson Jr. of Princeton, N. J , not only decided to go ahead with the purchase, they kept the house  a rambling twostory summer and weekend place typi: cal of shinglestyle houses in Massachusetts coastal towns.

description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 19 (UPI)William (Will) Joseph Carruthers, a sportswriter, was found dead at his home today of an apparent heart attack. He was 71 years old. Mr. Carruthers was a sportswriter with the Memphis Press Scimitar for 34 years before joining the Memphis Blues, an affiliate of the New York Mets baseball organization, in 1967. He became vice president and general manager of the club.

title: Hers
description: IAM TIRED of reading about women and their mothers. Oh, there is validity to it. After all, we are all daughters, we were all bonded to and immensely affected by our mothers, and many of us are now ourselves mothers of daughters. There is, I am sure, a consuming effort in our maternal introspections not to repeat the mistakes our mothers made with us, but to make up our own mistakes instead.

title: The Screen: A Curious Biography:Filled With Demons
description: WRITERS ARE notoriously poor subjects for biographical study. If the writer's life warrants close scrutiny at all, chances are that he or she was articulate enough to have dealt with the most interesting facets already, and that few biographers will be canny enough to develop a perspective more valuable than the author's. Malcolm Lowry is a case in point: Mr. Lowry captured a far more vivid sense of his own demons in "Under the Volcano," his one great novel, than the one evidenced by a new film biography entitled "Volcano: An Inquiry Into the Life of Malcolm Lowry."The film, made by Donald Brittain with John Kramer and showing at Cinema III, documents Mr. Lowry's life in a curious manner. Key events, such as the 1957 inquest that deemed his having choked drunkenly on his own vomit as "death by misadventure," are re-enacted for the camera, but they are staged too vaguely to have much impact, and too literally to cast any new light. To illustrate the fact that Mr. Lowry's house burned down, for example, the camera simply lingers over footage of another modern-day house on fire. To show that his book was successful, the camera whisks across rows of shelves filled with paperback copies.As the film often indicates, Mr. Lowry was a difficult character, an alcoholic so desperate that he would drink after-shave lotion when nothing more palatable was at hand. He was a hard man for even his friends and family to love, but his talents were extraordinary enough to make people forgive him his drunken excesses.The film attempts to suggest the scope of Mr. Lowry's writing, mostly through unidentified voice-over passages read eloquently by Richard Burton, but it in no way makes the genius seem as palpable as the unpleasantness. What remains is the portrait of a tragic and disagreeable man with many patient, all-forgiving friends.Mr. Brittain has made other biographical films, about people as diverse as Leonard Cohen and Henry Ford 2d, and he has also worked as a police reporter. His experience in the latter field is apparent in the thoroughness with which he reels off details of limited consequence: an old schoolmaster of Mr. Lowry's recalls that the boy slouched in class, and Mr. Brittain's narration adds that Mr. Lowry had small hands, was chronically constipated, and had a physique that made him a figure of fun on bath night among the other boys at school.Mr. Brittain's attention to fact, combined with his obvious desire to lend the film an impressionistic air, produces a strange sort of sloppiness. Chronology is sometimes sketchy, and many of the numerous people interviewed in the film go unidentified. Often this doesn't matter, but it does pose problems at times. "He chose to live as he did, and he produced 'Under the Volcano,'" says one man. "I chose to live differently, and I didn't produce anything much." "Well, that's not true," insists another voice off-screen. Maybe not, but how can we be sure if the man we're watching hasn't been properly introduced?"Volcano" presupposes a certain knowledge of Mr. Lowry's work on the part of the viewer, but it isn't really a film for Lowry scholars: there are few photos of the man here, little new information, and no insights not already provided by his work. Some of the interviews, notably one with Margerie Lowry, the author's widow, are quite moving at times, and the images of Mr. Lowry at his most grotesque are stark and mesmerizing. But a viewer who knew nothing about Mr. Lowry at the outset might come away wondering at the disparity between the caliber of the man's work and the wretchedness of his life. Mr. Brittain's "Inquiry" never satisfactorily addresses his single most important issue.

title: Jets to Work On Caster

The Jets are hopeful that their star wide receiver, who has been recuperating from broken hand, can go over the middle against the Oakland Raiders at Shea Stadium Sunday.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (UPI)  The House of Representatives voted today to spend $80 million to keep alive Tennessee's Clinch River nuclear reactor, which President Carter opposes because of its plutoniumcreating process.

title: U.S. Woman Says Ruse Saved the Hostages
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 19A ruse spared the lives of the hostages rescued by West German commandos yesterday from a hijacked plane in Somalia, an American woman said here today.

title: German Commando Leader Is a Stickler for Perfection
description: BONN Oct. 19When Lieut. Col. Ulrich Wegener learned five years ago that he had been chosen to build a West German commando force to combat terrorism, the lanky, craggyfaced veteran of World War II asked Israelis to give him intensive paratrooper training.

title: SARAH GREENBERG, AT 65, A BLIND ROBBERY VICTIM
description: Sarah Greenberg, a 65yearold blind woman who had been robbed five times in her little newspaperstationery store on Morningside Heights during the early 1970's, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital after suffering a stroke.

title: AbdulJabbar Breaks Hand in Fight
description: Kareem AbdulJabbar, the Los Angeles Lakers 7foot2inch center and the National Basketball Association's most valuable player in five of his eight pro seasons, suffered a fractured bone in his right hand Tuesday night. The injury occurred when AbdulJabbar hit and floored Kent eBnson, the Milwaukee Bucks 611 center, in the first period of the game.

title: Senate Panel Approves Judge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee approved the nomination today of Federal District Judge Damon J. Keith of Detroit to be a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. The committee also recommended Senate confirmation of the nomination of Eugene H. Nickerson to be a Federal judge for the eastern district of New York.

title: Drugs Reported in Blood of Presley
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 19 (AP)Ten drugs were present in Elvis Presley's bloodstream when he died in August and they probably contributed to his death, a published report said today.

title: Four of Six Unbeaten Eastern Elevens May Suffer Defeat on Saturday
description: Six of the 70 Eastern College Athletic Conference Division III smallcollege football teams are undefeated and untied so far, although four of this standout group may suffer their first defeats of 1977 this Saturday. The perfeet six are Massachusetts Maritime, Franklin and Marshall, Rochester and Upsala, with five victories apiece, and Middlebury and Wesleyan, with four victories each.

title: RUTH NORDEN LOWE
description: Ruth Norden Lowe, an associate editor of The American Journal of Psychotherapy in New York City, died Tuesday at her home, 10 Downing Street, after a short illness. She was 71 years old.

title: Cuban Oil Products, Despite Ban, Said Trickling Into U.S. Markets
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct 19At least a trickle of Cuban petroleum products has reached markets in the United States over the last several months despite Washington's long  standing embargo against trade with the Government of President Fidel Castro.

title: Family Money: How to Cut the Cost of Heating Oil
description: HOME heating oil prices have jumped from around 43 cents a gallon to about 49 cents gallon since the beginning of the year and are likely to continue right on rising as winter bites deeper.

title: Schleyer, Key Figure in Industry, Once a Top SS Official in Prague
description: BONN, Oct. 19When HannsMartin Schleyer, the bullnecked, chainsmoking automobile executive who was abducted by terrorists in Cologne on Sept. 5 and was found dead today at age 62, became president of the West German employers and industry federations last year, a newsman called him the top boss in the country.

title: Carter Calls for an International Nuclear Fuel Bank
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  President Carter called today for the establishment of an international nuclear fuel bank as an attempt to lower the incentives for nations to obtain equipment that could be used for military purposes.

title: Yankees Center of Controversy and Adulation
description: I don't like the guy, I don't like a lot of the things about him, one Yankee player said even in the exhilarating aftermath of the World Series. But, the same player added quickly, I have to admire what he did tonight.

title: AustraliaU.S. Base Pact Renewed
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 19 (Reuters) Australia renewed today a 10yearold agreement that allows the United States to operate its secret electronic tracking and listening post at Pine Gap in central Australia, Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser told Parliament. Pine Gap, near Alice Springs, is believed to be a vital link for American Polaris submarines in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.

title: House Vote on Cargo Preference
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 [AP)Here the rollcall by which the House defeated today by a vote of 257 to 165 the oil cargo preference hill. Those who did not vote are denoted by xxx.

title: Dow Earnings Drop 13.4%
description: Dow Chemical reported a 13.4 percent ord 25.5 percent rise in its quarterly net; Xerox's net was up 10 percent for a quarterly record; Polaroid had a 7 percent gain and American Airlines lifted its profits 39.9 percent. Page D7.

title: BOND RALLY TIED TO SLOW G.N.P. RISE
description: The credit markets rallied yesterday, and the Treasury's new 71 percent notes, which were sold Tuesday at an average yield of 7.27 percent, climbed enough to lower their rate of return to 7.18 percent.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of post positions.

title: SENATE VOTES TO CURB FORCED RETIREMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Senate, paving the way for thousands of older Americans to remain on the job, voted today to raise from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may compel their workers to retire.

title: Radical Redesign: Life Without Clutter
description: THEY WERE NOT born to this, the suburban byproducts of the postwar baby boomto minimalist design, industrial fixtures, neutral colors, broad expanses of white. Many of them grew up with Ethan Allen reproductions, pewter, landscape prints, canopy beds and avocado green. Formica belonged in the kitchen. Metal in the garage.

title: Man Trying to Board IND Train Without Paying Is Shot by Officer
description: A 22yearold Manhattan man was shot during a struggle with a Transit Authority police officer in the 155th Street IND station at 8:15 A.M. yesterday, the police reported.

title: Natl Basketball Assn
description: AT BUFFALO KANSAS CITY(108)

title: Personal Beauty
description: THE EXPERTS say it won't hurt, to wash your hair every day. But Shirley Knight gets eight shampoos a week, right on stage, too. Which makes her not onlythe busiest, but the dampest actress currently in the New York theatre.

title: U.S. IS TRAINING UNITS TO FIGHT TERRORISTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19At least two Ranger battalions of the United States Army have been trained as antiterrorist units and are capable of dealing with terrorist incidents involving Americans abroad, according to Pentagon sources.

title: Payne of Eagles Has Surgery
description: PHILDADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (UPI)Ken Payne, the wide receiver who was claimed by the Philadelphia Eagles on waivers from the Green Bay Packers two days ago, underwent an emergency appendectomy today at Methodist Hospital. An Eagles spokesman said Payne would miss the remainder of the National Football League.

title: Gangland Killings Stir Chicago
description: CHICAGO Oct. 19 (UPI)The week of July 22 saw the biggest rash of gangland killings in Chicago since the days of Al Capone and Bugs Moran, the Chicago Crime Commission said in its latest newsletter. At least six gangstyle killings were committed during that week, including the shotgun slaying of a former Austin District police commander, Mark Thanasaurus.

title: STUDY WARNS OF COLLAPSE OF 17 DAMS IN THE WEST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)A new study prompted by the Teton Dam disaster warns that 17 Western dams could collapse if subjected to extremely heavy flooding.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Earthquake Hits Anchorage Area
description: PALMER, Alaska, Oct. 19 (UPI)A moderate earthquake rumbled through the Anchorage area yesterday, causing no damage. The Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported the quake's magnitude as 4.5 on the Richter Scale. The epicenter was about 115 miles north of Anchorage,

title: U.S. Woman Says Ruse Saved the Hostages
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 19A ruse spared the lives of the hostages rescued by West German commandos yesterday from a hijacked plane in Somalia, an American woman said here today.

title: Trailways Bus System Planning Test of Movies for Passengers
description: The Trailways bus network said today it would begin testing movies for passengers on longdistance bus trips.

title: He Wins Right to Play
description: When St. Francis Prep meets Holy Cross High at Flushing Memorial Field in Queens Saturday, the St. Francis coach will have the best lineman on the team  back in the lineup. But it took a ruling from the city Department of Health to get Larry Carbone back on St. Francis's freshman team, even though he is its captain, because Larry has only one arm.

title: Notes on People
description: A Circuit Court judge in Chicago sentenced Saul Bellow to 10 days in jail for not making alimony payments to his third wife, Susan Gassman Bellow. The Nobel Prizewinning author was not in court, but Judge Mary Ann McMorrow told his attorney that if Mr. Bellow paid the $11,150 he owed his former wife, the jail sentence might be dropped. The writer, who has five days to file an appeal, used alimony disputes as important plot elements in two novels, Herzog and Humboldt's Gift.

title: Klutzification Day
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 19Every recent Presidency has had its Klutzification Daythat fearsome moment when we PoohBahs of the Media Mafia decide, as if on signal, that the President is staggering, demonstrably incompetent, and vulnerable.

title: Jobless Philadelphians Protest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)A group of 2C0 unemployed Philadelphians demonstrated today at the Labor Department to call attention to the nation's high jobless rate and to protest cutbacks in unemployment compensation payments. The demonstrators, members of the Philadelphia Unemployment Project, picketed outside the office of Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, and then marched to Capitol Hill, where they met with members of the Pennsylvania Congressional delegation.

title: John B. Oakes Receives an Award For Editorials on the Environment
description: John B. Oakes, the senior editor of The New York Times, has received the 1977 Environmental Award of the Natural Resources Defense Council for making The Times's editorial page the most vital and influential journalistic voice in America.

title: The U.N. Today
Commonwealth Is Urged to Keep South African Oil From Rhodesia
description: LONDON, Oct. 19 (Reuters)A Commonwealth committee today recommended to the 35 member governments that South Africa be asked for effective guarantees that petroleum products it imported would not be exported to Rhodesia.

title: Benefit Program Nov. 9 Of Agnes de Mille Dances
description: A special program with Agnes de Mille, called Conversations About the Dance, will be given on Nov. 9 at the City Center 55th Street Theater. The program is being presented by the Foundation for the Joffrey Ballet and the Agnes de Mille Heritage Dance Theater and will include excerpts from Miss de Mille's Rodeo and Interplay, done by the Joffrey Ballet. Other artists who will take part are Gemze de Lappe, Honi Coles, James Jamieson, Hortense Kooluris and Mel Tomlinson. with David Baker at the piano.

title: Q&A
description: Q I painted my entire apartment about give years ago cad the living room ceiling started peeling shortly after. Last year I scraped off what I could, plastered the entire surface and then painted with an ???? base paint. Now large patellas are peeling off again, including the plaster. What can I do to repair this old sur face and maize paint adhere? D.C., Manhattan.

title: Home Improvement
description: MOST homeowners are by now wellaware of the need for adequate wall and attic insulation. However, many do not realize that after inadequate insulation, the greatest single source of wasted energy (heat loss in cold Weather and heat gain in hot weather) is the typical singlepane window. The addition of snugfitting storm sash will, of course, help to cut this loss considerably. But more and more homeowners, especially in older houses, have begun thinking about replacement windowsthat is, installing completely new windows in place of existing ones.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Mice Play to Lunch Audiences Outside Pennsylvania Station
description: Colonies of mice flourish in the flower beds on either side of the stations Seventh Avenue entrance, darting out of the bushes to halfeaten pretzels and other food scraps tossed there by passersby or by the crowd that regularly gathers for an alfresco lunch.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1977

title: How Loud Is Concorde?Not Just a Matter of Decibels
description: Loud, unexpected noises  bangs, booms, roars, screams and othersare not simply nuisances.

title: 170 Wrestlers in World Meet
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 19 (AP)Olympic and former world champions head a field of 170 athletes from 29 nations entered in the world freestyle wrestling championships that open Friday. The Soviet squad is expected to dominate most of the 10 weight classes. Stanley Dziedzic of Lansing, Mich., who won a bronze medal in the 1976 Montreal Olympics, is among the contenders in the 163pound class.

title: HOUSE DEFEATS BILL TO GIVE U.S. TANKERS CARGO PREFERENCES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19In a chaotic session, the House of Representatives today defeated a controversial bill that would have required that 9.5 percent of imported oil be carried on United States ships.

title: Vote Slated in Music Hall Strike
description: UNION MUSICIANS will meet at 11 A.M. today to vote on what the Radio City Music Hall yesterday termed a final proposal for a new contract that would end a strike that began on Tuesday.

title: Conferees Say Carter Is Firm on His Energy Goals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19  President Carter told Democratic House conferees on the energy bill today that he would make no deals to compromise his energy stands to win sapport from Senate conferees, Congresssen at the meeting said.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: CRUDE IMPORTS UP IN WEEK BY 400,000 BARRELS A DAY
description: Imports of crude oil rose in the week ended Oct. 14, to 6.6 million barrels a day against 6.2 million barrels a day in the preceding week, according to the latest weekly supply statistics released by the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of crude oil were at 338.4 million barrels, an increase of 700,000 barrels from the earlier week.

title: Spreading the Word For Concorde Flight
description: Both Air France and British Airways are planning big newspaper advertising efforts to mark the inauguration of the Concorde's commercial service to New York.

title: Day After Triumph, Yanks Still Can't Shrug Off Inner Strife
description: In the rousing hours after they had won their Ilist World Series in 15 years, the New York Yankees basked in the ,city's victory parade yesterday but also braced for a renewal of the feuding that embroiled their key players during a tumultuous season.

title: HOUSE DEFEATS BILL TO GIVE U.S. TANKERS CARGO PREFERENCES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19In a chaotic session, the House of Representatives today defeated a controversial bill that would have required that 9.5 percent of imported oil be carried on United States ships. Only 3 percent of imported oil now carried on American vessels.

title: Senate Backs Rise In Minimum Wage To $3.35 by 1981
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 19 (AP)The Senate approved a bill today that would raise the nation's minimum wage in annual stages from the current $2.30 an hour to $3.35 an hour by 1981.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS BAN MAJOR BLACK GROUPS, CLOSE LEADING PAPER
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19The South African Government, charging that there was a campaign of hate against whites, today banned black protest groups, closed down the principal black newspaper and arrested its editor, Percy Qoboza, in the most drastic crackdown in nearly two decades.

title: U.S. to Study Steel Dumping Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The Treasury Department said today it would investigate a complaint by the United States Steel Corporation that the Japanese were illegally selling $1.2 billion in steel products in this country below the cost of production.

title: Sotheby's Sale Sets 7 Records
description: SOTHEBY'S first sale this season of Impressionist and modern art attracted a standingroomonly crowd of dealers and collectors who pushed prices above the high presale estimates in a score of cases and set records for seven artists.

title: Cattle Truck Crash Blocks Traffic
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct.. 19 (UPI)A collision between a cattle transport truck and a moving crane vehicle resulted in a massive freeway tieup on I10 between this desert resort and Los Angeles. The California Highway Patrol said the accident occurred west of here yesterday when the truck rammed the crane from the rear. The gasoline tank on the transport exploded and the spewing flames engulfed some of the cattle on board and the animals spilled into the highway.

title: Everyone Loves Parade at Joffrey
description: ANYONE who has never seen the Joffrey Ballet's revival of Parade has not merely missed one of the most important ballets in dance history but has also missed a delightful evening at the theater.

title: An Equine Whowunit
description: A horse from Uruguay that won at Belmont Park last month at odds of 571 was declared ineligible by the New York Racing Association yesterday until his identity can be verified.

title: Letters
description: The Top 10

title: Market Place
description: Motorola stock continued to tumble yesterday, with analysts disagreeing over the degree to which the diversified electronics company's flat earnings wer3 attributable to a glut of citizens band radios.

title: Indonesia Appears to Be Unruffled By Charge on Political Prisoners
description: JAKARTA, Oct. 19 (Reuters)The Indonesian Government seemed unmoved today by Amnesty International's announcement that it plans to begin a worldwide campaign for the immediate release of what the organization said were Indonesia's 100,000 political prisoners.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Hubbard Services Saturday
description: MILAN, Mo., Oct. 19 (UPI)Services for the baseball and football hall of fame member, Cal Hubbard, will be held at 2 P.M. Saturday in the Milan United Methodist Church, it was announced today. Burial will be in a family plot at Oakwood Cethetery in the town where Hubbard's first wife, Ruth, is buried. Hubbard is survived by his widow, Mildred. and a son, Robert, Hubbard, 76, died of cancer Monday night in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Robert R. Endicott, 72, Served for 22 Years As Family Circle Editor
description: Robert Rantoul Endicott, former editor of Family Circle magazine, died Sunday at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 72 years old.

title: Businessman Who Lied About Bribes to Nursing Homes Given 3 Years
description: An executive of a Brooklyn paperproducts company who was found guilty of perjury in denying that he padded his bills and then gave cash kickbacks to nursinghome operators was sentenced yesterday to three years in prison.

title: Senate Votes to Increase the G.I. Bill Benefits by 6.6%
description: WASHINGTON.Oct. 19The Senate voted 91 to 0 tonight to increase educational benefits under the G. I. Bill by 6.6 percent, but overwhelmingly rejected an amendment to provide major help to financially pressed veterans in New York and other hightuition states.

title: Del Tufo Approved for Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of Robert Del Tufo as United States Attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Del Tufo, New Jersey's Criminal Justice Director, had been nominated by President Carter to replace Jonathan L. Goldstein, a Nixon Administration appointee. The nomination now goes to the full Senate.

title: Issue and Debate
description: For the first time in more than a century, New York State voters will be asked next month to decide if they want to stop electing some of their judges.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS BAN MAJOR BLACK GROUPS, CLOSE LEADING PAPER
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19The South African Government, charging that there was a campaign of hate against whites, today banned black protest groups, closed down the principal black newspaper and arrested its editor, Percy Qoboza, in the most drastic crackdown in nearly two decades.

title: Pope Restates Hostage Offer
description: ROME, Oct. 19 (UPI)Pope Paul VI said today he would always be willing to offer himself as a hostage if by doing so he could save lives in hijackings, such as in the West German Lufthansa airliner incident. The 80yearold Pontiff spoke to a group of German pilgrims at his weekly general audience.

title: U.S. Assails Moves, Warns on Relations
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 19The Carter Administration said today that it was deeply disturbed about the crackdown by the South African Government on blacks and their supporters and warned that the latest actions had implications for future South African relations with the United States.

title: Art: Summing Up Raphael foyer
description: AT THE AGE OF 77, the American painter Raphael Soyer can look back on a long career, and this season his accomplishments are being honored with two exhibitions of his paintings and drawings and the publication of his Diary of an Artist (New Republic Books, $15.95). In New York, the Forum Gallery (1018 Madison Avenue at 79th Street) is showing a large group of Mr. Soyer's recent portraits and city street scenes (through Oct. 30), and in Washington the National Collection of Fine Arts has mounted a retrospective survey of Soyer drawings and watercolors, which includes work from around 1917 to the present day (through Nov. 27).

title: Architect of S.I. Rediscovered
description: The architect Ernest Flagg was a true eclecticwedded to no particular style, he designed buildings throughout a long career that skillfully combines elements from a variety of architectural traditions. He was best known for a building that is now gonethe Singer Building, a BeauxArts influenced tower that rose in elegant, slender splendor on lower Broadway until it was unconscionably demolished to make way for the box called One Liberty Plaza a few years back. But his Scribner building on Fifth Avenue remains, containing one of New York's finest storefronts.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Dorothy Kelley and her three children were jogging in Central Park the other day, trying to talk. It wasn't easy. Their conversation was punctuated by the jolt their bodies took with each stride; it was slowed by their heavy breathing and it was overwhelmed by the strident barking of their dog, Luther, who always runs with them.

title: Jury for Klan Trial Selected
description: AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 20 (UPI)A jury was selected yesterday for the trial of Buddy Cochran, the 30yearold mechanic accused of driving his car into a crowd at a Ku Klux Klan rally July 2 in President Carter's hometown of Plains and injuring 30 people. Also yesterday, the President's brother, Billy Carter, who was summoned by the defense, came to the Sumter County court house but left after being told he was not needed at the trial. I drove 300 miles to get here today and I ain't coming back, he told reporters.

title: Management
description: People constantly make Judgments about others, but it is also recognized that many of these informal judgments will be erroneous.

title: Men Look at Women in L.I. Prints Show
description: The image of Avomen, as seen through the eyes of male artists of the 19th and early 20th centuries, is the focus of a free exhibition of prints opening Sunday at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Israel's Likud Coalition Bolstered by Yadin's Party
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 20Prime Minister Menahem Begin's Likudled coalition Government was assured today of a comfortable and broadbased majority with the addition of a new political party.

title: Restaurants
description: SPARKS STEAKHOUSE, for many years on East 18th Street. has recently moved to a now home at 210 Fast 46th Street, right in the heart of steak city. By way of notifying the competition of their arrival, the management of Sparks has stated in advertisements that its steaks offer a superior value. It is necessary, therefore, not only to judge Sparks in relation to itself, but also by how closely it lives up to that competititve promise.

title: Tu Avu Triumphs in Golf
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20 (UPI)Tu Ayu of Taiwan captured the $71,428 Isuzu Ladies Cup golf tournament today with a tworound total of twounderpar 142.

title: After 70 Years, Sfluth Bronx Street Is at a Dead End
description: Joseph McNevin, who is now85 years old, knows Charlotte Street, the South Bronx block where President Carter took a walk, as it was in the 1920's, a street bf fine brick apartment houses, some with elevators, with embossed tin and carvedgranite cornices, wroughtiron stair rails, polishedbrass mailboxes and marble lobbies.

title: Deaths
description: AGINIrene L. Congregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sor row the passing of the mother of Mrs Martin J. Warmbrand and extends its condolences.

title: American Editors Qroup Condemns Closing of South African Papas
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP)Directors of the American Society of Newspaper Editors voted here today to condemn the suppression of three South Afri. can newspapers and the detention of an editor.

title: Congress Votes Minimum Pay Rise; It Would Aid 5 Million in January
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)Congress today sent President Carter legislation raising the current minimum wage of $2.30 an hour to $2.65 in January. Five million workers would benefit from this.

title: U.S. and Koreans Break Off Talks In Disagreement on Tongsun Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 20Afte four days of intensive negotiations, the United States and South Korea failed to reach agreement today and broke off talks on an American interrogation of Tongsun Park, the current central figure in an alleged influencebuying scandal involving Congress.

title: About Real Estate
description: It may be getting easier for the home buyerjn New York State to get a low down payment mortgage.

title: In Brooklyn, New Music in an Old Church
description: The Brooklyn Philharmonia will present Sunday at 4 P.M. a concert new music in an old church, the Bushwick United Methodist Church, Bushwick Avenue and Madison Street in Brooklyn. The works of six composers will be heard in this program, part of the Philharmonia's community serie.

title: Viking 2 Photos of a Mars Moon Show an Unexpectedly Smooth Surface
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 20The first; closeup photographs of Deimos, the outer, smaller moon of Mars, obtained last Saturday by the Viking 2 orbiter, have shown its surface to be unexpectedly smooth.

title: BERKOWITZ ASSERTS DEMONS RULED HIM
description: In a dingy, makeshift courtroom on the sixth floor of the Kings County Psychiatric Center yesterday, David R. Berkowitz, accused of being the.44caliber killer, !contended that not he, bu, evil demons !commanding his body, had carried out six murders with which he has been charged.

title: The New York Times/Tyrone Dukes
description: An electrical power failure stopped all train service into and out of Pennsylvania Station for four hours yesterday morning, delaying 90,000 rushhour commuters and several thousand more longdistance riders who came from points as far away as Montreal.

title: Koch Has Gainful Visit With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Representative Edward I. Koch, Democratic nominee for Mayor of New York, went to see President Carter this morning to ask for a White House coordinator of steppedup Federal action to help the South Bronx and to obtain some kind words in support of his own camnaign.

title: 6 Reported Killed As Plane Crashes, Rock Stars Aboard
description: McCOMB, Miss., Oct. 20 (AP)Six persons were kined when a twinengine airplane carrying about 25 persons, including members of the rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd, crashed in a swampy area of southwestern Mississippi tonight, medical officials here said.

title: College Results
description: SOCCER

title: PACIFIC BUDGET FARE PROPOSED BY PAN AM; CUTS OF 50% SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)Pan American World Airways said today it had proposed cutting the cost of transPacific travel in half next year by introducing in that area the same sort of budget fares now offered between New York and London.

title: Police Acts At Stadium Investigated
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd asked the Civilian Complaint Review Board yesterday to investigate charges that city policemen used excessive force in their efforts to control spectators who surged onto the field after Tuesday night's deciding World Series game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Pianist Approaches Quintet in G Single  Handed
description: When the Viennese pianist Paul Wittgenstein lost his right arm in World War I, he prevailed on some of the best known composers of the day to create a modern repertory for the left hand alone. That was how Ravel's familiar concerto for the left hand came to be written, as well as Prokofiev's Concerto No. 4.

title: Mandel Prosecutor Is Retiring
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP)Jervis S. Finney, the top Federal prosecutor in Maryland during the trial of Governor Marvin Mandel, today announced his resignation as United States Attorney, effective Jan. 31. Mr. Finney said he had sent a letter of resignation to President Carter. He said he had no idea whom his successor would be. Mr. Finney, Republican, was appointed to the post by President Ford in March 1975.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Daily Averages for the weeks ended:

title: U.S. Team Beats China In Tennis at Peking, 71
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20 (AP)A United States tennis team of four men and four women defeated a Chinese squad by 71 in Peking today, the official Hsinhua news agency reported. Four matches in Peking Stadium ended in ties. Hsinhua said.

title: Letters: On Tuition Costs
description: To the Editor: There is one aspect of the PackwoodMoynihan Tuition Tax Credit Plan which your Oct. 11 editorial How Not to Ease the Tuition Squeeze overlooked. Higher education is mightily encumbered these days by government rules and regulations. Some of these are justified, but the continuing erosion of academia's traditional autonomy is ominous. I submit that tax credits are friendlier to the autonomy of institutions than government appropriations.

title: Despite His Absence, Humphrey Is Toast Of Capital Party
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)Though he was at his Minnesota home and unable to attend, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey was the talk of the party tonight as long line of friends and dignitaries gathered to salute his career in public service. Senator Humphrey has not returned to Washington since surgeons discovered inomerable cancer on Aug. 18.

title: 4 California Papers for Sale
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP) Peninsula Newspapers Inc. said today has agreed in principal to sell the Palo Alto Times, the Redwood City Tribune and two weekly newspapers to Tribune Co. of Chicago. Details of the proposed sale are to be released in about a month and the sale, if approved by Peninsula stockholders, would be final prior to Christmas. The cash sale price was not disclosed.

title: San Diegan Wins $81,000 in Britain For Injuries in Bus Tour Accident
description: LONDON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)A judge awarded a San Diego psychologist $81,000 as a result of injuries suffered in an accident during a 1974 bus tour of Britain.

title: Companies List Reports Covering Their Sales and Earnings Figures
description: ACF INDUSTRIES (N)

title: T.M M. Study Barred In Jersey's Schools
description: A judge in Federal District Court in Newark yesterday barred the teaching of transcendental meditation in public schools, saying that the instruction was religious in nature and violated the First Amendment requirement for separation of church and state.

title: INTRUDERS NOT WELCOME: As a cameraman recorded the scene, members of the Ku Klux Klan, who were holding a news conference at airport in Sacramento, Calif.,
description: Associated Press attempted to keep a group of demonstrators from entering room where conference was begin held. Eventually, the door was ripped off its hinges during the struggle.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Neal llontl

title: Shipping/Mails
description: CUNARD PRINCESS (Cunard). Left Bermuda Oct. 20; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: The New York Times
description: ENDS EXHIBITION TOUR: Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnast, In New York yesteraay after tivecity, tour with a Rumanian girls team. She received the 1976 Pinch Woman Athlete of the World trophy and a 610,000 check for her feats at the Montreal Olympics.

title: WHITE HOUSE WARNS FED AGAINST LIFTING OF INTEREST RATES
description: In an unusual move, the White House yesterday warned the Federal Reserve Hoardwithout addressing it directlyagainst raising interest rates and thus hurting the economy.

title: Industrial Trade Between U. S. and Russia Is Slipping
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20  Five years after the United States and the Soviet Union inaugurated a new era in trade relations, business is stagnating, American companies have lost interest in opening new branch offices here and the expectations for the future are modest, not vet pessimistic.

title: Advertising
description: One doesn't have to be with the Magazine Publishers Association at their annual meeting that started yesterday at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla., to know what the animated luncheon, cocktail and dinner chatter was all about. Most certainly it had to do with the conflicting reports of magazine audience sizes released here yesterday by the country's two major providers of syndicated media audience data.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in new York denied a request by the Rev. Louis R. Gigante to put off his appearance before a grand jury to give him time to prepare an appeal. on a ruling that required him to aswer specific questions.

title: Alcoa Net Up 9% and Sales 6.6%; Alcan's Earnings Soar in Quarter
description: Two of the world's largest aluminum companiesthe Aluminum Company of America and Alcan Aluminium Ltd.reported yesterday earnings gains in the Quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30.

title: Aqueduct Is Expecting Full Barns This Winter
description: There may be a shortage of fans at Aqueduct once the cold winter months arrive, but, unlike recent winters. there should be no shortage of horses.

title: Black Confirmed as U.S. Marshal
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Rufus A. Lewis of Birmingham, Ala., black former civil rights leader, to be United States marshal for the middle district of Alabama. Senator James B. Allen.

title: KOCH HOLDING TALKS WITH LABOR LEADERS
description: Anticipating that labor negotiations will be one of his first priorities if he is elected mayor, Edward I. Koch has been meeting for conversations with municipal labor leaders, although he is giving no signal of any shift in his stiff stance on labor.

title: World News Briefs
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, Oct. 20 (AP)Maj. Ahmed Hussein alGhashmi, who assumed the leadership of Yemen after the Oct. 11 slaying of its president, was himself the target of subsequent assassination attempt, according to the emirates press agency.

title: CAIRO AFFIRMS U.S. PLAN TO OVERHAUL MIG ENGINES
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20 (Reuters)The United States has agreed to go ahead with, plans to overhaul the engines of many of Egypt's Sovietguilt MIG21 fighter planes, Foreign Minister Ismail Fahmy had disclosod.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise 10%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The Department of Commerce reported today that total weekly retail store sales in the latest week was an estimated $14.06 billion, up 10 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.75 billion. Department store sales were about $1.55 billion, up 16 percent from last year's $1.34 billion.

title: U.S. BACKS CURB ON KILLING OF ENDANGERED WHALES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Carter Administration sought today to resolve a classic confrontation between environmentalists and Alaska Eskimos over the hunting of bowhead whales, but the proposed solution elicited a charge from the Eskimos that they had been betrayed..

title: ExOfficer of Korean C.I.A. Tells House Inquiry That Covert Lobby Was Aimed at 50 Prominent Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20A former officer of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency disclosed today a new facet of the covert lobby intended to influence American Congressmen, an operation code named Ice Mountain that was aimed at 50 prominent Americans.

title: 100,000 Pakistanis See Flogging
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 20 (Reuters) More than 100,000 people watched the public flogging here today of Mohammed Kaleem, convicted of raping a 7yearold girl, the Associated Press of Pakistan reported. The paramilitary Government of Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq has enforced strict Islamic punishment, including physical mutilation, since coming to I'Mver in July.

title: PRESIDENT IS UPHELD AS THE HOUSE REJECTS FUNDS FOR B4 BOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Lastminute appeals by the House Speaker and a powerful. committee chairman reversed an impending rebuff to President Carter today and persuaded a tumultuous House not to reinstate $1.4 billion for the B3. bomber.

description: When the boys from down the block come visiting on Sunday, Holy Cross will, be ready. The Knights have a date with their Queens rivals, St. Francis Prep, Sunday at 1:30 P.M. and for fans of the two teams, pro football may as High School Sports well have the day off. St. Francis is undefeated in five games and the defending Catholic High Schools Football League champion.

title: PROTESTER RETURNS AFTER 7 YEARS'. EXILE

description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 21Thailand's military junta, in a coup that met no resistance, last night deposed the civilian Government it installed after a coup a year ago.

title: Art: Photo Roots or Shahn's Paintings
description: INAUGURATED by one disaster (the Crash), the era of the 1930's staggered through another (the Depression) only to be terminated by a third (World War II). Small wonder that its limp esthetic production has been eclipsed by the rowdier movement of Abstract Expressionism. Though the pericd is now enjoying a revival of interest, its art is proving no less difficult to reassess.

title: Castro, Visiting Jamaica, Drops His Plans to Appear at Two Events
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct 20President Fidel Castro, tired after three days of travel in Jamaica by road, plane and helicopter, canceled two appearances today.

title: Apples Leader Aims to Pare Deficit
description: Sol Berg's personal advisers keep telling him to dump his World Team Tennis toy. You've made it in business, they say, so why settle for a sour investment like the New York Apples?

title: Autry to Direct Angels, With Bavasi as No. 1 Aide
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)Gene Autry said today that he would take over personal control of his California Angels as president and appoint E. J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, formerly president of the San Diego Padres, as his top assistant. Arthur (Red) Patterson, the Angels president for the last three years, will stay with the American League baseball club to handle public relations and other duties, said Autry, the Angels owner.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The spring antiques fair in Morristown, N.J., has been so successful for a decade that last year its organizers decided to try a fall edition. The results were good again, and this year the fall fair becomes virtually a tradition. Nearly 100 dealers will show and sell wares spanning two centuries of styles, from Colonial to the day before yesterday, all weekend long at the National Guard Armory on Western Avenue. Something for everyone is promised, at prices ranging from 5 cents to five figures. Hours: today and tomorrow, 1 to 10 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission, $2. By car from Manhattan, take the George Washington Bridge to Interstate 80, west to Interstate 287, south to the Morris Avenue exit, which leads to Morristown Square. Western Avenue runs south from there. A Morristown bus leaves the Port Authority terminal every hour (fare, $2.15 one way; in formation: 4712300).

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE ARE here and there some mildly entertaining passages in Michael Korda's Success! For instance, in a section on how to call attention to yourself when you are just starting out in an organization, Mr. Korda suggests that you Spend the time to look at everything that crosses your desk, and send it back indicating that you've read it, if possible with a comment, correction or an expression of your opinion. It helps to develop a distinctive style, and the worse your handwriting is and the more cryptic your style, the better, since it will then be necessary for your subordinates to decipher what you've written, and ponder about what really mean.

title: CarterArtis Transcripts
description: PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 20 (AP) Passaic County officials say the transcripts to be used by Rubin (Hurricane)) Carter and John Artis in their appeal of their triple murder convictions will cost about $10,000. Martin Verp, County Counsel, said yesterday that the Appellate Division of Superior Court had approved a system to duplicate the 12,000page document, which will save the county $30,000. Mr. Carter and Mr. Artis were convicted last year in a second trial of the 1966 murders of three persons in a bar here.

title: Dollar Mixed

description: ATLANTA, Oct. 20  An alleged bank robber who hijacked a Frontier Airlines jet from Nebraska to Atlanta shot himself to death aboard the aircraft here tonight after releasing the last of his hostages unharmed.

description: HOUSTON, Oct. 20 (AP)The barely breathing Seadock deepwater port project remains alive today as its membership deadline was extended until April 20

title: Pop: Marilyn Sokol Sings at Town Hall

Marilyn Sokol, who opened Town Hall's 5:45 P.M. Interludes for the season on Wednesday, knows her schlock backwards and forwards. With a cutting Catskills voice, which she continually threatens to turn loose full force, and a sharp eye for stage mannerisms and routines, Miss Sokol is a natural at what she does.

The measure establishes the position of Associate Attorney General, and Mr. Carter said that he was nominating Michael J. Egan, an Atlanta lawyer, to the post.

title: Dog (Obedience) Days of October Marked
description: Mrs. Barbara M. alle is an innovative obedience expert responsible for the instruction of approximately 3,000 dogs over the last 15 years in the Westchester area. This week the White Plains woman was selected to repreNews of Dogs sent the MidAtlantic Obedience Association in accepting Governor Carey's proclamation designating Saturday and Sunday Dog Obedience Days throughout the state of New York. Assemblyman Peter M. Sullivan made the presentation Monday at General Foods headquarters in White Plains. Walter Chime!, director of the Gaines Research Center, said the proclamation resulted from the efforts of Assemblyman Sullivan, a firm believer in obedience training as a means of having all dogs become wellbehaved citizens of the communities.

The retirement was announced by Chief United States District Judge Frank J. Battisti. Miller and his colleagues in the Notre Dame backfield, Elmer Layden, Jim Crowley and Harry Stuhldreher, were elected in 1970 to the College Football Hall of Fame.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  The House and Senate conferees on energy legislad tion reached their first significant agreo ments today, but bypassed enough difficult decisions on the way to create a bulging agenda for future weeks.

description: AS BROADCASTING fate would too frequently have it, two of this weekend's better presentations are scheduled directly against each other. Following a birthday party for Marie Osmorid and an anniversary tribute to Las Vegas, ABC is offering Gabriel Kaplan Presents the Small Event on Sunday at 10 P.M. At precisely the same hour, Public Television's Visions is featuring a play called The Dancing Bear. Firstrate comedy or outstanding drama? You flip your channel selector and you make your choice.

title: Red Smith
description: Reggie Jackson posed leaning against the new Thunderbird outside the Fifth Avenue entrance to the Plaza. Beside him was his sister, Tina Jones, with her small daughter Alex. Tina is getting the car from Reggie, who drives RollsRoyce as befits the richest player in baseball. This the seccrtid time Sport Magazine has awarded an auto Jackson as the most valuable player in the World Series. In 1973 when he led the Oakland A's to victory over the New York Mets. he eave the car to charity but after his Sports of The Times three consecutive home runs destroyed the Los Angeles Dodgers Tuesday night and Sports gave the Yankees their first championship of in 15 years, Tina told him. My name The Times Charity. So yesterday they posed on the wet pavement while flashbulbs popped and crowds watched from the sidewalks and hotel guests packed the steps beneath the marquee. Over the traffic noises came a chant: Reggie! Reggie! Reggie! It seemed an echo from the rightfield stands of Yankee Stadium until the source was locatedcrowded windows on the ninth floor of the building that houses the Paris Cinema. Obviously, no corner of New York is off limits to Reggie Jackson's idolators this week.

title: Screen: Zola Adaptation Manquee
description: EMILE ZOLA'S "La Faute de L'Abb Mouret," written in 1875, is not, as far as I can learn, in print in English at the moment, but if it were. I doubt that the title would be "The Demise of Father Mouret." This is what the American distributors are calling Georges Franju's 1970 French film adaptation that opened yesterday at the Renoir Cinema.Most often "faute" is translated as "mistake," "shortcoming," "defect," and, I suppose, if the word were pushed, it could even mean "sin." To freight it with the finality of "demise" is really too much. It seems to be just another in a series of wrong decisions that began with Mr. Franju's desire to make the movie, which is a sort of fairy-tale version of the Adam and Eve story updated to the France of the Second Empire.Mr. Franju is not a well-known film maker in this country, perhaps because he is at his best when he is being what most critics think of as frivolous, though he's not a frivolous man. His fine horror film, "Eyes Without a Face," received few reviews when it opened here in a badly English-dubbed version in the mid-60's, though his more solemn, ambitious films, "Thrse Desqueyroux" and "Thomas the Imposter" have been reviewed, if not ecstatically."Judex," Mr. Franju's homage to Louis Feuillade, the creator of the great French silent serials "Fantomas" and "Les Vampires," simply baffled everyone not sharing the Franju opinion of Feuillade."The Demise of Father Mouret" is not likely to win him new friends, though I've no doubt that the film may be faithful to the novel, which I haven't read, and to Zola, whose occasional flights into a kind of naturalized romanticism haven't worn well."The Demise of Father Mouret" is a mixture of social realism and Walt Disney, about a delicate young French priest, Father Mouret (Francis Huster), who elects to take a parish in the provinces where the peasants have long since embraced every sin there is. The priest himself successfully sublimates his own lustful thoughts in prayer until one day he meets a strange young woman, Albine (Gillian Hills), who lives with her atheistic uncle in the remains of an old chateau set in the middle of a magic garden.Well, one thing leads to another and poor Father Mouret loses his memory long enough to lose himself to worldly pleasures in the garden with Albine, who, like Eve, tempts the man, though in this case the author is clearly in favor of apple-eating. Things go very badly for the couple. The priest returns to his church and Albine commits suicide in a way that is unique in my movie-going memory: She smothers herself to death with calla lilies.The actors are steadfastly unconvincing. The one interesting character in the film is an old lady we meet only after her deathsomeone, we're told in shocked tones, who, during the Revolution, posed naked as a living-statue of Reason.

title: HOUSE GROUP FEARS RIFT OVER NATO TANK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20A House Armed Services Committee panel warned today that political and diplomatic pressures could develop over an agreement between the United States and West Germany to use some common components in their main battle tanks.

title: POLICE IN SAN JUAN PRESS DIAMOND CASE
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct.20Puerto Rican police officials said today that they could now begin a more intensive investigation into the murderrobbery of a New York diamond dealer, Abraham Shafizadeh, since they had finally found his body and established how he was slain.

title: In South Africa, Black Misery
description: I have not to date come across any responsible black leader who has advanced the theory that whites are expendable and must be thrown into the sea. We have, on the contrary, over the years emphasized that whites are South Africans and have the right to exist in a common fatherland; and that all of us, around a conference table, must devise a formula acceptable for future coexistence.

description: THE POLITICALLY oriented dance that was so much a part of the 1930's has virtually ceased to exist in the modern dance world. An interesting exception was At That Point in Time, wihch Pearl Lang choreographed in the spring and summer of 1974, when Watergate became a painfully familiar locale. She revived it this season and presented the work Wednesday evening at the Entermedia Theater.

Ga., Oct. 20 (AP)Jerry Pate, the 1976United States Open champion who has been hampered by an injury this year, fired a sixunderpar 64 today and took a onestroke lead after the first round of the $125,000 Southern open golf tournament.
