Phi, major and misconduct, 18:16; Walker, Tor, maior, misconduct and game misconduct 19:10; Bridgman, Phi, major and misconduct, 9:10.

title: Calif anoBrademas Rift Reflects Tension Over Government Roles
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 23 Representative John Brademas and Joseph A. Califano Jr., longtime friends liberal Democrats and two of this city's most Witten. tial politicians, are engaged in a dispute. of surprising intensity.

title: NEWYORK PORT GROUP LEAVES JOINT TALKS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 23The New York Shipping: Association resigned from the North Atlantic employers group today and said that it would work separately with the ocean carriers toward an agreement with striking longshoremen.

title: St. Paul Orchestra Delights
description: In its second Alice Tully Hall concert last week, on Saturday night, the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra seemed intent on showing New York the kind of music it has been missing by not having fulltime chamber orchestra of its own. The program was a delightful one and contained about two hours of music that few members of the audience had ever encountered before.

title: Supplementary OvertheCounter Listings
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Byrne Tells Environmentalists Group That State Has Stymied Floating NuclearPower Plant Project
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 23Governor Byrne told an environmental convention here yesterday that for all intents and purposes, further development of a floating nuclearpower plant off the New Jersey coast had been stymied.

title: School Results
Connors Keeps Edge Over Rosewall, 75, 64, 62
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 23 (UPI)Jimmy Connors defeated Ken Rosewall, 75. 64, 62, today and won the $135,000 Australian indoor tennis championships.

title: Topics
description: Overweight youths had best think twice before applying for admission to Oral Roberts University in Tulsa, Oklahoma. Every student with 10 percent excess fatmeasured against standard probably devised by skinny statisticiansis expected to go into poundsoff program, and those who do not participate face suspension. The university's antiobesity campaign has aroused the Oklahoma chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. In a complaint to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, the A.C.L.U. charges that O.R.U. is violating Federal law regarding equal treatment for the handicapped in general, and fat people in particular.

title: Parks Service Scored on Fight To Remove Animal Nuisances
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 23The National Parks Service, long considered a friend to animals, is coming under fire for its policy on animals and plants that it deems not native to an area.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSElsie Clark. It is with deep regret that we announce the death of our beloved President, Elsie Clark Abrams. Howard Abrams & Company, Inc. Roosevelt, New York.

title: Mairnonides Begins Big Renovation
description: Mayor Beanie donned a bard hat and pushed a shovel yesterday to help Malmonides Medical Center in Brooklyn break ground for a $25 million construction and renovation program.

title: Colts Suffer First Loss As Patriots Stifle Jones
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 23The New England Patriots, a football team still defining its considerable abilities, had to win the game. The standings said that. A third defeat would have eliminated the Patriots from serious consideration as a playoff team in December and the opposition, Baltimore was unbeaten but not invincible.

title: U.S. Is Raising Objections Over U.N. Payments
description: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., Oct. 23 After months of often acrimonious debate, the 149 members of the United Nations are about to adopt a new scale of assessments that will spell out each country's compulsory contribution to next year's budget.

title: Front Page 5  No Title
description: United Prose International BACK TO WASHINGTON WITH PRESIDENT: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey greeting President Carter at the airport in Minneapolis, where the President stopped at end of crosscountry trip, to pick up Mr. Humphrey. Page 11.

title: OFFICIAL KOREA PLAN ON INFLUENCE IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 As the House ethics committee ended its initial round of Open hearings on the Korean scandal late Friday afternoon, Peter White, the deputy special counsel, asserted that an official plan of the South Korean Government to buy influence in Congress was an established fact.

title: Germans, Stunned by Terror, Fear That More Lies Ahead
description: BONN, Oct. 23 After seven weeks of terrorist violence, many people in West Germany feel emotionally drained and are bracing themselves for what they fear may he more shocks to come.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 23 (AP)An Ethiopian military court announced today that eight counterrevolutionaries had been convicted of sabotage, murder and assault and had been sentenced to death, the Yugoslav press agency reported.

title: Reading Anatoly's Mind
description: WASHINGTONHere am I, Anatoly Fedorovich Dobrynin, for 15 years the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, destined to return to Moscow next year in a blaze of glory.

title: Race Is On for RunningShoe Money
description: Yesterday's New York Marathon, the 26mileplus run through the five boroughs to a Central Park finish, was part of a larger, longer race that's just hitting its stridethe market for running shoes. More than a score of companies are competing to serve the sports phenomenon that has grown into what some say is a $500millionayear business.

title: Television
Giants Beat Redskins;
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The thing John Mendenhall likes most about hunting is that it reminds him of going after quarterbacks. The 28yearold defensive tackle turned Robert F. Kennedy Stadium into a happy hunting ground today as he sacked Billy Kilmer three times and Coach John McVay's Giants scored still another upset over Coach George Allen's Redskins.

title: Harlem Drug Clinic Contract Delayed Amid Criticism
description: Renewal of a contract with a controversial Harlem clinic for drug addicts has been held up by New York State's Office of Drug Abuse Services since a $linillion contract channeling Federal Funds to the unit expired Aug. 31.

title: Wife of a Jailed Soviet Dissident Struggles to Carry On
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  Her husband has been in jail for nearly eight months, yet she has not heard a word about his condition or about the charges against him. She supported herself by teaching Russian, but her students became frightened and left her. Now, Irina Ginzburg says, the K.G.B. is trying to turn a 17yearold boy living with the family against them.

title: A Fine Pianist
description: Gita Karasik opened the Metropolitan Museum's Introductions series in the Grace Rainey Rogers auditorium Saturday afternoon. A pupil of Lev Shorr, Rosina Lhevinne and Karl Ulrich Schnabel, Miss Karasik has played in many cities around the country and garnered a fair number of piano competition awards, including the Young Concert Artists Auditions in 1970 and the Ford Foundation Artists Award in 1972.

title: Wall Street Keeps an Added Eye On an Index That Signals Bears
description: Wall Street is watching for a sign. It may come today, it may come tomorrow. When and if it does comeaccording to one school of diehard theoristsit will confirm that the bull market is dead and a bear market has taken over.

title: Sports Today
description: Rams vs. Minnesota Vikings, at Los Angeles (TelevisionChannel 7, 9 P.M.) (Radio. WMCA, 9 P.M.)

title: The U.N. Today
Miss Foglio, Juilliard Alumna Married to Stephen Plunkett
description: In st. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday afternoon, Alicia M. Foglio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Foglio Jr. of Floral Park, L.I., became the bride of Stephen D. Plunkett, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Plunkett of Reading, Pa., and Boca Raton Fla.

description: Qualifiers For National Classic Superdog Division

title: Germans, Stunned by Terror, Fear That More Lies Ahead
description: BONN, Oct. 23After seven weeks of terrorist violence and other jolting events, many people in West Germany feel emotionally drained and are bracing themselves for what they fear may be more shocks to come.

title: E.P.A. Considers Rule to Prevent Adjustment of Auto Idle Controls
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23Car owners or mechanics would be prevented from tinkering with the idle mixture or the choke of automobile engines, under a pollutioncontrol proposal being seriously considered by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency,

title: Facing South Africa
description: The turn of the screw in South Africa poses extremely delicate problems in diplomacy for President Carter. His whole new policy toward Africa, and beyond that important relationships with friendly countries, may be affected by what he does or does not do in response to Pretoria's sweeping new moves to silence the critics of official racism.

title: Pediatrics Parley Opens in India
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23 (Reuters)An international congress on pediatrics opened here today to discuss all aspects of child health and development, including immunization, malnutrition, breast feeding and environmental hazards. The sevenday gathering is attended by 3,900 delegates from 80 countries,

title: Congress Official Wins in India
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23 (Reuters)The Congress Party chief minister of the south Indian state of Kerala, A.K. Anthony, today won a byelection for a seat in the state assembly.

title: A Bet Is Won, a Star Is Born
description: the New York Jets lost a football game yesterday. out they won the esteem of every longshot bettor in the land, captivated their first sellout crowd in more than a year and discovered the successor to Broadway Joe Namath. They were beaten by the Oakland Raiders, 2S27, but in the view of bettors who backed them and got 13 points was a eloriously immoral victory. For the Shea Stadium clientele  60,359 tickets were sold, and 56,734 buyers showed upit was stirring entertainment on a spectacular

title: Capistrano Swallows Make Early Departure
description: SAN JUAN C.ANSTRANO, Calif oct 23 (AP)As song and legend have ??? the swallows have, indeed, left Capstrano But not on schedule, to the disappointment of hundreds of tourits who turned up at the centuriesold Mission today. San Juan Day. That is when the birds are supposed to take off for their wintering grounds in South America. On March 19, St. Joseph's Day. they supposedly return.

title: French Relay Station Bombed
description: RENNES, France, Oct. 23 (AP)A bomb planted by Breton separatists knocked out a radio and televcsion relay station serving western France, authorities reported today. They estimated damage from the explosion near Laval last night at $2 million.

title: Associated Press Jerry Pate cooling off after parring the seventh hole at the Southern open in Columbus, Ga., yesterday.
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Oct. 23 (AP)Jerry Pate, regaining his 1976 United States Open championship form, after a shoulder injury threatened his career, battered par with a 66 today and captured the $125,000 Southern open golf tournament by seven strokes.

title: Two New Elements, Two Big Upsets
description: Minnesota called upon a new quarterback while Notre Dame wore new ierseys Saturday. The result was two of the season's biggest upsets: Minnesota over previously undefeated Michigan, 160, and Notre Dame over highly favored Southern California. 4919.

title: Serving Notice on Dr. Burns
description: The issue in Washington now is not whether Keynes is dead, but whether Arthur Burns is sunk. Last week, the prime rate rose. The stock market dropped. And the august chairman of the Federal Reserve Board was suddenly the target of a rare White House attack.

title: Consumer Unit Backers Try Again
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Advocates of an independent consumer protection agency will make another try for Congressional approval this week with a revised bill that abandons some of the powers in the original legislation.

title: Soviet Jetliner Sets a Record
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (UPI)  A Soviet Aeroflot IL62 jetliner carrying a female crew has set a world distance record for a nonstop directline flight, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: 3 Young Choreographers Show Their Artistry
description: Three more or less young choreographers who are not on the regular Dance Umbrella series this season received a special showcase in what. was called a Mini Umbrella matinee at the Entermedia Theater Saturday afternoon.

title: Millie Jackson Shares a Bill With O'Jays
description: At the O'Jays concert Friday night at Radio City Music Hall, the headliners came close to being upstaged by the opening act, Millie Jackson.

title: Port Authority Is Reportedly Sure That Concorde Flights Can Go On
description: Officials of the Port Authority of New York. and New Jersey were reported convinced yesterday that the modest; noise emitted by the supersonic Concorde airliner in test takeoffs and landings here had doomed the campaign to head off regular passenger service.

title: Advertising
description: Rupert Murdoch's Star is rising. The flamboyant tabloid, introduced in February 1974 as The National Star, now revamped and repositioned, with greatly improved supermarket distribution, is once again getting promotion support, and sales are booming.

title: Congressman Assails Proposals To Adjust Federal Wage System
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)The Carter Administration's proposed changes in the Federal wage scale could cost more than 6,000 bluecollar workers in Massachusetts about $10 million a year. according to Representative J. Joseph Moakley, Democrat of Massachusetts.

title: Congressional. Study Assails Plan to Give Bus Industry $200 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23An energy bill provision to give $200 million to the intercity bus industry is not needed and would not provide significant energy savings, as its supporters contend, according to Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Congressional Budget Office.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI}An Interior Department board will consider this week changing the name of North America's tallest peak, Mount McKinley, to its original Indian name of Denali, meaning the. Great One.

title: OFFICIALS SATISFIED WITH NUCLEAR PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 The Carter Administration is satisfied with the results of last week's 40nation conference on nuclear technology despite the fact that it produced no new agreements to slow the spread of equipment that could be used to build atomic weapons.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: United Press International SEVEN DIE IN CHICAGO HOTEL FIRE: Firemen carrying body of victim from the scene of fire in transient hotel Saturday night. Seven persons died and 14 were injured during the blaze at the Hotel Toledo, a twostory structure situated on Chicago's South Side.

title: Catalan Leader, Exiled 38 Years, Returns to Tumultuous Welcome
description: BARCELONA. Spain. Oct. 23 After 38 years in exile, losep Tarradellas, the embodiment and symbol of Catalonia's renascent nationalism, came home today to a tumultuous and sentimental welcome.

title: SOLVEIG (SUE) GORDON
description: Solveig (Sue) Gordon, a former president of Talbot Perkins Children's Services and a board member since 1959, died Friday of an apparent heart attack at her home in Port Washington, L. 1, She was 54 years old.

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: NEWYORK PORT GIMP LEAVES JONT TALKS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 23 The New York Shipping Association resigned from the North Atlantic employers group today and said that it would work separately with the ocean carriers toward an agreement with striking longshoremen.

title: Donnie Allison Triumphs
description: ROCKINGHAIVI, N. C., Oct. 23 (UPI)Donnie Allison, whose speed was unmatched all afternoon, won by 7.9 seconds from Richard Petty today in the American 500 stockcar race.

title: Russian Report Flight Record
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP)An allwoman Sowiet crew aboard an Aeroflot IL62 aircraft set a world record for nonstop femalepiloted flight for jet airliners, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. Tass, said the 625. 7mile flight from Sofia, Bulgaria, to Vladivostok in the Soviet far east took 13 hours and one minute.

title: Factory Heat to Be U.A.W. Issue
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23 (UPI)A United Automobile Workers union executive has vowed to make factory heat a key demand in local contract talks, even though the negotiations are still two years away.

title: Soviet Icebreaker Starts Trials
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (AP)The Soviet Union's third atomicpowered icebreaker, the Sibir, has begun sea trials, Pravda reported today. The Communist Party newspaper said the Sibir, built in Leningrad, was almost identical to the 460foot Arktika, which last. Aug. 17 became the World's first surface ship to reach the North Pole.

title: Stone Double Winner In Charles Regatta
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23Three thousand forty oarsmen and oarswomen took part today in the 18 events that make up the Head of the Charles Regatta, making this annual Boston event the largest amateur rowing regatta in the United States. The weather cooperated, making conditions close to ideal on a threemile course that starts at the Boston University boathouse and winds its way upstream through the bridges at Harvard.

title: Study Urges Federal Regulation Over Municipal Securities Issues
description: Citing widespread shortcomings in current methods of selling, state and local government obligations, an independent research group has called for Federal regulation of municipal securities.

title: Juilliard Quartet Presents Glorio us Mozart Program
description: The Juilliard Quartet seems to be concentrating on cycles this season. Starting Jan. 25 the group will present a sixconcert series of the Beethoven quartets at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. And Saturday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall the four players began a cycle of five programs devoted to Mozart quartets and quintets, rather giddily entitled A Glory of Mozart. But it was pretty glorious.

title: OIL CARGO BILL SPLITS JERSEY DELEGATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The defeat of the oil cargo bill in the House last week by 257 votes to 165 has left a split New Jersey Congressional delegation with this argument: Was the decision a victory for the public and the country's economy or a ripoff for multibillion dollar oil companies and another blow against the United States Merchant Marine?

title: Another World Series, Played in 7 Innings on Concrete
description: The softball playersotten men In their 30's perhaps a few In their 40'swere sliding into bases on the concrete field and crashing into cyclone fences for long fly balls.

title: Holy Cross Eleven Defeats St. Francis Prep by 1412
description: Holy Cross High School sent St. Francis Prep's football team packing down Francis Lewis Boulevard yesterday thanks to the accurate passing of Glen Tants, the talented toe of Tony Langone and two thirdquarter turnovers. Holy Cross defeated the Prep, 1412, before a fullhouse crowd of 6,000 at Flushing Memorial Field in Queens.

title: The New York Times/Edward Hausner
description: The four major candidates for Mayor of New York sat on a couch in a tiny living room in a building surrounded by burned and abandoned hulks in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday and told some of the neighbors what they would do to stem such blight.

title: News Summary
description: Panamanian voters were giving strong support in a national plebiscite for approval of the nzsv Panama Canal treaties with the United States. Representative districts in the capital showed that more than 60 percent of the early voters backed the pacts, and observers expected the favorable vote to rise as returns from the interior increased. One official described the voting as massive. [Page 1, Column 6.1

title: Success Doesn't Stop Steinbrenner
description: George M. Steinbrenner confirmed yesterday that he had been quietly buying out his partners on the New York Yankees, was now the majority shareholder and was reinvesting every dollar to perpetuate the world championship won by the team last week.

title: United Press International

description: GLASSBORO N.J., Oct. 23 (AP)Kathy Mueller of Trenton State won the singles title in the New Jersey Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for women tennis tournament today. She defeated Sandy Silverblatt of Rutgers, 6.0, 6.2, in the final.

title: Father and Son in California Held In Murder and a Bungled Attempt
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23Two members of a family made notorious by allegations of involvement with organized crime have been accused of a grotesque murder and a bunlled attempt at murder.

title: Esposito and Miss Bellamy Step Up Campaigns As Race Narrows for President of City Council
description: She's liberal, I'm conservativetake your choice, Assemblyman John A. Esposito said as he gave his view of the major issue in the campaign for the City Council Presidency between himself and State Senator Carol Bellamy< the DemocraticLiberal contender and the overwhelming favorite to be New York City's next Council president.

title: Cable TV, After Lagging for Four Years, Is on the Move Again in Area
description: After four years of little growththe result of the economic trials of the two Manhattan systemscable television is suddenly on the move again in the metropolitan area.

title: Sloop, Reported Overdue, Arrives In Bermuda With All Aboard Safe
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)A 32foot sloop, reported overdue, has arrived in Bermuda with all four persons aboard safe and well, the Coast Guard here reported today.

title: The Bushwick Area Is Struggling To Avoid Becoming a South Bronx
description: In the midday darkness under the el tracks. three months after the blackout looting that made the onceobscure Bushwick section of Brooklyn a new synonym for urban decay, most of the storefronts along Broadway are still sealed by steel shutters or are holes where twisted grates guard blackened rubble.

title: Small Business Agency Pressed By New Demand for Drought Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Small Business Administration, which promises soon to surpass the Agriculture Department as the chief dispenser of disasterrelief loans to farmers, has been working overtime this weekend at its newly assigned task of putting money into the hands of those who have suffered from the drought.

title: Disabled Should Not Be Placed inMakeDo Jobs, Conference Told
description: EDISON, Oct. 23Practical advice on career growth and devlopment for the disabled was given yesterday by five New Jerseyans who have achieved rewarding careers and a North Bergen personnel director who said businessmen could not afford to waste handicapped workers by outtin2 them in makedo jobs.

title: Italian Rail Workers Strike
description: ROME, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Italian train service was paralyzed today and hundreds of passengers were stranded by strike of nearly 200,000 railway workers demanding more pay. Hundreds of thousands of commuters will be forced tomorrow to find other ways to get to work. The 24hour strike by guards and locomotive engineers started last night.

title: News Summary
description: Strong support for Panama Canal treaties with the United States was shown in early returns in a national plebiscite in Panama. Voting was heavy, no disorders were reported and a visit to many polling places showed no signs of Government interference with the balloting. The Government hoped for a favorable vote by at least twothirds of the 800,000 eligible voters. [Page 1, Column 6.]

description: When stock prices are falling, in. vestors naturally regard the market with apprehension, few having the fortitude to buy for fear of continued selling.

title: Grocery Store Guides Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Federal Government is about to propose the first national guidelines aimed at keeping the country's 200,000 grocery stores clean, The Food and Drug Administration, which will announce the proposal in Tuesday's edition of the Federal Register, said no such model ordinance has ever been written for the retail food store industry.

title: Church to Study Rights Document
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 23 (AP)The General Assembly of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) voted today to accept. a report for study by local congregations that suggests the 1.3millionmember church should work for human and civil rights for homosexuals. The report is study document and is not to be construed as an official statement, the church said.

title: The Elation and Agony Of a First Time Starter
description: Bevis Longstrcth slept fitfully, waking every hour or so to glance at the alarm clock. I felt like a 10yearold on Christmas morning, he said yesterday on the bus that carried him and 40 other mostly middleaged, mostly male, mostly white marathoners to the staging area at Fort Wadsworth on the Staten Island side of the Verrazano Bridge.

title: Proxmire Proposes Setting Ceiling On Future Sales of American Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Senator William Proxmire proposed today a declining ceiling on the sale of American arms so that no more than $4 billion worth could be sold after fiscal year 1979.

title: Miller's Broncos Remain Unbeaten After Stopping Bengals by 2413
description: Robert (Red) Miller, after six weeks as a rookie head coach in the National Football League, still does not know how it feels to lose. Miller, who spent the last four seasons as coach of the offense at New England, was named in February to pilot the Denver Broncos, who strangely dropped John Ralston after he had led them to a 95 wonlost record, the best in Denver's 17year history.

title: Canadiens Tally 3 Early to Top Rangers by 62
description: The Rangers concluded a weekend defensive collapse last night with a 62 loss to tile Montreal Canadiens the day after the New Yorkers had lost by 72 to the Islanders. The peerless Canadiens took a threegoal lead, and each time the Rangers scored, their goal was answered within minutes by the visitoys, who seemed able to score at will.

title: The Homosexual in the Classroom
description: Should homosexuals be permitted to teach? Not the opinion of 65 percent of Americans, many of whom approve of equal job rights for homosexuals in other professions. The fear that a homosexual teacher may become a role model for an impressionable adolescent evidently worries most parents more than the injustice of barring an entire category of people from a major profession on insufficient evidence of danger.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Customs Service has agreed to install more than 200 bilingual signs at Canadian and Mexican border crossings into the United States.

title: Producer of Musicals Is Shot And Wounded During Argument
description: Norman J. Seaman, a producer of musical events in New York City, was shot during an argument Saturday evening outside Carnegie Hall. He was reported. to be in satisfactory condition yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Independence of Nuclear Safety Agency Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 A former top official in the Federal commission established three years ago to assure the safety of nuclear power believes that the commission is dominated by the Federal agency promoting the use of nuclear reactors.

description: A few days ago a reader wrooi to ahout the purchase of fresh clron in New York. Citron is a kind of lemon whose hestknown use is, outside the Jewish religion, in its preserved candied form chopped as an ingredient for fruitcake. I replied that I had never seen citron in any other form.

title: Officer Injured in Fatal Clash
description: PHILADELPHIA. Oct. 23 (UPl)A police officer was reported in fair condition today after he was accidentally shot by an offduty policeman in a weekend shooting that claimed the life of a North Philadelphia man. Police Commissioner Joseph O'Neill said the shooting incident early yesterday began when Edward Jackson attacked Officer Anthony Boyle, 125 years old, with a meat cleaver in a tavern. Mr. O'Neill said Officer Daniel Hines somehow got between the two men as Officer Boyle fired his personal revolver, a. 357 magnum. Mr. Jackson died in Temple Hospital.

title: Fira Benenson, Fashion Designer
description: Fira Benenson, who as head of Bonwit Teller's salon de couture from 1934 to 1948 was a leader in fashion design when Paris was occupied during World War II, died yesterday in her home, at 333 East 57th Street. She was 79 years old. Miss Benenson was the widow of Janusz Ilinski, an officer in the Polish Army who at his death in 1961 was chairman of the Carlyle Hotel and a vice president of City Investing Company.

title: A Paddleball Upset
description: Bobby Schwartz and Andy Krosnick of Far Rockaway, Queens, who had not lost a match in five years, were defeated yesterday in the semifinal round of the National OneWall paddleball championships at Queensboro Community College. They lost to Tom Lowy of Manhattan and John Faber of Budd Lake, N.J., 1221, 2220, 2220. In the other semifinal match, Barry Scheiber of Manhattan and Ron Richmond of Flushing, Queens, topped Mel Frankel and Cliff Lang of Brooklyn, 2118, 2114.

title: Javits Sees Problems Developing Between United States and Israel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reuters) Senator Jacob K. Javits said today there could be a crunch coming in AmericanIsraeli relations over the Geneva conference on the Middle East.

title: Bhutto, in Lahore Court, Fights for His Political Life
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Oct. 22 In a 100yearold pink brick courthouse here, former Prime Minister Zulfikar A:ti Bhutto is fighting hard for his political life.

title: A Buoyant Humphrey Returns to Capital With Carter
description: WASHINGTON, On 23 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey returned to this city today gatmt and hangard but almost as buoyant as ever after nearly two months of treatment for a Malignant tumor.

title: Cranberries to Be in Short Supply in State
description: CHATSWORTH, Oct. 23The cranberry harvest is at its peak, but the picking is slimmer than it has been for many years. The result will be a shortage of cranberry sauce for the Thanksgiving table, with a higher than usual price for the sauce that is available.

title: Chess:
description: The question that arises again and again in a wide variety of positions is whether it is worth the loss of a tempo to acquire the bishop pair.

title: Todd Excels in Loss, Passes for 4 Scores
description: One of the most powerful passing performances in Jets history, almost enough to engineer an upset over the strong Oakland Raiders, was reduced to an interesting statistic yesterday as the Super Bowl champions plowed sack to score a 2S27 victory over the New Yorkers.

title: Ready To Face Tomorrow
description: LOS ANGELESThis is the time of the year when, with Thanksgiving looming in the distance, people start putting together lists of all the things they have to be thankful for. I have different kind of list. It's of things don't havefor which I am very thankful.

title: Bridge:
description: MANILA, Oct. 23One of the two United States teams retained a bic lead at the end of play this afternoon in the World Team Championships, while the other clung to the vital second position by a narrow margin.

title: U.S. Appeals Order to Quit Pact That Bans Bowhead Whale Hunt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP)The Goverment said today that the slaughter and even extinction, of all whales could result if it was forced to obey a court order to withdraw from an international accord banning the hunting of bowhead whales by Alaskan Eskimos.

title: Earliest Life Forms Are Found in Rocks
description: The remains of the earliest known form of life to appear on the earth. microscopic onecelled creatures that are 3.4 billion years old, have been found embedded in rocks from South Africa.

title: Vietnam Veterans and Refugees Still Exist
description: WASHINGTONThis country's indifference to its Vietnam veterans is a national scandal. Equally outrageous is its indifference to the plight of the refugees who continue to flee the various Communist regimes in Indochina. The two kinds of indifference are related, I think, in that they both testify to our national inability to come to terms with what happened in Vietnam between 1961 and 1975.

title: Lester Markel of The Times Is Dead
description: Lester Markel, the Sunday editor of The New York Times for more than 40 years and an associate editor of the newspaper from 1964 until his retirement in 1968, died of cancer yesterday at his home at 135 Central Park West. He was83 years old and also lived in Oakhurst, N.J.

title: Lesbian Won't Seek Reelection To Legislature in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23 (AP)Elaine Noble, an avowed lesbian, will not seek reelection next year to the Massachusetts House of Representatives because her father is ill, an aide, Carla Brewington, said today.

title: Theater: A New Side by Side
description: The English accent with which Side By Side Sondheim arrived from London last April has been diluted in the new cast that took over officially at the Music Box last night. But it is still present in the voice of Hermione Gingold who has inherited the role of narrator previously played by Ned Sherrin.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of Oct. 7 Bearing Steel's Burdens is an eloquent statement of the case against quantitative restrictions on the world steel trade, but it misstates an important fact with respect to the enforcement of the U.S. antidumping laws.

title: Rodgers Once More Victor in Marathon
description: Maybe it was the crowded corridor that formed along First Avenue. Or the vision that suddenly came to Bill Rodgers after 20 miles, when his legs felt tight. Or maybe Rodgers is simply the world's best marathon man.

title: Commodities
description: Of all the noble metals, none has had a stranger pedigree than platinum. Until a century ago, it was cursed by frustrated miners as fool's silver and thrown away, although the use of platinum to produce flameless energy was developcd as early as 1807.

title: FED VOTED TO LIFT SHORTTERM RATES AT SEPT, 20 MEETING
description: The 12 Federal Reserve governors and regional bank presidents who set the course of the nation's monetary policy voted in midSeptember for the third time within a month and a half to push interest rates upward.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TONES AND TEAMS Doc Cheatham, the jazz trumpeter, bows in tonight for an engagement at Crawdaddy, reactivating a career that began with Cab Calloway's band in the 1920's and included a stint in the brass section of Benny Goodman's orchestra. Flanked by Chuck Folds at the piano and Jackie Williams on drums, Mr. Cheatham will play on Mondays through Fridays from 6:30 to 11:30 P.M. No cover or minimum charges at the Crawdaddy (6871860), in the Roosevelt Hotel building at 45th Street and Vanderbilt Avenue.

title: Exceller Overtakes Majestic Light on Canada Turf
description: TORONTO, Oct. 23 (AP)Nelson Bunker Hunt's Exceller overtook Majestic Light in the stretch today and won the $193,500 Canadian International Championship by a length at Woodbine.

title: Bonn Hints It Will Boycott Airports With Lax Security
description: BONN, Oct. 23West Germany demanded today that stiffer measures to prevent airliner hijackings be taken in many parts of the world, and indicated it would boycott airports where it considered security procedures to be too lax.

title: Leonard Silk
description: CAIRO. Oct. 23Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal's mission to the Middle East, which began here this weekend. has two main purposes. One has to do with oil and moneyan effort to persuade the leaders of the oilproducing countries that The their own economic and political interests, as well Economic as those of the United Scene States and other oilimporting countries, would he severely hurt by another stiff increase in the price of oil. The other aim is to provide economic backup for President Carter's efforts to ease political tensions in the Middle East and bring the Arab states and Israel together at Geneva for peace negotiations.

title: Lester Market, Former Editor Of The Sunday Times, Dies at 83
description: Lester Market, Former Editor Of The Sunday Times, Dies at 83Lester Market, Former Editor Of The Sunday Times, Dies at 83

title: 7 Years Later, McLucas Has A Last Battle
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23Seven years after a series of Black Panther murder trials raised the specter of mob violence here, all but one of the original 14 defendants accused of killing an alleged informer. Alex Rackley, have dispersed and faded into relative obscurity.

title: Runners Give Caso Leg on Rivals
description: In accustomed loneliness for a longdistance officeholder, Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso became the winner of a little extra preelection air time yesterday. The New York Marathon. with its resulting crowds and traffic patterns, delayed his two challengers arrival at a television broadcast at I West 67th Street, a block or so from the marathon's finish line.

title: Books of The Times
description: Daniel Schorr is, of course, the Emmy. Awardwinning CBS television correspondent who covered Watergate and the various investigationsby Congress and the Rockefeller Commission of the Central Intelligence Agency; who made No. 17 on President Richard M. Nixon's enemies list and was investigated by the F.B.I.; who passed along to the Village Voice the Pike Committee report on the C.I.A. after the House had voted to withhold that report from the public; and who was suspended by his own network even as he faced a contemptofCongress citation and a jail sentence for refusing to divulge his source for the report. After 40 years of reporting the news, here and abroad, Mr. Schorr became the news.

title: Compton Acquires A Part of Ross Roy

title: In Paris, Serious Undertones in Fashion's Superbowl

They drove up Prom the provinces after they closed their shops Saturday night. They took trains from West Germany and the Benelux countries and those who had seen the preliminaries, the first spring collections, came up from Italy.

description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that New York City would lose at least $23 million because of cost overruns and poor planning in the construction of its sewagetreatment plants and Sewer system.

title: Eobson's Choice at Long Wharf Is Like an Old WellMade Sofa
description: NEW HAVEN  Hobson's Choice, the 62yearold play about a comic but effective revolution in a shoe shop, is more than a chestnut but less than a classic.

title: Lester Markel of The Times Is Dead
description: Lester Markel, the Sunday editor of The New York Times for more than 40 years and an associate editor of the newspaper from 1964 until his retirement in 1968, died of cancer yesterday at his home at 135 Central Park West. He was 83 years old and also lived in Oakhurst, N.J.

title: G.O.P. Leader Opposes Cutoff in Aid for Korea
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) The House Republican leader, John J. Rhodes of Arizona, said today that he opposed cutting aid to South Korea in retaliation for Seoul's lack of cooperation with the influencebuying investigation on Capitol Hill. The Senate Democratic leader, Rohert C. Byrd of West. Virginia, has warned that South Korea refusal to cooperate with the inquiry could affect Congressional voles on foreign aid.

title: 2 Spectator Deaths Mar Hunt's Victory in Japan
description: GOTEMBA, Japan, Oct. 23 (AP)The 1977 Formula One altoracing season ended today with James Hunt winning the Japan Grand Prix in a race that did not change the world drivers championship standing, but one that was marred by two spectator deaths.

title: West Germany Is Said to Offer Guernica Bombing Reparations
description: BILBAO, Spain, Oct. 20 (UPI) West Germany has offered to pay symbolic damages for the destruction of the city of Guernica by German bombers during the Spanish Civil War, according to local civic organization.

title: Lawsuits Charge That DownFilled Jackets Contain More Feathers Than Fluff

title: Sculpture Pieces Enliven Grounds of Mental Center on Wards
description: Mental patients confined at the state's Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island have never had much to look at: massive, fortresslike buildings studded with escapeproof, steelribbed windows and a drab interior of locked wards and windowless corri dors. By any standards, it is dehumanizing and depressing.

title: Fire Routs Furniture Buyers

title: Ossining Skeptical About Status of Sing Sing
description: OSSINING, N.Y.Until about two months ago, Cellblock A at Ossining Correctional Facility, once called Sing Sing, had been vacant and unused for two years. The plumbing snaking into its 700 9byIfoot cells was rusted and unusable and its electrical wiring had nearly rotted.

title: EARLY RETURNS SHOW PANAMA SUPPORTING CANAL TREATIES 21
description: PANAMA, Oct. 23Panamanians voted today in a national plebiscite on the new Panama Canal treaties with the United States and early returns showed votes running about two to one in favor of ratification.

title: Victory for Mrs. King
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 23 (AP);Billie Jean King won her second tournament in her singles comeback today. She beat Betty Stove of the Netherlands, 61, 64, in the final of a $50,000 Grand Prix event. The victory was worth $14,000.

title: Lester Markel, 18941977
description: What does it mean, Lester Markel would have wanted to know about his life. First and last, that is always what he wanted to know from the generations of writers badgered so belligerently in creating and managing The Sunday New York Times, the newspaper of newspapers. Try to imagine The Times without its exhaustive Sunday exploration of every critical event and idea of political and cultural life. Try to imagine Sundays without such a Times. That's what it means.

description: GREENWICH, Conn.For the last nine years the Bangor Punta Corporation has kept an extremely low profile.

description: ROME, Oct. 23 (UPI)Leftwing terrorists shot and seriously wounded a Milan city councilman today and planted a bomb whose detonation left a policeman in critical condition in the northern city of Brescia. It was the sixth day of attacks on West German property throughout Italy, according to police.

title: The White House Attack on the Fed's Monetary Policy
description: Echoes from the Administration's attack on the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy last Thursday are still resounding in the business and financial world. The sharpness and the timing of the attack were surprising and raised questions about the current economic picture and the ultimate effects of the unusual criticism of the nation's central bank. Although the top echelon of the Administration's economic hierarchy had been publicly quiet on monetary matters since last spring, there were hints in recent weeks that some officials were becoming restive as they watched the steady efforts of the Fed to counter the rising trend of the money supply  and the accompanying inflationary danger  by forcing shortterm interest rates higher. Nevertheless, few financial analysts were prepared for the sharp criticism from the White

description: SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP)Victor W. Nash, 57 years old, owner of International Gemstones Inc of San Francisco, told the police that as he was leaving his motel room early today to enter his car, which had $2 million in jewels in the trunk, to go to a department store gem show, he felt a tap on the shoulder.

title: Gattuso, Chase Honored
description: CENTREVILLE, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP) Joe Gattuso, the Navy running back, and Ray Chase, a defensive end at Richmond, were named today Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I football players of the week. Gattuso, a senior tailback from Mickleton, N.J., scored twice and ran for 250 yards in Navy's 4217 victory over William and Mary. Chase, a junior from Great Mills, Md., made 10 tackles, including four quarterback sacks, in Richmond's 1714 upset of Virginia Tech.

title: A NEW WESTERN PLAN SEEKS TO END IMPASSE IN TROOPCUT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Carter Administration and its key allies in Europe have agreed on the terms of a new proposal designed to break the deadlock with the Soviet Union over negotiations on mutual reductions of forces in central Europe.

title: James Earl Ray Wants Mark Lane To Replace His Tenth Lawyer
description: WARTBURG, Tenn., Oct. 23 (UPI)James Earl Ray, the convicted killer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., asked today that his attorney, Jack Kershaw of Nashville, be replaced by Mark Lane, the New York lawyer who wrote a book on the King assassination.

title: Nid Tongootai Is Married
description: Nid Tongootai, a former broadcaster and translater for the United Nations, was married yesterday to Hedley G. Radford, former senior partner of the architectural firm of H. G. Radford in Kampala, Uganda, State Supreme Court Justice Jack Rosenberg performed the ceremony in his chambers. Both the bride and bridegroom were married previously and divorced.

title: INTEREST RATES EBB IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Short  term interest rates declined slightly in the money market yesterday, and the Federal Reserve promptly moved to prop them up.

title: New Report About Family Murder Causes Delay in TeenAger's Trial
description: HACKENSACK. Oct. 24The murder trial of Harry De I.a Roche Jr., the 19yearold former military student accused of slaying his parents and two brothers last November, was postponed indefinitely today amid a flurry of subpoenas over a weekend newspaper article in which the teenager was quoted as saying his younger brother, not he, had committed three of the murders.

ROY RILEY JR.
description: NASHVILLE. Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP)Roy Riley Jr., a sportswriter for newspapers in Tennessee, Alabama and Georgia, died of a heart attack early yesterday while visiting friends in Birmingham. Ala. He was 34 years old. In 1970 Mr. Riley was honored by The Associated Press for having written the best humaninterest sports story !n Alabama.

title: Poisoning of Sea Gulls Proposed at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI)Sea gulls, fed by refuse in municipal dumps near the coast, pose an increasing threat to aircraft in the Northeast, but the Federal Government thinks it has the solutionpoison.

title: Mrs. La Guardia Backing Cuomo for Mayor
description: Marie La Guardia patted a widebrimmed western hatthe sort her husband, Fiorello, used to wealflat on the head of Mario M. Cuomo yesterday and endorsed his candidacy for Mayor of New York City.

description: TOKYO, Oct. 24  A sharp drop turnover of foreign stocks listed on the Tokyo stock exchange and high auditing costs for their required financial reports are compelling some of the foreign companies to withdraw from the stock market here.

title: BYRNE, BATEMAN RUN $1 MILLION CAMPAIGNS,
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24Governor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman I are spending about $1 million each for advertising on New York television and radio in this year's gubernation election and an estimated total of $300,000 on Philadelphia stations in the first New Jersey campaign to make such extensive use of the electronic media.

description: HONG KONG, Oct. 24Chinese officials are concerned about a decline in the level of education in their schools, according to the press agency Hsinhua.

description: The Exxon Corporation, the world's biggest petroleum company, reported yesterday flat earnings in the third quarter on a revenue gain of 12.5 percent, to $14.5 billion.

title: Notes on People
description: That miracle the Rev. Clennon King hoped for has come to pass. Mr. King the black minister who got into the headlines shortly before last year's Presidential election when he tried to integrate Jimmy Carter's hometown Baptist Church in Plains, Ga., was about to be evicted from his own Divine Mission Church in Albany, Ga., last. Friday, for nonpayment of $550 in back rent. Mr. King last week said that only a miracle of God could stop his eviction, but just in time he received a $550 certified check from Percy Ross, a Minneapolis businessman, who told Mr. King he believed in miracles.

title: After the Canal Treaties
description: WASHINGTONThe Panamanians, in their plebiscite Sunday, voted for the Panama Canal treaties. The decision is now up to our Senate, which presumably will not vote on the issue until 1978. Unfortunately, the treaties have become a highly emotional issue. We know the Canal's history, we have begun to scrutinize the treaties positive and negative elements, but we haven't given much thought to the effects of an affirmative or *negative Senate decision.

description: N. Loyal! McLaren, who was president of the American Institute of Accountants in 194142 and chairman of the New York division of the Navy Price Adjustment Board in 1943, died at his home in San Francisco on Sunday. He was S5 years old.

title: P.L.O. Canvassing Arabs on West Bank

title: Barn Door in Congress
description: Mr. Lance has also left a legacy in Congress. Leaders of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, embarrassed by their hasty confirmation of hint last January, are now proposing to create a new Senate office to investigate the background and integrity of Presidential nominees before they are confirmed. The controversial resolution has been informally dubbed the Bert Lance Barn Door Bill.

title: Next Head of S.I.A. Would Widen Participation in Running Big Board
description: Calling yesterday for wider participation in the management and operation of the New York Stock Exchange, Robert H. B. Baldwin, president of Morgan Stanley & Company, said that member firms can't look at ourselves as though we own the stock exchange.

title: Shows Grow, but Noton Audience
description: I do not believe that there is a concerted effort afoot on the part of directors and actors to put contemporary audiences to sleep. Quite the contrary. It seems to me that the whole current thrust of theatrical activity is to keep the audience from ever getting to sleep. Haven't you noticed that performances these days grow longer and longer, keeping customers in the playhouse well past their bedtimes?

title: Ludwig Rosenberg of West Germany; Former Chief of Labor Federation
description: DUSSELDORF, West Germany, Oct. 24 (AP)Ludwig Rosenberg, a Jew who fled Nazi Germany and returned after the war to lead West Germany's Trade Union Federation, died today of a heart attack, the federation said. He was 74.

description: He will come out of the visitors dressing room Instead of the Knicks dressing room. He will wear No. 11 instead of No. 10, and his uniform will be portwine colored with gold trim, instead of white with orange and blue trim.

title: Correction Officials At Odds on Where Slayer Should Go
description: New York City and New York State correctional authorities are at odds over whether the slayer of two New York City police officers should serve his sentence in New York or be sent to California first to serve a Federal sentence of up to 25 years for bank robbery.

title: TV:2New, Very Sweet Families
description: Mulligan's Stew and James at 15 Offered by NBC ABC Examines TeenAgers Drinking and Drugs

title: Educators Fear a Ruling for Bakke Would Undo Minorities
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.As the Supreme Court ponders the arguments in the Bakke case, university officials across the country are expressing deep concern that a ruling against affirmative action programs would roll back the vast gains made by minorities in professional education over the last decade.

title: 27 Feared Dead in Sri Lanka
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka. Oct. 24 (AP)Twentyseven persons are feared dead in a landslide that swept over workers quarters on a tea plantation in central Sri Lanka on Saturday night. The police said that a hillside loosened by steady rains slid over the barrackslike structure flattening rooms housing nine families.

title: Attica Uprising Leader Held
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 24 (AP)An inmate leader of the ]971 Attica prison uprising has been arrested and charged with parole violation, the police here said today. The accused man, Roger Champen, was arrested at his home yesterday after two arrests for illegal possession of weapons in New York City, according to Ed Liddy, an officer for the State Division of Parole. Mr. Champen also was charged with possession of two onces of marijuana.

title: Post Strong on Defense But Once Led in Offense
description: C. W. Post has made such a drastic transition from an offensive football power to a strong defensive team that the Pioneers, who led the nation in smallcollege passing offense in 1971, are now among the nation's top five teams in rushing and scoring defense. They made the change under one coach, Dom Anile, who has been Post's leader for 10 years.

title: Blumenthal Seeks to Assure Israel Of Continued Support From U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 24Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, on his swing through the Middle East, sought today to give Prime Minister Menahem Begin and an anxious Israel reassurance of continued United States economic and military support.

title: Lanier and Money Star As Pistons Beat Celtics
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP)Bob Lanier and Eric Money paced a secondhalf blitz as the Detroit Pistons whipped the Boston Celtics, 10085, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Homosexuals In New York Find New Pride
description: It was Yom Kippur at Congregation Beth Simchat Torah, Manhattan's fouryearold selfproclaimed gay synagogue, and the temple facilities in Westbeth apartments in Greenwich Village were over flowing with more than 350 worshipers.

title: Truants Will Be Lured With T Shirts and Gifts
description: MIAMI, Oct. 24 (UPI)Dade County school officials have started an experimental plan to lure truants back to classes at two schools with gifts of Frisbees, Tshirts, yoyos and hamburgers. The program will reward teachers having the best attendance records with free gasoline, record albums and dinners.

title: IN THE NATION
description: just them downward. They believe rt.taining parole would retain much inequity and uncertaintyrather than guarding against themcause confusion, and perhaps even torpedo the work of the Sentencing Commission.

title: Soviet Accuses U.S. On Plane Hijackings
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Soviet officials today accused the United States of violating international conventions and using double standards on hiiackincs.

title: Tank Explosion Kills Worker
description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 24 (AP)A worker at the Union Carbide plant in suburban DeWitt was killed this morning when a large steel tank used to store volatile chemicals exploded, police said. The victim, Gerald Knafelc, 32 years old, was cleaning the tank at the time and was thrown against a wall by the force of the blast. The police said a drop of water or a spark in the tank, which had previously held calcium carbonate, could have set off an explosion.

title: All Is Fare in etc etc.
description: It may sound funny coming from someone whose airline passengers he's trying to lure away, but hooray for Freddie Laker! With his Barnum & Bailey enthusiasm, he's managed to restore some goodnatured fun to our industry. But we owe him an even more important vote of thanks.

title: Tightened Safety for Large Dams Urged in Research Council Report
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The Bureau of Reclamation, which has built and maintained most of the large dams in the West has been urged to tighten its safety procedures and install more sophisticated instruments to warn against leaks and deterioration.

title: Byrne Asserts Thousands of Jobs Would Be Lost in SalesTax Rise
description: Governor Byrne said yesterday mat thousands of jobs arid millions of dollars in retail sales would be lost if the state's sales tax were raised. State Senator Raymond H. Bateman has promised that if elected Governor on Nov. S he will run the state for four years without an income tax and only as a last resort raise the 5 percent sales tax by a penny.

title: City Opera Does Toppea
description: Monteverdi's L'Ineoronazione di Poppea may 42 one of the glories of the early Italian B7roque and one of the imperishable masterpieces of the entire operatic literature. But either the patrons of the New York City Opera don't know that, or they have rejected the company's production of the opera, which returned to the repertury Sunday night. This observer has never seen the New York State Theater emptier, at least when a performance was supposed to be going on.

title: FOUR NEW MINISTERS JOIN THE ISRAELI GOVERNMENT
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 24Four Cabinet ministers representing the Democratic Movement for Change joined Prime Minister Menahem Begin's Government today after the Parliament had voted confidence in them, 62 to 34.

title: New Era in Quebec's Industry
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 24The Quebec government has driven another wedge between its2Ii and the North American business world with its announcement that it plans to take over, by negotiation or by other means the American owned Asbestos Lorporation. By the same token, it has won points with most Quebec wage earners. The move was something the Parti Quebecois now in power had always said it would make. The businessmen, already alienated by the government's drive for independence and by social and language measures, nonetheless reacted with shock and dismay. The asbestos industry called it demoralizing and financiers said they considered it illtimed since it came in the midst of general economic depression.

title: New York City Agency Suggests Reopening of Airport in Flushing
description: New York City's Transportation Department recommended yesterday that the Flushing Airport in Queens be reIpencd as soon as higher safety standards ??

title: Riklis Plans Sale To Kenton of 23% Of RapidAmerican
description: Meshulam Riklis, the bouncy empire builder who in 1954 founded the RapidAmerican Corporation, moved yesterday to sell his substantial block of shares in it to a company in which his family holds a 40 percent interest.

title: The Desolation Of South Bronx Held Atypical
description: After President Carter's highly publicized visit to the South Bronx two weeks ago, the city's most desolate area bids fair to become one of the nation's most Perverse tourist attracttons. It is now

title: 30 NewYork Policemen Fail CorruptionComplaint Tests
description: The telephonecaller told the detective at the station house that his cousin had been arrested by a police officer who then stole $300 from him. A caller to another precinct said that his neighbor, who he believed was a police officer, was selling. narcotics.

title: Giants to Deal Tucker, End, To the Vikings
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 24From now on this year, any victory by the Giants can be marked down as improvement. After only six weeks, they have matched their 1976 victory total of three. Now, only two games removed from a 13 wonlost record and signs of breaking up, some of them are beginning to talk about the National Football League playoffs.

title: News Summary
description: Mutual reduction of forces in central Europe is the goal of a new proposal agreed upon by the Western allies in an effort to break a deadlock in negotiations with the Soviet Union. The proposal was formulated by the United States, Britain and West Germany. Officials in Washington said that the plan calls for the United States to withdraw 1,000 nuclear warheads and 29,000 troops from Europe in exchange for a Soviet cut of at least 65,000 troops and about 1,600 tanks. LPage 1, Column 6.]

title: Books of The Times
description: Thomas Jefferson once wrote that Advertisements contain the only truths to be relied on in a newspaper. Still, I thought I hated advertising, as unAmerican as such an attitude may be. And I could have sworn I had built up my resistance to a point where I never even noticed it anymore. Consider my astonishment then, when,

title: Byrne and Bateman Each Spending $1 Million for TVRadio Campaigns
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24Gmernor Byrne and State Senator Raymond H. Bateman are spending about $1 million each for advertising on New York television and radio in this year'sc gubernatorial elect tion and an estimated $300,000 on Philadelphia stations in the first New Jersey campaign to make such extensive use of the electronic media.

title: ANEW WESTERN PLAN SEEKS TO END IMPASSE IN TROOPCUT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 24The Carter Administration and its key allies in Europe have agreed on the terms of a new proposal designed to break the deadlock with the Soviet Union over negotiations on mutual reductions of forces in central Europe.

title: Japan Increases Budget
description: TOKYO, Oct. 24 (AP)Japan's Parliament today passed a supplementary budget of $1.06 billion for fiscal 1977 to stimulate the sluggish economy. The additional spending comes on top of the regular $97 billion budget for the fiscal year ending next March 31.

title: Carter Says U.S. Owes Debt to Vietnam Veterans, but Three Groups Criticize His Policy on Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Carter said today in a Veterans Day speech at Arlington National Cemetery that the country owed a special debt of gratitude to those who fought in the Vietnam War. However, several groups used the same holiday to criticize several aspects of Mr. Carter's policy toward veterans of the Asian conflict.

title: Undefeated Canadiens Turn Back Capitals, 51
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 24 (UPI)Guy Lafleur scored once and assisted on two other goals tonight to help the Montreal Canadiens defeat the Washington Capitals, 51, at the Forum.

title: New Report About Family Murder Delays Trial of Jersey TeenAger
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 24The murder trial of Harry De La Roche Jr., the 19yearold former military school student accused of slaying his parents and two brothers last November, was postponed indefinitely today amid a flurry of subpoenas over a weekend newspaper article in which the teenager was quoted as saying his younger brother, not he, had committed three of the murders.

title: Farmers in Plains Warn of a Strike Unless Prices Rise
description: PLAINS, Ga., Oct. 24 Georgia farmers gave standing ovations tonight in President Carter's hometown to speakers who condemned his farm program. Then they stood, applauding again, when called on to pledge support for a national strike for higher agricultural prices.

title: U. S. CONSIDERS STEPS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Highranking A riministration officials met today to con?? what concrete steps the United States might take against South Africa if, indicate its displeasure at the ?? last week on black leaders and organizations and their white support ers.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Rolling Stone Magazine Says Israelis Stole Uranium for Nuclear Arms
description: Israel secretly assembled a nuclear ar senal nearly a decade ago with enriched uranium stolen in the United States and Europe and purchased from West Germany and France under the cover of staged hijackings, Rolling Stone magazine reported yesterday.

title: Jackson Heights Man Dies in Fire
description: A Queens man, about 60 years old, died of smoke inhalation last night in a fire in his apartment in the Jackson Heights section, according to fire officials. The man was identified as Seymour Simon of 3910 75th Street. He was found in the living room of his fifthfloor apartment in the sixstory brick building. The fire was confined to Mr. Simon's apartment,

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Pirandello's Obscure but Fine Naked
description: Luigi Pirandello's Naked, now at Roundabout's Stage Two through Nov. 27, is little known and little performed. It deserves better on both counts. For although Naked incorporates themes familiar in Pirandello's workthe nature of identity, of reality and illusionit does so with such shrewd psychological touches and through such prismatic glints of character that they would in themselves be the substance of high comedy if the subject were not so melancholy.

title: Young in Favor Of Stiffer Steps On South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate here, said today that he favored imposing some form of sanctions against South Africa, which last week cracked down on blacks and their sympathizers, arresting hundreds and banning dissident groups.

title: Visitor to Manchuria Finds Nuclear Shelters Under Construction
description: HARBIN, ChinaAlong a main street of Harbin, day and night, seven days a week, power excavators, bulldozers, cement mixers and construction workers are building a deep nuclear shelter system.

title: William H. Leyh, 71, Architect For Penney and MONY Buildings
description: William H. Leyh, who retired in 1974 as a vice president of the architectural firm of Shreve, Lamb & Harmon Associates died Saturday at his home, 11 Cecil Crest Road, Yonkers. He was 71 years old.

title: Who's Got a Wild Card For the N.F.C. Playoff?
description: WANTED: a wildcard team for the postseason playoffs that will not absolutely embarrass the National Conference. As the regular season this weekend reaches the halfway mark, the seventh game for the 28 teams, the American Conference About has candidates galore for its four playoff positions while the other conference, the National, is short. Can one conceive of the Atlanta Falcons in the playoffs, or even the Giants?

title: P.L.O. Canvassing Arabs on West Bank
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. Oct. 24The Palostine Liberation Organization is quietly canvassing Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip seeking people to serve on a possible delegation to a Geneva peace conference, according to an authoritative source close to the organization's leadership.

title: Justice Being Retried On Perjury Charge
description: The perjury trial of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court reopened yesterdayafter a first attempt to try the case resulted in a mistrial three months ago.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 24 (Reuters)A special commission of inquiry is questioning President Tito's wife, Jovanka, who has been held at least three months at the President's private residence here, wellinformed sources said today.

title: Science Building Marks New Day For Architecture at Columbia U.
description: Romaldo Giurgola is an architect who has written movingly about his desire for buildings to appear as fragments of greater wholes, not as objects in themselves. His structures have not always brought this message across as clearly as his theories and writing have, out now at Columbia University there is a new work by his firm, Mitchell/Giurgola Associates, that brings to reality everything Mr. Giurgola has been saying.

title: The U.N. Today
Reluctance of Witnesses Hampers Inquiries in 2 Brooklyn Slayings
description: Homicide detectives in Brooklyn said last night that they had been unable to solve two open and shut murder cases because witnesses to the unrelated shootings had refused to identify suspects.

title: U.N. Committee Approves New Scale of Contributions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 24After spirited and sometimes bitter debate, a General Assembly committee tonight adopted a controversial new scale of assessments that will reduce the financial contributions of oilproducing and developing countries to next year's United Nations budget but will generally increase the share of the industrialized countries of the West.

title: Uncap the Offshore Oil Bill
description: For the second year in a row, a careful effort to reform the law governing offshore oil and gas leases is in danger of being killed by parliamentary maneuver. Last year reform legislation passed both houses of Congress and was approved by a conference committee only to be blocked in the waning days of the session. Now, seeking to repeat the coup of last year, a small group of representatives wants to throttle a new version of the bill even before it can be voted on by the House.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Five men were killed and seven others, includng two firemen, were injured today when fire broke out at a Washington club frequented by homosexuals. Several of the injured were in serious or critical condition.

title: Bridge:
description: MANILA, Tuesday, Oct. 25The United States team, the defending world charnpions, moved farther ahead in play yesterday in the World Tcam Championships,

title: Bay Area Rapid Transit Is Criticized As a Benefit for Middle Class Only
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24For a visitor reveling in the carpeted, upholstered, airconditioned luxury of a BART train speeding down the shoreline of San Francisco Bay, the question may be, why don't we have have something like this back home?

title: Dr. Ellwood A. Geiges, Creator Of Football Referee's Signals
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., Oct. 24 (AP) Funeral services will be held here tomorrow for Dr. Ellwood A. Geiges, 82 years old, the man who invented the hand signals referees use to indicate penalties in football.

title: Goodyear Profits at $33.9 Million In Quarter, Against a Loss in 1976
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest rubber fabricator( reported yesterday net income of $33.9 million for the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $5.3 million in the 1976 period when a fourmonth strike that ended in August closed 15 plants.

title: CETA HELD DRAWBACK TO EFFICIENCY IN CITY
description: New York City's government has lost flexibility and efficiency because of its growing dependence on workers paid with Federal job funds, according to some city commissioners and union leaders. The workers make up 15 percent of the staffs in departments directly responsible to the Mayor.

title: ABRAHAM M. RABOY
description: Abraham M. Raboy, vice president and treasurer of the Yoo Hoo Division, Carlstadt, N.J., of Iroquois Brands Inc., the beverage concern, died Saturday in his home, 52 Rockland Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Rams, Paced by Haden, Trounce Vikings by 353
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24Pat Haden, the healthy young Rhodes Scholar, displayed the one dimension Joe Namath cannot offer and led the Los Angeles Rams to a 353 rout of the Minnesota Vikings tonight. Haden's performance probably consigned Namath to the bench for the forseeable future, regardless of Joe's physical condition.

description: Tightening the Noose on Tax Shelters

title: St. Paul Orchestra Introduces Likable Brehm Piano Work
description: Alvin Brehm's Concerto for Piano and Orchestra is the most likeable new piece to turn up in quite a while. There will be those who will find that reason enough to condemn the score, since they have been bullied into believing that whatever gives immediate pleasure in the arts is by definition shallow and transitory stuff. But never mind. Pleasure is where one finds it in music, and probably always was.

description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Morgenthau Sets Up Unit To Prosecute Youths

title: Fashion's Stars Take the Wraps Off Spring
description: PARIS, Oct. 24Ask a dozen people who the best designer here is and half will suggest Karl Lagerfeld. Some are sure to say Kenzo. Both have just shown their collections, and both were impressive. Marc Bohan of Dior has unburdened himself of spring, too. Conventiont21 wisdom has it tha Mr. Bohan is always reliable. Conventional wisdom is right.

title: STUDY ON TV VIOLENCE CALLED MEANINGLESS
description: Six members of the House Communications Subcommittee have jointly issued a stinging dissent to the panel's Violence on Television report, calling the document that was issued last week a calculated distortion of the hearing record and one that is biased in favor of the networks.

title: HEARINGS SET ON PLAN ON HEALTH SERVICES
description: ROCHELLE PARK, Oct. 24  Public hearings will begin tomorrow on a massive plan to reorganize medical services in Bergen and Passaic Counties, including provisions for physicians for every 2,500 residents, a reduction in the number of hospital beds, an increase in nursing home beds and an expansion of rehabilitation facilities.

description: Morning

title: British Horse Wins Laurels in Jumping.
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 24After being left far behind in the first two classes, Britain rebounded tonight and won the Accumulator internationalopen jumper class at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: Homosexuals in New York Find New Pride
description: It was Yom Kippur at Congregation Beth Simchat Torah, Manhattan's fouryearold selfproclaimed gay synagogue, and the temple facilities in Westbeth apartments in Greenwich Village were over flowing with more than 350 worshipers.
