description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1977

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error in some editions of The Times yesterday, the rmount the New York City Board of Education says it spends on classroom instruction was incorrectly reportcd. The figure should have been 65 27Its of ch education

title: 2 C.B.O.E. Seats Bring $70,000
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange announced yesterday that two seats on the Exchange had been sold for $35,000 each, unchanged from the last sale on Oct. 21. Seats are now quoted at $35,000 bid and at 37,500 offered.

title: Port Groups Agree To Bargain Locally On Annual Income
description: North Atlantic port associations said yesterday that they had agreed to bargain with the striking longshoremen on a local basis, port by port, on the Issue of guaranteed annual income.

title: Spool Plant Cancels Move To Jersey to Stay in Bronx
description: A spool and tube manufacturer who had been on the point of moving to New Jersey announced yesterday that his company and its 125 jobssoon to grow to 200 jobswould remain in the Bronx.

title: Sound
description: THERE'S A BIT OF TRUTH in that snide old story about the audiophile who found his first live concert disappointing: ere were no tone controls for him to play with. Today, audio enthusiasts might be dissatisfied even if the Metropolitan Opera House or Avery Fisher Hall came equipped with treble and bass knobs. Now they'd insist on more elaborate controls, called equalizers.

title: AUSTALIAN LEADER CALLS ELECTION FOR DECEMBER
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 27 (AP)Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser announced today that national elections would be held Dec. 10, more than a year before they were due, and called on Australians to reelect his conservative Government.

title: Islanders Are Tied By Kings
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)Mike Murphy drilled in a fivefooter with 3 minutes 28 seconds to play tonight to give the Los Angeles Kings a 2.2 National Hockey League tie with the New York Islanders and snap a threegame losing streak.

title: BROAD STOCK RALLY SENDS DOW UP 11.87, BEST GAIN IN 6 MONTHS
description: The battered stock market finally put together a strong broadbased rally yesterday afternoon as the Dow Jones industrial average moved ahead aImos. 12 points for its best advance in six months.

title: PayinAdvance Rule On Charters Waived
description: Budgetconscious travelers who had to pay in advance for lowcost charter flights abroad can now buy tickets right up to the hour of takeoff, a tour spokesman said yesterday.

title: Paper Prints in Strike
description: The Asbury Park Press was pub. fished on schedule despite a strike by union representing delivery truck drivers, the newspaper said.

title: Sports Today
description: BOXING Vito Antuofermo vs. Mike Nixon, middleweight, 10 rounds, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.. Three other 10round bouts are on the card. First preliminary, 8 P.M.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Supreme Court upheld today a lower court order refusing to allow the financially troubled Philadelphia School District to receive a $50 million loan from several city banks.

title: Sherman's Fine Pianism
description: RUSSELL SHERMAN'S career began in 1945 when, at the age of 15, he made his debut in Town Hall. A decade later, the pianist was a frequently heard exponent of contemporary music, although he made occasional forays into the traditional repertory. He went into teaching for the 20 years after that, becoming head of the piano department of the New England Conservatory of Music in Boston. Then in 1975 he reemerged on New York's concert scene with a program devoted to Liszt's 12 Transcendental Etudes. His performance was as much admired for its analytical strength as for its technical command.

title: School Food Waste Is Studied
description: WASHINGTON (UPI)

title: Stage: Fiery Brontosaurus
description: IN LANFORD WILSON'S new oneaci play. Brontosaurus, Tanya Berezin plays a middleaging New York antiques dealer who is irascibl 2, toughminded and sophisticated a single woman with irony in her blood. Conditioned by disillusion, confronted by the callowness of youth, she feels that she is uselessas extinct as that title dinosaur. But she is, somehow, a survivor, like those antiques that fill her shop and her apartment. She has been chipped and abused, but she has never lost her polish or her idealism. I have a virgin streak in me, she then adds. Somewhere.

title: They Came So Far
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26They have never recognized the right of Israel to exist, said President Carter of the Soviets, explaining to an interviewer why he was proud of the joint U.S.S.R.U.S. statement on the Mideast.

title: Bronx District Leader Is Acquitted In Case Tied to Judgeship Inquiry
description: John J. Whalen, a Bronx district leader, has been acquitted after a twoday nonjury trial in State Supreme Court of charges that he destroyed records of the chauffeur agency that he heads. The records had been sought in a grand jury inquiry concerning charges of the sale of judgeships by Patrick J. Cunningham, the former Democratic state chairman and Bronx County leader.

title: Wells, Rich, Greene Gets Savin Account
description: The Savin Business Machines Corporation has appointed Wells, Rich, Greene to handle its $5 million national account. The selec. tion process was rather low key, with no big bidding war, according to the company. SklarLenett, of White Plains, the agency for Savin since 1975, helped in the search. The agency will still retain a lot of sales promotion and collateral projects.

title: People in Sports
description: Paul Blair, an eighttime golden glove winner who was used largely as defensive replacement for Reggie Jackson in right field by the New York Yankees, signed a threeyear contract wth the team yesterday. No other terms of the contract were announced. The 33yearold Blair was acquired from the Baltimore Orioles last January in exchange for Elliott Maddox. In 82 games for the Yankees Blair batted 262 and hit ftur home runs.

title: Article 6  No Title
Hudson Democrats Confident. In Senate and Assembly Bids
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 26Hudson County Democratic candidates for the State Legislature are not wondering whether they will win or lose but whether they will bring a fellow Democrat, Governor Byrne, to victory with them.

title: 4 Shot and a Bank Robber Is Slain After Chase Near Gramercy Park
description: A bank robber who took two hostages while trying to make a getaway was fatally shot yesterday and a policeman and three civilians were wounded in a fusillade of bullets on a busy street near Gramercy Park.

title: U.S.Insured Banks Ordered to Give Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)As a result of the Bert Lance case, the nation's 14,700 Federally insured banks have been ordered to supply information to Congress on several banking practices such as overdrafts, it was formally announced today.

title: CLARKE W. COSTIKYAN
description: Clarke Warren Costikyan, president of KentCostikyan Inc., an oriental rug company at 305 East 63d Street, collapsed and died Tuesday as he was leaving his office. He was 75 years old and lived at 167 Highland Avenue. Montclair. N.J.

title: Jazz: Joe Henderson Pays a Rare Visit
description: JOE HENDERSON, the jazz saxophonist who is at the Village Vanguard through Saturday, is a particularly striking example of the respected jazz musician who chooses to live elsewhere from New York, the jazz capital. In fact, he hasn't performed here for four years. But Mr. Henderson says he has no regrets about basing himself in the quieter San Francisco.

title: The Nnw York Times/Robert Walker
Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1977

title: Giap, War Commander, May Head ScienceResearch Drive for Hanoi
description: NEW HAVENA Yale University biologist who periodically travels to Vietnam reports that the Hanoi Government has embarked on fullscale development of its scientific research facilities, and is likely to name its supreme military commander, Gem Vo Nguyen Giap, to head the scientific program.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26 (AP)Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai of India, ending sixday visit here, said today that the Soviet Union had made a commitment by implication to continue economic aid to his country.

title: Scar !is Prime Clue in Ringer
description: A threeinch scar on the shoulder of the mystery horse in Belmont Park's ringer case emerged yesterday as major clue to the puzzle.

title: Banning: Unique South African Punishment
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 26 The beginning yesterday of the trial of Winnie Mandela, the wife of a jailed black nationalist leader and a heroine of the nationalist movement in her own right, has focused attention on a unique form of punishment herethe banning of people.

title: Passaic Holds Woman and Friend In the Death of Her Daughter, 2
description: PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP)A 21yearold woman and her make friend wre being held without bail here today in connection with the death of her 2yearold daughter.

title: Environmental Agency Suspends Key Provision of Clean Air Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Environmental Protection Agency, under pressure froM big utilities and their supporters in Congress reversed itself today and decided to suspend enforcement of the key provision of a new law protecting unpolluted air.

title: Pilot S pokesmin Berates U . N . on Hijacking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26The president of the International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations, in an unusual appearance at the United Naions, chastized its members today for what he called their pathetic record in ratifying international conventions on hijacking, which nearly a third of the countries represented here have not signed.

title: Cabin Cruiser Sinks Off Jersey
description: MARGATE, N.J., Oct.26 (AP) 60foot cabin cruiser burned and sank last night about three miles off the coast of this Atlantic County community, Coast Guard officials said. Authorities said the only man aboard, Alexander Hunter of Rumson, boarded a lifeboat and was rescued by a civilian vessel. When the Coast Guard arrived on the scene, south of Atlantic City, the burning boat was sinking, officials said. The cabin cruiser was owned by Mihn Entertainment Inc. of Sea Bright.

title: Lawyer Charged With Arranging Illegal Adoption of Four Infants
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Oct. 26A Manhattan attorney has been indicted by a Suffolk County grand jury on charges of illegally arranging the graymarket adoption of four illegitimate babies for fees of at least $5,000, the Suffolk County District Attorney announced today.

title: Britain Modifies Economic Goals, Eases Some Controls on Currency
description: LONDON, Oct. 26The British Government, in a sort of midcourse correction to its economic policy, laid out today wideranging plan it hopes will stimulate business activity and reduce unemployment.

title: Bridge:
description: MANILA, Oct. 26There was little excitement in the final qualifying round of Bermuda Bowl play for the world team championship.

title: SCHLESINGER ASKS AN END TO GASOLINE PRICE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 26 (AP)Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger proposed today an end to Federal price controls on motor gasoline. The more would leave controls on only a small number of petroleum products.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and American stock exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports of changes in stock of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed.

title: CORN FUTURES RISE BY 3 CENTS A BUSHEL
description: Despite the fact that the nation's stockpile of corn on Oct. 1 was the highest in five years and slightly more than Government experts earlier envisioned, futures prices of corn made gains of about 3 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: BAR TO A NOV. 8 VOTE ON NEW YORK BONDS IS UPHELD BY COURT
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday affirmed a lower court ruling that Governor Carey's proposal to issue $750 million in bonds to stimulate the state's economy was unconstitutionally broad and should not be on the ballot next month.

title: Ambach Becomes Education Chief ; Three ExGovernors Get Degrees
description: ALBANY, Oct. 26New York State installed a new Commissioner of Education today in a ceremony rich with the academic pomp and heraldry of the Middle Ages, but tempered by modernday concern about education costs and other problems.

description: People think they're kinetic sculpture. said Dean Kamen. But I don't really consider them art. I just like making machines.

title: Berra Interested In Piloting Braves
description: Yogi Berra indicated yesterday he would be interested in managing the Atlanta Braves, although he said he hadn't been approached about it.

description: PRICEJudge Saul. A monument te the memory of Judge Saul Price will be unveiled on Sunday, October 30th at 1PM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery. 7800 Myrtle Ave, Bklyn. Block C. Line 15.

title: Watkins Could Help
description: EAST RUTHERFORD. N.J., Oct. 26Bob Tucker's old locker was filled today at Giants Stadium. The one next to it remained empty The Giants won't admit it, but they have a fullback Problem.

title: HOUSE UNIT BLOCKING WEAPONS FOR KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The House of Representatives will not even consider President Carter's request to transfer $800 million worth of weapons to South Korea because of Seoul's refusal to cooperate with House investigations of alleged Korean influencebuying, the chairman of the International Relations Committee said tonight.

description: TORONTO, Oct. 26 (UPI)Ian Turnbull scored on a 40foot slapshot with 1:24 remaining tonight to enable the Toronto Maple Leafs to tie the Montreal Canadiens, 22.

title: Inquiry Finds Evidence of Wide Scheme to Steal U.S. Education Funds
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23A growing investigation by Federal and Massachusetts authorities into the misuse of education funds has uncovered evidence of a national scheme to bilk Government grant programs.

title: Alrnbassador May Be Ousted
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 26Foreign Minister Park Tong Jin hinted today that the South Korean Government might soon oust Kim Dong Jo, Seoul's Ambassador in Washington from 1967 to 1973 and now national security adviser to President Park Chung Hee.

title: Evaluate Your Warranty
description: NEXT TO HIGH prices, one of the things that frustrates consumers most is their conviction that warranties on such big ticket items as automobiles and home appliances aren't worth the paper they are written on.

title: CUOMO FLESHES OUT SECOND BALLOT LINE
description: Mario M. Cuomo sought yesterday to put some flesh on the bones of the Neighborhood Preservation Party, a second spot on the Nov. 8 ballot that the Liberal Party candidate hopes will attract enough dissident Democrats and independent voters to enable him to edge out Representative Edward I. Koch for the mayoralty.

title: Carter's Media Specialist Is Giving Up Politics for Films
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26When Jimmy Carter was elected President last year, a new world seemed to open for Gerald Rafshoon, the Atlanta media specialist whose television commercials helped lift Mr. Carter from relative obscurity to national prominence.

title: Red Wings 4, Penguins 3
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (UPI)Reed Larson's first goal in the N.H.L. proved to be the decisive score as the Detroit Red Wings beat the Pittsburgh Peguins, 43, tonight.

title: Missouri Plant Ordered Closed
description: LEMAY, Mo., Oct. 26 (AP)St. Louis County officials have ordered the closing of the NL Industries Titanium Division plant here, saying it has contributed to air pollution three times higher than the emergency level.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions FIRST$6,300, cl., 3Y0 and co, Ed. SE:VENTII314,C09, allow., 3Y0 and

title: Calendar
description: Boutiques de Noel, York Club, 4 East 62d Street

title: A JESUIT CANDIDATE DISMISSED BY ORDER
description: A candidate for the Jesuit priesthood has been dismissed by the order a year after he was told that he would be denied ordination because he was an admitted homosexual.

title: Cahill Endorses Bateman as the Best Governor
description: WAYNE TOWNSHIP, Oct. 26Former Gov. William T. Cahill said today that State Senator Raymond H. Bateman will be the best Governor New Jersey will ever have had.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1977

title: Jersey Considers Horse Clinic
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26 (AP)A survey will be conducted to determine if there is need for a veterinary diagnostic center for horses, state agriculture officials say. Dr. George Poppensiek, former dean of the Cornell University School of Veterinary Medicine, has been hired to conduct the survey.

title: Toronto Company to Test Formula Termed Useful in Cancer Control
description: TORONTO, Oct. 26 (AP)The Respirion Corporation said yesterday that it would test a formula that an 89yearold woman from Bracebridge, Ontario, says is useful in the control or cure of cancer.

title: Space Shuttle Makes a Bumpy. Landing, but Officials Are Pleased
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 26The spaceplane Enterprise made a bumpy touchdown here today, but was apparently good enough for project officials to declare the landing test phase of the multibillion dollar space shuttle program a success.

title: A $9,000 Antique (Circa 1969)
description: DEARBORN, MICH. (AP) The Henry Ford Museum used to brag that its Great Brewster Chair was n bona fide Pilgrimera relic. But now the chair is locked away, gathering dustfor it seems the chair is not a rare 350yearold relic after all, but the 1969 work of a Rhode Island woodcarver.

title: Kennedy Seeks To Heal Old Rift
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26Dr, Donald Kennedy, the head of the Food and Drug Administration, issued letters of admonition today to two high officials of the agency and made a formal apology to 12 of its employees and consultants as a result of a series of investigations of internal operations.

title: G.M. Quarter Net Up 1.3%; Chrysler's Falls by 55.8%
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26The General Motors Corporation reported today that earnings in the third quarter increased 1.3 percent from the yearearlier quarter. The Chrysler Corporation, meanwhile, said that its earnings had declined a sharp 55.8 percent.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOLDMae C. October 27, 1966. In memory of my tender loving wife who is always In my thoughts and heart. Dave.

title: It's S.I. Politics, But With Touch Of the Unusual
description: Even Staten Island, with its leafy, suburblike streets and its neighborly middleclass voters, has a few piquant items to stir into New York City's peculiar political mix this year.

title: Topics
description: If supermarkets can issue trading stamps and banks can give away toasters to drum up business, why shouldn't schools do some creative merchandising, too? That seems to be the logic behind an experiment in education in Dade County, Florida: gifts like Frisbees and hamburgers for truant students who return and gifts like record albums and dinners for teachers with high attendance records. The motives are not entirely. pedagogical. Even under the palmettos, truancy rates are high; and state education aid$824 per student is allocated on the basis of attendance. Hence, truants cost the Dade system some $3 million last

title: Man Kills Wife in Midtown Store And Seconds Later Kills Himself
description: A 40yearold Bronx man shot and killed his wife in a crowded midtown variety store yesterday and seconds later killed himself, the police reported.

title: MRS. LAMBERT FAILS TO WIN BAR BACKING
description: Marie M. Lambert, the Democratic candidate for Manhattan Surrogate, has been accused of unethical conduct and has been rated not approved by the executive committee of the City Bar Association.

title: Amrak Service Cuts in Northeast Corridor Are Delayed Until Nov. 6
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 26  A major reduction in Amtrak passenger service, involving the elimination of 22 of the 120 daily trains in the WashingtonNew YorkBoston corridor, was postponed today until Nov. 6 as Amtrak continued to hope for more money from Congress.

title: Sunshine From Paris: Billows and Blousing
description: PARIS, Oct. 26The readytowear collections shown this week are billed for the spring and summer season. Actually, they pass lightly over the first part and concentrate on things to wear in the sun.

title: Events/Sports
description: 2:30 P.M., WCBSAM, WINS, WNYCAM: President Carter's News Conference. (live).

title: United Press International QUEUING UP FOR BENEFITS: Some of the 17,000 members of the AeroMechanics Union on strike against the Boeing Company lining up at ticket windows of Kingdome yesterday in Seattle for first strike benefit payment. Some waited more than two hours on line that stretched over four blocks.
New Jerseyans Lose
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct. 26Though the Nets still have not won a game with New Jersey in front of their name, they came as close as it is possible to come tonight before falling to the Atlanta Hawks, 113110, in overtime.

title: Let Them Eat Poison
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 26  Ibsen's An Enemy of the People is set in a town known for its mineral baths. Dr. Stockmann discovers that the baths are polluted. When he advises town leaders, he finds that the truth is not welcome.

title: A Subtle Counterchic
description: EVERY YEAR for the past three years, a small hook of interiors has come quietly from a publisher with the evocative name of Quick Fox, and while they could not exactly be called subversive e books, there is something about them that suggests an assured kind of counterchic. Offbeat is not the right word, either, because these books are much better than that, What they seem to do, through a knowing kind of smple urbanity and calculated understatement, is to kick the whole model room, thisyear'shomefashion synuroine genty in the pants, and make the suave, professamal trendsetters look like hopeless overreachers. find myself studying these books, both for what is aihi isn't there, hecausc they are full of subtle design excellences and a gentle, sensuous pleasure in places and things.

title: Senate Panel Approves a Reduced Marijuana Penaltyl
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to reduce the Federal penalty for possession of small amounts of marijuana.

title: High Point: We Have Seen the Future
description: HIGH POINT N. C.  Once agan the rition's furniture manufacturers have :ooked to the past, producing a diverse harvest of historically based or nostalgic designs at the Southern Furniture Market, which ends here Friday. The backward looks range from period Oriental to 18thcentury American to Edwardian to Art Deco, from reproductions to inthestyleof adaptations.

title: To Make South Africa Listen
description: What should the world do now about South Africa? What can it do? The questions arise from last week's shutdown of leading black newspapers and virtually all organizations working to break down racial barriers. Clearly, Prime Minister Vorster and his Afrikaner colleagues have no intention of ever recognizing even moderate black political leadership.

title: Electric Boat Manager Irks Connecticut Congressmen Over Sub Layoffs
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 26The general manager of Electric Boat Company was summoned here today by members of the Connecticut Congressional delegation to explain his sudden decision yesterday to lay off more than 3,000 workers. His visit succeeded primarily in infuriating the legislators and raising the possibility that there might be further layoffs.

title: Memorial Secvices
description: GILLETTEGeorge Trofast. In Salisbury Conn. On October 23, 1977. Memorial services Saturday, October 79, St James Episcopal Church, Great Barrington, Mass.

title: MAN IS HELD IN MURDER OF 21YEAROLD MOTHER
description: Harold McCrae, acquitted last August in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of charges that he raped and stabbed a 13yearold girl, was arrested yesterday on charges of having stabbed to death woman whose body was found Tuesday in the building where he lives.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH new wallpaper can sometimes be hung directly over old wallpaper when redecorating, in many cases the old wallpaper will have to be removed. first in order to do a satisfactory job. For example, you should never hang vinyl wallcovering over old wallpaper pr over another vinyl. You should never hang new paper over an old one that bias a textured surface, which might ghow through, or over an old one that is not sticking tightly, as evidenced by signs of cracking or peeling.

title: U.S. and Allies Confer
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Thursday, Oct. 27The United States and its Western allies worked toward agreement last night on a unified position for Security Council action against South Africa.

title: Clyde and the Rebuilding Knicks
description: One by one the other members of the Cleveland Cavaliers were being introduced as they loped to the nearby foul line, but Walt Frazier sat in his gold satin sweatsuit, an empty chair on each side, knowing he would be the last to introduced. And the sellout 19,694 spectators knew it, too.

title: Music: A Berlioz As Is Rarely Done
description: CARNEGIE HALL last night was part concert hall, part theater. Keiji Osawa, leading the Boston Symphony, gave the Berlioz opera, Betrice et Benedict in its entirety.

title: House Panel Seeks Legal Advice On Rights Plan Ratification Date
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)Caught in a tangle with no legal precedents, a House Judiciary subcommittee has asked the Justice Department and legal experts whether Congress can give states seven more years to ratify the equal rights amendment.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN FOR CIVIL SERVANTS KILLED BY THE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The House of Representatives killed a provision in the pending Social Security financing bill tonight that would have made Social Security coverage mandatory in 1982 for all Federal civilian employees and for those state and local government employees who do not participate voluntarily.

title: Lighting the Way
description: If designers of furniture tend to look backward for inspiration, their colleagues in lighting are moving full speed ahead with 20thcentury design ideas. At least those supplying George Kovacs Lighting this season are. A rollabout spotlight on casters, with a shade n white, brown, red nr yellow, should make lighting in the living room as functional as it is in a photographer's studio. The light, Butler, by Louis Poulsen of Denmark, will be $150.

title: FEELING ABOUT BYRNE CALLED ELECTION KEY
description: A majority of those who intend to vote in the New Jersey gubernatorial election on Nov. 8 will apparently base their choice principally on their feelings about Governor Byrne and not on their perceptions of his challenger, State Senator Raymond H. Bateman.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a typographical error sorne editions of The Times yesterday, the amount the New York City Board of Education ways it spends on classroom instruction was incorrectly reported. The figure should have been 65 cents of each education dollar.

title: MARIELOUISE YORCK
description: MarieLouise Yorck, the former Countess Yorck Von Wartenburg, of Germany, died Tuesday at her home, 118 Huntington Road, Port Washington, L.I. She was 64 years old.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Federal Election Commission sued the election committee of an unsuccessful Congressional candidate from Bergen County for failing to file complete financial reports.

title: Blumenthal Puts Lid On Dollar Comments
description: KUWAIT, Oct. 26 (AP)Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal says he has learned not to clear my throat lest it affect the dollar.

title: U.S. Opens Restored Roosevelt Birthplace on His 119th Birthday
description: AFTER A RESTORATION project that called for detective work, serendipity, extraordinary craftsmanship and meticulous attention to detail, the allbuthidden Manhattan brownstone on the site where the 26th President was born 119 years ago today is back in business.

title: An Unconventional Musicthon
description: THE 92d STREET Y.MY.W.H.A. has expanded the range and luantity of its musical offerings enormously in recent seasons, and in so doing has tried out some unccnventional programming ideas.

title: LEROY A. EMMERICH, 58, COMMUNICATIONS LEADER
description: Leroy A. Emmerich, a senior partner in and founder of Management Communications Inc., which helps corporations improve communications with employees and clients, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla., after a short illness. He was 58 years old and lived in Warwick, N.Y.

title: $320,000 Due Knicks
description: The New Jersey Nets have twice missed the deadline for a $320,000 indemnification payment due the Knicks as part of the $4 million owed them for permitting the Nets entry to the National Basketball Association for the 197677 season.

title: A Reluctant Vote for Governor Byrne
description: The voters of New Jersey must choose this year between a lackluster governor. Brendan Byrne, who prosides over an honest but uninspired administration, and a challenger, Ray Bateman, who seems 2. Oable of vigorous leadership but has chosen to tie his hands with diehard opposition to an income tax. It is disheartening, to find the state mired in yet another debate about such a tax. Mr. Bateman forced the issue for reasons of politics rather than principle, but the entire state would have to live with the consequences over foul long years. It cannot.

title: NEW &
description: Waterscapes

title: CARLO DELCROIX
description: ROME, Oct. 26 (AP)Calro Delcroix, who became a champion of handicapped war veterans after losing his sight and hands in World War I, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: Detroit Mayor, Seeking His Second 4Year Term, Remains a Popular Leader Among Black Majority
description: DETROIT,Oct. 26If crime has been reduced in Detroit, a questioner asked Mayor Coleman A. Young in a campaign debate this week, does that mean the streets are safe?

title: Jets Make a Shift
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 26No one, not even a linebacker hobbling around on a severely bruised ankle, is immune from pro footballs putdown humor.

title: Stage: The Lost Stir Rum an Coca Cola
description: ART IS THE STUBBORN tendril that cracks the pavement. Calypso, that barbed and bobbing Trinidadian art, was crooked, lively assertion that darted through the poverty, apathy and social layering of a small, colonial island.

title: White House Denies President Is Unhappy With Party Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)President Carter has no intention of asking Kenneth M. Curtis, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to resign, White House spokesman said today.

title: U.S. Seeks to Deport 2 Lithuanians; Calls 1970 Hijacking Nonpolitical
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 26 (AP)The State Department said today that deportation proceedings were under way for two Lithuanians who entered the United States illegally last year and who are wanted by Soviet authorities in a 1970 hijacking.

title: HOUSE UNIT BLOCKING WEAPONS FOR KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The House of Representatives will not even consider President Carter's request to transfer $800 million worth of weapons to South Korea because of Seoul's refusal to cooperate with House investigations of alleged Korean influencebuying, the chairman of the International Relations Committee said tonight.

title: Beaths
description: ALBINDERAbraham. On October 25. 1977. Beloved husband of Ethel, devoted father of Max Meyer, David and Ann, Services will be held at the Midwood Chapel, 1675 Coney Island Ave near Ave M, Bklyn, at 1:15PM, Thursday, October 27, 1977

title: Robert Powell Dies; A Leading Dancer For Miss Graham
description: Robert Powell, formerly a leading dancer with the Martha Graham Dance Company and until recently its associate artistic director, died Monday in New York. He was 38 years old.

title: Lawyers to Get 30% Of Stores
description: About 61,000 people who filed claims in a classaction suit against three widely known Fifth Avenue stores for credits on alleged overcharges have learned from the United States District Court that about 30 percent of a settlement offer is going to their lawyers.

title: About New york
description: Macy's is mostly devoid of music, except for those bingkbingkbingk signals of the department store code sounding through the shoppers babble. So Louis Yelnick, who runs men's sports footwear in the midtown store, has an excellent point when he tells how his daytime salesman's job contributes contrast to his nighttime profession of turning the pages for pianists in concert halls around the city as they nod and throb with both hands on the keyboard.

title: The Boathouse: Perfect Home for a Nautical Family
description: SIENNA, an 8monthold Chesapeake Bay retriever, chases boats. Most dogs run after cars, said the retriever's owners, Edmond and Sandford Downing of Rye, N.Y., but Sienna just dives in and swims for the boats.

title: Sheila Younge, an Essence Editor
description: Sheila Younge, a former editor of Essence magazine, died at her family's home in Berkeley, Calif., last Thursday. She was 32 years old and had lived in New York City before returning to her parent's home last fall.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Ed Koch Unmovable
description: EDWARD I. KOCH, who according to the polls will probably he the next Mayor of New York City, unlocked the gleaming new Segal lock on his front door and led the way into what has become caminiign I sue of sorb;his $250.11month rentcontrolled apartment just off Washington Square. designed for him. I don't care what anybody says: won't give it up.

title: Hanoi Reeducation
description: The writer of the following dispatch covered the Vietnam War for The Daily Mail of London front 1968 to 1973. He returned to Vietnam lust month with West German tourist group.

title: Singing Wind Is Victorious At Washington
description: LANDOVER, Md., Oct. 27  The bubble burst for the United States riders at the Washington International horse show tonight at the Capital Centre.

title: Italian Bridge Unit Faces Cutoff
description: MANILA, Oct. 26The Italian Bridge Federation was threatened today with suspension from the world bridge organization on the ground that it had failed to investigate thoroughly the socalled smoke signal scandal, in which bridge players were accused of cheating by signaling their partners with cigarettes.

title: Maldive Islands Leader Reveals Moscow Sought Lease on Base
description: MALE, Maldive Islands, Oct. 26 (Reuters)President Ibrahim Nasir disclosed today that a $1 million offer to lease theformer Royal Air Force base on Gan. Island, turned down by his Governmentearly this month, had come from the Sovi:t et Union.

title: ENLARGED REFINERY DEDICATED BY EXXON
description: BAYTOWN, Tex., Oct. 26Exxon's enlarged Baytown refinery was formally dedicated here today as the nation's largest such facility, and Gov. Dolph Briscoe used the ceremonies to criticize President Carter's energy policies.

title: Judge, Munching Pizza, Digests Testimony on Pillsbury's Market
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 26 (UPI)Judge Joseph F. Dufresne munched 10 pieces of pizza and sat at a kitchen counter taking testimony in an effort to decide whether the Pillsbury Company has too big a slice of the market.

title: The U.N. Today
Home Beat
description: THE FABRIC world may not be the same after Les Levine, the Canadian conceptual artist who lives in New York, completes his oneyear stintstarting this week as one of the three artistsinresidence at the Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science.

title: Witnesses Give In; Man Held in Killing
description: After finally winning the cooperation of a reluctant neighborhood, Brooklyn homicide detectives arrested Joseph D'Amico yesterday evening and charged him with the murder of his neighbor, Angelo Treglia, on a crowded Bensonhurst street over the weekend.

title: TV: Best of Families
description: BEGINNING TONIGHT at 9 on Channel 13 as a twohour special, Public Television's The Best of Families emerges as a promising concept trapped beneath a mound of anxious research and unnecessary rationalizations. The expensive eightepisode series is the first adult dramatic project undertaken by the Children's Television Workshop (crw), whose educational productions incluth! Sesame Street and The Electric Company. One of the major underwriters is the National Endowment for the Humanities. And there, within that wellintentioned educational partnership, lies the irritating rub.

title: Vance Briefs U.S. Jews on Mideast; They Charge an AntiIsrael Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26A Carter Administration effort to explain its Middle East policies today turned into a forum for American Jewish leaders to express anger over what they perceive as an antiIsrael drift in those policies.

title: Market Place
description: There appears to be some hope yet for owners of 3.5 million shares of common and preferred stock of Schenley Industries who have tried since May 1971 to get more for their shares than they were offered when the company was taken private by the Glen Alden Corporation.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Competition in the computer textediting business intensified yesterday with the introduction by the Xerox Corporation of its 850 line of word processing equipment at a briefing and demonstration for newsmen at the Essex House.

title: Wharton Named Chancellor of State U. of New York
description: Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr., the president of Michigan State University, was named yesterday to he the next chancellor of the 345,000student State University of New York, the largest in the country.

title: Backgammon:
description: The experienced plax,er will always take advantage of a fuperior position to extract the maximam number of points from the game.

title: Buenos Aires Official Murdered
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 (UPI)A retired Air Force major, Rudolfo Matti, who was serving as a city official, was assassinated outside his home here today in a new outbreak of violence in Argentina. Three gunmen escaped in a car, police sources said. Major Matti was director of communications systems for the city.

title: Art People
description: WHO SHOULD pop into town the othar day but Pierre Alechinsky, en route from Paris to Pittsburgh to collect the fat ($50,000) Andrew W. Mellon prize for excellence of output from the Carnegie Institute's Museum of Art.

title: Concert: Musica Aeterna Tests Ingenuity
description: THE FIRST HALF of Musics Aeterna's concert in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night was typical of the orchestra and its music director, Frederic Waldman. It included two works for which the conductor has an understandable affection, Mendelssohn's Overture to Son and Stranger and Strauss's Suite from Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme.

title: MONDALE ENLIVENS MAYORAL CAMPAIGN
description: Vice President Mondale, enlivening what many New Yorkers perceive as a lackluster mayoral campaign, made his second visit in two weeks to support the candidacy of Representative Edward I. Koch and othe:. Democratic nominees for local and county offices.

title: Art: The Fantasies Of Joseph Cornell
description: AHIGH POINT in the Bicentennial celebrations was the arrival of the ships that made up Operation Sail. Descending on the Port of New York like so many birds presumed extinct, the craft could barely be seen for the wash raised by converging launches, themselves the last word in modern gadgetry. Mass nostalgia can effect juxtapositions that the hardestcore Surrealist might envy.

title: Senate Votes Tax on Industry Use Of Oil and Gas, a Key Carter Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27In a surprise move, the Senate today gave back to President Carter a key part of his energy programa tax on the use of oil and natural gas by industry.

title: Film: A Variety Of Animated Shorts
description: NIMATORS have more freedom than most other kinds of filmmakers, and Rapid Eye Movement, a program of 14 animated shorts, celebrates that freedom. The films vary dramatically, in length (the longest runs 13 minutes, tne Driesest a minute and a half), and in technique, to provide a lively crosssection of the effects that animation can produce. Some of the films are firstrate and others most emphatically are not, but quality is almost beside the point; the exciting thing about this program is its variety.

title: A Secretary Who Spurned the Coffee Detail
description: WATERLOO, Iowa, Oct. 27Diana Becker, a secretary in the Waterloo Community School District's administrative offices for 10 years, has lost her, job. She finally refused to make the coffee.

title: DR. JACOB ROBINSON, HISTORIAN,DIES AT 88
description: Dr. Jacob Robinson, a historian of the destruction of Eastern European Jewry during the Nazi regime, died Monday at the New York Infirmary at the age of 88. He lived at 125 Riverside Drive,

title: More Prepaid Medical Units Urged
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, called yesterday for a broad expansion of prepaid medical services and certified the KaiserPermanente Health Plan as a health maintenance organization for more than 3.25 million Americans.

title: At the Movies
description: THE SOUND, puzzling but bewitching, was not the sound of music. Yekkedy, lekkedy, dekkedy, yeeeekkkk, belted out Shelley Winters in a bravura demonstration of her bassosoprano, a thrill moviegoers must wait until Thursday to savor. That's the day Pete's Dragon a Disney musical in wincn tne intrepiu LI U Up. liaamonizes with the likes of Helen Reddy, Mickey Rooney, Red Buttons, a freckled, scenegobbling youngster named Sean Marshall, and an animated beast known simply as Elliottopens at the Music Hall.

title: U.S. Trade Balance Posts Best Advance Since May
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)United States businesses sold a record 510.9 billion in goods abroad last month as the balance of trade showed its biggest improvement since May, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Big Bands Spotlight Jazz on Bond Street
description: Jazz will return to the Ladies Fort at 2 Bond Street, near. Broadway and Bleecker Street, with the Battle of the Big Bands. Today, Frank Foster and the Loud Minority will appear at 8 P.M. and midnight. Tomorrow, it 7wi11 be the Monty Waters Big Band at 4 P.M., and the Sam Brown/Art Jenkins Big Band Experience at S P.M. and midnight. A jam session Sunday at 4 P.M. will feature Bond Street, with Tisha Campbell and Joe Lee Wilson.

title: Francisco Pignatari, 61, Onetime Brazilian Playboy Prospered as Industrialist
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 27 (AP)Francisco Pignatari, a wealth azilian Industrialist and onetime inter ational playboy, died today in a Sao Paulo hospiI tal. He was 61 years old.

title: Art: From Copley to Derain
description: MIXED SHOWS are fun to go to, but the devil to write about. Both A Gallery Collects at Hirsch( & Adler, 21 East 70th Street, and 40 Years, 40 Masterworks at the Perls Gallery confirm this. What is one to say about a show that begins with John Singleton Copley and ends with a landscape painted by Andre Derain in 1930? Or about one that begins, as the Perls show does, with a Vlaminck figure painting of 1905 and ends with a Calder mobile of 1975?

title: TAX REVISION PVT OFF UNTIL CONGRESS ACTS ON OTHER PROPOSALS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27  President Carter said today that he would further delay his tax revision package, making it unlikely that his sweeping proposals would come at all this year.

title: BACK FROM MOSCOW, DESAI SEES ACCORD
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 27  Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai, returning today from a sixday visit to the Soviet Union, said that India and the Soviet leaders were in complete understanding on his Government's desire for a nonaligned foreign policy in which India would have no special relationship with any country.

title: A Study of Genocide Should Be Required
description: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it. Ueorge santayana's admonition springs to mind upon reading the protestations of use Hoffmann [letter Oct. 18]...

title: Music: Andre Watts Excels in Brahms Piano Concerto
description: O NLY TWO works were on the New York Philharmonic's program last night in Avery Fisher Hall, but each was a blockbuster in its way. Andre Watts nlaved the Second Piano Concerto by Brahms, and that is of course one of the most demanding pieces in the repertory. Then Erich Leinsdorf turned his attention to the Also sprach Zarathustra by Richard Strauss.

title: Union. Breaks Off Negotiations On Coal Miners
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 27The United Mine Workers Union broke off talks with the coal industry today, charging that the companies were refusing so far to bargain on what the union regarded as the key issue in the negotiations.

title: FORD NET UP SHARPLY FROM A LAG CAUSED BY STRIKE LAST YEAR
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27The Ford Motor Company reported today that profits rebounded sharply in the third quarter from the strikedepressed quarter a year earlier.

title: Rock: Be Bop Becomes More Deluxe
description: BE BOP DELUXE, an English rock quartet, finished its first American tour as a headlining group at the Palladium on Wednesday. It had been almost a year since the band had performed here. and the impression it made then, as an opening act at the same theater, was a positive one. A live album, released during the summer, offered further confirmation that this is an unusually interesting band, if only because of Bill Nelson's spectacular guitarplaying. But in many ways Wednesday's show was even better than one expected it to be.

title: Dynamics Gets Contract
description: The e General Dynamics Corporation has received $65.3 million in Navy contracts for guidance equipment, wings, fins and other components for the Sparrow air combat missile.

title: New Rochelle, TopRated in Poll, Aims to Stay There
description: High School Sports

title: Voter Attitudes on Byrne and Bateman Coincide With Opinions on Income Tax
description: Attitudes on the state income tax issue provide one of the clearest barometers of the apparent closeness of the contest for governor of New Jersey as the campaign enters its final stages.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
A BrooklynBorn Artist Teaches the Blind to Draw
description: Eva Vazquez then 23 years old, and Lucy Torres, 20, each drew the Still Lifea glass and a half of an orange on a closed hook atop a table. They sketched a chair, a conference table. a furnished conference room and progressed to an Irish setter's head skillfully depicted by Miss Vazquez and a thoroughly recognizable portrait by Miss Torres of the then Soviet Premier, Nikolai Bulganin.

title: AlydarAffirmed Rivalry Will Resume at Laurel
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP)Calumet Farm's Alydar and Harbor View Farm's Affirmed will be battling for the nation's 2yearold, championship when the $145,150 Laurel Futurity is held Saturday at Laurel Race Course. It will be the sixth meeting of the year between the juvenile rivals, with Affirmed holding a 3.2 edge.

title: Auctions
description: GEORGE and Edith Kane Baker's pedigree English and French period appointments and art works which are going under Sotheby's hammer today and tomorrow, were maintained by an army of servants at their Locust Valley, L.I., mansion and their two Park Avenue townhouses. The late banker, who was the son of the founder of the First National Bank of New York (now Citibank) and its president until his death in 1937. built their Long Island residence in 1914. That pillared pile, framed by sweeping lawns, tennis courts, bowling alleys, stables and guest houses was Mrs. Baker's home until her death at 93 in April.

title: Shanti Prasad Jain, Indian Industrialist And Philanthropist

Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Team sters, who has been missing since July 1975, in hopes of identifying a skeleton found Monday in thick underbrush near Bethany, Pa. The skeleton was taken to New York and examination and dental charts were completed on it this afternoon.

To her demands for news of their whereabouts, the junta's answer is always the same: They are not under arrest, there is no order for their arrest and none for their detention.

title: Indian Summer
description: Of all our seasons, unofficial as well as official, Indian summer probably is the most indeterminate. It is generally agreed that it consists of a series of mild autumn days with clear skies, calm air, distant haze and cool nights. There agreement ends. How many times it may come in a year, when it comes, whether it will come at all, are constantly argued. So is the matter of where the name originated. The Indians had names for their moons, or lunar months, but none that even resembles Indian summer. The name did not appear in print or manuscript until 1794, by which time the Indian names for local phenomena were largely forgotten.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvania Offers Rialto
description: FOR ITS WEEK'S STAY at the Brooklyn Academy of Music the Pennsylvania Ballet is offering two programs, the second of which was unveiled on Wednesday night. In a sense it was an archetypal Pennsylvanian programit openeo wan a Balanchine classic, Scotch Symphony; continued with a work by the company's artistic director, Benjamin Harkarvy, Time Passed Summer; continued with a classic pas de deux, here the Don Quixote, and ended with a novelty, the New York premiere of Rodney Griffin's Rialto. Apart from the absence of a ballet by Hans van Manen (the distinguished Dutch choreographer with whom the company seemed to have been developing a permanent relationship) the program proved a copybook exercise in the company's customary planning.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The United States Secretary of Agriculture, Bob S. Bergland, announced in Rochester that Federal disaster aid had been approved for 15 more counties in New York State where farmers suffered heavy crop losses because of rain.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that Black Sports magazine was defunct.

title: SADAT PUTS OFF PAYMENT ON BIG DEBTS TO MOSCOW
description: CAIRO, Oct. 27President Anwar elSada??has disclosed that Egypt intends to postpone further payments on its large debts to the Soviet Union for 10 years, without Moscow's consent, starting in January.

title: Carter Pledges Slower Pace
description: WASINGTON Oct. 27  Paesident Carter signaled a change in his Presidency today by deeiaring that the legislative activism of his first year in office would be followed by a period of consolidation.

title: 4 Seized in Times Sq. Cleanup Of Prostitution by U.S
description: Federal authorities, intensifying an attack on illicit sex in the Times Square !area, charged four men yesterday with Federal crimes involving socalled massage parlors, including a club described by a prosecutor as probably the largest house. of prostitutIon.in New York City.

title: A Big Rise in Social Security Tax In High Brackets Voted by House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The House approved today a bill that would require large increases in Social Security taxes in the next few years tor persons earning more than $20,000 a year.

title: A Guide to the CitySuburb Rock and Pop ScEne
description: In the next three days Chicago, Frank Zappe, B. B. King, Muddy Waters, Linda Ronstadt, Larry Coryell, Patti Labelle, Jonathan Richman, Nils Lofgren, Buzz# Linhart, the Ramones, Komi and the Gang, Meco, Harry Chapin, Richie Havens, Bo Diddley, Sea Level, JeanLuc Ponty, Kenny Loggias, Dave Mason, Jack Bruce, Gladys Knight, the Stank) Brown Group and Albert King will all be playing in the metropolitan area.

title: Grunewald
description: A painting thought to be a rare and important lost work by the 16thcentury German artist Matthias Grtlnewald has been disclosed by its owner, the Cleveland Museum of Art, to be a fake.

title: Jury Convicts Ray Of Prison Escape
description: WARTBURG. Tenn., Oct. 27 (AP)Imes Earl Ray, serving a 99year term for the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.. was convicted today of escaping from a Tennessee prison last June 10.

title: Fortunoff's to Add Faces to Campaign
description: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware Inc., known to its friends as Fortunoff's and to readers of advertisements as The Source, starts a new campaign in print this Sunday and returns to TV on Nov. 21. And for the first time it is adding magazines to its media mix.

title: Koch Calls Westway a Disaster And Vows it Will Never Be Built
description: Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, vowed yesterday that the Westway will never be built and disclosed that he had appealed to state and Federal officials to reject permit requests for the construetion of the project as an economic and environmental disaster for the city.

title: SOUTH AFRICA OPENS INQUEST IN BIKO CASE
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 27A South African magistrate today assumed responsibility for establishing whether Stephen Biko, the country's foremost young black leader, died of head injuries inflicted by the notice or, as the Govern ment is now implying, suffered the injuries by accident.

title: Market Place
description: Freddie Laker's recently inaugurated discount fares between London and New York City seem to have ushered in an unusual burst of price competition among airlines.

title: HORIBLOWER, WEEKS AND LOEB RHOADES PLANNING TO MERGE
description: Loeb Rhoades & Company and Hornblower, Weeks, Noyes & Trask Inc., two of Wall Street's largest investment bank, ing and securities firms, announced yesterday their proposed merger in a jointventure partnership.

title: Travel and Troths at 2 Museums
description: Two of life's most moving experiencestransportation and getting married  provide the themes for two major new exhibitions at different Manhattan museums.

title: Screen: Alonso Shines on Film
description: ALICIA, the documentary feature that opened yesterday at the Renoir Cinema, celebrates one of Cuba's greatest living national treasures, Alicia Alonso, the ballerina who first gained fame in this country in the 1940's and who, since the Castro revolution, has served as the principal dancer and artistic director of Ballet Nacional de Cuba.

title: Business Records
Advertising
description: Next month, Lorillard will distribute 50 million coupons worth $1 each on the purchase of a carton of its reformulated lowerintar Kent cigarettes.

title: New Phone Rates And Service Fees
description: At 12:01 A.M. yesterday, telephone rates for customers of the New York Telephone Company went up by a total of $245 million under a temporary increase authorized recently by the New York State Public Service Commission.

title: Futures in Gold And Silver Fall
description: The Government's announcement of improved export figures for September compared with August helped strengthen the dollar in terms of gold and silver yesterday in the world market.

title: Notes on People
description: The Soviet Consulate in Florence granted a twoweek extension of her stay permit to Yelena Sakharov, wife of Andre/ D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist who is not allowed to leave the Soviet Union. Mrs. Sakharov said she needed the &tension so that doctors might have time to complete checkups in connection with tha eye surgery she underwent recently at Sienna, Italy. She suffers from glaucoma in her left eye.

title: People and Business
description: Anatoly F. Dobryntn and his wife, Inna, are on a quiet three day sightseeing tour of the Alaska pipeline as guests of the Atlantic Richfield Company, it was learned yesterday.

title: 39 TEACHERS SENTENCED FOR ACTION DURING STRIKE
description: FREEHOLD, Oct. 27 (AP)A New Jersey Superior Court judge today seritenccd 39 members of the Matawan Regional Education Association to up to 30 days in jail for disobeying a backtowork court order during a bitter 27day teachers strike.

title: Northern Energy Reports on Tender
description: The Northern Energy Resources Company, a subsidiary of the Pacific Power and Light Company, said 895,605 shares of the Nuclear Exploration and Development Company had been tendered in accordance with Northern Energy's preiiiously announced offer to buy Nuclear Exploration shares at $5.20 a share.

title: To Help New York City
description: To the Editor: In his letter to the editor in the Oct. 5 issue of The Times, Benjamin Gessula proposes a moratorium by unions whereby money required to be contributed to the pension plans of their members be suspended, in order to help the city out.

title: Letters
description: Hilton Rramer's Art Summing Up Raphael Sore [Weekend, Oct. 21], setting aside the attitude implicit in the very title, tells us more, it would appear, about Mr. Kramer's observational and reportorial powers than about Mr. Soyer's art. I, too, recently saw the Forum Gallery showing and am now in the midst of reading the Diary of an Artist. Mr. Kramer's remarks make me wonder, therefore, whether he accidentally wandered into some other gallery and read a different book. Certainly what he says about both bears little resemblance to what I saw and read.

title: Yale's Cozza Concerned About VictoryStarved Cornell
description: Ivy League Roundup

title: Art: New British Painter Dazzles
description: THE MOST AUSPICIOUS debut of the se an so farand indeed of many a season this writer can recallis that of William Wilkins, an English painter (born 1938) who is virtually unknown here though in fact he was included in a New Talent exhibition at the Allan Stone Gallery last year. Mr. Wilkins, whose first solo exhibition on this side of the Atlantic is now to be seen at the Robert Schoelkopf Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street, is a painter and draftsman of uncommon nuality. His show is an unalloyed delight.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: IN THE BUDGETTIGHTENING world of local television, original programming with claims of substance becomes increasingly rare. Among the pitifully few examples on current schedules is WNBC's Sight and Sound, a series of essays told entirely through film and the words of the people being covered. There is no formal narrator.

title: RALPH BORSODI, WROTE FLIGHT FROM THE CITY
description: Ralph Borsodi, founder of the School of Living colony in Suffern, N.Y., in the 1930's and author of the book Flight From the City, among many others, died yesterday in Exeter (N.H.) Hospital after a short illness. He was 88 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The daughter of a West Virginia coal miner, Hazel Dickens was writing and singing songs about the plight of miners long before her soundaack for the film Harlan County, U.S.A. boosted her into the limelight. Miss Dickens, who applies her strong voice and mountain drawl to traditional folk ballads and contemporary tunes is well as protest songs, will appear at 8:30 tonight at Montclair State College in Upper Montclair, N.J. For some numbers, she will be joined by a string band; for others, she will sing with her special forte, a cappella. Sharing the bill will be the Nashvillebased, Bluegrass band, Buck White and the Downhome Folks. Admission is $5. The concert, sponsored by the Bluegrass Club of New York, is part of a series at the college's Memorial Auditorium; the next attraction is Ralph Stanley and the Clinch Mountain Boys on Dec. 9. From New York, take the No. 66 DeCamp bus from the Port Authority Bus Terminala halfhour ride. Information:

title: Bricking Up an Antitrust Loophole
description: If an appliance store buys an air conditioner or a refrigerator or anything else and then discovers the price has been illegally fixed by manufacturers, it may sue for treble damages under the antitrust laws. But if it manages to pass the rigged price on to a consumer, the consumer is out of luck; he cannot sue.

title: Rangers, Islanders Experience Ups and Downs of locicey
description: No distinct pattern has emerged in the National Hockey League races this seasonwith the exception of Montreal's strengthand that had caused two predictable reactions on the local scene. The Rangers were happy and the islanders weren't.

title: Drama: Dewhurst Dwarfs Person
description: U SING An Almost Perfect Person as a vehicle for Colleen Dewhurst is like fitting out a kiddycart with a jet engine.

title: Dobler of Cards Thrives On LivingUp to the Image Of Most Offensive Guard
description: The clock was ticking off the final seconds of the Giants 1974 season and the St. Louis Cardinals had a 26.14 lead and the ball. There would be no more plays, and all along the line of scrimmage. Giant players were congratulating Cardinal players.

title: Lockheed and McDonnell Douglas Earnings Rise
description: Higher profits were reported yesterday for the third quarter by two major aerospace producers. The Lockheed Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, more than doubled its earnings while the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's profits were up 21.5 pircent.

title: Senate Unit Frees Airlines of Some C.A.B. Restraints
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The Senate Commerce Committee, by a vote of 11 to 2, today cleared a regulatory reform bill that would for the first time give airlines freedom to change routes and alter prices without approval by the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Minnesota Power Project
description: The Minnesota Power and Light Cornpany has received unanimous approval from the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency to proceed with its $400 million expansion project at the company's Clay Boswell steam electric station near Grand Gapids.

title: Local TV Viewers to Reap a FourGame Harvest on Sunday, Monday Night
description: About Pro Football

title: Money. Supply Drop of $1.1 Billion Spurs Dip in FixedIncome Prices
description: The nation's basic money supply declined $1.1 billion in the week ended Oct. 19. the Federal Reserve reported yesterday, but the drop was apparently not ??? laree as Wall Street had expected.

title: JERSEY WILL REVISE CIVIL SERVICE TESTS
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27The New Jersey Civil Service Commission acknowledged today that its testing system has been inadequate regarding women and minorities and agreed to revise its tests over the next four years to guarantee they are directly related to specific jobs.

title: Books: The Life of A Supreme Kidder
description: BILLY WILDER IN HOLLYWOOD. By Maurice Zolotow. Illustrated. 352 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $10.

title: New York Police to Begin Using OneMan Patrol Cars
description: The New York Police Departmentannounced yesterday that it would start using oneofficer patrol cars in seven precincts on Nov. 14. At the same time, the department will also introduce a new duty schedule that will put more police officers on the street during the highcrime hours of midnight to 2 A. M.

title: SPECIALIZED SCHOOL CRITICIZED BY LEVITT
description: A New York State audit has charged that public funds earmarked for the education of handicapped children have been used by a private school in New York Oity for nursing care for the headmaster's mother, personal trips to Europe and Morocco, and questionable realestate dealings.

title: About Real Estate
description: MINNEWASKA, N.Y.It was In the 1870's that the Smiley family from Providence; RI., built the immense mountain resort houses of Mohonk and Minnewaska in the Shawangunk range in Ulster County, west of New Paltz.

title: CRITICISM OF CARTER AIDE IS PICAYUNE, O'NEILL SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)The Speaker of the House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he did not know Margaret Costanza, a Presidential assistant, but called Republican criticism of her politically motivated and picayune.

title: New Chief at A.M.C. Says It Will Stay in Car Business
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27Gerald C. Meyers says that, contrary to rumors abounding in Detroit, the American Motors Corporation has no plans to getout of the business of manufacturing passenger cars.

title: GENERAL TIRE PRESIDENT TO PAY CONCERN $257,400
description: AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 27The General Tire and Rubber Company announced today that its president, M. G. O'Neil would pay the company $257,400 over three years as reimbursement for illegal corporate contributions he made to domestic political campaigns between 1968 and March 1972.

title: It's a Great Time to Be Irish
description: THIS IS THE Celtic New Year, the time in ancient Ireland for celebrating the end of harvesting and the beginning of another cycle of planning and hoping for a more productive year ahead. This weekend all can join in the celebration of Samhain (pronounced sowin) and hear the music of Irish pipes and drums and voices, at the Irish Arts Center's Celtic New Year Festival tomorrow from noon to 9 P.M. at De Witt Clinton Park, 11th Avenue at 52d Street.

title: Bonn Political Parties Agree on Terrorism Bills
description: BONN, Oct. 27All parties in the West German Parliament agreed today on joint action to fight terrorism, increasing the possibility of quick passage of legislation that would increase penalties for conspiratorial crimes, speed court procedures and redefine the rights of defendants and their lawyers.

title: Vandalism Trial Set
description: A judge ordered two Edison teenl agers to stand trial on charges they caused 5100.000 in damage at the John Marshall School during a threehour vandalism spree last weekend.

title: Sale of Federal Oil and Gas Leases Off Alaska Brings $400.39 Million
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 27The Federal sale of oil and gas leases in Lower Cook Inlet, off the south central coast of Alaska, brought $400.39 million in high bids and fixed bonuses to the Government today.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP)  The Philadelphia School Board, sidestepping skittish bankers and mushrooming debts, drew back today from closing its schools and voted to keep them open two more weeks while it looked for more money.

title: Mel Brewer, Helped Uncover Sports Scandal at U. of Illinois
description: CARBONDALE, III., Oct. 27 (UPI)Melvin C. (Mel) Brewer, whose disclosures led to the University of Illinois athletic department slush fund scandal a decade ago, died of cancer today in Memorial Hospital. He was 59 years old and had been director of service enterprises at Southern Illinois University since March 1968.

title: WEEK'S GASOLINE OUTPUT OFF 400,000 BARRELS A DAY
description: Production of motor gasoline declined slightly to 6.7 million barrels a day for the week ended Oct. 21 from 7.1 million barrels in the preceding week, according to the, latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute.

title: 69% in a Survey Get Their News From Newspapers
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27A group of 800 newspaper editors, wire service executives and journalists were told today that a nationwide survey had shown that most people still get their news from the daily newspapers.

title: Roving Rescue 1 Is Poised To Aid Subway Riders
description: At 3 o'clock the other afternoon, a 1013 signal blurted from the radio of Rescue 1, a van that is part of the New York City subway system's new Emergency Service Prgram and roams the streets above ready to provide help in a hurry. Emergency Service's main to provide fast medical rescue people trapped in most frequent call Is to heartattack victims, but existence it has had widely periences. Hearing the 1013, Leary, the Transit Authority cer at the wheel of Rescue by reflex flipped on the flashing lights and raced streets of downtown Brooklyn. He jerked the van to a sidewalk in front of a subway and he and his partner raced stairs, hands on their pistols. call means a police officer

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters,
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference yesterday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Stocks Continue Rally Second Day As Dow Advances 5.20 to 818.61
description: The stock market's longawaited rally continued yesterday but lost some of its momentum in lateafternoon trading.

title: Worker Productivity Rose 4.9% in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP)The productivity of American workers rose at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter, following a 1.1 percent decline in the second three months of the year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION RISING BY 13% FROM 1976 WEEK.
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP)United States auto production this week will be up 13, percent from the same week last yeah when production was intensified following a monthlong strike at the Ford Motor Company, an industry publication re ported today.

title: Tower Uses Energy Efficiently
description: To hear architect Hugh A. Stubbins Jr. describe it, the new Citicorp tower in midtown Manhattan is a monument to energy consciousnesseven without the solar panels that were supposed to grace its canted top.

title: China Grain Harvest Estimate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (Rtuters)The Central Intelligence Agency said today that China's total grain harvest this year was unlikely to increase significantly above the 285 million metric tons produced in 1976.

title: Terrorism Is Changing Executives
description: Businessmen in the major industrial nations of Western Europe and Latin America have altered their living and working patterns in the wake of extortion, kidnapping and murder by terrorists.

title: Workmen Close Up Vandalized Building In Brooklyn Section
description: Workers were busy yesterday boarding up the windows of 396 South Fourth Street, an apartment house in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. A squad car and four policemen stood on the street outside, and a city maintenance crew opened the pavement to turn off the water that had flooded the building.

title: Defender of German Terrorists
description: BONN, Oct. 28A Left Bank neighborhood in Paris was teeming with policemen on Sept. 30 when a West German lawyer, Klaus Croissant, was arrested at the request of the Bonn Government. The charges: complicity with terrorists and propaganda for a criminal associ. a

title: State's A F 1.C 10. Chief Attacks Koch on Opposition to the W estway
description: The president of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. assailed Representative Edward I. Koch yesterday for his recent rejection of the Westway project and called on union leaders and their members to vote for Mr. Koch's chief mayoral opponent, Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Gray Panthers Fighting Society's Treatment of the Elderly
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Oct. 28Not long after Hope Bagger turned 70, she was summoned for jury duty. When she arrived at the courthouse, she was told that she was too old.

title: 3Goalie System Helps Islanders Get to the Top
description: The threegoalie system, still being experimented with by National Hockey League clubs, remains a controversial matter. The Boston Bruins have three and are in last place in the Adams Division. The Islanders carry three and are tied for first in the Patrick Division.

title: 2d Nominee in Race For Surrogate Held Unfit by Bar Panel
description: Richard E. Coven, the Republican candidate for Manhattan surrogate, has been rated not approved by the judiciary committee of the City Bar Association because, it said, he lacks the requisite qualifications for iudicial office.

title: A. F. L.C. I. O. Favors 2 Sides In Some Races
description: The New Jersey State A.F.L.C.I.O. has included among its legislative endorsements in the Nov. 8 election candidates who in many instances are opposing each other.

title: U.S.E.T. Beats Canada for Nations Cup
description: LANLicArEn. Md., Oct. 28The United Stbtft Equestrian Team won the Nations tl.lipthe most important event of tne program for international teamsat the Washington International horse show tonight after a close contest with the Canadian Equestrian Team_

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to priceearnings real, the number of times the companv's latest 12month earnings can be divided Into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars. The letter u stands for new annual high end dIndicates new low.

title: Dollar Moves Down In Quiet Trading; Gold Closes Mixed
description: The value of the dollar declined moderately against most major world currencies in light foreign exchange trading yesterday, according to The Associated Press. The price of gold was mixed.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Friday, October 28, 1977

title: U.S. Notes Sold to Yield 7.24%, Reflecting Lower Interest Trend
description: In a financing that reflected the moderate move toward lower interest rates this week, the Treasury announced the sale of $3.25 billion of threeyear notes yesterday at an average yield of 7.24 percent. On Oct. 18, the Treasury sold twoyear notes at 7.27 percent.

title: STRICTER CONTROLS ON PENTAGON BUDGET ORDERED BY BROWN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Defense Secretary Harold Brown, seeking to cement civilian control over the Pentagon budget, has issued an order placing tighter controts on spending by the armed forces.

title: Coast Judge to Retire Early
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (UPI)Judge F. Talbot Callister, who placed Patricia Hearst on probation instead of sending her to jail last spring, has been given an early retirement from the Superior Court bench. Court officials announced today Years old.

title: Chicago a Supremely Confident Rock Band
description: Chicago, the rock band that was at Nassau Coliseum on Thursday and Madison Square Garden on Friday, has not changed very much. In about a dozen albums, made in the last 10 years, the group has explored a number of directions without ever straying too far from the glossy AMrock that has been its bread and butter, In fact, it might he said that Chicago was one of the first rock bands to realize that albums could be as slickly produced as hit singles.

title: Dorian Quintet Is in Top Form
description: Programbuilding for concerts is such an iffy matter at best that no surefire method of devising winning sequences of works in performance has ever been discovered. So much depends not only upon the works themselves but upon performers aptitudes, the sizes and layouts of halls, atmospheric conditions and other imponderables

title: THAI MILITARY PLANS WIDER ROLE IN REGIME
description: BANGKOK, Thailand Oct. 28The supreme commander of Thailand's armed forces said today that the military would hold key positions in a new Government 1 to be named shortly.

title: FORMER PROSECUTORS ASSAILED BY NADJARI
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, Republican and independent candidate for Queens District Attorney, yesterday assailed the 51 former prosecutors and law enforcement officials who had criticized him, calling them men who have failed as prosecutors and have left the criminaljustrce system in shambles.

title: Other Games Today
description: Home teams listed first

title: MOST IN A POLL FOUND VERY PROUD OF Sin
description: Although two professional sports teams that have moved from New York to the Meadowlands Sports Complex are reluctant to identify with New Jersey, most residents are apparently proud of their state.

title: Hanayagi Sisters in Intense Japanese Dance
description: It was not all that surprising to see several members of the dance avantgarde in the audience at Suzusetsu Hanayagi and Suzushi Hanayagi's program of Japanese classical dance Thursday night at Japan House.

title: Price Index of Commodities Fell To 201.9 From 203.2 in Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 201.9 from 203.2 last week.

title: RADIO STATION UPHELD ON CENSORING OF ADS
description: A complaint that radio station WSTC, in Stamford, Conn., had violated the First Amendment by censoring the campaign messages of two 1969 mayoral candidates in Stamford was rejected yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Three Danes Bring Poetry to U.S.
description: As languages go, Danish does not have a big, bestselling, Harold Robbinssized capacity, and most writers who use it do something else for a living to underwrite their literary efforts.

title: 8 Striking Westchester Teachers Jailed for Contempt
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28Eight teachers from the Lakeland School District in northern Westchester County, scene of the secondlongest teachers strike in the state's history, were jailed today for diso beying a court order to return to work.

title: Soviet Urges Measures For Diplomats
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 28 (Reuters)The Soviet Union called today for new measures to insure safety of diplomats and trade representatives against increasing dangers posed by international terrorists,

title: Marcia Lewis Back, Gleaming and Funny
description: Marcia Lewis, a round, gleaming, beadyeyed singer and comedienne, who made a dazzling New York cabaret debut last year, is back in town at Barbarann, 349 West 46th Street, where she is appearing this week and next.

title: Panel Considers Ways Women Can Play Power Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Sponsored by the Federation of Organizations for Professional Women entitled Women, Power and Public Policy, representatives of women's organizations met to learn the rules or the game of power politics in such diverse areas %as science, education, employment and health.
