title: Wealthy Businessman Is Kidnapped in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 28A wealthy 61yearold real estate operator and developer was kidnapped in the city center early today, and there were indications later that West German terrorists were his abductors.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Lefler designales OTB listing

title: Deaths
description: ADLERBerthold of Mexico City, Mexico. Died October 27 In Mexico.Beloved husband of Marion(Nee Balin), devoted father of Harry & Sina.Beloved brother of Else Stern of NYC.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Attorney General's office said it had filed another round of civil complaints alleging that land was obtained fraudulently in the Smithville Village section of the Pine Barrens.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Controversy over the Westway flared up again on Thursday when Representative Edward I. Koch, the Democratic mayoral candidate, called it an economic and environmental disaster, vowed it would never be built and said he would try to trade Federal funds for its construction for more aid to mass transit.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In a protest against reductions in unemployment benefits, four young men barricaded themselves for three hours yesterday afternoon inside the manager's cubicle at the State Unemployment Insurance office at 650 Avenue of the Americas, at 20th Street.

title: YOUNG STUDENTS QUIZ 4 MAYORAL NOMINEES
description: The four principal candidates for Mayor, accustomed to being quizzed on television by batteries of reporters, professors and Bushwick housewives went before a different sort of panel yesterday.

title: TV Ratings Battle to Peak in Next 4 Weeks
description: The television networks scramble for ratings, in a season that has developed as the most competitive ever, becomes intensified next week when for a fourweek period ABC, CBS and NBC will unloNstl a barrage of highpowered specials, miniseries and movies.

title: NursingHome Fraud Conviction
description: PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 2S (AP)An ad. ministrator at two Wayne nursing homes has been convicted of fraudulently re= ceiving more than $100,000 in Medicaid payments. The official, Ruth Hinson, 57 years old, of Wayne, was found guilty yesterday on 19 counts of defrauding.the State Division of Medical Assistance:ant Health Services. Miss Hinson, who will be sentenced on Nov. 29, could get thise years in prison and a $1,000 fine on each of the 19 counts.

title: AntiHijacking Group Is Formed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)The Coast Guard announced today the formation of an antihijacking task group to review and coordinate procedures for handling potential hijackings of vessels. The emphasis will be on finding ways to improve Coast Guard response to such incidents. The group is headed by Capt. Robert H. Overton 3d, chief of the service's ocean operations division.

title: Israel Abolishes Money Controls, Pares Subsidies
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 28Israel abolished its tight currency controls and floated its pound today in a dramatic swing toward a free market economy.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up 2.9% in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 2.9 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 483,540 cars, 0.5 percent above last year.

title: In Memoriam
description: MORGANMurray. We have not forootten and think of you often. Rae. Melvin, Roslyn, Bernice and Robert. Rest in peace.

title: New Zealand Calls Millionaire Too Unskilled to Be Immigrant
description: AUCKLAND. New Zealand, Oct. 28 (Reuters)A Belgian millionaire who wanted to settle in New Zealand has been told he must leave the country because he lacks the skills required of an immigrant.

title: About Newyork
description: Lacking the minor detail of the West Side Highway, the automobile, pernicious as the rest of life, continues to come and go by the Manhattan riverfront. On these Indian summer evenings, you can stand on the broken elevated highway, where thatches of weeds and wildflowers now grow in the traffic lanes, and look down on the autos, detoured below to West Street, zipping or grunting by, noisy and noxious.

title: Against Mrs. Lambert and Mr. Nadjari
description: Although the electorate is said to vote more often against than for a candidate, political establishments tend to favor a lofty and positive posture at election time. In two New York City contests this year, however for Manhattan Surrogate and Queens District Attorney usually cautious community leaders are saying some rough things and for good reason.

title: CARTER SAYS HIS AIM IS AN EVENTUAL END TO GAS PRICE CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Carter said today that he favors the eventual deregulation of natural as prices but contended that a House bill, which raises the controlled price, is better than a Senate measure that ends controls.

title: Two on Air Force Bomber Escape In Maine Training Mission Crash
description: ASIII.AND. Me.. Oct. 28 (AP)Both crew member.; aboard an Air Force FB1 1 1 escaped injury today when their plane crushed while on trainin;: inissnm Over northern Maine.

title: AXEL OLSSON
description: Axel Olsson, who spent most of his adult life as a paleontologist in Peru, Ecuador, Colombia and other Latin American countries, died Thursday in his home at Coral Gables, Fla. He was R7 years old.

title: Around the Nation
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (UPI)The national Center for Disease Control reported today the first influenza cases this fall, along with the largest increase in the number of deaths attributed to the disease since last spring.

title: Robert M. Morgenthau to Marry Lucinda Laura Franks, Writer
description: Robert Morris Morgenthau, Manhattan District Attorney, and Lucinda Laura Franks, a former staff reporter for The New York Times, will be married on Nov. 19 in New York.

title: U. N. Sanctions and The South Africans
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 28  Ask a South African whether the Government here will relent in its racial policies as a result of a United Nations arms embargo and he will talk about the laager, the circular encampment of ox wagons be hind which Afrikaner pioneers defended themselves on their great trek from the coast into the hinterland.

title: Byrne and Bateman Urge Voters to Approve 2 Bond Issues on Ballot
description: Two bondissue proposals that call for the sale of $150 million in bonds to firanee hospital facilities and the rehabilitation of harbor and beaches along the New Jersey shore drew support yesterday from both major candidates for Governor.

title: World News Briefs
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 28 (UPI)A large oil slick from a grounded Soviet tanker washed ashore on an island off the Swedish coast today and threatened to pollute the entire Stockholm archipelago. Experts said the lives of many birds were threatened.

title: Anueilings
description: PRICEJudge Saul. A monument to the memory of Judge Saul Price wilt be unveiled on Sunday, October 30th at 1PM at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Aye, Bklyn. Stork C, Line 15.

title: Graduate Schools Holding M.B.A. Forum
description: From Adelphi University to Yale, representatives from 80 graduate schools of business lined up in booths yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel to explain why their school might be just the place to get a degree of Master of Business Administration.

title: REP. DERWINSKI TIED TO ROLE AIDING KOREA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Representative Edward J. Derwinski acknowledged today that he was under Federal investigation for allegedly informing South Korean diplomats that a senior Korean intelligence officer was about to defect. But Mr. Derwinski denied the allegation.

title: Patents
description: WASHIINGTONComputerized head and body scanners, which operate by a form of Xray imaging, are highly regarded in the medical field. But the scanners are very sophisticated diagnostic instruments, and now a device called the Catphan Phantom has bedn provided to evaluate and insure their image quality and calibration.

title: Ship Lines Agree With Union to Talk On Annual Income
description: Members of the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations and the International Longshoremen's Association agreed yesterday to try to settle the issue of guaranteed annual income in individual port negotiations next Monday and Tuesday an industry source reported.

title: Nagasaki Protests Nevada Test
description: NAGASAKI, Japan, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Officials of this city, which along with Hiroshima was hit by an atomic bomb in World War II, sent a telegram today to Mike Mansfield, the United States Ambassador to Japan, protesting the underground detonation Wednesday of a nuclear device in Nevada..

title: National Anthem: Whose Broad Notes and Bright Tune?; Line in Old Volume Credits Londoner as Author of Vocally Trying Melody; A Music Researcher Finds New Evidence in Dispute on the Song's Composer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Did John Stafford Smith, or did he not, compose the music known to Americans as The StarSpangled Banner? After years of controversy over that question. William Lichtenwanger, a retired official of the music section of the Library of Congress is virtually convinced that Mr. Smith did, indeed, compose the vocally trying melody.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT ATLANTA LOS ANGELES (95)

title: Soviet to Expand Military Parade
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28The Soviet Union is preparing to double the size of its military parade on the Nov. 7 anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Western military officers said today.

title: BALTIMORE OFFICIAL GUILTY IN BID RIGGING
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 28  Ottavio F. Grande, Baltimore's deputy public works director, and five demolition contractors were found guilty in Federal District Court today on charges of mail fraud, racketeering, extortion, obstruction of justice and, in one case, income tax evasion.

title: Election Ballot to Be Blank
description: GRANT, Mich., Oct. 28 (UPI)The Nov. 8 election ballot in this western Michigan community will be blank. The mayor and three councilmen will not run for reelection and nobody has filed as a candidate to take their place. The only way the voters in the city of about 800 residents can get a new administration will be to elect officeholders on writein ballots.

title: The Cast
Senate Unit Approves $80 Million For Clinch River Breeder Reactor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)  The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved $80 million for the Clinch River Breeder Reactor project in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Personal Investing
description: When the Colonial Option Income Fund passed the $100 million mark in assets this week, Robert Murphy, sales head of the firm that markets the openend investment company, heaved a sigh of relief.

title: Tony Hulman Dies at 76
description: Tony Ilulman, who developed the Indianapolis 500 into the world's foremost auto race, died Thursday at the age of 7G. Obituary, page 26.

title: James M. Cain, 85, the Author Of Postman Always Rings Twice
description: James M. Cain, the American novelist known for his crime novels, including The Postman Always Rings Twice and Double Indemnity, died Thursday evening at his home in University Park, Md., after a heart attack, he was 85 years old.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Moves Ahead 4.07 to 822.68 As Market Gains for 3d Session
description: The stock market posted its third consecutive advance yesterday despite a mixed bag of economic news.

title: Portuguese Communist Restates His Party's Loyalty to Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (Reuters)The Communist Party newspaper Pravda published an article today by Alvaro Cunhal, the Portuguese Communist leader, in which he reiterated his party's firm loyalty to the Soviet Union and suggested that Eurocommunists were undermining workers faith in the cause of Socialism.

title: ACCOUNTING CHANGES FOR FUEL PRODUCERS PROPOSED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed that oil and gas companies be required to place a dollar value on their reserves.

title: Debt Limit Expiring
description: The New York Knicks and the New Jersey Nets were still at loggerheads yesterday over the $320,000 the Nets owed the Knicks for their entry into the National Basketball Association.

title: Music: Miss de los Angeles With Chamber Group
description: It has been five years since Victoria de los Angeles last sang in New York, and her presence on the program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall last night had aroused considerable speculation as to how she would sound. (She did make an unscheduled appearance last Sunday night in the Richard Tucker Memorial Concert in Carnegie Hall.) The great Spanish soprano had been having vocal difficulties and the question was whether the voice had improved or deteriorated.

title: 2 Patriots Compound Jet Task
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 28Less than a month after the New York Jets confounded the oddsmakers by upsetting the New England Patriots, the clubs meet again on Sundayand once more the Pats are favored by more than two touchdowns.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Oct, 29

title: A Cryptic Ploy in Cryptography
description: There are moments when a scientific development becomes too important to he left to scientists alone. When uranium fission was discovered, Leo Szilard tried unsuccessfully to get Western researchers to stop publishing; it took government action to keep research secret until after Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The same point was reached in molecular biology a few years ago when techniques for manipulating recombinant DNAgene splicingwere developed. This produced the selfquestioning that led to voluntary restraints, Federal guidelines and legislation pending before Congress. Now, some argue, the same critical point has been reached in the branch of applied mathematics that studies cryptography.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1977

title: Where I Stand on New York City Issues
description: Here is my campaign contribution to the people of New York.

title: Johanna Meier Sings Vivaciously in Recital
description: Johanna Meier's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night, a benefit for the Manhattan School of Music Alumni Association, was listed quite properly as a debut, but the tall soprano is no tyro. A versatile and valued leading lady of the New York City Opera since 1969, she appeared last season at the Metropolitan Opera and has begun building an international reputation. Still, fine opera singers often turn out to be disastrous recitalists, so Miss Meier's success in the genre was by no means assured.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY. OCTOBER 28. 1977

title: Pilot Survives Helicopter Crash
description: NEPTUNE, N.J., Oct. 28 (UPI)A helicopter crashed into a clump of trees off the Garden State Parkway here last night, but the pilot escaped injury. The pilot, Roger A. Leigh, 31 years old, of \Vest Trenton, N.J.. told the state police he had become disoriented in heavy fog and lost control of his craft while flying at low alt:tude. The helicopter, owned by the R. J. Longo Construction Company, was extersivelv damaged.

title: Justice on Trial for Perjury Testifies He Forgot Meeting Gambler
description: The defense in the perjury trial of Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court rested yesterday after the justice testified that he had forgotten having met with a convicted gambler about whom he is accused of having lied.

title: Scarsdale's Town Club Opens Its Doors to Women
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 28Last night, when the women's movement knocked on the door of this village's politically powerful allmale Town Club, something new happenedthe door opened.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: A DELICATE BALANCE The public is invited tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M. to view the opening show and to meet many of the artists represented in Flora and Fauna, the first exhibition at the new stainedglass art gallery, Glassmasters Guild, Avenue of the Americas at 19th Street. More than 3? artists are participating in the display celebrating flowers and animals in stainedglass panels, window hangings iwrors, decorative sculptures, terrariums and large threedimensional works.

title: U.N. Assembly Censures Israel For Settlements in Arab Lands
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28The General Assembly adopted a resolution today censuring Israel for the establishment of settlements in occupied Arab territories, calling the actions illegal and an obstruction to Middle East peace efforts.

title: U.S, ECONOMIC INDEX ROSE IN SEPTEMBER THIRD MONTH IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Government indicators today tended to reinforce Administration predictions of a slight upturn in the economy at the end of this year.

title: Bombing Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 28 (UPI)A former Ku Klux Klansman pleaded not guilty today to charges of killing four young black girls in a 1963 bombing at a Baptist Church in Birmingham. Judge Wallace Gibson set a Nov. 14 trial date for Robert Chambliss, 73 years old.

title: Rockefeller Angers Capital Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Richard Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence and no friend of the Rockefellers, drove five blocks out of his way while going to a blacktie dinner party to add his name and that of his wife, Cynthia, to the protest petition.

title: Friendship and Gifts Are Perennial Drawing Cards at April in Paris Ball
description: Friendship and greed. Put them together and they spell April in Paris.

title: Needless BreastRemoval Surgery Is Denied by Hospital in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 28 (UPI)  The director of an Atlanta hospital's breast cancer screening program denied today allegations by a Ralph Nader group that it had conducted needless breastremoval surgery on six women.

title: TED C. HINTON, 73
description: DALLAS, Oct. 28 (UPI)Ted C. Hini ton, the last surviving member of the sixman force that waited alongside a:, dirt road in 1934 to ambush Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow, has died at e. local hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Bonwit Ousts $200,000 Chairman It Hired to Revamp Store Chain
description: John Schumacher, who was brought in from the West Coast less than two years ago at a salary of $200,000 a year to prop up an ailing Bonwit Teller, was summarily discharged yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the Fifth Avenue specialty store chain.

title: Celtics Are Victims
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Oct, 28The New Jersey Nets won their first game in their new home tonight, 116109, from the Boston Celtics, and it was their newest playerBernard Xing of Brooklynwho provided the energy.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28The General Assembly adopted a resolution today censuring Israel for the establishment of settlements in occupied Arab territories, calling the actions illegal and an obstruction to Middle East peace efforts.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

description: While legal maneuvering intensified yesterday in the Belmont Park ringer case, investigators were leaning to the theory that both horses in the suspected switch were still alive.

description: MANILA, Oct. 28In a devastating turnabout in the final session of play, the defending champions were dispossessed of their Bermuda Bowl world team title here this afternoon.

description: Terry Miller, the Oklahoma State running back, does not major in rushing yardage. He is studying business and banking. During the summer he worked as a loan officer in an Oklahoma bank.

title: Puzzles From Uruguay; Is Cinzano Dead, or Is He in Fact Lebon'? If He's Not Lebon, Then Who's in Barn 59?
description: Columbo would have loved it. The diminutive television detective would have solved the Great Horse Racing Mystery within 90 minutes, less time for commercials, and moved on to his next assignment, mangy raincoat and all.

title: Belgrade Says Tito Is Tired After Trips And Will Need Rest
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. Oct. 28Doctors have ordered a fatigued President Tito to rest thoroughly for three weeks, the official Dress agency said tonight.

title: Staff at Hebrew Home for Aged. Accepts Recommended Pay Rise
description: Members of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Health Services Union who are employed at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx have voted to accept the recommendations of a factfinder in their contract dispute.

description: Music

description: Friday. Oct 21. 1972

title: Personal Investing
description: Options funds, the securities industry's newest packaging effort, aim at high returns but make no promises to investors. They are selling very well for the most part. Page 31.

title: YOUTH GETS 25 YEARS IN MURDER AND RAPE
description: A Queens youth who had pleaded guilty to the rape and murder last March of a young Brooklyn woman who was eight months pregnant was sentenced yesterday to the maximum terms, 25 years to life for the murder and, concurrently, eight to 25 years for the rape.

title: Skeleton Found in Pennsylvania Is Not Hoffa's, Examiner Says
description: A skeleton with $4,000 worth of gold teeth found Monday in thick underbrush in northeastern Pennsylvania is not that of James R. Hoffa, missing former teamsters president, the Chief New York City Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: Rep. Wiggins Enters Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2S (AP)Representative Charles E. Wiggins, Republican of California, entered Bethesda Naval Hospital yesterday for treatment of a kidney stone, an aide said today. He said that Mr. Wiggins. 49 years old, had a continuous problem with kidney stones. He said that no surgery was planned.

title: U. S. and. Soviet Aides Smooth Over A Conflict on Misuse of Psychiatry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28A sharp SovietAmerican dispute over allegations that the Russians have used psychiatry to repress political dissidents threatened to disrupt the healthresearch agreement between the two countries this week, but they agreed today to a statement that seemed to smooth the matter over.

title: U.S. Indictment Names L.I. Man
description: Prince Henry Evans Jr., a realestate ma from Baldwin, L.I., has been indicted in Manhattan on charges of fradulently obtaining $225,000 in Government checks. The I54count Federal indictment accused Mr. Evans of conspiracy, forgery and perjury. The United States Attorney's office said the checks were reported missing after they had been mailed to persons and organizations affiliated with the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx.

title: Arpino's Sacred Grove
description: There was a time when people with flowers in their hair got in motion to go to San Francisco, but that time is past, as is the time for ballets about the phenomenon. The Sacred Grove on Mt. Tamalpais is Gerald Arpino's tribute to that Arcadian outpost overlooking San Francisco Bay, and it was restored to the Jaffrey company's current repertory Thursday evening at City Center 55th Street Theater.

title: Article 3  No Title
Abductors Free Canadian Banker After Holding Him for 82 Days
description: SHERBROOKE, Quebec, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Charles Marion, a banker, was released last night, ending the longest kidnapping in Canadian history. He was freed after his abductors reduced their ransom demands from $1 million to $50,000, a figure they said would just cover their expenses.

title: Morrisania Designated by Beame For Urban Homesteading
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday designated a blighted 12squareblock area in the Morrisania section of the Bronx for an innovative effort to rehabilitate an entire neighborhood of apartment buildings through the joint use of Federal funds and tenants sweat.

title: PAY RISES IN 1977 TERMED SMALLER THAN 76 GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Wage increases in major contracts negotiated so far this year were generally smaller than the increases provided under 1976 settlements, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Senate Rejects Effort to Defeat Energy Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Despite opposition from an unusual coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats, the Senate today refused by a 51to30 vote to kill the energy tax bill sought by the President.

title: Notre Dame to Play Navy With Devine's Status Quo
description: Before the season, it was Don Shula who was going to replace Dan Devine as head football coach at Notre Dame. That was before the Irish opened with a victory over Pittsburgh and the Miami Dolphins began winning.

title: Africans in U.N. Press South Africa Curbs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28Western countries sought African backing today for their new proposal for a sixmonth mandatory embargo on arms sales to South Africa.

title: People in Sports
description: The Baltimore Orioles have been notified by the Major League Players Association that three of their players are planning to go through next week's reentry draft. The three are Elliott Maddox, an outfielder, and Ross Grimsley and Dick Drago, pitchers. Their contracts expired at the end of the baseball season and they sent notices of their intentions to the players association.

title: Csonka Rejoins Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Oct. 28Larry Csonka, who missed two days of practice because of illness in his family, returned to the Giants today and Brian Kelley, despite a bad hamstring pull, worked out in preparation for the team's Monday night game against the Cardinals in St. Louis.

title: Pate Among 3 Sharing Lead in Pensacola Golf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 28 (AP)Jerry Pate, a hometown hero, pulled his game together on the back nine, shot a fourunderpar 67 and moved into a threeway tie for the lead today after the second round of the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.

title: Carter Signs Bill to Aid Americans in Mexican Jails
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)President Carter signed today bills that will help Indochinese refugees gain United States citizenship and will help Americans now held prisoner in Mexico and Canada return to the United States.

title: RockaFella
description: ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 2S (AP)After 14 years and almost 100.000 servings, the RockaFella burger is gone.

title: The Martha Movement: Growing Advocate for Homemakers
description: Jinx Melia, aged 40, wife, mother, teacher of management skills to women and founder of the Martha Movement, emerged last weekend from yet another of the rapidly accelerating number of conferences about what she calls the nature of the homemaking bust.

title: A Movie Set Is an EyeCatcher
description: Flames shooting from two wrecked cars slowed pedestrian and vehicular traffic in the area of Columbus Circle yesterday and attracted thousands of spectators. But there were no injuries in the accident.

title: STRICTER CONTROLS ON PENTAGON BUDGET ORDERED BY BROWN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Defense Secretary Harold Brown, seeking to cement civilian control over the Pentagon budget, has issued an order placing tighter controls on spending by the armed forces.

title: QUEBEC PARTY DATA STOLEN BY MOUNTIES
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 28A security unit of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police illegally broke into Parti Quebecois offices in Montreal in 1973 and seized records of the separatist organization, which they copied and returned within hours, the Canadian Government revealed today.

title: A Former Astronaut Sells Moon Souvenir
description: PALM BEACH, Ha. (AP)A former astronaut, Edgar Mitchell, has sold for $4,200 a stamp cover that he took to the moon and hack, an action that drew criticism from a space agency official.

title: TASS SAYS SHCHARANSKY FACES A SEVERE PENALTY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 28 (UPI)The press agency Tass said today that Anatoly Shcharansky, who is awaiting trial on charges of treason, was a betrayer of the motherland who will be punished to the fullest extent of the law.

Starkey of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn came under sharp criticism in legal circles yesterday for speaking freely to a newspaper reporter about the forthcoming trial of David R. Berkowitz, the suspected 44.caliher killerand there were some indications he might be replaced as the trial judge.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Presidents always seem to grow older faster than other men, and Jimmy Carter is no exception.

title: Quebec Officials Not Surprised
description: QUEBEC, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Parti Quebecois officials shrugged off the disclosure today, telling reporters they had long suspected federal agents had been 1 spying on them.

title: Notes on People
description: An old soldier said farewall to southern California, where he had lived for 11 years, at a tribute arranged by the state National Guard General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, his voice and hands trembling, said, We shall miss California's warm hospitality, sunshine and laughter. The 84yearold World War II field commander reviewed six groupings of troops and was given an earshattering 19cannon salute. Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. gave him the state's Medal of Valor. The general, who suffered a stroke in 1975, will live on the post at Fort Bliss, Tex.

title: New England Fuel Distributors Finding It Hard to Do Business
description: Squeezed by unpaid bills, shrinking profit margins and proposed Federal regulations that may control prices, New England fuel oil distributors, who provide 85 percent of the fuel oil to consumers in six New England states, are finding it harder to an business.

title: Citibank Staff Learns at Lunch Seminar How Marriage Counseling Works
description: Nic and Olga's marriage was clearly in jeopardy, so they took their troubles to Dr. Selma G. Miller, a marriage counselor and president of the New York Association of Marriage and Family Counselors.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given over WQXR on the 6 P.M. news broadcast and on other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

description: Price movements were moderate yesterday in the grain markets, but rumors did capture traders interest. The rumors centered on Soviet and Chinese buying.

title: MacNeil Cancels Role in Rigoletto
description: Because of bronchitis, Cornell MacNeil has canceled his performance in the title role of Rigoletto, which will be presented in a new production at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night. His place in the Verdi work will be taken by Sherrill Milnes, who has sung the role before with the Met and many other companies. However, Mr. Milnes will be getting only lastminute rehearsals in the production, staged by John Dexter.

title: Soviet Is Reported Building a New Missile Submarine
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Soviet Union has begun building a nuclear submarine designed to launch 20 to 24 longrange ballistic missiles, according to American intelligence officials.

title: Movement Seeks a Women's Dialogue, but Fails
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Well, it had seemed like a good idea. But it came off better on paper than in execution.

title: 8 Striking Westchester County Teachers Are Jailed for Disobeying a Court Order
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28Eight teachers from the Lakeland School District in northern Westchester County, scene of the secondlongest teachers strike in the state's history, were jailed today for disobeying a court order to return to work.

title: National Science Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)President Carter will nominate James Krumhansl, a physics professor at Cornell, to be assistant director of the National Science Foundation, the White House announced today. Professor Krumhansl, 53 years old, has served on advisory committees for the Atomic Energy Commission the Defense Department and the National Academy of Sciences and was direcZcr of the Laboratory of Atomic and Solid State Physics from 1SSO to 1964: He will replace Edward C. Creutz, who resigned.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Weekender Guide in The Times yesterday, the audio of Te Juro Juana, Que Tengo Ganas, the new production of Rcpertorio Espanol at Gramercy Arts, 138 East 27th Street, was incorrectly identified. He is Emilio CarbaHid.

title: NEW BANK LAW URGED FOR ELECTRONIC AGE
description: A Congressionally appointed commission affirmed its backing yesterday for the evolving electronic funds transfer technology that is expected to change the way the nation goes about paying its bills. It urged changes in banking and consumer protection laws to prepare for the system.

title: DR. THERESE BENEDEI
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP)Dr. Therese Benedek, a psychoanalyst noted for her studies of women, died yesterday at the Illinois Masonic Hospital after a brief illness.

title: Terrorism Is Changing Executives
description: Businessmen in the major industrial nations of Western Europe and Latin America have altered their living and working patterns in the wake of extortion, kidnapnine and murder by terrorists.

title: Stock Tables Explained
description: P/E refers to price.earnIngs ratio, the number of times the company's latest 12month earnings can be divided into the stock's closing price. All prices are In dollars, The letter ustands for new annual high and &indicates new low.

title: Bonwit Ousts $200,000 Chairman It Hired to Revamp Store Chain
description: John Schumacher who was brought in from the West Coast less than two years ago at a salary cf S200.000 a year to prop up an ailing Bonwit Teller, was summarily discharged yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the Fifth Avenue specialty store chain.

title: 10,000 Laid Off in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Oct. 28The East Coast longshoremen's strike that has paralyzed 85 percent of Puerto Rico shipping has resulted in the layoff of 10,000 workers and sent food prices up by about 15 percent.

title: Kennecott Copper Shows a Loss Of $22 Million in the 3d Quarter
description: A downturn in copper prices, high inventories and strikes caused a $22 million loss for the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the third quarter this year, the largest domestic copper producer reported yesterday.

title: Defense Chief Says Britain May Cut Ulster Force
description: The British Defense Minister, Frederick Mulley, believes there is a good chance his Government will be able to reduce its forces in Northern Ireland if civil strife there continues to dwindle and if the Royal Ulster Constabulary is able to take over more security duties from the army. Mr. Mulley, who visited Washington recently to confer with Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense, made the comment in an interview.

title: Panama Final Vote Return Shows Margin of 2 to 1 Favoring Treaties
description: PANAMA, Oct. 28 (UPI)Final returns from Sunday's plebiscite on the Panama Canal treaties showed today that they were approved by a margin of more than 2 to 1 and that 96 percent of Panama's eligible voters went to the polls.

title: Planning Unit Proposed for Hudson River Waterfront
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 28A state commission proposed today a regional waterfront council for planning and implementing development of the New Jersey side of the Hudson River from Bayonne to the George Washington Bridge.

title: 4. Medical Salesman Did Surgery For Doctors, a Legislator Charges
description: A New York State legislator charged yesterday that a salesman of medical equipment had performed surgery in at least three hospitals for doctors who experienced difficulty in completing operations, The hospitals are in Suffolk County

title: FORMER PROSECUTORS ASSAILED BY NADJARI
description: Maurice H. Nadjari, Republican and independent candidate for Queens District Attorney, yesterday assailed the 51 former prosecutors and law enforcement officials who had criticized him, calling them men who have failed as prosecutors and have left the criminaljustrce system in a shambles.

title: Wealthy Businessman Is Kidnapped in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 28A wealthy 61yearold real estate operator and developer was kidnapped in the city center early today, and there were indications later that West German terrorists were his abductors.

title: Carter Says He'll Push Tax Cut To Offset Social Security Levy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Carter said today that the higher Social Security taxes he is proposing could have a slight inflationary impact and would probably have a dampening effect on the economy. He said he would compensate for the increases by lowering income taxes next year.

description: How much more civilized the world would seem if people still sent courtesy notes as they used to in a sweeter age, instead of priding themselves in the modern style on the unapologetic brutishness with which they do their worst to their fellow citizens. title: Aunt Sylvia. Iowa. Apples. Begonias. Family.
description: Conne Winkler's aunt Sylvia Laudon, who lives on eight acres in Fairfield, Iowa, and is going to be 67 years old on Tuesday, now and then dashes off a letter to her niece, in Chicago. She has to write fast, because she has six sisters and writes to them weekly, and 21 nieces and nephews and 24 grandnieces and grandnephews and writes to allor at least mostof them, usually on birthdays and other special occasions. Then, too, she has two daughters and a son, who all live within 35 miles, and seven grandchildren, with whom she talks on the telephone, or her citizen's band radio, and she takes care of her husband Elmer, who is disabled. A year ago June, she retired as secretary of the Iowa State University extension department, in Fairfield, after 22 years. When we spoke with her (it was a gray drizzly late October day in New York City), she was busy cooking the last of the sweet potatoes, to be put up. Anyway, not long ago Connie, who works for a company that makes computers, found a letter from Aunt Sylvia in the mailbox, and Connie wrote us, enclosing it: Getting home late from work and reading this I couldn't help but feel all's right with the world after all. She wanted to share her glow with everybody. We asked Mrs. Laudon if that was all right, and what about the misspellings? She said: I wouldn't be surprised if there wereI think faster than I writethat's the deal. Go right ahead. As is. That's fine.

title: The Man Who Stayed Behind
description: HOW fitting it is that Vicente Aleixandre has won the Nobel Prize! He is one of the greatest poets alive and his work stands for endurance, the roots under the tree of consciousness, the slowly growing trunk. He receives the prize for all the others of his generation in Spain, especially Jorge Guillen and Rafael Alberti. His generation was the astounding one, d concentration of genius unheard of in Spain Rif centuries, amazing in any country. Federico Garcia Lorca was the joyful bird of the group, composing poems on the piano; Rafael Alberti, the rationalist turned sailor, an ecstatic rationalist; Pedre Salinas, the gentle mason of love; Jorge Guillen, a worshipper of light; Luis Cernuda, who sang like a sad Job; and the enthusiastic Vicente Aleixandre, who was and is a kind of river, carrying trees torn up by the roots, everything turbid and wheeling, the things turned up frightening In the sunlight.

title: Memorial Services
description: HIGGSRichard. Memorial services for actor RICHARD HIGGS will be held at St. Clements Church, 423 W. 46 St., on Nov. 1 at 5:30. Mr. Higgs arrived in New York In the late fifties, and had performed lead roles in The Miracle Worker, Star Spangled Girl end I Do, I Do. He was wellknown in television commercials. His latest movie was Taxi Driver. He had also appeared in a running role in The Doctors, and at the time of his death was appearing as moody Andrew in Love of Life. He Is survived by a sister, Mrs. Dean Tanner, in Mitchell, S. Dakota, and a brother, Charles Higgs, In Orangeburg, California.

title: BRIDGE

Fifteen minutes later, after paying the bill happily, she was planning a letter of thanks when the tears started to flow again: She had lost the card.

title: Phoebe Snow Drifts Toward Blandness
description: phoebe Snow seemed to have everything going her way at the beginning of 1976. Her first album, Phoebe Snow, had been in the Top Ten twice and yielded a Top Ten single, Poetry Man. Her reviews had been extraordinarily positive. She had been on the cover of Rolling Stone and she had been given a fulllength profile in The Times Magazine, two almost unprecedented media coups for young performer with only one record to her credit. A legal battle with her first record company, Shelter, was behind her, and she was signed to Columbia, whose president counted himself among her most admiring fans. Her first national tour, opening shows for Jackson Browne, had been a success, and there was every expectation that her next tour would consist of amphitheater and stadium dates secondbilled to a major star.

title: Philadelphia Is Taking Ups and Downs in Stride
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27Philadelphians proper and in some cases not so proper are taking in stride the ups and downs of autumn life in the nation's fourth largest city. At different, sometimes overlapping, social strata, Philadelphians and their suburban neighbors are doing what they can about some things and talking about the rest.

title: Thailand Has Trouble Adjusting to New Order
description: BANGKOK, Thaila ndIn the two and a half years since new governments came to power in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, Thailand, more than any other nonCommunist country in Southeast Asia, has been having difficulty coming to terms with the new balance of power. A policy of rapprochement initiated by the previous, elected Thai government has been stalled since the country, more accustomed to authoritarianism than democracy, reverted to military rule after a coup d'etat a year ago. This month, the military reaffirmed its authority, dismissing a civilian prime minister who the generals claimed had aspired to govern in his own right.

title: Democracy Isn't Easy
description: NEW DELHILast year, when India was in the grip of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's stern and authoritarian emergency rule, she used to explain that she had suspended some aspects of this country's democracy for the sake of its progress and development. The emergency has helped us to streamline the economy and to deal with the problems of the poor, Mrs. Gandhi said in those days. We needed discinline, and now we have it. But the voters were not buying that argument and last. March, in tne greatest exercise of the democratic franchise in human history they turned her out of office, installing Prime Minister Mor,ardl R. Desai, who had been a political prisoner for almost the entire emergency period. Mr. Desai has pursued a course of strict neutrality in foreign affairshe returned last week from a visit to Moscow and next month he will play host to President Carterbut seven months later, how is India's highlyprized democracy doing in the attack on India's ageold internal troubles? So far, the results have been mixed.

description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 29 (UPI)  The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it had forbidden its employees and contractors to use humans in testing substance suspected of causing cancer or posing other risks.

Marcos to hold a new election for his position touched off confused debate in his Legislative Advisory Council today as some of his legal experts suggested that Mr. Marcos had already abolished the office and become PresidentPrime Minister indefiniteIv.

He said the program would cost about $1.75 billion in the current fiscal year and roughly $3.5 billion in the next.

Pressing at the doors of this shaky stable is a phalanx of Typhoid Marys threatening to annihilate the lot with the germ of women's lib.

However else they may spend their timeworking outside the home from 9 to 5 or raising a bunch of childrenthey feel guilty if they don't keep their homes sparkling clean themselves. This anxiety is probably the result of years of television commercials featuring women smiling proudly at gleaming kitchen floors.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THAT favorite gambit of flirtatious dinner partners and professional paneliststhe aphorismseems to spring most readily from the pens of conservative, misanthropic men. What swaggering pessimism in the pithy sweep of these assertions! We could be cowards, if we had courage enough (Thomas Fuller). Never to talk of oneself is a form of hypocrisy (Nietzsche). Men become old, but they never become good (Oscar Wilde). Genius is the gift for clever theft (Anonymous). The lapidary art of aphorism, perfected by such elitists as Montaigne, Halifax, La Rochefoucauld and Nietzsche, strives to deny us the most fundamental gifts and virtues and to unmask what we would most prefer to conceal.

title: Dengue Fever Kills 60 in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29 (AP)Dengue fever, a mosquitoborne virus, has afflicted 10,000 people and caused 60 deaths in a farming area 50 miles northeast of Cairo, an Egyptian official said today. The disease is completely under control, said Dr. Imam Zaglool, director of the National Serum and Vaccine Institute.

title: They Have Ruled for 41 Years. but Now the Regime Is Under Concentrated Political Attack
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua After 41 years of absolute rule, the Somoza family is losing its grip on Nicaragua. Leftist guerrillas have won the backing of nonMarxist groups and have started an open struggle to topple the regime. A power struggle has erupted within the ruling elite. President Anastasio Somoza Debaye is recoering from a recent heart attack and the Somozas are no longer assured of the automatic backing in Washing

title: Wilmington School Board Asks Early Desegregation
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Oct, 29 (AP)An attorney for the Wilmington Board of Education has asked Federal District Judge Murray M. Schwartz to start the desegregation of schools in the Wilmingtort area as soon as possible.

title: Help for Childless Couples
description: THE SIGHT of a pregnant woman triggers a fit of weeping. A party full of wellmeaning but inquisitive relatives becomes a trial. The increasing popularity and social acceptability of childless marriage is no consolation to the unhappy couple who want children but face an infertility problem. Feelings of guilt, confusion and a genuine lack of knowledge of available medical procedures often compound the problem.

description: LTHOUGH the Town of Hempstead, with a population of more than 800,000, is bigger than such major league outposts as Pittsburgh, San Francisco, St. Louis and Cincinnati, it doesn't have its own bigleague ball club.

title: BENJAMIN KESSLER
description: Benjamin Kessler, a Brooklyn realestate lawyer for more than 50 years, died Friday at Albert Einstein Hospital after a short illness. He was 83 years old and lived at 2106 Wallace Avenue in the Bronx. A graduate of Brooklyn Law School, Mr. Kessler leaves his wife, the former Sarah Shaler, and two sons, Philip of Westport, Conn,, and Paul of Collingswood, N.J.

Miss Salie found herself unable to accept her prizea twoweek seaside vacationbecause the hotel did not admit blacks.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The UNITED STATES TRADE DEFICIT in September, at a seasonally adjusted $1.72 billion, was the lowest since May's $1.22 billion, the Commerce Department reported, and was more than $1 billion below August's $2.67 billion deficit. Exports were a record $10.92 billion, while imports totaled $12.62 billion.... New orders for durable goods increased 0.6 percent in September, mainly because of growing demand for airplanes and ships.

These were questions frequently asked me by alumni during a recent alumni trip aboard the tall ship Barba Negra. With a German, Norwegian and American crew, Wesleyan alumni from New York, Boston, Rhode Island and Connecticut set sail to get a better look at the last few days of the America's Cup Races off Newport, R.I.

description: Philadelphia, Boardwalk and Camden are all status shows on the early December agenda. But this year there are a few changes. Camden used to follow Philadelphia, but this year its 45th edition moves Dec. 3 to Convention

title: Headliners
description: The great debate over who composed The Star Spangled Banner t.eemf: close to settlement with new evidence pointing to John Stafford Smith, a London composer and musician who died in 1836. Though every school child knows that Francis Scott Key wrote the lyrics, it is a more obscure fact that Mr. Key borrowed the tune from The Anacreontic Song, named after a British gentleman's club. Mr. Smith often performed for that club, and a retired librarian from the Library of Congress, William Litchtenwanger, has discovered a reference to Mr. Smith's authorship of the tune in the diaries  of another of the club's favorite musicians, Richard John Samuel Stevens. Though many music scho:ars have long believed that Mr. Smith was the anthem's composer, no firm evidence has been until

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: ONE suspects that all around us are architectural and historical finds just waiting to be found. 1 listen to my friends tell me about the real Chippendale they found in a Flemington flea market and about the bundle of Civil War letters in a Trenton attic, some faded scrimshaw in Perth Amboy and a 200yearold house in Sussex, and I wonder where our window is.

title: Rutherford, Indian Hills Notch No. 6
description: Jordan Jackson scrambled 14 and 61 yards for touchdowns as undefeated Rutherford made Emerson Borough its sixth victim, 2814. Rutherford struck quickly when Gary Nichols raced 57 yards to the Emerson Borough 4 with the opening. kickoff. Two plays later, Frank Manning sneaked 1 yard for the touchdown. Manning also tossed a 31yard touchdown pass to Nichols.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: EVERYONEwell, almost everyonehas heard about the SmootHawley Tariff Act, the TaftHartley Labor Act and the McCarranWalter Immigration Act. But how about that new one with two New Jersey sponsors, the ThompsonWilliams Labor Reform Act? Or is it the WilliamsThompson Act?

description: THEATER

title: A Boost to Business and Then What?
description: Beset by a lack of business confidence, President Carter last week postponed tax reform. Beyond that, he suggested that when it comes, it will include a hefty tax cut, to spur business outlays for investment. The President did what he had to do. Energy and Social Security legislation are still tied up in Congress. Until they are resolved, detailed tax legislation already in Congress has not only upset businessmen, it has upset Congress. Eliminating one ballLax reformfrom the legislative juggling act was not only shrewd politics but prudent economics.

title: The Successful Failure
description: WILLIAM SLOANE COFFIN was young, at least for that kind of job, when he was appointed University Chaplain at Yale at age 33. He remained as Yale's chaplain for 17 years. To undergraduates, he was one of the most powerful presences, even forces, on the campuscharismatic, mobilizing, with a style of speaking, a combination of the upperclass and the streetwise, that was engaging and demanding but also lent itself to a rather humorous mimicry.

title: Some Aerosol Cans Must Display Warnings Beginning Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Starting Monday, deodorants, hair sprays and other products in aerosol cans propelled by fluorocarbons must carry a warning label.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: SINCE the appearance in 1961 of her irst novel, Bonjour Tristesse, Francoise Sagan has (teen praised for the economy of her style. In Silken Eyes,  ter first collection of short stories, she econo. mites still further, perhaps to the point of parsimony. The French public, which is also noted for its love of economy, responded to Silken Eyes by putting it at the top of their best seller list. The critic of L'Express said of the book that Miss Sagan's art of almost nothing finds its ideal measure there. A few gestures, an instant or two, a smile, a couple of words, anguish, and that's that, with ease and precision.

title: Pay Tribute $18 Winner In Jersey
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., Oct. 29Elmendorf's Pay Tribute, who arrived froM California at 2 A.M. today, arrived first at the finish line tonight and captured the $176,800 Meadowlands C9p;the richest race at this thoroughbred meeting.

title: 2 Forced to End Himalayan Climb
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Two French mountaineers were flown here today by helicopter after frostbite forced them to give up their attempt on the 26,760foot Himalayan peak of Manaslu. Pierre Beghin, 26 years old, and Thierry Leroy, 27, had climbed to 24,935 feet in waistdeep snow last Sunday before having to come down. Both had frostbitten toes.

title: Aldrich's Score Decisive As Watchung Hills Wins
description: Watchung Hills upset previously undefeated Somerville, 8.0, on Tater Aldrich's 3yard touchdown plunge and a 2point conversion run in the second period. Aldrich, a sophomore, capped a nineplay, 49yard drive that was keyed by a 15yard pass from Scott Laughinghouse to Troy Dilzell and a 15yard run by Rick Titus.

title: PAROLES AWAIT AMERICANS LEAVING MEXICO PRISONS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)About 50 of the 240 Americans who are to be transferred from Mexican prisons in December will be given paroles when they reach the United States, a Justice Denartment official said today.

title: New Ideas Raise Food Yield in Poor Indian State
description: MANDASOR, IndiaLandowners in Madhya Pradesh in central India who have lagged behind their compatriots in such agriculturally progressive states as Puntab and Tamil Nadu are adopting new methods based on the use of hybrid seeds, fertilizers and lift irrigation with impressive results. As in other places, the initiative has come from affluent farmers.

title: Searching for a Voice
description: The drama of national rebirth, its struggle for survival, the human reality behind collective societythese are certainly the subjects of Israeli fiction and poetry most familiar and frequently published in this country. The portrait of Israel in this literature has invariably been an optimistic, selfassured one while its values have been equally reassuring, edifying and seemingly impervious to the hesitations of modernist literature, its desoakings and idiosyncracies.

title: Thompson Takes Lead by 2 Strokes
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 29 (AP)Leonard Thompson broke out of threeway tie with a solid, sixunderpar 65, established a twostroke lead today and confidently looked ahead to a victory in the $125,000 Pensacola open golf tournament.

title: Indira Gandhi's Car Stoned in South India
description: MADRAS, India. Oct. 29 (Reuters)Former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. escaped unhurt when stones and sandals were thrown at her open car by demonstrators in Madurai today, the news agency Samachar reported.

description: Harlem Drug Fighters, the controversial Harlem drug clinic, is the subject of four separate investigations by Federal, state and municipal officials, an executive of Harlem Hospital, which houses the clinic, reported last night.

This is a collection of incidental pieces of journalism from magazines as diverse as Penthouse, Vogue and Technology Review, mixed in with some of Clarke's recent lectures and a record of his testimony before the House of Representatives, Committee on Space Science and Applications.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Of all the crimes committed during the Vietnam War by various arms of the United States Government, literary piracy is surely the most surprising and the Department of Commerce the least probable offender. Yet it is George Condominas's solemn charge that his highly detailed monograph on the village of Sar Luk, published legally &n French in 1957, was brought out in an unofficial edition (complete except for indices) produced covertly by the Commerce Department for the use of Green Berets in winning the minds and hearts of the shamanistic highland people whom Mr. Condominas o minutely observed.

Oct. 29The United States and the Soviet Union are still some distance away from achieving a comprehensive ban on all nuclear testing, despite recent suggestions by highranking officials in Washington and Moscow that new accord might be achieved in the near future, Administration officials said today.

description: WARSAW, Oct. 29 (Reuters)The Roman Catholic primate of Poland, Stefan Crrdinal Wyszynski. and the Communist Party leader, Edward Gierek, met official1 y for the first time here today, the official news agency PAP reported.

title: DINING OUT
description: RIDGEFIELD RIDGEFIELD, a country town that has more than its share of good inland eating places, also boasts of a very agreeable seafood restaurant, the King Neptune. Every town should have a restaurant like it: simple, relatively inexpensive, familystyle, serving fresh fish and seafood almost exclusively (chicken is on the menu just in case). If you go there with your children, it could easily become a Sunday tradition.

title: A Late Atlanta Goal Brings 43 Victory
description: ATLANTA. Oct. 29Nearly everyone on the Rangers made a costly mistake or two at the Omni tonight, and the result a 43 loss to the Atlanta Flames, the Rangers nemesis of last season.

title: GARDENING
description: AT THIS time of year gardeners, like anyone else, may be tempted to turn their thoughts to mugs of warm mulled cider by the fireplace and football on television rather than to raking leaves and putting the garden to bed for winter. An extra bit of incentive may be required to raise one's enthusiasm sufficiently to get these tasks done, and this incentive might come from a visit to the fall flower show under way at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay.

title: Report Says Skateboard Injuries In 1977 Will Double 1976 Figure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)The number of skateboard injuries in the United States this year is expected V5 be twice that reported in 1976, and 40 percent of the accidents will require emergency room treatment, according to a Federal report.

title: Carter to Seek an Accord With Soviet on Arms Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Critical of the United States role as the world's leading seller of arms, President Carter says he will make proposals to the Soviet Union before long to limit sales of conventional weapons.

title: SENATE PANEL OPENS TRUCK RATE HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Senate, acting on the same day that it cleared for floor action legislation to bring price competition to the airline industry, has opened hearings on the cost of excessive regulation in trucking.

title: HighSpeed Train in Soviet Will Start Service This Week
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Soviet Union's new experimental highspeed train, the ER200, will be put into regular passenger service on the MoscowLeningrad run next week, according to the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda.

title: Little Bulbs Will Cheer Wintry Days
description: The miniature bulbs are ideal to pot up for forcing in the drab days of winter. They are attractive in unusual containers, never need staking and are colorful. Crocus are among the earliest flowering bulbs. Pots of them can be brought in at Christmastime for a welcome bit of blossoms. The little species crocus will flower earlier and with more flowers per bulb.

title: Joyce Sharon Strauss Wed
description: Joyce Sharon Strauss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Strauss of Ardsley, N. Y., was married last Saturday to Robert Paul Jonap, son of Mrs. Joseph Titunik of Great Neck, L. I., and the late Robert Jonap. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony in the Elmwood Country Club in White Plains.

description: LINCOLN CITY, Ore., Oct. 29 (UPI)A storm lashed the coast of Oregon and northern California yesterday, sweeping a 50yearold motel operator to her death and flooding resorts and highways. At least one other person was missing as waves up to 35 feet high roared in from the Pacific.

The adult who can steer his mind away from the obvious analogy is more pureminded than I. However, the object of this cat's obsession is incidental to Bernard Waber's sly satire on the accouterments of middleclass anxiety: a succession of

title: To Run Westchester and Nassau
description: County Executive is a title with little history or tradition, but it seeks to describe a post resembling somewhat that of mayorof a county, rather than a city, government. Until recent times, county governments did little more than keep records, collect real property taxes, and produce sheriffs to enforce the law. As government expanded its social welfare, health and sanitation programs, 18 New York State counties established the office of County Executive to handle such matters on behalf of their towns, villages and cities. Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk Counties are three of these. The terms of the Westchester and Nassau Executives expire this year and the incumbents are seeking to succeed themselves with widely differing prospects.

description: I was only 20 when I started liying in Berlin in the late 1920's; 1 left in 1932. Returning again, to see Trends of the 20's, the 15th European Art Exhibition of the Berlin Festival that took place in West Berlin this fall, I found myself comparing my impressions of the city today with memories of how it was nearly half a century ago. The Berlin I knew is that described by Christopher Isherwood in his Berlin stories. (Incidentally, there is not a single meal, or club, in the movie Cabaret, that Christopher and I could have afforded.) What we mostly knew was the Berlin of poverty, unemployment, political demonstrations and street fighting between forces of the extreme left and the extreme right. We did fre

They kidnapped a Dutch millionaire, Maurits Caransa, who had survived Nazi internment In World War II, from an Amsterdam street and demanded as ransom the release of an imprisoned German radical. For good measure, they also insisted on the abdication of Queen Juliana.

title: South Africa, A Loner
description: Where South Africa is concerned, protest is easy, effective protest is not. This seemed to be the Carter Administration's thinking last week when announced its response to South Africa's latest suppression of dissent. The United States, President Carter said, will support United Nations sanctions against the sale of weapons to South Africa but not the total trade embargo demanded by black African nations.

title: What's Doing in BUENOS AIRES
description: THE CITYBuenos Aires (known as B.A. for short) is the Big Apple South. More populous than Paris, with nine million people living in a metropolitan area larger than Chicago, it is one of the world's 10 great cities. Everything creativeand destructiveof which the Argentine people have been capable in the brief, turbulent life of the nation is concentrated here. As an urban achievement, the Argentine capital is impressive. There was no native Indian civilization to build on; even building materials were lacking, except for the mud to make adobe bricks. There were no natural hardwood trees or stone quarries. The ships that brought the European settlers to Argentina in the 19th century were ballasted with the paving stones that now cover the city's endless streets. But the agricultural and livestock wealth, once tapped, was so great that now the elegant city center is studded with family mansions on the scale of the Frick Museum on Fifth Avenue in New York, and spacious boulevards where apartments sell for $200,000. Substantial is the word for B.A., but there's taste and imagination in its design and the use of space, along with a Latin vitality that breaks through the monotony of the faceless, urban crowd,

description: THIS closely textured book assumes a reader already familiar with Frost's major poems, also at home in the main traditions of English and American literature, and prepared to pay strict attention to a serious critic. That may be assuming a lot. But those who do undertake the critical journey with Richard Poiriera journey swift, high, not always smoothwill learn how a great poet gets from poem to poem, and a poem from line to line, as an enactment of mind. Or in Frost's own, cannier words: What a feat it was to turn that way, and what a feat it was to remember that, to be reminded of this by that.

title: THE PRICE OF BLOWING THE WHISTLE
description: In the spring of 1974, Dr. Stanley Mazaleski, a Government scientist, began complaining about the sluggish pace at which his agency had set about designing safety standards for industrial workers exposed to carcinogenic chemicals. The following winter, Mazaleski's criticisms were leaked to the newspapers. Within a few months he was fired. And last May, after a twoyear fight for reinstatement, he won a court decision ordering the Public Health Service to hold a new hearing. It was a modest victory, just enough to allow his attorney to try to open negotiations with the agency. After a while, the lawyer called with the report that he had been in touch with the agency's general counsel to no avail. They said you're guilty, he told Mazaleski. Guilty of what? Mazaleski asked. I don't knowthey said guilty.

title: About All I Do Is Cut My Hair Differently
description: James Whitmore stands at the door, flashing a somehow familiar welcoming grin, and you realize with a start that his is one of Those Faces, made larger than life by a parade of films stretching back to Battleground in 1949. True, it's a face narked by the years, weathered now and grizzled. The always prominent eyebrows are bushy gray promontories shielding cool blue eyes. The hair, too, is graying, though the guardsman's mustache shows traces of faded reddishblond. Cardiganand slipperclad, puffing on a pipe, he has become the father of all those regularguy characters he once played so wellthe wisecracking G.I., the cops, the country boys, the honest American types that were the salt of the American earth.

title: THE GANDHI OF SICILY CONTINUING CRUSADE

But Danilo Dolci still weighs 275 pounds and is still crusading for a country that was neglected, plundered or conquered for 2.500 years before he arrived.

title: An Old Technique
description: Terrorism has been with us for some time, at the outer fringes of political discourse, and, while its vogue ebbs and flows, it shows no sign of disappearing. In his thoughtful, detailed essay, Walter Laqueur recalls that terrorists stalked and claimed their victims in ancient timesin first century Palestine the sicarii hid their swords under their coats and struck in broad daylightand that terrorist doctrine as we know A today was fully fleshed out in the 1800's. Conveniently, it serves terrorists of both the left and the right. Long live vengeance! cried Johann Most, a Germanborn publicist who drifted from socialism to dynamite in the late 19th century'. Let us all work for the day when attacks will multiply against all those who bear responsibility for the servitude, exploitation and misery of the people. Most pioneered the invention of the letter bomb and fantasized dropping dynamite on czars and emperors from dirieibles.

title: Governor's Disguise a Fright
description: DENVER, Oct. 30 (UPI)Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado donned makeup and a cloak to appear at a Halloween party at the Governor's Mansion yesterday as Dracula, but had to calm the fears of some of the youngsters. One of the children began screaming when he saw the Governor in his makeup. Mr. Lamm quickly soothed the youngster and his playmates. It's just me, he said. It's just the Governor. He added, I'm not as scary as I usually am. I usually dress up as a politician.

title: Boy Drowns in Fishing Accident
description: CLAYTON, N.Y., Oct. 30 (UPI)Troy Brockman, a 13yearold Webster boy, drowned yesterday while fishing with a friend at nearby Goose Bay, officials said. His companion, James Bongard, 13, also. of Webster, was taken to Mercy Hospital in Watertown with lacerations of the arms and legs. Officials said young Bongard had started the motor of the aluminum boat the two were using while it was still in gear. The craft jolted, and he was thrown from it. The police said they were uncertain how the Brockman boy had died.

We discussed a very wide range of international topics, including the United States, China and other countries, Mr. Andersen said after the ??ession, though he gave no details on the views President Castro had expressed.

title: Article 4  No Title
Red Reeder's Heisman Trophy Day
description: Doc Blanchard, Glenn Davis and Pete Dawkins were back at West Point, and autumn broke out her most exuberant banners to welcome them. There was a parade honoring Army's three winners of the Reisman Trophy, a special ceremony at midfield in Michie Stadium between halves of the football game with overmatched Holy Cross, a recetion after Army's 487 romp and, finally cocktail and a buffet in the Officers' Club. Blanchard, Davis and Dawkins  the names revive mermories of other autum Saturdays above the Hudson, unforgettable days of excitement. Blanchard was the irresistible fullback and Davis the quicksilver halfback on the teams that won 25 games in a row during and immediately after World War II, convincing some that they could have held their own with the Chicago Bears. Blanchard is a retired Air Force colonel now, a member of the landed gentry in Burnet, Tex. Davis runs football gamer, track meets, auto races and other promotions for The Los Angeles Times. Dawkins, tall and trim with the eagles of an infantry colonel on his shoulders and combat ribbons like fruit salad on his breast, is the commander of Fort Ord in California. In his time as a Cadet, a dozen years after the others, lie did everything on the football field, on the hockey rink and in the classroom  and sang in the glee club.
